Deities with control over the nature domain found the Limael’s destruction of the forests offensive, and worse still, hypocritical, as I was done it order to supposedly celebrate them. The gods had been keeping an eye on the Limael’s for some time, and seeing Nai simply walk off the way that she did entertained them greatly. Nai’s ‘luck’ was rather a direct result of their influence. Subtle, but just enough to keep her safe and healthy. Berries would come into fruit well before their time, edible tubers would be surprisingly close to the surface, fires for warmth would take just a little bit less to start, and last just a bit longer. Predatory animals would take no notice of the young girl and her crow, and shelter could always be found. Taking care of Nai as she walked became something of a game for the gods, and even the more sinister deities would take part. The Limael’s, distraught over their daughter’s disappearance, used every means possible to find her, but they never could. Storms would hit any boats searching for her. Searching parties by foot would find themselves hunted by wolves, and through a presence unknown to Nai, any magical attempts to find her were blocked. They searched for years before calling off their efforts, deeming it fruitless, but Nai was always blissfully unaware. She kept walking, with a skip in her step, driftwood in her hands, Korko by her side, and gods at her back. And so, she kept travelling. Walking along the coast, deciding to see more of the world and taking a detour, before deciding to head back. She had no means of knowing where she was, but she had her own unique way of having a general idea of where she was. Large rock formations that had no other significance served as landmarks, remembered fondly because they looked like her favourite animals, though the resemblance was often very obscure. She zigzagged across the continent, occasionally backtracking, wishing to spend time at a particularly nice creek gain, or turning around to climb a specific tree because she liked the view and wanted to see it again. And throughout all this, the gods would continue to check up on her occasionally, giving her a little helping hand if she ever needed it. After many, many years of wandering, Nai happens across a vast forest. It’s vivid green, and gorgeous, and lusher than any she’s ever seen before, so, of course, she enters. Unknown to her, however, she’s being watched, and not just by the gods. An elderly, druid man, keeps a careful eye on her, not wanting to scare her, but ready if she ever poses a threat to this forest that he’s become a part of. She wanders among the trees, taking in the sights, but never noticing the old druid. However, on the night of the full moon, she does encounter something peculiar. A disc, floating, large enough for her to step into if she wished. It looks like a mirror, reflected in it, an incredible forest, not unlike the one she’s in right now, but vastly superior. Larger, more beautiful, with plant life growing in ways she’s never seen. She steps into this mirror-like portal, and the druid man, who’s been keeping a careful watch moves to stop her, calling out a second too late. He opens his mouth to yell out to her, but she steps through, and suddenly, she is gone from this plane.Nai finds herself in a new, extraordinary world, inhabited by creatures and plants she’d never seen before, not on land, nor from the ocean. The trees here are taller than any she had ever seen, and vines wrap themselves around the branches with intricate detail. Fungus grows on the floor of the forest, the fruiting bodies easily ten times bigger than any Nai had ever encountered, softly glowing a variety of hues, and the moss under her feet is softer than any sand. She wanders for a while, progress slow as she pauses to take in all the sites, choosing to take one item from this place. A small skull, the size of her fist, which she adds to her staff. Korko also finds some things of interest, adding a number of odd flowers to Nai’s hair, which appear to settle themselves in, wrapping roots around a small section of hair and happily adjusting to this new, mobile place of residence. It takes a number of days before she finds anyone sentient, and when she does, they’re shocked to see her. A pair of Satyr, understanding that she must be lost, ask where she came in from, and, knowing the lay of this land, agree to help her get home. She learns that that particular portal won’t open for a month, so they show here around in the meantime. While here, she never learns where she is, but she knows it’s beautiful, and extraordinary, and unlike anything she’s seen thus far, so she focuses on soaking up every gorgeous detail of the landscape, from the trees, to winding rivers not bound to any riverbed, to mountains that go high into the clouds.The month passes in a flash, and before she knows it, she’s guided back to the portal. The satyr wave goodbye, and she passes back through, reappearing in the same location she went through, the same lush forest, which now seems somewhat drab in comparison to the wonders that she’d just seen. But she and Korko aren’t alone in the forest. Standing in front of her is the druid that had been watching her a month prior. He looks as shocked to see her and she is to see him, and finally, he speaks first, asking how she survived and how long she thinks she was gone for. Taken aback by these questions at first, she answers honestly. She was helped by some satyrs, and she was gone for a month exactly. To her surprise, the druid shakes his head, and invites her to come with him. He takes her to his home. A humble shelter, consisting of just a roof and a makeshift bed and fire pit. He introduced himself as Oberon, and he explains that the place she had just been to was known as the FeyWild. When he first came to this forest, he went through the same portal. For him though, he was trapped in there for five years. It took him that long to figure out the timing of that portal, but when he came back through, everything was the same. His memories of the place are fuzzy, but he vividly recalls the state of things before he went through the portal, and he quickly figured out that he had only been gone for 5 minutes. Initially, he thought that time in the FeyWild was just much slowly than this plane, but Nai has proved that this is not the case. He’s been keeping track of time for her, and Nai is surprised to her that a month passed in the Feywild, but here, in this plane, she had been gone for 15 years. Oberon is surprised by Nai’s relative lack of reaction, and he eventually lowers his voice, asking if she’s a druid. Nai admits she doesn’t know what that is, and Oberon chuckles, saying that’s not a surprise. He asks Nai to stay with him a while, he’s had no company for a long time, and he’d appreciate it very much, as he’s getting older. Nai doesn’t quite understand this, but she agrees. Oberon is an eccentric old man, but Nai grows to enjoy his company greatly, even if the conversations don’t make sense and are very one sided.  Weeks pass before he says he’s willing to teach her Druid magic. Nai admits she doesn’t know what that means, and he happily demonstrates. Nai watched as he takes a breath, closing his eyes, and then, smooth as silk, his form changes into that of a bear, a little shaggier than average, and pure white. He changes back and immediately Nai agrees. She’s never seen magic like this, and she’s keen to learn, so, they begin. First, he teaches her Druidic. Teaches her the script, the speech, and how to sense druidic messages in an area, and she takes to it faster than even Elvish. Then, she teaches her to manipulate nature. He explains the Druids don’t ‘control’ nature, they’re an extension of its will, it’s protectors. They’re one with the natural world, and it is one with them. Nai takes to these lessons like a duck to water, and he teaches her the basics of Wild Shape. He teaches her basic survival skills, and gifts her one of his furs, enchanted to keep her warm and dry, no matter what the weather. He always warns her of the dangers of being a Druidic. Telling her with spite in his voice that there are folk that want this branch of magic gone. He recognises that names are lost on Nai, so her draws out a symbol. A religious symbol, and explains to her that anyone that bears this symbol is not to be trusted. He explains in vivid detail a druid culling, where members of this group targeted and killed many people like them, and almost succeeded. But, some druids survived, and like a flower in crack in cobblestone, nature will grow and adapt, as will the druids. He explains that she cannot use Wild Shape in front of others, unless she absolutely trusts them, and that teaching the Druidic language to anyone other than a Druid is forbidden, and she understand from the tone of his voice alone that she’s been trusted with something great.However, their time together is relatively short. Reaching the end of his significant life, Oberon falls. He explains the a confused Nai that this is how nature works. Druids are blessed to be able to be one with it for an extended period of time, but every creature has their time, and this is his. She asks what she can do for him, and he simply replies that he wishes to be buried at the base of the giant Oak at the centre of this forest, and she complies. With his last strength, they move him there, and he passes away peacefully. Nai doesn’t understand death, but she knows he is gone. She grants his wish, burying him, and sits by his grave, and in her own, silent way she mourns. Upon leaving, she takes an acorn from this tree and a memento of her teacher, and much-loved friend. She places it in her staff, and within a couple of days, it takes root and grows, producing a single, bright green oak leaf. Nai doesn’t notice, but since this, the staff gradually feels lighter to her, and is easier to carry, this large chunk of driftwood now becoming a focus for her magic. She continues her travels, practising her magic whenever she’s confident no one is around. But then, one day, Korko does something he’s never done since their first meeting. He pesters her. He comes back from a flight, scrap of paper in hand. It’s written in common, so Nai doesn’t understand what it says, but she can tell that Korko is trying to tell her something. So, she follows him. She follows him West, and eventually, South, to a small town she would later learn goes by the name of Narazar.
Pirate quartermaster who is illiterate.

Mentally disabled ranger who has issues using a gun and training animals; so he trains larger bugs and uses a sling. he is the dog you see in the park who chews on grass and then licks a tree for a few hours.

A rogue that found out slavery was a better trade than adventuring. He began building a city made off the backs of slaves that were once nefarious prisoners. He received tithes for taking truly horrible people and made a keen living off of others misfortune. His personality was basically the biggest asshole dog you can think of.

Raised as the outcast, changeling daughter of a poor spinning and weaving family on the outskirts of the city, Nellyn spent her days living in shame because her green skin was a reminder of her ancestors' dalliances with the world of the fey.  Longing to prove herself as a worthy daughter, a competent hero, a good human, Nellyn spun wool quietly in her room and learned to use her charm and beauty to her advantage whenever she was allowed outdoors.Her life changed one day when a satyr, dressed in royal garb, arrived at her parents door with a scroll glowing faintly of moonlight.  Within the scroll was an official notice of courtship, a formal request from the Archfey Maiden of the Moon, who declared her intentions to wed Nellyn--her ancient fey bloodlines were of political import to the Maiden, and the marriage would be purely out of social convenience.  In return for accepting her hand, the Maiden offered Nellyn magical abilities and a chance to leave her quiet home and truly prove herself.  Nellyn readily accepted, leaving behind the family that was all too glad to send her away, and hopes to earn the favor--and perhaps even the love--of her betrothed.

Fiammetta, born to a well-known Baldurian merchant family, had always been somewhat the spoiled sort as a child; though her Efreet father had been rightfully run out of town when she was barely old enough to walk, the word "want" was nonetheless rarely found in her vocabulary, as what could someone want who already has nearly everything? During her days, or at least when she was not helping tend to the affairs of the House of Garazzolo's thriving caravan business, she could often be found taking a stroll not through the wealthier parts of town, but through the poorest, going on "slum safari" as she and her friends would call it, flashing her wealth and often donating it to the needy she would encounter — not out of some genuine desire to help, but rather out of one to remind them of who is on top.But though her life was often easy, rarely is not never, and after seeing her consummately honest mother's business destroyed by a significantly less honest competitor employing scores of Orcish bandits, what Fiammetta wanted more than anything was justice. After forming a failed coalition with several other nobles to round up the people responsible — hiring mercenaries of their own to do the dirty work — she found that delegation was not for her, and decided that if you want a job done right, you have to do it yourself.It was not long after that that she gathered what money she could, placed some orders with the local blacksmith, and set out to do just that.
His clan was killed by giants when he was a child, but he managed to hide. An elven friend of the family, Sinfler Greenleaf, helped him survive and trained him to survive and take revenge.

The birth of a Forest Gnome is a wondrous thing to behold. I don’t know exactly how other types of gnomes give birth, I’ve never seen it. But us forest folk? Well, it’s a sight. We’re born casting illusions, and some of the more mystically inclined folks in the clans like to say the first illusions of a newborn help set the fate of that gnome, and set them on their path in life, and the majority of the clans tend to believe them. Some, like my cousin Goldencircle, come out blasting growing trees, fountains of arcane life, and the calming glow of the central Forest. Others, like my brother, Brindleberry, show a series of other figures working alongside them, building great tunnels and intricate mechanisms above and below the trees with sweeping gestures of a many-branched wand. So, it’s not all that surprising that  I lived a lot of my life treated like a rare and dangerous thing. Far from the magical and natural picture-shows of the rest of Clan Forestward, I was born appearing to have blades in both hands. My Uncle, Crosswood, once said “Chirpy (that was his nickname for me between the ages of 20 and 30. More on our proclivity for naming things soon), you damn near gave your old grandmother her death with your appearance. First, the thing with the swords. THEN, you projected all sorts of horrors around the room, each of them running towards you, and each of them somehow missing you, to disappear into some corner or other.” Sure enough, Grandmother Phloremore never really warmed up to me, and always sent me on the most physical and dangerous tasks outside of our warren. She once snidely remarked that it was due to my mother’s Rock Gnome bloodline, and I dismissed it at the time, but thinking back, it’s probably at least partly true. So, some background on my warren: The Forestward clan, as our name implies, are protectors of our little branch of Home Forest. Mostly, that involves attending to the growth of things, balancing out the workings of predator and prey, leading foreigners away before they can interfere with us, and learning new magics. Oh, the magics. We’re a very studious bunch, us Forestwards. We have a long tradition of sending the best and brightest of us off to the various wizarding colleges of the land, and those best and brightest continue to make a name for themselves for a bit abroad, performing what some think of as miracles, but what we know are family-kept secrets, before coming back by their hundredth birthday to resume the mantle of Warden of Home. In this way, at our coming of age ceremony, the most important part of the week-long festival  is the Magical Aptitude, Recognition and Knowledge portion, or MARK. My clan never really worried about MARK day, really. Generation upon generation of Forestward names are grown into the top of the MARK tree, and if you touch those names, they’ll show you a preserved illusion of the events that brought them, and our family, the honor and reverence of the surrounding forest. My own MARK test was what some might call an unmitigated disaster. I tend to think it was somewhat mitigated, but that’s neither here nor there. See, as I grew, I was more of the bruiser type, by looks. Tall for a gnome, and far stronger and more acrobatic than my peers, I grew up at the tops of the trees, swinging where others could only occasionally climb, catching the animals unaware in their dens and hunting with their young. I learned how to catch a bird in flight by the time I was 15, how to forage enough meat, nuts and berries by 17, and by the time I came of age at 25, I was fully able to cross the entire Clansgrove unseen carrying several times my own weight in material. On the day of my MARK, there were five of us up for admission into the wizard’s grove: My forementioned cousin, Goldencircle, who I’ve always gotten along well with and share many childhood memories with; Balliecharm, a young man from the Spectraldeer Clan who I barely knew, but seemed to resent me for some reason or other; Callieflower, who I courted once, awkwardly, and who I could never get anything right around; Calladario, her brother, who liked me fine before my MARK, but not so much after; and myself. The others spoke their charms, summoned their fae creatures, lit their fires, and performed their minor miracles easily enough, to the glee of the judges. As for my MARK, well, the headmaster eventually recovered fully, and the nickname Blunderstab sticks with me to this day. Hell, I self-apply it, to remember where I’m from, so to speak. Oh, yeah. Names. We gnomes really love naming things, and each other. You might hear of me as Chirpy, Stelfins, Elftalker, Grounder, Cereliphian, Dragonpunch, or Formie, or any of a dozen others, depending on who’s talking. Some of those come from interesting incidents, some just sounded good to someone. Anyway, we name things by our moods towards them at the time, and it changes depending on all sorts of circumstances. I don’t know how you big people do it, keeping just one name all the time for each other, when sometimes you just feel differently towards each other constantly. It just adds a lot of context to how you interact is all I’m saying. After my MARK disaster, I was denied admission to the Magegrove for further instruction, and had to find my own way. The next couple of years were less than ideal for me. I’d been somewhat shamed, didn’t have much of a career path set for me, and was avoiding everyone who was caught in what was called the “MARK of the long knives,” which is hard in a bustling warren like ours. I took to becoming somewhat invisible, honing my natural skills to the point where I only could be found when I wanted to be. I managed to strike up a few good friendships with local elves, and would occasionally trade them secrets learned from the local animals for lessons in the Fae language and additional blade practice. It seemed a fair trade, and a useful skillset. Where others might have used these skills to empty the local treasuries and move on, I took to sneaking into the wizard’s grove to peek in on the studies going on there. Some of that might have been friendly competition with my cousin, some might have been to see more of Callieflower. It was my rebellious 30s and 40s, I can’t explain it better than that. Anyway, that’s where most of my magic comes from these days. I saw the effects from a distance in hiding, and have spent the intervening years reverse-engineering the effects using my own latent magical powers. Something in my Rock Gnome blood led me to fiddling about with various materials to duplicate the effects magic couldn’t, and I used that to self-teach myself as, well, I wasn’t sure what I was being called to, just that all this tinkering, stealthily moving about, and being able to out-fight anyone in my clan seemed very important to me. Taking risk upon risk only could hold out so long, however. Shortly before my former MARK-mates graduated from the local school and moved on to the bigger wizard’s academy, to join others of our clans that had stayed there to teach, that my luck finally ran out. I think it was Balliecharm, actually, who cast a spell I haven’t been able to duplicate yet, that sent me hurtling from the nearby nook I was auditing the class from and into the circle formed by the class. It was a unique case, as nobody had ever been caught sneaking INTO a school in our long history. It was finally decided that although no crime was committed, it might be best for me and my clan (and by that I mean mostly my clan) if I were to see the world and serve the needs of the Home Forest abroad. I was tasked with seeing the world, righting wrongs, gathering information, and making myself known in the world, but I was never given a timetable to come back and report. I never asked, and I found a kind of joy on the road, so I never sought out the road home. There would be plenty of time for that, later. That was about 30 years ago now, and I’m approaching the age where a gnome of my station should consider doing his one great deed abroad before settling down in the Home Forest to continue to serve the Braided Clans. My former classmates are almost graduated from their academy, and should be taking their own journeys abroad in the next year to see the world and to enjoy what of it they can. With that in mind, and hoping to maybe see one or more of them on their journey, I recently heard tell of a great unrest on the borderlands to the south, and journeyed where rumor and weather led me, until one night, camping with strangers found upon the road, we were surprised by a goblin attack. The rest, as they say, is history.
She was taken in by a necromancer and taught the ways of dark magic. one day she accidentally brought the towns dead back to life and chaos ensued so she escaped.

Being part-elemental, was a guinea pig for some dragon cultists; some adventurers freed him; dedicated himself to follow their steps; trained himself in the art of wielding greatswords; was killed in a dungeon; was resurrected by Bahamut and became his prophet/evangelist; encountered a darker half of Ao who was inclined to destroy everything and gambled; now leads a party of wannabe-superheroes who were cursed for immortality by said half; was buried for 45 years in the collapsed cave; was stranded for a year alone without a leg and any means to forage any food; accidentaly, while trying to save his unconcious friends after this yeard passed, got almost killed in a dungeon and was left here for nine years until another band of adventurers found them. being immortal is fucked up, turns out.

When Aquis was 5 years old, her life changed. Her father, Aukitza, was a Genie. Aukitza married a young human woman, Rose, and had their first child, Dinnis. The people of the main Kingdom would torment him for their wishes to be answered, so Aukitza decided to leave to have some peace in their lives. He found a travelling group of nomads that consisted of Clerics and Druids trying to cope with poverty in the harsh deserts to the west. There, they flourished. Rose became a priestess and Aukitza helped raise new temples and barns. Eventually they had another child, Aquis. Aquis, like her brother Dinnis, was a Water Genasi. The two of them could create clean water to fill the reservoirs for the clergymen and poor of the temples. One fateful night, upon arriving home, Rose walked into an ambush that had been set up by a corrupt group of men from the main Kingdom. They demanded that Aukitza grant them a wish, or they would kill him. Aukitza, while inherently magical, actually had no ability to cast a wish. Then, one of the guards killed Dinnis, who was only 7. Aquis watched in horror as her mother and father were helpless to meet the demands of these warriors. They then threatened to take Roses life. Aukitza looked into Aquis' eyes, and with his last words said "I'm sorry", as he charged forward attempting to grab his scimitar off the wall, when Rose was struck down. As the guards went to apprehend Aukitza, one of the guards made what appeared to be a killing strike on him and he burst into smoke. The guards started shouting at each other, thinking they could maybe take his daughter for ransom, but ultimately decided to leave because there was nothing more they could do without the Genie who was dead. So they left. Aquis cried until the morning clutching her dead mother, where she ran out of energy to carry on. The tribesmen found her and decided to bury Rose and Dinnis and hold a funeral that night. Aquis remained with the small group of nomads which formed into a small town of 1,000. While she mostly worked in the temple, she was always interested in the druids of their settlement, and noticed that one of them was a survivalist trainer. After filling the water reservoirs in the church, she would go train with the druids, eventually learning interesting magic from them. She vows to get revenge on the band of warriors that slayed her family in front of her, and wields her father's scimitar in the hopes that she crosses their paths. Little does she know, her father is still alive.

Sod was raised in a relatively mild-mannered wood genasi family in the woods far to the east of the Southron Lands. For generations, Sod's family has cultivated weapons grown from the very woods in which they lived, a careful process that takes a great deal of attention and is done with meditative focus. Although not well known by name, due to the humble nature of his community, the weapons produced in his familial grove have earned an impressive reputation for sturdiness, reliability, and impeccable craftsmanship. While Sod’s family has never taken up arms themselves in any sort of organized, martial fashion, they nonetheless take a great deal of pride in the work of their hands, choosing to believe that their weapons are always deployed in self-defense, of either one’s one self or one’s own people. Their connection with the earth runs deep, and through this recognize that conflict is one turn of the wheel of a peaceable society.Sod, a rambunctious youth, never quite fit in with his family. The wood genasi family of which he is a part is generally open and accepting but nonetheless is driven by rather stoic and conservative values, privileging family, tradition, craft, and above all, peaceful coexistence with nature. Sod, a loud, gregarious youth, more interested in a good story and meaty pun than the stolid assessments of recent rainfall and preparations for the upcoming harvest, found himself often at the outskirts of conversations. Despite an intense desire for the community that seemed to be proffered by his village, he was never quite able to find his way in, no matter how good his card tricks. He gamboled and jape through most of his youth, but knew that his life was meant for something different.  For Sod, this disjunction between the perceived comfort of his upbringing and his yearning for an outside became increasingly difficult to reconcile when, as he moved into his adolescence, he began to realize that his connection with nature went beyond the demi-religious and traditional and in fact manifested in his realization that he was intrinsically entwined with what others about the world call “wild magic.” His first encounters with magic were haphazard and uncontrolled – an unexpected fireball here, a little light telekinesis there – which he and his family did his damndest, in a campaign of self-denial, to write off as youthful imagination run roughshod. However, at a certain point, his natural aptitude for magic could no longer remain secret, when, in the midst of a particularly vivid daydream, he inadvertently cast a flaming sphere that engulfed a broad swath of juvenile longspears that his family had been cultivating for 35 harvests.His family, while supportive of his odd personality and his occasional magical mishaps, grew increasingly wary of the destructive potential of his newfound magical potential. Paired with his temperamental differences, his newfound magical identity proved a particularly challenging obstacle to his fitting in with his community, and while there was never any direct hostility – the wood genasi being a peaceable, respectful people on the whole and his community being a particularly accepting one, all things considered – he nonetheless felt the pressures of being different compounding. His outgoing nature never quite fit in, and once word spread of his “condition,” he found it ever more difficult to find his way within his society. Despite the pressures of his community, he nonetheless found the time to practice his newfound abilities, seeking out secluded glens in which he could attempt to cultivate his magical abilities, with dead saplings suffering the brunt of his early attempts at reigning in his power. It was in one of these arboreal hideouts that he first discovered his ability to summon Frank, his stalwart hedgehog companion, with whom he shares a strong bond of friendship.When Sod reached late adolescence, he knew it was time to leave, and he took it upon himself to seek out the broader world beyond his coniferous confines. Choosing a prime shortspear from the latest harvest, and gaining the reluctant support of his parents, he made his way shortly to Pole by way of his affability and impressive intuition for navigating local taverns in search of adventures large and small.

Orphaned after their wagon set ablaze, killing his parents.  SweerTar found himself alone on the streets of Waterdeep "procuring" food to survive.  His only friends being the creatures of the city who were just as despairing as himself.  It wouldn't last long though.  Soon less favorable institutions discovered his small size and special ability to communicate telepathically a great benefit.  SweerTar quickly rose through the ranks at a young age as a quite formidable thief and look out.  Until one day the mark was a magical bag found inside a lesser known Druid Guild in Waterdeep.  Although SweerTar procured the bag, he was soon caught of guard. Dumbfounded as how he triggered a spell that made all the house plants grow and grab his body.  Holding him there until the authorities came.  At his trial, which would ultimately lead to death or hard labor, an elder Wood Elf Druid named Rolen, convinced the court of something different.  Rolen would take the young SweerTar and have him work off his punishment in the Druid's Guild.  Thus was his life until he reached adulthood.  Life wasn't all bad though.  SweerTar found himself fully fed, clothed, and educated in a short time.  Simple spells were learned where he could manipulate earth and water, even produce a small flame in his hand to light candles or fires.  The little freedom SweerTar had was dedicated to helping his oldest friends, the animals of the city.  No other before had advocated for the dangerous dog packs, the wretched rat, or the packs of cats in heat.  Rolen enjoyed watching SweerTar engage these animals and with little effort taught the first of his many great spells.  The spell that allowed him to talk to animals.  Not long after SweerTar had the greatest communication network in the city and beyond.  Good and bad stories all around but the need to help those taken advantage of sprung forth.  Thus started SweerTar's quest to not only help the animals of the city but also the injustices caused by a piece of his past, his old Thieve's Guild.

Rydell is not precisely what'd you'd expect from an ancient undead abomination. For the most part she seems very much like a kindly grandmother who instead of dozing in a rocking chair affixes herself at the front of a ship, acting as a living figurehead. She tends to have tea and hard candies on hand to offer to folks, and she can usually be found absentmindedly rolling a jawbreaker around in her mouth.Only that's not a jawbreaker. It's a bullet. And the reason it's in her mouth is because she's coating the damned thing in venom, and as a member of the living dead she isn't worried in the slightest about lead poisoning.The old ghoul has seen and done just about everything and she's always ready and eager to share some of her wisdom on various subjects, though her memory has gotten a bit spotty since she got shot in the head quite awhile ago, and spent a few centuries sleeping it off.Which is how she's ended up in the Dreamscape in the first place. She murdered everyone aboard a ship at sea and attached herself to the front of it disguised as a figurehead, and then woke up some time later attached to a complete different ship in a completely different plane.Precisely how much of her personality is original and how much is head trauma is something that she doesn't quite remember. She remembers being part of a literal adventuring band in the past, all musicians of some sort. A bearded, mighty thewed orcish barbarian guitarist who would shred on his axe and then shred with his axe, a tiefling druid guitarist who played instruments of living wood, a goblin vocalist who was also in charge of pyrotechnics and was a real Jekyll and Hyde diva, a human violinist whose sorrowful tunes would wake the dead, and herself a young Elven beauty who played wind instruments who could be so haunting that it formed spectral shapes that became real.Those days are long gone, and she does not even remember their names, but their deeds set her on the path to being the monster that she is today. She can recall something terrible occurring, something that twisted and warped them all, changing Rydell from a beautiful Elven maiden in a copper-played, winged abomination blooded by the elves' ancient rivals the dwarves.In questing to restore her elven beauty, Rydell only found herself becoming more monstrous. Her once heroic self turned towards the darkness, valuing her lost looks over all. To that end she eventually became one of many cultists brought together by an enigmatic group known as the Quills, who seek to gain knowledge (especially dark and forbidden knowledge.) The cult concealed themselves as devotees of a goddess of beauty, dwelling in "The City in the Valley," a vast metropolis where all things art and beauty were celebrated.Attempting to bring something (she no longer recalls what) horrific and powerful into the world and eager to reap rewards for doing so, the cultists drew the direct ire of the goddess they had been masquerading as followers of. The goddess unleashed her wrath upon the beautiful City in the Valley. Those within found themselves transformed into reflections of their inner selves, Rydell and many of her fellow cultists altered into serpentine forms befitting their status as treacherous, backstabbing snakes, their hair transformed into a writhing nest of serpents to represent their co-conspirators.But the good people in the City in the Valley were not spared the horrors that befell their sinister neighbors.The dark powers invoked to try and bring the Great Horror into the world twisted the weather, forming an immense, ceaseless blizzard in the midst of summer in a land that had never known the caress of snow. Even had visibility been decent, the valley passes would have been choked by snow, the the high winds destroying any ship that dared attempt the escape.And so the good people of the City in the Valley fell to the monsters the goddess of beauty had created, as did many of the monsters.Amongst them Rydell's life ended, and her unlife began.Risen as a Lacedon, a horrific aquatic ghoul, Rydell was able to escape the charnel house that the City in the Valley had become, protected from the billowing gale above by so much icy water. Her undead form immune to the chill of the water around her.Mind and body broken by the incident, Rydell found herself bereft of many of her former bardic abilities, though she did retain some aspects of her ability to perform as well as serving as a font of knowledge. But her abilities were just as warped. Her capacity for knowledge came from whispers from her serpentine hair, each snake seeming to house a portion of the knowledge of each member of her cult in miniature. Her bardsong no longer able to inspire courageous deeds as it once did, instead serving as a muted echo of the corruptive song that the goddess of beauty sang sealing the City in the Valley to its fate, empowering her allies with physical and mental alterations and empowerments.From there the memories grow blurry, Rydell recalls training to gain martial prowess to replace the spellcasting capability the goddess' curse had robbed from her. Scraps of memory place her studying at the vaunted Crashing Tempest Academy, which seeks to study every aspect of fighting no matter how unorthodox, serving as a Judge of the Scales of Morning, seeking to preserve the balance between life, death, and undeath (usually by applying death and undeath in places where life has gotten a titch too big for its britches), and serving for quite some time as a privateer.Rydell recalls being far, far more powerful than she currently is, rather sure that the bullet to the head took away her memories of her strongest abilities and techniques, as well as requiring a great deal of power to be expended to restore her body from the brink of destruction. But seeing her in combat one can easily see her prowess. One can also see that quite frequently she's holding back. She seems to want to give her foes a sporting chance as well as allowing her shipmates, who don't have decades (possible centuries) of adventuring experience to figure out how things are done. But if situations are sufficiently dire, she will unleash her full, terrifying combat prowess.Though capable of creating more lacedons, Rydell is usually loathe to do so. She doesn't want to leave a trail of rampaging ghouls behind her wherever she goes. She doesn't have the time, or the interest, to personally oversee each one and make sure they're under her thrall, as well as keeping them under her power. Left to their own devices her babies have a tendency to be naughty and not particularly hospitable to her living (and tasty) crewmates.Sure, they could likely be fed raw meat in the ship's mess, but Rydell's gargoyle-like nature is essentially the only aspect of her monstrous form that she CAN'T pass on to somebody. Meaning that they'll be quite ravenous and frequently hungry, instead of only occasionally requiring a bit of rare steak, or a chicken breast run through a warm roomAlso she doesn't want to impugn on the captain's hospitality, after all. And suddenly dumping a pile of powerful undead guests in the ship's lap needing to be fed raw meat frequently is not a particularly polite thing to do.Though if asked, she'll happily kill someone and have them reborn as an undead abomination under her thrall. Despite being quite grandmotherly, she is actually rather happy to go about killing and murdering and whatnot.

Zeth was raised in an academy to be a knight. Typically, the way to become a Githyanki knight is to kill a Mindflayer in single combat. Unfortunately, he was something of a weeaboo for Illithids, having secretly learned their unholy language, which he practised by whispering erotic phrases to his Mindflayer body pillow. As such, when he entered the ring to complete his final assessment and kill a Mindflayer, he got painfully aroused and started trying to chat it up. When the onlookers realised what he was doing, they chased him off and banished him permanently from the realm. He stole a red dragon and tried to escape, but as they were flying into the material plane, he made an incredibly pervy comment to the dragon, who tipped him off onto a mountainside.

Timon split away from his tribe of Gnolls, hunting those that couldn't fight back felt wrong and cowardly to him. Traveling through the country, he would look for people to test his physical prowess, often times challenging them to a wrestling match or an arm wrestling competition. Eventually he came upon a cleric who told him the ways of Kord, the God of Strength and Competition. Ever since then he has committed his life to challenging and improving the physical state of himself and others.

Gnozz was part of a pack of Gnolls that worshiped their patron deity Yeenoghu. Their way of worshiping their god was to spill blood in his name, and slaughtering all in their wake. Gnozz's heart was never really in it though. He took part in their raids and slaughter but only because it was what he was raised to do, not because he lusted for it like the others. He was much more attuned to his Hyena spirit than his fiendish blood. During a raid of a village one day he spared the life of a human child. By sparing a life, you are stealing blood from Yeenoghu, so sparing a life was blasphemy, and so his pack turned on him. He was barely able to escape. He left the continent for a new one to avoid being hunted down. He is trying very hard to change his ways and become good, but his frame of reference for what is good and bad is so extreme that even when he thinks he's doing good, it's really just less bad than he's used to. This makes him very naive. Now that he's join an adventuring party, he has fierce loyalty to his friends which he considers his new pack.
A wild child raised by wolves
An entertainer and cook, staunchly loyal, astoundingly cunning!

Allan Vidok and his older brother Piquat were young thieves, never getting caught, leaving evidence behind, and completing their jobs so quietly that nothing seemed stolen. While Allan was content, Piquat wanted more, so he joined the Thieves' Guild. Piquat revelled in it, dismissing his brother's doubts. Then Piquat took on an assassination, not telling his brother the goal until the knife was at her throat. Allan cleaned up after his brother, but vowed vengeance. That very night, he went out and stole a ruby from the head of the Thieves' Guild. He left it in his brother's stash and showed his loyalty by "catching" him. The Guild awarded him, imprisoned his brother, and Allan retired. Ever since, he's been focused on thwarting violent criminals, especially those who slip through the cracks. Allan hews to a strict moral and legal code, moreso than most local authorities.
Farthicus used to work for the temple of pelor as a kind of librarian but then the dark lore he read drove him insane and he started raising skeletons from the grave yard

Character's name: Grentus Gromulous Grumble, son of Grimble
Character's backstory: Grentus Grumble is the son of an adventuring Gnome who had a big adventure amidst the grass, per the Pink Floyd song. Upon his father's retirement, Grentus took up the adventuring life himself, learning to cast spells through music and song.

Daughter of a powerful family of the underground gnome mafia. Got caught messing up some basic roguery and realized she faced no consequences because people were afraid of her family name; decided to get out from under that shadow and prove herself.

Glib is (was?) an actor who studied extensively to be the best portrayal of a paladin for his troupe of thespians. Unfortunately he was approached while on break and asked to go adventuring. He, being perfectly in character at all times, joined the party as their stalwart champion of goodness, right, and valor.

He was a gnome from the forest village, when he felt nature calling him. He left the village and wandered around the natural landscapes of the world for 15 years. He realized that creatures from the natural world were being threatened, that is when nature gave him his druidic magic and he promised to protect all creatures.

Rajcha is a veteran of the Gnomish Irregular Light Cavalry. He served in the most recent Dwarf / Goblin war, where lost his innocence, his idealism, and most of his troop. His cavalry division was stranded without support when political infighting in the Dwarf kingdom erupted into a civil war. Dwarf soldiers were suddenly recalled, leaving their Gnome allies in the field - suddenly, drastically outnumbered.

Gnareth was in a party of forest gnomes, but his grumpy demeanor didn't play well with all of the other more jovial gnomes. Plus he was always more interested in animals, taming big cats and horses to bring into the gnome town that would then cause terrible havoc. He was eventually kicked out, and now roams around adventuring with his animal friends rather than trying to settle down again.

Raised by a traveling group of tradesmen, they were trained to be a professional mourner, singing the dead into the next life and picking up some bardic magic in the process. However, once their spouse died, they became a traveling knit goods salesman and adopted a catfolk wizard. Once they and their new acquaintances attracted the attention of the gods and were assigned a quest, however, they picked up their bardic magic once more.

Gracie is grew up in a small rock gnome village and eventually became the village midwife.  After almost 300 years her village was cursed by something unknown and children stopped being born. No one within the village or who had ever lived in the village could conceive anymore. Gracie being the oldest, with a job now defunct, left to find what cursed her village and joined a group of adventurers as a friendly encouraging grandma.

Pups is little more than the unexpected product of a reincarnation spell used by a naive cleric with good intentions - she was once the pet (dog) of Lord Tomblay, who upon hearing that she was killed by carriage demanded her resurrection. He was repulsed by her reincarnated state, and Pups was abandoned on the side of the road in a box, where she was discovered by her traveling companion Ramsey. She now owns a rummage shop & tells mediocre jokes.

Gord is the eighth son of a seventh son. As the youngest of eight boys (Aord, Bord, Cord, Dord, Eord, Ford and Maximillian) he was often left to his own devices. Gord grew up idolizing Maximilian, and once Max set off to seek his destiny as the seventh son, Gord realized that he wanted to make his own way in the world. He's got a sharp sword, a big heart, and a world full of trouble just waiting for him to dive in and find a destiny of his own.

Ren set down the plow and picked up the sword to help control a growing population of wolves near the village he was born and raised in. He was as surprised as anyone that it was an implement he excelled with, though he covets a secret hope that someday he'll come back and retire to a life of warm, breezy summers and cozy winters. Small in stature, Ren takes particular pleasure in defeating larger foes - though this can lead him to making choices which seem reckless to the casual observer. Above all other companions he shows his affection and respect for the group who gave him the benefit of the doubt and helped him cull the pack.

Wrenn (Wrenn Eldon Uptree Frogbother Prickleback) grew up in Benklur, a small wooded town in Geflesh. His parents were both carpenters but Wrenn lacked the desire to follow in their footsteps, showing more of an interest in books and learning.After leaving home, he found work in the city library at Engrel as an apprentice researcher. A fire caused the library to reshuffle jobs and focus more on procurement of new books and manuscripts – for Wrenn this meant heading back out into the world as a field researcher.On the road, Wrenn fell in with less-than-savoury characters, developing skills with thieves’ tools and weapons. These skills have saved his skin more than once in his search for rare literary works.

Gnorgi's gnomish clan was almost completely destroyed in his youth, as the hills that they called home were overrun by goblins.His family was reduced to the basest living, hiding most of their time, and foraging the meagerest bits of the natural world around them.They have fallen into a cycle of cultivating fungi, tubers, and insects in a very small burrow that has escaped notice for years.Gnorgi has become very adept in working with the nature that is just below the ground- communing with the vermin, cultivating the most potent mushrooms, and tapping the magical currents that he can feel in the soil.He might be happy to always live his life this way, but he is always in danger of discovery by the goblins all around him...

Linn grew up in a rock gnome community within a large dwarven mining town. She apprenticed with an accomplished silversmith and eventually went into the business independently. Magic was always just a hobby for her, a way to learn a few convenient tricks and keep her mind nimble. She and her husband Ollie, a gemcutter, fell in love while haggling over the cost of rubies. They lived six happy decades together and built a thriving business, with city nobles clamoring for their jewelry. But then on a trip to the capital, Ollie was killed by a rampaging giant. Unable to remain alone in the home they had built together, Linn decided to set off into the wider world. Maybe she could discover the cause behind the giants' madness, or at least prevent such tragedies from happening to others.

Dimble was born during a solar eclipse in a small gnome village at the base of the Wetfoot Mountains. This means that he was chosen to be the guardian of the Gnight Springs at the base of the mountain. He began training from birth and at age 44 assumed his position as guardian. There he lived and worked for the entirety of his service, 100 years. At 144 years old Dimble left the spring and went to the town bar for his first drink in 100 years. On his was there he encountered a butterfly, chased it, fell down a ravine, and had a vision. In his fall he forgot many of his spells/disciplines. Believing it to be fate, he set out with other fellow explorer in a quest to gain back his mystic knowledge and to discover more about the world and how it works.

In his younger years, the settlement he lived in in the Underdark was attacked by the Illithid. He was taken to become a Mozgriken, an experimental procedure in which a gnomish host is implanted with an illithid tadpole. The procedure did not go as planned, and Alvyn maintained what little is left of his sanity through sheer willpower. His many years spent near the Illithid God Brain expanded on his minor psionic powers gained through the introduction of this tadpole to his brain. He escaped after a long 70 years, eventually making it to the surface. He made his new life in a cave near a dwarven city, with a newfound respect and need to protect personal freedom. He spent 50 years there with his imaginary friend Mac before he came forth as the entire world's freedom became threatened by an imminent demonic invasion. With his mastery of the element of air and the innate freedom it inspires, he set forth to find a group of capable adventurers to help to stop this invasion.

A former hypeman for the Underdark Fighting Circuit's own Drek Boneduster, Goliath Barbarian. Stanford's job was to set up the fights, arrange betting and payments, build up hype in whatever town they were in, and to generally take care of everything shy of beating the everloving hell out of whatever poor chump was slotted to fight Drek. Stanford was a natural, almost to a fault, at convincing people to take bets they had no business taking, while being a large motivational factor towards his fighter's success. Mortally afraid of combat, Drek was his own personal meat shield of sorts. After 72 straight wins, Stanford went all in on a fight taking place in Dragon's Throat, knowing he could fleece the local mobsters out of some gold, going as far as to spend his winnings before he earned them. Drek lost, and was killed, ending his career at 72-1, simultaneously ending Stanford's career as a hypeman, and getting him in deep with the mob in Dragon's Throat. On the run and out of cash, Stanford finds himself looking for new companionship and hiding himself away from the people trying to get their money back.

Myron was born into a family of clock makers in Hope's Rest, but when his mother died, he left home to join the church as a local Pastor, caring for people and communities and cementing The Church's influence across the land. During his training, however, it became clear that Myron had little concern for curing colds and consoling those who had gotten splinters, and he was informed that he did not have what it took to be a Pastor. The Church did not want to write their investment in him off completely however, so instead transferred him into Arbiter training, where he would use weapons, rather than kind words, to protect communities. Once trained he was stationed in a cluster of small towns and villages in a remote plateau, were he spent as much time defending them from savage beasts as he did from encroaching enemies. The wilderness made him hard, and his nature made him distant, almost feared, as he wandered from village to village, doing what needed to be done. Eventually, he came across a small boy whose parents claimed he had The Sight. On reporting the supposed vision to his long-standing confident Arbiter Kyros, she showed him a glimpse into a world that suggested that The Church might not everything it appeared and that his view of the world might not be complete.

Moss was found in the forest by a group of people from a hunting guild. She was taken back with them and was raised by the guild. he was taught how to track and how to use a bow. Her life seemed set, she'd keep learning from the guild, and when she came of age she would become a full member. However the course of her life changed when one night she was led into the nearby forest by a strange magical energy. Moss followed for what seemed like hours until she realised she didn't recognised the woods she was in, she had been taken into the fae wild. Moss was scared but figured she had come this far, so she continued following the energy. Eventually Moss was led to a clearing where a huge blue stag stood. It saw her and bent it's head and touched it too her own. Then Moss woke up, face down in the mud right outside of the hunting guild. It was then that she decided to travel in search of answers. Years passed until she came of age and was ready to leave home, it was around a week into her trip when she realised she didn't have any money.... And so, using her excellent tracking and knowledge of animals, she became the world's first (and therefore best) pet detective!

I grew up in an ancient temple to a forgotten god.  The monks were long gone, but my parents (apparently) didn't know that when they left me there.  I don't remember my early childhood, but the god of the temple must have taken care of me.  A travelling scholar studying the architecture stayed with me for a few years, teaching me languages and literacy.The temple was curiously pristine, dust never seeming to settle anywhere for long.  Once the scholar left, I found a cache of old scrolls, the parchment still malleable and the symbols fresh.  I studied them for years.When I was a little older, some halfling soldiers out rampaging stopped by.  I hid while they desecrated the temple, destroying its furnishings (which had otherwise remained unscathed over the centuries) when they realized that there was nothing of value to be found and taken.  I was about to leave after them when the god of the temple spoke to me for the first time I could remember.  A feminine voice told me to wait for a little, and then follow and cleanse the world of their evil ways.I did as requested. I took a few days leaving, gathering all of the things I owned, leaving one final offering on the altar.  Right down the trail from the temple lay one of the soldiers, brutally dismembered.  His armour, surprisingly, fit well, and I took it (along with his weapons) to cleanse the world of such evil.

Character's name: Bingo Einie Huffmaster Bertolt Jingo Spinnacre
Character's backstory: Bingo was captured by wizard as a very young child, and enslaved/trained using a spell that overrode his will. While the most common outcome of such situation is learned helplessness (the will-overriding spell slowly becoming unnecessary), Bingo continued to blindly resist. Eventually, used over and over again, the spell burnt in: both into his mind and into the magical pathway between him and his master. In a sullen rage, after a particularly heinous day, Bingo could suddenly feel a way to “push” the spell backward — to send it back up the well worn path between him and his master. He had no practice phrasing orders as precisely as the magic demanded, however, so when he said “Stop!”, the wizard did. Completely and permanently.Bingo is still a young man, but does not trust people to see his youth, or what they would see as naivety, so he whitens his hair and gives himself the appearance of middle age. He travels in order to spread his economic and political theories, but like many young men ‘s ideas, they were formed rapidly and only from the evidence of his own life. Their premise is this: a person’s will is sacred, so must not be suborned; and doing something for free is akin to slavery. He will always demand a payment, and will always pay. Gifts make him profoundly uncomfortable. However, he’s a Gnome, he has little money, and many things freely given aren’t worth very much anyway — so he often pays with strange tokens, gestures, nose-booping, etc.

Talikah was a quiet Gnome. She lived deep in a forest with her familiar, a white tiger named Amberlee, and her mentor. Her mentor was a rough man, a human of few words and fewer kind thoughts. She never learned his name, referring to him only as "mentor" or "master" all through the decade she was his apprentice.One day Mentor told her that she needed to take a trip into the Guildlands. She was to deliver a letter for him; a letter he claimed was of great importance. Talikah was led to believe that she was finally doing something that would win her mentor's affection and approval.So she left the forest, Amberlee at her side, headed for the great human city of Brightstone. The journey out of the forest took several months. Mentor was very serious about his seclusion. Upon arrival in Brightstone, Talikah sought out a guard to ask for directions. She showed him the letter so he could read the address. The guard's face scrunched a bit before quickly re-assuming the professional neutrality the city's protection was known for. Talikah, having very little experience with people, did not notice. She thanked him for his help and went about her way, occasionally petting Amberlee to reassure her that no harm would come to her from all the humans around. Eventually she found the address on the letter. Once inside she was taken to the owner of the place. The letter was addressed to him. She assumed that the man would pen a response and she would be on her way home. She was very wrong.The man sighed. "You said your name 's Talikah, right?" Talikah nodded."Well Talikah, make yourself at home. Your so-called 'mentor' sent you here to work off his debt. You belong to the guild now." Talikah was slotted into a group with other debtors and sent adventuring to pay off the money her former master owed.
former janitor in a morgue, turned grifter and adventurer
Goblin monk who left his clan disgusted by its leaders atrocities, was taken in by monks who trained them as best he could before he left their company and ventured into the world.

Was adopted by dwarves, but has no beard so he plucks his hair and glues it to his chin to get a beard. Also he plucks his eyebrows and glues it to his lips to make a mustache. He is now bald and has no eyebrows.

Goblin factotum, same level as party, low, raspy voice, bleakly sarcastic, pure neutral in the middle of a shift. Has a dark past that he doesn’t want to talk about. Learned to make the best of the Orc enslavement, and kept his people’s spirits up. Now that they are free, he is growing into the leader of his people.

After leading a goblin raid against a merchant caravan, Narvy found a book with a coin embedded in the cover. His fruitless attempts to remove the coin led to reading the book, which turned out to be about the goddess Tymora. With repeated readings, Narvy became obsessed and declared himself a Paladin of Tymora. Tymora, being a goddess of Luck and Good Fortune, saw a bit of fun in having a plucky goblin looking for redemption as one of her champions.

He was raised on a pirate ship and got used to seeing thing like raids and rape. But one day the entire crew was captures and sent to prison, including him (he was around 18 then). He and his mates were treated horribly and he saw many of them die. He couldn't ubderstand how someone who was supposed to be good could treat them so horribly. This is also the reason he became neutral chaos, if I remember correctly.That's it :)

Raised in a hilltribe as an ordinary goblin, Snarg was on the fast track to getting killed before his 8th birthday like any other goblin. Only he was swept up by great events. Great Events. A wizard on a battlefield fumbled a spellcraft check and decided to counterspell a magic jar with a limited wish which shot wild magic all over the kingdom. A shard of that wild magic hit Snarg's cerebral cortex and imbued him with a 3rd grade reading level and the ability to cast cantrips!His journey begins...

Zime Murgan was born in a Goblin village, yet he had no time to learn the Goblin ways of life; a party of paladins cleansed the village in the name of Heironeous, sparing only the Goblin young. The young were taken from the village's burning husk and brought back to the paladins' town of residence. These paladins--reasoning that the young goblins had not been damaged by the evil ways of their tribe--raised them as if they were humans, and soon recruited those who accepted the god as squires and pages. He in particular had an extreme fascination for human culture, and above all else, saw their god as a source of incredible inspiration--even considering himself to be human, in adoration of the paladins and their devout culture. At the age of sixteen, he completed his training under the paladins' watch, and officially attained the status of Blessed. Following his graduation, he set off into parts unknown with the intent of delivering "a great conquest" for the war-god... all the while insisting he was indeed a priest, and was just as pious as any upstanding human, thank you very much.

Beedle Grimgulp was found as an abandoned baby by an a group of anarcho-syndicalist Dwarven miners on their way back from an expedition in the Earthspur Mountains. The miners, being brutish men, bickered amongst themselves whether to throw the green mass in the crib into the river, or stab it and move on. However, Beedle’s adopted father, Magnus Grimgulp, felt a stirring within his heart. Even though the Dwarves and Goblins of the Earthspur Mountains had been enemies for centuries, Magnus could not let a wee child simply die through no fault of its own.He convinced his comrades to take the child, and named him “Beedle”, after one of his companions said the baby looked like an overgrown insect. Beedle grew up among his many Dwarven adopted parents and learned to become a miner and tracker, deep within the hills and mountains. Although his true name is Beedle, his adopted community has called him Peaches, as the first word he was able to mutter was not “mama” or “dada”, but “peaches!” when the Dwarves were resting and eating peaches in the woods after a particularly exhausting day in the mines.Recently, during an expedition deep into the bowels of Faerun, his group of miners dug too deep and stumbled upon a demon in its lair. The demon absconded with Peaches’ family and fellow miners, and he has tracked the demon all the way back to the plane of Pandemonium to rescue his loved ones, and exact revenge.

Pio was born as a new crime gang overtook a small city of Rom just south of Unn. Despite the very poor and crime ridden environment, his parent's raised him to the best of their ability and taught him how to defend himself. When money became tight and the family became homeless and lived on the streets, Pio began stealing to help his sick mother stay alive. He would do anything he could to save his mother. When Pio's mother died after being 3 months in critical condition, he fled for the forest, running from his father who had turned to drinking and became abusive. He looked for answers and prayed to Silva. He survived off the wild for 6 years before his first non-animal contact since leaving Rom, a large robot, that seemed to be lost was bulldozing its way through the forest making a huge amount of noise. Pio spoke with the robot and lead it to his shelter, where he began inspecting it and poking and prying. He realized that the robot was sentient and came from the dwarvish town of Jun. Pio and the Large Robot that proclaimed himself as "The Bulwark" returned to Rom and began ridding the streets of the gangs and violent thugs. He found his father in the same state as he had saw his mother just before leaving. Pio could barely recognize his dying father covered in dirt on the side of the road. He did everything he could, but to no prevail. After he had lost everything, him and Bulwark travelled to Unn and began a new life, even though he is gone from his home-town, Pio often thinks that it is his fault that his father is dead, and that he hasn't made either of his parents proud and therefore does everything to please their dying wishes of him living, and to honor their memories.

Goliath who lived in the mountains. Culture believes heavily in reincarnation. She is the reincarnation of one of her ancestors, and through her quests she must figure out whether she is her own person, or simply a tool of fate.

She was a member of the church worshipping Malar but she delved too deep into the lore and became convinced the only worthy hunt to worship her god with was sentient beings. She got kicked out of the church when it was discovered she was hunting and eating humans and other sentient races.

Wasn't a strong fighter but kept trying to live up to his older brother (an adopted human named Nightslayer). Then a group of gremlins crashed a rocket into his encampment one winter. The winter was hard, the Dragonhold Peak clan wasn't sure they would survive, and knew they wouldn't with the gremlins around, so they were going to leave them to die. The gremlins were willing to kill to survive. Facebreaker, then known as One-of-the-Beat for his love of music, went to the gremlins and negotiated a trade. The gremlins used their explosives to blow up the cliff face, creating a harbor against the elements. In exchange, the clan taught them to hunt and grow food. The winter was tight, but they all survived, and Facebreaker was named for the cliff he caused to be destroyed. Seeing how he could bring people together, he decided to leave the clan and join the military as an Arbiter.

As a young man, Mahak was frequently found out at night. Spear in hand, eyes towards the skies, as if searching for something. When asked what, Mahak only half-smiled, 'Something is out there. Something is wrong out there'. The head of his clan thought such a behavior odd, but allowed Mahak to continue. When word of trouble away from the mountains came to the clan, Mahak half-smiled to himself 'It is time'. With this, grabbed his spear and his pack, and marched off into the night.His family name is not from the line of chiefs, and he has no desire to become chief. His blood-family consist of his Father (Puthok Keeneye), Mother(Louthou Heartweaver), and two Sisters (Mola Proudroar and Goupi Claysmasher) but, as with most Goliath tribes, he was raised by the whole clan--hunting from some, rope making from others, etc. He has had limited interaction with non-Goliaths. He and his father ran into a band of roaming Dwarves once, a group that was seeking passage over the mountain to the valley on the other side. Mahak commented on their size, slightly bemused at the dwarves, hip deep in snow.

Urulo Ogolakanu is a Goliath War Cleric. Dubbed Coldwhisper by his tribe, he is an honor-bound warrior as cold and hard as his homeland.    Guided by a divine vision, Urulo discovered a shrine to Heironeous, a god mostly forgotten in Faerún, on a bleak mountaintop near his tribe’s homeland. He knows not what era this shrine came from, nor who built it; all he knows is that upon finding this shrine, he was struck by a bolt of lightning. Not only did he survive – he was granted divine power. Urulo left his village to live alone at the shrine, earning the name Coldwhisper for how he conversed stoically with Heironeous himself.    Now he serves as an aspiring avatar of this god, who represents honor and courage. A silver lightning bolt adorns Urulo’s shield and a war cry for justice echoes from his lips as he enters the fray. Having come so closely in contact with an actual divine power, Urulo is definitely a strange and aloof individual, whose primary motivation in all things is service to his deity. Goliath culture values fair battle, so valor and honor were instilled in Urulo from birth, but the other values are ones he strives to instill in himself and his companions.    Heironeous’ primary demand for Urulo Ogolakanu: to bring the virtues of justice, bravery, and chivalry back into vogue amidst a lawless and backstabbing world. Visions of a resurgence of Hextor, god of dishonorable battle and chaotic warmongering, motivate Heironeous’ desires for Urulo. A scroll containing the details of Hextor’s predicted rise and the steps to shut him down can be found stored safely at Urulo’s home shrine.    Urulo has been sent to civilization according to the whims of Heironeous, who has promised that fate will bring this Goliath to his rightful place.

Lyra Feldspar, a cleric of Melora, was not always the healer she has become. Once, she was a battlemaiden in her barbarian tribe of the Northern Wilds. She and her husband, Gravehardt, helped lead their warband in many raids over the years, but when he was killed in a battle with the nearby orc tribe, Lyra went mad with rage. When she had killed all that she could, she wept, and fled her tribe, unable to face them with out her beloved. Her life changed once more the first time she crested the mountains near Waterdeep and beheld the sea for the first time. Something in that vast ocean, and in the waves, called to her, and she prayed for the first time to a god she did not know in thanks. Melora heard her prayer of gratitude, and gave Lyra the peace she needed to clear her mind, and Lyra was reborn in the sea goddess's service. As part of this newfound faith, Lyra as sworn never to kill in rage again, though she will defend herself if called on. Instead, she has learned to channel the powers of her goddess to the healing arts, and bring her blessings on her allies in order to aid them in noble causes. As a Goliath, her stone flecked skin has veins of sparkling pink-grey stone running across her body, and her imposing height leaves her towering over all the sapients of the lower lands. She wears a battle-tested mail armor beneath a long robe of hand-spun cloth, bleached nearly which in the sun, with the fur edges still flecked with blood of battles long passed. She bares the sea shell sign of Melora on both a necklace and a set of shells she had added to her bracers.

Aglath grew up in the mountains with his Goliath tribe. From a very young age, he  trained and competed as a remarkable athlete. During the Goliath festivals, he was always known to win the competitions in his age categories. He began playing the Goliath ball game when he was an adolescent, and he quickly rose to be famous among the various tribes as the greatest athlete of his generation.It wasn't just his physical prowess that made him stand out, but also his cunning and natural intelligence. He could always outthink his opponents in addition to being such a powerful natural athlete. This is what made him so exceptional at the Goliath ball game. He was able to quickly adapt his team's tactics to match up against his opponent's and use his team's natural abilities to their advantage.The year that he came of age, his team won the inter-tribal competition marking them as the greatest players in the ten tribes. But what truly made this unique was that there was an ambassador from the Lord's Alliance at the tournament. Tiamat had recently rose, and the Lord's alliance was desperate to find warriors of any kind that could help beat back the Tyranny of Dragons. This ambassador had come to negotiate with the Goliath tribes and bring back warriors to help them fight.When Aglath talked to this officer, he was convinced that he needed to help the Lord's Alliance defend the realm. He and his team all joined with the Lord's Alliance as an elite unit of Goliaths, and he was chosen as the leader. He and his soldiers quickly rose through the ranks and he became a ranking officer. However, now that Aglath had the opportunity to meet with more diverse people from a wide-ranging set of backgrounds, Aglath realized that he was not as intelligent and cunning as he had always thought. Where he had stood out among the Goliath athletes, here he was merely average. Because of this, Aglath has worked hard to be the best soldier that he can, following orders as perfectly as possible and training as much as possible so that he can excel just like he did as a youth.Recently Aglath has received some strange messages from the Goliath tribes. He hasn't seen them in years, but they speak of something strange happening with the Giants and the Ordning, and Aglath decided that he needed to investigate. When he brought this up with his commanding officers, they told him that they couldn't spare an entire unit, but that they would give him a special assignment to investigate and report back.

Keothi was born to clan Nalakigo, the warrior-priest faction of the Black Lightning tribe, a group of goliath that make their home among the peaks of the Stormcrest Mountains. Life in the mountains is subject to various challenges, from dangerous creatures to the terrain itself, including dangerous storms from the nearby Lucian Ocean. As a result, the Black Lightning tribe has paid tribute to Kord for as long as the oral histories can remember. The Stormlord values strength and bravery over all else, but requires the responsible use of that strength. Clan Nalakigo ensures the tribe lives up to these ideals. They fight to protect what is theirs from the various other tribes of kobolds and lizardfolk that also live in the mountains, but trade with the humans, elves, and other humanoid races that make their homes in the more hospitable lower elevations nearby.Keothi was raised, like most children in the tribe, to fight, but as a member of clan Nalakigo, she was also thoroughly schooled in Kord's teachings and the healing arts by her father, Ilikan Steadyhand. She earned her name when she was 18, during a kobold raid on the tribe’s main encampment. Keothi held the door to Kord’s temple alone, swinging her warhammer with deadly accuracy, protecting the sick and wounded inside. As she was swarmed, she felt The Stormlord’s power flow through her for the very first time. With a clap of thunder, she threw several kobolds back from the entrance, dead. The head of clan Nalakigo, Uthal Thundercaller, christened Keothi ‘Stormhammer,’ and she became a fully-fledged member of both clan Nalakigo and the Black Lightning tribe. The Black Lightning tribe owns a relic of Kord: Thunder-Forged, a glass blade made of sand struck by lightning and carried by the head of clan Nalakigo. Six years after Keothi earned her name, she was on the boundaries of the village when another raiding party attacked the tribe. When the attack was over, Uthal Thundercaller was found dead next to a charred corpse, and Thunder-Forged was missing. Manneo Stormchaser, Keothi’s brother, was with Uthal at the time, and was nowhere to be found after the battle. His own greataxe was lying next to the burned body. A search of the area around the village ensued for the assassins and thief, but they and the blade were nowhere to be found. With the threat from the nearby lizardfolk and kobolds and the rumors of the new tribe of goliath revenants spreading from the Ashen Gorge to the south, it was deemed too dangerous to send warriors en masse to search for it. Keothi’s mother, Eglath Lightninghand, was elected the new head of clan Nalakigo and rechristened Thundercaller, as per tradition. Manneo Stormchaser was presumed dead, and the tribe resumed normal life. Clan Nalakigo, however, deemed the missing blade and the murder of two of their members a blight on their honor, and the new Thundercaller sent Keothi Stormhammer to find and recover Thunder-Forged and serve justice for her murdered kin.

The thrill of combat. The shouts of battle. A surge of power. A relationship changed.Soldiers and mercenaries alike caught in an intricate dance of death and carnage. Some peoplejust aren’t very good dancers. I am not one of them. Years of training have made my mindsharp, and my blows deadly.With a single swing of my maul, another foe falls. Perhaps he screamed, I do not know. My mindremained focused on the task at hand. I take in my surroundings. Block left, parry right, swing.Another enemy down. This fight is my dance, and this battlefield my stage.Across the plain I see my brother, as brutish and brutal as always. He is not the most elegantfighter, but he is effective in his work. Hold on… something seems… wrong. His stance is nothow I taught him, nor is it anything I’ve seen him do before. His battleaxe is flailing wildly, thereis a bloodlust in his eyes that I haven’t seen since….Damn, I’ve been hit. I was so focused on my brother, I didn’t even notice the arrow comingtoward me. Another scar, another learned lesson. Swing down, sidestep, uppercut. Two moreout of the way. Two fewer standing between myself and my brother. He needs me. He isn’t inhis right mind. He isn’t following the plan.I start to hear the shouts. Not of the small ones, no. I hear my brother. His words arenonsensical, but his fury is palpable. I can feel it in air, I can smell it on the wind. It’s sickening.Parry, sweep the leg. I’m almost to him now. There are six of them. Hell, two of them aresupposed to be on OUR side. He seems not to care. He barely seems to notice. In one move,all six men fall. I have to stop him. He’s going to get himself killed. This is unacceptable.“Brother… Brother!
