BROTHER!” I shout to him, he seems not to notice. Three more of our menand four of theirs seem to have put aside their differences to take my brother down. Lungeforward. Block right. Turn. Swing. The small ones will not stop me, and they will not stop mybrother. That is something only I can do.The battleground is calm now. Both armies have retreated, which I suppose means we won. Idid not return with the rest. I need to stay and help my brother. He is not well.He finally stirs. I have a hold of him, I must keep him restrained. “YOU WISH TO CHALLENGEME!?” He forces the words out, almost as though he doesn’t know who I am or where he is. Ittakes all of my might to keep him pinned down. “BROTHER,” I shout at him. It seems to work,the rage is leaving his eyes. He tries to tell me he is okay, but I know better. With a firm grip of him, I force him to his feet. “Look at what you have done,” I command him. I know this will not beeasy for him. It is not meant to be easy. It is meant to help him grow.I can see the horror come upon his face. He did not mean for it to go this far. “Brother,” heasks,” what have I become?” I am unsure of what to say. All I can do is look upon him and hopethat I can be strong enough. Strong enough to stand by him, to help him control his fury, to helphim become the best that he can be. I will not turn away, brother, for I am all you have left.

History & Background-	Kidnapped by slavers from his mountain home at the age of 3. He knows his home was near a place called Guathak’s Great Leap (a chasm), which is in the mountains in the top left of the Dunlin map. However, he has little idea where his home might be, as the name is not known by non-Goliaths and there are Goliath settlements all along the northern mountains of the eastern big island. -	After a long journey, he slavers sold him to the brutal slave fighting pits of Dirkheim (central island). Dirkheim is a mostly dwarven city made rich by trade in minerals from the adjacent mountains and as the principal port between the central island and the eastern island. Dirkheim is ruled by the oppressive Black Boulder clan, with the aging Dagmar Bloodbeard at its head.-	The fighting pits are also a major source of income for the clan: huge sums are gambled on the outcomes of big fights, and slave owners from across the islands bring their fighters to compete in the hope of collecting a major purse. The clan takes a cut of all transactions. -	The fighting slaves of Dirkheim live together at the bottom of a huge cavern. None of their rudimentary buildings have roofs or ceilings, and guards monitor all activity from a web of walkways above. Supplies and new slaves are dropped in via a system of moving platforms. These are carefully designed to prevent any escapes.-	Koivu was raised by slaves, and taught to fight by slaves. The majority of other slaves are orcs, goblins, hobbits, and dwarves; they were either enslaved after being convicted of a crime by the Black Boulders, or were born in the slave pits. Other races were highly prized as slave fighters, particularly very large humanoids (firbolgs, goliaths), and elves. All sorts of half-breeds between different races have been born in the slave pits.-	There were three other goliaths in the pits when Koivu first arrived, but these all perished shortly thereafter in the infamous ‘Great Moon Bloodbath’ held to honour Dagmar BloodBeard’s 400th birthday.-	The biggest Dirkheim spectacles involved outnumbered bands of elves against some combination of wild beasts, bezerker dwarves and the large humanoid races. This was naturally a great source of irritation for the elven city states of the western island, and had caused several wars in past decades.-	Koivu fought his first arena match at the age of 10. Matches involving children were a popular family outing in Dirkheim, and (normally) involved blunted weapons.-	Black Boulder tradition demanded that the winner scalp the losers, and these trophies were displayed in the Dirkheim gladiator hall alongside each fighter’s biography. Since many of the slaves knew each other well, they also exchanged a lock of hair prior to every fight. The winner was responsible for both preserving the victim’s hair, and taking over the victim’s own stash of locks. Fighters knew their hair collections intimately, and memorised the name and deeds of each lock’s former owner. A lock collection was generally preserved as a carefully woven rope.-	The other thing of great importance to the slaves was their god, Khush, or ‘the chained god’. Almost all of the slaves prayed to Khush each day, begging for easy work, a merciful driver, a chance at freedom, or even a quick and painless death. Worshippers in Dirkheim generally wore a chain of black iron, with a link for each moon they been enslaved.Koivu developed into a skilled fighter. Given his presence, generosity and natural inclination to fairness, he was also very popular among the other slaves. Under the tutelage of Marmok, a priest of Khush, he became a fervent believer in the need to end slavery across Dunlin.

Standing proudy at 7’11”, Koloi Stormcaller is the chieftain of Boroza, the capital city of the Skeijeh (cloud goliaths) in the Teeth of Maduros.  Optimistic and always eager to lend a helping hand to the less fortunate, she is seen as a great positive force in her city.  Though she places great value in the traditions and customs of her people, she also sees the value in innovation, hoping to help bring the Skeijeh into the modern world.  She always tries to be patient and understanding towards others, but, unfortunately, Koloi is ruled by her emotions.  She can only be pushed so much before she will push back.Like most of the Skeijeh, Koloi has grey skin, slightly pointed ears, and icy bluish grey eyes.  Her wispy teal hair is kept back, for the most part, in a loose braid that just barely reaches her waist.  She has a very basic tattoo of five black dots under her left eye, which she received as part of her induction into the Heralds of the Storm King.  All of Koloi's clothes are woven or knitted from the fleece of the cumulobovus bison.  She sports dark brown woven leggings and a deep purple shirt, though these are rarely visible under her armor.  She wears a thin woven "circlet," dyed orange, an azwood wedding band, and two leather-corded necklaces.  The first necklace is a wooden pendant with the holy emblem of Deneth carved into it: a wheel pierced by a lightning bolt.  The second necklace hold five knuckle bones, also carved, but with intricate patterns of leafy branches covered in chains.  She also carries an azwood walking staff, covered in runes and containing a secret compartment at each end.  This staff is very old, and marks her status as chieftain of Boroza.They say that Koloi was marked for greatness from the moment of her birth. Koloi's mother, Kayen, went into labor right as a fierce summer storm hit. The storm raged for 5 days and 5 nights, all while Kayen struggled. On the dawn of the sixth day, a bolt of lightning struck a tree outside of the house right as Koloi was finally born. The storm lifted, and the shamans of Boroza said that this child received the kiss of Deneth, god of storms. Unfortunately, the labor left Kayen in a weakened state, and, when an illness swept through the village a few months later, she became sick and passed away. Rhudan Brohn, Koloi's father, was captain of the Skyguard (the group of warriors in charge of protecting the settlement and keeping peace) at the time, and his duties prevented him from raising his daughter on his own. Therefore, Sana Handag, Boroza’s head priestess and mother of Kayen, helped to raise the girl. Koloi practically grew up in the shrine, and she sees it almost as a second home. She excelled at the different fighting styles at an early age; that, combined with her devotion to serving Deneth primed her for a spot in the Heralds of the Storm King, a division of the Skyguard who devote themselves to the patron god of Boroza.When Koloi was 21, the previous chieftain, Vastur Cloudsinger turned 55, ending his term as chieftain. She was elected into the position, and she was appointed with the name Stormcaller. Finding Vastur to have a wealth of information and experience with the trade and export of goods from his past days as a merchant, she eventually asked him to help manage finance and trade. This involved making the the two-day journey to Clove Town to exchange bovus wool for necessities like metals and wood. Not many people in Boroza were willing to leave, and his aid meant that Koloi would not have to take one week out of every month to make the trek. However, having never been outside of the Teeth before, Koloi found life in the bustling city fascinating. Twice a year, she would take her husband Mhasad (and, eventually, their son Trell) with her, and they would spend an extra day there to catch up in current events and to purchase gifts for family and themselves.Koloi also made a friend in Clove Town: a Halfling woman named Minnie Greycloak.  The goliath chieftain has a fondness for sweets, and, during her first visit to the city, she managed to stumble across Minnie’s bakery.  The two hit it off immediately, and they have been good friends ever since.  Koloi has even knitted her friend a couple of blankets as gifts, though Minnie could almost use it as a tent due to its size.  She would often keep Koloi up to date with the latest news in town, and it was from Minnie that the chieftain learned of the laws and new technologies being developed in Clove Town.  She realized just how isolated the Skeijeh were, and, from time to time, she would wonder if this isolation were hampering her people's growth.Eight years after beginning her role as chieftain, it was discovered that, somehow, someone had been traveling to the azwood grove in the middle of the night, cutting down eighteen of the sacred trees. Koloi had known that something was wrong, for the past three nights, she had frightening dreams of being ripped apart by a beast. She formed a small scouting party, telling no one but her grandmother and her husband, and they took watch that night within the grove, in case the culprits returned.It was not long before a group of men and women appeared, saws and axes at the ready, ready to cut down the azwoods. The warriors confronted these loggers, telling them that they had no right to take what isn't theirs. A fight broke out, but these trespassers underestimated the skills of the Skyguard, and they were quickly slain. Koloi and her team found an encampment about a mile away in a small cave. Stashed there were the azwood logs, as well as a contract between some official named Drukhmoor and the former chieftain, Vastur Cloudsinger.After reviewing the evidence, the Council found the former chieftain guilty of desecration. Stripped of all names and titles, Vastur was Exiled.  During his execution, he claimed that all he had done, he had done for his people.  He said that their way of life was growing stagnant, and that they need to change to adapt to the new world.  His arguments, however, fell on deaf ears, and, with one swift strike of her sword, he was silenced forever.  Koloi now has five of his knuckle bones on a string around her neck. His body was not given a sky burial, as is the custom of the Skeijeh; instead, it was chained to the bottom of a pit and covered with heavy stones, never to reach the skies.An emergency council meeting was called. The azwoods were the source of power feeding the Azure Ward, the barrier responsible for protecting outsiders from entering Boroza.  That power was waning. The people were at a loss; what could they do to fix this?After many arguments (and one cracked table), Koloi proposed that they should try to cultivate the holy trees, in order to increase the barrier's power back to full strength.  There had been rumors of azwood saplings appearing where none existed ever before: one on an island with sandless shores, another in the middle of a sweltering jungle, and the last at the base of a mountain with the face of an elderly man.  According to the old stories, these trees could be sought out, and their cultivation process could be determined.  Some council members thought that this was a foolish task; it could be considered blasphemous if they tried to replicate a gift of the gods.  Others thought that it would not work, because, even if they did manage to grow new azwoods, they may not contain the power that would be required to maintain the Azure Ward.  The journey would be for nothing.Koloi told the Council that, if these actions offended Deneth, he would let her know.  And, if this plan does not work, then they must change their way of life.  Though his actions were reprehensible, the Exiled was right about one thing: they have been all too willing to cut themselves off from the outside world for too long.  There had been an increase in the emigration of young Skyeh from the Teeth.  More and more of their people grow curious of the outside world, a world that they choose not to acknowledge.  This ignorance, Koloi said, will be their downfall.  Koloi offered to take on this task herself, as it was her duty as chieftain to protect her people (and since nearly everyone else was too afraid of the outside world to leave). She appointed two interim chieftains to take care of Boroza in her absence, and, after a few days of preparation, she and the two temporary leaders set off towards Clove Town, so that she could introduce them to the trading contacts.  Head Priestess Sana promised that she would keep in contact with Koloi from time to time, to give her updates on the village and to check in with her.A successful trade contract drawn up, Koloi parted ways with the two chieftains.  She returned to her favorite inn, the one where she always stayed in Clove Town.  During dinner, she struck up a conversation with a sweet little gnome named Wrenn.  Intrigued by his tinkering skills, she offered to introduce him to her husband Mhasad one day, as the two of them would get along wonderfully.  Wrenn seemed delighted, and did not mind that it would be a while before Koloi could do so.  After talking late into the evening, they both finally retired to their separate rooms at the inn.That night, Koloi was attacked by an assassin in her room. The killer was no match for the towering goliath, and, in self-defense, she killed the man. Guards came, and she told them all that had happened. They accepted her story and moved on. However, when morning came, she awoke to no less than ten guards placing her in chains, claiming that she was guilty of murder. When asked who made this claim, they showed her the official warrant, signed by one Ezekiel Drukhmoor.  The Stormcaller felt her rage swell within her, and the last thing she could remember was strangling some poor soldier before a sharp blow to the back of her head knocked her unconscious.

Allora is the daughter of a well-off merchant and his upper-crust bride.  While her father Elan came from humble beginnings and earned his success through cleverness and a discerning eye for superior merchandise, her mother Idris is from a long line of grey elf aristocrats.  Allora has many fond memories of her time spent traveling with her father as a child, and just as many memories of moments when her mother has been overbearing in their extravagant home in the mountains.	Idris is a high-strung woman with overwhelming expectations and a strong sense of propriety and elitism.  Her marriage to Elan was largely to replenish her family’s dwindling coffers, although Elan worshipped the ground she walked upon.  Allora is their only child, and has been burdened by the heavy weight of her mother’s expectations since birth.  Idris’ preoccupation with high society gossip is only rivaled by her fascination with magic.  When Allora demonstrated magical aptitude, Idris insisted that she attend a college for warmages so that she might use her talents to serve their kingdom. 	Allora was certainly a gifted student of the arcane arts, and her sharp mind made up for her frail frame and relative ineptitude with weapons.  Despite Allora’s talent, Idris’ influence indirectly prevented Allora from serving in the royal military.  While Allora was a student, Idris made a staggering number of donations to the college.  Upon graduation the college was loath to put a cash cow onto the field lest she die in battle and her parents stop donating, and they instead employed Allora as a liaison between the college and the temple of Raygus.  	Allora has served in her position at the temple for many decades now, her position requiring her to perform various odd jobs, including recruitment for the college.  While she has practiced her magic and studied diligently to keep her skills sharp, she has had very little experience using them in combat.  Despite her mother’s disappointment in where her career has led, she is rather proud of representing the warmage college.  Despite her complacency with her career, she has been very driven to learn in her private time, and while many of her studies revolve around the arcane and history, they have also grown in scale to include nature and religion.	Allora’s family on her father’s side largely consists of farmers, and they are all devoted followers of Largus.  Her father instilled his love and reverence of the natural world in his child from an early age.  Allora has spent over a century as a zealous patron of the temple of Largus, and her passion for her god has forged strong connections between Allora and some of the temple staff.  Her cold and critical personality seems to be partially shelved when dealing with like-minded devotees, and many of the priests have found that they can look past her somewhat insufferable personality when she becomes engrossed in her religion. 	Her most reliable ally is Bernard, a favored soul in the service of Largus that hails from the same farming community that her father grew up in.  While Bernard is closer to Allora’s age than her father’s, he developed a steadfast friendship with Elan while he was alive.  After Elan’s passing, Bernard became Allora’s closest confidant.  He has guided her in study and prayer for many years, and Allora has developed a combination of admiration and affection for him.  Bernard has also become fond of Allora, although he does not return her romantic interest.  	Elan was killed by bandits on the road home when Allora was 150.  35 years later, she still feels the ache of her loss every day.  Idris has re-married an aristocrat, and she remains as dominating and withholding as ever.  Very rarely can Allora see her mother without hearing about her disappointment, so she makes it a point to avoid her on a day-to-day basis, though she still feels obligated to remain available to her mother.	Allora lives alone in a modest home and divides most of her time between work and the temple of Largus.  While her home is not overly grand, it is well protected from thieves, as she has a hefty sum of goods and funds from her father’s passing stashed away in a magically-protected, locked trunk hidden under her floor, the door completely unnoticeable beneath a fine rug.  She keeps two different keys to it, the first key tucked away in a tiny pocket with a snap that sits on the inside of her breeches and the second buried beneath a bush behind her home.	Allora has left her hometown several times to perform duties for the temple of Raygus or the college, but always returns to her relatively mundane life.  It is hard to say whether that is because of her affection for Bernard, her place in the temple of Largus, or her sense of duty to the college and her mother.

Hazel was born in the southern region of the world of Yun Ast, which had emerged from a harrowing age known as The Long Dark less than a century ago. Her family grew tea on the slopes of a small mountain, and Hazel learned the art of brewing tea at an early age. When she was five, her family left their tea farm and moved far up north, to the sleepy village of Iremur - and they never told her why. Bitter about leaving a place she loved behind, and never really feeling at home in Iremur, Hazel grew up into a teenager with little respect for the property of others, a distrust of adults, and a plan to go back home; back to the tea farm. She doesn't quite know how to get there, but when her friends set off on an adventure, seeking answers to why monsters now roam the woods in numbers unseen since the Long Dark, she tags along. Adventures are fun and profitable, and if she can save the world while she's building up enough of a fortune to pay her way back to the tea farm, well - that's no bad thing.

LyKitina Adventure LogWell that's my name, I will make it a great one!I guess I should start at the beginning, huh?  Well here it goes.I was found by my parents when I was but a bare kit.  They were heading into town on the main road when they rounded a blind corner and came across the remnants of brigands' ambush.  There was very little other than trash remaining of the 2 wagons that had been attacked.  The wagons themselves had been flipped over and burned.  Everything they carried had been torn, shredded and scattered beyond repair or retrieval.   It was an abandoned battle zone at best.  As they stood there gaping at the proof of the dangers of the road they heard a small cry from below the biggest wagon.  Working together they were able to use their team of horses to right the wagon, despite it's size.  As they did so they saw a flash of light, the final breaking of a protection ward.  As it did so the crying got louder, hey I was hungry!  Needless to say they retrieved me and decided the only thing to do was to bring me home with them.  They didn't have children of their own you see, as their only son had died of Scarlet Fever the winter before.  I was their hope and turned into the child they no longer had.  I have no complaints.  They totally ignored the fact that I was a different race, and did not tolerate anyone around me who had issues with it either.  So all in all, I had a great childhood.  We were not rich in mortal treasures, but everything else was readily available at all times.  That ranged from hugs of encouragement, chores, and blessings.  I grew up on a ranch, at the foothills of the mountains.  We had animals of all types, as we firmly believed that as long as we took care of nature, it would continue to take care of us.Three years ago, I found my own foundling, kind of anyway.  On the way into the City on a trade run, I heard hollers for help ahead of me.  I took off expecting to finally deal with some of the brigands that were known, (personally) to haunt the road.  Turns out I was right and wrong.  It wasn't a brigand, thief or rouge.  It wasn't even gang of them.  It was a Tiger that was attacking the small family.  Now this tiger wasn't exactly fat, but was the largest one I'd ever seen.  She was fierce in her attacks, the family was loud with their screams.  Even when I joined in the attack, she refused to run.  She was that desperate.  Now I may look quite a bit like a cat, but that doesn't mean I condone unethical attacks on anyone.  Not only that, but she was not of my race.  She was just a wild and crazy animal.  I had to put her down for the safety of everyone.  I did so and was thanked repeatedly by the family I rescued as I continued to check out my kill.I was able to find the causes of the attack.  When I passed it on, they too agreed it was a shame to have to kill such a majestic creature in self defense.  First she was injured.  She had a piece of an old trap pierced through her hind foot.  It was old, rusty and very infected.  She could hardly walk, much less hunt for herself.  That was why she had hunted the only prey that couldn't outrun her.  The weaklings on the road.Second and of more immediate concern, she was a nursing mother.  Somewhere there was at least a cub that was not going to get dinner at best, at worst it could become dinner to anything that wanted one without it's mother to defend it against the predators that abounded in the area.  I knew I couldn't let either of those things happen.  I tracked her back to her lair, and found the only cub left of a litter of 3.  They were all skin and bones so there was no doubt about what had killed the other 2.  He was hiding under the bodies of his litter mates, trying to stay warm with their cooling corps.  It was sad.  I managed to coax him out from under the stack with some fresh rabbit that I'd caught while tracking his mama back to him.  He crawled his way out on his belly, barely strong enough to cry and to smart to make enough noise to scare the rabbit away.  I crooned encouragingly to him the entire time.  I made a friend that day.  I named him Lyger as from the beginning he was determined to grow into his appetite.  He never stopped eating and growing for years it seemed.  He is definitely one of the largest of his race I've ever seen.  He has grown rapidly and earns his own keep now by guarding the ranch well.  He has always been a loyal friend to me. I trained him just like the war-cats that protect the nearest village.  He earns his keep, no matter where he goes.  He has been a great friend since I carried him home as well.  I sure needed one too.Together we are leaving in the morning.  I always knew I would be leaving to find my own way around the world.  So did my parents, they are wise about things like that.  That was why they made sure I have the skills I needed to do so.  I know how to cook, I know how to clean.  I know how to mend my gear.  I know how to trade, I know how to talk to others, even though in general I prefer not to.  None of that was hard to learn as I always loved spending time with my parents as they did all of those things routinely.  That is hand on learning that I like the most.I've always had a knack for working with animals especially.  My parents have encouraged me to go and discover the world for myself.  They want me to try and find my people at least.  I am always welcome back, but they are well aware of the fact that the horizon I can't see yet, is where I want to go next.  It is time to start my story.  I promised them it would be a great one, and they promised to read it. _Oracle CurseI was communing with nature again as my teacher kept harping on when I heard screaming coming from over the hill.  I took off and found a small family fighting against a large pack of wolves.  They were not doing well against them at all.  As soon as I showed up  they all turned on me like they had been waiting on me alone.  They totally ignored the others as soon as they could and seemed to get stronger the longer they fought me.

Half drow bard. Abandoned by one of his parents by the side of a busy road, he was picked up by a bounty hunter that took pity on the infant and took him in as a younger brother. The two traveled constantly due to his work, and Izzy often found himself in taverns, sneaking to watch the bards play. He was facinated by them, and wanted to be one, so his brother found him a lute and Izzy tried learning to play by himself - and he did a poor job until a minstrel found his playing to be a crime against music itself and taught him the basics.Izzy took off on his own upon reaching adulthood, as he knew his brother's rotation and how to find him again shoukd he want to return to him, and was courted by a rich couple, but it soon became evident that while the husband's desire for another lover was genuine, the wife wanted to keep him as more of an exotic drow pet. He parted way with them quickly, but kept the pendant of his goddess he had recieved as a gift from the husband as a token of affection.

Character's race (human, elf, dwarf, etc: Half dwarf, half elf/orc (don't question it)
Character's backstory: They were raised on a spider farm where for generations their family has collected webs  from their spider livestock and sold to other companies, such as a vineyard to fake the ages of their wines and to seamsters who weave their own thread.
Soldier
run away from rich family due to pyromania
Prince of a fallen kingdom, now works as a mercenary and treasure Hunter with his muscles and psudeo-brother, alphonz
Discriminated against by her racist, rich human family. She is going on a quest to prove herself to them.
Burglar. Betrayed by master thief "The Harrow" and captured while robbing a lord's manor, Elolin will stop at nothing to gain vengeance against those that ruined her life.
Was a leatherworker for a lord until that lord killed his kids. Now he is on a new continent to find friends and get stronger to avenge his kids.
In the person or knowledge the stumbled across "forbidden" knowledge that the elders of her tribe wanted to keep under wraps. She thought this was excellent and stole the lot and ran off with it.

Felix is the son of a powerful merchant, trained from birth to take over his fathers empire, until he had a mental breakdown. He fled his home, leaving behind his wife and daughters, now working as a charlatan and occasional pimp.

Was a petty theif in a big family, in a big city but was shit at it, got caught and branded. Escaped sharpish and then became an enchanter along the way. Joined up with a half orc and got on really well

Shunned by both Elves and Humans, Aramil lives a solitary life in the wilderness outside the city of Everlund. He is often hired by farmers to hunt animals that threaten their crops and herds. Occasionally he is hired to hunt more sentient creatures, but it's just another job to him.

Sent away from home young because she had magical abilities and a fire spared her but consumed her home. She was found sleeping in the wreckage and sent to a wizarding school. She learned of her draconic ancestry late, and her duel-nature and lack of wizarding skill then made much more sense. She left school and became a spell-sword.

Raised by wolves, Veda understands the tattoos all over her body and when she comes of age she follows a map on her thigh to find an alchemist kit in a cave and makes powerful bombs and potions. Unfortunately life in the civilized world causes her to turn to drinking and she abuses those potions, making stronger and stronger formulas to get a fix. She joins a band of wanderers and is an indispensable if not unstable/volitile  part of the group.

Offdir comes from the proud and renowned Branespout, most well known for their brewery and swathes of farmland. At the tender age of 15 Offdir's father sent him off to adventure and create his own legacy - unbeknownst to him, he had actually been sent to a summer "adventure camp". Once the summer had ended the camp councillors (who played the goblins) revealed this to him, making Offdir swear to abandon his family and forgo any money or possessions, and to live in a temple as a monk.

Naeris has ventured up and down the Sword Coast in search of opportunities to learn and gather knowledge of magic and the Weave. He has ventured from Waterdeep, where he picked up a brief understanding of magic and enough control over the Weave to be able to perform his first cantrip, down to the sequestered and magic infused land of Halruaa, and most recently on the hunt for a tome to dedicate to the library of Candlekeep in order to gain access to its boundless troves of knowledge.With news of the giants surfacing and plaguing the Sword Coast, Naeris is afraid that their mayhem could not only ruin his home city, but also spread farther south, eventually reaching Candlekeep.

JOURNAL ENTRIES(Al ”Derek” Thornstrike)I am writing this now to help straighten out what I know and am learning into a logical fashion.  My story  is one of  bizarre coincidences to be sure.  First off my family’s legacy of a magical bow is mine without any instructions.  I know my elven relatives are quite affronted by my  mother’s temerity in naming me as the bearer of the bow.  I know that it has a long and involved history, even if I don’t know what that is.   It is a family heirloom.  The one obvious thing that it does is magically create it’s own arrows.  I know it glows sometimes but I haven’t decided if it glows around danger or evil, to me or it.  My teacher I think knows more but chooses not to tell me for promises to my parents who were great friends of hers.  I know that she decided to take me on out of friendship for them and I think, regret that she was not there to help when they needed it most.  My parents were well known as hero’s and adventurers even while they  were shunned for being together and even more after I was born.  They didn’t care what their families and friends thought, they belonged together and that was that.  The 2 of them together were a sight to see, you could easily visualize their connection.  When father died at the hands of some undead minions, mother knew right away.   He had been guiding a group into a new settlement area that was supposedly safe.  The only reason mother wasn't with him was because she was working closely with a wizard friend on a secret spell against the undead.  Later, after she finished the research she went after his killers.   Although she took down the undead that killed him, she fell into depression and faded away.  There was nothing I could do to help.  I had to watch her slowly die.  I found out later that the research she completed after father died she paid for literally with her soul.  Once her quest for vengeance was over, she had to pay the price.  That is why I know that the undead killed both my parents.  I have hated and hunted them since.  I still don't know exactly what the spell was that she sold her soul for, she  just said that the success would help me and my children against the undead.  Then she named me as the next bearer of the Family Bow of Infinate Arrows.  Only one member from her family attended her funeral and the only reason he came was to pick up the Bow.  He was furious when he found out that she had passed it on to me in front of witnesses even he couldn't discredit.  He never said a word to me just insisted that upon my death the family had the right to the Bow.  I will pass it on to someone who is worthy, for I know that is what she would have wanted.

As the child of an illicit tryst between a human hunter and an elf from a highly closed and xenophobic forest community, Sovan’s only connection with his elven father was an amulet with a symbol of darkened moon and a letter apologizing for sending him away. He lived in the city with his mother until he was six years old, at which point she died suddenly and tragically, leaving him alone in the world. Sovan was entirely unequipped to fend for himself on the streets, surviving more by luck than skill. He was on the edge of starvation, too faint from hunger even to look for food, when a green dragonborn child approached him in an alley and offered him a sticky bun. Suspicious, but too hungry to say no, he let her approach, and ate the bun.When she realised how desperate he was, the child offered to bring him more food the next day, and over time, Sovan and Fær became close friends. She snuck food to him whenever she could, and protected him when the older urchin children would try to steal from him or beat him up. With Fær’s friendship and protection, Sovan had a fairly happy childhood, despite his circumstances. They played together almost every day, and Sovan made up games for them and sang her songs he invented.When he got a bit older, Sovan eked out a meager living singing at low class taverns. He knew he was talented enough to do better, but no one would take him seriously due to his lack of social connections and generally shabby appearance. He was desperately jealous of more successful bards, especially the well-known and well-loved Tütz Malüts.Sovan’s big break came from a surprising source. When Fær and Sapphira got married, Sovan’s wedding gift to them was an original song, written in the style of traditional dragonborn love ballads and performed at the wedding in flawless draconic, which he learned for the purpose. Sapphira’s family connections meant that the wedding was overflowing with wealthy dragonborn elite, who were equally charmed by Sovan’s talent and the novelty of a half-elf performing draconic music.From that point on, Sovan’s life improved immeasurably. Sovan became a highly desired performer at high class dragonborn events, and the head of the Bella Cuprica clan (Sapphira’s extremely rich and important family) took credit for “discovering” him and became his patron.A few months later, Sovan decided to write a song about Sapphira and Fær’s honeymoon trip to Silanya. He started researching the new continent, conducting interviews with sailors who worked on the ships that traveled back and forth between the continents. A particularly successful interview resulted in Sovan being invited back to her berth, and a misunderstanding of the ship’s schedule resulted in him oversleeping and still being aboard when the ship cast off for Silanya.During his accidental journey, Sovan forged close friendships with most of the crew, and planned to make a short visit to Sila to see his friends and the town before re-boarding the ship and traveling home with them. However, a massive storm destroyed the ship just before it reached Silanya. Sovan managed to swim to shore on a piece of flotsam, but nearly everyone else drowned, and Sovan was sufficiently traumatized to swear off boats for the foreseeable future.Now that he was trapped in Silanya, Sovan basically thought “Well, I’m here anyway, may as well have an adventure” and joined the guild.

Sydna is a former sister-scholar of an order of Oghma and as such had devoted her life to knowledge and understanding the arcane. In the kingdom where her order resided, a lord and his order of knights demanded the secret knowledge the sisterhood retained regarding neighboring factions. To the angered disappointment of the lord, the sisters refused to get involved and locked away any books or scrolls relevant to what the knights were searching for. Weeks later, on a fall night, Sydna awoke to screams and metal footsteps. The knights had broken into the compound and began ransacking and slaughtering the sisterhood. Sydna ran to her mentors room where she was already ushering in some of the younger sisters into a secret passage. As Sydna was the last to crouch into the passage, her mentor gave her a book of gods before sealing the entrance with her on the other side. Sydna rushed down the passage, as she heard the sounds of swords penetrating flesh echoing behind her. Once she caught up to the few remaining sisters of her order, they exited the passage well outside of the complex but much to their dismay, they turned to see what was once their home ablaze with knights riding about rounding up any survivors. The other sisters decided the best course of action would be to move with the cover of night and head towards a neighboring nation with a known sisterhood of Oghma. Sydna however could not ignore a growing pain and anger in her heart and so she opened her gift from her late mentor and frantically scanned the pages for a suitable god to call upon (as clearly she felt betrayed by Oghma for letting this happen). Her mind felt ashamed but her heart and eyes could not be pulled away from the entry on Shar, The Mistress of the Night and Lady of Loss. She called upon the goddess to smite the knights and lord that had caused her such pain and much to her dismay, the Mistress obliged. Sydna only remembers through her tears and sobs, a dark figure approaching her, wiping the drops off her face and asking "do you promise to serve me? To seek vengeance against all who oppose me?" And in her heart she replied yes. Shar entered Sydna then and began to lay waste to the remaining knights who had not returned to their castle, silent as a shadow and deadly as a storm. At dawn, Sydna awoke in the rubble of her fallen order, charred bodies she recognized and mutilated armored bodies she did not, lay about her in the destruction. Looking over her body, with new power coursing through her veins, she recognized Infernal script written all about her torso and upper arms. They state repeatedly "I serve the night mother, I wield the shadow weave, and I will have my vengeance". Looking out past the destruction, once again she saw the shadowy cloaked woman, but this time a large armor clad devil stood beside her. The devils form dissipated into shadowy smoke with hellfire burning throughout and rushed through Sydnas body. "You are now bound in service to me, you will offer your accomplishments to me, and seek out the Order of the Dark Moon for greater truth and power" spoke the lady, at which point she vanished. Sydna searched through the rubble for her mentor and retrieved a necklace to her former patron Oghma, in honor of her past. As she lit ceremonial incense for safe passing of her mentors soul, her body began to burn into black smoke. Sydna does not know if her mentors spirit passed on to Oghma through her ceremonial rites, or if she had damned her to servitude to Shar, but as such Sydna now offers souls to the god that she once knew, and the goddess she's now bound to and let's the dead settle their disputes. With no where to go nor anyone to turn to (as Sydna knows nothing of her past other than she was an orphan who was taken in by the sisterhood) she ventured out in hopes of finding the Order of the Dark Moon to obtain enough power to destroy the kingdom that wronged her and took away the only family she knew.

Memoirs (SASCHA TREEBURN )I figured I'd better start writing down my story or no one would ever believe me when I get older, not even me.  I guess I should start at the beginning.  My name is Sascha Treeburn and I am a fighter primarily.  I also discovered that I have a small talent for magic as well.  My village was destroyed when I was a toddler but I was rescued by the Forrest Witch that lived nearby.  She said that the animals came crying to her saying that the evil one had come to destroy the peaceful village that legend said a defiant one would arise from that would be his undoing.  To keep this from happening he sent an entire army to utterly destroy the village and every man, woman and child in it.  He has a reward out for the head's of all who were from there as well.  Me, he does not know of as everyone believes me to be the bastard daughter of the witch and a spell entranced knight.  That lie was spread for my safety.  I do not believe I am the one foreseen to cause his destruction, but I will take him down given half a chance.  His name is Nikeal Angrenian and after all he has done he deserves to die and I hope I can help him on his journey to hell.  My mother, yes mother for she has raised me, told me I needed to go and find my niche for myself. "I have traveled long and far to find my home, the spot that is my own.  The journey was only as important as the knowledge gained from it.  This is the home I found, the life I chose, now you must do the same."   Then she went to an old, ancient tree and said a spell or perhaps a prayer of some sort, the tree started to burn with a strange, magic fire and then it was consumed from the flames and in it's place was an ordinary looking bag.  She picked it up and opened it.  She put her whole arm in it and pulled out a round object, kinda the shape of a plate w/o the center.  It has a reddish tinge to it.  Even then I could tell there was something special about it.  "This is from my family, it is a chakram of fire and has saved me many times.  You are the true daughter of my heart if not my body.  To you I give this and a small bag of holding stocked with what you need to start your journey.  It is the same thing which my mother gave me and one day you will pass it on to your child.  When the time comes and your journey ends it will once again become the tree of burning for disguise and protection.  So walk this world with pride and no regrets Sascha TreeBurn, it is waiting for you to make your changes.  Do not waste your time or attention on fools or idiots, save it for those who are worthy, judge not from appearance but from heart which is where true treasure lies.”Since then I have traveled far and learned alot.  I have discovered that I have within me the ability to do magic.  I am learning more every day.  I have learned and earned a familiar, his name is Copper and he is a weasel.  His mere presence makes me feel stronger.  I can see thru his eyes as if we are one.  I can read his emotions, what there is of them.  The more he is around the stronger our bond is.   Copper’s personality is becoming more defined as time goes on as well.  I am trying to teach him to detect traps, magical items, and gems.  He is figuring it out more and more.  He is very mischeivous as well as curious.  He is always finding something interesting and bringing it back to me.  A couple of times he has brought me jewelry he obviously just dug up.  Nothing magical unfortunately but worth something when I cleaned it up and sold it as costume jewelry.I found  ”FlameHeart” a greater sword of Fire, this is the sword that I carry now.  Of course, I carry my family Chakram of Fire as well as a long bow.  The spells I have learned are few, but very useful.  I’ve picked up a few other things as well.It was weird I could have sworn I was sitting at camp, getting ready to roll up in my bedroll and then with out any warning I was standing in a road in a field.  There were 2 others there, the one I recognized was one-twoly, a large human.  The other was someone I’d never seen before, a dwarf who introduced himself as Da Morgan, he appears to be a cleric.  We decided to head towards the mountain in the distance.  It took all day but we found a cave entrance and decided to do some exploring.  We went down the passage and came across a large room that looked like a temple.  In the center there was a shield and a hammer. one-twoly picked up the shield and it transformed to look like a pair of  bracers.  No one could lift the hammer and so we left it.  We found three boxes on a shelf in the back of the alter.  We each took one and opened them.  Mine had a copper headband that I decided to wear.  I put the box in my bag and continued to look for further treasure.  Copper found a hidden passageway and there was an alchemist’s lab at the end of it.  There was a shelf of extremely rare spell componets that I took all of and another of potions that I stocked up on.  We found another room that was full all kinds of things.  I found a magical elven thin blade, some boots, a set of bracers, 2 bracelets, a necklace and 8 rings to wear.  I put a bunch of other stuff in my bag.  I keep seeing the same design on all of this stuff and I think it is a forge mark of some kind, this stuff looks like masterwork quality stuff.  Copper found enough bracelets to entirely cover his body.  He looks kinda cute, like a weasel ready for battle.  The guys got weapons that actually talk to them.  My sword doesn’t talk, at least it hasn’t yet.  Copper led us to another room that had a bunch of switches in it.  We finally got them turned to the right combo and 4 doors opened off another big room.  We decided to take a break before when any further.  There was nothing else of interest in the caves.  It took awhile but we made it to town and each decided that even though it had been profitable, it was time to make our own way.

Born the third child, and first son of Seraphina and Brinyold Fev’rton (II), Brinyold found much of his life planned out for him from the very beginning. His parents were the front-runners of what had quickly become a household name. Using their combined knowledge of craft and magic, they specialised in producing many enchanted goods for common folk, introducing a little bit of magic into the household lives of those that would probably never see it otherwise, aiming to make general living and labour just a touch easier, and more interesting. With his wife’s encouragement, they also branched out to creating armour, which also boomed, becoming a well-known name for many militia, and many soldiers can boast that their lives were saved by the plate mail bearing the Fevr’ton family crest. However, the happy couple has both agreed to never use their company resources for any objects that may be used in battle, a fact that Seraphina told her first son many times over. Brinyold was raised to be the heir of such a company. A large task, considering its booming popularity. He looked up to his two older sisters, Lilith and Dimetra, and though he believed that either one of them would be better suited to the task, the role was given to him. His father was a kind man, but rather old fashioned in his views, believing that a male heir would benefit the company more.  So, Brinyold was kept indoors to study, while he watched his sisters longingly, watching them both become people he admired greatly, and had a strong relationship with. He was close to his parents, and took to his studies without complaint, realising that a person who feels sick at the thought of going outside and getting muddy has no place in the adventuring lifestyle that his siblings had found themselves in. So he stuck to it, growing into a fine young man that friends of the company admired and saw much potential in, despite seeing him so rarely. On the cusp of adulthood, however, his mother fell ill. An illness that not even the most divine clerics could identify, and sadly, she succumbed to it, dying in her sleep surrounded by family. Brinyold and his sisters, now older and in their own positions of power (Lilith a respected arch mage, and Dimetra the head of militia, both situated in one of the largest cities on the continent), mourned the loss of their mother, a who was a kind and understanding women that all three had a close bond to. Their father, however, had taken a cold turn. Not long after the passing of their mother, and almost immediately after Brinyold’s sisters returned to their city, he had found himself a new spouse. A fellow Moon Elf, Aravae. Within the span of just under a year, they had married, and had their first child; a full Elven blooded son, which threw Brinyold’s life into a spiral. Addressed with a cold demeanour, the news was broken to Brinyold that a full elven heir would be a far better suitor for head of the family name. So in a flash, Brinyold’s rights were revoked, handed to a half-brother that Brinyold had never bothered to remember the name of.Harbouring a resentment towards his new step mother, and a sense of betrayal towards his father, Brinyold took his first independent step. He decided to leave. …Or, he tried to. It took many attempts to gather the courage to go outside, so he started small. A trip into the garden, a walk through the marketplace. Eventually he built himself up enough courage to be able to go outside without too much of an issue. Touching people without his gloves was still out of the question, and dirt of his boots still caused discomfort, but it was as good as it was going to get. This delay worked in his favour, however. Despite his mother’s promises, Brinyold heard via trusted servants that Aravae had plans to change the company. They would start building weapons, and that plans for new, deadlier weapons were in progress. Wanting the Fevr’ton name to have no part in this bloodshed, for his mother’s sake, he started planning.He played it casual. Now that he was no longer heir, he had nothing stopping him from going on his own travels, as he put it, though there were many who questioned if he had what it took, including Brinyold himself. But nevertheless, after a number of attempts, he found himself working up enough courage to pack what he needed, and set out on his own, out of the city. But, not before running one last errand. He made a trip into the city’s slums, and eventually, into its’ crime circle, and, despite the ridicule, he was able to find the man he needed for the job. He hired a rogue, famous for his silence and quick hands, and ordered him to steal these weapon blueprints, replacing them with altered copies. At first glance, they appeared the same, but the calculations on the forgery were nonsense. The rogue returned to Brinyold the next night, blueprints in hand. He paid the rogue handsomely for a job very well done, and set out of the city, hiring a carriage to take him to the nearest town. Blueprints in hand, and Aravae’s plans to change the company taken back a few notches, he set out on his journey. Arriving in the next town, it clicked now how widespread his family’s name was. Armed with just his belongings, weapon blueprints, and a silver tongue, he realised that the Fevr’ton name was rather well known, and he felt a melancholy feeling in his heart whenever he saw the family crest on items his mother had a hand in creating. Determined to make good use of this head start he’d given himself, he got to work. Using his family name, he gained access to many a library and laboratory in this new town, studying these blueprints intensely and tinkering when he could. Progress was slow, initially, but after a while, he found himself passionate about the craft. Oil on his hands no longer made him sick, and it clicked that he only felt this way about things that he loved dearly and was passionate about, things he no longer saw as gross. Before now, that honour was only held by his sisters and mother. But once he stopped being afraid to get his hands a little oily, progress quickened, and before long, he was able to fill in the blanks of this blueprint, creating the first firearm. However, making it proved to be the easy part. Making it /functional/ took far longer, but after many months of challenging work, experimenting with triggers, and ammunition, he finally did it, putting a smoking hole in a barrel a good foot lower than the bottle he was aiming for. Even with this success, he kept working. Figuring out the fastest ways to reload, how to keep the hand steady when firing, the best stance to take, and so forth. He kept his creations a secret, as if word of a weapon like this found the ears of his family back home, there would be hell to pay. He’d created the first firearm, and had a head start, but this head start was short lived. While he continued to create, and experiment, word reached this town of new, dangerous weapons being distributed by the Fevr’tons. The production of such weapons was set back, sure, but having many experts on tinkering at their disposal, it didn’t take them long to overcome the hurdle Brinyold had set for them. He still had a head start though, and Brinyold planned on utilising it. He still had a weapon unique to him, and he aimed to use it to take back the company that’s rightfully his, and bring it back to the peaceful glory that his mother had envisioned for it.
Soldier, ex-Flaming Fist Mercenary, Warpriest of Tempus
He's a half orc mercenary captain that loves to paint.
A trained chef turned warlock after unknowingly forming a pact with a demon of gluttony. He constantly travels to find new ingredients and dishes in order to satiate his patrons never ending hunger.

Rhollo and his two brothers grew up together and, as brothers do, became very competitive. As sons of the tribes best blacksmith, they first began there, trying to one up each other on quality and appeal of their creations. After nearing adulthood, they set off together on their own ship to begin their adventure. Their favorite pastime was stealing from pirates, because if they didn't earn that loot then they didn't deserve it. A little hypocritical on their part but it's whatever. It didn't take long before their competitive itch needed to be scratched. They all agreed to get their own ships with their own crews and See who would have the best adventures!

Raised in isolation by a former adventurer mage.  The mage's adventuring party was going to leave Onsul for dead after clearing out a tribe of orcs from some ruins near Phandalin.The mage took him in and left off adventure to raise Onsul.Despite his lack of natural talent Onsul tried and tried to make it as a wizard's apprentice.  He would have made a much more gifted warrior but his pride demands nothing less than mastery of wizardry.His "father" Eirik as an adventurer had been raised from death, so the curse has affected him.  Now Onsul seeks to break the curse and save the only family he knows by learning about the curse and stopping it for good.

Gharsh is a paladin of Erastil, the god of hunting. He went on a hunt once with a fellow Erastil worshipper who turned out to be an anti paladin. Once Gharsh had proved himself a worthy foe, Landry the anti paladin hunted him down and cut his leg off. Now Gharsh uses a mechanical leg he barely understands as he tries to help small communities in the face of organised crime.

Derek was born to a Elven mage who's husband had died an adventurer. He had sent back enough money to ensure she'd never want for anything. Except companionship. The form of which came from a mysterious man who made his home deep in the nearby swamp, calling himself a traveling mage the two met in the town market and eventually had an affair of which Derek was the result. Sadly his mother fell ill while he was still little and eventually passed, leaving her small home on the edge of the swamp to her son. Derek never knew his father, and lived on the streets as no one wished to take in the obviously tainted child as his tail and scales marked him as and outsider in the closed community of elves.His own natural talents with magic manifested themselves early and he ended up in the care of an elderly mage and then passed off to one of the mages fellows who took the child on adventures and taught him the ways of sorcery as it came naturally to him since Magic quite literally resided in his blood. Eventually Derek returned him as a youth and spent no time at all getting into trouble with the locals and making a nuisance of himself with his friend and often times lover, Lyandria.

Born to Joscelina Nenlaer, the favorite daughter of the prominent Waterdhavian merchant Markus Nenlaer, Alunira’s childhood was quite different from that of other children in merchant Houses.  Her mother had developed rebellious tendencies in her early teens, coupled with a streak of wanderlust.  This dangerous combination led to Joscelina’s eventual escapades into Downshadow, Waterdeep’s newest “neighborhood.”  Though the magical echoes of Halaster’s Call had faded a century earlier, adventurers were still drawn to the area, and it was there that Joscelina met Anafein Zelith, a drow rogue on the run.Having led a short-lived resistance in his home city, Anafein was betrayed by one of his followers who feared the matron mothers and Lolth’s ire.  Forced to flee, he escaped the Underdark through one of the caverns leading into the depths of Undermountain, and from there made his way upwards through the dungeon’s levels into Downshadow.  Joscelina took more than a passing interest in the dashing, handsome drow, and visited him with an increasing frequency over the next year.  Slowly, the relationship between the couple grew more intimate, though Joscelina had to hide it from her family.Joscelina and Anafein’s relationship came to an abrupt halt when Anafein was arrested by the Watch and accused of the attempted murder of Dagult “Dagger” Neverember, the current Open Lord of Waterdeep.  Though Anafein was innocent of the charges against him, he was brought to trial and found guilty.  The Lords of Waterdeep needed a scapegoat to punish for the crime, and the public execution which followed the trial served to reassure the city’s citizens and show that the murderer had been brought to justice.  When the news of Anafein’s tragic death was brought to Joscelina, she fell insensible to the floor in her family’s North Ward home.  Though Markus paid for the finest of healers from all the temples of Waterdeep, none could rouse his daughter from her coma.  The healers did, however, give Markus some surprising news: Joscelina was pregnant.Five months to the day after Anafein’s unfortunate demise, while the worst hurricane in Waterdeep’s living history raged up and down the Sword Coast, Alunira Nenlaer was brought screaming into the world.  Though Markus had hired the best midwives to be found in the city, they were unable to stop Joscelina’s bleeding, and later that evening she passed away.  Though Alunira showed signs of her half-drow heritage such as her slightly pointed ears and dark skin, she was Markus’ only solace in his grief over the death of his daughter.  As she grew older, her grandfather continued dote on her and swore to raise her in a manner befitting House Nenlaer.As Alunira was teased and bullied by the other children of the merchant houses of Waterdeep, she spent most of her time with her tutors or otherwise absorbed in her lessons.  In particular, Alunira showed great promise with her studies in history, religion, languages, swordplay, and especially music.  By the time she reached ten years of age, she could play the lute, lyre, mandolin, harp, and flute as well as compose poems and ballads.On the occasion of Alunira’s sixteenth naming day, Markus announced that Alunira was to travel with House Nenlaer’s merchant caravans, following their usual route south along the Trade Way to Baldur’s Gate and then east to Suzail in Cormyr.  Though she didn’t realize it, this was Markus’ way of testing Alunira to see if she was ready to start controlling a stake in House Nenlaer’s trade business.  At first she enjoyed leaving Waterdeep and seeing some of the great cities of Faerun, but by the time the caravans reached the Dragon Coast, she was bored with the slow pace and distinct lack of excitement.Prompted by a sudden need for adventure that she had never felt before, Alunira decided one night to steal the money that the caravan had acquired.  From there she stowed away on a ship leaving from Bolliver’s Wharf in Suzail, with grand plans to see the entirety of the Sea of Fallen Stars.  However, this dream was cut short when the ship was boarded by pirates from Mirg Isle, one of the many rocky islands that comprise the Pirate Islands.  Exposed as a stowaway, Alunira managed to convince the pirates that they would be better off if she joined them, rather than killing her.Alunira spent several years working her way up the ranks and eventually became Captain of the Dark Desire.  However, many of her crew disagreed with her methods and found her to be too kind-hearted for a life a piracy.  After being caught letting Officer Ryl Obarin of the Cormyrian Navy go free instead of killing him or holding him for ransom, the crew of the Dark Desire mutinied against Alunira and threw her overboard.  She has since washed up on the shores of Suzail, penniless and missing Black Bellamy, her parrot familiar.

Bazil never knew his Ogre mother, being raised by his Dwarven father withheld from the rest of the clan. Due to his odd heritage he was often alone, easing his mind with martial arts and smithing. His father never spoke about his kin nor Bazil's mother. Before Bazil's birth, he was high-born, and did his best to teach Bazil manners and civility. Bazil had a great command of language and a sharp wit, but was quick to anger and was never truly comfortable around others. He left his home to find his mother and his place in the world.
Noble
urchin
Travelling the world to become a Hero and a Pop star
Researcher at a University with a focus on planar magic and planar travel
Prince of one kingdom kept secret now working as a spy for an allied kingdom.
Cedric loves magic and couldn't decide whether worshipping Mystra was better than being a practicioner of magic so he became both.
Tzu has made a living doing a lot of different tricks and scams, but has decided to turn over a new leaf and live an honest life from now on.
As a young man, Lugh was recruited to the army of the empire he'd been born in. He quickly showed his skills in deception and combat, becoming part of the empire's elite corps.

Youngest child, one of too many kids, parents sold him to the Church of Vernera. Was raised as a cleric of knowledge, truth and justice. Graduated from the seminary as a lawyer and now acts as a travelling judge

In a world where elves are despised by humans, a human noble impregnates an elf warrior-princess and the resulting baby is left with the human. Wishing not to see his son derided for his father's mistake, he sent him away to a far off land.

Grew up with her human mother, learned woodlore from her father's people, trained to be a bard and traveled a lot. Both parents still living! No siblings. She led a boring but interesting life of travel and friendship. Parted on friendly terms from her entertaining troupe shortly before meeting up with her current party.

abandoned at the church when he was a baby and, after a near-death experience when he was a child, trained to be a Paladin. After a disagreement with his church about whether he should use his Divine magicks to help the general population or just the church itself, he left to find his own path.

Sally bat Faisal is a wild child, born and raised in the Red Town district. She studied hard and partied hard. Her father is a local magistrate who was frequently embarrassed by the men and women making the walk of shame from his townhouse. Appealing to her filial piety and academic bent, he strongly suggested that she join the priesthood of Athena, hoping she would calm down. She didn't learn celibacy, nor even chastity, but, after hearing the story of Medusa, she did learn discretion. Nevertheless, the temple is quite eager for her to "spread the word of the Goddess" ie, go away before she corrupts anyone else. She was Keejee's babysitter before she was kidnapped, and, since Keejee gained her freedom, she has been obsessive about keeping her former charge healthy, especially mentally. Sally also knows that she is being groomed to take over from her father when he retires, so she studies law, history, and religion obsessively in her spare time.

The son of two nobles who tried to raise him in a small village due to a curse. On his twelfth birthday, a wicked witch activated the curse, sending him to a faraway city. Subsequently fostered by a private detective, he trained as a receptionist and interviewer. When he was fifteen, his psychic powers manifested and he left to explore his origins.

The son of two trade magnates, born to wealth and privilege, and the middle child of four siblings. Attended a prestigious wizarding college, where he studied illusion magic and dungeon interior design, but only achieved mediocre grades. Spent several years of his education partying and accidentally missed his finals as a result. After being financially cut off by his parents, he began to make his living as a con artist instead.

Rannok used to live in a small village near the coast. One cay, he found a small nightmarish idol on the beach and took it home with him, where it gave him horrible dreams why he slept. He ended up fleeing the village after the villagers chased him out for practicing black magic. He ended up in an old abandoned Temple of Cthulhu, where he began to worship him as a god.

A (not very good) cleric with light fingers and wandering hands. She was sent off to an out the way temple where it was hoped the peasants worldly goods of turnips and manure wouldn't tempt her. As fate would have  it, she sccidentally ended up being compelled to join a passing band of adventures - after the disasterous consequences of having filched the talisman that was keeping their own, otherwise injured, cleric alive...

Daughter of a scholar of the planes, Lisette had always been interested in creatures and landscapes of the planes. From an early age she learned simple magic, biology, ecology and geography with the help of her father. This love for exploring and science led her to become an adventurer. With the help of her summoned creatures she travels the land with adventuring friends, exploring everything creatures, people and their habitats have to offer

Varis the bard grew up in poverty until he saved up enough money to buy a lute. His family needed the money so he started playing at the local inn. One day, Varis was playing and the crowd started swarming him. All of a sudden, a bodyguard that he hadn't hired named Buck Fireforge started pushing the crowd back. Soon a friendship developed and he was hired. Varis now adventurers in a group of five.

Yennica is the fifth of sixteen children. Her father, the prince of a small kingdom, had four wives, all of whom died of mysterious illnesses, leaving him all their land and assets. The fifth wife killed him and fled. With the succession unclear, Yennica's kingdom plunged into civil war between all her siblings. Yennica pledged herself to the god of stars and wanderers, whose followers are required to travel and wander as much as possible, and fled the kingdom.

Raised in an elven homeland, does not know human mother (Emelia Leadenfell), father is Balzeiros Admaris who is an artisan who crafts magical objects, went to academy but was expelled after an incident where through carelessness she accidentally used her lover Beiris Wranric Erxidor as a vessel to channel ancient gods which caused him to be lost in a world of paranoid delusions and to forever be under the control of the ancient gods, she now adventures to find a way to atone for the pain she has caused,  alignment is now lawful neutral

Ivellios was raised in a monastery, where he proved to be excellent at martial arts and really, really bad at meditation and spirituality. As a youth, he started sneaking into the village to enter gladiatorial contests, or sometimes just to challenge strangers to an exhibition fight. Now that he's an adult, the abbot has suggested that he leave the monastery for a while, gain an understanding of the wider world, and come back when he's ready to take his vows seriously. He's been supporting himself by continuing his gladiatorial career and thinks he's much more famous than he really is.

Danoleth spent most of his young adulthood as a squire for a high-ranking Knight, hoping to become one himself one day. When Orcs invaded his Nation and he found himself on the front lines, he nearly lost all hope. His Knight was killed and he was left crippled and unable to fight. Though he crawled away from the battlefield he feared he would die of his injuries. His luck turned however when he crossed paths with a Druid, whom offered to heal Danoleth. He agreed to study under the Druid, maintaining his Paladin's Oath while focusing on preserving the natural balance.

Garruk never wanted much from life beyond peace and quiet. That was until a group of Dark Elves burned his entire village and took him and various others as slaves. After being sold and abused repeatedly he was saved by a group of adventures. Joining their side, they went on a quest to find the queen of the Dark Elves and put an end to their slave trade. Everywhere Garruk went he burned them as they had done his home. Eventually he hanressed the power of these flames and would often turn into a fire Elemental to truly show them the power of fire.

Rozhenya, the bastard daughter of an elven noble, was raised at an elven embassy. She was raised as an aristocrat, but treated with coldness or indifference by the pureblood elves. She quickly soured on noble life; after a web of extortion which she had built trying to find out her mother's identity collapsed around her, she fled the embassy. At the suggestion of her friend Aleila, a courtly entertainer, she instead sought out the House of Black Drapes, a den of thieves and cutthroats, where she received thieves' training. She now travels the world, plying her skills as an entertainer and a criminal, seeking new experiences.

Talia was a teenager when an infernal force swept through and sundered the keep she and her family lived in. In the chaos, she mistakenly stepped onto a pirate's corvette and found herself a prisoner. However, she was able to prove herself by saving the life of her captor - in gratitude, she was freed and adopted the moniker "The Eel", a creature she admires for its flexibility and adaptation. As one of few women leaders among a confederacy of pirates, she wears the guise of severity while each day she fights to preserve a solemn love for her lost brother, whom she one day hopes to find.

Erika was the only daughter of a druid and a tailor. When she was 12, a group of cultists framed her family for summoning a demon and the church of Tyr burned them at the stake. Erika escaped and tried to make a living on the run, always afraid the Church was following her. Eventually, she was picked up to be a sacrifice to a demon lord. With her quick wit and a boot dagger, she instead tricked the high priest into being the sacrifice and accidentally formed a pact with Malcanthet, demon lord of succubi. Now she travels the lands stirring up trouble and discrediting the Church as her patron demands.

Shushken was taken in as an orphan by the Aspen Witch, a kindly old grandmother to the entire island. Shushken natural had an inclination to study magic, and apprenticed under the witch. Shushken's curiosities eventually turn to necromancy, and despite the usual stigma against such practices, Aspen did her best to foster the child's curiosity in a healthy way. She taught Shushken how to use magic to mediate with the dead, to help them accomplish unfinished tasks or bring closure to the bereaved. Shushken set their sights on being able to fully resurrect one of the fallen. It was their goal to be as powerful a medium as they could, easing the passage of the dying and returning those whose lives had been cruelly cut short.

Grew up in the town that houses the sole wizarding school in the country the campaign is set -- after graduating from it, she stayed behind as a researcher in the archives, only to uncover a deadly secret: the town council are actually allied with the Big Bad Villain. Once the council found out they banished her, framing her for a different crime, but also did something much worse: they harnessed the power of the Big Bad Villain to curse her with an illness called "the Filth", that leaves black patches on your skin, turns your blood black, and makes you dizzy and weak as you hallucinate into other dimensions. So she's on a mission to defeat the Big Bad Villain, cure herself, and clear her name.

Grew up in the town that houses the sole wizarding school in the country the campaign is set -- after graduating from it, she stayed behind as a researcher in the archives, only to uncover a deadly secret: the town council are actually allied with the Big Bad Villain. Once the council found out they banished her, framing her for a different crime, but also did something much worse: they harnessed the power of the Big Bad Villain to curse her with an illness called "the Filth", that leaves black patches on your skin, turns your blood black, and makes you dizzy and weak as you hallucinate into other dimensions. So she's on a mission to defeat the Big Bad Villain, cure herself, and clear her name.

Jamenas was a druid for a small tribe of elves and half-elves. They lived in harmony with the land, giving back as much as they took. Though, unbeknownst to them,a cult of fire was scrying on them, searching for a druid in touch with nature and the elements, that they can cleanse the world in a fire ball. They raided the settlement, and burnt a large section of the forest. Jamenas was taken, and imprisoned in a fire cult cell. Jamenas, desperate for vengeance, pleaded to the gods. One minor god, though not minor compared to mortals, answered his pleas. Hoar, the god of vengeance, had a new champion! Jamenas escaped, slaying any cultist he found, until he reached the outside world. Thirsty for vengeance, Jamenas adventures, calling on both his druidic magic, and the power of Hoar, to quench his thirst!

Allister is the youngest of three siblings born into poverty. Their mother was a prostitute, and their father an unnamed elf. After their mother was killed by guards, they had to turn to crime to survive, stealing from peasants and guardsmen. After years of barely surviving, they moved into a church as helpers to leave the dangers of street life. But Allister came home one day to find their church on fire and his older brother wielding strange magical powers, standing over the corpse of the priest who took them in. His sister, Emeline, was battling him, also wielding strange sorcery. At that time, Allister felt a pull within him as his own latent powers awakened, and the resulting magical explosion teleported him outside the city's walls, ready to begin a new life as an adventurer. Allister has since become a fire magic specialist, prone to laughing incontrollably as he sets his enemies on fire.

I grew up as an orphan living on the streets with no one but my little brother. I was forced to defend and fend for myself and my brother. One day, my brother is stricken ill and resigned to his deathbed. A voice comes to me in the darkness offering help...for a price. I signed a contract in blood, offering my life to this voice in the darkness known as The Great Other to save my brother. However, I did not realize what this truly meant, and I am now forever a servant of this being. The sealing of this pact, while giving me great power, has also changed me, leaving me with blood red eyes, pale white skin, and an overall very creepy looking appearance. I spend my life trying to stay under the radar of The Great Other and preparing for the day, should it occur, that he comes to collect on his contract, I only hope that I can be ready.

Conrad grew up in an isolated village in the northern highlands, where he was a hunter, one of the best archers in the village. However, a clan of orcs moving through the area attacked his patrol party, killing all of the hunters, and they'd thought they'd killed Conrad, too. The orcs' leader, a shamaness with six fingers on one hand, took a trophy from the fight: Conrad's pendant, a family heirloom, left to him by his late mother. Once Conrad recovered he left the highlands and has been tracking the orc with six fingers and her clan ever since, plotting his revenge and searching for his lost pendant.Conrad is sociable and friendly, although he doesn't trust strangers any further than friendly chit-chat. He also doesn't really understand how cities and civilization work, given that most of his life was spent in his tiny village and the huge surrounding wilderness, so he tends to be cautious and a little naive. He's still young, but looks even younger.

Torvald has been fascinated by magic ever since before he realized he could wield it. If only he could wield it consistently... despite his years of intense study and self-imposed hermitage in the bowels of a swamp (for ambiance, you see) he has a rather poor success rate with casting spells, earning him the title "Literally The Worst Sorcerer Ever." He prefers it when his spells fail, rather than backfire though. That time he turned himself into a potted plant in the middle of a battle... not the kind of showing the bards would sing home about. Or at least not in any flattering way.
