They took him back to their fishing village of Rydehook, which is actually a collection of house boats lashed together, where he was taken in by the local healer, and follower of Habbakuk, Petros.  In addition to learning martial combat to defend the village from pirates, Petros raised Jordan to respect nature and the sea in keeping with the traditions of Habbakuk.One day during a particularly violent pirate attack, Jorma called upon Habbakuk for help and unleashed a Thunderwave that killed the pirates but also destroyed a  portion of the docks.  This village, being wary of magic users of any kind, exiled Jorma for his "neglectful use of magics."  Before leaving, Petros encouraged Jorma to explore the world, helping anyone he could, always be learning, and to call on Habbakuk if he needed help.

Kerri is the daughter of a noble house, but she is a noble in name only. As natural disasters shook Neverwinter, most of her family's land was devastated, with only a remote manor left to their name. Thus, Kerri grew up desiring a comfortable lifestyle, but being strongly aware of what she would have to do to earn it.Kerri began training as a fighter when young. She took to it well, and while she was also a capable student when it came to history or courtly manners, she felt comfortable with a weapon in her hand. It wasn't until a failed kidnapping attempt, thwarted by herself and her bodyguard, Ser Battlehammer, that she began to think of leaving her family estate for good, and embracing the life of an adventurer.While other adventurers aim to explore the world or become more powerful, Kerri wants to stay close to her homeland, gaining riches, knowledge and connections which will help her improve her family's standing.

Shandra Karlen was raised by her mother to be the perfect noble's wife taught how to dance and sing, to understand court intrigues and navigate the world into which she would be entering. Not having a son her father quietly passed on his own knowledge of battle and war through instructors carefully picked from the men who had returned with him from the wars in the south when he retired.At the age of 14 just four days before she was to be officially presented at the annual gathering of all the noble families in Silverbay she was returning from a hunting ride with her favorite instructor Davin to find her home aflame and men ready to take her. Davin threw himself upon them yelling to her “Run Shandra! Run and hide”…… five long years later Shankar has learned to hide amongst the dregs of Silverbay. Adapting skills she’d been taught to navigate high society and using them to survive in the underworld of thieves and murderers.

We know his given name was Bregget. We don't remember how we came to use the surname Minder- some say that it was because his pa was seen minding sheep, some that his pa was clearly a miner, and it has changed from that.Bregget came to town at a young age with his father, who was mugged and killed, without knowing a soul.The boy ended up in a gutter rat gang pretty quickly, as this small town had very little means to support an orphanage.As he aged, he was quickly one of the largest boys, and was selected as leadership as an enforcer. This earned him the name "Berk the jerk" among the smaller boys- to chide him.In later years, Berk left the gutter rat gangs because he didn't like what he was being asked to do. He qualified as a town guard simply by his size and strength, and all was okay...until his gutter gang past and city guard present ran afoul of each other...

Danann was an up and coming soldier assigned to a small regiment located east of Red Larch. He became a friend to the villagers and a brother to his fellow soldiers. While patrolling the fields on the outskirt of town, he was knocked unconscious by an unknown assaliant. When he awoken the fields were hot cinders and the livestock inflames. A searing pain was felt on his neck, a brand of the mark of those that burned all the villagers that were in town, and all the soldiers that were meant to protect them. Nobody blamed him for the outcome. No one except Danann himself. To cope with the pain he felt, Danann resigned from active duty, and became a wandering bard. telling stories, singing songs, entertaining and brightening the day of everyone he meets. But don't let the performance fool you, he still keeps an eye out for any clues about what happened to the people he cared for, and any sign for those that are to blame.

She is the wife of the head of the Maelstrovich crime family, Dominic Maelstrovich, a purple-skinned tiefling warlock pact-sworn to the Great Old One Ithaqua. Of their family, she is the only one who has not made the warlock pact, though she was present for her son's initiation, and will be there when her daughter Nikola turns eighteen and is imbued with the ancient power that has kept their family powerful. Charani's magic is different, darker and far more primal, and it was their mutual darkness that drew her and Dominic together. Despite his heavy-handedness and her rough nature, they managed to raise their children in a loving and supportive household. After all, if Alexei turns out to be better at diplomacy than interrogation, or Nikola at invention rather than socializing, their family will still benefit from their talents and fill in the gaps with other employees. She herself has no qualms about getting her hands dirty, and often acts as her husband's personal guard or, if no one capable is available, his brute squad.

Serenity's father was a blacksmith. Evil empire rolled into town and demanded her father craft the Emperor the finest sword. He refused and took his family and hid out in the mountains. Empire found him, and slaughtered Serenity's family. She escaped into the woods and grew up there as a wild child. Serenity was discovered many years later by the Empire, the emperor was with the soldiers, and kept them from killing her. Instead seeing her ferocity as a tool for his army. She had become quite feral and didn't remember the empire, or what happened anymore. Just the forest. He took her from the forest, educated her, and taught her to be a killing machine. She rose through the ranks and became a feared general for the evil empire. She was sent on a special ops mission from the emperor to infiltrate the party, and ensure they failed in rescuing the princess of the good nation. She would assassinate them if the need arose. This is where she entered the story, game, and set forth.Backstory.

Born on an Adeptus Mechanicus forge world his family was loyal to the ways of the Machine God with family becoming priests or artisans. Xanthis however showed little affinity for technology he was withdrawn and uncaring. He ran away while young and hid in dark places, of his world, where upon he saw heretics learning and taking apart technology, his skin crawled so much at the sight of this heresy against the blessed Machine God he killed them as they slept. In the fires of their death Xanthis rose made a new, fresh with purpose from the Machine God itself, he would purge the world of weakness and heresy, and their spilt blood would fuel its eternal cogs. Eventually he caught the eyes of the ever watchful Mechanicus and was brought into their fold, a weapon, a tool to be used to further their ends, even in the folds of the Inquisition itself, although the urges within Xanthis were difficult to control he did his best only occasionally seeking out weakness to be purged when not directed.

Lucius grew up in a monastery dedicated to to Theidon, the God of Knowledge. A few generations prior, the wizards of Glyndor raised their continent into the sky to live among the clouds, opening a rift to the underworld whence hordes of demons erupted into the world. They sewed devastation wherever they went, but eventually the neighboring kingdoms managed to achieve balance and peace. Lucius grandfather was a Paladin of the God of Knowledge, wandering the land in search of old tomes and stories. He disappeared when the continent ascended. Lucius's people learned to fear magic, even those in the monastery nominally dedicated to learning and study, and it became outlawed in the Kingdom of Ardellon. When his latent magical abilities began to surface, he experimented with some old scrolls he found in a forbidden area of the library. But he could not fully control the magic, and he caused a portion of the monastery to burn down. He fled, vowing to continue to studying and championing knowledge in the face of ignorance, and to find out what happened to his grandfather.

Not much is known of the Rangers of Azilla and what is known is mostly rumour. It is said that they roam the wilderness south of Silverbay, preying on the brigands and other wild things that plague the land. Their skill with both bow and blade is renowned. They hold with no code or forms of fighting but are driven by a voracious appetite for survival.They shun human contact and choose a path to go around villages and towns where they can. This isolation fosters suspicion and fear in the minds of locals and it has been known for rangers to be driven off when venturing near the border towns.Not much more is known of Ronen. He has made the wilderness his home for eight short years and still his name is known to only a handful of fellow Rangers. He is marked by a darker complexion and olive skin that are unusual to find among the people of the wilds.He is accompanied by his faithful hunting dog Fenton. Fenton is a young hunting dog, trained to follow orders, but still young and over eager.

Ozvanna is a gypsy child. A member of a ragged, traveling band.Her parentage isn't quite known...maybe just not talked about. It doesn't matter in this clan, where all of the children are raised by all of the parents.As a young girl, Ozvanna assisted a crooked old fortune teller. She would help gather crowds, and talk people into getting their fortune told. She'd spy, flirt and wheedle to get information to pass the old woman- to assist with her fortune telling swindles. Here and there she would pick a pocket or two, maybe arrange a bigger score by finding out details on local homes and personal wealth.Minor magical learning was a part of her training, as the fortune teller used charms and beguilments to get cash and information out of her clients, and was teaching Ozvanna to do the same.Now, in her teenage years, she has felt grief and guilt over the lies and theft that she has always practiced.In the still of a moonless night, she decides to leave. She steals a handful of needed supplies (she helped to collect it all anyway), and sneaks away...vowing never to see her clan again.

Born into a military family of watchmen, Older Ander thought that he would live out his days on the high tower keeping watch for orc raiders, bandits, forest fires, storms, armies, and caravans. His childhood was interupted by an Ogre incursion which his family got eaten alive. The raid was harrowing and the keep endured heavy fighting and losses for two weeks before the army saved them. The good monks of Magere, god of disipline and the Mantis in the Rose, brought him up and taught him the virtue of hardwork. He took up the family post for a while as a watchman, but after the resurgence of the great Ogre wars, he retired and vowed to heal rather than to injure. He became a guild Apothecary and lived to a ripe old age. But then the King gave the called to all available hunters. Something had gone wrong with the great Hinkley hunt 200 years ago. Evil's festering had blossomed and threatened the nation. So, Older Ander Ravenhorn dusted off his city issued armor and weapons, packed up as much healing herbs as his horse could carried and answered the call to do his duty.

Rufus is a man of the people, through and through. Growing up with his druidic tribe, he was often the one chosen to interact with outsiders, managing to find common ground between the Druids and others.He is not as zealous as some of his bretheren, and while he feels uncomfortable in cities, he doesn't react as violently as some druids he knows. This has helped cement his role in his circle and village as the go-between.Rufus is married and currently has seven children. They all live in a small village on the Dessarin River, where Rufus mediates disputes between villagers,  and helps farmers with their fields. It is a happy life, and he is content.However, recently their village has been raided by bandits coming from the south. During one such attack, Rufus was able to lead some of his fellow villagers in the town's defence, and managed to thwart the raid. During an interrogation of captured bandits, he found the bandits were acting on the behest of a man called Gar Shatterkeel. Rufus knows of this Gar, being a fellow druid, and he makes plans to travel south to find this Gar and convince him to stop.

Born with the mark of Istus (goddess of fate and destiny) on her shoulder, Iris was raised in the temple as soon as she was old enough to leave her parents. For the first eleven years of her life, it wasn't clear why she had been chosen. She was a competent fighter, a good student and a passable healer, but showed no exceptional skills or talents. Then, the nightmares started. And then they started coming true. Iris spent the next five years of her life poring over ancient tomes and heavy manuscripts in an attempt to understand the visions of the future that plagued her, but gathered no substantial information. Eventually, at the age of sixteen, she grew restless, and chose to the leave the temple that she had called home for as long as she could remember. Resenting the burden Istus had placed upon her, Iris shied away from the destiny that seemed to be laid out in front of her, becoming a thief on the streets and rooftops of the city of Kerrel. But try as she might to avoid her destiny, it seemed Istus had other plans, as a vision led her straight into the path of a misfit group of adventurers.

As a child, he grew up without his parent who died due to a famine in his village. He lived in the church of Tyr, the god of justice. The priest looked after him and helped him find odd jobs around the village to do.When he was a teenager, he began training to fight to help support the village and possibly get a job as a malitia man. His training was greatly influenced by his teaching and his goal became to help rid the world of injustice.Soon, another drought came upon the village and all the villagers put together their money to afford to pay a caravan for water. Ander, seeing a huge injustice took it upon himself to rob the rich Lord that lived nearby.He made his way into the castle by persuading the guards that he wanted to build a small shrine on order of the Lord. As if by some divine luck, the door to the treasure room was unlocked. He then locked himself in and threw all the gold he could out the window to the town below.Now hunted by the Lord he robbed, he continues his journey to rid injustice and wrong doing from the world and help every creature he can....

Toren is an eleven year old child of ambiguous gender. She uses female pronouns for everyone. Her patron is an ambiguous embodiment of Luck, which is a true neutral deity. When crossing a street and a car passes right in front of you, you think yourself lucky because you didn't get hit by the car, but you're not getting hit by a car right now are you? That's Luck in action, neither giving nor taking with intention. Toren joined the circus after growing up on the streets and owes her life to the woman who took her in. Occasionally she stumbles upon an imp she calls One Esk Nineteen who helps her on her adventures. After defeating an ice dragon deep in a glacier, Toren delved deep into a YuanTi temple where she saw her future in its entirety, bought the freedom of a very broken slave who she named Sievarden. She showed the lizard man agency and he died for it and now she seeks his ancestors to return his remains to their sacred rituals. Has seeing the outcomes for every action disproved the existence of her God? Will she find Sievarden's ancestral home? What does the symbol burned into her face after seeing her future mean?

Kayla was born to a human prostitute in the city of Elmund, her father most probably being one of the many elven adventurers and nobles that visited the brother where her mother worked, given Kayla’s clear elven heritage. Her mother, kept docile by the matron of the house with a combination of alcohol and drugs provided very little for the growing girl, leading her to spend most of her time running the streets with the gangs of urchins that pickpocketed and stole what they needed to survive. Soon Kayla was leading her gang, her quickness with a knife backing up her forceful personality. One day, when breaking into an old wizard’s tower she was caught, her lack of arcane understanding proving her undoing. The wizard killed her companions and placed Kayla under a domination spell, forcing her to take part in a ritual, too abhorrent and evil to print here, that bonded Kayla with a terrible demon, birthed from her own body, a demon that killed her master and freed her from her slavery to an evil wizard and instead placing her in command of a power beyond that of most mortals. The demon has not forgotten her, however, and watches her movements with great interest, it’s goal unknown.

Born as a bastard from one of the Druidic Sect of the Gatekeepers, a sect based off keeping the world from the unnatural and protecting the world from dimensional threats, Jack Moriarty was placed into a ranger school, at the mercy of his father, and trained there his whole life. He was a promising student, and learned the craft of monster hunting quickly, but the sect was disgusted by his unnatural upcoming.  Later down the line the daelkyr started to invade the plane, and during this war his ranger school sent on suicide mission to close a portal used for the invasion of daelkyr. Most of his school died, including the master druid of the school, Moriarty’s father.With his father out of the picture and no one to say otherwise, Moriarty was discharged from service, as he was the last in line to train new rangers of his school, but deemed to unnatural to be a leader. Moriarty then left his lands to find purpose. With his combat prowess and knowledge of the monstrosities that plague the land, he became a bounty hunter to make a living, and ultimately as a to stave off the civilization from the unnatural and extraplanar. He holds the values and core beliefs of his sect to heart even after being cast aside.

I am the second son of the Morgwend noble family, the family set up as the next ruler in the cyclical monarchy that exists in the frigid kingdom of Arena. My eldest brother`s untimely death and the uncertainty of the legitimacy of his heirs made my father gather me and my brothers and proclaim that if one of us gets to rule their own land or obtains great power, without defining what "great power" would be, he would become the new heir, instead of the children of the one who planned our brother`s widow and her family, which we suspect of having planned his death. I value power, as I need it. I value carnal pleasures more than I should. I value a peaceful community and my authority as a noble. Friends are things I have very few of. To earn my trust is to earn the right to have me shed my blood for you. I trust no women. To me, they`re like a wine merchant while I`m a poor alcoholic, so I never trust any person who has this kind of power over me. To fulfill the wishes of my father, I decided to travel the world, searching for  magical items that produce heat or alter the climate of a large area, to aid in the expansion of our kingdom.

Dren grew up in the farming town of Orthantis with his twin sister Nala and his mother Ada. By the time the two of them were born, their father was no longer in the picture, but was never explained to them by their mother the exact reason of his absence, be it either gone or dead. His mother was one to stay sick quite often, so it fell to him and Nala to be able to provide for them.Their official job had always been street performers, usually a form of acrobatics or dance, though Nala had always been the better of the two in that aspect. To supplement this, Dren took to petty theft and always had an excuse for his actions, though never stealing from someone who could not afford to lose it. Eventually he stole from the wrong noble and was caught, faced with imprisonment. Though from the good nature of a traveling monk, Akta, he was given the choice of training and reform under the monk's teachings.Isolated with Akta in the mountains for almost eight years now, he has learned to be self sufficient and has trained much under his teacher in learning peace and the ways of the monk tradition. Akta had set out on a journey some few months prior and while Dren trusted their safety, has started to become concerned.

Cassius was born in the small village of Valmir off the coast of the Blood Sea. Being small, he was often bullied by the other kids in the village. This led to him becoming very troubled and the more they beat him, the more he began to enjoy it. He began to revel in his pain and the pain of others. Cassius hit puberty and went from a small 5 feet, 100 lbs. to a towering 6'9, 200 lbs. of raw muscle. He left the village and went to join the King's army. After 20 years of being a soldier he was kicked out for being too brutal and it was found that he had been collecting the hands of those he killed in battle. Angry at being kicked out Cassius becomes a drunk and often found himself involved bar fights. Cassius found himself on the wrong side of the law after one bar fight where he resumed his habit of collecting hands. Fleeing from city to city, Cassius's necklace and belt and hands waved menacingly from his neck and waist. Forever growing and becoming a warning to everyone. Wandering the wild, on the run from the law and looking for purpose, Cassius joins a group of adventures on a quest to save the world. It was time for this psychopath to do some good and redeem himself.

Mirellia was raised in a rural backwater village on the edge of a forest. The daughter of a blacksmith, she loved nothing more than "testing" the weapons he made for adventurers who came to town. She felt torn between her family and her desire to see the world... until she was fifteen. On a gloomy autumn morning, Mirellia was stalking a deer to kill for venison when she heard the howling of wolves--coming not from the deep woods, but from the village. At the sight of smoke rising over the bare branches, Mirellia sprinted back towards her village... to find her family, and most of the other villagers, dead. Their flesh was carved with deep fang-marks and wolf-tracks surrounded the huts, some of which had been set alight.Mirellia fled to a nearby Elven village, which kindly took her in. There she learned the forest-craft of the rangers, all while cultivating a deep hatred of the beasts that murdered her family. She learned enough to know that those could not have been ordinary wolves; but the elves could tell her little of what they actually were. Still, when it was time to set out on her own and, if she could, avenge her loved ones, Mirellia took on a name that she thought fitting, and became Mirellia Wolfsbane. To this day she is the huntress of all lupine things--werewolves, worgs, and winter wolves alike are her prey.

Tejain Armacre is the youngest son of a conservative, wealthy, hawkish family. They were instrumental in starting the war, profited from it, and have absolutely no sense of shame or noblesse oblige - only anger at how they were treated. (They ran out of allies, and their extensive estates became battlefields and, later, chips on the bargaining table, leaving them refugees.)Tejain had three older brothers. The two elder died nobly (or pointlessly) in battle, and the youngest carries on the fight even now. They are the pride of the family. Tejain's service was minimal, secret, and totally unappreciated - he saw one engagement at Miton's Wells, an utterly pointless massacre just after Sark River that Sullane and Halcrest both pretend didn't happen.Tejain was trained by an upstart mage named Rindimar who insinuated himself into the government as a sort of secret weapons program. He was a horrible person - his training methods killed several "promising" students, and the rest either hated him or followed him slavishly. His unit of journeymen wizards - "The Red Brigade"  - lost badly, and he himself was captured. There are rumors he now serves Halcrest in some function. His most loyal students don't believe this, and fight with the guerillas.Tejain has two younger sisters - young enough to actually adapt to their new lives, if given a chance. Tejain does care for them, to the extent that his father sometimes refers to him as "my eldest daughter."

Rarian Everfeth grew up with a love for reading and learning. He soon became an apprentice librarian, and years after that, became one of the sole proprietors of one of the largest libraries available to the academic and arcane community. His constant immersion in literature, religion, history, and sciences gave him a wide knowledge of virtually anything books could teach him, as well as some of the darker things the library held in some locked shelves, such as books written in infernal and abyssal.Rarian's childhood friend became sick, and even with all of his knowledge, Rarian had no idea what could help his friend recover. After months of searching, and his friend only getting worse, he turned to something he never should have: a pact with a devil.The devil, once summoned, made a pact with Rarian. Rarian would help him pay off a debt and, in turn, the devil would give Rarian the knowledge he needed to save his friend. Once Rarian agreed, the devil revealed that his friend could not be saved, that it was too late, and then took his end of the bargain. The debt the devil held was one to a greater devil. The debt was one human soul. Rarian will lose his rights to his soul once he dies. The demon vanished, and soon after, Rarian left the archives, picked up the sword, calling upon the goddess of knowledge to help him seek vengeance, for his soul, and his friend.

Finn was born in a large city in an influential province. Him and his best friend Gill have always dreamed of being treasure hunters. One day while reading in the library they learned of an ancient tomb, possibly unopened, nearby. The two journeyed out to it and determined that the seal on the entrance was unbroken. Excited to uncover new treasures, the two delved into the tomb, disarming the traps in the halls with ease. When they finally made it to the treasure room, they discovered that it had been looted. Someone had dug a tunnel into the back and taken all the gold. The only remaining bit of treasure was a golden ring on the finger of a skeletal lord. Gill removed the ring, and in doing so awoke all the skeletons in the room. They attacked him and killed him, ripping the flesh from his bones. Finn barely made it out alive. Unable to stand the thought of his best friend's fate, Finn re-entered the tomb a month later. Using tomb's existing traps and his superior wits Finn systematically killed all the skeletons over the course of a few days. When he finally made it into the treasure room again Finn came face to face with his best friend's skeleton. Without hesitation, he caved in Gill's skull with his crowbar, ending his undead servitude. As a final memento, Finn took the ring off Gill's finger and put it on his own, keeping it as a reminder of his friend. Now, he adventures not only for his own dreams, but for those of his fallen friend.

Although marrying outside of the noble bloodline is usually frowned upon the young Lord Alfredo courted a wealthy merchant's daughter (Isabella Argentaria). He finally gained his family's permission, but perhaps not total blessing, to marry her.  Their first child Calvados was a natural sportsman compared to the next child, Eduardo.  Eduardo after his studies became a rebel against the nobility and decided, against his parents wishes, to be with the comment man and become a physician.  Eduardo opened a free clinic and treated all comers.  Over this time he also developed an understanding of herbal remedies from local ‘witches’.  Eduardo is very protective of his younger sister Connie.Calvados joined the military but on his second campaign was slain by a mace blow to the head.  Barely alive Calvados was returned home, and Eduardo was sent for but it took a couple of days to find him as he was away herb collecting.  Calvados died several days later and Eduardo believes had he been there that he could have saved his brother.  Because of this he vowed to not leave this family again and setup a workshop in the noble court as a doctor.Connie was brought up to be a lady of the court, but like Eduardo, yearned for learning and became a student.  After meeting other like minded students Connie decided that work wasn’t really for her, or court life for that matter, and she has taken up with playwrights and poets in the city.  Her father and mother were not impressed to say the least.Recent events have ended in the vile attempted murder of Lady Isabella Vizzini and the disappearance of Lord Alfredo Vizzini...

The Wheezers were a family of artificers - grandfather, grandmother, two mothers and their partners, half a dozen kids.  They ran an extensive workshop outside of the Imperial capital; making wands and rings and amulets for the general market and a few homunculi to help make other things & to sell to high-end customers.  But it had been getting harder and harder to get supplies; due to the rebellion and the trade embargoes.  Then the Imperial regent announced an increase in taxes, to pay for expanding her palace as well as to fund yet another military expansion; and decreed that all artificers would retroactively pay those taxes for the years since she'd been made regent.When the Wheezers refused to pay, because they didn't have the cash or the goods for that, the regent ordered her enforcer; Commander Rubin; to take the workshop by force and "make an example of them all".The last time Wheezer saw his family - from his wife to his daughters to his grandkids - was when Rubin's wizard launched a fireball and the entire workshop went up like alchemist's fire.  Shadow, the best of the homunculi, had somehow gotten a wand of dimension door; grabbed Wheezer; and teleported them repeatedly away from the explosion.And that was how Wheezer began to work for the rebellion; and to plan eventual vengeance against now-General Rubin.Or at least, that's what Wheezer told the rebels; when they questioned him in a zone of truth.  The reality is a bit more complicated: Every member of his family was teleported away under the cover of the explosion.  They all made it out alive.  But they'll have to stay in hiding as long as Rubin and the regent are in power.

Daughter of loving parents but raised in abject poverty near Waterdeep's docks, Elspeth was orphaned at the tender age of six after a bar fight erupted into a fire that engulfed their tenement. She was adopted by her aunt, who dabbled in some minor fence-work on the side of more reputable shop work, but fell under the sway of her eldest son Otilio, a thief and rogue who used a group of street children to orchestrate pickpocketing and robberies. Young Elspeth was not a skilled pickpocket or burglar, but she was naturally sweet and charming, making her ideal as a distraction, often playing the part of a lost child. Otilio later placed her in the home of a spoiled debutante, Elsa Brook, as a servant, where the bright and worldly young girl quickly became a confidante for the heiress. Otilio acted as a young nobleman from outside the city, wooing Lady Brook with his agent on the inside encouraging the affair. Once she had agreed to take his hand, Otilio provided poison for Lady Brook's father which Elspeth was to administer. Despite her misgivings, she went ahead with the plan and the new Lord Brook was set to inherit everything. He murdered his new wife, making it look like a suicide, and told Elspeth that she would be implicated in Lord Brook's murder if she spoke up. Then he banished her from the city on a ship set for Amn. En route, the ship was taken over by pirates who set the passengers adrift somewhere off the Sword Coast. With no home, family and only a small pouch of gold to her name, Elspeth took to adventuring to get back on her feet and, eventually, get her revenge on her treacherous and now-ennobled cousin.

Leyland was a young man when he joined an order of paladins who policed the land and confronted evil. But like them, he was dogmatic and merciless and believed himself righteous above judgement. On one expedition he and his fellows came across an evil blade of the Shadowfell, which used a dark power to tempt them into seizing it. Some paladins were able to resist, but not those like Leyland, who were driven by ambition and fury instead of a righteous cause. The enthralled paladins slew their fellows, and then each other, to be the sole owner of the blade. Through luck, more than anything, Leyland triumphed and gained possession of the blade. Afterward, the madness passed and Leyland realized what he had done, but he found that the sword was bound to him and he could not discard it. Sickened by his actions and the revelation that he was not the incorruptible force for good that he had supposed, Leyland vowed to go into exile with the blade and live a life of peace.Decades later, an ageing Leyland was forced to break this vow when a great evil threatened the land. Using the dark blade, and with the help of other adventurers, he was able to save the inhabitants of a nearby village from a group of these villains. Leyland realized that he had a chance to atone by confronting this menace, and to put the sword to a noble purpose. United with his new companions, he swore a new paladin oath - this time driven by a sincere desire to do good, although he knew he could not promise that the sword would never be able to cause him to do harm again. But he has vowed to do all the good he can, and make right any wrongs he might cause.

Jonah started sailing at sixteen. He got his first job as a crewman on a cargo ship. He spent the next few years hopping from ship to ship, finding work where he could. When Jonah was twenty, he began work on The Royal Fortune, a ship owned by a wealthy merchant Berrian Goldpetal. Jonah spent several years with this crew. He grew especially close to a Halfling named Cade Thorngage. The crew became dissatisfied with the small amount they were being paid to transport such expensive items. They were doing the most work while Goldpetal made by far the most money. Their anger was egged on by Cade and eventually culminated in a mutiny in which Captain Ironscale was killed by Jonah. The Royal Fortune spent over a decade as a pirate ship captained by Cade, and they terrorized a small section of sea in the south. They particularly targeted other ships owned by the Goldpetal Trading Company.  Jonah had the position of Quartermaster and commanded the ship while not in battle or actively searching for treasure. The ship was not far from the coast when it got caught unexpectedly in a powerful storm, worse than any any of the crew had seen before. The ship was destroyed. Jonah washed up on shore, badly injured, particularly his right leg which he would eventually lose to an infection. Jonah struggled to understand how he could have survived that storm which he assumed was a direct punishment from Melora. As far as he could tell, he was the only one that did. Jonah became convinced that Melora kept him alive for a purpose, to serve Her and atone for his past actions. As Jonah walked along the shore, collecting the few items from his old ship that had washed up, he found a ordinary looking blank book whose pages were somehow completely dry and undamaged.

Len grew up in a cult. His society lived in caves in a great steep-sided mountain, and developed ways to hide themselves from the world. They were the last survivors of a race long thought to be extinct, and they knew many things. As a child, he cooked and sang and studied with his mother, counted sums and wove images with the golden priests. From his brothers he learned how to smuggle a mouse into a bed, throw a rotten fruit through a window, or make a terrifying beast manifest in a bedroom. One warm day in autumn, he went out to play in the leaves and fell asleep until dusk. He came back and found all the people had gone. A bitter-smelling purple powder was scattered everywhere. It made him cough and he went home to bed but nobody was there and the powder was there, too, and he woke up sick. He wandered the mountain in the full moon, burning with fever. He slept by a waterfall and a lonely road. Someone carried him. He woke up in a cart in a big village full of tall curving buildings and endless rushing people, and he ran away. A kind woman gave him food. A strange dog bit him and he screamed at it and shoved it away with his mind and its face came off.  At fifteen, Len has been in the city for six years. He is small for his age, half-starved, and frequently covered in bruises. He speaks with a bizarre accent that nobody’s ever heard before, and his pale skin looks forever out of place, but he knows where to beg and where to steal. He lives in condemned building with a small group of similar boys. He is starting to accumulate a few possessions and think in the long term. His highest aspiration is to have money and safety.

Deep in the heart of the Karthas Mountains, there lies a small village of outcasts. Made up of elves, orcs, half-orcs and humans from the surrounding area, this nature worshiping village carves out a meager living off of the land and by offering their skills as guides through the surrounding area. It is in this town that Trar Dewstream was born and raised. Born to human parents, he learned from his druid father to respect nature, care for animals, and how to earn a living as a guide to those looking for passage through the mountains. Not one to care too much for the city dwellers in the valley below, he spent most of his years communing with nature and learning the ways of the wild. That is until his 26th year. A Peryton came down from the mountains and kidnapped Trar's parents while he was in the settlement of Glasspring after just finishing guiding a group down from the mountains. Returning to his village and hearing of the deaths by the beast, Trar left on a quest for revenge. It took a year of mapping the mountains and tracking down rumors to discover the creatures lair. Roosting high in a hidden mountain forest, a mating pair and their two offspring had made a nest. Here, Trar found the remains of his parents. Flying into a rage, he killed the foul beasts without mercy. Taking a trophy from the creature, a stag horn from the head of the beast, he set up a home in the forest to mourn the loss of his parents and commune with nature. Here he had his first vision of the disaster that was coming. For three years he prepared, honing his druid abilities, haunted nightly by the visions of the cataclysm. Until another vision came. A vision that took him down from the mountains to the outskirts of the great city of Waterford.

Eris Nilodian is a human scout/ranger from the Elvish Northlands. Eris’ parents are part of The Order of Al’Asran, based out of Trezna. The Order of Al’Asran is a small, secret, militant, secular sect of undead-haters that chose to name themselves after one of Pelor’s aliases solely to signify their commitment to eliminating all undead in the Northlands. Though the Order of Al’Asran itself is secular, members are not required to be non-religious. The Order of Al’Asran was founded by the nobles of Trezna, who created it as a means to an end in order to eliminate the lich Xanaphia Siannodel. However, Xanaphia is well-protected by the people, and so the Order has yet to confront her at all. Most of the tireless efforts of the Order have only gone toward destroying minor undead in the area.Eris was raised within the Order, and her speed and dexterity made her a fine candidate to be trained beside scouts and rangers. Before she was old enough to begin her class training Eris developed a passion for dance, and that passion heavily influenced her goals for her career – she has known that she wanted to be a dervish, just like some of the quickest and most cunning combatants in the Order, since she was a child.Eris left Trezna two years before she met The Raiders of the Forsaken Dragon on the aisle of Zegara. She has been traveling, with the Order’s blessing, to broaden her experiences so that she may return with the power and wisdom to bring down Xanaphia once and for all. She was drawn to Keshiki four months before meeting The Raiders, and has spent the last two months in Zegara completing quests for the Zegaran Adventurer’s Guild to increase her skills and acquire the funds to buy new equipment. She has a fiery hatred of the undead, and a singular, overarching commitment to becoming a weapon against them.

In his younger days Kano was a petty criminal. That career came to end when a local street gang, annoyed by the freelancer stepping on their territory, ambushed him and beat him within an inch of his life. Kano was pretty skilled with his bare hands, and managed to take out a few of his assailants. Before long though, he was overpowered by the thugs. The last thing Kano remembered from the fight was a quarterstaff sweeping in take out one of the gang members.Coming to after the fight, Kano was greeted by a monk sitting cross legged on the footpath beside his body. The monk explained that Kano had done pretty well in the fight, all things considered, and that the Monastery of Standing Stone was always looking for people that could fight. I didn't  seem like there was very much left for Kano in this town, and the Monastery had skilled healers. Kano took up the Monk's offer. At first he wanted only to train enough to come back and destroy the gang that had attacked him. Over the course of his time at the Monastery he learned to control his instinct for vengeance. Instead, he has dedicated his life to the Monastery's mission of protecting the weak and allowing order and good to flourish in the world. For the most part, the Monks of The Standing Stone achieve this goal by doing good deeds, or perhaps standing up to criminal gangs and would-be tyrants. Kano is special, one of a hand full of field agents free to follow their instincts and fight darkness where ever they find it.Kano's training has allowed him to master his own greed and need for validation or renown. However, he still struggles on control his emotions when he sees people without power being mistreated. Thus, he is likely to act rashly in order to save a few people immediately, even when a more thought-out approach might save others from suffering.

Razalas was born in the Turmish Republic, in the capital city of Alaghôn. Their mother was an actor who achieved minor success on the stage, but turned out to be a great success as an officer of the Turmish Guild of Theatrical Entertainers, eventually serving a term in the Assembly of Stars. (Their father was one of the best musicians in the city who specialized in esoteric forms too obscure to ever achieve much financial success, but made a comfortable living playing for festivals.) She installed in her child a passion for strong guilds and republican democracy, and a love for--if not talent in--the theater. Razalas early on displayed an aptitude for the arcane arts, and after exhausting the magical training available in Alaghôn (and despite their mother’s dismay that they would never tread the boards), went on to study at the Jedea Academy in Mordulkin, followed by a research position at Candlekeep. They might have gone on to a quiet life of research, unremarked upon except by their fellow specialists in Abjuration, if it were not for their ardent syndicalism and inability to leave a mystery alone.  Razalas happened to learn that Lord Frath, a minor scion of the noble Belt family, had conspired to cheat members of the Drovers and Teamsters Guild out of their due payment for a delivery. In their attempts to redress this grievance, their investigation eventually revealed a plot involving arms smuggling, infiltration by the Red Wizards of Thay, and fiendish corruption of several nobles and government officials in the Gate region. This drew the attention of the Harpers and left Razalas now unsuited for the stuffy confines of academia. While their lack of guile would ensure Razalas would never be a master of spycraft, the Harpers were impressed with their zeal and talent for investigation, as well as their considerable arcane prowess. Now Razalas is an agent at large for the Harpers, preserving knowledge and fighting the abuses of the powerful.

Evelynn has blocked out her childhood memories prior to the age of seven, when the house fire in Brindol killed her parents.  Her first real memory is actually that of being pulled from the burning wreckage of her home by her twin brother, Mezzo, and being left at the Church of Pelor.  She has no recollection of the beatings she received at the hands of her father or the fact that Mezzo himself set the fire.The quiet life at the Church of Pelor suited Evelynn.  The clerics taught her how to read and write, a skill she later passed on to Mezzo on the select occasions when he came to visit.  She also quickly picked up the basics of how to treat those afflicted with sickness and disease, and showed surprising skill with healing magics.  Because of Evelynn’s talent, she was often allowed to accompany the priests on short missionary trips outside the city walls, where she helped to spread the word of Pelor and gave succor to those in need.However, as Evelynn aged, she found herself losing interest in the Church of Pelor’s doctrines.  She began attending services at other temples in Brindol with the hopes of finding a new god or goddess to dedicate herself to, but was unable to identify with any of their teachings.  It wasn’t until Mezzo exposed her to the tenets of the Raven Queen and Evelynn realized she knew the cold hand of fate firsthand that she found her true calling in life.	Believing that everything is predetermined and that circumstances occur in order to guide her throughout her life, Evelynn fled Brindol with her brother after his troubles with the law.  She considers herself indebted to Mezzo for showing her the “true” way in life and is reluctant to leave him for more than a few hours at a time.  Evelynn does not agree with all of what Mezzo does, however, and hopes to someday guide him to a less violent path.

Onan had a grandmother who fell ill. No cleric or druid could diagnose her ailment; it seemed a supernatural sickness, and her last few days were in anguish. He spent what time he could with his fading grandmother in her last days. A very unpleasant experience, as the woman he knew and loved now seemed vacant. Her identity, health, and sanity drained. One day, feeling in his heart that he had little time to say goodbye, he rushed to visit his grandmother one last time.As he entered her room, he found not his grandmother, but some other being, hunchbacked and foul. She stood next to his grandmother’s empty bed. The last thing Onan saw was this old crone drop his grandmother’s heirloom ring into a pouch on her belt, and then vanish in thin air. The theft of the ring robbed him of all he’d had left of his grandmother’s faded memory. Onan learned what he could of this creature: not much. His one lead was a tale set in the moorlands with a villainous witch matching her description.Onan begged to accompany his merchant father, Metin Bakkal, on the way to Duragzhar. When passing through the moorlands Onan wandered off on his own, hoping to find the foul creature who killed his grandmother. He lost his way and was never seen by his family again. He was taken in by druids and attempted to learn their ways, but was never successful. During a coming of age ceremony, he was made to wander the moors alone. He came across some ruins whose strange nature put him in a trance and opened his mind to the power of the Great One. Though he knows little of the Great One, its power flows through him. When he returned, the druids recognized an unnatural power emanating from him and exiled him from the moors.After leaving, he made his way to Duragzhar where he was able to put his warlock powers to use working in black market trades, smuggling, and treasure hunting.

"You want to know about me.  Fine.I'm from a small village you've never heard of.  Because it's gone now.  See, it existed on the edge of what turned out to be a rather nasty forest.  So nasty in fact that the village had its own small group of druids to protect us from the forest and what was in it.  When I was young, I was apprenticed to join those druids.But then the war happened.  And his royal dipshitness needed every man and strong lad capable of bearing arms to rebuild his losses from being a dumbass.  So I "joined" the army.  And I "fought" in the war.  And I survived because I made a noise at the right time while clerics were searching for the dying among the dead on the battlefield.  I don't know why they did it at the time, espeically since I wasn't on their side.  Now.  Now it'd probably some phrase along the lines of "a dead soldier learns nothing from his time in battle".So I recuperated under the care of a cleric of The Red Knight, until I was healthy enough to be a prisoner until the war ended.  And then I went home.  But there was no home to return to.  The forest had reclaimed it while I was gone.  No where else to go, I sought out the cleric of The Red Knight again and "enlisted" as a follower of the goddess of war.  Now don't give me that look.  They don't call her "Our Lady of Strategy" for nothing.  They could tell I was a shit soldier even without my own first hand account of how shit I actually was.  But experience and healers make good soldiers into better ones.  So I studdied medicine, and tactics, and served my time as a front lines healer.  And now that I'm out, I hire on with any adventurers trying to do good.  Well, the ones that don't seem to be completely lacking a brain cell between them, at any rate."

Merry Wrenwright was born in the bustling metropolis of Bichi to a retired mercenary (Anthony Wrenwright) and an independent courtesan of minor renown (Luna Misteye). Merry's life has been shaped by unfortunate events borne from her budding magic, her young adulthood peppered by incidents of bad luck and loss.Around the beginning of her puberty Merry's peers began noticing that her presence usually guaranteed that someone would get hurt a lot more than usual; when Merry came out to play bruises and cuts rarely occurred, but instead more severe injuries were the norm: sprained ankles, dislocated shoulders, and broken bones. The children began avoiding her, causing Merry to spend the bulk of her time alone or with her little brother, Thomas. When Merry was 12 she lost track of 4-year-old Thomas as he played on a busy side street, catching sight of him just in time to witness him trip and fall beneath a runaway wagon.Heartbroken at the loss of their youngest child, Anthony and Luna made a special effort to invest in Merry's development, passing on their wisdom to her. While Merry's mother made an effort to direct her in channeling rudimentary arcane abilities, Merry grew especially close to her father as he taught her about the arts of combat and gambling. All of the time that she would have spent playing with other children was instead spent developing her martial prowess. Over the years Merry grew into a relatively solitary adult, eschewing friendship in favor of a life free of commitments and intimate entanglements with anyone except her family.Merry's father introduced her to a number of contacts throughout the city, and at 17 she began working for them as muscle for hire, usually performing small jobs like debt collection, protection, and intimidation. Anthony died of a fatal stab wound from a mugging months later, and Merry moved out of her mother's home into a shabby room above a blacksmith's shop. Merry received her mysterious letter on the day she turned 19, and departed from Bichi without telling her mother she was leaving town.

Elise has little recollection of her parents, as they both were killed during Szass Tam’s abortive attempt to become immortal and live without his phylactery when she was a toddler.  Orphaned on the streets of Eltabbar, she was discovered outside the church of Ilmater by the prelate, L’eric Wrightsdale.  She lived with L’eric and the other Ilmatari for several weeks, as the undead threat in the country became increasingly worse.  Eventually one of the Chosen of Ilmater, known only as “the Soft,” moved the main church of Ilmater out of the hazardous location of Thay to the town of Riverdale, south of Waterdeep.  Accompanying “the Soft,” L’eric was reunited with his sister, Erin Wrightsdale, the current head of the church of St. Evelith of the White Gardenia in Riverdale.	Knowing that she had no living family and no place to go, L’eric decided to keep Elise with him in Riverdale.  After several years growing up in town as a normal child should, Elise was no longer recognizable as the scared, malnourished youth that had taken shelter with the church of Ilmater in Eltabbar.  She showed surprising promise with divine magic and quickly took to Ilmater’s tenets, perhaps as a result of having seen suffering firsthand.  Upon Elise’s sixteenth birthday, both L’eric and Erin were pleased to formally accept her as an Adorned in the ranks of the Ilmatari.  The church of St. Evelith of the White Gardenia has a history of accepting orphaned children into their fold, so their subsequent adoption of Elise was not considered unusual.  It was then that Elise’s real training began.Forgoing the traditional method of fighting unarmed as the Chosen Evelith had, Elise trained with an elite group of blunt weapon wielding warriors under L’eric’s guidance.  Known as the “Painbearers of the Pure,” they act as the fighting arm of the church of the White Gardenia, going on covert missions to punish those who harm others.  After four years of intense instruction, Elise was given her first assignment.  Instead of being tasked to secretly eliminate a tyrannical leader, she was instead to search for any information or evidence regarding the disappearance of Evelith, who had gone missing a year before.

Fellan has dedicated her life to recording and sharing the history of her tribe. Libraries and scriptoriums would not survive long in the lush rain forests of Bhiena, so this history is not recorded in dusty tomes or hidden scriptoriums. Instead, Fellan herself is a repository for her ancestor's wisdom. As one of the Lore Keepers, she preserves this history in songs, epic poems, plays and stories passed from one generation to the next. The Lore Keepers are an important part of Bheinan society. In addition to sharing their knowledge with the tribe at large, they council their chiefs and perform for the governing council. They are shrewd political operators in their own right, and the particular stories or songs they share at a given meeting are carefully chosen. Fellan loves the thrill of performing her works. Though she takes her formal role very seriously, she get's a great deal of joy from launching into a song or recalling a memorable line from a poem at less formal social gatherings. She is very socially adept, and finds it easy to navigate Bhienan society and bring almost anyone around to her way of thinking. Though she knows many stories of heroes conquering wild places, she has never had any desire to be in one. She is happiest in society and has not enjoyed the wilderness on the few occasions she has been subjected to it.As the first born of Berlon, another Lore Keeper, Fellan was brought up be a Lore Keeper. From an early age she received training in performance and learned the stories and songs that recorded the ancient knowledge. She never could pick up an instrument, but she shone as an actor and story teller and could sing well enough to get by. Before long she was playing for audiences, and even before the chief of her tribe. As she has matured she has taken up a more senior role among the Lore Keepers, and is know part of the inner circle of the group and is teaching new initiates.Her life has largely been dedicated to her own tribe, she has never been beyond Bhiena and only travels outside of her tribe's lands to attend the annual governing council.

Dear Korra,I don't know where to begin. But I do know where I'm going to end, and so I'll start from there.I think your mother gave me the bug.  Ever since she left on that final adventure of hers, and even more when we found out she'll never return, I've felt empty. And anything I do doesn't make it better. I've felt the way she described feeling since she told me she was pregnant with you.Don't get me wrong, we were both overjoyed. And she was determined to give you the proper raising her parents never gave her. She loved you so much, no one can begin to understand. But she had to leave on one last trip after ten years of none. She promised it wouldn't take long, and she cried as much as you did. But I couldn't stop her.And even knowing what I know now, knowing that I'd never see her again, I couldn't stop her. Not just because of her stubbornness, but I couldn't keep her away from what made her truly happy.This is hurting as much as it's hurting you, but I have to do the same. I have to see what was so alluring to her, I have to go on these adventures she loved so much.You're your own woman now, I've taught you all that I know. All you need is experience, and you'll be better than I ever was. You can manage the shop yourself. You're strong, gods you're strong. You finally beat me, didn't you? That smile on your face was the widest I've ever seen on you. It suits you you know. Don't ever stop. You have your mother's face, my eyes, but her face. Did I ever tell you that? You're so much like her, without the sense of adventure of course.I suppose it's kind of funny when I think about it, I thought you'd be the one who'll eventually write this letter. But no, adventure's not for you. You have a smithy to operate! And you love it as much as I do, or as much as your mother loved you-know-what.At the beginning I said she'll never return. I was wrong, she's always with us. She gave me her bug, and you, everything else.I love you,Don't hate me,Dad

After her mother died, Belle's father took her to a small village in an attempt to find a soft, lovely place where they could both heal and escape the memories of the past. Unfortunately, it was not long after they arrived that they discovered the woods were much more sinister than any they had ever seen. A darkness was creeping over the land, and soon packs of wolves twisted by dark magic prowled closer and closer to the settlement, making leaving the village next to impossible. They made a life for themselves, even if Belle constantly chafed at the rest of the villagers, considering them stupid and shallow. She dreamed of the day she could leave, but did not expect that day to come in the form of her father disappearing into the woods. Loathe to tell Gaston or anyone else of her plans, and convinced she could handle the situation herself, she trailed her father to the castle deep in the woods and confronted the monster within. While tales of heroic sacrifice and impossible romance in her head, she agreed to stay in the castle forever if her father was set free, unable to comprehend what horrors awaited her. The prince of the castle was no fairytale prince, and he cared not for her attempts at kindness. She was chained to a demonic altar as a virgin sacrifice when Gaston burst in, the magnanimous hero come to save her, the damsel in distress, the very thing she'd always loathed and swore never to become. In that moment, she honestly didn't know which was worse: being sacrificed to open a portal to hell, or having to witness Gaston save her and then never shut up about it. By time he listened to her angry screams and released her, every evil thing was already dead, every mirror smashed, and there was nothing left to take out her rage on except her own psyche. Her belief in romance and fairy tales died in that castle as well, and while she still found Gaston to be boorish and pigheadedly misogynistic, she found she didn't care nearly as much as she used to. When Gaston, Claudette, and Scarlett set plans to leave the village to go "adventuring," Belle asked to join them. At least finally she would get out, even if she now knew there was nothing out there but more blood and ichor.

C. Sativa was content with his life, living in the woods outside a village in the Southern Wildlands. They seemed inappropriately named to him, as the days passed peacefully, and saw him growing herbs and foraging for mushrooms to sell to the locals.He kept himself to himself, but he didn’t mind that; he was happy to spend his evenings enjoying his own produce. He spent so much time in the woods there was even a rumour that he was part tree himself. When asked, he would rub unusually calloused hands together and smile slightly and ask “How would that work, then?” And if anyone asked what the C stood for in his name, he would say “secret” and no-one would pull him up on his spelling.But he was well-liked nonetheless. If the local Baron thought that maybe the herbs Sativa sold to the villagers made them a bit… relaxed, then he turned a blind eye, since the mushrooms Sativa sold to the Baron were sure to make a party go with a bang.One day, all that changed.He noticed the smell first, as though an enormous bonfire had been lit nearby. At first he thought there was a party that he had forgotten about. But then he heard shouts, and they weren’t shouts of joy. He climbed a tree and looked across to the village.The Baron’s castle was a ruin. The village was ablaze. Dead bodies were everywhere. And approaching, very close already, were dozens of bugbears wielding swords and axes and clad in rusty armour.Bugbears run fast, and they had already seen him, and who knows how many more there were spread through the woods? It is likely the only thing which saved him was an overeager bugbear bearing a flaming torch. It grinned, and thrust the firebrand into Sativa’s latest crop. Smoke billowed. Bugbears coughed and stumbled. Even Sativa, with his high tolerance, felt faint.Disliking violence, and with nothing to stay for, he stepped over the now-snoring bugbears and salvaged what he could - some clothes, food, and a half kilo of his finest greenery and a stock of seeds.Now, he travels the land, hoping to find a new home. To his astonishment, few places are grateful for his skill in herb growing and mushroom gathering, and he finds himself run out of town after town.One day, he hopes to find a place where he can be happy again.

Danell was a street urchin for most of his childhood, up until the revolution.  When Magenta's outer city fell into a state of civil unrest and eventually all-out war following the assassination of the king in the inner city by the visitors from another universe, Danell and his fellow kids formed a gang of child soldiers to help defend the townspeople from the royal guard, who had begun to be increasingly harsh, blaming the townspeople for the king's death.  Eventually a group of mercenary ex-artisans recruited the kids into a formal role in the war, and Danell personally helped to steal supplies from the barracks and run them to the city through the sewage lines.  In doing so, he befriended a flutemaker who happened to be a retired bard, Geo Nester, who taught Danell the basics of bardistry and even introduced him to the last surviving member of the group of outsiders.During a particularly important raid, one member of the group of artisans betrayed the group to the guards for a paltry sum, and the children were all captured.  Just as Danell was about to be executed, Geo and a few other artisans stormed the courtyard.  They were killed within minutes, but this gave Geo and a few of the other children time to escape.  Danell was supposed to meet up with the others, but he instead ran back to try to at least bury Geo's body — only to find it had already been fed to the wild animals.  He went back to the spot where they were supposed to meet, but nobody was there.  The gang of child soldiers was no more.  Some consolation could be found, however, in the fact that their “side” of the revolution, spearheaded by a relatively small religious group, did end up winning.After the city settled into order, renaming itself Fuchsia and forbidding any mention of Magenta, Danell was eventually recruited to the new city watch, where he worked to protect the citizens.  He would use his position to help out those less fortunate, and while not a major political player, was a member of a political organization devoted to easing the burden off the lower classes (so as to prevent another civil war).  He honed his skills at both the flute and the rapier, as well as practicing and improving the bardic magic taught by Geo.Until one day, when he would be assigned to a very important mission…

Ander Brightwood grew up as the son of a farmer in a nameless village. His life was mundane and simple, the normal life of a peasant.At the age of 16 Ander was conscripted into the army of a passing lord, forever changing his life. There is a need for more than soldiers in an army and Ander's stocky build and history with animals made him a good choice for the wagon trains that kept up with the army. He honed his ability to drive wagons and cook. He also picked up some of the Halfling language from the friendly folk that accompanied him.After a particularly bloody battle, Ander was pulled from the teamsters to fill a gap in the line. Despite his easy going demeanor and less than average intelligence, he became an adept spearman and would continue to serve in the line for several years.Ander's sergeant saw promise in the young boy and recommended him for training with sword and shield. Here, his size and strength made him a formidable soldier. He would attain the rank of corporal and become the standard bearer for his unit. He served with distinction and pride until and ambush his unit was caught in the path of dueling wizards on a battlefield. The group of swordsmen rushed to attack the enemy sorcerer, but most of them were burned alive by firebolts. Ander, dismayed by the deaths of his comrades around him, planted his banner and charged. Miraculously, he was not hit in the melee around him and was able to slay the mage.A promotion to the rank of sergeant was Ander's reward for surviving the battle, but he saw little point in continuing with the army. He had lost too much.After mustering out, returning home was Ander's goal. Unfortunately, being from an unnamed village and lacking the ability to read made for a difficult return journey.After wandering for a year and spending most of his funds from the army, Ander settled for mercenary work and a life of tavern gambling.When he sleeps, his dreams are a constant reminder of the oceans of blood he has waded through, but this does not deter his will to fight if he thinks it is for the greater good. He carries a piece of the robe from the wizard that wiped out his unit and harbors a hatred for combat magic and sorcerers. His combat experience makes him an adept fighter and his rank of sergeant proves that he is a leader of men.

Avric was born the second son of innkeepers in the south of the country of Thaver. When war came to Thaver, both Avric and his elder brother Felix joined the army, Avric as a footsoldier, Felix, who was more intellectually gifted, as a Lieutenant. The war lasted for 6 years, and when it was over, Thaver was defeated. There wasn't much glory or use for the defeated soldiers in a lost war, so Avric was left to serve as a day laborer in the town of Parrick. He could not afford a house, so he rented a room in the inn. He was a jovial sort, and managed to brighten the common room with his presence, which the innkeepers appreciated. He wrote to his brother often. After a couple years, however, a new road was made in Thaver, and traders passed less and less through Parrick. With fewer traders, the wages of a laborer grew less and less. He stopped responding to his brother's letters. Eventually, the jobs became scarce and Avric fell unemployed, and soon thereafter, homeless. During a rainstorm, Avric broke into the local temple for shelter and a place to sleep. Come morning, the Priest saw him and took pity on him, and hired him to work around the temple, and offered him lodgings and food. Avric never was much for religion, especially after the war, but the priest's kindness inspired something in him, and he devoted himself to caring for the temple. About a year later, the priest died and a new priest was brought in to shepherd the town. The new priest was not fond of Avric and threw him to the streets. Angry that his devotion was rewarded with such an injustice, Avric once again broke into the temple, and the new priest called the guards on him. He was arrested and sent to the regional prison, where he was cellmates with a halfling Jonn. Avric was a man of great stature, and as such he required more food than the prisoners' allowance. Jonn, as a halfling, did not need as much, and was inclined to share his meals. The two became friends soonafter. Five years into his imprisonment, there was a riot at the prison. Avric decided not to take part in it, but Jonn was killed in the battle. From then on Avric became much more solitary and cut off from the world. At the end of his ten year prison sentence, Avric was a broken man. He had no wealth to his name and a lifetime of weariness. The only thing he was ever any good at, in his mind, was fighting, so he became a mercenary, and traveled through the towns to look for work.

The youngest child and only daughter of Vennic and Alis d’Lyrandar, Shaelyn was born in the island city of Stormhome, the seat of House Lyrandar in Aundair.  Though stemming from an obscure branch of the Lyrandar bloodline, Shaelyn’s parents were longstanding members of the Windwrights Guild and raised their children to be as comfortable on dry land as on the deck of an elemental galleon.Expected to follow in her older brothers’ footsteps working as crew or dockside support for the elemental galleons and airships of House Lyrandar, Shaelyn was instead apprenticed into the Windwrights Guild after her Mark of Storm manifested at age thirteen.  Though her parents were at first disappointed that her arcane and navigation training would take her away from them and Stormhome, they quickly came around after realizing that Shaelyn would now be in a position to brush shoulders with some of the more powerful members of House Lyrandar in Sharn.After arriving in Sharn, Shaelyn was set up with one of the masters of the Windwrights Guild to begin her in-depth training.  Loraste was considered an expert, though a bit extreme in his teaching methods.  Shaelyn was quickly tossed into a “sink or swim” situation to learn a mix of everything – how to control the elements, predict and change the weather, minute details of navigation, and the finer points of sailing.  In her off time, she was expected to take geography classes a Morgrave University, and to study the many, many maps in the extensive library. With the end of the Last War and the current state of peace in Khorvaire, the viceroy of Lyrandar’s affairs in Sharn, Solia d’Lyrandar, decided that it was high time for the newest crop of recruits to begin hands-on training.  Under the guidance of Loraste, Shaelyn has spent the last few months as an apprentice navigator on several elemental galleons and airships voyaging in and out of Sharn.In addition to gaining practical knowledge of sailing and navigation, these trips taught Shaelyn other important skills.  She learned how to mediate between crews and captains, placate angry passengers, and to make small repairs.  She also learned more about Baron Esravash d’Lyrandar, the young and bold female head of House Lyrandar, and has dreamed about gaining prestige within the house through discovery of new experimental magic weapons for naval use.After returning from one such trip for a well-earned week of shore leave, Shaelyn bumped into two friends she had made while living in Sharn – Pippin and (Guid’s character).  Knowing that they would enjoy a getaway, she convinced the two to (stow away/buy a ticket/whatever fits with their backgrounds).  This pleasure cruise will be Shaelyn’s last as an apprentice under Loraste before being conferred the rank of navigator within the Windwright’s Guild.

He calls himself Bronze Fury, though it's unclear if that's what others in his clan called him or if it's a nickname of his own devising. Bronze Fury is young, rash, and thirsting for glory. A compact young man, wandering to prove himself, he comes from a proud race, the people of the dragon. They live on sere and rocky land, the northern face of Naemara's central mountain range.  They make a yearly trek up and down the north-western coast of Naemara. His war pick is really a native weapon, used for climbing, digging, and killing. Bronze Fury carries a chip on his shoulder. People do not like him when he's angry. Bronze Fury longs for the simpler time of his heroes, brave warriors of the tribe who defeated their enemies and protected their clan. These days his matriarchal society emphasizes trade and the precepts of society. Even the men, traditionally raised for an ordered defense of the tribe or foraging sorties into the jungle now end up fishing and gathering more than the women. So Bronze Fury takes his strength and his pride and strikes out his own path, as did the heroes of legends. He knows he will have a special place in his clan's history, he must first prove himself out in the world. Bronze Fury seeks renown and glory. The old stories tell of dragons, or at least one dragon, who patronized the People of the Dragon, visiting its rulership from across the sea. In a lot of ways the tribe of today reflects the ancient one subservient to the dragons: they are a LG nomadic tribe of ~200 humans that migrate between the frigid north then down south and west to the sea, staying in the foothills. They have close ties to the dwarves found under these mountains. The more mystically-inclined seek out the Renmul wood elves to learn their craft. The People of the Dragon used to be thought of as barbarians by the humans who inhabit the fishing villages of the coast and the outposts in the mountains, though in the last century they have gained some acceptance. This has been an active pursuit of the People, as they moved to adopt more modern ways. Some families have even settled permanently and taken up agriculture. Historically, the People have used the phrase "seeking a dragon" literally to mean searching for a dragon guardian for wisdom and guidance. Nowadays the phrase has a derogatory connotation, and refers to when a young tribesman does not agree with the Mothers, sometimes striking off to forge their own way. But in Bronze Fury's great-grandmother's stories to "seek a dragon" is to go find find yourself and prove your bravery. This is what Bronze Fury plans to do.

On one rainy night, Sabira Basha showed up at the home of Aseir Jassan, with a baby in her arms. The child was their illegitimate child born out of wedlock, and now that Sabira had birthed her, Sabira wanted nothing to do with her or with Aseir. Aesir took their child, and named her Vaalia. Unlike the mother of his child, he was instantly smitten with her, and vowed she would have a happy life. Vaalia had a happy, but mediocre upbringing, with her father rising through the guild artisan ranks to become a high-ranking guild artisan. Vaalia, however, had no interest in the world of the artisans, and found herself drawn to the arcane. Encouraging her scholarly pursuits, Aesir sought out a kindly wizard for her to study under. She was sent to live in the neighbouring town, under the tutelage of the wizard, away from her father, though they wrote often. Whilst she enjoyed and excelled in the scholarly aspects of her apprenticeship, and became fast friends with his other apprentice, she was dismayed to learn that her own magical capabilities were non-existent. The wizard, kind as he was, could do nothing to help her use magic. When Vaalia received news that her father was ill, the wizard sent her home with a potion to cure him, and the grave news that perhaps she was never meant to use magic. Distressed, she travelled back through the woods to her home town. She carried the potion, and some food in a basket, with the wizard assuring that he would send on the rest of her belongings in the morning, when they could arrange a cart and protection for it. In her haste and the dimming light of the setting sun, Vaalia tripped over a root, breaking her basket and along with it, the potion with the cure. As she watched all the potion sink into the ground, forever lost to her, a stranger appeared. A seemingly kind fellow, he offered to help her in exchange for some favours. The man offered his hand, seemingly to help her up, and as she took it he gave her a sly grin that revealed his arch fey nature. As she felt new magic course through her, she realised that she unwittingly entered into a pact with a fey.  When he withdrew her hand, she was left with a small crystal in her palm, and an empty forest. When Vaalia made it home, she administered her father’s potion, and he made a swift recovery. She stayed for some time to care for him, but eventually the time came for Vaalia to leave her home town and strike out into the world to see what else she could learn about magic, warlock pacts and the fey.

Nyiah grew up in a small village on the borders of the Eldwin Forest. Her father was a blacksmith and her mother a leatherworker. She spent the majority of her childhood either in her fathers shop, watching the forge fire or out playing in the woods with her best friend Loric. As she got older she became fascinated with fire, getting in trouble frequently for setting fires, though she was always careful not to let them damage other people’s property or harm anyone. Soon she discovered she had a spark for magic, able to perform small tricks and start small flames with a click of her finger. The only person she shared this secret with was her friend Loric, now grown up somewhat into a handsome young man. Soon they grew from friends to lovers and on Nyiah’s 16th birthday they were married in the town. Loric worked with Nyiah’s father as an apprentice blacksmith while Nyiah worked as a washerwoman to save up for a house. Soon she fell pregnant, and the couple moved into a house a few months before she gave birth to a child she named Emma.
