She continued working to provide for her daughter and the three of them lived happily together. A year later she was pregnant again and she hoped for a boy. One day as she was delivering a load of clean washing to her neighbour she heard a cry of alarm come from the towns edge and turned to see the sky turning red and grey from flames and smoke. Throwing the clothes to the ground she ran towards her house. As she approached, her worst fears were realised. Her house stood aflame, surrounded by bandits carrying torches and wicked axes. She screamed and threw fire before dashing inside with no fear for her own safety. “Emma! Loric!” Inside she found her parents, consumed by flame, ignoring the flames licking her skins she rushed back outside in time to see Loric being cut down by a bandit as her daughter screamed. Nyiah fired a bolt of fire at the bandit and killed him instantly as another bandit picked the crying Emma of the ground and drove a knife through the child’s body. Nyiah was consumed with rage and the flames around her swelled to cover her body, lashing out, she sent waves of fire through the entire town, incinerating townsfolk and bandits alike, when she came too nothing but ash and bones remained. Feeling a great pain in her stomach she looked down to find her legs covered in blood, an arrow imbedded in her belly and her unborn child miscarried.In the years to follow Nyiah wandered the wilds, killing bandits and other beings that threatened innocent villagers, soon she found herself in Tor amol, searching for something.

Calanthe “Callie” Tommard was born and raised in Yalistar and is the only child of Janna and Arden Tommard. She spent her younger years helping her mother with her apothecary and learning about herbalism from anyone willing to entertain her questioning. On the days that Callie spent in the forest with her father, a woodsman, she would try to bring back odd items including plant and animal parts, minerals, and colorful insects. Eventually these collections became harmless decoctions and infusions as Callie experimented making tonics, play-acting that she was one of the famous druid healers of Yalistar. Her reclusive nature hindered making friends with the other children of the city, and she had a relatively lonely childhood until her teenage years. Fed up with Callie’s antisocial behavior, her parents forced her to travel to Mandilin for a month to visit her cousins during the summer, coinciding with the Drawbridge Festival.It was during one of these month-long visits, made every year, that Callie met Bronwyn Ryll and Finnegan Dunn. Bronwyn bullied Callie into joining their game of hoodsman’s blind and though Callie disliked the other girl’s strong-willed nature at first, she realized she had fun playing with Bronwyn. When Finn was able to escape from his duties as an apprentice smith, Callie would tempt him into playing piquet and draughts, though he always beat her at both. At the end of the month when they presented Callie with a piece of onyx to take home to Yalistar as protection against the White Woman, Callie realized she had made new friends. The yearly visits to Mandilin never seemed so bad after that, even though she hated the crowds attracted by the Drawbridge Festival. Upon returning to Yalistar, Callie would spend several days sequestered in the back of her mother’s apothecary adjusting to the quiet without her friends. She would lose herself in the stillness grinding herbs and making tisanes, and occasionally experimenting with a decoction of her own. Though she had caused a few small accidents by overheating glass phials or mixing healing herbs with poisonous ones, no one expected the explosion. In addition to almost killing Callie, part of the root of the divine tree beneath which the shop was built was scorched and the outcry from the community was immediate. The Tommard name was blackened, and Callie was exiled from the city. She has yet to tell any of her friends what she did, and why she had to move to Mandilin for good.Through Bronwynn and Finnegan, Callie met Marin Caen. The group was together in Mandilin during the Emerald Lottery when all four of their names were drawn from the crystal vessel. Callie suspects her name bring drawn was a convenient way for her to disappear so she will be unable to cause more destruction, but has no real proof that the lottery was rigged.

Ezen is an old man now, but he's been studying magic since he was 17 years old.He was raised by loving parents and grew up well. They we're not poor, but they we're not wealthy either. Ezen had a fair life, if not a bit cold for some.Ezen grew up in the town of Holden in The Ever Reaching Rise, an area of very tall, snowy, and secluded, mountains in the north. His family had moved there before he was born seeking a close-knit community away from the bustle and trouble of the rest of the world. Ezen and his family found a home there. Ezen, and he grew up, began to take interest in Rummiara, the town Magic College.The magic fascinated him, especially how the basic elements of the earth could be manipulated and summoned at will. After his regular schooling, he enrolled at Rummiara as soon as he could.He is an old man now. He's 73 and studied magic for 56 years, and his taking a delicious nap. Suddenly, interrupting his sleep, a dull pinging rings in his head signifying someone has dropped a letter through his mail slot.It's a rare event, and Ezen is both curious and cautious. He lives alone near the top of the mountain now, not many know his address, and no one has ever delivered mail. He runs down the 161 stairs of his perfectly round mage tower to pick up the letter.It reads: "Ezen, I remember when you were so excited for magic and i hope you haven't dulled in your curiosity in your old age as some of my colleagues have. If you're up for some adventure, we at the college think we've located an object you may be very interested in. The Frozen Star. We don't know much expect that it's an object capable of near limitless power in the area of Evocation, and especially cold and ice. We at the college can't pursue it, either because we're either teaching students or are too lazy! If you find it, come drop by and show us."The letter was signed, "Fargrim". Fargrim was the most scholarly dwarf Ezen had ever met, and was his Evocation professor at the college. Fargrim was like Ezen's second father. He'd be about 250 now. The letter also contained a map with a circle around the area they believed The Star was.Overjoyed at this information, Ezen let out an excited YA-HOO. He's been looking for a reason to get out and quest, test out all his research, and an artifact of cold? what could be better?He grabbed as much adventuring supplies as he could stuff in his backpack along with his leather-bound spellbook that had a quite ornate snowflake on the front.Then donned his hat hung on a hook by the door, blew out all his candles, grabbed his staff, tipped his hat to the tower, and limped out the door.

Alicia comes from a wealthy family of minor nobles. She took naturally to wizardry, but her extraplanar interests confounded her tutors. So, she began to consort not (particularly) with dark powers, but with strange powers - many who speak dead tongues or live deep beneath the sea. Her behavior as of late has led to a certain amount of estrangement from her family. Her parents believe that Alicia's experimentations are having an adverse affect on her health and sanity, and have curtly refused to fund them any further. The relationship between Alicia and her parents is further complicated by the fact that Alicia’s elder sister, Esme Merideth de Luna, has recently pledged herself to serve the church of Cyndor as a paladin, renouncing her claim to the title of Contessa...which will now, unexpectedly, fall to Alicia.Alicia is undaunted. She considers herself bohemian, and cares little for any law but her own - including the natural laws of the prime material plane. She respects that others maintain and act upon their own beliefs, however, and does not court conflict with them - to each their own. She has an extensive correspondence with experts in a variety of fields, from diverse backgrounds with wide-ranging philosophical views. With them she is known (often under a pseudonym) as an expert in history, spellcraft, and the arcane - and most especially, of the planes. She quotes often from her readings, and has published a small number of well-regarded monographs, one of which has been censored by three churches - a fact of which she is quietly proud.Alicia is surprisingly well kempt for someone so distracted from the mundane, an appearance she maintains with cantrips out of habit. She has light brown skin that seems paler than it ought to, and fine features. Though petite, her breeding and training have gifted her with what actors call “presence”. She is polite and generally without malice, though ruthless under provocation.As a result of the meditations that allow her to command shadows of the denizens of alien planes, she has somewhat rearranged the furniture in her head, and her affect is subtly askew. (To give one small example, she has not yawned in over eleven years.) She tends to unnerve people, a fact which she is aware of - and unashamed of! - though she will make an effort to compensate for it if circumstances demand it. She is a talented liar, but only for advantage - she does not lie reflexively, or to toy with others. Her sense of humor is...unique.Her right eye is bright blue with an unusually small pupil; the left is charcoal grey; dark enough that it’s often difficult to tell where the pupil begins. (This is a physical consequence of her budding transcendence).When she wants to, she can become the nightmare image of the craftily and capriciously mad gentry. Lately that also seems to happen when she is short on sleep or abstracted.

I tell many stories of my origin, but none are true. I can't risk letting anyone know how I became what I am today. That information is just... too dangerous for ordinary men.So anyway, it began when I was a young man, ready to take on the world with nothing more than my bare fists and the clothes on my back. I was a high-flying and cocky rookie of the Domestic Protection Unit. We weren't much more than glorified exterminators, but damn near everyone in town knew our names. Every once in a while, we'd get something fun to do; fight some goblins, kill some raiders. This was one of those times. We were dispatched in the dead of night, with a map that lead to a supposed bandit outpost that was just a bit too close for comfort. We were prepared to kick more ass than a Taiwanese donkey trainer, but when we got there we were ambushed. They had hidden their numbers, and planned to swarm us. My entire group was decimated. I saw my best friend die in front of my very eyes. At that very moment, just as I charged in with my fist held high, something happened. Suddenly, I was struck by lightning, bitten by a radioactive rattlesnake, bombarded with gamma rays, and set on fire. Also my parents died.I blacked out harder than a drunken dwarf. When I woke up, I was standing on the top of a mountain. I was surrounded by the souls of dozens of kung-fu masters. They told me I was the spirit-descendant of the greatest martial artist of all time, and I was destined to carry on his incredible legacy. They used their ki to unlock a power inside me, and suddenly... I was a kung-fu master.They sent me back to the material world, and I woke up to find a scene so horrible it would make a succubus blush. The raiders had killed everyone. Filled with righteous fury, I charged into battle, and fought for hours. They were clearly no match for my incredible powers, but they were tenacious. After dispatching the rabble, I confronted the leader. We fought hand-to-hand, mano-a-mano. Of course, I was victorious. Before he died however, he knocked over a candle and it set fire to a nearby lamp-shade. Fire engulfed the building. I know that I ran, but I barely remember what happened. Eventually, I collapsed from exhaustion.I woke up in the courtyard, the warlord and his men were gone and I was left in the rubble.Realizing the immense responsibility that had been placed on my shoulders, I ventured out into the world, determined to fulfill my destiny. But I knew if this was to be accomplished, I would have to change my entire life. I took a new name, and promised to tell only the closest of souls my true origin. When I ran through the gates of the encampment, there was no more Lawrence Wolfgang.There was only Jackson Kickass.

I was once a professor at a university in Proliet, with my own office and my own private collection of books, teaching the next generation of geniuses, philosophers, and researchers that were bound to come out of this school. I was fairly young to be teaching, especially at a Proliet university, but that was my passion, I never went in depth into a particular study. I had a wife at home, Alahna, whom I had only recently married, and she, of course, was more brains than beauty. But that is what made her perfect: a brain to challenge and compliment my own. It was the perfect life for me..... Was.    One day, as I arrived home after a late lecture, I saw the door to my - our - house broken inward. Fearing the worst, I ran inside. All of the valuables in the house were gone. Okay. A robbery. A simple thief. A thief is there for the money, not blood, so no one was hurt, right? My Alahna must not have been home, otherwise they wouldn't have went through with it, right? I knew I was just trying to come up with a logical explanation for an unlikely outcome. As I knelt there, above who was once one the two most important things in my life, I came to a shocking realization....Knowledge.... knowledge doesn't matter. Knowledge doesn't give power. I could guarantee that Alahna was smarter than at least half of my fellow professors. What did that get her? Nothing. It didn't protect her or give her the ability to protect herself. What use was there in knowledge when this world was dictated by violence and strength? And if there was no use for knowledge, what use was there for me?    Coming to a decision that would not, could not, be changed, I left for my office at the university. As I entered, I closed the door behind me. I had intended to end myself alongside the physical representation of the last rock in my life, my rare book collection. Looking at the tomes now, I was disgusted. I strode towards them, destructive intent that I would have thought impossible for me earlier that day was on my mind. Reaching for the shelf, my hand grasped a delicate tome.....     And I was in a different place. Looking forward, I saw my hand clasping the same book I had grabbed on my shelf. But this wasn't my shelf. I looked side to side, and saw a seemingly endless aisle stretching on either side, lined with rows upon rows of books. These shelves looked ancient, yet in pristine condition, at the same time. A voice spoke into my mind. Since that day, that has been the only time I heard that voice, and yet I cannot recall what it said. Despite this, I know what I learned. Knowledge was power. And that meant this place was power, as it was knowledge incarnate. Now I work to preserve and expand that power, if not for my own sake, then for Alahna's.

BackgroundQuill is a 23-year-old human merchant and recent warlock. His great grandfather made a pact with a demon pledging a son in exchange for his house having one hundred years of prosperity.  He was born with a brand on his hand and his birth was met with a volcanic explosion destroying his house’s lands. Further disturbing maladies and coincidences in his family have left him the last scion of a once proud house.Distant relatives (3rd cousins) of the house Goldthorn took him in after his parents died.  They trained him in their family business as weapons merchants.  Owing to his significant skills of persuasion he was quickly able to prove his capability to pursue lucrative contracts with the guild and his adoptive family's support.  Despite his successes the leadership of the guild keep a wary eye on him due to his severe temper, especially after the incident where he nearly strangled to death a small town mayor who tried to renege on a deal with his bare hands.  His temper has always been quick but as he has gotten older he’s begun to feel power emanating from his brand.  It seems to whisper to him in his moments of passion.After a few years of working on others behalf the perfect opportunity arose.  It was a gamble taking that large of a loan from the Goldthorns against everything he owned, but the temptation to tackle a lucrative contract on his own was too promising of an opportunity to pass up. He put together a caravan including a young half orc named Biter as a caravan guard.  After successfully delivering the weapons, he and his caravan celebrated that evening by drinking Biter’s potent "experiments" at the local tavern.  In the pre dawn morning he awoke with a powerful hangover and the previous night a blur. Confused he should have awoken to a hot bath and payment awaiting at the town’s bursar.   Instead he awoke to the ruins of a smoldering tavern. It took all of his presence of mind to grab Biter (his only other surviving caravanner), and take them on his cart out of the village as quick as the mule would go.  Soon the villagers would be looking for the cause of destruction with pitchforks (or worse considering the recent delivery of weapons).  With a worrying glance at his brand as the smoke from the inn fades in the distance he reflects on his change of fortune.  He contemplates a new path, at least until he can figure out what happened that night and how to repair all the things that have gone wrong and the bridges he’s burnt.Since fleeing the town he has discovered new powers that he has begun practicing with.  Additionally he has been surprised and touched that Biter has stayed with him through this trying time.  What do you do when you when you want to turn over a new leaf in life?  You head home!  Upon reaching Neverwinter the town where he was born, he found work with a dwarf named Gundren Rockseeker.  He will join an escort to protect a caravan en route to Philandren.  Some day he will figure out what is this dark power in him is, he will repair relations with the Goldthorns, and he will restore his house from the ruins of Corlinn Hill.  Until then he will survive.

Tristram was born in Katagia, the first and only son of Starn and Vinvella Arverus. Like many citizens of the “Last Bastion of Atlantis,” Tristram is of Atlantean blood, and has always lived like one, born with a silver spoon in his mouth. The wealth of a three-generation-long mercantile empire of the Arverus family combined with Vinvella’s youth and wits (being that she is twenty years younger than her aging husband), led Tristram to have a pampered, perhaps even spoiled, upbringing.As the child of such doting parents, Tristram was provided an education on a small but sizable fortune. Starn and Vinvella wanted nothing but the best for their son and hired only the best tutors to cultivate their son’s growing mind. Tristram excelled in the subjects that interested him: history, medicine, religion, and most importantly, magic. It wasn’t long before Starn and Vinvella realized they would need to find a teacher of more occult leanings.By chance, while gambling at the Katagian pits, Starn met a surly, but well-spoken man named Graeme, a self-proclaimed “scientist” who conducted necromantic experiments on the unwanted corpses of pit fighters who perished in the arena. Although Graeme was never the mentoring type (unsurprising considering how irritable and antisocial he was most of the time) he was in need of an assistant. Starn’s goodwill and trusting character got the better of him, and at the age of fifteen, Tristram began to study science and magic under Graeme as his apprentice.Graeme and Tristram’s relationship was rocky at the best of times. While Graeme acknowledged Tristram’s intellect in private, he never professed such thoughts aloud and instead often patronized Tristram to the point of bitter arguments. Despite their differences, Tristram always came back the next day and Graeme continued to tutor him for the next six years. However, as Tristram grew older and began to more adamantly challenge Graeme’s theories, the old wizard pushed back harder and their already unstable relationship fell apart. For a few years, Tristram studied on his own during the twilight hours, while working for the family business during a more reasonable time of day. Mind you, it wasn’t genuine interest that brought Tristram to the family business, but the prospect of freedom, coin, and power. You see, over the years Tristram had developed a want for importance, lusting for fame and glory, but not from simple merchantry or with Graeme’s name attached. Tristram wanted real power, the power of conquest, the power over life and death, to seek forgotten relics, forbidden knowledge and making coin all along the way. Tristram had a plan: escort a merchant galley along the coasts of Thule, all the way to Quodeth and make off with the merchandise, the gold, all of it, leave his parents, his teacher, all of Katagia behind him and make a name for himself, a name to be respected, perhaps even feared. Unfortunately, his plan never quite came to fruition, as the merchant galley was sacked by pirates outside Marg and he was left with nothing but the gold on him as he washed up on the shores of Thule.Marooned, Tristram trekked through the wilderness and found himself, by chance in Quodeth, ragged, hungry, and injured, but demoralized? Oh, no. His tenacity was fueled on pure spite, and desire for vengeance against the pirates that took the gold that was his to steal.

At 6 feet tall and 158 pounds, Arthos is tall and skinny. He has fair skin and light, almost white hair. His origins are a mystery. He was found as a baby by the Wizards of the Green Eye in the doorway of their tower one morning. Hoping that this would bring them fortune, or possibly that it was a test of the Gods, they decided to bring him up and teach him the ways of magic. Sadly this was an almost complete failure as he demonstrated absolutely no talent whatsoever. However, he retains a fascination for all things magical and will invariably opt to get hold of magical seeming things if possible. Misguidedly he believes that is merely practice that he lacks rather than native intelligence. He only speaks Common but knows lots of magical words, without necessarily understanding their significance.The Wizards of the Green Eye retain a great fondness for him (even though they make fun of him behind his back), and he a loyalty to them for their support. In part this comes from the services he has done for them over the years, using his strength and nimbleness for things like cleaning gargoyle poo out of the gutters  (the bursar told him that it was a valuable ingredient for spells). In spite of his attempts to become a magician coming to nothing, he nevertheless has the soul of an adventurer. His facility for combat first came to light when a failed experiment created a swarm of giant bees which began to menace the residents of the tower. He rescued one wizard, out of spells, by hurling ornamental stones from the rockery with great accuracy at the bess, smashing them to pulp. He subsequently extracted an intact stinger from one of the insects, prizing it for its lustrous qualities. However he began to annoy the wizards owing to his tendency to slaughter any flying creatures – friendly or otherwise - that he came across, though they admired his skill with missiles.His reputation was sealed when the Wizard's Tower was attacked by a force of brigands who used a spell that put all magic using creatures inside the building to sleep. Arthos was, of course, unaffected, and leapt to defend the tower from being pillaged. He took out several bandits with hurled crockery filled with gargoyle poo before being cornered by the leader. In desperation he pulled out his stinger and fenced with it, scratching the man's unprotected wrist. To his surprise the bandit collapsed, swelled up and died. The other bandits ran for their lives. Arthos is convinced either that the stinger is magical or that he somehow performed a spell to save his friends, in spite of no divination showing any evidence of either. The locals nicknamed him “Stinger” in honour of this  feat (a definite step up from Bonehead), something he is quite proud of.Recognising his talents and the need to get rid of someone with a tendency to assassinate homunculi, familiars and butterflies, the Wizards suggested that he had the potential to be a “Warrior Mage”. This naturally involved him going somewhere else to learn the Warrior part. After some initial lessons at the local fighting school he has set off to find his fortune, vowing to return when he has mastered both magic and combat so that the wizards will be truly proud of him.

Viktor Katz was born on a farm near a village in Krynn. A small village, surrounded by hilly woods on one side and farm lands on the other.As he came into the world, he was possessed by a newly spawned demon. The demon would randomly take control of his body and commit mischief, causing Viktor’s family a lot of grief. Putting fragile objects close to edges, putting round objects in walkways to cause trips, etc. At first Viktor, being the innocent child he is, was amused by the mischief. However, as the years progressed the mischief turned more gruesome. Harming small animals, dissecting the barn cats, etc.When Viktor was 10, the demon caused his 4 year old brother Alexander to drown in the river near the farm. Viktor, not knowing being possessed is not normal, tells his parents he did it. His parents just think he says it out of survivor guilt.At the age of 12 the demon inside Viktor escalates to murdering a couple of the villagers, and does so undetected. Except Viktor, who witnessed every murder.On his 13th birthday, the demon decides to kill his family. The demon sneaks up on Viktor’s parents as they sleep and knocks them out with a club. The demon then has Viktor tying up both of them, before overpowering his little sister Anna and tying her up as well. Then, once Viktor’s father is awake, the demon uses Viktor to kill his sister and mother while his father is helpless. As the demon controlled Viktor finally cuts his father’s throat, a neighbor happened to be dropping by and hears the screaming from outside. The demon takes the backseat again, and watches as Viktor collapses in horror and grief. The neighbor returns with a posse he rallied, and they lock him away. As they discuss what to do with him, a traveling cleric of Mishakal called Lukas hears of the horrible murders, and comes to investigate. The town elders allow Lukas to examine Viktor, while they watch. The demon responds fiercely to the cleric’s holy powers and, with Viktor being restrained, finally leaves the boy’s body to battle the cleric in its true form. The cleric manages to vanquish the demon after a hard fought battle.The town elders, having witnessed the battle, set the boy free, but are not willing to take him in. Lukas takes him with him to the main temple of Mishakal, where Viktor is raised by the acolytes of the temple, who also train him over the years to be a cleric, as Viktor has made it his mission in life to prevent what happened to him from happening to anyone else.At the age of 18, having become an actual cleric with Mishakal’s blessing, he starts traveling the world, at first along with Lukas, and after a couple of years decides to set out on his own.After multiple decades of travel, in his 59th year, Mishakal’s calling leads him to travel into the mists that lead to Barovia. Unbeknownst to him Mishakal had sent Lukas to Barovia many years before, where he had been driven insane by Strahd. Mishakal sent Viktor to rescue Lukas, and to aid him in what might be a lengthy mission, she slows his aging down to a mere trickle. As always, his goddess leads him to places, but that is the extent of the interaction. He himself has to figure out what needs doing.

Denizens of the Kymal Badlands are no strangers to dark deals and backstabbing.  The political landscape of the region is tumultuous at best and open war at worst.  The warlords who call themselves the Barons of the land are in a constant struggle against one another to grab any small amount of power they can.  Rayleigh Oromund spent his formative years witness to countless treacherous pacts.  He was fortunate enough to be born into the relative wealth of a “royal” family in the Kymal Badlands.  His uncle is the greedy and bloodthirsty Baron Morgan.  His mother and father, loyal servants to Morgan, were granted a lavish lifestyle and Rayleigh had a privileged upbringing.  He was trained to fight from an early age and groomed for command of part of Morgan’s army.  Rayleigh takes great pride in his skill as duelist, even if he isn’t keen on fighting fair.  He will go to any length to defeat an enemy, honor is meaningless to him.  After all, in the Kymal Badlands honor and chivalry will leave you on the ground with a knife in your back.  Rayleigh was seemingly set to live in relative ease compared to the majority of residents of Kymal.  Perhaps that’s why he caught the ire of Baron Morgan.  In his paranoia, the Baron saw Rayleigh as a treat to his rule.  He invited Rayleigh on a hunting trip, during which he was set upon by the Baron and his men who tortured him, lashed him to a tree, and left him for dead, telling his family he had died in an hunting accident. For 4 days and nights he suffered.  Delusional from hunger and dehydration he slipped in and out of consciousness and lost all sense of time.  In what felt like his dying moments, in a last ditch effort for survival, he called out for aid from anyone who was listening. Recalling books he had read about powerful extraplanar entities, he begged for a chance at life, whatever the cost be.  An obscure and ominous entity reached out to him.  It offered him power and a chance at revenge.  It offered a deal: Become a soldier in it’s army, a piece in it’s plan, and in return have a chance at revenge.  Rayleigh accepted.  He awoke the next day invigorated, unbound, and with a mysterious pendant around his neck.  Rayleigh traveled south towards the wall, instructed by his patron to hone his powers before confronting his family.  Rayleigh had 2 impossible tasks ahead of him.  Crossing the wall into Acelia was nigh impossible, and once across he would have to hide his identity, lest he be deported or killed on the spot.   He was fortunate enough to happen upon a group of freelancers, the dwarf Ukrag “Krag” Duli and his party from. Rayleigh begged for help and gave a show of his newly acquired powers.  Ukrag helped Rayleigh recover and inducted into his group where Rayleigh worked for free as repayment doing various odd jobs of questionable morality.Krag and Rayleigh eventually went their separate ways.  It’s been more than a year since they last spoke and Rayleigh has been wandering around as a sellsword doing various odd jobs.Rayleigh has received no guidance from his patron since he was ordered to hone his skills.  He is hiding his background and offering his services as a mercenary.  He loves the work he does even if he is relatively poor and under-equipped at the moment.

Bobert Dobbs is a neutral human illusionist. He's out to find and loot an ancient temple for artifacts. He also occasionally makes references to being a Duke of Waterdeep, and has a great fake signet ring to go with his charlatan backstory. In reality he's got a wife and three daughters who live next to his mentor's mage tower. His recent jail time was for running a ball and cups scam on a town guardsman.  While technically it was an illusion discovered it was really subconsciously self-inflicted so he could get some breathing space away from Connie and the girls. You would think a learned wizard with an unnaturally high IQ and eidetic memory would remember to take the garbage out at night, but Connie always seems to be reminding him to do chores and constantly reminds him of his other failings as a member of a functioning household. Bobert met his wife while they were running scams together in the city and she's quite a talented rogue herself.   Once the kids arrived, Connie got sensible, Grew Up and Became Responsible.   Bobert is a bit baffled by the change.   Like, he gets the concept of Responsibility and knows why it's good to have.  He has nothing but respect for the responsible people (when he isn't scamming them).  But, when the boots hit the trail it's just not something that he applies to his everyday life.   His usual coping mechanism when faced with things he doesn't want to deal with is to reduce it down to immediate comforts like "Why is there no good wine on this Demiplane of Evil?" or "Instead of talking to these spooky druids why don't we just fireball them and be back at the inn by sunset?"  He's realized illusions are one of the best ways to avoid thinking/dealing with the truly awful things that happen in the world.  That said, Bobert adores his wife as much as anyone (other than himself) in the world.   Leaving home on a moment's notice to find and loot a temple wasn't really a family decision.  The intensely angry response when he got home was answered with a "Sorry honey, trapped on a Demiplane of Evil!  No way to get a message back!  Hey look at this amazing staff and chest of gold!"  Although he does drive Connie crazy she realizes he's still the wild and fun guy she fell in love with.  She just expected him to, you know, GROW UP eventually.   She's still waiting.Bobert's daughters LOVE their dad.  With his illusions he is the BEST quasi-adult playmate EVER and stuffed monster tea parties with Dad are AWESOME. He's a 'kids should be free to be kids' type in his head but it actually turns out more as an 'I don't set healthy boundaries with children and really most things they break can be fixed with a mending cantrip so why worry' absentee parent. He has a soft spot for kids but after saving them he's blind to any supervisory needs and just kind of assumes they more or less take care of themselves (kind of like cats).           Once he learns the secrets of Ultimate Wisdom and gains Artifacts of Awesome Power his plan is to make the entire family thing actually work for a change and give them all a good life. Unfortunately a few steps in The Plan For Family Success are a bit hazy and his general plan is to simply throw an excessive amount of money and/or magic at things until they're fixed.  It's also more than likely he'll just move on to some other messed up scheme and end up back where they started.    Anyway, after looting that temple and getting rich, maybe he'll get Connie a maid and this whole 'you never take out the trash Bob' thing will blow over.

Shay was born to the Milliners in Harstvale. Her father was a milliner by profession, but Harstvale was not a place that ever seemed in particular need for fancy hats. Her father had never really fit in at Harstvale and he'd always wanted to leave and take his hat-making skills to one of the big cities, but he and her mother, the butcher's daughter, had accidentally conceived Shay when they were fooling around for the first time. When her mother was discovered to be pregnant, her father was forced into a spearpoint wedding that would tie him down to Harstvale forever. Being tied down was particularly difficult because her father never really liked women in that way, but people like him didn't fit in in Harstvale, so he had tried to make things work that one time with her mother, and he was a shocked as she was to find out that she was pregnant.Oddly she doesn't really bear much of the features of either her father or her mother. The person that bears the most resemblance to her is the town drunk, a half-elf with green eyes and auburn hair that had been an archer in the wars against Tiamat and had come to the town with nightmares and a habit for drinking. Her mother says that the resemblance with this half-elf is pure coincidence.Her mother named her Beshada, after the goddess of ill fortune. There might be some truth to her name; her mother was watching her one day near the edge of the forest when a group of Goblins came out of the forest and abducted her mother and left her screaming alone for help near the trees. Since then, she has been raised only by her father, who calls her Shay.She was always mischievous and the town of Harstvale all took an interest in trying to raise her, and it was when she was young that she first took up archery. The town drunk, Delaan, gave her a bow on her 6th birthday, the year after her mother disappeared. He has always claimed that he was too drunk to remember buying it for her, but Shay thought it looked curiously like it had been hand-made in the style of Delaan's own bow. It was almost as if Shay had some elven blood in herself, since she took to archery so naturally. She had soon surpassed the abilities of all the grown men in town except for Delaan who would always stand by and watch her shoot in competitions and the like, and it seemed to be the only time when he wasn't laying about drunk.Like her father, Shay also loves to make hats, and she creates them in a variety of colors. For herself, she likes to wear a green hat with a red feather in the hat, but she's frequently putting something together in her spare time.Once she was older, her village was besieged by a band of Goblin that had decided to work together for some ridiculous reason. No one could really fight them, and the whole town was destined to die, until Beshaba challenged their bugbear leader to a fight. He came out ready to crush her, but she pulled out a sling and a stone and hit him right in the eye, and he fell down dead.Shortly after this, her father sat her down and explained that he couldn't stand to see her get stuck in Harstvale just like he did. It was difficult, but he told her how much he admired her, and that it was her responsibility to get out and be his eyes to see the world. He taught her too that it was her duty to use her talents to help those that cannot help themselves and that change only happens when people stand up and fight for it. So she left, determined to make the world a better place.

Shula Shaga was Riverbridge born and Riverbridge bred. Although her family was never particularly wealthy, they always had enough to get by, and going hungry was a rarity, typically happening only during the occasional economic downturn. At 14, when she was old enough, she began her apprenticeship to Glimrock Axenhammer, one of the guild's finest blacksmiths, and though she was neither the fastest learner, nor the most skilled, she was certainly the most persistent, and by far the slowest to give up in the face of frustration and failure.A few months after her apprenticeship finished at age 20, however, a mercantile caravan with which she was traveling found itself ambushed near an entrance to the Underdark by what appeared to be some manner of fish-men. A blow to the head knocked her senseless, and before long she was bound, paralyzed by some manner of poisoned crossbow bolt that was now sticking out of her left shoulder, and being dragged toward the entrance.At some point, her consciousness left her; when she awakened, she found herself right back where she had been captured, slumped unceremoniously over one of the caravan's dead, slightly-rotted horses alongside the corpses of the caravan's guards, although not all of them. Despite having no idea what had happened during that time, she also discovered that she somehow knew roughly how long she had been gone — nearly a week. Additionally, however, she found that she had absolutely no curiosity whatsoever about how she came by that information, nor about what had happened during that time; and nor did she find her lack of curiosity at all strange.So, barring any feeling that anything was amiss, aside from the caravan attack itself, she simply made her way back to town by way of hitching a ride with a passing carriage; and, after some medical attention for her shoulder wound — sadly too late to avoid a prominent, and always slightly sore, scar — she returned to her life of forging weapons and armor for the city guard, the local militia, and anyone else with coin, and occasionally volunteering with said militia to help take out minor threats outside town, be they bandits or bears.And thus did it continue for a number of years. But ever-present in Shula's mind, whispering at both her conscious and unconscious, was a deep and abiding desire to do *something's* bidding — and not just any something, but that of an Ulitharid, a tentacled flayer of the mind from the darkest parts of the underground; and moreover, that of the Elder Brain with which leads and directs the colony. Alongside that desire came a second one: The desire to keep that knowledge, the information about her servitude, to herself.Unknown to both Shula *and* the Elder Brain, however, was that this Ulitharid, the very same being that had led the process of enthralling her in the first place, was no ordinary one of its kind (if any of them could indeed be called ordinary at all), but one who had secretly turned to the arts arcane to augment its own natural abilities — a being known among the Illithid as an Alhoon, seen as a deviant to be purged once discovered, for Alhoons worked not for the continued survival and betterment of the colony and the Elder Brain, but for their own self-interest, with many striving toward lichdom. And indeed, unknown to the Elder Brain, its own control over Shula was entirely a sham, with the Alhoon simply relaying the same commands when given in order to maintain the Brain's illusion of control.These desires and orders conflicted frequently with her innate desire for independence and honesty, and the mental anguish produced by the clash was extreme, particularly during the times when the Alhoon compelled her against her will to perform actions she found distasteful or even abhorrent: Revealing information about the goings-on in the city, or spying on certain important individuals, or even the removal of others. To what end, she did not know, and with the control exerted by the Alhoon, she had not even the *ability* to desire to speculate.But she did have the ability, very much so, to be afraid.

Long ago, when her name was Brynd, she lived in the distant border land of Odrith, among the vineyards tended by her father. Her mother was a known adventuress, the town witch-doctor, and a local hero of no small repute.  All this was fine and normal for a country girl.  The land even enjoyed peaceable co-existence with the nearby goblins of the Yk_d, but there were so many of them. Then came the day when the hobgoblins and orcs came down from the mountains and whipped the Yk_d into a frenzy.  The people of Odrith rallied around their heroes, and in mortal combat withstood the onslaught of the horde at tragic cost.  Her mother fell in battle, and despite all help and good intention, her father was ruined afterward.  The vineyard failed and there was not enough food for either of them, until the Winter Carnival came to town.  The master of ceremonies expressed an interest in her singing and dancing talents, so her father let them take her.  But when he later realized he had sold his daughter to the circus for food, he fell into darkness and despair.The child travelled with the Winter Carnival for months and years. Never one for book-learning, she quickly enough caught on to the tricks of the carnies, the acrobatics of the tumblers, and the Sword Dance of the Bessarabian Cossacks. (Though the clowns really creeped her out.)  When she came of age, she made her debut as “Augustanna Fortune” and delighted audiences around the countryside with her dazzling displays.  In due time, the Winter Carnival arrived in the Imperial City of Rochaven, and performed for the Garnok Emperor himself.  Augustanna caught the eye of the Emperor, and he took her in among his court, where she quickly became recognized as a favorite of the Emperor.  This led to all kinds of unwanted attention from obsequious courtiers, and especially drew the ire of the evil Barnaby, the court jester, who was always plotting against the throne. Now, the Emperor was a good patron to Augustanna, and a noble steward of the Empire.  He was, though, not bold and visionary like his predecessor, nor brash and ruthless like those who would follow him.  He was an old warrior, just keeping the throne warm between ages of Imperial glory.  Barnaby never saw Augustanna as more than the Emperor’s tart of the moment, until she foiled his plots to bring about the Emperor’s downfall.  Though Barnaby’s treachery was not fully revealed, the Emperor saw that it was no longer safe for Augustanna in the Imperial court. He released her from his service, but gave her the protection of his finest Assassin of the Imperial Guard, Colonel Nors Spikes and his henchmen (Rolf and Pauly).She made her own way in the city of Rochaven, avoiding the truly abhorrent, but ultimately falling in with a vile, fat tiefling named Tobin Chort for a manager.  With help from Col. Spikes, she learned the ways of the street, rising above Chort’s machinations to become quite the celebrity in town.  Against better judgement, she was still a frequent guest at the Imperial palace, until the night the Emperor died.  (It should be noted that he passed peacefully, in his sleep, through no obvious fault of hers.)  It all happened so fast … Augustanna was ushered out of the palace that night by Col. Spikes to safety, but Barnaby made sure to raise implications that she was involved in the murder plot when the new emperor started an investigation.She finally had to leave the city.  Col. Spikes had arranged for her passage on board the clipper “Marathon”, captained by Laras Trent.  They learned that Rolf had been killed.  Col. Spikes then ordered Pauly to escort her through the murky back streets of Rochaven to the harbor, but they were beset by the jester’s goons.  She saw Pauly die before they could reach the rendez-vous point.  On her own, Augustanna lurked on the docks while the watchmen of the Imperial Guard confronted Captain Trent.  Yes, he was supposed to carry a girl out of the city, but she had never shown up. They searched the ship and found nothing; only after the guards departed did she sneak aboard and disappear onto the midnight seas.

The fourth son of a military commander, Markus grew up idolizing his father and the military. Dreaming of becoming a soldier like his father, Markus did his best to learn as much as possible from his father in the short time that he knew him. When he was 9, the elder Drakarhis was slain by an orc during a night time raid on their camp while defending the border from potential threat. Haunted by the death of his father and racked with guilt at his inability to do anything to save him, Markus IV sunk into depression. Despite his age, Markus blamed himself for his father's death, believing that if only he were old enough to join the military then he would have been able to save his father. After years of private training and education, 14-year-old Markus enrolled in the military academy with the aim at being the soldier that he knew he could be, the one that would make his father proud.Shortly after enrollment, it became obvious to those around him that he was gifted. His peers became jealous while Markus developed a sense of superiority over them. While he was not outwardly callous in his treatment of his peers, he developed a sense of arrogance towards them that his teachers picked up on almost immediately. In order to curb this, the head of the academy immediately withdrew Markus from his martial training and placed him in the care of the army clerics of Vartiel - hoping that it would prevent the young Markus from further developing his arrogance, while teaching him the structure that he sorely needed.In the beginning, Markus rebelled against the teachings of Vartiel, viewing them as overly regimented and pointless in his ultimate goal in becoming a soldier. It was not until he met Kildrak Ungar, a battle-priest of Valtiel, did he become aware of just how connected the teachings of his God and the tenets of the military were. With renewed vigor, Markus set out become not only the best soldier in the military, but a battle-priest beyond compare.Upon graduation, which coincided with his 21st birthday, Markus had made a name for himself that would have undoubtedly made his father happy. The arrogance banished and his training over, Markus was assigned to a small border town that had come under attack several times by bands of orcs and the occasional group of bandits. All of his dreams were finally coming true and he relished the opportunity to further make a name for himself and rise in the ranks of the military. Unbeknownst to Markus, however, his time in the military would be a short one.The first night after his arrival, the town came under attack by a large band of orcs. They burned, killed, and pillaged anything in sight and the small regiment was no match for them. Knowing this must be what his father had seen before drawing his last breath, Markus was paralyzed with fear and guilt, unable to assist in the defense despite having every desire to do so. The town was almost completely destroyed and most of his regiment, his friends and new family, were murdered. The few survivors blamed Markus and his inaction for the slaughter and he was immediately discharged with great shame.Unable to face his family back home, Markus wandered the wilds on his own, trying to seek solace in whatever he could find. He blamed himself, he blamed the orcs, but mostly he blamed Vartiel for seemingly abandoning him. Turning his back on his faith, Markus attempted several times to take his own life as the depression of his youth resurfaced. Unsuccessful, he continued to wander from town-to-town doing odd jobs when he could and sleeping in stables when he could not.This continued for some years until a fateful encounter with a priest of Stagg. Who, after some time in his company, managed to convince Markus that his past was nothing to be ashamed of and that all was not lost. At 27, he converted to the worship of Stagg, believing that the warrior God enabled him to use his skills as a battle-priest while avoiding the rigid tenets of Vartiel. Deciding that while his military life was a failure, his life did not need to be and his name did not have to remain sullied. And so, with renewed vigor, he would reinvent himself as a mercenary and guardian for the poor, downtrodden and helpless. Protecting them from the evils that would do them harm... with a hammer and a prayer.

Tess Evenwood is a good person at heart, though gives the first impression of an inconsiderate jerk. She cares about helping people, she just has none of the social skills to show it. She speaks very directly, without regard for common courtesy, has a tendency to ignore people when she's doing something important, and is often oblivious to her surroundings and the people in them. All that aside, Tess has expert focus when plying her trade. 	Tess grew up in the enormous metropolis of Waterdeep, City of Splendors, exposing her to all sorts of people and faiths. And while her parents held very free-thinking views on the subject of the gods, they still insisted she find and devote herself to one above all others. Uncertain, she often wandered the temple districts to eavesdrop on services or clerics discussing their faiths. All these gods seemed so far above common men and women, she could smell their apathy for their followers and she failed to embrace any major faith which distressed her parents to no end. Then, as she wandered near the city gates to watch travelers arrive she met someone a bit different. He had to be the most jovial, high-spirited elf ever to visit Waterdeep. Rhistel, or Rhis, noticed her stares and came to greet her. Befuddled by his convivial attitude, she asked why he did not take his visit more seriously. “Life should be filled with good times and laughter! These merchants work so hard for their wealth, but I never see them enjoy it!” That took her aback as she thought of her own dour-faced parents in their all too serious lives. Seeing her interest, he told her about his adventures in the High Forest and his many travels. When she expressed shock that he could just go off adventuring on a whim, he laughed, “How else would you go? After heavy thought? Best to go on a whim, before you can change your mind.” That too left her stunned, and as she asked more about him, Rhis began to tell her about his goddess Lurue, the Unicorn Queen. Far from the distant and uncaring gods of the temple district, Lurue felt more connected to her followers and the world. When she mentioned that, Rhis nodded and told her about his trip to the Unicorn Run: a river descending the southern face of the Star Mounts. She’d heard of the place, a pristine forest where tradition held the gods of the forest walked. He smiled again, and nodded. He’d seen his goddess there, walking the forest in the guise of a unicorn. Then he knew which of all the gods deserved his worship. Awed as only a ten-year-old could be, Tess found her faith in service to the demi-god Lurue.Stories about heroic adventurers and daring deeds abounded, as more than a few of those adventurers passed through the city’s markets in search of rare items or provisions on their journeys further north. Tess stood in awe of them… they were all so… stupid. Running around in ancient ruins or fighting off hordes of monsters! Getting maimed or killed! Stabbed, shot, bitten, clawed, poisoned, plague-stricken. Driven mad by horrors below. What kind of fool ran off into that sort of danger? And yet… they did so much good, even as they ran off in search of dubious treasures. Someone needed to keep an eye on those morons. Patch them up.At the age of 14, Tess saw the gods cast from the heavens during the Time of Troubles, causing her to doubt their real power and the nature of her world. At the time, she had been studying Lurue’s faith and seeking guidance as to her future profession. The crisis of the gods did at last conclude, with the fallen deities returning to their celestial homes. Sadly, that happy ending came at Waterdeep’s expense. Myrkul, Lord of Bones and former god of death, attacked the city in a desperate bid for power. He attempted to slay the adventurers who had resisted him, the very people whose actions brought this chaos to an end. With Myrkul slain, two of those adventurers ascended to become gods themselves. Leaving behind ruins in Waterdeep’s dock district. Tess ran out to volunteer what little medical aid she could. She saw the importance of healing those brave heroes that had stood against such evil, and too in the healing of all those wounded in those battles. She took it as a sign from Lurue, dedicating herself to the healing arts so that she could keep adventurers alive and clean up after their messes.

The downward slide in prominence of many noble Waterdhavian Houses has been just one of the many consequences of the Spellplague.  Though once powerful and influential, House Thann and House Wands had both slowly diminished in status since the initial outbreak in 1385, the Year of Blue Fire.  Determined to reverse this decrease in standing, Rhammas Thann III and Marcina Wands saw a union between their houses as an ideal beginning to restore their previous prominence.The result of the union?  Adelina Cassandra Thann - her parents’ best hope for the future of their bloodlines.  From an early age Adelina showed her proclivity towards arcane magic, perhaps a result of both sides of her lineage breeding true.  She was tutored briefly by her cousins in House Wands before they abruptly canceled the lessons, stating that Adelina was “too stubborn” to be taught.  She lasted even less time at the fabled Blackstaff Tower, where she was dismissed within a week for being “too unsuited to a life of quiet study and scholarship.”  Though the apple of Rhammas’ eye, her father was livid upon learning that Adelina was discharged from the very school of magic created by her many times great-grandfather, Khelben Arunsun.Upon reaching her majority at the age of sixteen, Adelina was granted several vineyards in the South to control and maintain.  Meant as a way for her to prove herself worthy of managing the family business, she considers the job tedious and prefers to delegate the work to others.  Paying only enough attention to be able to take a controlling hand when things go badly, she has charmed her bailiff and steward into performing all the menial, though necessary, day-to-day management duties.  Adelina is only known to visit her holdings when her quarterly percentage of profits is due, which she promptly fritters away in the typical spendthrift ways associated with young nobles.  This attitude towards work and money had gotten Adelina through most of her teenage years and into her early twenties, right up until she met Renaer.When not slumming it at the taverns and festhalls in the Dock Ward with other bored young nobles, Adelina can often be found at Tymora’s Fancy, a gambling establishment in the North Ward.  It was there that she first laid eyes on Renaer Neverember, the son of the Open Lord of Waterdeep.  Though Renaer has only spoken to her once or twice, Adelina harbors a secret crush on him and is jealous of his relationship with Laraelra Harsard.  In an effort to draw his attention towards her and away from Laraelra, Adelina accepted an invitation to join the “Disciples of Darkness,” a group of indolent noble scions who claim to supplicate devils for their own petty ends.  In reality, the false cult laughed their way through pseudo-religious rituals around smoky braziers before degenerating into bouts of excessive drinking and partying, customarily held on the first of each month.On the first of Flamerule, Adelina was held late supervising a meeting of vintners at one of House Thann’s warehouses in the Trades Ward.  When she arrived at the meeting of the Disciples of Darkness, it was to discover a ritual chamber covered in blood and gore.  Her fellow cultists had been brutally dismembered and the pieces appeared ravaged by claws and fangs.  As Adelina surveyed the room in shock, the central brazier blazed up, radiating a malevolent crimson hue.  Drawn towards the light like a moth to a flame, she approached the brazier only to have a searing pain drive into her chest like a lance.When Adelina woke the next day, it was in her own bed in House Thann’s villa.  She was about to dismiss the horrible memory as a nightmare until she felt an echo of the searing pain from the prior evening emanating from her chest.  Ripping open her bedrobe, Adelina could only stare in shock at the crimson mark of Asmodeus branded into her chest.  Raising her eyes slowly to the mirror across the room, she was further shocked to discover a book imp grinning maliciously at her from atop the furnishing.  Confused and scared out of her mind, she threw on the nearest clothes to hand and rushed out of the house, only stopping when she made it to one of the seedy establishments in the Dock Ward.  Tossing a handful of gold at the proprietor, she ran up the stairs to the first vacant room and locked the door behind her, only to hear a voice squeak out in a language she didn’t know but she could understand, “We can do this alllll day!”Adelina spun around, her hands covering her mouth in surprise.  The imp had followed her!  And it was speaking!  As the enormity of what had happened the previous night slowly sunk in, Adelina knew her life would never be the same.

His father, Jurgo, was a local official in the mountain town of Pinyon Fork, and pushed him to enter the bureaucracy.  He secures Andom a position as a clerk for the regional governor.  Growing up, the family was not particularly religious, but Andom’s father would sometimes bring the family to attend services at the temple of Amaunator. His mother’s name is Pret.  He is an only child.  When he was growing up, he would often go climbing on the rocky cliffs surrounding the town.At the governorate in Cupriston, as an official clerk, Andom had privileged access to all the texts in the state library.  One day, while perusing the titles, he happened to come across a text called “The Ashes of the Gods”, by La Rang Chen. It’s an encyclopedia of all the gods thought to have died.  As he flips through the book, he comes across an entry for Auppenser.  When he reads the name, it’s like an icicle is driven into his brain, as he is exposed, for just a second, to the divine essence of Auppenser.   When he comes to, he’s captivated.  He reads the entry on Auppenser in the book, then he pours through the library for all the texts which might mention the god,  He pieces together that Auppenser still lives, but in a deep sleep, and that his followers are all gone.  In reading about his values and precepts, Andom feels a sense of real connection.  Over the next few year, he pores over the few texts in the library that give even a passing mention to Auppenser, and tries to learn everything he can from them.  He teaches himself to meditate.  As well, he focuses on trying to develop a more stoic outlook on life.  During this period, one of his biggest supports was his friend Birmo Stubb, a halfling and a fellow clerk.  Initially, when Andom told Birmo about his new interest in Auppenser, he was not taken seriously.  But after some time, Birmo finally understood that Andom was a sincere believer.  Shortly before Andom’s departure, Birmo converted to the Church of Auppenser in a private ceremony in his apartment.  Departure:  It was in the back of his head for a while, but when he converts Birmo, he becomes acutely aware of how little he still knows about Auppenser or His former church.  He realizes that he cannot solidly reestablish the church if he remains ignorant about the fundamentals of his faith.  He resolves to go wandering in order to learn, both to find texts and other sources of knowledge that might not have made it to his library, and to try to find spiritual enlightment and wisdom, which could point the way to Auppenser, in his travels.  Andom bought some travelling equipment, resigned his commission, said his farewells, and left.  Birmo stayed behind to continue work as a clerk.  When Andom had brought up the issue of Auppenser, and especially when he resigned his commission, his father Jurgo Perronick strongly disapproved,  seeing the Slumbering God as being even less worth the trouble of working with than a regular, living god.  As a going away present, Birmo gave him a poncho he had made; this poncho is now one of Andom’s most prized possessions. Andom carries a journal with him as he tries to reassemble the shattered faith.  In it, he writes down all the information on Auppenser that he is able to find in his researches, as well as the sensations and thoughts he experienced during profound moments and contacts with the divine, his personal musings, and any other information or bits of wisdom which might help to guide a future Church of Auppenser.  The book is thus both a personal journal and a holy text.After leaving Cupriston, Andom wandered the land looking for libraries and ruins that might contain shreds of information about his adopted faith.  As he traveled, he would pick up odd jobs here and there.  He had some skill with cooking (simple stews mainly) and so was able to find some work as a chef for merchant caravans.Although he strives towards the stoic ideal of a servant of Auppenser, he often falls short in rage and frustration.  Although he would be unwilling to admit it, much of his motivation for seeking to achieve great deeds is selfish; he wants the respect that comes from heroics and mighty accomplishments.  Preoccupied with proving himself, especially to himself.  Because of this, he will often choose the bolder, flashier, more ambitious choice out of an array of options, even when that may not be well advised. He is scared of deep water. He is close friends with his first convert, Birmo Stubb, a clerk in Cupriston.  His father Jurgo Perronick tried to steer him into the bureaucracy, and strongly discouraged his new faith.  Andom’s attitude towards his father contains elements of resentment and pride, despite genuinely loving him.

The birth of Sigrid was received with mixed feelings by the people of Rek. For one, it was a blessing, after years of being childless, the Chief finally had an offspring. On the other hand, that offspring turned out to be a girl; tradition dictates that the firstborn is supposed to succeed the Chief, however, the law forbids women from becoming Chieftains. Two years later, Liulfr was born and anointed as the successor to the throne of Rek.It’s not that women are regarded as inferior or that they need protection, the gods know that Rek women need no one to protect them, but their roles are far more important than government or war, they are tasked with the spiritual and social wellbeing of the society. As such, from a small age young Sigrid was taught the traditions, laws and history of her people, molding her to one day succeed the eldest. And for a time, she was happy, that is until she was 12, the age when all Rek citizens, men and women alike, are required to learn basic defense and weapons training. The axes became an extension of herself, battle training was the highlight of her days and soon, one day becoming the elder, was no longer as important as the excitement of combat.Training after “boot camp” was an uphill battle for Sigrid, her mother and father were not eager to allow her “hobby” to continue, yet she pressed on and became one of the fiercest warriors of her age. She trained and trained in her ever shrinking free time. Yet no matter how much she trained, her fate was sealed, real combat or chief hood were out of her reach, she was almost ready to give up and accept her face and then, Liulfr turned 12 and began his combat training, what she saw horrified her. Liulfr’s combat style was not honorable, he bragged about his dirty triumphs and humiliated his opponents, this, was not the way a future chief was supposed to behave. Attempts were made to modify this behavior, but sometimes it is futile to fight against someone’s nature.5 years passed, Sigrid was now 19 and Liulfr 17. The two of them and a small contingent were sent to a frontier village facing raids from an expanding neighbor. Having talked to envoys declaring their intentions to annex Rek territory, Sigrid concluded that staying and fight was the obvious course of action, however, Liulfr had ideas of his own. He arranged a secret meeting with the envoys and gave up the town in exchange for some gold and exotic items from foreign lands. Hours later, Sigrid, Liulfr, the warriors and the villagers who agreed to leave town without a fight were en route back to the capital. Sigrid watched as those brave villagers who stayed behind to defend their property were being slaughtered and their town razzed to the ground. This was the last straw, by Tempus, she would no longer stand by and allow her cowardly brother to shame her family name. When they were back and Liulfr explained how the raiders’ numbers were superior and the town served no strategic or economic value, Sigrid lost it, she charged at her brother. He was bigger and stronger, but Sigrid smarter and more determined, they battled for minutes that seemed like hours, at the end Sigrid stood above a defeated Liulfr. Her time studying and learning the laws of traditions of Rek were finally put to good use, citing old law concerning the wives of death Chiefs, Sigrid issued a challenge to his brother, she would leave, and return only in glorious triumph, which meant having earned the admiration and respect of both enemies and friends upon which a final duel between her and her brother would decide who would finally become Chief.Storming out of the great hall before anyone could stop or talk to her, she walked away with only what was already on her, her trusty axes, her battle armor and the few rations left from her trip to the frontier.3 weeks into her pilgrimage, she met a group of villagers who were trying to hunt down a slave party who had raided their village and took their possessions and women. Sigrid was able to track them down and simply walked into their camp with the villagers behind her, demanded the release the prisoners, and when the slavers refused, Asvald and Athils (her two small axes) flew across the air and found their targets in the chest of two slavers, using the ensuing confusion to charge against the biggest man, who was possibly the leader. In a swift move, she took her battle axe and slayed the man. The villagers were successful in killing or apprehending the rest of the slavers, soon, the slavers were inside the cages and the women free. Upon returning to the village, a small elf girl who didn’t seem to belong there, caught Sigrid’s attention. The frail elf didn’t seem to have a home and was eager to follow Sigrid on her journey, for her part, Sigrid was happy to have someone to talk to, also believing that if she ever wants to be Chief, she must take care of the defenseless first.

The first time she tried to summon her totem animal, she nearly froze to death before returning to the barbarian encampment empty-handed.  Five days she spent out in the wilderness, slowly growing more hungry and more numb as the certainty that this was her path faded into nothingness and she was left with only herself, small and empty and alone.  She'd tried so hard to learn their ways, despite not being one of them, honing herself to be stronger and work harder and be as harsh and severe as the north winds.  But no spirit animal came, and only then did she let the truth sink into her heart like a cold heavy stone.She was unworthy.  Too civilized, too ignorant, an outsider.Maybe it was cowardly to leave.  She'd learned much from the tribe, made friends, learned their ways to the best of her ability, learned how to live off even the most uninhabitable tundra lands, and somewhere deep down she was grateful for that, but the rawness of her heart made it impossible for her to stay.  So she wandered in the only direction she knew, finally arriving home to her modest childhood home.Her father had always been a wild soul, so different from her quarter-dwarf mother, who was calm and solid and steady as the earth.  He was gone often, always wandering the wilds and bringing home strange artifacts and stranger creatures, spouting cliche little proverbs about protecting nature and the magic of the earth.  He always grew restless before even a fortnight passed, promised to be back soon, and left again.  If Tanna's mother ever minded his long absences, she never showed it, content with taking good care of her home.He barely made it home the day he died, weak and ashen with a death rattle already in his throat.  He told Tanna and her mother he loved them, and as his weathered hand weakly grasped Tanna's, he whispered, the last hoarse words of an old man, "Be good.  Be good."She stayed with her mother for a little while, but before long her soul ached with wanderlust once more."You have much of your father in you," her mother finally said, "and you're wearing holes in my carpet," and all but pushed her out the front door.Finding her cousin Adric was both harder and more joyful than she'd anticipated.  Deep in some caves finding treasure and fighting elementals, he was nearly impossible to track down, but seeing his face again after a year and a half was like seeing the sun for the first time.  When was the last time she'd laughed, or even truly smiled without the weight of the world on her shoulders?  He didn't comment on her appearance, but she caught his sidelong looks, and she knew him well enough to recognize his concern.  They'd practically grown up together, only one town apart, and everything Adric had learned about fighting he'd taught her as well.  They both shared the same hint of dwarf blood from their mothers, naturally strong and wide and both possessing the same love of the thrill of battle.  And the same love of good strong drink, and good food, and beautiful women.They sat around a fire that night, drinking all of Adric's ale and telling each other all the stories they'd missed over the past eighteen months, embellishing and exaggerating until they were in stitches from laughter.  It hit her like a wave, deeper than oceans, the way she loved him, the way she loved this, aching with travel and laughter, drunk and overwhelmed with joy, once again filled with the surety that the world was a vast and unimaginably beautiful place.They traveled together for a while, drinking and laughing and camping their way through every imaginable climate, making friends wherever they could and fighting all manner of beasts and fiends, picking up companions here and there and staying up nights staring at the stars and telling stories and laughing themselves sick.  They stayed in taverns when it was clean and convenient, but Tanna loved sleeping on a bedroll on the dirt under a canopy of trees and clouds and wild night sky more than any bed.As much as she loved the camaraderie of a party of like-minded adventurers, even more entrancing was every new village they found, every new and wild and far-flung tribe that she could convince or bribe to teach her about the land, what plants were good to eat and how to find water and what to avoid and how to survive.  She made every climate and every biome her friend, coaxing out its secrets with bright-eyed adoration, and those nights when she fell asleep with charred meat and sweet mead in her stomach with stars whirling overhead, she thought she could happily live like that forever.But there was something that still whispered to her, in her heart of hearts, something deep in the earth that was ancient and powerful and benevolent and was ever calling her by name.  She began dreaming of the sun, of warm wind and fast clouds and the soft susurrus of tall grass.  And a voice, deep and mellow and honey-gold, speaking words she couldn't yet understand.  So she and Adric parted ways, he compelled home for the love of his family, and she unable to shake the thought of south, south from her mind.

The Patrin are a nomadic community of Central Europe-like place.  They are stereoypically thought of as vagrants and theives.  But, they have a full robust culture of mystics, entertainers, traders, artisans, and philosophers.  They have dark hair usually grown long.  Patrin make fine wigs which command a fair price but take quite some time to make due to the nature of the materials.  Skin tones range from pale olive and tan all the way to deep chestnut brown with close relatives typically sharing similar complexions.  Eye colors other than brown or black are extremely rare.  Body types also range from short and slight to tall and broad, with little variation between men and women.  There are occasional pockets of half evles among the Patrin.Evgeni is not one of that sort of Patrin.  He is a thief, a burgler to be exact.  Bands of Patrin will sometimes sneak into communities at night to rob from unattended businesses or carry away other valuables.  These items will then be sold at the next town for a much better price than would be availble from a local fence.Abraxas the Unfathomable is one of the dreaded Demon Kings that Conn defeated and sealed away before the founding of the Empire.  Evgeni accidentally freed Abraxas while robbing the Temple of Bufkabufta, a monlithic monument built nearly 600 years ago.  This is considered an equally heinous crime in the Citystate of Nexus, the Connen Empire, and among the Council of Free Kingdoms.Bufkabufta was a king allied to the Empire who ruled the area during the Decline.  He is considered one of the honored Host of Kings in the Connen theocracy but is also celebrated locally for his benevolence and wisdom.  Bufkabufta is known in legend across most of the civilized world as a proxy for especially kind, benevolent rulership.  Abraxas gifted him the power to use magic and commanded him to sow chaos and destruction.  Evgeni has not seen or been contacted by Abraxas since that time.  He is unsure if the command was meant to be taken literally or if Abraxas has any interest in checking in on him.  That is for the best as Evgeni is wanted in most civilized nations and traveling has been difficult."Ok, so...  We were in the Temple of Bufkabufta and we were robbing the place. Granted we, we were but it didn't start like that.  We were told that the temple was built on top of a ruin from even earlier than Bufkabufta that we could get into an find something to make a little money.  The ruins were there but it took forever to get to them because of all the people trying to keep us out of the temple.  Once we got in there were a ton of traps, bad ones.  We were almost ready to cut our losses and get out of there and we found the tomb thing.  It was a big stone door probably 20 feet high and just as wide.And there was this poem, and it said something, but it was a riddle.  And the answer to the riddle was that you had to light something on fire, we didn't really know the language, I mean we did, but in retrospect, no.  No, I guess we didn't.  But, we figured out that you had to light something on fire to "unlock" something.  And we had to light a couple of things on fire, but we put em out when they didn't work.  Until the last one, the last fire did something because the whole door of the "tomb" thing shifted and moved and rolled over to the side and this thing comes out.  And it's got like the body and arms of a man but snakes for legs, and it has a rooster's head and a golden sheild but it's not holding the shield it's just like wearing it up on it's shoulder.  It's got a scourge in one hand and in the other, the arm with the sheild, it's got the reins of these four huge white warhorses.  And they're hooked up to this gold chariot, but the thing isn't in the chariot it's just floating in the air above the chariot.  And this thing is probably 14' tall and the horses are huge and there's four of them and a gold chariot so all of this comes rushing up out of this tomb thing and it knocks over the oil lamp we were using to light things on fire.  And there was no wick in the lamp.  We took it out to get a bigger flame to light stuff on fire. In retrospect, that was a mistake.  But anyway I honestly didn't see it get knocked over because the whole time this thing is talking and not like with its mouth... beak.  It's talking inside my head, and the guys I was with too I guess, but they're dead.  Probably.  And its all talking about how it's "Abraxas the Unfathomable"  and we freed it and it's going to give us power and then it screams at us to "Go forth into the world and bring CHAOS AND RUIN!"  And then it flew away.
