Like the horses ran but they ran up the air and the whole thing just flew off.  And that's when we noticed the fire which by this time is admittedly, pretty huge.  I got separated from Hristo and Petya while we were escaping and haven't seen them since then.  And now I can cast spells."

One day a halfling woman named Cora Springbreeze was out gathering herbs near the forest by her village. The baby was covered in moss in a shallow pit at the base of a large tree. She reached for the child, who was giggling and smiling, despite his circumstances. She took the baby home and her and her husband Wellby cleaned all the moss off of him. However, no matter how often they cleaned the moss, the moss on his shoulders always grew back, and would even cover that spot oh his clothing. They looked for his parents, but never managed to find them, and eventually took him in as their own. They named him Alexander Springbreeze, and from that day on he was loved and would want for nothing.  	Growing up in the Harmonias Knolls was always interesting, the town trived off of being a middle ground for people to meet up and do bussiness. People came from far and wide to meet and do bussiness here, because of how nice the people were, and more importantly, the wonderful food. It wasn't uncommon that older folk would come and vacation, and once and awhile someone would end up staying. When Alexander was a young child the village was entirely Halfling, but by the time he was a teen a few humans, an elf woman, her human husband and thier 2 half elf daughters Tera and April (who Alexander had a crush on), and a grumpy old dwarf had built homes in the village. Alexander was always a bit of an odd child, everyone was a little taken back by the moss that grew on his shoulders and his talking to plants and many off the villagers took to calling him Moss Ball, but his sunny disposition always made them friends in the end. 	For as long as Alexander could remember he had been talking to plants. They would tell him stories, and he was always at ease in their pressence. The plants always called him Pothos, he never knew why, but also never felt the need to question it. He was actually quite fond of the name, as the name Alexander just never sounded right to him. He loved plants of all varieties and when he was of age to start working would spend his days gathering wild herbs, fruits, and mushrooms. The villagers loved him for it because nobody has ever gathered as much as him, it was as if the plants were finding him they thought. Alexander was truely happy, so much so that nobody could remember him being anything else.	One day when Alexander was out strolling through the meddow he ran into a beautiful large blue flower. He spent the entire day talking to that flower and when darkness came and Alexander was about to say his goodbyes, the flower thanked him for his time and asked him to please come by in the morning, and that there would be something waiting for him. The next day Alexander went back into the forest to find the flower, but it was gone. In it's place was a small bundle of leaves, which upon inspection, contained 4 seeds. Alexander asked the surrounding grass what happened, but grass thinks of little besides "bask and eat" so he took bundled the leaves back up and took the seeds back home with him.  	Just before ariving at his village, he saw a dense black smoke on the horrizon. He ran and found a group of bandits surrounded all of the villagers, pillaging the houses and harrasing the half elf April. For the first time in his life, Alexander became angery, and he leaped on the first bandit he saw and bashed him over the head with his staff. Seeing this 2 of the other bandits grabbed their swords and before they could do get close enough to attack massive thorny vines grew out from the moss on Alexanders' shoulders, wrapped around his arms and lashed out ripping the the throat of one, and choking the life out of the other. Then an arrow went wizzing by alexander, he turned to see another bandit with a bow reloaded and aimed right at him. As he released his arrow Alexander took the bandit he was choking and moved him so that the arrow struck him. He released the now dead bandit and with his other, now vineless hand, reached out towards the bandit and shot out a liquid directly into his face. The bandit screamed with pain as he fell to the ground, the skin on his face bubbeling and melting away. "someone help!" he heard, coming from the burning home of the grumpy old dwarf, Rold Frostbeard. Alexander rushed into the burning home and came back out moments later, with the dwarf in his arms. The moss on his right shoulder on fire he quickly smothered the flame. He then heard a scream, as he looked up he saw April, with a bandit's knife to her throat. Alexander disapeared, and repeared as a massive wolf behind the bandit, tearing at the bandit's throat. 	With the last bandit dispatched, and all of the villagers saved, Alexander turned back into his normal self, covered in the blood of the bandits and burns covering his right arm. He fell to his knees and cried for the first time in his life. Not entirely sure what he did, or how he did it, all he could think about was all the pain he inflicted. His mother stood up from the crowd and went over to him, as she neared and he looked up at her she stepped back, for just a moment, afraid. Seeing this Alexander returned to his wolf form, and ran away, dropping one of his 4 seeds behind him.

_Hideyama Kurisuma is a true warrior. With strength, cunning, and leadership, he can best any foe. As a samurai, he goes against custom by being his own master. To most, he is a Ronin. Masterless. Without cause. Lost. But to him, it is more freeing than the greatest fight. Higher than the tallest mountain. Stronger than the hardest steel. Let us start where Hideyama's story began. He was born in a humble monastery in Quyu. Trained from the age of 3, he quickly mastered the art. By age 16, he was taken to the dragon temple, but did not succeed in being selected. His prowess, however, did not go unnoticed. A great samurai master, known as Ryku quickly took a liking to him, and trained him in the military arts. When Hideyama was 20, he fought his first battle, with a small group of bandits that had been harassing the locals. He continued like this for many months, then Ryku decided to teach him tactics. Hideyama, being a good student and eager to learn more, accepted the promotion to Lieutenant, and given a horse. He trained hard and long, and eventually, after 2 long, hard years of work, was granted his own small group of foot soldiers. After many successful raids, Hideyama's name was well known in the area. But the Emperor also took notice. A samurai that seemed to be sworn to no one. The Emperor sent envoys to meet this mysterious samurai, and offer him vassalage under the Emperor, the rightful ruler of the land. Hideyama was surprised that the Emperor had taken such notice, and accepted. His platoon was immediately moved to the temple of the Dragon in the Imperial city. His job was to oversee a small army that defended the city walls. It was a daunting task, but Hideyama accepted the challenge. Nothing eventful happened, until Lord Ido slaughtered the other Dragoneyes , the keepers of the peace, and Lord Sethos became the self proclaimed emperor 3 years later. Hideyama joined the rebellion, along with many of his troops. The battle to escape was long and bloody. Hundreds of good men died that day. Realizing his mistake in trusting that a vassalship would be beneficial to him, he vowed that he would be his own man. Sworn to no one. Commander of himself. He set out to find himself in the wilderness. On his journeys, he met several people. On his journey, he found a great and mighty temple. The monks there were kind to him, and noticed his damaged equipment. They granted him a set of armour, and a few weapons. First, a lordly set of samurai armour, faded red with gold lining, of great thickness. A long cavalry sword called an Odachi, a shorter sword called a Wazikashi, and a long spear with a rectangular banner on it called a Yari. He set off, and with these wapons did many great things. During his exile, there were a few people that stood out to him. His mentor in the woods, Hokichi Royama. A great sensei, and a master of forgotten techniques. Hideyama learned much about being a samurai, and learned the true weight of being a Ronin. His companion, for a time, a fellow ronin, Sakuraba Kojimo, who taught him the art of resisting mental and physical tortures. His Kenjutsu Hansi (master) who did not have a name, but helped him master Kenjutsu himself. His student, Kumage Shohei, whom he taught almost everything he knew, and sent off on his own path. When Hideyama emerged from his self induced exile, 18 years later, he was a changed man. His experiences had taught him much. At the ripe age of 43, his hair was graying, but he was ready. In the woods, he had learned of an ancient temple. One that would lead him to a new land, where civil unrest was unheard of. He searched for this temple for many years, almost losing hope before unearthing a new clue. From book, to artifact to unbelievable rumor, he searched. When he finally got a location, he has much time had passed. 4 long years he had searched, and finally it would come to fruition. He set out for the temple, and the journey was quite peaceful. As he climbed the steps, he began to wonder. What would this new land be like? Who would be in it? Would he be out of place in it? Would he be able to speak with the natives? These thought ran through his head, but did not deter him. He reached the temple. It was not very grand, in fact it was quite small. The temple looked like most other temples, but most of the ornamentation was gone, and the colours faded. The majesty that most temples have was absent. It felt like it had been abandoned, forgotten, or perhaps hidden. Hideyama entered the temple, and immediately was assailed by a horrible stench. His time with Sakuraba served him well, and he pressed on. At the end of the temple, there was a statue of the mirror dragon. He knelt at the statue, and rested for a time. He didn’t know how long he sat there, but suddenly he felt like he was in a different place. The gods had granted his wish. He opened his eyes and looked around. He was in a large, circular room with a bar in the middle. The bar’s skirting and openings were reminiscent of the entrance to a temple. The walls were mosaics of red and gold. Hideyama was kneeling on a cushion at the bar. A portly white man walked up, and said with a subtle but distinct accent “Hello. I’m Mitchever, the barkeep. Can I get you anything to drink?” Hideyama was confused by this man, but did not let it show on his face, regardless of his mask. To be polite, he raised the mask and asked for some spring water. When his drink arrived, he inquired about this world, wondering if it was the haven he had been led to believe. Hideyama learned much in the next few hours, from Mitchever, and a few other patrons. But the most intriguing fact was the promise of great power, locked in a mysterious tower. The Tower of the Fool. It only appeared for short times, and quite infrequently. Hideyama felt that finding this power would teach him more about himself, and decided to wait for it to appear...

Cerise Firevale was born on the first day of summer alongside her twin sister, Ferra. While the two shared nearly identical faces, they were almost the complete antithesis of one another. 	Cerise was gifted with the vibrant red hair of her father's, while Ferra inherited her mother's jet-black locks.	Cerise grew to be curious, generous and unerringly kind, whereas Ferra became colder and more distant the more she aged.	The more the girls grew it became clearer and clearer that they were fated to be polar opposites of one another. It was odd, to say the least, but Cerise never seemed to mind. Being the kindhearted girl that she was, she always tried to get along with her sister when they were younger.	That all changed the moment it came time for their schooling at age 7.	The Firevale family is a house of nobility that is well-known among the townspeople of Ashbourne. They have a stunning reputation as a family of spellcasters, every single member of the core bloodline becoming a successful sorcerer or sorceress... That is, until Cerise.	The polarity that existed between the twins appeared to extend even to their talents, and saw Ferra being gifted with immense magical acuity just begging to be fostered and developed into terrifying thaumaturgical prowess.	Cerise, on the other hand, possessed no magical talent whatsoever. Try as she might, she couldn't even conjure a simple Prestidigitation spell. She tried and tried, desperately wanting not to disappoint her parents, but to no avail. She just didn't have what it took to become a sorceress and continue the family tradition. When she begged her sister for help, Ferra simply dismissed her, saying she had always known this would happen, that she would be the one to further the family's tradition. According to her, Cerise hadn't the temperament or the mental fortitude for the magical arts. Ferra then left her there, that conversation marking the beginning of Cerise's new life.	Her parents pretended not to mind. They enrolled her in martial training instead, to see if she would be better suited with a sword or an axe in her hand rather than a book or a staff. When she immediately began to excel, Cerise could tell that her parents truly gave up on her. They tried to disguise their disappointment, but Cerise could tell. The longer it went on the more it felt like the love they expressed toward her was just a lie, an obligation. A formality. But it didn't last long.	As time went on Cerise's parents grew colder toward her, similar to the way Ferra had. Cerise suspected that she embarrassed them. That they were tired of the residents of Ashbourne asking about her, querying why she wasn't being raised as a sorceress like Ferra was. Cerise began to feel that it was her fault, that something was wrong with her. She felt like a guest in her own home. A guest that was overstaying her welcome.	Cerise began to wander outside of her family's estate. She felt claustrophobic within its walls, as if she would be suffocated if she stayed there too long. It was refreshing to talk to the townspeople. They never judged her the way her family did. The streets of Ashbourne soon became Cerise's new home where she would stay whenever she wasn't otherwise kept within the Firevale estate. Her family never cared enough to ask where she was during the day, instead showering Ferra with attention.	At the age of 10 Cerise met a man from a party of adventurers that often came to Ashbourne to spend a few nights at the inn and resupply. The man's name was Bardren, a roguish type with a dazzling smile and a kind heart. He gave silver pieces to the children around town, who would always go and spend them on candy. Cerise would always be seen trailing behind him whenever he was around. He told her the most fascinating stories about the outside world. She'd never left the town of Ashbourne, left completely ignorant of life elsewhere. Bardren told her tales of towering castles, crumbling caves, terrifying dungeons, and people of all kinds.	The only experience Cerise had with other races was the innkeeper – she was an elf. Aside from that, at least as far as she knew, all of Ashbourne was human. Bardren spoke of dwarves, drow elves, halflings, gnomes, even the living dead. The more stories he told her the more she desperately wanted to see it for herself.	Eventually Cerise told Bardren of the way her family had been treating her. Though clearly upset by it, he promised her that he wouldn't make any trouble over it. He didn't want to make things worse for her. Instead he continued to do what he always did, telling her stories whenever she asked and allowing her to follow him around. He soon became the caring family Cerise so painfully craved. As long as Bardren continued to visit Ashbourne, Cerise had something to look forward to.	Years passed. Cerise began to find that as she matured, the more she thought of Bardren differently. Dreams of him taking her to see the world were sometimes replaced by the two of them having a wedding together. These bittersweet dreams often ended with Cerise waking in the middle of the night, crying. She didn't want to think of him that way. Those feelings would only serve to remind her that he wasn't her real family, that her real family had all but abandoned her when she was just a child.	On her 20th birthday Cerise went out to find Bardren, who had promised to meet her. She couldn't find him. She did, however, find his party, looking much worse for wear, as though they had been through hell and back. Fearing the worst, she asked them what had happened.	Bardren was dead.	Cerise stood there for the better part of an hour. When she looked down at her hand she was holding a bright gold amulet. One of the party members had placed it in her hand, saying Bardren had wanted her to have it. With that they left her there, in shock and very much alone.	Cerise decided to leave that night. She wouldn't stay in the house that had shunned her for another moment. Waiting until the dead of night, she gathered the things most important to her and crept outside. She made her way into the guardhouse within her family's estate and took a set of armor, as well as a sword and shield. It was the only time she had ever stolen anything and she felt terrible, but Bardren had taught her that the world is wrought with danger.	Cerise had a goal, and that was to earn her family's respect. She refused to be ashamed of her surname, instead embracing it and hoping to one day return as a successful and proud warrior. Until then, she would travel the lands and help as many people as she could.

Randal’s mother, Anet Cor Marak, came from a well-respected merchant family living in the city of Ankhapur on the Lake of Steam. The “bloodline of fire” (hereditary traits passed down from the efreeti rulers of nearby Calimshan’s past) burned strongly in her family, and showed clearly in Anet. Her hair flickered with all the motion and color of flames, and the ever-present scent of smoke followed wherever she went.When Anet came of age she traveled to Waterdeep to pursue her own ambitions, eager to establish herself as a successful businesswoman. While not the largest or most successful in Waterdeep, her trading company has established itself as a notable authority in coastal trading. Anet met Randal’s father while living in Waterdeep. A mediocre wizard and member of the Watchful Order of Magists and Protectors, Grim Wolfswit assisted Anet when her distinctive appearance drew hostility from groups who mistook her for a sorcerer. Each sparking curiosity in the other, the two courted and after several years married. Anet & Grim had two sons, Gewar and his younger brother Randal. The bloodline of fire continued, though faintly, in the brothers.Gewar never looked kindly upon his brother, and from his very birth he had seen Randal as a thief. His parent’s time and love kept being squandered on the little brat, when really he deserved it more. Growing up, Gewar never held back in fights with Randal. Randal in turn learned very quickly how to protect himself, how to take a hit, and how to give back as good as he got. Randal spent his whole childhood fighting someone bigger and stronger who genuinely hated him, and grew up to be someone who never backed down even against overwhelming odds. In Randal’s teen years, he grew stronger than his brother who chose not to fight him physically after having lost for the first time. Gewar’s resentment only multiplied, while Randal became restless. The frequent fistfights had been a much needed routine for him, and without his usual opponent he sought out an alternative. He discovered vigilante groups like the Red Sashes, and took to the streets at night where he put his fists to good use. He learned cruel things operated in the city’s darkest corners, heard names like the Xanathar’s Guild.Gewar had long seen mastering his father’s trade, learning to work magic, would finally prove him the better and smarter son. As they grew older, Gewar’s insistence intensified to a level of harassment that burned into argument when Grim snapped at his demanding son. After the worst of those fights, Gewar despaired thinking his father would never share his arts. His despair turned to rage, his addled mind saw this as just one more thing stolen from him by Randal. He would solve this, and prove his worth all at once. Gewar stole magical implements from his father’s study and prepared a lethal trap. He planned to murder his brother using the very magic his father deemed him unworthy to learn. And he would watch it happen. Gewar set his trap and waited. He knew Randal came home late most nights, and he had prepared perfectly. Grim, laying awake that night, thought to get up and go speak to Gewar. He knew the boy showed promise, but had trouble getting him to proceed at the proper pace. Grim came out to see Randal stepping in, he saw Gewar waiting in the shadows, and his senses soon noted the mystical energies suffusing the room. In a moment of unthinking panic, Grim threw himself forward and knocked Randal out of the way of the trap. Randal looked up to see his father slain in agony as conjured spears of ice skewered him from all directions.Gewar went mad. He lept from hiding to beat his brother with his fists, shouting how Randal had taken his father from him. Randal took the first few hits, still too shocked to believe what he had seen. When he did piece it together, he knocked his brother off him with a single punch. Gewar unconscious on the floor, Randal went to his father’s side. Already he knew nothing could be done. A noise came from the stairs. He looked up to see his mother frozen in place, her features lost in silent horror. Randal couldn’t think, he felt guilt, imagined Anet blaming him for everything. He couldn’t face her, but he couldn’t leave her alone with his murderous brother. He took Gewar and left.Carrying the unconscious Gewar through side alleys and rarely used streets, he left for somewhere unhealthy. Randal met with the Agents of the Eye, what those in the Xanathar’s Guild called themselves. Slavers, blackmailers, thieves, and worse. He dropped his brother at his feet. He’d heard the stories, he knew you couldn’t join the guild without a blood offering. Though Xanathar’s offerings required a family member, dead or given to the slavers. He joined that day, and never went home. Years in service to the Xanathar’s Guild wore on Randal’s mind. He’d tried not to think too much about his work, preferring to just act in service to the guild and collect his pay. He turned to Cyric’s teachings, hoping religion could help him accept his chosen path. Yet as time passed, he started to think himself a fool. He’d blamed himself for his father’s death, no one had done that to him. And he’d never even asked what it was his brother had attempted or why. He hadn’t cared, just cleaned it up. He didn’t even know any more whether or not his brother still lived. Randal reached a conclusion one day: he’d done nothing wrong the night his father died. Not until he’d joined the Xanathar’s Guild. And he’d spent years serving them, inflicting pain and death for his masters. Now he had done something worthy of the shame and guilt he’d felt that night. Randal considered that maybe it was too late, and what he’d done couldn’t be redeemed. But he knew trying had to feel better than continuing on this way. He left the Xanathar’s Guild as quietly as he could, hoping to leave little of a trail for them to follow. Similarly, he looked for a way out of Cyric’s church… but feared some divine retribution for his abandonment. His thoughts turned to the gods Cyric hated most: Mystra & Kelemvor. Kelemvor’s church taught the importance of honoring the dead, remembering what they had contributed in life and serving their families in trying times. Randal couldn’t speak to how many lives he had ended prematurely. He could be sure it hadn’t been countless, just that his mind struggled to forget what he had done. One day he might die and find himself in Kelemvor’s presence, judged as one of the False for betraying his vows to Cyric’s church. Maybe that inevitable sentence could be lessened by doing penance in service to Kelemvor’s faith. Maybe if he joined a group of adventurers he could find enough opportunities to redeem his past actions. If nothing else, perhaps he could do enough good he could face his mother without feeling so ashamed.

Andi was born in a small town a stone’s throw from Telis. Her parents met abroad; since they were from the same area and visited the same markets in Telis, he from within the city and they were from the same area and visited the same markets in Telis, he from within the city and she from a village half a day’s journey out, they had a lot to talk about. It was an odd pair. Mother was a second-generation immigrant, raised practical and worldly, while father was a child of a family long known for its doctors of magic and administrators of wizard matters. He was getting older and restless, and she was intrigued with his restlessness despite his privilege. Their choice of place to settle down was tactical, not too close to his origin, not too far from hers, but adjoining Telis for its opportunity. She wasn’t anxious to start a family, and it was longer than he or his kin liked before Andi was born.When Andi was eight, she gained a brother and her mother left. It wasn’t entirely clear that the boy’s father was the same as hers. She hadn’t seen her mother since. Andi half-raised her much younger brother, adding an extra burden to the intense pressure to be a high achiever. Her father moved back to the family estate in the city and took the kids with him. He was out most of the time. Her brother was a bad combination of defiant and a little dumb. Her father grew sad and cool, and their relationship was turbulent.After an eternity, Andi made it out of first school and her father gladly paid her way to the top-tier boarding school of her choice, at the foot of the mountains outside of Scandrow. Her brother began military training soon after, in his early teens, and she would only see him once in all her time at school.The boarding school was full of rich girls and overqualified teachers who were delighted with any student who really wanted badly to learn. She was such a student. She ate up history, arcana, languages, and wealth studies. She was clearly fast-tracked for advanced wizardry. Always a straight-edge by necessity, she did not indulge much in her freedom away from home, finding more comfort in books than in friends. Her achievement made her unpopular; her skin, one shade darker than the crowd, subtly alienated her. Her strong opinions about the ways the other girls ought to be using their expensive time at school, and her liberty with snapping at them, didn’t help.Extra time was occupied by two newfound passions: botany and martial magic. Her introductory plants and lifeforms class introduced her to the astonishing variety in land flora. The teacher conspired with the groundskeeper to grant her a tiny plot to garden, eager to see a student pass in her studies from the labeled drawings in the required reading into the real world. Andi was not excellent at gardening, but she found unusually pure joy in her trivial successes at making life.As in many high-end boarding schools, there were exotic options for fitness credit; one on offer was combat spellcasting. The quiet, focused instructor became her first real friend at school. Andi would stay after class, half practicing, half confiding. With shared trust, the pair were able to go further than gym credit, taking on riskier combat techniques: fire, and blinding light. When Andi could finally relax with her magic, she found that she could move small objects or cause people to hear or feel brief illusions without much effort. After that, she had no end of fun sharing subtle magical jokes with her mentor and friend in class at the other girls’ expense.There was a cultural enrichment exchange program with the native dwarfish folk of the mountain. Unsophisticated but wise people, they often conferred with local earth elementals about weather or war. Andi studied up on Terran and excitedly enrolled. She would meet briefly with her large and profoundly foreign exchange student, and then she would trek with a donkey, a guide, and a few interested others up the valley. The natives were gruff but generous with their time, laughing at her Terran pronunciation mistakes and sending her on errands to find novel forest foodstuffs. In the evenings, she would be reluctant to leave. Never once did she see an elemental. Still, the folks’ grounded lifestyle rubbed off on her, feeding a lust for the outdoors and unknown places.Matters of the heart were never tidy for Andi. As an upperclassman, she cautiously tried at romance with the other girls a few times. Andi could never fully connect, and so she broke some hearts before she decided that now was not the time for her. In lulls she would often imagine where her mother had gone, and what kind of person she had become. Her memories of life before she left had become scattered and vague. It was an unconscious certainty to her that someday, she would have to find her and put her story together.The one time she saw her brother when her leave overlapped with his, she found that he was doing frustratingly well. Apparently, his intellect was better suited to tactic than primary math; he had risen to Corporal, re-stationed at a northern city at the border. Andi felt acutely that her life was on pause.Andi graduated half a year early. She rented for a time in metropolitan Scandrow, immediately catching a job as a low-level library administrator. Upper-echelon urban wizarding establishments knew the Arewas name. She did not tell her father she had exited school, and she had no intention to return to his sad and empty home, though she felt awful for scorning him so. Untied from all commitments at last, she experimented tentatively with pubs and intoxicants in her restlessness. Still, guilt over her lapse in discipline nagged her every day.Once, word got around that a bandit camp in the hills had been deserted all at once, leaving valuable goods behind; no one knew why. Seeing adventuring parties emerging, all intent on getting the first pick of the treasure, she decided that enough was enough waiting for her life to begin. She hastily purchased quite a lot of adventuring goods and some very nice leather armor, using up most of the money she had on her. She was able to convince some very loud young men that they could use a wizard on their way to the empty encampment. That party’s story ended prematurely when an injury halfway along the trail forced them to return to town. Anyway, she couldn’t cast in the stiff armor. The last night before arriving back in Scandrow, the young men decided to make up for their unrealized treasure by lifting hers. On returning, empty-handed, Andi found that a week’s unannounced time off had cost her the library job.Furious and disappointed, Andi might have spent a good deal of time tracking those idiots down. Instead, before sunrise the following morning, frantic news all over the city made her personal matters seem small: fighting had broken out where her brother was stationed, and war had begun.

-38Edrik is born in a distant country of Tollaug.  A mountainous region, Tollaug was somewhat insulated from the brunt of aftermath of the Awakening but not from frequent wars with its neighbors. By the time Edrik was born Tollaug was fighting with three of its four neighbors. The bitterest war was with the largest country on their border, Garstin, and that war had last for hundreds of years.  The Tollaugens had needed to adapt their culture to survive and defend their homeland.  Nearly every able adult became a warrior in the Tollaugen military and by necessity the state overtook the responsibility for rearing children ((sort of Viking-style spartans but with primitive guns)).  Thus Edrik never knew his parents.  He grew up with his peers in the capital city of Belstein, raised to fight in a war that seemed would never end.-26Edrik saw his first battlefield when he was 12.  Belstein was seized by Garstin forces and he watched from the ramparts with his peers as his kinsmen fought then opposing forces.  Eager to punish the invaders he dedicated himself to his martial training.  -28-19Though most recruits were not accepted into the military until they were 16, Edrik fought for and earned a position in their version of the assault infantry when he was still 14.  As one soldier in a battalion of hundreds he traveled over the mountains to fight on Garstin ground.  His notoriety grew within the unit, first due to his age and then due to the vicious efficiency with which he fought.  His only friends were the other members of his squad, though the brutality of the war meant he was frequently making new friends.  He earned their respect through his competence and willingness to keep them alive on the battlefield. By the time he was 17 he was made Captain of his squad.-19-10Eventually, Edrik's notoriety grew beyond his own battalion and he was reassigned to an experimental new unit: the Kitehawks.  Despite their military prowess, the Tollaugens were losing to the Garstin.  The Tollaugens had the larger military with better equipment, training, and officers but they had relatively few mages.  With their larger population the Garstin were able to embed mages regularly throughout their ranks and more than counter the advantage of the Tollaugens.  The mission of the Kitehawks was to infiltrate enemy territory before a battle and eliminate any prominent mages.Initially the team had six members:Sigmar - Commander, Dwarf Male Fighter/Rogue, a cunning old warrior who was equally adept at battle and planning strategies.  Sigmar recruited each member of the Kitehawks personally and exercised a lot of autonomy in how the unit was operated.  The Kitehawks essentially belonged to Sigmar. ((Hannibal from A-Team))Larin - XO, Half-Elf Female Rogue; a devious, clever spy who always seems to know what's going through someone else's head (and she might!), functions as the Kitehawk's intel officer ((probably a bit Garik-ish in that it's difficult to tell what side she's on sometimes))Enger - Male Human Barbarian; a giant man with a gregarious attitude ((Armstrong from FMA))Reivar - Male Human Ranger, a cunning woodsman and scout, a scary good sniper who used a custom built rifle to kill targets before he was ever seen. Known as "Ghost" by the enemy. ((Saito from GitS))Edrik - Male Human Fighter, a relatively young fighter who proved quick to pick up new skills. He was trained by each of the members of the team, becoming something of a jack-of-all-trades for the squad.Halin - Female Gnome Rogue, a cheerful gnome, Halin seldom took part in the actual fighting but functioned as the squad's support officer.  She developed most of the custom equipment they used and arranged their transportation (often with a good deal of creativity) ((Prolly like that fellow in F4 Railroad))Other members occasionally joined, died, or were reassigned but the team never numbered more than 9 and the 6 remained its core.  Edrik spent much of his time training with his teammates.  From Sigmar he learned battlefield tactics. From Enger he learned how to build his strength and hone his body. From Reivar he learned how to survive in nearly any environment.  Halin taught him much about their equipment and together the two of them constructed Hrunting, then a prototype.  But he may have learned most from Larin who taught him how to move without being seen.  Edrik grew very close to his teammates over the years and may have had a more than strictly professional relationship with Larin.The squad itself was such a success that they, almost single-handedly, changed the scope of the war.  On a typical mission, Edrik and Larin would infiltrate the enemy's camp while Sigmar, Halin and Reivar observed from a distance, providing field support through "comm MIs".  Enger with his large size, was kept in reserve.  If a distraction was required or something went wrong, Enger and Sigmar could swoop in while Reivar raised some chaos from a distance.Soon they were targeting more than just mages, taking out enemy commanders and officers as well.  Most often they would remove the corpse, or any other sign they had ever been there and leave the Garstin forces to wonder where their General or mage had disappeared to.  Sometimes they mutilated the corpse and prominently displayed it.  The Garstin tried many tactics, decoys, deployments, guards, but it seldom took the Kitehawks long to foil them.  When they began extracting high value targets, rather than killing them, the Tollaugens suddenly had a wealth of intel on their enemy.  The tide of the war began to swing and the Tollaugens took back territory they'd lost long ago and they swept into Garstin like a cutlass swings for a bare throat.-10Eventually the Tollaugens had fought right up to the Garstin capitol, Erba.  With the bulk of the Garstin military in ruins behind them their victory seemed assured.  The Kitehawks were sent in to capture the Garstin King, their most dangerous mission to date.  This time they all went into the field, taking different routes to meet up in the castle itself.  They fought/snuck to the King's chambers and found he was already dead, shot from a far through a window.It was then, in the sanctity of the King's chambers, that Sigmar revealed his ultimate plan.  He had determined that Tollaug couldn't hold onto Garstin, the other country was just too large.  Whether they conquered Garstin or were conquered by Garstin their culture and people would be assimilated into the larger country.  What's more, Tollaug had been at war for so long that it had forgotten how to be at peace.  With the resources of Garstin they would be able to crush their other neighbors and would soon lose their own identity.  Sigmar's plan was to manipulate the political field, to make it seem as though the Garstin King were still alive and commanding the army but in order for his plan to work he would need to destroy most of the Tollaug army outside the city.Hallig was the first to protest, arguing that even if Sigmar might be correct they couldn't kill their own countrymen.  The argument went back and forth for a few moments before Sigmar shot her.  At that point Edrick moved to draw his own pistol but a move from Larin stopped him.  Realizing he'd have to fight his own squad if he stayed, he grabbed Hallig's body (perhaps not realizing she was dead) and dove out the window.  He felt a bullet bite into his shoulder half-way to a river hundreds of feet below the castle keep.  He lost consciousness before he even hit the water.When he woke up Hallig was nowhere to be seen.  The river had carried him far from the city and deposited him on a distant bank.  From where he sat he could see smoke and flame in the distance and the river around him had a distinct reddish hue.  It almost looked black in the morning light.  He had been shot in the back of his shoulder but his armor had kept him from bleeding out, barely.  He was too weak to search for Hallig and was forced to escape with whatever he happened to have on him.  He resolved that Edrick was killed in the fall and he would become someone else, abandoning his life to that day.He never learned what became of the Kitehawks after that.  Sigmar's plan was complicated and Edrick never expected he'd heard all of it.  Explosions, either from magic or some hidden chemicals, destroyed 2/3s of the Tollaug army just as they broke the walls of the city.  The remainder fled back towards Tollaug but they were caught by the remains of the Garstin army.  Very few of those troops would ever return to their mountainous home.  Within the next few years Tollaug would be invaded again. They would repel that invasion, construct barricades, be invaded before the barricades were complete and according to myth an allegiance of the Garstin and the other enemies of the Tollaug were able to wipe them out. By -6 years the nation of Tollaug is no longer considered to exist.  -9From the banks of a river in Garstin, he wandered without much purpose.  He turned his back to Tollaug and just kept walking south.  He found his way to a northernish forest ((similar to Pac NW maybe)) and began to live as a wildman.  The events in Erba had left him shattered, a wreck of his former self.  His body recovered in time but he had simultaneously lost every purpose he had.  Only his training and an inability to give up kept him going.  He reasoned he could live out the rest of his life in this remote place and never see another person.By circumstance the cabin he built was close to a wolf's den.  He ran into the shaggy grey wolves from time to time but after their initial introduction they left each other alone.  The unspoken agreement was that he wouldn't interfere with the wolf or his bitch and they wouldn't try to eat his face.  That didn't stop the bitch's cubs from tromping through his cabin once they started leaving the den but he let them do as they would.Months later a clan of trolls moved into their valley.  He came back to the cabin to find the wolf, wounded and bloody.  He followed it's trail to find a troll squatting by the wolf's den, eating the last of the cubs.  Enraged, he attacked the troll, calling on skills and training he hadn't used for a year.  When the troll's corpse smoldered next to the den he lit his own cabin, tossed the wolf over his shoulders, and moved on.He nursed the wolf back to health since it seemed like the decent thing to do.  There after the wolf followed him, perhaps not quite a friend but a companion.  The wolf's wounds left it too weakened to survive on its own but he was content to provide it food in exchange for the company.-8The man and wolf seldom stayed in one place for terribly long.  It seemed everywhere they went there was something trying to eat them.  They didn't wish for much, just a place to live in solitude.  They avoided cities and people, keeping to the wild.So it was a perhaps a surprise when the man found himself waking in a cage.  A box of iron bars, large and strong enough to hold an ogre, encased him and beyond it was an ornate chamber.  Walls decorated with art and trickling water forming delicate pools among polished stones.  Lush plants lined the room, leading the eye towards a great desk at the far side of the room where a young man sat.  At least, he seemed young and quite handsome.  His features made it difficult to discern if he were human or elf, probably a mingling of the two, but he exuded charisma and confidence.  His name was Kolan and he was a prominent officer within the Order of Scales; a quasi-religious institution outwardly dedicated to maintaining the balance in the world. The organization's roots lay somewhere beyond the Awakening but, like most things about them, were shrouded in mystery.  Kolan explained that they had preferred to guide civilization through subtlety but that they had had to change with the times.  They were now a global organization that, on the face of things, might seem like another religion with interests in trade.  In the shadows they did much more than pray and broker politics.  Kolan explained that he was recruiting him to hunt down a particular woman, a sorcerer who had once been a member of the Order.  Kolan suggested he was familiar with the Kitehawks and could contact them if so inclined.  He could arrange a reunion or assassination, whichever was more likely to motivate his captive.  So the man was coerced into adopting the identity of Gunnolf, a roaming bounty hunter specializing in retrieving, or eliminating, mages.Once he had accepted this he was sent to a gnome named Zevan, another agent of the Order.  Zevan marked the back of Gunnolf's back hand with a symbol that would only appear under a magical lamp.  This would serve to mark Gunnolf as an agent of the Order to members of the Order but would otherwise be invisible.  Zevan equipped him as well, with armor and various magical items of some considerable worth.  Gunnolf learned that Zevan would be his handler and support officer, supplying him with information and equipment when he was undertaking missions directly for the Order.  Most of the time he would be undertaking public bounties and keeping an eye out for the sorceress.  And that's how a kid from a government school on the northern edge of the globe came to be a world-class bounty hunter of mage-types.

The fading light of day cast elongated shadows across the city of Monarchia, the towers of brass reflecting the crimson red sun of dusk. There was a silent breeze drifting in from the north, causing Severus' cloak to flutter in the still air. He was standing upon the balcony atop the Senate building. It was a large oval building of marble, held up by columns of rune-inscribed white stone, which towered over the rest of the city. Severus was enjoying the spectacular view granted by the vista. He was clad in the traditional robes of the monarchian nobility, a pristine cloth coloured light blue trimmed with purple around the neck area. His back was covered in the cloak that was as dark crimson as the sky he was looking at.He turned and walked to the opposite side of the balcony which offered a different, if not as beautiful, view.Below him, he could see the senate floor where the hundred or so heads of nobility sat in discussion over the intricacies of tax collection. Occasionally a senator would rise from his seat and give a small speech on his opinion of the subject before sitting down to the applause of his supporters and the booing of his rivals. Nothing really changed until the final vote would be called, which would be at least another hour of tedious discussion by Severus' estimation. He sighed.'Not the most interesting of sessions, is it?' asked a voice behind him. Severus turned and saw an older man in his fifties emerge from the stairs. He was wearing the same traditional clothing as Severus, although this had a golden trim down the middle of the robe, indicating an elected Senator. 'Ah, Senator Tullios.' he remarked. Severus smiled at the old politician, although he groaned inside. 'Always a pleasure. Please join me.' waving his hand to indicate the spot next to him. 'My father sends his thanks for your hospitality during his visit yesterday. He was very pleased that he expect your support during the next election.' said Severus as Tullios came to stand next to him, following his gaze down to the floor below.Tullios smiled. 'Ah, it was no trouble. My home has and will always be open to the Trevelyans.' He turned and looked at Severus. 'And how is the High Legate? I had expected to see him in session today.'Severus wanted to sigh, but he kept up his political correct facade and smiled. 'My father is well, thank you. He regrets that he could not attend session today, his duties as High Legate prevents him so. He is out in the field. You understand, I'm sure.'Tullios nodded. 'Ah, yes. The duties of high office, of course.' He said disappointed. 'I was hoping that he might propose a motion for me as a favour.''He did send Axios, however.' Severus cut in. 'My brother is a senator and has the full backing of my father and his supporters. Don't worry, Senator. We Trevelyans remember our friends.' He sighed slightly inwardly as he, yet again, quoted the old maxim. Severus never liked these political conversations. It was all promises, alliances, rivalries, and so it had been for the past three hundred years. One could never be upfront about anything, not even with those who you were publicly known to be friends with. Every relation was to be used as a tool to further ones own goals.Tullios looked relieved 'Ah, excellent. That settles my worries so.' He looked down into the crowd of senators. 'I hope you will not be offended if I take my leave, I believe your brother Axios and I, have something to discussion.'Severus smiled, the first genuine smile at the old man. 'No offense taken. I understand completely. Please, give him my regards.'Tullios vanished down the stairs soon after. Severus noticed that the sun had gone completely now and he stood alone on the light-less balcony. He flicked his wrist at the braziers around him, and fire began to consume them, providing a shadowed light. 'Bastard old goat.' he murmured.'You shouldn't speak of our friends in such a tone, Severus' said a soft voice behind him. He smiled and turned, recognizing the voice.'Elyria! Sister, it has been far too long.' he said as they embraced for a moment. 'How have your travels been? We didn't expect you home until next month.'She smiled. 'I got tired of the dreary weather down south. It was quaint for the first week but that novelty quickly wore off.''Please.' said Severus indicating the spot where Tullios had stood only a minute before. They looked down in the Senate where a small woman was making a surprising passionate speech about the importance of tax exemptions.'Same as always.' Elyria mumbled.'At least you have a chance to travel.' said Severus. 'If father has his way, it will be me in a couple of years who's down there making speeches.''If you want for adventure so much, just join the Skitarii, they can always use more men, and it is prestigeous.' she remarked'Yeah and that is the problem. With fathers influence, I'll be an officer in a day, in two months I'll be commanding a whole brigade, and back to the politics, now with soldiers at my back. Oh yes, that would please him.' Severus said sarcastically.He sighed and leaned on the stone railing. 'No.. I need to leave Monarchia.' he stated with conviction.They were quiet for a while, simply watching the proceedings below. Even the Archon himself looked bored at the whole thing.Severus noticed that Elyria was biting her lower lip, a tic she usually had when she was thinking. 'I may be able to help you, Severus.' She finally uttered.He looked at her curiously, waiting for her to elaborate.'I came home early, not just because of the weather, but because I was asked to.. find somebody in Monarchia who would be willing to serve a greater purpose. I honestly doubted I'd find such a character in our Monarchia, but neither was I thinking of you.' she explained. Severus was about to speak, but she continued. 'This is not something you should take lightly, this is dangerous work. This.. might kill you if you're not careful.'She had a concerned look on her face. Severus knew her well enough to know that she rarely wore that particular expression.'What have you gotten yourself into, Elyria?' he asked plainly. 'I can't say.' she said. 'But I need to know if you truely want this. Tell me you want the job, and I'll make sure you get it.'Severus paced back and forth, weighting his options. Elyria continued to watch the exchange in the Senate, almost ignorant of his dilemma.He finally stopped, standing at his regular spot again besides Elyria. His voice dropped to a whisper. 'And what about.. Him?' He asked quietly. Elyria looked up. 'What about Him?' she asked.'Don't be coy.' Severus said, clearly annoyed. 'You know as well as I that we are bound to.. Him.'He had almost said it's name out loud. He fortunately had been able to hold his tongue, one does not utter the name of Ka'bantha without consequence. All the children of the Trevelyan family was bound to that creature when they turned 16. It was a family secret, one even not the closest friends of the family knew of. It was how the Trevelyans had risen to nobility some three-hundred years ago. Magical power was everything to the nobility of Monarchia, and the entire Senate below them were Wizards, Sorcerers and users of more exotic magics. Mages of all kinds were represented.Elyria smiled. 'Don't worry about Him, Severus. He is too busy with the schemes of the Nine Hells politics himself.' She shot him a glare. 'Just don't mention Him to anyone outside of Monarchia, they care as little for pacts with Devils as the narrow-minded fools down there.' she motioned to the floor below them.Severus nodded. 'I need time to think on this.' he stated. 'Can we meet tomorrow? Perhaps for breakfast?''Certainly.' replyed Elyria. 'I will see you tomorrow then, Severus.''Yes. See you there.' he said absent-minded and walked down the stairs, home to the family villa.The next morning Severus strode into the atrium of the Trevelyan villa. It was a large open space, with a view to the clear sky where the morning sun was shining brightly. The servants bowed as he took place at the table sitting at the centre of the atrium, they quickly rushed out with plates filled with fruit, meats and breads. He poured himself a glass of wine and took a quiet sip. It was rather warm, likely having been left on the table since the last meal.If he desired he could have one of the servants whipped for that, but he remained silent and simply cooled the wine he was holding with a thought before taking  another sip. It was perfect temperature.'You're up late.' said Elyria as she entered the atrium from the foyer.'I've had a lot on my mind.' he said, sipping the wine, savoring the flavour as it touched his tongue and rolled around in his mouth before swallowing.He looked up at her as she took a seat and poured a glass for herself. 'I need to know more about this purpose you're suggesting.'Elyria sat the jug of wine down. 'Leave us.' she said to no one in particular as she snapped her fingers. Within moments the servants had left the atrium. She leaned forward and looked Severus in the eyes. 'I can't tell you much. But what I can say is that you'll likely be working with a team of people to find and investigate magical disturbances. That's all I can say.'Severus scuffed 'Why do they need me for that? Don't they have Wizards of their own?' he said mockingly.Elyria shot him a glare. 'You forget that outside of Monarchia, magicians are more rare than they are here. Their nobilities are not made up of mages like they are here.' she explained.'Hm, maybe there's less arguing in the courts then.' he smiled.'No, unfortunately there is just as much arguing there as in Monarchia.' She looked around. 'I've been asked by the Archon to attend the court in Forlos. I can take you with me and let you off in the capital, or maybe even one of the smaller towns on the way. It'll be no trouble.'Severus thought about it for a long moment, before finally relenting. 'Very well, I shall accompany you to Forlos.' he paused. 'And see what this job you have for me is.'Elyria clapped her hands in excitement. 'Excellent! I'll make preparations immediately. We should be able to leave in a few days, I'll send word.'They both looked up as footsteps approached from the foyer, until Axios stepped into the atrium.'Ah, Good morning you two.' he exclaimed as he took a seat at the head of the table. He looked around for a moment. 'Where has all the servants gone? Am I suppose to pour my own wine?'They all laughed at the joke. 'It wouldn't hurt with some humility once in a while, brother.' said Severus as Elyria snapped her fingers at a much louder volume that should have been naturally possible. Moments later, the servants hurried back into the atrium to attend them.'Oh, I'm sure you're humble enough for both of us, Severus.' he said with a smile. 'Just as you have twice the ambition of the rest of us.' Severus retortedThey laughed again.Elyria spoke up after a moments of silence. 'I was just telling Severus that the Archon had requested that I attend court in Forlos.'Axios eyes focused on her. 'Indeed? Forlos.. that is rather far away isn't it?' he said thoughtfully. Elyria nodded 'About two weeks travel with carriage. I've been there once before. A novel people, if rather..' She sighed 'Uncivilized.'Axios scoffed as if that was the most obvious thing in the world.'She also suggested that I accompany her.' said Severus. Axios gazed at him with a rather surprised look. 'I was unaware that you wanted to play ambassador.' he remarked. 'I could have made arrangements.' he drained the rest of his glass in a single motion. Moments later the glass was full again, filled by a servant without a request. Axios didn't seem to notice it had ever been empty.Severus held up a hand. 'No no, it's quite alright. I'd rather see the people without having the duties of an ambassador hanging over my head. That was I may observe the proceedings with a clear mind.'Axios winked at him. 'Ahh I get it.' he said, likely without getting it.'We'll be leaving at the end of the week.' said Elyria 'Sadly the Archon said that this was rather urgent.'Axios looked at Severus. 'I know you don't have any proper traveling clothes. We shall have to call the armourer and have him fashion the finest armour for you, Severus.' he proclaimed loudly. Severus was less than enthusiastic. 'That won't be necessary, Axios. Just some plain leather will do me fine. I don't want to outshine the entire court.'Axios laughed 'Non-sense, I insist!' that seemed to be the end of the discussion.Three days later, Severus and Elyria was standing at the edge of the city in front of the city gates. The walls themselves surrounded Monarchia, with the nobilities villa having been built close to the Senate itself, with a marked district in the outer areas. The plebian population was mostly living outside the city-wall where a they were another city onto itself.The carriage that was to bring them to Forlos was rather plain. Severus approved. There were also four Skitarii guard which would escort Elyria on her official visit to Forlos.He looked at himself, in the armour that Axios had commissioned for him. He had been happy when he had seen it, for it was much more plain than he had expected from Axios. It was excellent quality, created to his exact dimensions, but lacking much of the decoration that Axios himself would have demanded.The only exception to this was the family crest which was embroidered onto the chest-piece of the armor: a fiery phoenix embracing a book.'I listen to you more than you give me credit for.' said Axios with a smirk on his face. 'It would appear so.' said Severus before smiling at his brother. 'Thanks, Axios.'      'Don't mention it.' he said, extending his arm. Severus grasped it, holding his brother in a strong grip at the wrist, as his brother did the same. 'March with fortune.' they both said at once and broke the grip. 'Tell father, I'm sorry I couldn't say goodbye.' Severus said. Axios merely nodded.Axios and Elyria made their own goodbyes as Severus climbed into the carriage. He sighed heavily, filled with an excitement that he could barely contain and nervousness.Elyria climbed inside soon after. 'You can strike that grin off your face, I'm not looking at that for two week.'When they reached the edge of the city-limited, Elyria fished out a letter from the satchel she was carrying and handed it to Severus. It was sealed in wax with her personal heraldry, a slight variation of his own fiery phoenix and book motif, as the stamp. 'Keep that close to you.' she said. 'It will be your entrance into the order when we arrive.' Severus raised an eyebrow at a mention of "the order" but from the fact that Elyria now seemed to ignore that any conversation took place, he merely smiled and put the letter in his own satchel bag.

The Exile was born into a small clan in the far north. He was raised to be a retainer in his lord's house. As a young retainer, his lord was attacked by a monstrosity. He shied away from fear and allowed his lord to perish. For that, he was banished from his homeland, never to return. Nine years have passed. He has wandered Fae-run looking for purpose. As he rests one night, he has a vision from the goddess, Selune, to go to Waterdeep and redeem his honor. Now, he journeys with a purpose and a calling: to defend all the free peoples of Fae-run.

Born in Farview in the Moonshae Isles, Caul comes from a family of sailors and merchants. He worked on his family’s ship throughout his childhood and teen years and is very comfortable on the sea. When he was 15 his family’s ship was attacked by pirates and most of the crew and his family was put to the sword…he escaped with his life because he was knocked unconscious by a sword blow to his head (causing a scar and seemingly dead eye). He awoke shivering in the cold water, floating on the debris of his family’s ship, and was discovered by a member of the Order of the Flagon. The Order of the Flagon is a monastic order that resides at the Iron Keep, a small former military stronghold on Omans Isle. Scale, the monk who rescued him, gave Caul the name Shivers because of how he was found. The Order of the Flagon is comprised of ex-military and sailors who have tired of their former lives and seek deeper meaning to their existence. At the Iron Keep the monks focus on a number of things: training their minds and bodies to be weapons, harnessing potential innate magical abilities, assisting all those who may need it, maintaining a proper sense of humor about most things (they consider that the only appropriate response to the randomness of the world), and brewing ale so good that a sip may help you see the workings of the universe…they tend to drink their brew pretty heavily. During his years there, Caul discovered an affinity for martial arts, both empty-handed and with a quarterstaff, as well as some innate druid magical ability; he also became the assistant brewer for the order by the time he was 20.The tradition of the Order dictates that individual members go forth into the world for at least 2 years in order to enhance their fighting training, help those who need it, and to research ingredients and techniques to experiment with new beer recipes and styles. Caul left the order at the age of 24 and has now been traveling the Sword Coast for one year. He is currently in Waterdeep working as a bouncer at a popular waterfront tavern and brewery called the Besotted Beholder and experimenting with their brew system whenever he gets a chance. Caul carries a long carved ironwood mash paddle that he uses as a quarterstaff when fighting. It is carved down from an oar that he was clutching after the his family's ship was destroyed. It is reinforced with iron strips along the sides and wrapped in leather at several points.

Young Jango Dongsworth was tailor before to the Duke before he was found mysteriously murdered, garroted with a tailor's measuring tape and stabbed with a pair of tailoring scissors. He now specializes in burglary (the sexy kind), hiding in bushes (both the sexy and not-sexy kind), and seducing everyone he meets. He possesses a truly enormous love trumpet.

Rhalia's life was turned upside-down the night The Orc Lord of Laerhaven attacked her home town. Lander, Captain of the City Guard; her husband and father to their 10-year-old son, Valen, was killed in the attack. As the Orc Lord's raiders ransacked the town, Rhalia hid Valen away in their home before being captured and taken prisoner to be used as a slave in Laerhaven's dungeons. Using a warlock's powers, she, and the rest of the slaves, were kept under control. If one tried to escape, a location spell would easily track them down and punishment would be severe.As time went on in the dungeons, Rhalia became hardened by her mistreatment. She spent her time studying the filth and scum that inhabited the city of Laerhaven. A thief and charlatan named Jakobi was also imprisoned after trying to cheat a trader in town. Rhalia grew close to him and learned many skills and tricks. They learned the nature of the spells and traps used to keep the slaves under control. They learned the limitations and extent of those as well.Her heart mourned for her home and family but Jakobi was a much needed helping hand. Soon she became pregnant. She knew that there would be no chance of survival for her child should she be discovered. She feigned injuries and illnesses- just enough to keep her from working but not to be considered useless- to keep her pregnancy secret. The orcs were ruthless but they were not that smart. On the final night of her pregnancy, Jakobi did the unthinkable for her. He attempted an escape in order to distract the guards long enough from the cries of the child being born; and to buy Rhalia enough time to smuggle her away from the city.Rhalia had connections outside the city walls. An entity known only as "Grandmother Night" had kept her and Jakobi supplied with tools and food while they were imprisoned. A troupe of travling lightfoot halflings was dispatched to help smuggle a package out of Laerhaven's dungeons. The package they received was not the one they were expecting. It was an infant girl named Joy Beestinger. As Rhalia watched her daughter taken away to safety, she turned and ran back towards Jakobi's planned escape route. She arrived in time to see Jakobi on his knees, captured by the barbaric guards. She watched in horror as he turned to her and winked just as a sword was plunged into his chest. She knew not to scream. She only cried.Years passed and finally, it was time. Under the cover of darkness, Rhalia led a small group of slaves through the sewers but not towards the outside walls. They emerged in the basement of Laerhaven's fortified hall. They slaughtered the bodyguards in silence. They butchered the warlock in his sleep. Only the Orc Lord remained. Rhalia would slice his throat herself. She was cold and unfeeling as the life seeped from the wound and onto the filthy sheets of the giant bed. The Orc Lord was no more. They were slaves, no more."Mother. Forgive me. You raised me better than this." She muttered as a small figure met her outside the town walls. The smell of baked goods and honey met her nostrils."Nonsense, child." The halfling woman stepped into the moonlight. "I raised you to fight for what you believe in and do what is right. The same things you taught your own child, whom you should see, by the way. He's so handsome!""Valen is alive?!" Rhalia's knees buckled and she fell in front of her mother. "But.. I had not thought of him- I didn't believe he could be.." Her mother's small hand on her shoulder steadied her."Alive and well. As is.. Joey?" She added."Joey?" Rhalia looked puzzled for a second but smiled again as tears streamed down her face. "Joy. Her name is Joy. My Joy." She closed her eyes and remembered the words of Jakobi. ("You are my joy.")"Go to them, my dear sweet child.""Yes, mama." Rhalia breathed in her first deep breath of freedom in very long. "I will go to my children. Thank you for everything, mama. I love you.""I love you, too." Said the small woman, holding a staff out for Rhalia to take. "You'll need this." She smiled. "Oh! And these. You look hungry, dear, eat before you set out." She handed Rhalia a sweet-smelling bundle wrapped in an elegant kerchief and with that, seemed to disappear into the shadows.Rhalia smiled and sighed as she looked up to the heavens. She would need money to travel.. and armor.. and more weapons. She knew just where to go.

Tulip has spent most of her life in the care of a mental institution. She was discovered amongst a number of ill-treated prisoners in ragged clothing kept hostage by a group of insane cultists of the Great Old Ones some years ago.On the surface she seems to be child-like, her way of speaking and mannerisms playful and whimsical, talking of playmates, friends, tea parties, candies, cakes, cute puppies and kittens, that sort of thing.Over the past several years, however, her once placid and innocent behavior has descended into greater and greater violence. While once it may have been that her imaginary friends were just that, imaginary, it seems that the stars have aligned and something dark whispers to Tulip."Tea party" seems to equivocate to severe violence perpetrated by the tea party hosts upon the guests, who are then sent to "The Grandest Tea Party of Them all," whatever that is.She was discovered living quite happily amongst the corpses of the two dozen or so patients and six staff, covered in blood, drawing dark and arcane sigils on the walls, amidst drawings of the happy and pleasant things her speech is often peppered with.The bodies revealed that they did not died pleasantly, set upon and partially devoured by beasts with claws and fangs. Tulip was certainly not responsible for this, instead somehow managing to summon vile creatures into being. The only one left behind was an animated skeleton Tulip dubbed "Mr. Buttons," who she made herself.One of her imaginary friends, whom she calls the Lady in Shade, told her that she was meant to be a princess. Tulip decided that as a princess, she needed a butler. So she made one.Obviously mentally ill, Tulip was then placed in far stricter and more controlled medical care. Pages upon pages are devoted to conversions between Tulip and her primary care doctor and read as a descent from a good and noble doctor into a mad lunatic seeking to curry favor from dark powers from beyond time and space.Tulip, apparently, had learned how to spread her warped state of mind at a touch. Once again she was discovered happily amongst a massacre, quite contently having dinner, dressed in a ball gown, being doted on by her followers amidst the patients and staff who had turned fearsome cultists who regarded her as a gateway of power and insight from their new dark masters.Tulip was exorcised, a dark spirit that amplified her power driven from her. That did not, however, prevent her from once again murdering a careless guard and recreating Mr. Buttons.No longer thought of as merely mentally ill, Tulip has been sentenced to death for her part in the blasphemous murder and ritualistic sacrifice of the staff and patients of the hospice that did not come under sway of the cult.She doesn't quite seem to understand her fate. She insists that she be given her dress back, as she has a ball to attend. She is a princess, and she is finding this time out very inconvenient. And also boring. She's also lost her puppy, he flies, you know.

DYNAMIC ENTRY they're a warrior bard. They will jump through windows and derail fights by singing so beautifully everyone's enraptured. (All of the natural 20s all of the time.) They're non-binary, prone to giving away all their money because what is both good spending habits and a frugal nature, and they'll apparently punch Billy Joel fans so hard they die in one punch.

He was orphaned at an early age, after his parents were killed by a group of xenophobic humans who saw Ifrits as animals, and wanted to harvest their valuable fireproof skin. A girl from the southern lands (Read: Australia) who was travelling with her merchant father came across the young ifrit and they became good friends, and her father eventually decided to adopt him. The girl, Emily, gave him the human name Dave after her grandfather David who had recently passed. When the three returned home, the girl's mother did not like Dave being a part of the family, and made life miserable for him. Many years later, after the mother had passed, and the father reached an advanced age, he bought a parting gift for Dave and Emily as he knew he would not be long for this world. The gift was a wolf, who the pair named Luna, and she was to protect them and comfort them in the years to come. One night, the father passed of an illness. Dave and Emily wept, and eventually fell asleep in each other's arms. Dave was awoken by Luna's howls, and found that Emily had gone missing. There was no immediate sign of a struggle, but none of her belongings had been taken nor had she left a note to explain her absence. With Luna by his side, Dave left on a mission to recover his friend and sister, vowing not to rest until she was returned safe. It was on this mission that he stumbled across a tavern, filled with an unlikely band of heroes, including (among others) a drow, a bear and a priest who was having an animated conversation about candles. Little did he know, these unlikely friends would enlist him for a ridiculous quest, involving a nearby Emerald Spire...

When the Riedran assassains came, Gideon fled the Adar keep of Dvaarnava along with his twin brother, Galadir, and a few companions.  The reluctant adventurers made their way to Khorvaire traveling up the Dagger River to Breland.  Sometime after landing in the Breland capital, Wroat, Galadir and Gideon had suffered a philosophical disagreement leading the former to remain in Wroat while the latter journeyed north toward Aundair.  While Breland and Aundair were not in open war, circumstances prevented the two from communicating frequently.  Gideon and Galadir were never forced to face one another on the battlefield.In contrast to his commanding brother, Gideon is quiet and unassuming preferring thought to words and careful planning to quick action. Gideon was serving as a cleric in a shrine to Arawai at Passage when a summons came from Queen Aurala ir'Wynarn.  Since the recent losses preceding the Treaty of Thronehold the Queen pressed Gideon into service at Fairhold and he subsequently joined the Sky Knights division stationed there as a battlefield cleric.

Riedran assassains forced twin brothers Galadir and Gideon from their home.  Fleeying the Adar keep of Dvaarnava on the far-flung continent of Sarlona with twin brother Gideon among others, the small group of adventurers made their way up the Dagger River into Breland.  Sometime after landing in the Breland capital, Wroat, Galadir and Gideon had suffered a philosophical disagreement leading the former to remain in Wroat while the latter journeyed north toward Aundair.  While Breland and Aundair were not in open war, circumstances prevented the two from communicating frequently.  Galadir and Gideon were never forced to face one another on the battlefield.In contrast to his thoughtful brother Gideon, Galadir often uses his physical prowess and force of will to the advantage of intimidation.  A flashy smile and air of importance generally comprise his countenance.  King Boranel quickly recognized the ease with which Galadir handled everyday Wroat and enlisted him as a officer among the Paladins in his service.  Though changing hands numerous times previously, under Galadir's eye Cragwar remained controlled by Breland for the signing of the Treaty of Thronehold and away from Aundair and Thrane.

Fodel Stefanov, Kosef’s father, was a simple wheat farmer living just outside Tantras with his half-elf wife, Jhessail, until the 13th of Eleasis.  In the Year of Shadows when Torm chose Tantras as his home among mortals, Bane led an army to destroy the city and steal something precious from the god of duty.  To protect their only son, both parents gave themselves to Torm that day.  Kosef’s only other living relative in the city at the time was Sergor Stefanov, his grandfather, but he had disappeared a week earlier… along with many others who worshipped gods other than Torm.  Dorn Greywood, Jhessail’s father and Kosef’s grandfather, is a retired merchant who did well for himself.  Now residing in Harrowdale Town, Dorn prefers his solitude.  Over twenty years ago his elven wife, Imizael Eveningfall, left him when she followed the elves of Cormanthor in the Retreat.  Dorn spends most of his time smoking his pipe and contemplating Imizael’s reasons, sure that if he could understand them perfectly he would know what he should have done to keep her from leaving.  In his youth, Dorn traveled the Dales and nearby regions both on business and as an amateur adventurer dabbling in magic.  This was before he picked up the regular route that took him through Tantras, which is how he befriended Fodel and how Fodel came to marry his daughter.  Jhessail’s life had been so awkward up to that point that Dorn was happy to see her wed to a good man who would care for her.  Stefan, Kosef’s great grandfather from whom the family took its name, was a great warrior and is a renowned folk hero in Kosef’s hometown.  The locals attribute a great many battles and victories to Stefan, and at least one of them is true: Stefan single-handedly turned back a Drow raid bent on razing the town.  One of his neighbors even commemorated the battle in song (see below).  Stefan renounced his familial ties to the Xinleal family when they embraced the Zhentarim, but he could not bring himself to destroy the truth.  Because of this he pens a book, The Ancestry of Xinleal, detailing his family’s history as far back as Brennus Xinleal and his origins in the ruins of Hlondath.  No living Xinleal or Stefanov knows their heritage extends back to Karsus of Netheril, as it was purposely forgotten after the fall.  The Xinleal family of Zhentil Keep, a family whose traditional service to the Keep’s military over the past seven hundred years, are Kosef’s cousins who exiled Stefan over seventy years ago to prove their loyalty to the Zhentarim.  Unquestionably loyal and holding prestigious positions in the Zhentarim, the Xinleals fell to worshipping the God of Strife after Stefan’s exile.  With Bane’s death and the rise of Cyric, the Xinleals followed Fzoul Chembryl’s example in paying lip service to the new god despite their distaste for him.  During Cyric’s madness, the Xinleal family predicted the catastrophe in Zhentil Keep and relocating to the Citadel of the Raven, which now serves as headquarters to the Zhentarim.  When Iyachtu Xvim emerged from the rubble of Zhentil Keep the Xinleal family gladly dedicated themselves to the Baneson’s service as did their role model, Fzoul Chembryl.  The Xinleal family dedicated a portion of their resources to the reconstruction of Zhentil Keep and a portion of the family continues its residence in the Keep if for no other reason than to avoid breaking a tradition of over 700 years of residence in Zhentil Keep.The Stefanov family has kept secret their familial connection to the Zhentarim for over three generations.  No Stefanov in that time would choose such an allegiance, and none would have wished their family name slandered with mention of such a connection.  Kosef is still oblivious to this, as he never read The Ancestry of Xinleal.An even older secret is the Stefanov family’s heritage which dates back all the way to Karsus of Netheril.  The Xinleals (whom the Stefanovs trace their heritage to) felt shamed by their relation to Karsus and concealed it just as the Stefanovs now conceal their relation to the Xinleals.Kosef is a devout follower of Torm, having been raised in the faith by his father who also believed.  His mother, while not claiming Torm as her patron, had a strong sense of duty concerning her family and was supportive of her son’s choice of worship.  Additionally, seeing the god of Duty die in the name of his duty to protect the city of Tantras cemented Kosef’s belief that Torm was the most noble and honorable of the gods.
