Late in the night, he locked up his shop and struck out for Cana.

"On the day of the alignment, when all the signs are present, one will be born of the greatest evils of the world, that will bring destruction to his enemies."So... happy birthday to me, I guess.Look, I wasn't there.  Alright, technically, I was.  What I mean is, I wasn't... aware... enough at the time to take note of the "signs" myself.  So for all I know, someone read some sign wrong.  *growling* Or perhaps cutting me out of my mother at the "appropriate time" doesn't count as being "born" as far as mystical prophecies go.  *growling intensifies* Or maybe expecting an infant to slay all of your enemies for you...*takes a few deep breaths*Sorry.  Sorry.  In any event, it would appear that the "chosen one" wasn't quite as chosen as they wanted.  So my youth wasn't very pleasant.  On good days, it was near constant labor:  serving meals to the leadership, cleaning up after rituals and experiments, that sort of thing.  On the bad days... well, they had someone, a reminder of past failures, to take their frustrations out on when another one of their plans didn't go quite as they hoped.When the scales started growing in, I thought it was due to years of having to clean up some fairly noxious substances.  I did my best to keep them hidden while I tried to figure out what was causing them on my own.  And when I did..."By the scales of his bloodline shall you know him."No.  *growling* After everything they put me through... *deep breath*  I was not going to be their chosen one.  So I grabed as many scrolls as I could, and ran for it.  I've been living in seculsion for a while now, doing my best to survive, and study the various writings I brought with me.  As much as I hate to say it, there may be something to them.  There have been enough little details proven right to make me think something... big... is on the horizon.  Something that's going to be bad for a whole lot of people.It's not me.  I won't let it be me.  Because I'm going to stop whatever it is.Somehow.

Malfior was born to enslaved parents and taken from them shortly after hisbirth. He grew up in the slaver's house and worked in the kitchen, which kept him sheltered from the true atrocities committed by his owners. 		One night as Malfior was finishing cleaning up after making dinner another slave came bursting into the kitchen with slashes and bruises all over his body.Malfior had absolutely no idea who the slave was or what to do. Moments after the unknown slave burst in, two of the master's sons walked in and killed the unknown slave in front of Malfior, exposing him to what life was really like for those not fortunate enough to be in a comfortable position. After seeing themurder of another fellow slave he started planning an uprising with theother slaves in the kitchen. They slowly spread the word to the otherhouse slaves, and it eventually made its way to all the slaves on the property. 		The uprising was brutal, bloody, and fast. The slaves who were tasked with guarding the family were the first to turn and bear weapons on their masters. After the family was dispatched it became a free for all on the remaining extended family members and paid staff. After all was said and done the house layin ruins and anything of value had been looted. Malfior left before he could see any other person be killed. He adopted a life of crime to keep himself fed andclothed. He never took more than he needed and never stole from someone who didn't have extra to spare.		 One night he attempted to steal from a lavish temple in the biggest city he had taken residence in yet. As he was going through the coffers and offerings he felt a hand on his shoulder. The high cleric of this temple had heard the noise from his chambers and had caught him in the act. Malfior expected swift and harsh punishment, but was offered two options. Leave as he came and never return,or learn the teachings of helm and pick himself up out of the life of a thief. He chose to dedicate his life to the teachings of helm and use his power to ensure he never has to see another good person die again.

My Tiefling heritage is evident in my reddish skin, pure white sclera, horns & lithe tail. My horns measure 9" in length, curling up over my black hair, coming near to meeting in a point past my crown.I grew up in Baldur's Gate with my human mother (Tessele), a scullery maid. My Tiefling father (Reverence) having been a mercenary in the employ of the Flaming Fists, had died during guard duty, whilst attempting to drive off a lycanthrope. My mother worked the kitchen of the manse of Stor Wallwind, a Cleric of Helm. A Paladin of Kelemvor (Sealmyd Dulsaer), tracing a series of murders believed Stor to be a vampire . He decided to "cleanse" the manse & attempted to put all the inhabitants to the sword, before burning it to the ground. I watched as my mother was gutted and flung to the ground. As Sealmyd slid his blade through my throat, Stor ran. A cleric in service to the God of guardians, protection, and protectors ran. He left the innocent to die. As I lay with my life leeching from my body, the Weaver called to me offering power to change the world; to remove the destructive influence of the Gods. To end the evil deeds done in the name of the Divine. The speech of a god is the act of creation itself, but what happens when the gods lie? The small accumulated deceptions come together, forming a creature of webs and treachery, lies and deceit. The Weaver, it is called, but it is a being woven from the lies of the gods themselves. Its influence is felt each day, in the small comforts one tells oneself to the greatest of blasphemies against the divine concordant. Spiders toil in service to the Weaver of Lies.The Weaver of Lies is a dark being in the shape of a giant blackish purple spider with glowing orange eyes. My arcane focus is an orb reminiscent of the Weaver; a dark purple orb streaked with thin white lines with a dim orange glow at the center.As I toil to reduce the power of the Gods, my current alias is that of a lost descendant of Duke Jananth of Baldur's Gate, "attempting" to acquire allies and equipment to take back the keep that is rightfully mine.

Antheia, or "Anthy" as she prefers, was raised by her mother in a vast swamp, known simply as "The Mire." Their hut sat atop stilts in a grove of willow trees prone to dramatic fog banks. She was raised as a Druid, learning to live off the land, monitor the health of the bogs, and drive away destructive creatures. Her mother said once that her grandmother joined the Druidic tradition in atonement for a crime against nature by infernal ancestors, but Anthy didn't listen very close and doesn't remember the details.They did not live in complete isolation. Anthy's mother was a skilled apocethary and sold herbs, potions, and even poisons to those who sought her out. Sometimes they dealt with the lizardfolk tribes, but more often they traded with the citizens of Muddybottom, a backwater riverside town nearby. Her mother played up the aura of fear and mystery from her Tiefling features and magic to keep trade terms agreeable and to protect them, maintaining a dramatic "witch" persona. Anthy took to her mother's art and soon did the bulk of the potion brewing, but considered the theatrics more of a fun game than a necessity. Her mother often said they must be self-reliant due to their race, but Anthy found it hard to believe people are as cruel as her mother claims.A few months back, her mother left abruptly at the call of The Splintered Oak, a Druidic organization. Anthy began to worry when she did not return for months, as these excursions had previously never lasted for more than one month, but continued to keep shop in her mother's absence.One day a rather rude customer made threats to Anthy, demanding ludicrous prices with the excuse of "the magistrate will have your infernal head soon anyway."  While this left her confused and shaken, weeks went by without incident. Then, one evening upon return from gathering herbs she saw her hut being set ablaze by armed soldiers of Muddybottom.  Her shock was broken by a crossbow bolt grazing her horn and soldiers rushing at her. Calling upon the swamp to entangle them, she hastily retreated into the bogs where they could not hope to track her.  While Anthy can live off the land, she cannot bear the thought of a forever solitary life and has made for the nearest city, hoping to find this "Splintered Oak" to track down her mother.

Patches has been my best friend for as long as I can remember. For a long time I didn't undersatnd much of what Patches would say to me, but it didn't matter, he was still my best friend. I'd talk to him all the time, even when I didn't understand his answers. Patches taught me lots of stuff, like about what he calls arcane sigils and Elditch invocations, so I could play with lights and fire.I liked it when Patches taught me to speak to mummy without moving my lips, and we played tricks on the other children when I'd speak without lips and say I was a ghost. They got all scared and one boy wet himself. It was super funny.Mummy didn't like it though. She always got angry when I spoke without lips and was very cross when I listened to Patches and not her. She said sorry once for being cross with me and gave me a really special cake with lots of icing and rainbow sweeties too. It looked so delicious I gave mummy a big hug. She was very funny and started to cry and told me to be a good boy and eat the cake. Patches got very angry and told me not to eat the cake. He said I should give it all to mummy because I'd made her cry. We went out to play, and when I came hom, the cake was in the bin. Mummy said it wasn't good anymore, but I think she was cross with me again.My favorite game to play with Patches was Hero Adventurer, So the night that Patches woke me up and something smelt funny, I was excited because it was finally time to be a real hero adventurer. I grabbed my hero kit and Patches told me to be very quiet. We played a sneaking game to trick mummy and go outside without her knowing. Patches made me take my good winter coat, and that was good because it was cold. I tried my best to be very quiet when we sneaked through the city, and I must of been the best at the sneaking game because we didn't see any city guards. The smell got really bad but Patches told me not to worry about it. I trust him, so I didn't.And he told me where to go and how to become and adventurer and now it's super amazing because I'm in an adventuring party and were going to have real adventurers, not play ones, and I'm going to be a real hero!

About nineteen years ago, my mother was raped during a raid-nine months later, poof-baby Tiefling with bright red skin, horns (which grew to be a hands' length, pointing backwards) and a particularly thin, arrow-headed tail born to a human mother. My sapphire-blue eyes and dark blue hair must have been unnerving against my ruddy skin, and my mother abandoned me on the steps of the Cleric healer's convent of Pelor ((also called Al'Asran), the god of the Sun. Older man, golden hair and beard, shining white clothing) a few hours up the mountain outside of town. She probably thought that, as holy people, they would dispose of me.Instead they sought to change my negative past into a positive and named me Gold-Heart, taking me under their wings. I was raised by the Clerics, and tried to take their path. I had little skill for it, however. Rather, I had little patience for the rituals and little interest in memorizing the complex prayers, preferring to spend my time with wounded children and cheer them up. The nurses didn't begrudge it-in fact most of them were grateful that the children had someone their age to play with and keep them occupied, as they prefered to tend to the adult wounded.When I was nine this became easier as my talents as a Sorceress made themselves known. One night I was dealing with a child in particularly bad pain-I believe she had been cursed, and the matrons were having difficulty naming it in order to produce a counter. One of the elder Clerics, a stuffy man with little sense of humor, came into the room and asked me curtly to make sure the girl, only about five, 'kept it down' so he could attend to a passing noble with a flesh wound. Understandably, the girl was embarrassed and I was angry at his obvious lack of concern for those with less money. I wanted to punish him-but mostly I wanted to cheer the girl up. I wished suddenly and intensly that I could scare the living daylights out of the old bastard! The ability to manifest the illusion of a spider the size of a dog, I thought, would be hysterical.And suddenly a spider the size of a dog appeared in front of him. He let out a loud shriek and stumbled backwards-the girl was frightened for just a moment but she saw the grin on my face and must have realized it was my thoughts creating the spider. She started giggling and clapping her hands.I was sent to bed that night without dessert by the elder-but some of the nurses brought me up some after lights out time. Thereafter I got the nickname "Mischief" for the subtle pranks I played on the staff members and some of the better humored patients. By then I knew about Tiefling heritage and that a Valor name is usually taken, and I thought this one particularly fantastic so I adopted it as my first name. None of my caretakers objected. As a convent, we had plenty of books, and I trained myself in the way of a few basic spells and cantrips. One of the elder men at the convent had a few adventures under his belt and happily taught me staff fighting.  Whether he wanted to relive his glory days or give me a suitable and safe outlet for my energy I know not. Another ten years went by and I grew more and more restless--I was still a Tiefling, after all, and my penchant for causing Mischief (however well-meant)  was also growing to be more and more of a pain for the Clerics. Still, they always appreciated that I kept the children happy whenver I could. When a visiting Paladin nobleman came through the convent and offered to take me adventuring with him, I doubt he expected me to nearly jump on him with enthusiasm-but I did.

It came as no surprise to the young tiefling, Khari, when he was sat down in front of his parents and told that he was adopted. He had already suspected as such, being that one parent was an elf and the other was a half-orc, and neither was inclined toward any sort of infernal arts. The fact that they were lesbians would normally have clued him in as well, but at such a young age, he didn't quite make the connection. They told him that he was found as a young toddler, unconcious and abandoned in the desert wastes by a passing trade caravan, where he was taken to the tiny backwater town of Dust. Truth be told, the news didn't exactly change anything for Khari. With such a low population in general, there were only a couple other tieflings in town, and Khari, specifically, was the only imp-spawn, so he already felt like an outcast. As he grew older, Khari rebelled against his loving parents, and with Dust having a very short arm of the law, the tiefling garnered quite a reputation for bringing trouble wherever he went.Eventually, however, that trouble caught up with him, when, one summer night, a short series of misadventures ended with a stable fire. The fire killed many of the town's horses, and the blame was placed on Khari. Dust's old Sheriff had had enough, and Khari found his arms shackled in cold iron for the first time in his life. Khari was to wait in the Sheriff's jail until the local Marshall could take him to trial, but with the threat of severe punishment on the horizon, Khari managed to pull out one of his teeth and use it to pick the primative lock on his cell door and escape into the night.Catching up to a trade caravan that had just left town, Khari managed to hitch a ride to the nearest port harbor of Starboard. The tiefling wasn't prepared to be on the run, however, and tried to steal some food once he had arrived, but was quickly noticed. It seemed that the bustling city was all too familiar with Khari's brand of trouble. The tiefling managed to evade capture, but he was afraid that the chase would bring notice of his presence to the Marshall that would be hunting him down, so Khari snuck aboard a trade ship and waited until they were out at sea to reveal himself.In the nature of Khari's ever evolving string of bad luck, it turned out that the ship he found himself on was crewed by a group of pirates that weren't too happy at the notion of being a taxi service. Instead, they alleviated that frustration by pressing Khari into their gang. The imp-spawn, of course, hated it. He was stripped of his belongings and forced to work the gross, menial tasks that the ship needed performed. As such, he continued to cause trouble for the crew, picking fights and spreading mischief. But, as time went on, the pain of servitude lessened, both from familiarity and from climbing in the crew's duties, and Khari began to work alongside the crew instead of against them, coming to even enjoy his life as a pirate. The tiefling began to see the rest of the crew as something of another surrogate family, and they saw him as the little devil imp they had adopted.This too, unfortunately, wasn't meant to last. Around the time that Khari finally came of age, he became distracted while performing his duties in the crow's nest, and a Captial Navy vessel crept up on them, opening fire in the dead of night while most of the crew slept. The ship ended up sinking, but having gone down relatively near Aurias' western coast, it was thought that there might have been survivors. And so it was, as Khari eventually drifted to shore, alone and afraid. After a day of wandering, he stumbled upon an old cottage, where an elderly man helped nurse him back to health. Not wanting to bring attention to himself, Khari pretended to suffer from amnesia. After a couple of days of rest, a Naval official pounded on the cottege door, and asked the man if he had encountered any survivors of the battle. The old man surprised Khari by denying any strange visitors or happenstance, sending the official away. While the old man believed that it was likely that Khari was, in fact, one of the shipwrecked pirates, he believed that in his amnesiatic state, he could start a new leaf and leave that troubled life behind.This entire time, Khari had gone nameless to the old man, in order to keep up his ruse. It was at this point that the old man suggested that the tiefling adopt the name Trouble. He admitted it was a bit superstitious, but he thought that perhaps by placing his "troubles" at the forefront of his person, he could avoid it affecting him as it so clearly had in what they believed to be his past life. The imp-spawn took the name, and agreed to be led to the nearby city of Height, in order to truly find his new lot in life.As soon as the old man left the newly christened Trouble to his own devices, however, the tiefling almost immediately fell back to the only way of life he really knew. With naught to his name, he started raiding food stores, and ended up running into the local underground in the process. Asking to work with the group, he started working his way up the ranks of the criminal world, much like he had on the pirate ship.***It has been two years since he first came to Height, and in the process has worked a lot of easier jobs, like lookout and bagman, as he properly learned the trade of larceny. Caught on a charge of loitering (while casing out a joint), Trouble ended up working a job for Height's High Mage, and in the process ended up saving the city. This had the unfortunate effect of putting his face out there for the city to see, but even the criminal element was grateful for his efforts. After seeing what he was capable of, Trouble was promoted to a full, proper thief in the organization, and now works with DAN THE HARVESTER, using the lich as a fence.Trouble loves his new life, and has grown attached to the people of his organization, people who he's tempted to call his third family. He even greatly enjoys the thrill of working for the "good guys", and there's always a grin on his face when Va'al drops by for a visit. But much like his other adventures, he's sure that it's just a matter of time before his troubles catch up to him once again, and then this too, will end. Only time will tell how messy it will be, if Trouble's luck of escaping it even continues at all.

What should have been a wonderful day turned into quite a shock. Although her mother was fair and charming and her father was strong and rugged, Cináed took it to an extreme. She was born with a Infernal and a Primordial Bloodline by no choice of her own, but just the funny coincidence that the exact time that those curses or blessings would surface in one body, hers. In contrast her twin brother who came out only minutes later had no strange features at all.As you might imagine this has the potential for a lot of trouble. Since tieflings are almost universally hated or treated with prejudice, because of a certain stunt Asmodeus pulled claiming all tieflings as his own and changing their appearance to be more devilish. Furthermore primordials are known for their wanton destruction and selfishness. Though one thing stood against that all the one thing you could call a bright spot in this amalgamation of negativity, her incredible beauty and this caused some trouble of its own.Noya Cináed Coldsplitter was born in Waterdeep, the City of Splendor. She lived in the South ward, the poor section of the city. Her father was a dockworker, until he died by a falling crate when she was 15, and her mother is a seamstress. Although they were poor they did manage to get by and not go hungry all the time, which is quite a feat considering she had six siblings. So from a young age Noya had to help her mother with her craft which kept her conveniently away from the children who teased and bullied her about her appearance and her lack of a shadow. The times she didn’t have to help her mother were less pleasant, however her brother was always there to support and defend her.Contrary to what one might think about her personality Noya was actually quite outgoing and mischievous. Frequently getting into trouble because of the pranks she pulled with her magic. Though she quite often managed to get away with it because she was so cute and charming then. However it’s unsure if it was her own charm or her magical talent. Her brother wasn’t so lucky, but she never let him get punished from the things she did or they both did.Not all pranks ended so fortunate. One time at the age of nine when pranking a merchant with an illusionary sound the horse startled and ran her over. This incident caused her to almost lose her life, leaving her within an inch of death.	If it wasn’t for her supernatural toughness she would have been no more. While there was a great downside to her injuries, she was bedridden for many months, there was also an upside. Noya became more adept at sewing and making clothes, even designing them. Although there was little opportunity for the latter, because of their low wealth. Eventually in later years she managed to attract attention for her works by a more famous seamstress, dressmaker or tailor called Madeleine. Whatever you wanted to call it, she was good at it. Madeleine was really what got Noya into tailoring and dressmaking. Madeleine taught her the tricks of the trade and mentored her. She introduced Noya to the high society and taught her how to behave in such company. While simultaneously modeling the garments, with her brother, her mistress created in exchange for her apprenticeship. This and an extra stipend allowed her parents and her siblings to live more comfortable and not have to slave away at their jobs, though they preferred to continue their professions.Of course this got Noya in touch with the noble’s son and daughters some of which took a fancy to her, while others were put off by her appearance. In her early teens Noya learned a bit more about some noble’s sons, but it was never more than that.At her 15th year a horrible event occurred. Noya’s father was killed in an accident at the docks. Getting crushed under a crate his death was swift, but the consequences were not. This event had a profound effect on Noya. Her father, Malcer, was her rock. If she ever needed help he was there for her. That was now gone and she didn’t handle it well. One noble son took advantage of her vulnerability and with his charm he managed to gain her interest. During the dance, one of the many she had attended in name of her mistress, Madeleine, the noble’s son grew impatient. The reason he had approached her was because of her beauty and exoticness. Noya was to be another mark on his post. One more in a long line of defiled girls. One more girl to boast about to his friends.After a few hours he tried to coerce and pull her into the gardens. The gardens wherein so many girls before her had lost their innocence, but Noya did not want to be one of them. She resisted and pulled back, but her strength then was not what it is now and she couldn’t stop him. That is when she revealed her magical ability and she viciously mocked his charm, his manners and his appearance leaving him spitting blood and it enabled her to escape from his grasp long enough for her brother to come her side and defend her. The noble’s son being humiliated in public so audibly fled in his shame and he still holds a grudge against Noya to this day.Rumors were spread about Noya, her being a devil’s child and dancing naked under the moon singing in prayer to her patron and on other days she would supposedly cut open babies and eat their hearts. People avoided her for this for a while, but not everyone was so susceptible to the ridiculous rumors. A small group either not caring about her enough to believe the rumors or knowing Noya enough that they were false.One such a boy attracted her attention. His name was Torlyn Wands and he was seemingly unaffected by both her appearance and her magical abilities. Which of course was the result of his familiarity with this. It is he whom she gave her innocence on her sixteenth birthday and it was he who she planned to marry when she became eighteen. However it was not to be, the closer Noya got to eighteen the more restrained their relationship became. Until he at last confessed to her the impossibility of their marriage due to the pressure his family put upon him to instead marry a girl with a less ill repute. Heartbroken she could not stand being in Waterdeep where such precious memories lay dormant, but also great pains, so she left the city seeking means elsewhere.The years after she spend traveling from city to city finding work as a seamstress, before eventually traveling further, because no city was like home. On her travel she occasionally had troubles with bandits and monsters and had to reveal her magical talents to fight them off. Something she preferred not to do, because it would gain her unwanted attention. Which Noya already got enough of if not for her beauty, it was for her devilish or elemental appearance.What she not wanted did eventually happen when she was 21. In the city of Neverwinter Noya was accosted by a drunk merchant in a particularly high-end establishment. No matter what she did, from polite refusal to angry shoving, nothing worked. Eventually she told him to take a hike with more force than normal and as soon as she was done the man turned around abruptly and walked out of the establishment to the astonishment of a lot of people inside. To be using magic so blatantly and openly on another citizen is not something many would dare. Realizing what she had done, Noya quickly gathered her belongings and fled the building. She started making her way home making sure not to take a direct path to make it more difficult for anyone to follow her. It took Noya a while to get there. However finally at home she wasn’t alone. A man was inside and he offered her a proposition to join their organization and they would help her stay away from the guards that time. This is how she got to work with the Order of the Star Mages and it is how she got where she is today.

In a backwards land, a small and insignificant lord tried to summon a Devil to try and become a Warlock. Unfortunately he was tricked by the Wizard that sold him the ritual (or the Wizard was way less capable than he believed) and instead ended up face to face with a Demon not interested in upholding any side of any contract.Some time after the failed attempt, a child birth is preceded by all kinds of strange events: 9 goats started ramming their heads against rocks until killed, black, distorted frogs rained from the clear sky out of nowhere, all milk turned sour as soon as the sun went away, kids refused to make any sound for the whole night and every domesticated animal ran away from the mother in labor, going as far as hurting it's handlers if they tried to stop the animals. The woman died during childbirth.The kid was something from the nightmares and scary stories: two curved horns, bright eyes without pupils, a long tail moving slowly and several pointed protrusions over its dark red, almost brown skin. The baby, covered in blood and happily chewing parts of the deceased mother is taken to the nearby forest and left alone by terrified midwifes, certain they have angered some vengeful Devil or Fey.An old Druid woman stumbles upon the baby while investigating the strange behavior shown by the wild animals and decides to raise the creature and gives it a human name, Sebastian Clearsky.The kid grows up mostly alone with his foster mother in the forest. He's able to hunt, though not reliably - some animals can't abide his presence, yet others just stand deathly still when he's nearby. He can light a fire and set up camp. He learns how to read the marks on the vegetation to know if there's a pack of Wolves hunting game or if there's a Will-o'Wisp bothering the pregnant bear nearby. He knows what plants will give him edible fruits and which branches are better to support a tent. He's not exactly attuned to the nature around him, but even though he struggles, he learns how to deal with the his reality.Strange things sometimes happen around hi: claw marks in tress that belong to no known animal or monster nearby, fog and hail appear for some minutes in the middle of summer and every once in a while bugs will appear in masses inside one of his footsteps.Humans he interacted with were either afraid or angry at him; people just assumed he was an evil being. His mother, Lorena Clearsky, never judged him for what he was, but she never judged him for what he did either. She believed that things were what they were and her job was to help nature balance itself - which was the natural flow when things just were what they were.The idea that Sebastian was something other than what he thought he was terrified him. He didn't want to be a mere spectator to his own life's fate. 'What if I'm evil, no matter what I try to do?' He didn't really strive to be a beacon of good of morality, he just wanted to be himself, not a puppet to gods, devils or ancient dragons.When he's a little over 14 he comes across a young woman guarding a merchant cart all by herself in a desert road. She's the first person not to be afraid of him and even start talking to the Tiefling and being pleasant. Her name is Clarissa, she's short, head filled with a blond wavy hair, fair skinned, with small tattoos around her green, round eyes that blend with her multiple freckles. She's just turned 18 and isn't lean nor chubby.They quickly turn into friends and meet each other every week to chat, exchange stories (she once helped his uncle deliver a beautiful jade crown to the nearby lord's daughter's birthday! She been to cities, she's seen elves and dragon bones and gnomish trinkets of all kinds!) and just enjoy each other company. After a few months he's completely charmed by her beauty and joy and sincerity and gracefulness. She invites him to an encounter under the full moon's light and, delighted, Sebastian drinks wine and dances with Clarissa until he passes out.He wakes up on his back, black roots chaining him to the ground inside a crudely drawn circle of weird symbols. His chest is bare and Clarissa towers over him, holding a twisted bright-red blade attached to a handle made of distorted yellow bone, pulsating like a living thing. Her green eyes are inhumanly pale and she's completely naked, tattoos covering her body from the neck to her knees. The tattoos move, scorpions, snakes, spiders and shadows woven into her skin moving swiftly, as if fighting for another inch. From her mouth come wrong sounds, like a serpent or stone crushing or ice snapping or fire melting skin and charring bone; still he understand that she's singing. She's singing, no, she's calling for something bigger and older than creation.As soon as she brings the knife to Sebastian's chest the pain makes the world goes dark; he touches the coldness of the void, he sees depths of the nine circles of hell, he feels the despair of every agonizing soul held away from their gods and penitence. He hears his name being Called, his fate being pushed and pulled around like a dead rabbit thrown to rabid dogs, something dark and powerful and hungry for his role to be fulfilled toys with his soul.He hears and feels and sees everything yet he refuses to let reality have its way. He does not pray, he does not wish, he wills his truth into reality and, for a fraction of a second, creation bends to him. One last image is ironed to his mind before everything goes dark: Clarissa, eyes wide with terror, holding the blade with both hands, all her tattoos gone and his own blood covering her arms up to the shoulders.Sebastian wakes up in the morning alone, shirtless under the cold drizzle. All around him there are crumpled roots and dead things. The stench of rot and acid makes him gag. He feels his chest and finds a neatly healed scar, bright red, in the form of a small rune no bigger than his fist. He touches the weird rune and at once understand its meaning: [BANE].The red dagger is on his left hand, deformed and half melted. The blade is dull, the bright red now faded to an almost rust like color. The yellow bone is shattered but somehow every piece is still in the correct position. It doesn't feel right to leave the dagger in the forest, so he tucks it away and looks around.He can't find any sign of Clarissa or the circle. If not for his scar he would believe it all to have been a strange dream. Strange nightmare, more likely.Sebastian goes back to his hut and finds it completely deserted. No sign of anyone ever living there, just an empty place. He stays there for 3 months, every day going back to the place he woke up and finding nothing different, except for himself. He could feel power, someone's power, his power running inside him.Every day, before leaving the hut, he'd find a rune written somehow. Once it was a swarm of insects that moved together to form the symbol, once the rune in a dead goat's insides. One day it was clawed in every tree around his hut. Blood and feces on the ground; formed by the tangled antlers of a two rotten deers, locked in battle; appeared on patterns on the back of a dead frog, half eaten by the skeleton of a spider.Every day the same rune, the same idea would become clear in his mind as soon as he spotted the rune: [DISTANT CITY](It really depends on the game being run, the idea is that some outer power is prodding him to go to the city where the adventure will being) . He couldn't just accept that thing's order, whatever it was, but he couldn't deny Sebastian has hundreds of questions and no answer:Where was Lorena Clearsky? What happened to her?Who really was Clarissa? Did I somehow cause her to be possessed? Had she been trying to use me since the first day? Was she a good person - the only other person to treat me well - that suffered under some kind of otherwordly horror because of me? Was she a bad person all along that just saw me as an evil source of power? Where is she? What happened?Where is this power coming from? Who is trying to control me? Why [BANE]? Who is toying with my fate?No answers would be found here, there was only one way. Forward, always forward.Sebastian would move on, toward the city. He would grow strong to control his own fate and discover what happened to him.

Lemire grew up in the slums of Solarisane. Her father abandoned Lemire’s mother, Daspira, when Lemire and her sister were small children. Although Daspira never told her children much of their father (other than that he was a rotten bastard who deserved eternal suffering in Baator), Lemire suspected that he was the fabled assassin Barlech, and that he abandoned his family for their own safety. For the first few years of her life, Lemire’s family subsisted on a regular delivery of a few coins, presumably from her father. After some time, these deliveries stopped and Daspira soon turned to prostitution to keep her children fed. Daspira was able to fetch a surprisingly large amount of coin selling her body, with many men coming to the slums to fulfill their violent fantasies of “taming a demon.” At the same time, she was subjected to much abuse, and would often come home bleeding and with bruises. Daspira spent more and more time away from home, leaving Lemire to care for her young sister, named Gentle (Daspira had regretted not giving both her daughters “virtue” names, and often referred to Lemire as “Hope,” a name she rejected even as a small girl). When Lemire was twelve years old, she discovered her mother in a tavern purchasing black mold spores. Although Daspira denied that the drug was for her, for Lemire the last several months came into focus. Her mother’s erratic, inscrutable behavior and long spells away from home suddenly made sense in the context of dependency on the evil spores. The worry for her mother that Lemire had carried with her gave way to intense anger. She told Daspira not to bother coming home. Lemire would not see her again for four years. Needing to fully provide for herself and her sister, Lemire took to picking pockets. She was a natural petty thief, and soon became an accomplished pickpocket, cutpurse, and burglar. Although the slums did not offer many lucrative opportunities, the young tiefling felt safe there. While her brick-red skin and budding horns made others mistrustful of her, she knew that the slum was far more accepting than the world at large, and here she did not need to work especially hard to hide her race. When she did venture from the slums, she took care to cover herself in a heavy cloak and scarves to hide her face. While the purses were much heavier in the city center, there was also greater risk of being caught, and Lemire knew that her race would do her no favors if she were put on trial--if she even survived that long. She had heard many tales of tieflings ran through in the streets by the Gold Cloaks and city guards who would leave the bodies in the street while laughing and heading to the tavern for a pint. Needless to say, she only left the slum when she and her sister were especially in need.Lemire and Gentle lived this way for several years. Now old enough to take on some work of her own, Gentle found a job washing tankards at a grimy tavern. The tavern keeper was known for being kindly to tieflings, even when it hurt his business to do so. Many times he would open shop only to find TIEFLING LOVER and nasty epithets painted on his walls. No one knew why he took to tieflings, although Gentle had suspected he had once loved one. Though Lemire’s experience of the world was broader than Gentle’s, it was still rather limited; yet, Lemire felt she knew better than naïve young Gentle. No human man had ever loved a tiefling. Over time, Lemire learned to target other criminals: other cutpurses at first, working her way up to robbers and spore dealers and illegal weapons traders and worse. She especially delighted in stealing from those working for Geth, an infamous human gangster known for being cunning and cruel in equal measures who had taken over most of the black market trade in the slums. She targeted Geth because she had once heard a rumor that Geth had trapped and killed Barlech in his quest to consolidate power. One day, she saw Geth himself perusing wares in the market. She couldn’t believe her eyes. He had three body guards with him, but they seemed to be paying more attention to the shopkeepers and street vendors than they were Geth. She was sure that she was skilled enough to get Geth’s purse, which was tied loosely to his belt. She was wrong.Geth’s guards knocked her unconscious and brought her to one of Geth’s many safe houses. When she came to, the crime lord—slender, tall, gesticulating wildly while he spoke—revealed that he had set a trap for the young tiefling. Suspecting that she had been targeting his men specifically, he decided to present her with an opportunity she could not resist. He was impressed by Lemire’s audacity and told her as much. He asked her why she had been targeting him, but she refused to answer. Even after several broken fingers, she still resisted. “Like father, like daughter, I see,” Geth said, all but outright confirming Lemire’s suspicions that the assassin Barlech had sired her. “Well then, let’s try a different route.” One of Geth’s goons brought forth Gentle, who was restrained at the wrists and ankles and paralyzed with fear. “If you come to work for me, your sister will never want for anything. Riches will be yours. You can even deliver your whore mother from her wretched work.”Lemire, all the wrath of Nine Hells coursing through her, knew she had no other choice. Choking down her disgust and hurt, she agreed. Geth’s face twisted in a wicked smile. “Well, that was far too easy. Your father had much more fight in him.” He signaled to one of his guards who swiftly cut Gentle’s throat. Lemire screamed, kicking, trying to get away from the man who was holding her. Her tail lashed wildly. Geth’s gaze pierced her. “You’re a good thief, this much is true. But you flatter yourself if you think I have any need for a fucking tiefling daughter of a whore. You know, when I killed Barlech, it wasn’t just because he was a threat to me. I did the world a favor by ridding it of that demon spawn. You and your kind are abominations, girl.” Geth told her to leave town by next sunset. “And lest you think I will kill you if you don’t, a fate you’d probably welcome with open arms, know that what I have in mind for you is far, far worse than death.” Geth’s men blindfolded Lemire, knocked her unconscious, and dumped her in an alley.When she awoke, she immediately sought out her mother. She wasn’t sure why. For comfort? To say good-bye? She found her in a decrepit inn near the seaport. She wasn’t easy to rouse, but when she came to, Lemire could tell that her mother already knew what had happened; perhaps she had even helped Geth set his trap, who could say? Lemire didn’t bother accusing her mother; in fact, no words were exchanged between them. Daspira, looking as though she had aged decades, barely able to walk, hobbled over to a chest of drawers. One drawer had a false bottom, and from this hidden chamber she produced a small golden key. In Lemire’s career as a cutpurse she’d seen many such keys; they were for the personal vaults at the central bank. Daspira pressed the key into Lemire’s hand, and looked at her daughter with a sadness that knew no end. The two embraced.That night, Lemire painstakingly filed her horns and packed her few possessions, including a locket belonging to Gentle. She slept fitfully, and in the morning she dressed in her cloak and scarves. She knew she was being watched and did her best to evade Geth’s men. She suspected that they would not follow her into the city center, and she was right. At the central bank, she moved swiftly to the private vaults, her tail wrapped nervously around her left leg. She had expected to be stopped, asked to prove her business in the vaults, but no one so much as looked her way. She made her way to vault 406, the number imprinted in a tiny scrawl on her key, her good hand shaking as she inserted the key, the broken one hanging limply by her side. The lock clicked loudly as it unlatched. She looked over her shoulder. Still, no one was watching. She wondered if the key were perhaps imbued with some kind of magic. She opened the door and couldn’t believe what she saw before her: a silvery-blue needle the length of her arm, thin as spider-silk. She held it, turning it away from the light. She gasped as it seemed almost to disappear.With the small amount of gold she had been saving, her sister’s locket, and her needle wrapped in a scarf, she stowed away in the belly of the caravel The Grey Griffon. Lying uncomfortable in the ship’s bowels, her  dark eyes narrowed. The burning hatred inside her gave her confidence and resolve. “I’ll be back for you, you bastard.”

Leucis spent many years on the high seas as a part of the local slave trade, except in the raw end of the deal. On his 17th birthday, Leucis, two halflings, a minotaur, and a young tiefling named Tharrakir rallied their fellow slaves and took over their ship. That point onward, they took the ship known as "The Sad Devil of the North", and these men were pirates. Some time later, after enjoying their newfound freedom, the men were in port at a town known by Novinia. That is were Leucis met his newfound love, a human noble named Violette. Before setting out again, Leucis promised Violette untold riches and treasure when he returned from sea. However, the minotaur thought otherwise. The minotaur, known to some as Caesar, hated being under the leadership of Leucis and his quartermaster Tharrakir, who was but a boy. That trip saw Caesar staging a mutiny to kill both of the tieflings. Thrown overboard and cast away, the two fell-born men found them selves adrift in the eastern coast of Akenmir. With no knowledge of where their ship was, or where Violette was, Leucis used his natural knowledge of the land and Tharrakir's talent for magic to make way as mercenaries. Becoming known as "The Salted Devil" or "The Cast-Away Ranger", Leucis now finds himself traveling in caravans with Tharrakir, a human woman named Nova, a halforc mercenary named Aleksi, and a younger halforc named Henk.
Good-at-heart former inquisitor pledged to uphold the Tymoran faith as one of her very first paladins.

Koschei was a street tough, more a mugger than a thief, until one day he broke into an old mans house and found out he'd intruded on a shrine to The Traveller, an obscure old god with a single worshipper. When he went to steal the altar piece, he was struck with a vision from the traveller, and immediately converted, becoming a champion for the sick and helpless. Now he's a stringent believer in equal rights, helping he helpless, and not taking advantage of others

He seeks an ancient tome of legend. Supposedly, it gives a detailed history of his bloodline. But more importantly, he wants to use this information to exorcise the demonic lineage he was given at birth, because he believes the demonic side of him is responsible for his anger and evil acts. He sins and delves into all kinds of debauchery, but he seeks something to make him more human, and to make him love.  Little does he know, the power he draws from naturally in his body is connected to the demonic side of him. If he removes it, he may very lose his power, but also possibly his own life with it. He has a family friend he wishes loved him, for she is the one who gives him hope that he may one day achieve his dream of being good and human. She balances his evil tendencies, making him see the light.

Despite his low life expectancy, Skel is determined to learn everything he can. After learning 9 languages with (Linguist feat plus knowledge domain), he decided the best way to find knowledge is to quest for it. Packing his books, he sets out to Chult (this character was made for ToA) to find a party that can help him find something priceless.

Zohlos was a soldier in his kingdom's army. The kraken attacked the city and fled. Zohlos and the rest of the soldiers followed. During the fight, Zohlos was summoned to speak to a God and when he returned, his comrades were dead. Zohlos returned to the kingdom,  where he was labeled as a deserter and banished from the kingdom. Zohlos asked the king if he could return if he killed the kraken in the king's name and he agreed.

Sera and Erin are a sight to see, resembling a seven and a half foot tall, two-headed elf the sisters are a unique sight to see.On the right is Sera, she of slightly fairer skin and raven black hair kept straight in a simple ponytail, on the left her sister Erin, darker in skin tone with a fiery mane of hair that in parts flows free, and in others decorated with complex braids.The pair are quite a resplendent sight to see in their polished breastplate and violet cape, often astride a titan of an equine mount dubbed "Leviathania" or "Tania" for short.The duo wields a massive copper-plated sword atop an elongated hilt that makes it seem to function more of a spear than a proper sword, dubbed the Titan Blade, is based off of Tian Xian Nodachi, but with a longer, thicker blade, and a shorter haft.Dubbed the Magnum Opus, the weapon is the sisters' pride and joy and the shining paragon example of their craftsmanship at work. The pair have put their life savings into the blade, which may harbor a few tricks.The pair are well built and athletic, their frame made strong by working the force, their might for practicality, not beauty.The sisters share the du'Wyvern eyes; violet with a discoloration in the iris resembling a brown X, a family of minor nobility with branches scattered throughout the major cities of Golarion.The pair have different preferences in fashion, with Sera preferring beads and dangling rings, while Erin prefers more solid pieces and dwarven things that menace with spikes.The pair are part of the du'Wyvern noble family, a moderately well-off lineage spawned by the famed adventurer Thea du'Wyvern. Thea has left a trail of half-everything children spread over the globe in her centuries of life, and has started pawning off new ones on the fully grown ones in order to have more time for adventuring.The pair see their mother once, perhaps twice a year. She's currently south of Cheliax, poking around in the Mwangi Expanse. The sisters were instead raised by their older sister Kary, who is half-elf and half-dwarf.Sera and Erin's parentage has rarely come up, with Kary stating that the matter is "An unpleasant family shame that should not be spoken of."Sera and Erin took this to mean their mother had been forced into carnal relations with an Ettin, but the truth of the matter is that Thea is in fact a shape-shifter of some sort who travels the world not only for adventure, but also to basically boink anything that moves, and a few things that don't.Sera and Erin are two sides of the same coin. Sera is somewhat shy, quiet, and bookish, while Erin is loud, aggressive, boisterous, and utterly bereft of an indoor voice.Sera likes making things, while Erin likes wrecking things.Their mutual love is forging weapons and armor, which they do as a career. They get to make things that they then use to break things. They frequently take out new arms and armor designs on short adventures to test them against monsters and bandits and make their neck of the woods just a little bit safer.The pair are quite fond of their home city, though they generally find the rest of Cheliax to be rather unpleasant, and as a result have loose ties to certain rebel factions.Mostly it's slipping a little financial support here and there, occasionally it's making weapons and armor on the sly, free of any tax mark or artisan's stamp.As a result they have ties to the black market, able to sell for a little more and buy for a little less than most folks.The pair have had a classical education, and are quite intelligent and try to know a little about a lot, though their main branch of study was history and philosophy. Not particularly useful for an adventurer, but maybe some day they can branch out their studies.Despite their various shades of awkwardness, Sera the quiet nerd and Erin the immature jock, something just seems... different about the pair. Some natural aura of power or strength that makes lesser men and women look the them for leadership.Or maybe it's just because they're seven and a half ruddy feet tall and easily stand out in a crowd.Sera and Erin are trained the the path of the Warder, a knight-defender who emphasizes guarding their allies and stymieing the movement of their foes. The sisters' nature as two minds sharing one body gives them the capacity to easily wield what to most people would be a primary weapon in each hand, though they prefer to use their gigantic Titan Blade to keep enemies at bay, and retracting the shaft of the mighty polearm when foes get up close and personal, adding body blocks with their spiked armor to complement the dire blows from the Blade.The pair are trained primarily in the use of multiple weapons, requiring the use of lighter armor than most noble knights receive in training to better be prepared to make multiple angles of attack, but they make up for it by being able to almost always manage to get a weapon in the way.And like any knight, the pair have been trained in mounted combat, and despite their lack of a delicate touch and extreme personality, actually seem to ride and command their steed better than one would expect them to.The pair's mighty steed is a massive war-trained beast named Leviathania, or Tania for short, but when not in battle the horse is actually rather placid and surprisingly gentle.The sisters often treat Tania more as a pet than as a proper warhorse, and the creature is left in her stable as often as not when the sisters go adventuring. Sera is shy and tends towards quiet introspection.Erin is loud, often obnoxious, and has no filter between brain and mouth.And to top it all off if being seven foot tall and two headed wasn't strange looking enough, their shadow also happens to be weird. It changes shape based on whatever the pair is doing, usually in a form that seems to be some sort of quasi-sarcasting commentary on whatever they're doing.Adding angelic wings when Sera is giving an impassioned speech about the rights of the downtrodden, adding clawed fingers and devil horns when Erin is getting a little bit too bloodlusty in battle, making cartoonish, exaggerated sneaking motions when the pair are trying to be quiet while clanking about in the noisy armor covering their large, clumsy frame.It doesn't detect as magical, it doesn't respond to exorcism, the sisters have just learned to ignore it and state that it's the result of an obnoxious fey curse. To which their shadow makes a :P on itself where their heads would be.Sera and Erin have ties to their older sister Kary, Kary's handful of servants, a few folks in the smithing community, and a few people she's kept in touch with from her school days. The du-Wyvern townhouse would be in Villegre somewhere.For the most part her deepest ties are to several organizations that have agents in Kintargo working to keep the negative influences of Cheliax out.One such organization is the Cagebreakers, agents of chaos devoted overcoming tyrrany. Though them Sera and Erin have learned to channel the raw, chaotic power of the elements through their strikes. Though other Cagebreakers on the ground in Kintargo are few and far in between, some might be able to get word out to someone bigger (or badder, Cagebreakers aren't picky about the sorts they recruit, just that they want to bring down The Man), or point the way to a long disused cache of equipment. Or a storage locker full of crap no one cares about. Same thing, really.The pair also have ties to the Empyrean Guardians, a group that seeks to defend the innocent from those who would bring them harm. The Guardian Order are the ones that instructed the pair in the way of the Warder, as well as teaching them the Silver Crane discipline, allowing them to draw strength from blows dealt against the darkness to heal the wounds of the light.Though for the most part the Empyreal Guardians usually present in Kintargo have left to take part in the Glorious Reclamation, battling the wickedness of Cheliax on a grand scale, the people that they have aided may perhaps return the kindness of the defenders of the light.On one of the pair's adventures they did a service for a dwarf, rescuing his bard friend from a once magically sealed tower that had been recently re-opened to the world.Defeating a motley crew of Troglodytes with several other adventurers, the duo made acquaintances with a rogue named Martin, a Dragonborn sorcerer who introduced them to her family, and the dwarf and bard themselves.

Felleran was once a Red Wizard of Thay, the ruling class of a proud nation fluent in powerful magicks, but in a deal with Szass Tam, he presented his own body to go through lichdom, and become an undead creature to continue with his devious plans.

Bernard was born in a litter of pups to a pair of ursine parents. when the other pups learned to speak common, Bernard could still only growl wild-bear speak. In their society, the custom was to put him to death, leaving more food for the strong pups in the litter. Ashamed of siring a defective pup, his father had in mind to have him killed, but his mother hid him with some wild bears. Raised by wild bears, Bernard never mastered the art of speaking common, but understands it and can speak in the guttural wild-bear-speak. Bernard left his adoptive parents by choice, yearning for intellectual equals. Bernard became depressed and lonely, an outcast in the two worlds he knew- that of the ursine and wild bears. Bernard wandered, spent a few years in the circus, then wandered some more, doing good deeds when people’s fear didn't prohibit him from interacting with others, and eventually meeting friends who took the time to learn to understand his wild-bear-speak. Bernard looks up to his friends and depends on them to translate for him. He tries to never leave their side and is protective of them.He has a bit of an inferiority complex about being the weak cub that wasn't killed, and will try to showcase his strength and prove he is a valuable teammate whenever possible. Bernard plans to spend his first 1000 gold on expensive beard care products, and maybe a breastplate.
Long lost imperial battlemage, on the search for the way he was created and believes magic is the way to do it.
She's a biomechanical war machine created by their Red Dragon "god", but in truth is but one shard of a divine machine that has lost its way.

Dudikoff 7 was built for frontline combat, but found that he enjoys subterfuge much more.  He is trying to turn himself into the ultimate stealth weapon, though lately he has become more concerned with helping the communities he encounters in his journeys.

He was reactivated after centuries of being kept offline. He stumbled into a city and heard music for the first time. Inspired, he took up a horn and began playing to earn his keep. Eventually, he found refuge in an newly opened orphanage and worked as their bodyguard in exchange for shelter.

Built to be a weapon of war, Loupe was a unfeeling fighter until he grew a conscience.  After understanding what he'd done, he hid away in a cave for several hundred years, then returned to one of the cities he'd helped raze. He took a job as a jeweler, determined to avoid fighting and war for the rest of his existence.   That didn't happen.

Flyx lost their memory after being 'rebooted' and decided that they didn't like their position of being a servant. They left, joined the current party, and ended up becoming a freedom fighter while trying to spread hope and equality throughout the region. In their free time they use their Artisan (blacksmith) background to create/upgrade [magical] items and make sure no one else is getting themselves killed by falling off the party's new-acquired airship.

An elven artificer, during his golden years, started attempting to home-make a Warforged person. His first attempt failed, and he believed that in order to better work with what he had, he needed help. So, he made a small construct in order to help him with his work. Over the next ten years he'd made three more attempts at a Warforged, all of which failed. Finally, near the end of his life, he attempted one last time. It worked and he, sensing he wasn't much longer for this world, gave his Warforged a name, his construct assistant and a broadsword. Finally, Five was given his creator's Alchemist's Bag. He then was let loose to make his own destiny.

There was a medical student on the island of Novus. The third son of four in a middle class family, he didn't stand out. He got a partial scholarship for school, but it ran out and he was forced to search for an apprenticeship. The only arrangement he could get was more like indentured servitude. His new master separated him from his family and his few friends. The youth's curiosity and eagerness to make something of himself were all that sustained him. Early on, his studies continued almost as they had at university. Eventually, however, his master began to berate him for having only middling intellect and talent. His lessons became shorter and less frequent, and his days were filled with drudgery. His master took on other students, from wealthier families; smarter men and women who lived up to his strict expectations. They were allowed into the master's lab, when re he conducted secret research. Finally, when the student become servant had given up hope of being a doctor, the master invited him into the secret lab. Here, the master conducted experiments aimed at achieving takwiin, the creation of artificial life. Instead of being allowed to help conduct these experiments... The former student became a subject. With the help of advanced healing magic, he was kept alive and conscious as he was dissected and put back together, over and over, until the master believed he fully understood the mechanisms of life. Then, the subject was taken apart one final time. It took months, for the master went much slower this time. Each piece of the subject was removed, labeled, preserved, and used as a model to create an artificial replica. Then the new piece was attached. Piece by piece, the subject was disassembled and remade, aware the whole time. There are no words in any language, save perhaps infernal, to describe the pain. He begged every day, or at least every day that he had a mouth to beg, for the torment to end. The master was cold and unyielding in his amoral scientific fervor, but the other students left, one by one, and never returned. The doctor was left alone with his creation. Towards the end of the process, one other person did appear. The haze of pain masked their appearance and their words to the subject, but their purpose would become clear in hindsight. In fact, it would become nearly all-consuming. On the final day, the subject's pain faded, leaving him clear-headed and... Whole. Intact for the first time in what seemed like a century, but couldn't have been much more than a year. The master was there, looking at him, scrutinizing him with dispassionate eyes. The master said"Your name is Victor, and you have been given a purpose. Kill the High Inquisitor. You have been created for this reason, and no other. You have been given the tools and skills you will need to accomplish this task, and no more. Your name is Victor, and you have been given a purpose. Kill..."No more words reached Victor. Information flooded his brain. How to pick a lock. How to kill a man with a crossbow bolt from fifty paces. How to remain unseen. How to create deadly poisons. False memories also jostled for space inside his skull. They threatened to erase any remaining traces of that old, unfamiliar life that someone else had lived in another body. When Victor was again aware of his surroundings, the master was gone. The room was empty. Victor hesitantly stood, testing the leather, wood, and steel that now made up most of his body. He walked through an archway into the room beyond, and found a low bench with clothing and a pack on it, as well as weapons. To the side was a mirror that reached floor to ceiling. Victor stared. He saw a naked man, short and slim, with skin the color of well worn leather or waxed mahogany. A seam ran down his chest, starting at the base of his throat and ending at his navel, and inside he saw gears, shafts, dials, and wires. In the center of his chest, nestled among the machinery, glowed a red crystal shaped like a heart, with perfectly chiseled chambers and valves. Victor tore his eyes away, and quickly fastened the opening shut with implanted reflexes. He turned to the clothing and gear, and meticulously equipped himself. Then he left. A purpose burned in his heart: he was going to kill the High Inquisitor--it was what he was made to do.

Delnita's life has been sharply split into "before" and "after." The "before" is hazy, but she recalls a life as an ambitious Gnome mechanic in Redair.  There was a promising career, a stable relationship with her husband, as well as three precocious children.  She feels it was a good life, but dislikes dwelling on those memories.  Their inconsistancy discomfits her.  Sometimes there's clarity: she'll recall with exacting detail how she completed a contract to outfit a machinist's bench lathe with a multi-step cone pulley system.  Then, upon deeper reflection, she realizes that she cannot recall her wedding or the sound of her own daughter's voice.The "after" began the day she awoke in darkness, completely entrapped, unable to move or breath and yet not suffocating.  Struggling proved fruitless, but her cries for help rang clear despite her inability to breath.  Her restraint was soon released by a half-orc woman crowbarring the lid to her transport crate open, drawn by the muffled noise from within.  Unfortunately, and to Delnita's great surprise, her struggles manifested as an eruption of arcane lightning from her hand as the lid was opened.  The half-orc took the brunt, laying her out flat on the floor as Delnita stared at the unfamiliar hand in front of her.This racket drew a middle-aged human man, whose reaction to seeing the smoking, prone woman was to pull a pistol on Delnita. The ensuing standoff didn't last long, as Delnita's panicked feminine voice gave him pause, along with the half-orc's strained insistance that she was merely singed.  All parties soon realized their confusion was mutual, with Delnita particularly befuddled by the foreign metal body she was inhabiting.Once all calmed enough for conversation, the human introduced himself as Myrten, and the half-orc as his wife, Gortence.  He explained that they had purchased the mechanical body Delnita found herself in as part of a recent transaction, pointing out its intriguing features: the pristine condition despite signs of age, strange runes inscribed along her joints, and the huge citrine crystal imbedded in her palm.  They, of course, were eager to know who Delnita was and why she was inhabiting their new purchase. But, searching her memory yielded nothing, and discussion of her most recent memories as a gnome revealed that more then a year had passed since her last recollection.This was the beginning of what turned into a long relationship between the three.  She began doing odd jobs for the couple in exchange for using their warehouse space, and quickly became a full time employee for a minimal salary.  Myrten and Gortence expressed no desire to claim ownership of Delnita after discovering her sentience, and offered her higher rates, but she felt indebted to them after learning what they had spent to purchase her.  Her current body didn't need to eat, anyway, which made budgeting fairly easy.For the following year, Delnita tirelessly delved for clues, quite literally as her new body required a scant four hours of rest each day.  She methodically scoured Redair, from it's booming tech scene to its criminal elements, reactions to her form ranging from curiousity to disgust to avarice.  This only brought dead end after dead end.  Even the information on her receipt of purchase proved false, her seller vanished, with even her employers able to locate them again.  Her one certainty was that she was an anomaly: no arcane or technological expert she questioned had ever seen anything like her.Throughout this, Delnita considered seeking her family, but always resolved to address her current predicament first. She knew her career wasn't waiting for her: arcane monstrosities were not looked upon kindly in Redair's tech focused community.  And besides, her finances would assure her family's comfort in the meantime.  And, more concerningly, she found herself unsettlingly disconnected from her prior life, as if she was an observer rather than a participant.  Unsure how confronting them now would impact her or them, she concluded that nothing good would come from a reunion before regaining herself.Now, she feels her best chance of doing so is to learn more about this construct she inhabits.  Unravelling its secrets could provide clues about happened to her organic body, could help her restore her memories, and perhaps even return her organic form.  Tired of being stonewalled in Redair by the disdain for sullying technology with the arcane, she now reluctantly finds herself bound for Naurecht to continue her research.  While she had previously shared that disdain for unpredictable magic, she cannot deny her body is a conduit for it, and she doubts she'll get answers without embracing it.

When his master's castle fell in the war, his high lord used his own children as human shields. Thus Tower rebelled against his orders. Lost he wandered the world seeking unity, peace and meaning, until he was drawn back to protect his lord's lost children.

Tharsus was born to a family of sailors, and became captain of the family ship. One night a storm struck, and the ship was capsized. As Tharsus sunk to the depths, he prayed for his family to be safe. Unfortunately for him, the Goddess Umberlee answered. The evil queen of the sea offered him a quest in exchange for the lives of his family, which he accepted. "Bring me the trident known as Wave, or they will never leave my watery gardens."

She lived in a high class city with her father, who worked as a courtier. Her father taught her all about morality and law, and this combined with her inherited magic from her mother, led her to teaching herself Divination magic. When she had just turned 15, her father was suddenly arrested for treason, found guilty and thrown into prison for life. Flow knew her father would never do such a thing, so set about trying to find out why this happened. She's currently travelling the world to find the people responsible and avenge her father.

Zula ReedZula Reed’s childhood was spent, for the most part, at sea. Her Mother was the captain of The White Wail, a notorious pirate ship known for attacking military and noble ships alike.When Zula was born, her father stepped down from his duties as First Mate to tutor Zula in the ways of the sea, and in her own Genasi culture. What little her father couldn’t teach her, she learnt from the rest of the crew. The crew was mostly other Watersoul Genasi, though there were Genasi of other manifestations aboard the ship.They were a tight knit family on the White Wail, and all of them did their best to keep Zula out of trouble, as well as happy. All of them took turns in teaching Zula how to defend herself, and she soon learned she had a knack for fighting. Her preferred weapon was a trident, and it became a symbol of pride for her. One day, while they were sailing around a particularly tricky rock formation, they stumbled across a deactivated warforged. They hauled him aboard the ship, and booted him back up, before setting him to work as a deckhand. When the White Wail was attacked by a navy ship, the warforged saved Zula from meeting her end at the barrel of a gun. After the White Wail had thrown off its attackers, Zula and the warforged, Pierce, became fast friends. The two became inseparable, and a friendly rivalry blossomed. When Zula decided it was time for her to set out on her own and earn her ship and crew on her own merit, Pierce followed. She still keeps in contact with her parents when she can.

Grew up hating his animal side, always trying to keep it at bay using his gifts to mock those who he felt took it all to seriously, such as binding a rubber chicken so it stays with him. Eventually he found peace not in the rights and passages of his people but the church, an odd place for a werewolf but one where his faith became so strong it could burn, and his path took him to place he never dared dreamed, even into weaver herself.

SKYEWOLFE’S JOURNAL ENTRIES-	The village council has called me into town.  I’ve been in the southern border guarding against orcs for the past few summers.  I’m not sure what they want, but it does require me to go into the village which I prefer not to do.-	They are sending me on a mission.  I am going to be working with the Montinubris Military to protect our interests.  To this end I received a bag of holding and a few other items that may or may not be useful.  I also have a list of magical items to watch for and hopefully return with so the mages can study them further or try to duplicate them.  Forrest Storm said ”It’s time to stop hiding and find your own path.  There is a huge world out there waiting for you.   It’s time to find your answers there.”-	I arrived in town today.  I met my contact and was told that I would be a consultant with the military group.  There is something going on on one of the outlaying plantations that they require assistance with.  Apparently they have loosed a nightmare creature of some sort that is wreaking havoc with the commoners.-	We came to the plantation yesterday.  There is some sort of trial going on.  Some fighter beat the crap out of several guards and got caught.  Where and why was not mentioned. I’m going to try to find a place to work out before I go stir crazy.  This whole area is barren.  Oh, how I miss my forrest with huge trees and lively animals to talk to. I’m staying in the plantation house as there are not exactly alot of females and they have no place else to put me.   As if females are not twice the fighters males are!-	I had a fairly good work out in the workout area.  The commoners must really be leary of fighters as the practice area is far outside of the main plantation area.  I was approached by Grok, one of the other fighters and he requested to spar with me.   We are fairly evenly matched so it was a good workout.  He did try to disarm me and got punched for his efforts though.-	Today we rode out to a cave system that was recently opened and is believed to be the origin of the creature/s.  There is writing on the cave that I can’t quite make out other than sealed, Master of Shadows, and MARKELL.  I get the feeling that this place was sealed for a good reason and it was NOT supposed to be reopened.  2 rangers have disappeared w/i it’s depths already.  The very air reeks of evil near the entrance.  May the Goddess of the Woodlands protect me in this alien place.-	We entered the cave late this morning.  It was dark and dank.  We followed Jumper, the halfling, as he is the trap expert.  We found the remnants of a bar that was apparently cursed.  It was almost stopped in time.  The remains of 3 cages were also found, torn apart from the inside out.  There was more writing on the walls that appeared the same as the wall outside.  I couldn’t make out anything else though.  The fighter Grok asked what I was reading and when I told him he dropped like a stone.  We took him back outside to help revive him.  After he woke up he told me of his strange dreams he’s been having.  They appear to be closely related to whatever is happening here.  The bodies of the missing rangers were found torn limb from limb in the back of the bar.  There was no blood anywhere.  I don’t know what type of creature did this, but it is undeniably evil.-	By the time we roused Grok it was starting to get dark so we decided to continue our cave explorations in the morning.   Then the alarm went up from the main plantation in the distance.  The entire party rushed back and we found another victim behind the house.  It was obvious that whatever was in the cave had escaped.  I tracked it to the edge of shadows and the tracks just disappeared.  Then I heard the comment that ”It can’t just disappear, it must be in the ground”.   Next thing I knew the creature exploded up out of the earth.   It vaguely resembled a troll w/ metal of some  sort running thru it’s body.   I got the first shot in and hurt it.   Grok threw his weapon at it and missed the thing completely.  His weapon struck the party leader in the shoulder instead.  I hit the thing right in the privates and it went back into the earth.  The cleric said a spell and sank  his sword into the earth where it disappeared.  It came boiling out of the earth again and it looked like it had started to heal itself.  I got it again, immobilizing one hand and the halfling immobilized the other.  Someone else hit it and it howled and turned to ashes.  I hope this is the last I’ve seen of these creatures. -	Father Collins said that this is probably one of three creatures beleived to have escaped from the cave.   So we have at least 2 more to go.-	When we went back to the house Bobbi went in the wrong door and got tripped over by a huge cook who was carrying a large, boiling hot pot of soup.  He was immediatly drenched with turnip soup.  He yelled and took off down the hall at a rapid rate.  Tolir was royally pissed and called the guards.  Bobbi bounced off the wall and went back the way he came.  He was snatched and held aloft by the guard.  Tolir’s daughter intervened for him and Tolir agreed not to harm Bobbi.  Bobbi was taken to the bunkhouse and the guards were told not to let him out again.  -	I decided to try and find a library but was told the lord was particular about who went in there.  Instead I decided to wander in the hopes that I could locate another creature.  I located Grath and he agreed to accompany me.  We found Bobbi sneaking around outside and Grath started to haul him in but Bobbi offered him a Fairy drink and Grath forgot all about a possible bounty and joined him for a drink instead.  Then they turned around and followed me.  Bobbi  got a bright idea and decided to try and summon the creature.  The first time he was successful I got the creature in the hand, after which it sank back into the earth.  The second time it didn’t materialize enough for me to hurt it, but it began to hunt Bobbi. he ran for the bunkhouse and exploded out the back as it gave chase.
