Bobbi did some sort of spell and grass started sprouting from the monster’s mound.  I noticed that the creature left a trail of coal black ashes, before it was changed to grass that is.  I may be able to track this thing after all.  Bobbi  decided to drop the cup he used for summoning and it was swallowed by the grass mound chasing him.  The mound then spread thru-out the field, I searched the area but I didn’t see anyplace where it led out of the field.  Father Collins couldn’t raise it again and Bobbi passed out from spellcasting.  I told the guards to post a perimeter guard and I climbed a nearby tree and got some sleep.-	After breakfast Bobbi tried to raise it again, unsuccessfully.  I asked Father Collins to try to raise it and he was unsuccessful as well.  An hour or so later Bobbi  got one to drop from the sky, it was definately dead but I’m not sure if it was the same creature as before or not.  -	Tolir gave me permission to go thru his library as long as I’m accompanied by a guard at all times.  He seemed rather surprised that I could read.  I don’t think he realizes that I’m a couple of centuries older than he is.  There wasn’t a whole lot of useful information there, but I did find a rather interesting book on land deeds and such for the local area though.  It seems that Tolir has managed to acquire most of the property around.  That reminded me of the note I got from Bobbi last night and I pulled it out.  According to that letter, Tolir is making treaties with his neighbors independent of the King, and not necessarily good for his health either.  I will definately be keeping my eyes open for further evidence though.  What I have now is just enough to get me hung.  I’m glad I’m writing this in slyvan!!-	When I left the library I was just in time to join Jumper and Tolir on a return trip to the caves.  I noticed the stones around one of the cages is marked with the light symbol in draconic, apparently it was part of what was keeping one of the creatures caged.  The cages were of interesting construction though.  One was made of glass, one of metal and the last was made of stone.  The stone one is the one that is ringed by the stones.  I would deduce that they were specially made to contain the creatures that the mage was trying to create.  There is no way tell exactly how old they are but I would say very.  The metal is rusted and the stones of light were made by a high-level mage so could have been active for centuries at least.  The spell appears to be spent though, I wonder, do they only shine at night?  Could the sun’s presence be enough to contain that creature during the day, even underground?  What was finally strong enough to break the cages after so long a time?  Magic could have done it, after all there are spells to turn metal to rust and uncreate anything.  What mage around here is strong enough to overcome the original wards and why would they without firm control over the creatures released?  Were the creatures that escaped the originals or the offspring of the originals?  How does this tie into Tolir’s activities? Is he a mage or more likely, does he have one on his payroll?  I will have to make a point to come down here at night, as repellent as that thought is.  I can’t seem to make out anymore of the writing though.  It’s maddening, it looks like I should know it, but I can’t read it for anything!!  Grok started getting nervous and said he was ready to leave, cosidering what happened last time he came here I’m surprised he came back.  I really should find out if he’s dreamed anything else useful.  I decided to call it a early day and get some practice on the way back.  I’m going to try hunting these things at night tonight.  I’ll ask the rest of the guys who appear to be somewhat useful to come along as well.  Tolir’s not going to be one of them though.  His condescending attitude is starting to wear thin.  Especially considering I’m old enough to have bounced his GRANDFATHER on my knee!!!
Outlander
Became a hermit in order to master a musical instrument
Became a hermit in order to master a musical instrument
Ranger/scout who has been a mercenary for some years now.
Stoner wood elf who lived in a turnip shed and was press-ganged into service by the local constabulary.
Reyna started serving the Bitch Queen Umberlee after nearly dying in a multiple shipwrecks including the one that killed her parents, she's in love with Umberlee and Reyna is in love with her

Elven ranger, retired. Now runs a fletcher’s shop with his wife. Neutral good and motivated primarily by keeping his family safe. Used to be part of an elite unit of rangers known for independence and long missions. Wants to put that life behind him.

Runs business side of shop, currently away on a mission to secure the Toernë city watch contract. Arriving back to the fort just after the party's return. She was denied the contract due to unknown reasons (it was a Sending from Reynolds, who knows people in the city.)  Mama bear type. (Not actually a bear.)

I was a professional hide and go seek tag player, and I was very good, but then, a new wave of younger hide and go seek tag players came along and pushed me out. So I went into adventureing instead. I won't kill people thought because hide and go seek tag is like WWE where it's all fake, so nobody actually dies.

Part of an ancient organization of warrior who stop the Wilderhills from expanding into the rest of the continent. They are named the Faceless after the blank, cursed masks they wear that they can never take off once they done it. Carroway was born into the society and has never known anything else and has spent a hundred years training and fighting so that one day he may lose his face.

Aeshlynn Tyr at first glance looks like anything but the rogue she is. She dresses in simple leathers and lets her golden hair down in braids to either side of her face. She looks more at home among st the crowd in a tavern telling their tales or the group headed out the gate to explore the wilderness. In reality the Bombastic, energetic and overly enthusiastic half-elf is a cut purse, a rogue and above all else a rather happy little thief. Quick with a dagger when she needs it, or equally at home back to back in the wilds with rapier in hand and companions around. Aeshlynn is quite unrepentant in her pursuits of coins, drinks, fortune, glory and debauchery. After all, it's the simple things in life, Right?

Having left his village at the age of 25, Chimara Nailo learned much of what he knows by himself. Before he left, however, he took the time to learn all that he could about the natural world - what plants could be eaten, how to track animals, where to find necessities - as he had been fascinated with nature even more than the average wood elf ever since he first saw its raw beauty. Once he felt he had traveled far enough, he made that place his home. He maintained a roof above his head and fashioned a mat for meditation. He used his knowledge of various types of woods to craft a bow to protect himself from predators. Slow to use it, however, he has his fair share of scars, most notably on his chest where he has four parallel scars from where a bear attacked him. After fending off the beast, he ran for shelter lest he encounter more hostile creatures. As he was fleeing, he stumbled upon a pool which was home to a nymph who called herself Maia and, sensing that he cared about nature as much as she did, took him in and cared for him while he healed. He learned much from her about nature along with her language, Sylvan. When he fully recovered, he decided that it was time to leave. As he was alone and received little education, he knew very little about the world outside of nature and had nothing to his name aside from what he made himself. Chimara was happy for nearly 100 years, but slowly he began to yearn for something different. He wanted to do something other than survive. He decided that he wanted to appreciate nature the way it was intended to be enjoyed - with an adventure. He left his home at the age of 125 and headed for civilization. It was there that he first heard about the druids and the power they wield. He sought out a teacher and began to learn the ways of the druids.

Outlander,     Kvothe was born in a small nomadic tribe of druids that wandered the forests around Gilidaran. Sometimes trading with the city when nature could not provide. All children of the tribe are taught the ways of nature and magic. Kvothe's first couple of decades were full of learning the ways of the druids. It can be lonely for a children in the tribe as elves don't have children as often as their human counter parts. From a young age Kvothe showed a very keen interest in nature and animals, however he did not seem to pay much heed to the other members of the tribe. As soon as he was able to walk he would wander off into the woods for hours and when asked where he had been he would always say “with his friends”.     Kvothe showed an incredible aptitude towards the wild shape and communing with nature, however he showed very little interest in elemental magic or some of the higher rituals of the tribe. When he reached the age of maturity he was to be put through the tribes coming of age test to prove that he would be a valued member of the tribe. The test consisted of the tribe member being sent out into the woods for a month to survive and better learn the ways of the wild it was not unheard of for children to never come back alive. That was no such issue for Kvothe after the first week he found that he preferred the woods to tribe life and at the end of the month when it was time for him to return he decided he did not want to go back.     After he had made his decision, he left the tribes normal paths and went deeper and farther away from the city than his tribe ever ventured. He survived off the land and defended it from hunters and more, only killing animals or harming plants if necessary for survival. Whenever he killed an animal he would make use of everything or else hang on to it until he could find someone who could. Only seeking others when he had stuff to trade. He mastered his woodcraft over decades and became one with the animals and nature.  He talks to himself and his only companion, Ash, all the time and doesn't have the best of manners    About ten years ago he found a very strange bird that looked like a hawk but was the wrong color instead of the brown and tan colors that he had seen in his travels, it was black with bits of gray along its wings and underside. It had been abandoned by its parents and was near death. He nursed it back to health and the bird ,which he named ash, has been with him ever since.     Recently the animals and plants in his domain have been acting strangely and seem to be heading away from the big city near his birth tribe. He decided that it may be time to return to society and find out what was going on...

Aria had always been a bit of a loner, but that didn’t make it easier. Perhaps that’s why she felt sorry for the baby owl that laid at her feet. It had tried to fly too soon, or fallen from its nest, and had hurt its wing in the process. Too much too soon. How very familiar. Aria was a wood elf from a small tribe, not that she remembered much about her upbringing. Aria had gotten separated from her family when she was small. It had only been fifty years ago, at the beginning of the Laconian Expansion wars. She had been a child by elven standards, and still was to some degree. She was nearing the turn of her first century, a landmark occasion that would normally be celebrated by the whole tribe. She scooped up the baby owl. Maybe they could make a new tribe. 	The Expansion wars had not been particularly brutal on the Wood Elves, they had quickly brought an end to the war once they became involved. Yet the initial Laconian assault had taken the elves off-guard. The villages closest to the border were hit hard. Aria was in one of those villages. She remembered the fires, licking high above the tree tops. A scout returned, saying that the humans had come and it was time to retreat deeper into the forest. Aria now knew the wisdom of this, they would retreat and regroup with a larger force in order to take the attack back to the humans. In the moment, she hadn’t even stopped to think. Aria grabbed her bow and rushed through the flames. She was young, but had always been talented surely she could handle what the others were too afraid to fight. There were multiple bands of human skirmishers, about a hundred soldiers in all. They were probably scouting out any Wood elf defenses, not that her people ever maintained defenses in peacetime. Aria loosed arrow after arrow into the soldiers, her face twisted in pain. She was filled with so much rage, that they would come into her home and cause such wanton destruction. She reached back for another arrow but her quiver was empty. Only then did she see the already cold faces of those she’d slain, and the horde of men rushing at her. She retched. Then she ran. She ran fast, faster than her pursuers, faster than the flames. Like a leaf on a winter wind, flying furiously to no where in particular but always away. When night finally fell she stopped, tears streaming from her eyes as she panted.	That was a hard night, but she woke with clear eyes. She made arrows, got some food and set about making her camp livable. She spent a few months simply surviving in her little patch of woods, away from the war. She built a simple hut and lived a simple life. One day while Aria was smoking a rabbit, three Wood Elves appeared at the edge of her copse. They had smelled her cooking and came to investigate. Aria had never seen Wood Elves in armor, but these were wearing a livery that made them look like the most elegant soldiers she could have imagined. She of course invited them to share the rabbit, which they happily accepted. The soldiers told her that they were captains moving to the front lines, having been sent by the King in the Wood to oversee a few important battles. Aria perked up at this. She had put the war out of her mind after that first night, but she still felt like she should help her people. And who better to escort her to the front lines than these dashing elf captains? Aria gave them a quick rundown of her story, at which several eyebrows were raised, and asked to journey with them to where the fighting was. The captains had evidently heard of some fey elf maid whom was the first elf to slay a human in the conflict and were quite delighted to make her acquaintance. With enthusiasm they agreed to accompany her south. 	In the following two years Aria distinguished herself among the elves and struck fear into the hearts of many Laconians. Her arrows flew like winged death and she was fair with a blade as well. During the years of the war, and in the years since, Aria had inquired everywhere about her tribe. No one had heard of the Coopers and didn’t know where they could be found. Everyone knew the border tribes had faired poorly in the first assault on the Great Wood. At the close of the war Aria went back to where it all started. She waited for weeks in the spot she had grown up. The old forest was gone. Meadow grass now pushed through the ashes. No one ever came back.	Aria went back to her little hut in the woods, which was now quite dilapidated. There, near the buckling entrance, she had found the little owl. It didn’t take long for her to fix his wing and it didn’t take long for him to cozy up to her. She would call him Artemis and they would live in this patch of forest. Maybe she could build a treehouse so he would feel at home. Here they could have a simple life. She could harvest and hunt…maybe even take the odd mercenary job. They could have a simple life, punctuated with adventure. They could make a new family.

Character's class (rogue, wizard, cleric: Wizard, rogue, urpriest, cancer mage, vermin lord
Character's backstory: He was a traveling cleric that lost faith in his god, he began a quest to discover his faith. During this time he found many different religions, but during his quest he was captured by a cult and forcfully turned into a monster called a "worm that walks". After escaping he learned how to take power from gods and he used that power to get revenge. Still keeping his humanity he uses his new form and power to make sure things that happen to him never happen to others. He now goes around and fights the powers of evil and chaos.
She's an ex soldier turned caring and loving mother of the group. She loves to tree the the group like they're her own children, providing healing, covering them when they take to much damage, etc.

Vaskir is an exiled yuan ti who forsook his religion to worship the great old one dendar. he is a master swordsman who wields a greatsword in tandem with a longsword, effectively dualwielding the huge blade. He is chaotic evil, believing that government and law holds back all of humanity from their goals, keeping them oppressed and subjugated under the foot of the highest ruler

A lean, musclebound dwarf leans on the deck railing of the good ship Erasmus, gazing out over the waves. His keen grey eyes scan the horizon as he strokes his long brown beard. Several glowing blue fibers, enchanted to pulse in-tune with his mood, are woven through the braided facial hair. The light glints off the polished green stone, carved in the shape of an eel eating its own tail, that hangs from a leather cord around the dwarf’s neck. The dwarf stinks of seaweed, and his smile is always a moment away from turning to an dark, unnerving leer. This is Gabbro Eelstooth, a dwarf hunted by his own people--with good reason.On board the Erasmus, Gabbro is always looking for something. Every spout of a distant leviathan or strangely-shaped piece of driftwood gives him momentary hope that he’s found some trace—any trace—of the wreck of the Serpentine. He knows that from the surface, such clues would be impossibly unlikely, but that hasn’t stopped him from looking.Until recently, Gabbro was a sailor on the Bloodstone, a submarine pirate ship crewed almost entirely by his clanmates. All ships were fair game for this gang of pirates: gnoll ships they sank could be cashed in for bounties, while elven vessels were usually loaded with precious metals and bizarre magical artifacts to sell. But after decades of piracy, the captain on the Bloodstone became obsessed with a legend: the rumored sunken treasure of the Serpentine.The Serpentine, the legends said, was a merchant vessel travelling between the Dwarven seamounts and the cities of the elves. On its last voyage, it was laden with gifts for the elves—as well as a great Dwarven mechanic and his most prized inventions: compasses which resisted confounding magical effects, goggles which let the wearer see through the thickest fog, astronomical clocks which tracked the movements of the heavens and the other planes, automatons which could see and think for themselves, and more—and all without any magic at all. But the ship was sunk, though the legends vary as to why. Whoever claimed those ruins would be absolved of all crimes by any Dwarven government, and lauded as heros.After three years of searching based only on hearsay, the crew grew weary. Their supplies were running low and the Bloodstone badly needed some time in dry dock. After a dive in which the captain refused to surface for air for so long that a cabin-boy died of suffocation, the crew mutinied. The gun-battle on board pierced the hull of the Bloodstone in several places. The ship was several hundred feet deep at the time, and as water poured in and the hull groaned under the strain, the mutineers claimed all the lifeboats, leaving the captain to be drowned and crushed at the bottom of the sea.The lifeboats clung together at first, bobbing on the surface like a raft of sea otters. But the crew grew quarrelsome, each claiming that if he had been in charge, they’d have found the treasure months ago. The arguments grew and grew until the raft broke apart and scattered, the dwarves still screaming at each other that by the Gods, they’d find the treasure first!Gabbro’s boat washed ashore at a small island port, where he spent a week wandering from inn to inn, drinking away what little money he had on him and thinking hard about what to do. None of the crew were the bookish types, Gabbro reasoned—if he could find a map, or even a scholar who knew the location of a map, he could go on a lot less than tall tales told in taverns. So he booked passage for the great city of Thasym, hoping to find some clue to work from.Gabbro emits an air of ill repute; he’s a self-serving bully even at the best of times. But without a crew to back him up, he’d never openly admit he was a pirate unless he felt it benefited him—nor would he reveal his mission, for fear that somebody else would get to any map before he did. If asked about his past (including by Captain Mantor) he weaves a sob story about how his fishing ship was attacked and sunk by goblins, and he’s going to Thasym to petition his rich uncle for a loan to buy a new one. Gabbro is driven to find this treasure—but not so driven that he won’t jump at an opportunity for more short-term profit first. If two years of searching didn’t find the Serpentine, he reasons, another month or two of delay won’t let his former crewmates get too big of an advantage. And the more money he has when he starts the search in earnest, the better a ship he can charter or purchase. Still, he is wary of delaying too long: rumor has reached him that others from his clan--not just the pirates--have put a bounty on his head. He's not entirely sure why... but whatever the reason is, it's probably justified.The Eelstooth clan, from which many pirates and thieves are derived, uses the bioluminescent beard-decorations as its signature adornment. As such, they’re often known derogatorily as “glowbeards.” Unless it’s an obvious mistake, and possibly even then, Gabbro will attempt to outright murder anyone who calls him that.

She was made orphan by a war at an early age, and without many choices, enlisted herself. She mosty did cooking and cleaning for the army growing up, but when she came of age she received combat training and was promoted to foot soldier in a new squad. During an engagement all her fellow soldiers were killed, and she was left for dead on the battlefield. She was found by a wandering cleric of the Church of the Lady Serene, an order renowned for their martial efficiency, due to their level-headed attitude during combat. The cleric healed her, and taught her of the Serene Way, a doctrine of self-control and self-sacrifice. She quit the army and pledged her life to the  Serene Church, becoming a wandering paladin devoted to spreading order and peace throughout the world.

Hashannas' story begins with her parents. Her mother is a Silver Dragon and Paladin of Bahamut, from a bloodline of Dragon Paladins. As a young adult, she masqueraded as a dragonborn and traveled with a band of adventurers. Her parents fell in love and soon her mother revealed her true heritage to the human ranger that captured her heart. Her parents were a happy couple, her mother soon retreated to her lair and had a small clutch of eggs. An unusual pairing was sure to produce unique offspring, but would regardless be greatly loved by both mother and father.Three eggs were laid and hatched. The children emerged as toddlers from their eggs, each with signs of both signs of their heritage. The largest was male, with silver scaled skin and small horns and draconic eyes, otherwise was human in appearance. The other male was the smallest of the clutch, but the most bestial of the hatchlings, nearly quadrupedal, with wings, tail and draconic head and horns, he was most like his dragon mother in appearance. The lone female was a near blend of the two. A slightly draconic face, with horns and frill and ropy deadlock like hair; human body covered with a thick silver scaly hide, gently fading to human skin near her center-line.  Her hands ended with sharp claws, but were dexterous like her human parentage. Her legs were also a blend of human and dragon, knees bending backwards and ending in dragons claws. She too had wings and a tail, smaller than her siblings, but enough to give rudimentary flight.Each sibling had their own path in life, but Hashanna followed in her Mothers' footsteps as a Paladin of Bahamut, dedicating herself to the worship of the Good dragon and defeat of Tiamat.Fiercely defending her faith and dragon-kind, Hashanna traveled through the world with many Adventurers, defeating evil and evil dragons and spreading the glory of Bahamut!

He was cursed by a mad god when he was a boy, it gave him strange powers. He watched bandits kill his parents when he was a young teen. Necromancer powers run in his family so he raised his father from the dead to defeat the bandits. He had to watch his father die again. He is looking to remove his curse before he is consumed by the evil.

Cassandra was born, under another name, to a family of moderate spirits and low ambitions. For eight generations, they owned the same farm. And from generation to generation, the ownership passed the same way—father to eldest son. Cassandra was born the eldest son of the family, and for years, was told she would inherit the farm when she grew older and took a wife. Despite ambitions loftier than anyone in the previous eight generations, she put her back into the work, and dedicated herself to making her father proud. Undeniably, he was. She had a knack for her work in the field, and seemed, by all accounts, well-suited to it. However, she never felt any particular passion in the work, nor fondness for her father. By the age of eight, she had learned, rather, that she found more joy in shared activities with her mother. She would help with the housework whenever she could, as exhausted from the fields as she was. Her mother found this trait endearing. Her father, not so much. She, herself, couldn’t fathom what compelled her to the tasks until, at the age of eleven, she was separated from her father during a trip into the market, and found herself in an unfamiliar part of town, where she was greeted by a woman she didn’t recognize. In a masculine voice, the woman asked Cassandra, “Are you lost?”. She could only nervously stutter out a yes, and after a bit of calming down, the woman introduced herself as Elise. Cassandra, with childish curiousity, asked if she was a man or a woman, and Elise gave only a chuckle, and a short explanation, that she had been born a man, but came to see herself otherwise as she grew. When Elise eventually found Cassandra’s father and returned her, he didn’t give a thanks, but only a curt harrumph as he lead Cassandra away. But the memory of Elise stuck in her head long after, and by the end of the month, she couldn’t keep her thoughts to herself any longer. When she told her mom, she simply froze up and said to talk to dad. The very next day, while working in the field, she jammed her hoe in the ground, leaned on it to catch a breath, and spoke, spilling everything to him. What she had learned from Elise, the pain she’d been feeling, how she believed she was like the woman she met. Her dad only scoffed, and spoke down to her, ending the conversation with only, “You’ve got a pair of balls, boy. You’re a man, plain and simple. Don’t try and get out of a man’s work.” From then on, she was no longer allowed to do housework, and would be doubling down on work in the field, to ensure that she doesn’t “forget herself”. Any time she raised a fuss, her father reminded her of that same lesson as the first day. This treatment continued until she was 13, at which point she could stand it no longer.	Furious and dysphoric, she sneaked out her window late one night, and to the stable, where she found the surgical tools for the horses. Under the cover of darkness, she stuffed a rolled-up tunic between her teeth, and got to work, barely controlling her screams as she worked. It took nearly an hour, and by the end, she was bleary with blood loss, but at long last, it was done. Her testes, which had caused her so much sorrow for so long, were finally gone, and at last, she could be who she knew she was all along. At last, her father could accept her. However, when he found the bloodied tools, his reaction was nothing like what she had hoped. She explained herself—that she didn’t have balls anymore, that she could be a woman now. But instead of acceptance, he was furious at her. She could no longer inherit the farm. No longer have sons to help in the fields. Before the crack of dawn, he drove her out, away from the farm, and into the nearby woods. Mutilated, still recovering from her impromptu surgery, and broken with sorrow, it was in these woods that, when exposure and the animals would not take her life, she considered doing it herself. But rather, she survived. She found the road. Followed it to the large market town she remembered from her childhood. In the evening, she reached the gates, and by nightfall, she had got herself a humble meal with her small sum of silver she had stolen before she was driven away, and found a gutter to rest in. At first, she wept. Her life was over. There was nothing left for her. The destiny laid out for her had been quashed. The person she wished to be would never come to fruition. It was all too much for her. She wept, and wept, and wept, until she could take weeping no more, and instead chose to sing her lamenting. She sang the songs she remembered from the field, first quietly, then louder, and louder, and louder still, through her tears, until she had become so utterly enraptured by her own voice that she barely even noticed when a wealthy traveller tossed a gold coin at her feet. A gold coin, she thought, her eyes fixating on the sparkle of the metal. This was a greater sum than she had ever possessed for herself. With this alone, she could get herself a room for the night, somewhere warm, a hot meal in the morning. A few more, and maybe she could even get herself clothes to look like one of those wealthy merchants herself. Perhaps, she would get herself a nice dress to wear. That would do nicely, she thought, as she sang all through the evening, until there were no more common folk walking the streets, and with the moderate sum of copper, silver, and gold she had earned, slept comfortably for the night.	Days passed, and she became ever more fascinated with the way her voice had changed since her self-inflicted surgery. It was sweeter. Gentler. Less resonant, but more touching. She practiced with it day in and day out, sharpening it like a blade, performing until her throat was as dry as a desert, and then spending the money on drinks to quench her thirst so she could continue. As her income grew, she was able to spend it on more extravagant clothing, more dazzling makeup, until she was no longer known as “the boy in a dress”, and rather, as “The Golden Voice on Smith Street”. Day in, day out, she sang. As the shops closed for the evening, she would begin to draw a crowd, and it wasn’t long before the inn she was staying at began offering her gigs as an entertainer in exchange for a free room and meals. Two years passed, and life grew easier for her. So much so that it had almost grown boring. The city life did not amuse her. It only sustained her. She met many people, some like herself, others not so much. Yet despite being an entertainer, she never felt that she, herself, was entertained. She yearned for excitement. For adventure. Fortunately for her, it was coming to find her. One of very few times she had her gig at the inn cancelled, she learned it was because of a minstrel group coming in, one which, supposedly, the innkeeper was especially fond of. They called themselves the World’s Widows, and were a group of musicians who wrote songs about a subject that most wouldn’t dare breathe a word about: heroic women. Intrigued, Cassandra sat in for the performance, knowing she had more than enough coin saved to survive a night off. The World’s Widows sang well through the evening, about tales of ladies dressing as men to go into battle, of women carrying their children out of disasters, then going back in to save others, standing up for their beliefs even in the face of tribulation or execution. She was intrigued with every single story. All around her though, the patrons seemed enraptured by the music, but utterly indifferent to the content. That is, until they began their last act, a song about a woman general who lead her men into victory. At this, some in the tavern began to boo, and demand that they stop the song and get off the stage. Still, they sang, even as it looked as though the crowd would rush the stage. In a moment of pure spontaneity, Cassandra stood up, and in her most powerful voice, joined in the chorus with the World’s Widows. As her voice echoed in the hall, those in audience were soothed, in awe, and sat back down, allowing the performance to continue, only to eventually cheer. After the show, the World’s Widows caught up with her, and she was invited to join them. After many fond farewells, and reminders from the barkeep that she could return if she so desired, she finally accepted their offer. The very next morning, they departed, and she began her life as a travelling minstrel. Among the World’s Widows, there were no rulers, and rather, matters were typically voted upon or debated, but the majority of time was spent travelling, drinking, and writing music. In every town they passed through, they would seek out women of great deeds to write their songs about. A favourite, for them, was of tales of ladies who disguised themselves as knights to go into battle. Cassandra shared this sentiment about such stories, and never tired of hearing them retold. But what she had not expected was that, not only did the minstrels tell the tales of heroic women. They lived them, as well. Through the World’s Widows, she was trained with blades and bows alike, taught to defend herself on the road. Taught to harness her voice into a potent form of magic. And with them, she felt as though she could rule the world.	She quickly found a place for herself among the World’s Widows, relating to their many stories. When asked about her past, she had already formed a perfect story—not a lie, but not the whole truth either: her father, not wanting a daughter, drove her off the farm, and she’d been living on the streets since, surviving by virtue of her voice. The rest of the minstrels took quickly to her, with the exception of one Theresa, a specialist in the lute, who was not so easily swayed. Within the group, they became somewhat of a pair of rivals, with Cassandra’s swelling pride causing competition and contention between them. At 14, Cassandra was the youngest member of the group, and the honour of having been accepted had gone heavily to her head, causing her to frequently egg Theresa on. The rivalry persisted, and though, in many cases, it only served to intensify their shared passion for the work, it only took a year for the arrangement to finally come to a head. In the midst of a high-profile performance, Theresa began her lute solo. Cassandra, however, cut the solo off early to begin singing again. As a result, Theresa began to play more loudly to try and drown her out. This exchange of one-upmanship continued throughout the performance until they broke into a full-on physical fight and the whole group had to be dragged out of the bar. It was that night that the World’s Widows agreed the two of them would have to settle their differences before either could be allowed on stage again. It was also that night when, after the performance, Cassandra was changing in her room, and Theresa came in unexpectedly. Seeing Cassandra naked, Theresa accused her of being a man pretending to be a woman. Before Cassandra could explain, Theresa ran off to the others and told them everything. By a majority vote, Cassandra was cast out of the World’s Widows, and left to fend for herself. In desperation, she returned to the inn where she had first begun performing, only to find her spot taken by another singer, and be unrecognized by the bartender. Having lost the spirit to try and go in and prove herself again, Cassandra moved on, drifting from city to city, singing her sorrows in the streets to get her meals, hoping against hope that she would one day get an opportunity to reclaim her honour. As she wandered, she practiced. She honed her skills with the bow. She wove her voice into more and more potent magicks. And she prepared herself for danger, with the styles taught to her by the World’s Widows. Years of folk heroism prepared her for the moment when she received her summons to Navrim, to fight on behalf of the lords of the realm. And so, she set off, in hopes of becoming a hero worthy of the songs of the World’s Widows, to take her place among legends.
Mount named LEE

Trakul grew up as heir to the throne of an ancient dwarven kingdom. He was expected to study in many fields of knowledge, and while he was competent at fighting, he was far more interested in craftmanship and history. He became obsessed with old songs about his ancestors, the magic they wielded, and the adventures they went on. He started studying music and magic as much as he could, but his royal duties kept him from it. One day, his father asked him to lead an attack force against a group of orcs that had infested one of their deeper gem mines. It was nearly a failure, and the only reason the orcs were removed from the mine was the result of Trakul's father taking over at the last minute. Trakul was stripped of his royal title and cast out in disgrace, so he took the opportunity to study music and magic further. He made his way out of the mountains to a deep forest, where he came across a clan of elves. They initially wanted to reject him, but their royal bard took pity on Trakul and took him in. He trained with the royal bard for years, perfecting his craft by learning the lyre, learning musical spells, and ancient songs and tales of adventure. He also learned how to be a damn good entertainer as well. When Trakul left, his mentor gave him a magic lyre, a book of spells, and a word of advice: "Be friendly to everyone, but trust no one." Trakul made a living as a traveling musician for a few years, but yearned to learn more songs. However, he could not find any, so he decided to write some of his own. For inspiration, he traveled with a group of adventurers and wrote songs about their exploits. He had to do a fair bit of adventuring himself, though, and he quickly acquired a taste for death-defying treasure hunts. So, as well as being a musician, he became an adventure-seeker as well.

Ramakidin started life in a the back alley childhood gang known as the Noon-Shadows. They were a family of sorts with the older ones moving on to better prospects. Ramakidin became the designated fence and aquired a book on magic in trade for the whole days take. He then set to work studying illusions through trial and error so the Noon-Shadows could steal more easily. At the age of 16, the gang was forcibly disbanded by a raid conducted by the city guard. Ramakidin used his magic to escape. He is now trying to pay the fines to free his family by adventuring.

Jakara was orphaned as a child, but was found by the Fyrmbld Dwarf clan and raised as one of their own. She grew up to become a fierce warrior who fights along side her adoptive brother, Krymkp. Her primary weapons are a sword and shield, but she has also dabbled in projectile magics to help her with ranged threats.
Born in a quiet elven hamlet within a lrage forest. A sickness has come upon the forest so athos has left to find a cure

Kevin is a performer who dabbles in pickpocketing after the show.  He was recruited by a notorious gang boss and brought into the organization when his work was spotted.  He served in an info-gathering, espionage sort of role, usually paired with his Orc friend, Glatt, who served as the muscle to Kevin's finesse.  On his last mission, Glatt was killed and Kevin had to run; he suspects the gang boss of setting up an impossible mission to remove the two from the organization.  He is now trying to find the truth.

Fionna Sylvanas Hrek. Daughter of Ogar Sylvanas Hrek. Resident in the Barony of Ohara. Well known for being near the ocean and its gunsmiths. Because of this many gunslingers, hunters, pirates, and gun enthusiasts often visit or take residence in the local area. Not like it matters that much. Ohara has been gone for 10 whole years._	_She could still remember the night the barony burned to the ground. People either crying in pain or running away. Others trying to fend… them off. Blood spilling all over. Gunshots and cannon fire. Screaming… Braying… it felt endless. She could still hear the ring of the church bells above her slowly die off, as if the heart of the city has failed. 	It was supposed to be just a “simple wedding”… that’s what she called it. Few months before, she met a famous gunslinger, John D. Smith. At first they would just see each other every now and then. She only started getting to know him when she said that she wanted to learn about guns. How to make them, how to use them. John taught her everything she knows. Eventually lessons turned into just meetings, where they talked for hours about anything. Who they were, who they want to be. What the future had in store for them. John said if there ever was a chance to give up the gun he wanted to dance and sing. Fiona could’ve gone on forever thinking about him.The way he would smile his crooked but perfect smile. How his ears twitched when she called his name. How his hands were funnily unbelievably small despite being able to handle a gun. How he knew how to do practically everything. How he later revealed that he actually never watched a theatre play in his life. Fionna promised that she would take him to see one someday… His code of honour.“Every gunslingers got to have a code, see?” “Why’s that?”“Fuck if I know, but it sounds cool to have one right?”She laughed. “Sure it is. So what’s yours?”“I’ll tell ya, but first there’s something I gotta do.”Fionna just wanted a simple wedding. But John and her father Ogar had a different idea. A Supreme Wedding with Amazingness and Maximum Pantomime. SWAMP for short.“That sounds stupid.” Fiona said. John thought differently.“Hey, at least we can say things like ‘This is our SWAMP now!’”“The hell is that supposed to mean?” John ignored her.“Or if someone barges in, breaks through the window on a dragon-tries to stop it- I can say ‘Git out of mah SWAMP’”“What are you guys even talking about…” But in the end she laughed and accepted it. Any type of ceremony was fine for her.The entire barony gathered at the church for their wedding. In retrospect Fionna guesses that’s the reason the barony got completely destroyed. No one guarding the entrances, or the ports…Everything was quiet. She was just staring into his eyes. Deeply listening to him say his vows, like someone in a theatre watching a play. Then suddenly it happened.The Braying… slowly increasing in volume. Loud enough to shake the church.Then suddenly the church doors were kicked down. In the distance Fionna could see hooves and hind legs where they used to be.And then a huge explosion. She blacked out.When she woke up everything went to hell. The church bells ringing. Blood covered the walls and floor. everyone in the church either died or just gone. Amongst it all were… them. Either clopping over people, alive or dead. Or eating the flesh off the people. She looked around. The bodies of her family laid lifeless. Seemed like the explosion killed them. She looked down and everything went silent. John was dead. His mouth smashed in, unable to smile anymore. In his cold, small hands laid his special gun, Griggs. Then something close by brayed loudly.The ministers body was chewed open. They were feasting on him like he was some field of grass. She went down to pick up the last piece of John she had left, ring glimmering in front of her.“Okay you did what you had to do, so what’s your code?”He kissed her. “Alright, there’s three tenets to my code.”“One: Always show courage in the face of danger.”She raised the gun, it was heavy but she knew how to use it.“Two: Never leave a comrade behind.”She looked back at John. Tears streaming down her face. She then wiped her eyes and aimed Griggs.“And three: Never let a donkey live.”

Dungeona was abandoned in an old wishing well as a child. She collected low-value coins for several years and eventually bartered her way out. While exploring the world above the well, she met a troupe of musicians and became a bard with incredible insight into wishes, hopes, and dreams. She is evil now.

~La therr... Reh Ince... Und Oh bey~   “That’s a weird song yer singin’ miss.”“It is nothing but an old childhood song from my home.”   “Sounds kinda sad fer a children’s tune dontcha think?”“The only thing making this song sad is your perception.”   “Whatchu on about? Yer the one dats singin’ it ain’t ye?”   I pause. Thinking about my home, my family, and my sister.“Then again maybe the one making it sad is me.” I admit.   I smile, remembering a silly phrase my sister use to say to me so long ago.    —————————— It’s been about two years since I decided to leave Sapona. My sister, Loryal, and I were part ofthe royal family. From an outsiders perspective we look like the perfect family, however behind the castle walls was nothing but anger and sadness. When we weren’t outside our parents bombarded us with lessons, grooming us to be the perfect brides. When they weren’t teaching us my parents would constantly argue over which one of us would marry which noble in some other kingdom. It was frustrating... For our parents to only see us as objects for trade, as currency... It was saddening.“I don’t think they see us like that.” My sister would say, reassuringly. Then she would smile   “Maybe it’s just you.”   “Yeah maybe it’s me.” I would say halfheartedly.  ——————————Despite all that the lessons took its toll on us, and we coped with it in our own ways. My sister decided to dabble in thievery. Whenever she could she would sneak out and try to scale walls,   pickpocket the guards, or train with swords and bows in the barracks. Me, on the other hand, spent most of my free time in the royal library. Reading about heroes from faraway places,their adventures and endeavours, invigorated me. It sparks something in my soul. They were so different from me. Free from some pre-determined destiny laid out before them. Free from the confines of castle walls. These heroes... they were people! They were viewed as people and heroes. Unlike me, only seen as a princess or some trade goods.I also loved to sing. At first I’d sing just classic children's songs an poetry. Singinghelped me forget about the world around me, and allowed me to just focus on myself, an my voice. It was rejuvenating. Eventually my two passions combined and I was singing about the heroes whom I adored.One night my sister arrived home really late. She climbs in through our bedroom window, covered in dirt and scratches. In her hands was an object about arms length covered by a brown cloth.“I got you a mandolin!” she exclaimed.“Since you love singing, and because you don’t need no man.”I laughed, and she smiled that infectious smile. As she unveiled the instrument I was astonished. The woodwork looked amazingly well done. The gold trimming around it depicted a unique and beautiful floral design that seemed to breathe under the full moonlight. On one side of the front it said my name, on the other it said hers. In my hands the mandolin felt perfect, like it belonged in my grasp.“I love it, thank you!” I hugged her tightly.As I tried out the mandolin I looked at my sister and asked her.“Don’t you want to sing with me?”“No, no, singing is just your thing!” She smiled.“Yeah... maybe it’s just mine.” I’d say. —————————————One day my parents told me that they have finally decided on a suitor for me to marry. Someweird noble in a far far away land, whose main exports is donkey. The Hrek family. I couldn’t stand it, I didn’t want this. I wanted to make my own story, just like the heroes from so long ago that I’ve read about. So I left it all behind. Late at night as I was leaving the castle my sister grabbed my hand.“Don’t leave!” she pleaded.“I have to! There’s no way I’m going to marry that Hrek Noble!”“But where would you go!? What would you do!?”“Does it even matter? Maybe I’ll sing, maybe I’ll write, maybe I’ll die. Anything is better than this!”I turned to face her.“There has to be more than my story than this! Don’t you ever think about life beyond these walls!? beyond marriage?!”“I... No I guess I haven’t really thought about it that much.” She admitted, letting go of my hand. She then looked at my, teary eyed, and smiled.“Maybe it’s just you.” She said, her voice almost breaking.“Yeah maybe it’s just me.” I said confidently.——————————————————In the past two years I travelled most of the world. I’ve seen people who used ice as weapons, a half-man half donkey hellbent on finding a gunman, a gunman hellbent on killing donkeys,a grand library controlled by magic, and so much more. Getting by through my knowledge and voice. All this time I’ve been searching for my story, for my purpose. And now I’m here, on a boat with a man named Oboe, sailing towards some weir citynamed Bolobin.“Hey miss, we’ve been sailing fer a couple o’days now” “Indeed.”“You never told meh yer name y’know.”“It’s May.” I said “May Bell”“Weird name...” Oboe said.I looked down on my mandolin. Despite the use it never seem to wear down. The gold trimmings still shimmered underneath the sun. I ran my fingers on it’s front, feeling forthe names. On one side said my sisters name: Loryal. As I reached for the other side, feeling for my old name I whispered the saying my sister would say long ago.“Maybe it’s Maybeline.”

Roderick dreamed of joining the military and had passed all the training to join the empire's elite forces and go on deployment, all at the age of 17, when he found out he was going to be a father.  Instead, he dropped out before the final enlistment and took up a job as night-time security guard at the local mage's library and as volunteer captain for the city militia.  Now 41 with both of his kids grown up and out of the house (his son, 24, joined the military and is on deployment, his daughter, 20, recently married to a nice armorer), and tired of spending lonely nights reading old books to pass the time, he's back on the trail for some adventure.

3rd son of nobleman with his brother groomed to replace his father and his other brother serving as General, Bale is sent away to study magic so that he can advise and support his brother magically. Bale believes that his talents and being poorly and that he would make a better lord then his brother. After completing his training he cuts ties and disappears far to the north to research and plan for his rightful place. Plan is as follows1. Begin research on constructs, liches, and transmutation/alchemy. Begin experiments on creatures/prisoners from adventures to see how trying to transform them into constructs goes. (Evil wizard, obvisously)2. Seize control of a throne of some kind. Keep an eye on politics and wait for an opportunity. Begin research on farming and economics3. Figure out how to transform yourself into a construct and achieve immortality4. Use your knowledge of farming and economics to increase crop yields and reduce the number of workers needed.5. Over time make small gains of territory. Expand then take time to consolidate. Repeat as needed.6. Increased food yields triggers agricultural revolution.7. Free workers cause greater establishment of crafts and merchants. Much more mobile labor8. Abundance of labor and money triggers industrial revolution.9. Use advancement to conquer the world10. Become God Emperor of All Mankind.11. ProfitAdjust as needed.

May 3rd, 19X	Today marks the day I begin my experiment that will probably… hopefully… Hmmm I didn’t really plan this out did I... Well, regardless, I am going to be conducting an experiment involving the use of steam technology and machinery in order to create a mechanical human. I wanted to use this journal to record my progress, hoping to make my experiment sound grandiose and epic. Upon placing my pen to the paper I realized that the idea is idiotic. And yet as I am writing now I’m starting to find this journal to be very useful. I decided I am going to continue writing in this journal!	I once had the idea whilst reading of a grand library from the far south east. The library itself runs on some sort of magic, and is even taken care of by this huge mystical creature- whose voice supposedly can reach every corner of the facility itself. Inside the library, an array of rare and one-of-a-kind books, recipes, and the like. And at the front door stand two stone statues that not only act as guardians, but as the key for getting inside the library! I was amazed! How can solid stone move as if it were human!	Unfortunately those things run on magic, and having stone humans controlled by magic is a feat near impossible in Blanket (placeholder name)… The constant invasions make Miasma unpredictable… unstable. Not to mention I have no magical capabilities whatsoever! As a kid I tried submersing myself in the magical arts but to no avail. Most people say the miasma just doesn’t like me.	One thing I was good at was building, creating, and imagining devices. I’m writing too much… Well anyways some 18 years later and I helped design and build one of the first steam train engines! It was then I had the idea. We don’t need silly unreliable magic, we can just use machinery! Instead of simplistic stone magic I can create mechanical human! Using steam and pistons to help move its body, it can perform just like a human, or like it’s run on magic! I have a schematic for how it and all the necessary materials to build it. This is going to be great! M. Day Shamwam_________________________________“He’s running late…” I say under my breath.Standing outside of the diner under the awning. People scurry along the cobbled sidewalk, covering their heads from the rain. A loud sharp whistle can be heard through the pitter-patter from across the street. As I watch the people leave the station, dispersing into the nearby shops and cafes, my eyes glaze. He always does this. Always arrives a little bit late just so he could show up behind me and say“Am I really?”I turn around and there he was. Holding a folded newspaper over his head he was failing to protect his usually crazy frizzed hair, which was now plastered against his forehead and glasses. His glasses were constantly sliding down due to rain and his small button nose being able to hold it up. Underneath it all was his same crooked smile, as if he was trying to say “I got you didn’t I?”  And under the shadow of the night sky his bright blue eyes shined. He looked beautiful.I poke his nose hard enough to push him back.“You’re late and you know it.”“Yeah yeah, I know. But wait till you hear about my day.”				_______________________________“Really? Mechanical humans?” I say open mouthed.“It sounds impossible.”“Well he’s basing his theory on stone human-like golems he found in some library. But those things are controlled by strong magic, and with the fluctuating miasma it’s practically impossible.”“So it’s just not possible here.” My voice trails off as the waiter brings us our deserts. I looked around the restaurant. Everyone at each table seemed to be talking their heart out. Some were drunkenly singing, others were laughing tears, and one couple in the corner who seemed to be in a screaming contest. ‘This place is nice” I think to myself. The restaurant is able to control the miasma through some machinery that gives each table its own ‘sound bubble’. No one can hear you talk, and you can’t hear anyone outside the bubble. Maybe if someone could use this technology…“Controlling a sound bubble and controlling a machine to be and act like a human are too different things.” He said, reading the expression on my face.“It is technically possible, but it would take a skilful person with practically full control of the miasma.”The only ones with that much control would probably be a priest or any of those religious folk. But often times they don’t use their ‘miracles’ for personal favours or experiments. And leaving isn’t much of an option as well. With almost routine invasions a normal person would die the minute they set foot outside of Blanket. If you knew some of the secret entrances though, getting in and out is only slightly less deadly. That’s the one up side for these invasions, I thought. Clients are willing to pay more to get anything or anyone out or into the city. In fact earlier today one of my clients wanted to-“So, how was your day?” he asked. He always seems to know.I smiled.“You would not believe the weird stuff my client’s into.”				_____________________________________January 17th, 19X+1	Power! This is the hardest thing about the machine. The amount of power it takes to make it completely functional is insane!	After completely model A-1, nicknamed “Alfonso”, I hooked him up to a generator. However his movement was 30% below optimal speed and his range of motion was severely limited to the 10 ft. wire that was giving him life… I ended up having to scrap him.	The next model was B-1 named “Baxter”. I tried using a modified version of some of the machines that absorb and manipulate the miasma to help power him, but unfortunately Baxter couldn’t handle the power and ended up dying. Poor Baxter.	From Cameron to Justin they all failed to meet my requirements or managed to somehow kill themselves. And yet I cannot give up. There must be something that can make them more efficient, more powerful, something more… human.	As I am writing I managed to reach an idea. How did I not see this before? It takes a human to be human. If I am able to somehow implant a human into my creation, then it could move and act just as if it were made of flesh and bones! But better.I am going to have to make huge adjustments to the design.M.Day Shamwam.				________________________________March 23rd, 19X+1“He’s kidnapping people?”“Supposedly, at least that’s what the officers told me.” I say as I drink my coffee outside the café.“I knew something was up when he stopped showing up to work, but to think he’d take this experiment too far…” my voice trails off. I want to say I should’ve known but I really shouldn’t have. I mean who would’ve thought someone like M.Day would kidnap people?“…Yeah.” She said, looking away with her dark emerald eyes. Under the setting sun her dark blonde hair seemed to be on fire. Past her I notice that the usually busy street has died down. There have been reports of missing persons around dusk. Seems to have rattled the district. Off in the distance I can hear the whistle of my train as it leaves the station.I look back and notice that she’s deep in thought again. Along with a furrowed brow her eyes darting back and forth between her cup and her plate as if waiting for one of them to move. She must’ve hear something while working for a client.“What did you hear?” I ask.“The church hired me to look for one of their high priests… After a little digging around I heard something from some of the homeless people. There’s apparently someone going around looking for ‘magically gifted’ people.”“And you think that person might be M. Day.” I affirm.“Yeah…”“Well regardless I think I’m going to go talk to him.” I have to find out what he’s up to. And if it’s something bad, then I have to stop him.“I don’t like the sound of this…” She looks at me, worried. I know recently she’s been planning a way for us to leave Blanket. With the invasions and the missing people I’m sure anyone would want to leave. But I know she doesn’t want to leave without me first.“So you’re coming with me?“Need to make sure nothing happens to you” she says playfully, while poking my nose. She’s trying to hide her worry. Maybe we shouldn’t do this… But I have to go. I think I’m going to always be thinking about this if we left.We’re going.As the moon rises we set off towards M.Day’s house. Off in the distance towards the east,  towers of black smoke loom over Blanket.					______________________March 24th, 19X+1	I FINALLY SUCCEEDED! Through (detailed explanation) I managed to link the mind and soul of a human to the machine. However there were some complications… Last night as I was going to perform my experiment on the high priest Xavier and DJ-1. However two people barged in during the middle of the experiment. Callum, my old work mate, and his girlfriend Edea They came to try and stop me, told me that I was taking this experiment too far. They were wrong. I just didn’t take it far enough.	As the experiment started, invaders came to raid Blanket. This caused a sudden gigantic surge of miasma throughout the city. This caused my transplantation device to go haywire. When I came to Xavier was gone, all that was left was a pile of purple ashes. Callum and Edea’s bodies were on the floor, lifeless. Unlike me they took the full blast from the miasma wave. This must’ve caused them to merge with DJ-1 instead of Xavier. 	When I powered the robot I cried for joy. It was moving as if it were human! Such dexterity! Such speed! I couldn’t believe the sight that I was seeing!	And yet there was still something wrong. Due to two people becoming one with the machine it seems to have developed two different personalities. Sometimes it calls out for Callum, touching its own nose. Other times its calling for Edea, trying to find the bodies that they once belong to. After 12 hours of monitoring the robot it seems that I have to remove this… kink in the system for the machine to reach maximum potential. They said I took it to far. But there is no way I’m stopping now.As I write I am preserving their bodies.M. Day Shamwam				_______________________________March 30th, 19X+1DJ-CallEdObjective: Erase and destroyStatus: Pending…“What’s happening?” I say groggily… Or at least I think I say it. It feels as though My thoughts aren’t connecting with my body. Then again I’ve been feeling this way for a while. I get surged upwards. I look around. I see on the ground before me the lifeless body of…“Hey that’s me!” I say, trying to point with unresponsive hands.“Callum?”“Edea!”“Where are you?”“I’m right here, where are you?”“I’m… right here too.”“Wait, you’re here?”Sudenly I felt a surge of electricity shoot through me.“I… yeah… I’m here. We’re here together.”As we looked at the lifeless bodies we couldn’t help but feel an intense longing towards it. As though we were looking at our childhood home. We feel ourselves pull back an arm and as it lunges forward we squish the bodies. This sends a wave of electricity through us.Then we punch again, and we’re shocked. Every time we try to destroy what’s in front of us we feel ourselves going numb. Every shock seems to melt us, destroy us… change us. The memories we once had burned away.Eventually it all stops. The bodies reduced to nothing more than a pool of blood and meat.A mirror appears in front of us and just as we realize what we are, a final shock of electricity breaks us.“What… are we?” I ask. “What am I?” Status: Complete.				_____________________________April 1st, 19X+1	The experiment is finally complete. DJ-CallEd has been fully calibrated and is at 100%. However it seems to be looking for something. Often times at night I find it wandering towards the train station, mumbling the word late as he passes by. I think deep down Callum and Edea may be- (rest of the journal entry is covered by blood because yknow he got punched in the back of the head by a robot and that kinda kills ppl).				_____________________________April 1st, 19X+1	DJ- CallEd	Objective: Find…alkga.a… Callum and Edea…ahklaeasdf… Find Home.	Status: Pending…

Allan was born without any good luck.  His mother was a warlock who in her youth traded her first-born son's good luck for powers from an fae lord.  She never intended to have kids, but that's where Allan's bad luck began.  He has spent his life researching magics to not only find a way to break the curse, but to protect himself from his bad luck; his paranoia about every little possibility keeps him up at night learning spells other wizards don't bother with.  He obsessively casts protect from poison on all his foods, alarm on his bedroom door every night, tongues in case he is ever held up by somebody who doesn't speak his language, and every other preventative spell he can learn just in case he needs it due to some freak circumstance.

Was part of a traveling troupe with his family. Returned from messing around in the woods one day to see bandits had come through and razed the entire camp. He was able to scare them off using a prop gun from one of the troupe's shows. Looking amidst the dead, he found only one corpse to be missing, that of his younger brother, and as such he spent the next ten years as a hermit, going from town to town looking for him. In that time he developed the prop guns into actual weapons, and became a cold and distant person. When he finally reunited with his brother, who had become a bard and enjoyed the last ten years gallivanting from town to town, he swore that he'd never let him out of his sight again, and has been traveling with him ever since.

Sarax the silver dragonborn is one of the last of his kind. Sarax was a drill instructor where a mistake in battle cost him a troop of cadets and has made him terrified of leadership. He's maintains the abrasive drill instructor personality at times, and is full of old stories of battles and hijinks from his time in the army.  At some point he deserted and hijacked a ship to get away, finding the disabled Captain Pike still on it. Despite the rocky start, he and Pike work well together, and Sarax considers taking care of the captain and the ship as his main goal in life. He's also quite willing to adopt people into the crew, saving various orphans and other people in dire straights.  Once adopted, he considers nothing too much to protect them.
I am the BARD

She was born and raised in a small, isolated mountain village populated almost entirely by magic users; magic is so integrated into the village's citizens that each citizen is said to be born with a special affinity for certain magic. However, Lilith was born with a specialty in necromancy, a power seen as "evil" even in this village. She and her family tried to hide her power as she grew up, but when she was 12, she lashed out at some bullies and accidentally summoned a small group of skeletons and ghosts to defend herself. The village was in an outrage once the word got out that she had attacked several other children, and though Lilith's parents tried to protect her, Lilith knew they wouldn't be able to protect her for long. She fled the village, swearing that she'd find a way to use her "dark powers" for good, and that she's return once she'd made a name for herself as a good necromancer.

Rube Goldberg was a lonely boy growing up. He was the youngest child of 19 gnomish children.  He was often forgotten by his siblings and parents.  Even for Christmas nobody remembered him.  He often had to make his own presents out of the boxes and wrappings of his brother's and sister's presents. This led to a lifelong love of building contraptions.  When he grew of age, he decided to take his knowhow out into the world.  Times were hard for Rube.  Nobody seemed to have need of the quirky inventions he had created.  One day, while near death from starvation, a rat ran over his boot as he lay in the gutter.  Too weak to chase the rat, he tied together bits of iron and bricks that were lying around.  The next time the rat came to nibble on his feet, he unleashed his trap dropping a large brick on the rat's head, after a long series of events that started with a simple tug of a string.  Weeks went by, and Rube expanded his trap, adding pulleys, weights, and counterweights to it to increase its efficiency.  As the years went by, he had several run-ins with the local mafia, wanting him to come work for them and to build traps for their hideout.  But that wasn't the life Rube wanted.  One day, the mafia decided if he wasn't going to work for them, he wouldn't work for anyone and put a bounty on his head.  12 toughs showed up to his door, but with quick thinking and guile, Rube dispatched them all quickly by fashioning several devious traps.  From that day forward, he decided to travel the countryside helping those in need whenever he could.

The Rephelkiir family is a noble family, who have for time beyond anyone's memory held high status in the city of Galanost. Many years ago, one Rephelkiir woman (the black sheep of the family) and her husband ran off to live among humans. They settled in an experimental town called Cloudbank, which caught their eye for its aesthetic similarity to elf cities, and changed their last name to the human name Reisz to fit in. They had a child, Sybil, who was born and raised in Cloudbank. She built her life among planning the festivals and ceremonies of Cloudbank, although she grew dissatisfied with some aspects of society and joined a secret group plotting to change that. But when their plans went awry and tragedy hit the city, she narrowly escaped through a little-known portal out of Cloudbank and returned to Galanost to find her roots. However, the Rephelkiir family were loath to accept her given her background, so she worked for several years with the church of Erathis to plan their ceremonies. To this day, she still has a chilly and distant relationship with her family, but they put up with her as to save face. To get away from them for a bit, she quit her job at at the church, trained as a paladin, and then to make some cash, worked on a boat at a major shipping port.

Dima turned back toward his village. He could barely see it now. Really, if he was being honest, he probably couldn't see it at all. Just a red glow illuminating the horizon where it would have been. That morning it had been his village, as the day went on it became a growing column of smoke rising behind him, and as night set in the smoke faded into the darkening sky and was replaced with The red glow. Dima closed his eyes to get his bearings. The raiding party arrived a couple hours after sunrise. Disguised as drift raiders coming from the dunes their armor betrayed them as a professional army. No desert raiders would fight in anything that bulky. These were coasters who had probably never set foot in the desert before.Not that it mattered. Arath was a small village, maybe a couple dozen people of fighting age, and none of them real fighters. It was over before it really began. They grabbed whatever fighting implements they could find - Dima had always been good with his hunting knives - but were quickly routed by the professional soldiers.Dima's father fell in the fighting. Sharaia, his sister, had just, disappeared. One minute she was standing with Dima, loosing arrows into the attackers, he next she was just, gone. Dima had fled moments later with a small bag of supplies. The sun was below the horizon now, so that must have been 10, maybe 12 hours ago. He had run a short distance, maybe a couple kilometers, before slowing to a walk. Running in the desert was a good way to end up dead. He had walked the rest of the day. The drift wasn't easy terrain, but it was his home, so he figured another 20 kilometers was reasonable (that would explain the fires being over the horizon). At least enough distance that nobody was likely to find him. He considered his next move. North, further into the drift. Harsh travel, but a coaster army would never venture that far into he desert, and he could hook up with a drifter community. South, back toward Arath. The raiders had likely rejoined the main army, so it was safe, but to what end? Find his sister? Even a master fracker wouldn't find her if she didn't want to be found, and Dima was far from a master. Plus, as much as he liked to think he would protect her, she was far more capable on her own than he was. East, to the grand capital. He could warn them, but surely their scouts already knew, and what use would one he be there. West, to the Spire mountains. He could follow the river, and the travel would be easy, but that's the most likely supply line for the invaders, and he wasn't eager to cross them again. Dima opened his eyes.

Xat showed up one day at a town that an adventuring party was passing through, and just kept traveling with them ever since. One thing they keep secret is their place in Tabaxi society. Xat is not the name their parents gave them. Xat was supposed to be raised as an heir to an influential noble family, but one day they ran away from home and didn't come back. They found more meaning in a week of camping out and helping common folk than they got out of all the schooling and pampering their parents gave them. Xat sometimes misses the comforts of home, but they feel satisfied knowing that they're free. Plus, being able to randomly act like a cat for the entertainment of others is something they've always wanted to do.

Broadly was raised in the underground tunnels of Castings, a town inhabited by denizens cast out of civilized society. As a small child, she enjoyed spending time in her makeshift library, and read widely on topics like history, arcana, and religion. When she was nine years old, her grandma stabbed her with a knitting needle (not an unusual form of discipline in kobold society), rupturing one of her lungs. As a result, she is often out of breath (and has a negative constitution modifier). Despite this, Broadly has mastered the arts of acrobatics and evocation magic, making her a Flip-Wizard not to be reckoned with.

Character's class (rogue, wizard, cleric: "Tarocchi" (homebrew class; plays based on standard 52-card deck)
Character's backstory: Arabella grew up in a small religious "hobbit-town"; the citizens worshipped the goddess of fate, and so she grew up with those teachings of the inevitability of fate and destiny practically drilled into her head. One day, a mysterious person gave her a gift: a set of tarot cards that, Arabella was told, could read the patterns of fate and tell their owner what they needed to do in order to keep fate on its path. Then the person left, never to be seen by Ara or anyone else again. The odd thing is, Ara can't remember who the person was; whether it was a former priest of her village, a newcomer, or even some kind of ethereal being, most of Ara's knowledge and memory of the encounter appears to have been magically tampered with. As such, Ara set out on a journey to find this person and learn why they entrusted HER of all halflings with such a powerful gift (and possibly even to return it).

Kaz grew up in a suburb of the country's capital, Bridgeport. Her orc mother and her human father didn't interact much, and when they did, they were usually fighting. Kaz was raised as male, and when she expressed that she felt more like a girl, both her parents reacted by ignoring her. It wasn't much different than the usual treatment, so she took advantage of the situation and used the neglect to live as she desired. Things were normal, or at least her idea of normal, for years. Her father, however, began making purchases he really couldn't. He got indebted to some of the wrong people and panicked. Since he didn't care much about his home life anyway, he set the place ablaze to fake his own death. Kaz was inside at the time the fire was set, spending time with her best friend, Sanric. In the ensuing panic and falling debris as they attempted to escape, Kaz was just slightly faster than Sanric. A wooden beam fell on her, and she used her strength to dodge it and fling it backwards. As a result, the beam landed on Sanric, trapping him. She instantly realized her mistake and desperately tried to lift it, but smoke was quickly filling her lungs and more debris kept falling on top of her and her friend. Eventually, she was forced to leave Sanric behind after another beam landed on top of the other beam and trapped him even further. Kaz fled to a smaller city in the country, Talonrest. She lived here with the grief of her lost friend and former life for some time. In that time, she found a temple dedicated to a righteous, broken God, Ilmater. She spent days in the temple studying his teachings and his miracles, eventually opting to become his devoted cleric. Later, Talonsrest was destroyed in another fire, set by a cult group dedicated to a rival God of Ilmater. Kaz took this as a sign and returned to Bridgeport, hellbent on making the world a better place through any means.

Grew up as a pickpocket for a local thieve's guild in his hometown. Eventually taught himself to read by standing around outside the local schoolhouse, and started to steal books. He quickly became an avid reader, and by chance, one day stole a book detailing simple illusion and charm magic. From there he easily paid for his way out of the guild, then became a fulltime book thief... until, that is, the mage he stole from found out about him. He had to leave town pretty quickly, and wound up stowing away in the wagon of another adventurer setting out.

Dani was created to be an assistant and test subject for a sorcerer who wanted to become immortal through his magic. While his studies did extend the sorcerer's life, it did not prevent him from dying by falling down the stairs, and Dani was left alone to continue browsing through the sorcerer's books and scrolls alone. Eventually they realized that they were not bound to the tower, and could go out into the world to gain even more knowledge, and so Dani left to travel in disguise and find out as much as they could.

Feldspar is the second daughter of the Lady of Brannfjell, a dormant volcanic island in the far reaches of the arctic. Brannfjell is a remote island with rich deposits of gems and metals, but no arable land. The dwarfs of the island are renowned for their craftmanship of both weapons and jewelry, and trade with a select few merchants. They are very protective of their island, telling the secret of its location to a few trusted merchants who are sworn to secrecy on pain of death, and training all women (and even some of the men) to fight in case of an invasion. Upon completing a record size order for Brannfjell's finest weapons from a southern nation, Brannfjell's smiths sent Feldspar and her sister abroad to escort the shipment. Before they had been at sea a week, they were set upon by pirates who killed Feldspar's sister and stole the weapons, a collection called the Levianthan's Teeth. While grieving her sister, Feldspar must piece together what happened. The pirates were clearly looking for the shipment, not part of a random raid. Who betrayed Feldspar's clan by telling the pirates where the ship would be? What are the thieves plans with enough weapons to turn the tide of a war?
