Feldspar must figure this out for herself, separated from her clan by their secretive ways, she is a stranger in the world, unable to even book passage back to her home.

Following a devastating tunnel collapse, Ambeeo's tribe was forced to move into the sewers of a nearby city. With poor disease resistance, most of the tribe fell prey to infection and the large vermin within. However, Ambeeo displayed a peculiarly strong immune system and an affinity with rats that allowed him to survive the conditions that killed the rest of his brood. Time in the darkness deteriorated the luster of his scales, making them a mottled, sickly hue and damaged his already tenuous grip on reality still further, leading the young kobold to grow up... odd. He is highly abrasive and somewhat repulsive in his appearance and behavior, but is possessed of a fiendish intellect and can engage in lively discussions with his preferred variety of mammalian life: Rats. He eschews the typical kobold trapbuilding in favour of sewer magicks and potent unguents of his own design. He approaches each new adventure as an expedition of great importance to his alchemical research, and when outside the comfort of his makeshift laboratory he is often found in the presence of Foamface, an albino rat with which he feels a special kinship.

No.153 is a robotic entity, one of many whose sole purpose is to travel the land and gather data; in 153's case, specifically musical data. When asked about why they do this, 153 explains that their master, R. Kiever, desires to collect and consume all knowledge in the world, and created an army of robots specifically to help him carry out that task. However, 153's descriptions of Kiever are vague at best, and the more they are pressed on their master's identity and intentions, the cloudier things tend to become. It seems even No.153 does not know who they or R. Kiever really are...
Hes a doofus

Mira Trill is a young female Halfling that loves life and doesn't take anything for granted. As a child she had everything she ever wanted, her parents were both real high society Halflings. Mirabella Trill was born to Michelangelo and Rachael Trill. The two Halflings made their life by killing in their assassin's guild named Night's embrace. When the two had Mira they left the guild and the guild never had any problems however they were sad to see their best two assassins leave. A man in the guild that went by the name Darkblade, which fit him because his blade was pure black, got the couple a job in town working as assistants for big businesses and soon they were promoted and Michelangelo soon owned his own business. Being very wealthy they soon were able to pay for anything and everything young Mira wanted. She got it all and was soon a spoiled yet humble child. The city she lived in was very big and like any other big city had its share of poor citizens. She grew up fine but lonely she had her friends that she loved to hang out with go to parties and explore life with but for many years she never had a boyfriend or even a male friend at the least. When she turned 20 her friends threw her a very big party for her Birthday. Everyone of importance was to be there everyone their age and more. She had a wonderful time and the party lasted well into the night. Towards the middle of the night she met a halfling that had just turned 20 a week ago himself. His name was Niccolo and he made her feel better than any other girl in the world. You see the reason why she had no other boys in her life wasn't because she was ugly or anything it was no other boy paid her any mind. They all chased after the girls who gave themselves to them willingly. However Niccolo was different he was mature and handsome also. He was also the first boy her age ever to notice her and call her beautiful. From that point on they both knew they were in love. After that night it was all she needed to know who she wanted to spend her life with. He told her he would come see her the next day for dinner. The next morning she couldn't wait and went to see her new love as soon as she could. She had her connections look him up and find where he lived and she went instantly. When she got there she was surprised. He lived in a middle class district and worked for a blacksmith as his apprentice. She went to him and he got angry with her then he calmed down and apologized. He never told her about where he lived or what he did because he knew who she was, everyone did. They all knew she was the daughter of a business owner that owned a lot of places in the city. He didn't want her to be turned away from him because of who he was. She just told him “If I wasn't in love with you do you think I would of went this early to see you?” He just smiled then kissed her. She had her first kiss then. Halfway through she moved in with him. Her parents paid for the place it was in a market district not to far from Niccolo's work and it wasn't as poor as his old home. They were upper middle class and a year later they were engaged. The marriage was planned for a year after the engagement. Her parents getting on in years had decided one of the last things they wanted to do for their daughter was throw her a big wedding. It was planned to be at their mansion and many people were invited. However 2 months prior her father died. They had the funeral and all of her father's friends and family were invited. Darkblade was there and was now the leader of the guild. He talked to Mira and asked her to join eager for the daughter of the two best assassins to join. She declined. Her mother now in charge of the business needed help and Mira decided she wanted to take over the business when she was old enough. Niccolo had no idea what her parents did until that day and after was kind of scared of Mira and her family. Mira reassured him that she wanted no part of that life and her parents gave it up before she was born. He was still a little unnerved by it but let it go by. Then a week before the wedding Darkblade arrived on Mira's doorstep. Mira was furious telling him to leave that she had no intention to join the guild and push him out the door. On his way out he told her that he had no intention of asking her to join just that there was an assassin after her family from a rival guild. He told them they needed to leave at once to avoid conflict. Thinking this was a way to get her to join the guild she told him never to come back and to leave her family alone. The next day at the wedding rehearsal everything went perfect. At the dinner they had a toast and as they all took a sip everyone but Mira started to fall out of their chairs. Suddenly three men came into sight. Two of them grabbed Mira and the other started slitting the throats of her friends and family in front of her. As they worked up the table they reached her mother and Mira cried out for them to stop. The man simply stated she had a choice, her mother or her fiancé. She sat there terrified then with a quick puff of smoke the men were killed and her mother spared. Darkblade had rushed in to save her and her mother. He explained she needed to leave and head back to the Guild Hall for safety. Her mother revealed Darkblade had been her brother and never kept his eyes off the family. Niccolo was upset not knowing what happened while he was drugged. His family had been killed and now he was to be relocated to an Assassin Guild. His only saving grace was Mira was untouched. They both decided to train with the guild and learn how to better defend themselves in return they would serve the guild. Niccolo often stays behind forging weapons for the Guild while Mira prefers to scout for intelligence. They both frequently write letters back and forth when they're apart.

Finnan Thornmwatch is the last surviving member of the Thornwatch clan, sworn to protect the Ruins of Graythorn. He never had any siblings and when he was 8 years old both his parents died when an invading nation attacked their town. After the shock of losing his parents he fled to the woods to live among the ruins his family had been protecting for many years. He knew there was purpose to their protection, even if he didn't know what that purpose was, and being among the ruins he swore he could still feel the presence of his family. He felt comfortable and safe there and he knew his family would want him to be there.Abandoning the civilized world at such a young age to guard these ruins, Finnan grew very close to nature and would often meditate and commune with the spirits of the surrounding woods. One day while in this meditation, Finnan noticed an elvish figure tracking and hunting a large brown bear. Recognizing the bear as the recent mother of 3 cubs Finnan ran and leapt in front of the hunter's arrow to protect the bear shouting "You mustn't kill her! She has cubs!", being shot in place of the creature. Startled, the hunter rushed to Finnan's aid but it was too late and the arrow had struck right through his heart.Sylvanus, God of Wild Nature, came to Finnan in death and told him that he had given his life for a noble cause but being the last living protector of Graythorn he could not die just yet. Sylvanus then told Finnan that he would revive him for a cost that he would one day need to pay, but not to worry for as long as he stood protector of Graythorn he would not need to pay this debt. Finnan accepted and was revived, still laying in the hunter's arms. Finnan spent the next few days healing and getting to know the hunter, spilling his life story with the first person he had seen in the 12 years since his family had died. The hunter was actually a huntress. A short athletic Drow named Zar'rae who too lived just outside these woods nearly 80 years, raised by her adopted Wood Elf family.During the few days spent healing Finnan's physical features began to slowly shift from human to almost demonic. His light hair grew even lighter until it was pure white. His pale skin grew darker and more red in color. His brow slowly lost all hair and merged to form a set of 4 small toothlike horns. His teeth sharpened almost vampirically, the front teeth growing in length as well. And a thin tail with a pointed spade shaped tip poked it's way through his pants. Seeing this transformation from a paleskinned Human to a redskinned Tiefling, Zar'rae knew all too well from her being a Drow, how ever good Finnan may be, if he ever were to rejoin society now he would surely be discriminated against. Zar'rae began to take pity on him and offered her friendship to Finnan, visiting him daily at the ruins.Naturally, as time passed Zar'rae had finally grown old enough in her family's eyes to set off and travel the rest of the world, and so she did, and Finnan became alone once again. After a few weeks, Finnan decided to set off on a journey of his own and catch up with his only friend... wrecklessly abandoning his sworn duty to Graythorn... and his debt to Sylvanus...

He was a young goblin cast from his cave dwelling, for his passion for music was considered strange to the other goblins. He left with only his hand carved Toot Flute, into the night. After hearing about a magical golden flute, he searched for 2 years, coming across ancient ruins filled with cave drawing about the true power of a real Bard. After researching for another year, he left the ruins with his bewfound powers of magic music.

Mav’ren Tomas (or Mav to those he trusts) understands the Law of Threes because he’s experienced it.Mav was a child when he arrived with his merchant parents in Saerloon. His family was of some considerable wealth, at least enough to afford the tutelage of the displaced Rasheman witch Ivani. When he was six years old, his parents left him in Ivani’s care as they departed for a trademeet. They never returned. To this day, Mav doesn’t know what happened to them. Luckily, they left Ivani a fine inheritance so she could take him in as an apprentice.Mav’ren was a capable, if difficult, apprentice. While he understood the theory behind magic, he had difficulty grasping at the threads of power. Because of this, Ivani crafted for him a special focus: A ring and bracelet fashioned of copper wire. Within each is a tiny needle, enough to prick the skin and draw blood, closing a circuit of energy that allows Mav to manipulate the forces needed for any spell.Ivani was a good mentor, taking care of Mav’ren for three years. One day, she left with what Mav could only describe as a band of men. She left with some urgency, gathering her spellbook and whatever she could cram into a backpack.None of them ever came back. To this day, Mav doesn’t know what happened to them, or why they left. If Ivani had a journal, she took it with her.or seven months, Mav’ren took care of himself. He knew all the passwords to the wards, where all the gold was kept, where all the good books and reagents were stored. It sucked not having Ivani around, but Mav could take care of the place (as was part of his apprenticeship).That changed when Cranmer broke into the place.It was clear that Cranmer had no business being there, but being a thief, a wizard’s manse that had been empty for over half a year was up for exploration – at least, before the other gangs barged in. But seeing Mav on his own… well… Cranmer wasn’t about to leave the boy on his own, so he made an offer. Mav’ren took about five minutes to come to a decision.Cranmer’s Guild, the Crows, had the most unique weapon amongst the gangs of Thieves in Saerloon: diplomacy. They established the boundaries of the various Guilds, cobbled alliances, and helped keep the peace in the city – and all profited from it. Cranmer led his crew through respect, both given and received. It was here the Mav’ren’s talents came to light.As he lived amongst his guildmates, Mav continued his studies. In the process, he also understood how criminal activity worked. Five years after he joined the Crows, Mav became aware of the activity of a freelancer disrupting the peace. Cranmer put Mav to use, letting him establish the pattern of activity, the mode of operations, and other patterns that brought the rogue to the Guilds’ own justice.Mav continued this line of work for years, helping the keep freelancers in line and the Guilds accountable. The Crows were small but efficient and profitable. One Crow, Thalia, took an interest in Mav, helping him “become a man.” It was a mutual arrangement given she became a woman. Despite the nature of thieves, the two became a loving pair.Six months ago, Mav needed to travel to Selgaunt for a particular tome he needed. When he returned, his guild house was empty. No sign of forced entry, no sign of battle, no sign of treasure. Despite this, Mav found several trinkets left behind that he knew no Crow would abandon. In his lover’s room he found the silver locket he gave her, his lock of hair still inside.Given all the signs, Mav knew he had one course of action: get the hell out of the city. He burned the hair in the locket and departed Saerloon, looking for numbers to keep him safe.To this day, he doesn’t know what happened to the Crows, but whatever pattern’s been established, he intends to decipher it… and break it.
Banished for stealing to pay off his gambling debts.
Son of ex-adventurer's, looking to see what adventuring life is like.

After her village was massacred by soldiers, she was raised by a human scholar as a nature-versus-nurture social experiment. Now she seeks to follow in her adoptive-father's footsteps as a master of the arcane and scholar of psychology.
Sage

Verthag came from a large and noble family that didn't accept her gentle nature. She wanted to dress and be referred to as a woman and had no interest in plundering or sex. She left her family because they refused to respect her gender identity. In a tavern she met with a band of misfit adventurers- at first she joined with them for money, then for the fame as a musician. Slowly she came to care for them as her new family and felt very protective of them. Particularity a young elf cleric and a ranger of middle years who was as silent, stoic and fashionable as she. A flaming haired capricious rogue captured her heart and probably some of her gold while Verthag tried to puzzle out if her flirtations were genuine and worried over whether or not her own asexuality and the fact that she's a trans woman were deal breakers or not.
Youngest in a hobbit household, with an decidedly unhobbitish interest in exploring. Also a skilled fingersmith.
Scout for a roving hoard

The daughter of 2 tieflings who both are far enough removed through blood that they mostly look like tinted humans. Nixi, actually named Bluebell, came out in a more concentrated form and is more like tiefling light. She has a brother name Lavender. Her parents own a bakery in a seaside town. One day, the bakery gets an infestation of something and they call in a specialist in weird vermin to come and take care of it. The vermin are some sort of small magical thing and it takes the wizard a few weeks to fully get rid of them. The whole time Nixi is fascinated with everything he does and she follows him around, learning and helping. This sparks a love for magic and a great desire to learn more about magical vermin and pests. Throughout her teens, she teaches herself magic and how to locate small magically entities. When she turns 19 she leaves/runs away her home for a city that's inland. She stays in the attic of some building and begins advertising herself as being able to take of things worse than rats and smaller than boars. Any time she catches something she takes it to the city outskirts and lets it go, but if it's something she's never encountered before she keeps at least one live specimen. Later, she's made aware of a city watch that specifically seeks out and hunts similar, but larger nuisances. She hops on board and starts a career seeking out and leaning about everything weird and misplaced.

Left alone as a child for provoking a lynch mob by being a psychopath, he wandered for quite some time and found someone willing to take him in: a drunken bard by the name of Paultin Seppa. He'd disappear for days or weeks, on adventures he couldn't tell, but he was still the father to a couple dozen random children who had nowhere to go. Trenos was raised by Paultin to become a strong fighter and adventurer, with large amounts of knowledge of beasts and evils. Unfortunately, when he was swept into Ravenloft by an enemy of Paultin's, he made the mistake Paultin swore he'd never let anyone make: he betrayed his party. After killing Paultin in exchange for power, Trenos ascended to become the Darklord of Infernum, opposed by an "elite" group of shit people: his father, resurrected by his husband as a vampire. Escher, Paultin's vampiric husband. Van Richten, who murdered all of Paultin's family. Count Strahd Von Zarovich, mission control for these fucks. Nicolas and Evie, resurrected party members out for blood, the first of whom is insane and the second who is an Inkling from Splatoon. Diath, Strix, and Evelyn, resurrected party members that Paultin betrayed. And that's where the campaign begins.

Nek'Tass Ketachi is used to being alone. A solitary wyrmling from an isolated dragonborn clan, Nek often wandered the desert by himself, learning the danger and beauty of the sea of sand. Uninterested in the arts of combat, Nek apprenticed to the shaman and studied the ways of magic, learning how to bend and shape the structure of the world around him. The vision quest of his adulthood rites showed that clan leadership was to be his, but only after he finds and defeats a mighty enemy yet to appear. Determined to seek out this test, and with the blessings of the clan council, Nek journeyed to the edge of the desert to temper his knowledge with experience in the world beyond the sands. The dragonborn wanders now through a world full of peoples and wonders he has never dreamed possible. Moving among so many sentient beings is unsettling for someone so solitary, but Nek recognises the strength that comes from clan, and that he will need friends to aid him when his great battle comes.  For the enemy is approaching. And Nek will be ready.

Carol was studying astronomy when the spirit of her dead father, Carmine - a renowned storm sorcerer who died while adventuring, came back to her and compelled her to seek out his killer by haunting her to no end.  She would really rather not, but she made a promise with him that he would stop interfering in her life and questioning her decisions and finally go on to the afterlife if she solved the mystery.

The name is Beech. Jeremy Beech. Jeremy has spent many years in service to the Crown, gathering information through clandestine operations for the Kingdom Intelligence Service. He usually gets what he wants through his considerable charm and guile, but he is not above using intimidation or physical coercion to pursue his goals. A few years ago, he bit off more than he could chew and found himself in a situation he couldn't escape. With no other choice, he made a deal with the devil. That's not an expression - he quite literally bargained his soul to a fiendish entity to gain his life and freedom. Now tied to a fiendish pact he doesn't want, he works to confound his patron by doing good wherever he can, and plots to one day escape the chains that bind them together.

Salarian Fleetfoot is used to being admired. He recognises it's a burden that someone of his magnificence cannot escape. A boisterous, loud and confident youth, adults admired him for his skills, women admired him for his looks, and other boys admired him for his daring. In adulthood, some of that sheen tarnished, as people began to see him as arrogant, self-absorbed and uncaring. His deeds could not be ignored, however, so he continued to enjoy status in his clan. His achievements grew so many that a clever rival convinced him to leave the highlands in pursuit of greater deeds in the wider world. Clueless to the sarcasm and cunning, Salarian agreed the clan had grown too small for his heroism, and set out in search of others to bathe in his glory. With his legend preceding him (if only by the distance of his own voice), Salarian walks the land, bestowing his greatness on a troubled world one victim at a time.

O'Akeecha is trying to find his way home.The Aarakocra fledgling was fascinated by magic and spent hours observing the shaman at work, watching her preparations, memorising her rituals, recording all he learned in his journal. Impulsive and curious, he took an opportunity when her back was turned to try what he had observed, using some of her collection of magical components and artifacts.The results were unfortunate.A bright flash surrounded him, and the scroll he was reading crumbled to dust in his grip. O'Akeecha, startled, found himself looking at an alien landscape. He overflew the land, seeking help, but every humanoid he approached drove him off, startled by his appearance and manner of speech.O'Akeecha has come to realise that he is in a different world altogether. To have any hope of returning home, he must become a skilled practitioner of magic, able to bend reality and reach out to other planes. He has no home, no funds, no allies, and no teacher - only the notes in his journal of magic.Lost and alone, he has no idea how to start.

Some people think Selwin insane. Selwin is one of them. From an early age, his sleep was torn by nightmares of death and destruction. Whole towns burned, the population slaughtered. And always, there was the image of Selwin standing over the corpse of his father, a bloody dagger in hand. His father had no patience for the crazy child. The big man's violent nature resulted in many beatings, and eventually in the drunken murder of Selwin's mother. His father left without a backward glance. After a period of wandering and begging to survive, Selwin found himself within a monastery. The abbot declared him touched by heaven, and took him in. Years of meditation, martial training and discipline brought Selwin a level of control, but his nightmares never left him. In his 10th year at the monastery, Selwin's vision finally became reality. A military force attacked and destroyed the town and sacked the monastery, slaughtering any who resisted. The leader of the invaders was Selwin's father, who didn't even recognise his son. Would the destruction have been avoided if Selwin had obeyed his vision and killed his father? Unable to answer, the tortured monk drifts the world, fleeing his nightmares.

Tempest blames his misfortune on his parents. To be fair, so do they. They sought a blessing for their unborn child, that he might fully achieve his potential. Neither knew the secret shame of their bloodlines; a djinni ancestor in his, and a draconic ancestor in hers. Thanks to their well-intentioned efforts, their son is forced to suffer the marks of his double heritage. Patches of bright copper scales cover his arms, legs and back, and his skin and hair gleams a light blue tint.Tempest is not amused by this cosmic joke. As short-tempered as his name suggests, he takes umbrage at any slight. There were many such insults during his youth, and it was during one of the resulting tantrums that the boy first exhibited signs of magic. Tempest has embraced this power as a means of revenging himself on those who insult him, and he is liberal in his interpretation of what constitutes an insult. As a result, Tempest has few friends and is rarely able to stay in one place for very long. Not that he cares; he prefers to rely on nobody but himself. He may work with others for as long as their purpose aligns but as soon as the job is done, Tempest is in the wind.

Bigman has failed.Bigman protected the Forest with his tribe. One day, the Forest told him a man had come. Bigman went to watch and see. Father Thomas said, "Hello, big man." Father Thomas was a friend to the Forest, so the tribe decided he could stay. Bigman spent much time with Father Thomas, who taught him about the Goddess. The Goddess loved the Forest, so Bigman decided the Goddess was good. Bigman liked the Goddess. Then the Forest told Bigman that monsters had come. Bigman ran to his tribe, but monsters had killed them all. Bigman ran back to Father Thomas, but monsters had been there also. Bigman did not know what to do without his tribe or his friend. The Goddess told Bigman to take money from Father Thomas and leave the Forest. There were too many monsters and Bigman could not fight them all. The Goddess told Bigman to find new friends and train hard and one day come back to the Forest and face the monsters. Bigman is sad for his tribe and his friend and the Forest. But Bigman trusts the Goddess.

Berenthos Frostmantle had every reason to be happy. He was married to a woman he loved above all other things in the world. He adored their daughter and their home and their lives. He loved his trade, and he was good at it. Under his hands, timber was carved, shaped and made to live again in a new form. His pieces were sought after, and the Frostmantle mark was a status symbol in homes of the wealthy. He reveled in the love of his daughter, who smiled over the texts she studied so hard, overjoyed every time he brought her some new trinket carved just for her, laughing like the child she used to be. Berenthos was lost when he found the body of his wife, and the single set of bloodied footprints leaving his home for the woods. His mind went away for a time, and he wandered the forest looking for his missing daughter. She must have been taken by someone, he reasoned. Someone who left no prints on the bloodied floor. Someone who left no sign of their presence. There was no other explanation. Eventually, the forest was more his home than the building that had once held his life. Berenthos lived wild, always searching. He had no use for love any more, or compassion. He grew into a hard man his family would not have recognised. And he went out into the world, seeking what had been taken from him, and vowing to take it back.

Life isn't fair. Crag Stonethrow is determined to fix that. The Hiwi-Toka tribe taught Crag that a thing no longer useful is abandoned. A childhood friend was crushed by a falling rock; leg useless, he was shunned until he fell behind the tribe and died. Crag felt it wasn't right for one to be punished for misfortune not of his own making. He began intervening in similar situations. He carried an elder when she fell behind the tribe. He defended a husband from a drunk wife. He took the misfortune of others upon himself and made it his mission to solve their problems. Crag's life changed the day he stumbled onto a human caravan raided by bandits. He tracked the bandits, challenged them, and left their unconscious bodies behind him as he carried the stolen goods to the rightful owners. The grateful caravanserie fed him and told him tales of a world in which such injustices were common. The goliath, shocked at what he heard, left his tribe without a word or second glance and set out to even the playing field.  Crag now makes his way through the world, fixing it one wrong at a time. He doesn't know where his power comes from and, frankly, he doesn't care. As far as he is concerned, the world is broken. And he's not going to stand for it.

All his life, Elegy Smith escaped into stories. Children, including his brothers and sisters, tormented him for his pointed ears. His father resented him for being a constant reminder of his mother's unfaithfulness, and his mother's eyes filled with regret for a lost love every time she looked at him. Mother never spoke of his true sire, so Elegy sought refuge in tales of elf princes and lost inheritances. Eventually he began to create his own stories, which he hoarded like precious gems. He never realised that his talent for spinning tales could be of practical use, until a week of foul weather stranded a minstrel in the village. Elegy listened to the troubadour singing tales of legendary heroes, enraptured. By the end of the week, he was determined to make the singing and telling of stories his profession. Leaving behind few who missed him, Elegy made his way to the city and won a position in the college of bardic lore. He excelled at his studies, but tutors felt he spent too much time in research and recommended a few years of practical experience on the road to make him a truly exceptional performer. Elegy packed his things and set out, his mind set on creating the greatest ballad of the age. Stories are everywhere, he reasoned. He just needed to find the right one.

Ammon Greenfield was a rebellious youth. In a community known for dependability and conformity, this halfling displayed a stubborn insistence on satisfying his whims and desires instead of contributing to the fabric of society in any meaningful way. Then he fell in love. When she spurned him in favour of another despite his determined campaign of wooing, he fell into a rage and exchanged blows with his rival. He was soundly beaten and woke from unconsciousness in the medical care of a nearby monastery, a newfound anger and purpose driving him.Cue the training montage. For a year, Ammon worked under the tutelage of the monastery's masters to hone his body to the peak of martial skill. Then he returned to the village to challenge for his beloved... and found her married and nursing a newborn. Bitter and full of regret and bile, Ammon went back to the monastery, further developing his unarmed combat skills with a zeal unmatched by any other. He refused to let go of his anger, despite his sensei's attempts at instruction, and eventually left to seek a new purpose. He is still looking.

Balto Cole grew up in an orphanage, like many others in the aftermath of the war between orcs and men. He learned the value of friendship and used his size and strength to protect those younger and weaker.He took a job as a labourer for a merchant, learning combat skills from caravan guards during their layovers for cargo. He supplemented his income by fighting in the pit for the purse on offer and the wagers he made on his ability. When finally the day came that Balto was forced to kill a man, it wasn't in the ring. A noble with a large sum of money wagered against Balto sought to improve his odds by injuring Balto before a fight. The scuffle went badly, and the noble took a mortal wound. Balto knew he had no chance of a fair trial, so he left his life behind and fled.Since then, he has travelled, selling his swordarm and evading the law. He dreams of going far enough to outrun the reach of the noble family that hunts him, or to earn enough money, power and respect to defeat them and return to his home in peace.But for now, there is the road and the sword. And for now, that is enough.

Justin Bell was a merchant for many years. He traveled extensively in his youth, seeing many places and learning a variety of skills. He had a knack for talking people out of their gold and wasn't inhibited about a little light-fingered liberation of valuables when attention was directed elsewhere. If people don't take care of their possessions, they don't really want them, do they?In his thirties, Justin set up a store where he bought from merchants to sell to customers, rather than doing the traveling himself. He became known as a procurer of specialist items for a discerning type of client. Sometimes these items were owned by other people but Justin felt that liberating them for somebody who obviously wanted them more was a public service, and one that he was uniquely qualified to perform. It was inevitable that one such liberated item would be traced to him eventually, and Justin had all his property seized and spent some months in prison. Now released, with no ties, no money, few possessions, and even fewer scruples, Justin is looking for a new direction. Surely his skills must be valuable to somebody?

Tennyson Shott always found comfort in structure. Order brings certainty, he used to say to the university kitchen staff who worked under him. If it's good enough for the wizards, it's good enough for those of us that feed them. He was more disciplined than, say, the apprentice wizard who ruined a potion through carelessness, then then threw it into a hastily conjured rift that accidentally targeted the soup Tennyson was stirring. The cook managed one confused sip of the suddenly frothing mixture, just before it exploded. The wizards healed Tennyson, theorizing about the unique causes of the magical energy that now burst from him at irregular intervals. When he was well, they thanked him for his service. Then they fired him, explaining that he was far too dangerous to have around volatile magics. His life in ruins, Tennyson wanders the world, unable to keep a job for more than a few weeks before the magic bursts out of him and destroys something. Nerves frazzled by the chaotic existence he is forced to lead, he desperately searches for somewhere even vaguely normal where he can belong.

Arrow Flight was the best scribe in his flock. He hated it. The endless routine of copying information from one piece of paper to another confined him to drudgery when he longed for excitement. When it became too much for him, he put away his quill, took up a dagger and set about emulating the rogues of his flock by robbing the townhouse of a wealthy merchant. Standing by the hangman next day, noose around his neck, Arrow Flight desperately sought escape. Hearing the creak of leather gloves on the release handle, feeling the trap door beneath him drop away, he closed his eyes and prayed to any power that could save him. And was answered. In the scintilla of time before the rope drew taut, Arrow Flight felt a dark presence enter his mind, promising survival for service. The Kenku agreed immediately, and the rope broke as he reached the end of the drop. In the confusion, using the crowd as cover, he made his escape. Now he has the excitement he craved, but his life is as tightly controlled as before. Never his own master, he wields his patron's magic in his service, collaborating with others when possible, working alone when necessary. He has the life he wanted. And he hates it.

She ventured through a portal in a storm water drain, from our world to the Dragon Empire. She emerged in New Corgshire, a Fey  Corgi village, and was quickly adopted by the local blacksmith as her sister. As a side effect of the interdimensional travel, Cupcake found that she could see the threads of fate and time and used this to her advantage in and out of the combat.

Zubokar has come a long way from the swamp.Exiled from his tribe after a clash over a female, Zubokar encountered a human hiding at the edge of their territory. With nothing better to do, Zubokar accepted coin to act as bodyguard. The lizardman followed his employer to the city, where they met with the guild of thieves. Zubokar's employer challenged the guild leader to trial by combat to resolve whatever issue had made him hide in the swamp. Zubokar stepped forward as proxy for the fight, then switched sides when the guild leader offered a greater sum of money than his current employer. After killing once for the guild leader, it was easy enough to keep doing it. Zubokar lived in the sewers beneath the city, guarding the guild's hideouts, killing when ordered, and occasionally eating a city worker who ventured into his territory. Life was good.Unfortunately, Zubokar killed a member of the nobility who was investigating "the monster in the sewers". With the city watch scouring the undercity, the guild leader suggested the lizardman leave the city until things calmed down. And so, with a little coin, a big appetite and a lot of time, Zubokar drifts through the world, looking for whatever comes next.

Mica Dross has always felt like a freak. His family history was a list of the most famous warriors the clan had ever produced. It was an unstated expectation that Mica also would become a mighty champion for the Kingdom Under the Mountain. That didn't happen. Mica chose instead to mine arcane libraries, seeking out rich veins of magic and absorbing what scant spellcasting knowledge was available under the mountain. He wore the armour and wielded the hammer, but it was a sham, an attempt to fit in. When he finally admitted the truth to his family, he was ostracised. His name was famous, yes - but as one of his people's very few spellcasters, an unrespected profession followed by only a handful of dwarves. When he left the mountains, seeking greater arcane knowledge, he remained a freak. An armoured spellcaster with a warhammer, from a race known to distrust magic, he was viewed as a curiosity, like a dog walking on two legs. With no place anywhere among his people or the wider world, Mica lives a gypsy lifestyle, wandering aimlessly, looking for a place to fit in.

Want to hear a story? Mist-on-the-water is your man.Mist grew up in the back of a wagon. His family wandered from place to place, performing for whatever crowds they could find. Mist learned to play the tabla, drumming while his sisters danced, or accompanying his father while he spun tales of legend. His father's stories were catnip to Mist. The youngster sought out other legends and folktales wherever they traveled and began to perform them himself. After several years, Mist and his father agreed that his continued development could best be served by striking out on his own for a time. Following a celebration full of song, dance, joy and pride, Mist-on-the-water left his loving family troupe to go solo.The years since have been good ones. While his curiosity sometimes gets him into trouble, his quick wits and fast talking just as often get him out again. Often alone, sometimes traveling with a troupe for a season, Mist continues to wander the world and gather the tales he loves.

Arashi Stormborn was ostracised from the day of his birth in the midst of a raging tempest. The horns that indicated his demonic heritage drove his horrified father to leave that same night. He was raised by his mother, shunned by the village. He grew used to the whispers and fearful looks whenever others saw his horned visage and ice-white hair and skin. He was lonely for others his own age, but his mother ensured he always felt loved. A series of bad harvests during his teenage years saw the villagers looking for a scapegoat for their misfortune and eventually a violent mob brought torches and pitchforks to burn them out. The youth fled for his life, as the mob fell on his mother. Hiding his demonic heritage beneath stolen armour, he spent several years alternately guarding caravans and stealing from them. What truly drove him, however, was prevention of the kind of ignorant superstition that destroyed his home, and his lessons were not gentle.  Stories of the armoured one grew more numerous, and Arashi began to see himself as a force of nature, a hammer wielded by the Lord of Storms himself.  Moving from place to place and job to job, always hiding his demonic appearance, Arashi Stormborn delivers divine wrath to the unjust.

Edmaris is, literally and figuratively, a fish out of water.The triton raised his family, served with honour in the Marisian Guard, and won the respect of all who knew him. He was groomed for command, but always demurred with the reply that he was focused on his daughters and their welfare. When the last and youngest of his girls married only a year after his wife's death, everyone expected Edmaris would finally accept his commission and join the military leadership of Marisia. Instead, the middle-aged triton resigned from the guard, packed a few belongings and left for the surface world. Free of his responsibilities, Edmaris is finally able to indulge his wanderlust. He moves from place to place, selling his martial skills to mercenary companies or in the gladiatorial arena, marvelling at the wonders of the surface world. With few needs and an insatiable curiosity, Edmaris seeks adventure.
He plays drums and has the memory of a gold fish. Amanal like!

When he was 17, Kalkheus started working with his master, a draconian artificer and master engineer called Jinroth. Jinroth taught him his craft over several long years. He was not, however, alone in this - his master had another apprentice, a half-elf by the name of Elqarim. Elqarim was the son of a noble, and Kalkheus always secretly assumed that he had bought his way into his master's workshop. Kalkheus was never a man of means, so there was always a disconnect between them, stemming both from Kalkheus 's jealousy and Elqarim's haughtiness. Elqarim would always act superior to Kalkheus, and was always one-upping him, much to Kalkheus 's chagrin. While Jinroth liked to think he treated both apprentices equally, he always seemed to work Kalkheus harder, and his criticism was harsher even when it wasn't nearly as deserving as Elqarim. Mostly, Jinroth was scared of any repurcussions from Elqarim's family, as they were very influential. Eventually, both apprentices were skilled enough to be recognised as proper artificers. Finally, their invention contests would come to an end...or so Kalkheus thought.Afterwards, Kalkheus received no immediate work and so furthered his studies for a year. Eventually, Kalkheus spent many years as a sailor on a ship, travelling the coast from port to port. He worked under Captain Orvelle Fogwatcher, a female human. The long days at sea gave him ample time to tinker on and off, and the hard work kept him physically fit. His inventions occasionally helped operation of the ship, which earned him favor with his captain and crew, whose work was made marginally easier. Any engineering problems on the ship were also his domain. His reason for the life of the sea was to discover artefacts. Sailors traverse great destinations across the land, and port cities are fountains of information. Unfortunately, his old apprentice rival had his money in more pockets than even the trade winds could reach, and every opportunity Kalkheus discovered was a bust - for him. Elqarim was once again one-upping Kalkheus, this time with his magical discoveries.Determined to show his nemesis up, Kalkheus decided he needed to do away with his familiar sailor life and get his hands dirty if he was going to harness unknown magic and powerful objects to expand his craft, receive recognition and unravel mysteries known to no others. He left the ship behind, much to the disappointment of the crew. He had grown rather close to them, especially his captain and while there was regret in leaving, he knew his desire to discover and his pride would not let him stay.

Gordito grew up in the Central Valley.  His parents had managed to buy a little house in town, with steady work supervising a couple of square miles of orchard and working in a restaurant.  Their ambition was to get their kids, Gordito and his younger sister, to attend college.Gordito fulfilled that dream.  He'd become fascinated by Japan in high school, and found the language easier than his teachers expected for someone raised on Spanish and English.  His teacher guided him to a language scholarship at San Francisco State instead of track at Fresno; suggesting he might become a translator.  The big city brought aikido and kung fu and comparative linguistics; and running up steep hills late at night, stopping to try to help a few of the people left behind on the street by the economic disruption of technocracy.  He had a foreign exchange trip to Japan in his senior year, the first one in his family to go abroad, and his aikido teacher Kenji suggested he stop by a particular monastery in the mountains outside Kyoto where "they might let you do their training".At the monastery, they didn't know what to do with the gaijin who didn't have an accent and who didn't want to leave.  Eventually a young-looking master in an old-looking robe said he could stay - if he could run the monastery's marathon meditation course around the mountain at night.  That's when things got weird.  He ran that course in half of the time he'd ever run that far before, in the dark, without ever misstepping.  It was as if he could see the path through his feet, and skip every other step.  Then the master came, and told him of the Akhasic fellowship and who he had been."A fellow's avatar passes from themselves to another after they die, as for all but the nonreturners."  She gestured him through the ritualistic pouring of the tea.  "Some who have awakened into the Akhasic or other traditions in a past life we find when they are children.  Some we do not find for many lifetimes.  You were Hayato in your last life.  Kenji thought you were one of us, and that you might awaken here."He stayed there a while, to the mixed disappointment of his professors and his parents when he missed graduation.  But eventually, he came back to San Francisco.  Even as he learned Akhasic discipline, right perception, right mindfulness, and how martial arts could be refined into the Way; he realized that he could not let go of the street - he was not a nonreturner yet.  He bunked at Kenji's dojo, helping to hide it and its students from the Technocracy, and dropped the prospect of translating for corporations in favor of training as a paramedic.If the Technocracy could not be stopped in this lifetime, some if its harm could be limited by saving those harmed by it.  And perhaps they would step towards enlightenment, and realize their own liberation.

She was found as an infant in a patch of clover by a human family. Her dead mother was covering her the best she could. This was during a period of unrest between humans and orcs, and it is thought that the mother was escaping a routing party that was hunting an orc village.The humans took Clover home and raised her more or less as their own. She was raised and taught alongside their own daughter, and trained to be a companion and body guard to the daughter, but she was treated like a family member for the most part. When she was a teenager she ran an errand for the family to another town. During her absence a band of raiders killed her adoptive family. Her neighbors were not convinced that she was innocent, so she could not stay to find out who was the culprits, but she swore that she would do what she could to protect other families. This is how she became a Vengeance Paladin.

Bluebell was the daughter of a successful weaver family. She had trained up in the business with every intention of remaining in the family business. One day when she was out collecting herbs and flowers used to create the dyes for the business needed, she happened upon a Fey of some sort, she knew nothing of such things. This Fey was able to take advantage of her innocence to strike up a bargain with her. When she was finally released and allowed to head home she realized what she had done. She did not know what would happen to her or what she might be convinced to do now, so fearing for the lives of her family she went home and pretended all was well until she could pack up some supplies and sneak out of the house. And so she started off to seek her fortunes, or to find help, or to become rich and powerful, or to learn her limitations. Whichever.

Rhogar had few ambitions beyond pursuing an uneventful, scholarly life before he began to manifest scorcerous abilities. Feeling amongst his clan were mixed regarding Rhogar's abilities and Rhogar retired to a life of seclusion and study in an attempt to understand and master his new abilities.Despite learning much, Rhogar eventually realised that not all his answers could be found though scholarship or contemplation.Rhogar joined the expedition after recalling his childhood curiosity over the legends of this lost city.

Verguldi was formerly a sailor on a Skovlan merchant naval vessel, the Emmenhorn. On a delivery carrying gold to Ilysia in Akoros, took aboard the privateer Sevario Casta as a passenger. Late one night during the voyage, a huge explosion ripped through the ship apparently killing all aboard but Verguldi. He managed to get into a life raft, grabbing a few supplies and fishing gear to improve his meagre chance of survival.As he escaped the sinking wreckage, Verguldi caught sight of a large military ship far away. It continued on its way though it must surely have seen the smoking wreckage. As he began to row, Verguldi saw the ships mascot, a weasel called Fretten, swimming from the wreckage. He scooped it up and carried it with him in the life raft, eventually keeping it as a pet. After many days at sea, with nothing to keep him alive but the strange and frequently toxic fish and plant life he pulled from the Void Sea and none to keep him sane but Fretten and his old harmonica, Verguldi arrived at Doskvol, but was turned away from the shipping gates. Almost dead, he was hauled out of the ocean and cared for by the Lighthouse Keeper, Celene Langor. With no home or money and barely any belongings, Verguldi soon fell into a life of crime among the docks using his skills learned manning ships and protecting them from pirates and other dangers.

Raised by a wealthy family in the lands of Terkea (somewhat similar to Greece/Ottoman empire, mediterranean peninsula, known for commerce and ancient studies), he started studying as cleric of Egeo, god of seas, and soon departed as on board cleric for various ships. One day he happened to get tricked and ended up in a slavist ship, the crew mutinied and soon after a storm caught them. When he was drowning he got a vision from his God and managed to shore alive with his bless. He didn't know anything yet, but soon found adventurers to buy as escorters and find out the truth about a magical and powerful scepter, apparently made out of void and a golden prison written in scriptures...
Sailor

Abandoned by his tribe as a child for reasons he still does not know, Dagg nearly died alone in the mountains, before being found by gnome scoundral and member of the thieves guild, Antonio Tygorr who took him in as his own sons and tought him the ways of stealth and extortion.

I grew up in Silvanus, the son of Esvele and Anton Buckley. I never knew my father, since he died during childbirth of an unrelated heart attack.I always had a love for the arts; dabbling in poetry, painting and ballet before falling in love with the art of mime. My tutor was a halfling named Cedric Tallbottom. I learned from him through my late teens until, at the age of 23, I was discovered by a theatre owner named Jhessail Ramondo. She allowed me to perform at her theatre for free, though we split the profits. The turnout and crowd reception amazed me and from that moment I devoted myself fully to my art. I vowed to never leave character and to entertain people wherever I went.After the show I noticed a young scruffy looking man (Maxime El Cuervo) steal a coin purse from a well-dressed old lady. To my surprise he then came to speak to me, apparently a big fan. I motioned for him to return the purse but did not tell anyone of the crime. We bonded over that moment and Maxime became a regular at my shows. He would always bring friends along with him so I offered him employment as my promoter.Two years later I left for Neverwinter to perfect my art, since I had learned everything Cedric could teach me and wanted the challenge of a new crowd. Maxime came with me.After 13 years Maxime was tasked by Talos to help slay a dragon. I trained in combat at his temple but arrived too late to help.

Lillian grew up in a town with her family. Her father a blacksmith and her mother a revered member of the towns guard. She also had a sister a few years younger than her, Abby. Lillian and Abby were very close. They did everything together growing up including training with their mother to defend themselves and a bit of blacksmithing with their father.As they grew older they both made other friends. They still shared their bond but didn't see each other as much. Lillian grew close with two of her friends, Elaine a human girl and Tristan a half elf boy. She treated them like she would her sister. Abbys friends seemed strange and Lillian saw her less and less. One day Lillian was invited to the local tavern with her friends. She told them she would be there later as she needed to help her dad with some smithing. While outside on a break from her work she heard screams coming from the tavern. She ran over as fast as she could. She entered the tavern and it was pitch black, suddenly she is tackled and pinned against a wall. It's her sister, but she wasn't the same. Abby was about to kill her but at the last moment released her and ran away. Lillian collapsed to the ground only to realize everyone in the tavern was dead and blood leaked everywhere. Among the dead was Elaine and Tristan still wearing the jewellery Lillian once made them.The town mourned the dead including lillian's friends. She didn't have the heart to tell her parents that it was Abby. Instead they thought bandits has done it and that Abby had been kidnapped and killed else where. Lillian was destroyed. She had lost her best friends as well as her sister. She decided to join the town guard along with her mother and train in combat. She trained for roughly a year or so every single day never forgetting what happened. In her line of work she was tasked a few times with catching a thief or bandit but in her anguish would often kill the person she was hunting. During this time she would read in the library to find out more about what her sister had become. She learnt of vampires but also learnt about holy knights who swore a oath of vengeance. After a year of training and working for the guard she decided to swear such an oath to kill her sister and whoever made her what she became. With all her training and study she was ready to begin her journey. She told her parents she was leaving to travel and sell her jewellery but the real reason was far more sinister.
Rono was once engaged to a princess, but through certain events he ended up very, very far away from her. He has been trying to get home since then and searches for clues on how to get back there.

The Valon family hails back generations as one of the most loyal families to the Crown. The personal bodyguards of the Royal family were drawn from six houses, the Valon among them. These guards were trained in the powerful art of bladesinging, and forbidden from letting it be revealed to anyone outside their families. When the Crown was succeeded by the Theocracy, the Royal Guard was disbanded. Generations have now passed, but the Valon family has trained the eldest child of each generation in secret to carry on the tradition. Arkas is the latest in this line. He wishes to put his skills to use, rather than have them waste away in seclusion, and has ventured out in search of adventure.

As a son of a minor noble family in Ched Nasad I was apprenticed to a stuffy old wizard, Dresmorlin of House Melarn, at a very young age. There I met Kiara, the 5th daughter of a minor priestess of House Melarn and half a year younger than me and we became fast friends immediately, even though she was a female of a more noble house. She, however, had no interest in becoming a priestess of Lolth and was more interested in swordplay and war magic and so we met in the practice yard and the library and our friendship grew.  Although I am of above average intelligence, very curious and not untalented I lacked the focus and commitment to make it as a wizard and this and my low birth caused my master to neglect and mistreat me.  Over the years I learned the basics of magic, delved deeply into history and honed my reasoning and deduction skills. My friendship with Kiara slowly grew into love, a rare thing for our people and thus we kept it a secret.  One day, about a month ago, I found an ancient book of summoning rituals in the wizard's library and decided to try them out. The first ritual summoned a quasit, which proceeded to wreck the alchemy lab and left behind a small brass orb etched with strange symbols. Encouraged, I decided to try the ritual on the loose leaf at the back with the mad scribbles in the margin. When at first nothing happened, I was disappointed, but I suddenly felt an alien presence pressing on my mind and a voice told me that if I could survive the nightmares, I would be allowed to live.  In these nightmares I was constantly stalked by something huge slithering just outside my peripheral vision. I learned the two spells and one cantrip that I know, the Dissonant Whispers spell is just a reflection of my own experience and the Armour of Agathys spell and the Chill Touch cantrip come from inscriptions I came across in my dreams: the Armour of Agathys I found inscribed into the a cuirass, Chill Touch into the palm of a withered hand. Eldritch Blast was scribbled into the margin of the paper with the ritual that summoned my patron.  That night I packed my things, including the book and the loose parchment, said goodbye to Kiara and left for the surface world and adventure. My goals, that I hope to achieve through these adventures, are to learn who my patron is, and with my new found power, to gather riches, knowledge (especially of the forbidden and forgotten sort) and to gain enough power and experience to avenge myself on my former master.

I come from the far northern mountains, specifically a village of humans near a dwarven mine. I was orphaned when I was five years old, when my village was attacked by goblins, bugbears and hobgoblins.  I was captured and lived in slavery among the goblinoids for seven years. I managed to escape when I stole back my father's knife, that he had given to me just as the goblins attacked our village to defend myself with and that a goblin had taken at my capture. I used it to slit my jailer's throat and steal the keys and then slit a few more goblin throats in my rage while escaping.  I have since then lived on my own in the wild, learning to hunt, fish, keep warm, not get lost and defend myself. I have been killing goblinoids if I come across them and have thus picked up a little money and a bit of equipment.  My temper had manifested quite early in my life. Even before the goblin attack I was know as wilful and wild and both my parents had terrible tempers - they both killed large numbers of goblins and even bugbears, and my father even took down two hobgoblins all on his own.  My captors soon found out about my rages and after whipping and starving didn't cure me of it, they decided to use me for their entertainment: I was forced to fight in the pits. This, however, helped me with my escape since it gave me much training in fighting, both against animals and humanoids (I was a regular training exercise for young goblins).  Recently, the horde of goblinoids that destroyed my village have started expanding the territory they control southwards, driving people and beasts before them. I have thus been forced to move south, into more civilised lands.  I have since decided that maybe I can find some other people to help me deal with this threat and hope to find them in these more settled areas.
He's a cultist trying to collect the scattered bones of his deceased mentor so he can bury them. Said bones were scattered by his pet dog Gus while his back was turned.

Eaghan Holt was born in the year 4361 FR, when the Bloodbone warband started invading Beleroth. His father was a ranger who lived near the eastern border with his family to keep eyes on the movements of the Orcs. As the warband started pushing further and further west, they were forced to move west as well. When Eaghan was old enough (about 10 probably) his father started teaching him how to handle a bow, and how to survive in the wilderness (basically how to be a ranger like his father). As he grew older and learned more he started joining his father in his expeditions.As the warband pushed further and further they eventually wound up in the capital, where they stayed for as long as possible while Aldyn continued to teach Eaghan. Eventually, near the end of the siege Moreen convinced them to flee from the capital before it was too late, for the sake of Eoin who had been born about a year before. Eaghan was insistant on not leaving Beleroth behind however. His uncle Morris had told him of a resistance movement being formed by Lady Kathleen Hane and intended to follow his uncle in joining it. Much argueing ensued. Moreen wanted to go to the camps to ensure the safety of both her children. Aldyn admired Eaghan's spirit but placed his family's safety first. Eventually it was decided that Eaghan would go with Morris to join the resistance, while the rest of his family would go south to the dominion, to one of the camps.In the following years he was guided mostly by his uncle. While his father mostly taught him about stealth, archery and how to survive in the wilderness, Morris educated him in old ways to appease The Giver and request his magical aid (That works right? I'm imagining the components of spells corresponding to mini-rituals of sorts). Eaghan prefered raids at night, since his training and The Giver's magic gave him the advantage over the orcs in the darkness.While he was very devoted to the cause, he also grew impatient. He felt like no progress was being made, and was still bitter about the Dominion's lack of help in resisting the Warband. He reasoned that if they were to give their full support, and every able Belerothi rised up as well, they could beat the Warband. So he planned on leaving Beleroth (for now) and joining the High Shield. He would try to rise up the ranks and try to get the Dominion to invade Beleroth. After a discussion with his superiors, he left for the Dominion. [Would there be any kind of message they'd want him to pass along? I don't know how much contact there is between the resistance and the Dominion]He stopped by one of the northen tent camps where his family was supposed to be. He found that his parents were content to settle down, to his disappointment. He then headed to Fort Laham, to join the ranks of the High Shield. He did a few jobs in the area to prove his worth. One of these jobs was to escort a group of Turian pilgrims down south. [I imagine either they were brought to Laketown or he finished the mission and headed to Laketown for further orders, at which point he meets the party?]

Distant star was named after a shooting star that could be seen the night he was born. He showed above average intelligence and an eagerness to learn that got him selected by the mystics of the clan, most importantly his father, to be taught the mystic arts. His main mentor was his own father, Rock on the Mountain (Rock). He took to it well and showed particular interest in the disciplines related to manipulating other minds, mostly out of a kind of scholarly interest (although admittedly he doesn't mind messing with people in non-harmful ways).He started his Journey shortly after he finished his mystic training, and left for the mainland not too sad for leaving his home behind, but rather excited for what the Dominion has to offer.After he landed in Portsmouth he travelled through the land, stopping at practically every tavern he came across to tell stories from his clan and listening to tales from strangers he met, and passing on their stories to others. He wrote down every story, every tidbit of knowledge and lore, personal journal entries recording his journey and everything else he found interesting in a large tome (book of lore from scholar's pack). His idea is that when it is full he will return to his clan with it to share it's contents.He was also very interested in the history of this land, and thus visited many libraries and spend time talking to scholars. This behavior attracted the attention of an agent of The Red Cloaks, a Turian human named Brynstan, who approached Star under the guise of a scholar interested in helping his research in the Dominion's history. They got talking, and eventually the scholar revealed himself to be an agent of The Red Cloaks and offered Star a position in the faction as a Watcher. From what he had learned about the history of the continent and the goals of the Red Cloaks, he felt their cause was just and gladly joined.When he visited Dorwine he also met Marlyn on his way out of the city. After talking and sharing stories (real and fake ones) he remembered some messages offering a job to adventurers and passed it on to Marlyn, who indicated that he was interested in taking it and invited Star to join him in that. Star was not very interested in the job itself, but he did take a liking to this half-elf and decided that he might meet more interesting people on this job, and so he traveled with Marlyn to the Naked Hero.
Raised by wolves and is extremely prejudiced against cities in general and city folk he hasn't gotten to know. Turns into a lion, tiger, or bear to preserve cognitive dissonance.

Nevy was in an adventuring party many, many years ago. The party seeked to enter the Warlock's Crypt to defeat Larloch, find treasure and attain glory.  With her, she had an inherited sentient sword that would for one time, save the sword's wielder from certain death by switching the souls of the wielder and the weapon, breaking afterwards ( if that makes sense ). It is the reason why she survived the initial encounter with Larloch. Her whole adventuring party was either killed or horribly cursed, including her. She, and her whole lineage, was cursed to start decaying rapidly. To prevent the death of her ancestors and herself, she made a deal with Larloch. She would free her relatives of the curse, removing all effects it had had on them. But she herself retained the effects of the curse. Although she isn't decaying anymore, her body is visibly half-rotten, she reeks of death and suffers from malnutrition. Larloch, as a part of the deal, has granted her enough immortality to keep her alive, so she can go around the Realms and do odd jobs for him. Nevy never knows why she is doing the jobs, all she knows that it is what she must do to stay alive. Nevy herself seeks revenge on Larloch, for effectively killing all of her friends and relatives , and cursing her( although some relatives and members of the adventuring party remain, she does not know their location).

Growing up the only half-orc in a small rural town was rough. His mother didn't survive childbirth and so was raised in a church in a high mountain pass, his attention was always drawn by airships passing through, and dreams of an escape. Leaving to strike out on his own as early as he could he made a living for most of his life as an airship sailor, and occasionally a pirate. A single storm visits him throughout his life, marking every major event or turning point in it. Lately latent divine magics he has had his whole life have been bubbling to the surface, along with nightmares of that storm. Are they connected? If so how?

His family was happy, once. His parents ran a small shop on the outskirts of the city, and Ty grew up there with his brother Sven. One day, Sven was brutally cut down in the course of some gang violence. His parents were never the same again.They could not accept that their darling boy could be killed so senselessly. They mourned, and grieved, and wailed to the gods to right this grievous wrong; no answer came to them. So they sought out diviners and fortune tellers and mystics who all promised to contact their lost child; no answer. So they used all of their money, sold the shop, went into debt with all the wrong people to seek out clerics to bring him back; the rituals all failed. So they turned to darker paths, and sought to pull their son from the depths of the afterlife through strange and unknown magics; and one goddess took note.The Raven Queen does not like necromancy. She does not like those who try to cheat death, or pervert the course of life. Ty never saw his parents again. The Raven Queen does not like necromancy, but she is not a cruel goddess. Ty was now alone, and so the Raven Queen sent him a guardian to keep him on the straight and narrow: a small raven called Allie.With the strength his new ally gave him Ty grew strong living on the streets; he did what he needed to survive, but did his best not to let the Raven Queen's kindness go unnoticed. He was eventually placed into an orphanage where he made friends and found purpose working with an old gnomish chef named Faetra. She taught him everything she knew and gave him a cookbook of his own, one that he keeps with him to this very day. Life was good, for a while.But all good things come to an end. The city of Bubastis was beset by the Chaos Horde, and the orphanage was destroyed. Ty, his friends, and a few of the younger orphans managed to escape the devastation, but the city is not the same. Gangs of scavengers and goblins roam the streets, and small communities have grown like mold in the dark places.Ty and the others have found a town house to hole up in, and have built a small community for themselves. They have a garden and some chickens, but it is not enough to feed them all. Sometimes Ty has to go out and get meat from... other sources. Sabriel can't even eat regular food any more, and needs a special diet that doesn't bear thinking about. His old cookbook is still always on his person, but now its pages have annotations and incantations scribbled in the margins. Ty is pretty sure he didn't write all of them, but who else could have?In recent days his faith has been tested. The church of the Raven Queen has been re-opened after the attack, but the new priest is not who he seems to be. His faith is weak, and his desire for followers is strong. Ty has also been courted by a patron from Below, though his faith in his goddess has not yet been shaken. He just needs to hold everyone together. He can't lose another family...

As an infant he was collected out of the anthropological zoo collection of the largest and most prestigious institution of learning, by an anthropologist looking to discern whether or not the evilness of goblins was innate or taught. Raised by a human academic in an academy surrounded by learning and wizards was an amazing experience, and to always have it held at arms length from you because you're a goblin is heartbreaking. Never being allowed to learn arcane magic, a major turning point for Scrimmick was a field expedition where they came into contact with an old druid, a gnome, who took to them. Having been shown a thing or two, upon getting back to the academy they tore through every book they could find with information on druidic magic, and signed up for every field expedition they could, eventually getting a proper grasp of druidic magic and striking out on their own.
Found in woods as child, raised by human Monk master in secluded village, one day the Master disappears...

He has amnesia, cannot remember his past. He has certain items on his person which may be from his past. He has interpreted them to signify that he has some kind of noble past (others are skeptical of this theory though).

This genderqueer elf from Barovia was a victim of the vampiric baron of that land, a sort of Mina Harker in League of Extraordinary Gentelman by way way of backstory.  They'd been built for a Ravenloft one-shot & then I had to leave early so the story had always been that I decided to flee & live...right into a Temple of Elemental Evil campaign.  The party was made up of 4/5th rogues & 4/5th elves, so we found all the secret doors & just lived in the walls of the Temple for most of the campaign.  I ended up befriending the myconids & slimes of the temple, through various plot reasons & stupid dice rolls, & had a habit of defacing Zuggtmoy's icons-- thrones, idoles, sigils-- with my name.  Like bad tagger.  I'd also picked up, over the course of Adventuring, the ability to read minds, through a magical amulet from a man called Darkstrider.  All this combined at the Golden Throne of the Temple, which puts you in theophany with Zuggtmoy...where, with her stolen children & her defaced arcana, & my skills at mind-manupulation...& three successful "save or die" rolls, & an epic d% roll...I stole the divine portfolio of "Queen of Slimes & Fungi" from her, leaving her still a demon lord, but without her pilfered divine mantle...which transfered to me, as Saint of Slimes & Fungi, at the campaign's end.

A siamese twin, Len Rago each chose to take half of their given name. Rago is a fighter whose body is fully formed and strong, but he is slow of mind. His brother Ben grows out of his shoulders but his body is only a head, one fully formed arm, and a hand and forearm. Ben is a Wizard and the brains of the operation. When wearing a cloak or seated at a bar - they are often mistaken to be two men huddled together for warmth.

In the time of his birth to the Brightfern family in a village not far from Neverwinter. Ander surprised his parents with his celestial heritage. Calling the local priest, he proclaim this a sign of prosperity from ander's fate was touched by the morninglord itself. Not a week later, clerics from the temple of Lathandar in Neverwinter proclaimed that when the child will reach the age of 5 that he should be brought and be trained in the scriptures of the morninglord. The Brightfern knew that their son's fate can not be averted. So they decided that in the little time they have with him, they will give him memories for a life time. So among his parents, older brother and older sister, Ander's first 5 years of life were of kindness.When the time has come, the priests took Ander to the cloister to learn. But before leaving, he smiled to his parents that he will remember and will return to visit.At the cloister, the life were austere but fair. It was different kindness that Ander experienced there. Not of family, but of the sun shining on all lives. Learning the best of his ability ander proven himself wise, although sometimes missing classes to hear bards tell stories of heroes and adventures.So in the day that he received his amulet and vestments, Ander first thing volunteered to the lords alliance to bring forth light among the people. And the second thing was to visit his family. There he met with the same love he remembered from childhood and that in return strengthen his resolve to protect this feeling and other like that.He knew that in ensuring the survival of civilization's light, he would be able to repay this kindness.

Aodhnait was born in the Underdark to a family of drow nobles. When she was just a baby, her father took the unearthing of a mysterious runestone to be a symbol of the end times. He renounced his title and devoted his life and lands to the founding of a doomsday cult. The cult awaits a giant worm which will swallow the earth, destroying the surface realms. They hope to survive, deep in the Underdark, as all surface races perish. As part of prepping for the worm's arrival, the family's lands were converted into a large scale mushroom farm. The cult grow, process, can, and store emergency rations for later use. Unknown to her husband, Aodhnait's mother runs a successful side business selling the cult's surplus of dried mushrooms and mushroom jams in the surface realms. She doesn't understand that the mushrooms are highly toxic to the surface races and her goods are used as potent poisons.Aodhnait accompanied her mother on trips to the surface from a young age, visiting small settlements where her mother would trade. Seeing the beauty of these places, Aodhnait vowed to explore as much of the surface as she could before the coming of the great worm. She followed in the footsteps of her elder half-brother (her mother's son from a previous marriage, missing and very dead), learning music and song so that she might record the ways of the doomed surface cultures in ballads. When she came of age at 110, she was ready for adventure. Aodhnait's father, desperate for his only child to stay with him, offered her an arranged marriage and a key role in the cult. Aodhnait's mother, fearing the death of her daughter's dream, offered her a beautiful lyre made from the young would-be groom's skull, and a fat sack of mushroom money to get by in surface society. Aodhnait accepted her mother's gifts and travelled alone to the surface. Naive and eager for new experiences, she was immediately attacked by the first person she met, robbed blind, and abandoned in a forest to die. Rescued by the party, she offered them use of her bardic skills in exchange for their guidance and protection, and there the game began.
After an affair with a high ranking dwarf, they were exiled from their homeland. They spent the follwing years travelling the country and brewing lemon vodka to make ends meet.

As a young boy Calloway was whisked away by a clandestine clan of bio-engineers and given the finest physical enhancements of his age. After he escaped Calloway found himself adrift in an uncaring world and so took up questing as a means of satisfying his wander lust

Ivan grew up in Neverwinter, a large city. He had always been fascinated with watching the stars as a child, and so he was extremely excited when he won the right to go to the royal academy to study astronomy.
