Ivan spent several years there, learning much and earning the fantasy equivalent of a bachelors degree. He attempted to earn his masters, but it grew to be too much for him, so he dropped out. Ivan was traveling along an icy road when he came upon an injured Druid on the side of the road. Ivan helped the woman back to health. Sensing Ivan's potential, she began to teach him the mystic ways of the Druid. Ivan picked up the ability to cast spells, and a penchant for doing such hallucinogens as mushrooms. Ivan kept working on a tome about the stars, hoping to one day return to the university and finish his degree. He eventually left his master to a cave of his own, and began looking for opportunities to out his newfound abilities to the test.

Can no longer tell the difference between cooked meat and small children Kansif:Kansif, though not the biggest, was one of the roughest and toughest orcs of her tribe. There was nothing she couldn't she.  She always got in on the crazy bets that often ended with her bloodied or . " 1 gold you won't wrestle that bugbear." "1 gold says I can sit on that cactus longer than you." "one Gold you won't ride this catapult." That last one is what got her in this last predicament. No body expected her to fly so high. Nobody thought about the fact that she only weighed  a fraction of the normal ammunition. It threw her so high, she never came back down.Fortunetly for her she flew so high she only fell a few feet onto the edge of a massive island that was floating in the sky. While exploring the island she came upon a Laboratory. Seeing as it was getting late, she decided to find a place in there to sleep.  While in there she saw many things that she did not recognize. all kinds of trinkets and gadgets she had never seen before. She also saw a variety of weapons she recognized, but seemed a little... different than they usually do. She found a pair of throwing axes that she thought looked cool. While she continued to explore the facility she eventually found what looked like 3 small metallic huts that had connecting glass chimneys for some reason. the middle hut was closed so Kansif figured it must be occupied. In her excitement of finding a place to sleep she accidentally clasped the two throwing axes together which caused them seemingly fuse together into one large battleaxe. Startled by this she drops the axe and stumbles back. Thinking the ax is cursed she leave it there end enters the hut on the left.  As soon as she does the hut's doot automatically shuts behind her. She is troubled by the fact that she tries to find a way to open the hut but she can't seem to figure out how. Being extremely tired she decides she will figure it out when she wakes up. When she is just about to fall asleep she hear's the sound of something scraping against the floor out side quickly followed by someone shouting "Shit!" she then hears the sound of something large hitting the ground followed by what sounds like the other door closing and there was a great big flash. Everything just changed. Her molecules got all rearranged. When she first woke up she noticed she didn't feel nearly as large as she was before. the second thing she noticed was that this new body of hers didn't respond to her and seemed to move on it's own. This freaked her out trying in vain to control her own body which seemed to be looking around for something. Then she said not of her own volition and in an unfamiliar voice "hello? who's there? I can't see you. wait... is that my voice?"...Lorraine Reilly:As a competitive Dungeons and Dragons player she knows every book inside and out. She takes pride in playing the strictly by the rules. Her many characters were carefully crafted to fulfill the specific roles they were made to fill. Anyone using "home-brew" material obviously don't know the joy of playing the game in it's purist form.One day she woke up in a strange place. Not sure what was going on she took out her cell phone and found she had no signal. Looking around she realized she was in some sort of lab. While exploring the lab trying to figure out what was going on, she came upon a weird machine that had 3, what looked like, small rooms. All but the right most room were closed.  Not sure what to think of this Sci-fi contraption she decided to take a closer look. Because she was so taken aback by this machine, she failed to notice the large battleaxe that was laying on the ground. Because of this, she tripped and fell into the room on the  right. As soon as she was in the room, the door shut behind her and there was a great big flash. Everything just changed. Her molecules got all rearranged When she first woke up she realized everything part of her body felt swollen, not hurt, just bigger and heavier than she remembered. As she gathered herself she thought  "wait what am I wearing? and who is that freaking out? maybe I should say something." She decided to call out to the the person who seemed to be paralized "hello? who's there? I can't see you." As she said this she realized that her voice didn't sound like her own. "wait... is that my voice?"Lorraine-Kansif Reilly :Eventually they both realized  that they had been fused together.  after Lorraine finishes freaking out about her new appearance and realizes she eventually realizes she is in a D&D world and is appalled  when she realizes that she is in some shitty home-brew setting or else all this technology would not be here.  who needs Synths mucking up her fanticy games anyways? Kansif things she is crazy. The decide to try and reverse the fusion, but the device that fused them together seems to be able to only fuse things. realizing this but not her own strength, Lorraine accidentally breaks the machine. She eventually picks up the Battleaxe that Kansif kept calling cursed and figured out how it worked. Lorraine and Kansif did not get along at first, but eventually learned to like each other after spending 5 years literally together stuck on this island with only the dredge there to talk to. and by talk I mean kill. and they are now best friends and get along famously. They decided if they ever made it back to society they would go by "Lorif" During one of their endeavors they found a bracelet that granted them the power of time travel. They could only use it to revert themselves back to as they were a few seconds ago while everything else seemed to view it as them teleporting and/or healing. This got them out of a lot of tight jams seeing as they did not have natural healing abilities, and the time jumps made running away a bit easier for them, though they could only use the bracelets once every minute.One day Lorif found what appeared to be a solid cloud. They eventually were able to figure out that it was actually a piece of technology that you could fly on by standing on it and using your feet to direct it. Wanting to test fly it they headed outside. and while they are doing so they realize they could get off Laputa and go to the main land. Though, even with the dredge, the island had become their home over the past year and they weren't sure if they were ready to leave. As soon as they decided they wanted to stay on Laputa a gust of wind knocked them off of the cloud which drifted vaugly downward as they plummeted.What will Lorif do in this situation? will they figure a way out of this? will they be crushed by the ground below?Find out what happens to them on the next episode of Dragon Ball Z!

Illegitimate offspring of Human mother and elf father after one night fling. Mother never saw the father again.Always met with distain from motherNever given a name. grew up only ever being called  "boy" or "it" or "the half breed" or "that thing"Was always looked down upon for not being human enoughOnly thing that brought him joy was dancingHe was a sad childHis only friends growing up were the instruments he stole from the local music shop.Orphaned at the early age of 33 when mother died. This made him even sadderAt 66 he realized he had magic potential and found he could channel it with his instrument. Became great at casting a minor Illusion in cities to hide his pointed ears to hide the fact that he is half-elfEventually he became so good at it he is now able to completely change what he looks like if he needs to with his magic.Eventually he figured out how to manipulate this change in look to walk around as an independent image that he can manipulate freely.Because of his rough past, he doesn't like getting close to people, strangers in particularFell in with a small time half breed thieving group who were mostly half orcs and half elves where he learned to speak orc.Because of his musical and magical talents everyone started calling him "Bard"This group and upgrade in name made him slightly less sadHe was still a bit of an outsider in the group because of his tendency to only play songs in minor keys and temper towards people that tried to make him less sad through pep talks.the hole not liking to get close to people thing didn't help either when they were supposed to be thievesto get around the last issue he developed a way to conjure a magic hand that he used to rope people from afar. he eventually got good enough at making these temporary magic constructs that he can now summon an invisible minion that can do steel for him.he figured out that by using both his image and servant spells he could make an actual physical human.he did this by having the construct get caught stealing in a shop he was in and taking what he wanted when the owner chased after the construct.Some of the half-breeds were not able to speak common so he developed a spell that translated other languages into a form he could understand.This group is also where he learned how to use a rapier incase the bard ever needed to defend himself and his charming good looks didn't.The group tended to get into fights with other small groups of bandits,  and groups of people who hated them for being half breeds(and/or a batched theft). The group didn't have anyone skilled on healing, so Bard figured out a way to at least lightly heal his comrades. These were the best years of this sad bards life.Once when in a town he heard that a group of adventurers that had 2 dwarf brothers in it were hired to take out our group. This is the saddest point in Bard's life. the only thing that brought him any joy was dancing until a powerful witch cursed him, after he upset her, to no longer be able to dance.He is currently working on a way to apply the invisibility of his humanoid construct spell with his disguise spell to be able to make himself invisible. as well as He caries with him 2 sheets of paper with an unfinished song on them.This song was being written by one of his companions before she was killed.He is also working on a way to conjure knives out of thin air.

Abandoned as a baby in an orphanage, Nev spent 12 years there bullied for being too different, and because of that he ran away, spending the next 2 years living in the streets, until one day Gavrain Dagus, a human Wizard of great influence and power, took him in as his apprentice and son. After a few years of study of the magical arts, an experiment goes wrong, opening a rift between dimensions throwing Nev into the Feywild and also causing his magic to go all out of wack, whilst trying to survive in this realm Nev encounters an ancient diary which belonged to a Necromancer, with 7 pages missing, and kept it for himself so he may translate it and protect it's secrets from the wrong hands and use them for good. After 5 years surviving in this realm, he mystically finds himself back in the material plane, but, 20 years in the future instead of 5. After learning his adoptive Father had also disappeared, Nev makes it his mission to locate his father, dead or alive. And also locate the 7 missing pages of the Ancient diary.
He was exiled from his homeland for treason committed by his father. It was later found out his father was framed.

Character's name: Veronika Corvus Aveline Thana de'Valdis The Second of The Shadowfell (Vi)
Character's backstory: The de'Valis family has long been rumoured to be descendants of The Raven Queen. With their dark eyes, pale skin and brooding demeanour it was either that or vampires. However the de'Valis are an ancient clan who are almost fanatically obsessed with escaping their dark origins, the ancient de'Valis joining with Pelor, God of Life and Summer in an attempt to burn away the darkness of their past. For centuries, it seemed to work, with Veronika's mother, Merletta, giving birth to Victor, Francis and Theon, Veronika's brothers without issue. However, that all changed on Veronika's 1st name day, during the de'Valis ritual of atonement. Designed to cleanse the child's soul and bind it to Pelor, a raven perched on her crib, interrupting the ritual and turning a strand of her golden hair black, marking her as under The Raven Queen's protection. The Elders, fearing for the child, locked her away and rigidly trained her in the healing arts, hoping it's light would free her soul from The Raven's grasp. However, Veronika, seeing her brothers' freedom, grew bitter and resentful towards those she saw as honouring their title over family.She was freed, however, on her 18th name day, when the ritual was attempted again. This time, The Raven Queen herself descended, shaming the family for dishonouring their blood, forcing her into a life she wasn't destined to lead. The family tried to plead their love for Veronika, saying that they were only trying to keep her from the darkness and pain of the world, but her bitterness wouldn't allow her to heed their words and she followed her ancestor to Letherna within The Shadowfell, a realm of Darkness and Shadow. Finally inheriting her true powers, but ignorant, The Raven Queen soul-bound Veronika to the soul of an adventurer in a far flung realm of the Primaterial Plane, the dashing Elven rogue, Vy'dan Vexalis, allowing them to converse across the cosmos. Through him, Veronika learnt the combat of darkness, to use stealth and shadow to destroy the Undead that stood as an affront to both The Raven Queen and Pelor. Tragedy struck when Vy'dan was felled by a great necromancer and raised as a ghoul. The stress of the broken connection and the sorrow at her friend's loss, both physically and spiritually, had a profound effect on Veronika. Unable to avenge him, or release him from his torment, she fell to the Sorrow of The Shadowfell, her golden hair fading to ash as the light and life were drained from her. In hopes of saving her life and restoring her light, The Raven Queen sent her back to the Material Plane and her family. However, upon returning to her temple, she found it abandoned, profaned with the symbols of Orcus, God of Undeath and enemy to The Raven Queen. Shamed by her callous dismissal of her family's love, Veronika vowed to find them, and avenge them if need be.

brought up poor in the inner spirenever knew her father, mother died when she was 14orphaned, trying to make a living and a home for herself, she grew to resent the wealthy merchants of the spire who dressed so warmly and never went hungryshe fell quite happily into piracy, taking by force what she had tried so hard to earn ‘fairly’over the course of a decade, she worked her way through the ranks on the wind dagger until she was made navigator. she was content, guiding her crew through the treacherous skies, and earning the respect and even affection of her captain, an older elf woman named aviv who was quick with a smile and quicker with a dagger; and her quartermaster, a gruff gnome woman named ebele whose enemies lived to underestimate her only oncethey took what they needed from merchant ships, plus a little more to fence for extra coin. nurit had a good, exciting life. she and her crew protected each other, and they were the closest thing to a family she had known for a long timeon a day like any other, ebele led the attack against a merchant ship like any other. nurit followed, cutting down crew in her way, until she had cut her way to a tall human woman in worn but well-cared-for plate mail, laying her hands on someone nurit had just mortally slashed. this was not a pampered merchant, indeed, this was a woman whose face told of kindness and whose armor told of hardship. however, she was between nurit and her goal of leaving this ship with the goods aboard, so they clashedthe armored woman was strong, but nurit was fast, and that slight advantage was enough to leave a breathless nurit holding her blade at the woman’s throat. the woman stilled, looked searchingly into nurit’s eyes, then smiled beatifically and pulled a pouch from her belt to drop onto the ship’s floor. feeling inexplicably overcome, nurit found her wits enough to cut the woman’s throat and, half in a daze, pushed her over the ship’s rail. she stared unseeing at the woman’s falling body until another of the merchant’s guard attacked, and she threw herself back into the melee. after ebele had secured the ship’s cargo, nurit nearly tripped, then saw that her boot had caught on the armored woman’s pouch, so she attached it to her own belt and returned to the wind daggerfor a week, she was too unsettled to look in the pouch. she barely slept, haunted by the woman’s calm smile just before her death. she eventually talked herself into it - it’s only a purse, what is she so afraid of - and discovered a bit of coin and a leatherbound journal. nurit read the journal of the woman she had killed and she was spellbound. her name was gideon, and she had been a paladin in the service of avandra. she traveled among and within the spires, healing people in exchange for a meal or hiring her sword to protect travellersnurit’s poor sleep worsened for weeks, and her focus and stamina suffered greatly. aviv and ebele expressed their concern, but she waved them off. she attended to her duties the best she could, but the crew had begun to look at her askancethe next time the wind dagger docked at the spire, nurit took up her pack, and gideon’s purse, and walked. she walked aimlessly around the spire, neither seeing nor caring where she was going. she found herself at an inn and realized how hungry she was - she must have been walking for hours. when the innkeep asked for her name, she answered ‘gideon,’ and she slept through the night for the first time in over a monthnow, she uses gideon as a surname and few if any know her as nurit. she has dedicated herself to avandra, and tries every day to do some small good to assuage her guilt over killing a good woman

Kidnapped from her tribe in South America, Ariché grew up as a slave on a plantation. When the plantation was sacked by a troupe of pirates, they freed the slaves and took 10 year old Ariché under their wings. She trained with the pirates, learned everything there was to know. But the captain's obsession with finding the legendary golden city drove some of the crew to mutiny. Ariché and other non-whites were sent over the plank. Now Ariché is all alone in the New World - and swore to find the treasure of legend, her father figure dreamed of.
A child, conceived during a dark ritual, Abres entire life is devoted to Socothbenoth, Lord of sin and pleasure.
Woke up with no memory in a tavern with a sealed letter from one of the princes of hell.

Eyrdway Demara's birth was the result of a whirlwind romance between his "teenage" wood elf mother, Haisa of house Demara in the grand city of Haynhold and Saxifrage Russell, a human Enchanter and diplomat from the Republic of Huly.  The scandalous affair and pregnancy wasn't able to be hidden by house Demara, due to Haisa being too indiscreet about both.After Eyrdway was born (on May 21st, of 487 AD) his mother was cast out of their house and married off to a "low-class" wood elf merchant, Thema Brimo, who was a rich member of the Alchemist's Guild.  Eyrdway grew up in comfort, with tales of elves from his mother and interest in the pursuit of knowledge from his step-father.As Saxifrage had need to visit the libraries of Arkanne with some regularity he would contact Haisa when he stayed in Haynhold, but only in secret.  The most Eyrdway ever knew was that Thema wasn't his birth father, but the topic was not discussed in the household further than that, despite Eyrdway's curiosity about his heritage.Eyrdway began an apprenticeship to an skilled alchemist friend of his father, Kashban Beatbrass, at the age of twelve.  By the age of 18, having become a skilled alchemist, he was imbued with his wild magic sorcerous powers when his master was working with a wizard named Yendri to experiment on a pot of paint from a set of Nolzur's Marvelous Pigments, only to have the work be destroyed in a magical explosion that killed them and grievously injured Eyrdway.  Unknown to Eyrdway at the time was that Carathros, a wizard rival of Yendri, had used a subtle enchantment on Kashban, which caused Kashban to unconsciously sabotage the experiment.While the resources of Eyrdway's family resources kept him from immediately dying from his injuries, he remained severely burned and in a near coma.  Thus Haisa used a scroll of Sending that Saxifrage had given her and, in secret, Saxifrage arranged for a cleric friend of his to volunteer his services for Eyrdway's benefit.  After the magical healing, it still took many months for Eyrdway to recover. He was left with a hand-sized burn scar over his heart.Half-way through his nineteenth year, strange events began to occur around him and he slowly realized that he was the cause, thanks to a pulsing that would occur in his scar when the events would happen.  By the time he was twenty, several wild magic surges had happened and few were dangerous enough that he sought out help from wizards in Haynhold.  Through their study and knowledge, he discovered his sorcerous nature and despite their misgivings (and with some "donations" from Thema) they quickly taught him enough to allow him to rein in his powers, or so he thought.Thinking that his problems were past him, Eyrdway tried to start an alchemist's shop in his twenty-second year. Sadly, in his twenty-fourth year, he found that his powers began manifesting without his ability to control them again.  The wizards refused to help him any more, as they did not want the possible side effects of wild magic to bring harm upon them.  Somewhat thankfully, Eyrdway realized that he could keep the wild magic manifestations at bay by casting his spells (but not his cantrips) regularly, upon actual targets.Thus, in his 24th year, he sold his alchemist's shop and turned to adventuring.  Eyrdway's first adventuring group consisted of Sharplin, a wood elf ranger; Amook, a wood elf druid; and Kalya, a half-elf paladin.  Their adventures took them underground, against various denizens of the Underdark that were causing issues for the villages and farms around Haynhold.  After a couple months of successful adventuring, their group (the Lithe Runners) were defeated by a drow ambush deep underground.  Eyrdway only escaped thanks to a potion of invisibility.Disheartened from loosing adventuring companions, Eyrdway wanted to take some time off from adventuring.  One of treasures that he had managed to escape with was a wizard's spellbook and something about it drew him too it.  Eyrdway discovered that, for reasons beyond his comprehension, his attempts to study the spells in the book helped keep his need to cast his spells daily at bay.  He attempted to pursue rigorous magical learning in Haynhold, but the wizards there were even more wary of a Wild Mage that had grown beyond his initial power and they would not help him at all.Eyrdway was not skilled enough to teach himself what he needed and his attempts to manipulate (and sometimes charm) people into helping him drew the ire of Carathros.  In his arrogance, Carathros revealed his place in Eyrdway's fate, but thanks to a wild surge, Eyrdway was able to escape his clutches.  Under pursuit by Carathros and fearing for his life Haisa was once again able to contact Saxifrage.  The powerful Enchanter teleported to Haynhold and, with Haisa revealing to Eyrdway that Saxifrage was his father, whisked Eyrdway away to the far-away city of Hinuedon.In Hinuedon, Saxifrage was able to trade in some favors, from his many years of diplomatic travel, to have Eyrdway learn the basics of ritual magic from wizards he knew there.  Saxifrage could only stay with Eyrdway for a few days, however. He left Eyrdway with enough resources to complete his education in ritual magic, along with a Bag of Holding that he no longer had a use for and then had to return to the Republic of Huly.With new-found abilities and tools, a new familiar, and a reference from one of Saxifrage's friends, Eyrdway decided to try his hand at adventuring again.  He was in a strange new land and would have to make his fortune there.  He also wanted to stay out of well-known areas, to keep the ire of Carathros at bay.

Tegwyn grew up in an idyllic wood elf village. Falsely accused of murdering her mentor, she was cast out from her tribe. The naive young elf turned to dark rituals and accidentally sold her soul to a creature from beyond the stars.

Killian was never welcome at home, and eventually was exiled to serve as an unnecessary diplomat with the largest Human city in the area. Having negative Charisma, this didn't last long, and Killian wound up joining the army as a clerk. He served for years there, being much better with numbers than people. Unfortunately the army got into a war, and his clerks were decimated during a sneak attack on their HQ. Killian lost the tip of his left ear, and now sports a grisly scar on the left side of his head, all from an axe blow that nearly killed him. Ever since that fight, Killian has had severe memory problems. He also keeps a hat or head wrap of some kind to cover his scar. Killian has no idea how long he wandered the world after his injury, but he recently was contacted by the Master of Time. He struck a deal with that entity and now travels the world, mostly healing people in his spare time. He hires himself out to nobles/the rich as a bodyguard using his mystical powers.

Thoren is the offspring of a human mother, hailing from Anganor and an elf father who hailed from the High Forest. He was raised until the age of 12 in the house of his maternal grandfather, Seaian Dryadson. Upon reaching maturity, he was sent to the High Forest to learn the ways of the Wood Elves and become a ranger like his elvish father.As the bastard child of a noble lady, Thoren spent his entire life as an outsider. Rejected by the human children of Anganor, Thoren spent his childhood training for his eventual return to the forest of his father. He spent much of his childhood in the wwoods on the borders of his grandfathers estate, honing his skills as an archer, and tracker. Thoren was raised, primarily, by Tyrus Vicelord, the head of his grandfathers Houseguard. As a Half-elf, Tyrus and his family, were the closest thing Thoren had to a family during his formative years. Though his grandfather allowed him to live on his estate, he was never treated as a member of the Dryadson clan, and upon reaching maturity, he took the name of the man he considered his true father.Upon reaching the High Forest, Thoren was faced with adapting to a society that was wary of the outside, as well as his heritage. His father, Jamros Woodsoul, was, during his life, the greatest Ranger in his clan. Being renowned both inside the High Forest, and among the humans of neighboring cities for his abilities. His renown as a tracker is what led him to meet Thoren’s mother, Lyanna Dryadson, while adventuring through Anganor. Their torrid, short-lived, affair produced little more than their bastard son. Jamros, though not married upon Thoren’s birth, refused to leave the High Forest to rear his son, striking an agreement with Lyanna’s father, instead, to take the boy when he reached maturity, thus ending any responsibility the Dryadson clan had for Thoren. Thoren met his father for the first time on the eve of his 13th birthday, when Jamros ventured to Anganor to fulfill his debt to the Dryadson clan, and return with his son to the village of Ethyreen, deep in the High Forest.Upon his arrival in Ehtyreen, Thoren was met with derision, most poignantly from his father’s wife, who cared no more for his mixed heritage than had his grandfather. Jamros’ other children, as full blooded Feywild, were always given favor over their bastard half-brother, causing Thoren to retreat even deeper in to the development of his skills. His half-brothers (Yennan, Thoros, and Traster) were destined to follow in the footsteps of their maternal grandfather, all three becoming Clerics of Melora. Jamros’ adventuring had left them, often, without a male influence other than their grandfather, and they had all sworn off their fathers occupation by the time of Thoren’s arrival (though none had reached maturity at the time). Though Thoren was not accepted by his wife, or the two eldest boys Yennan and Thoros, his youngest half-brother Traster took an instant shine to his older brother, and was the lone source of sibling affection Thoren had.At the time of Thoren’s arrival, Jamros had become reclusive, choosing to spend his time, primarily, in a small lodge away from the family his wife, Irann, had assumed control over the family. Irann, a daughter of Elven nobility, had not taken kindly to the offer of her hand to Jamros, who was the son of a bard, in return for the rescue of her youngest brother, Traster, from a Drow clan that had made several raids in to the High Forest near Ethyreen. Jamros, who was approaching the age of ninety at the time (shortly after Thoren’s birth) had accepted the offer primarily out of the duty to preserve his line, as he was the last of his name.Irann had never taken to Jamros’ adveturesome lifestyle, preferring the safety and security of the Wood Elf’s haven in the High Forest. His absentism had led to a rift, especially after Traster’s birth, that drove them apart, leading to Jamros’ self-imposed exile to his hunting lodge. Though he, initially, brought Thoren to the home of his wife, when Thoren’s training began, they lived for months at Feyrun (his fathers lodge deep in the forest). Jamros’ taught Thoren everything he could about tracking, archery, two-handed fighting, and inundated his eldest child with stories of his years in the world of men. Though, eventually, Thoren grew to love his father, he was never able to forgive his fathers abandonment, and refused to adopt the Woodsoul name, refusing, even at his fathers deathbed, to relinquish the name of the only family he ever had.Upon his father’s death, Thoren left Feyrun and returned to Anganor, reuniting with Tyrus Vicelord just months before his passing. His “brother”, Tytran, a bard of some renown in the Human cities of the low plains, encouraged him to ply his skills in the Human cities in the north, where there was much need for skilled trackers. Tytran, who’s travels had taken him far above the Neck, led his “brother” Thoren off towards Winterfell, where, on his 20th birthday, he encountered a small band of adventurers looking for a tracker to lead them through Wintershold forest.As a young child, Thoren was visited by a member of his father, Jamros’, clan in he woods near his Grandfathers’ estate. The man, who did not give his name, but called himself Thoren’s Uncle, told Thoren that he must grow to be the man his father could not be.Not long after Thoren began his formal training with his father, he was targeted for “education” by his younger brothers (save Traster). His brothers, Yennan and Thoros, slipped a non-lethal amoung of nightshade in to his bread, leaving Thoren poisoned and near death for several days. As a result, Thoren is overly suspicious and will rarely eat anything he did not make himself.Before setting out with his “brother” Tytran on the adventure that brought him to Winterfell, Thoren had a brief, life-changing, encounter with the daughter of his Grandfather’s stable-master, Yehreena. Though he will not admit it openly, he dreams regularly of eschewing the vocation his father imparted on him.

Zûkhwlaaey grew up in a typical orcish tribe in the frozen north, the child of an accomplished huntress and a human herbalist who had been adopted by the tribe as a lost child. When Zûkhwlaaey returned from completing their adulthood tasks (most importantly, killing a bear on their own), they found their village razed to the ground and their tribe gone. Not having the marks of adulthood, but also not being able to repeat their tasks (killing a bear binds its spirit to yours, and binding more than one inevitably leads to them tearing your spirit apart between them), Zûkhwlaaey was forced to leave orcish society altogether, and has been wandering more or less southwards, doing odd jobs and performing music to scrape a living, ever since.

The Brightwaters are an old, well-established trading family that transports goods back and forth from their home port in Memnon and along the southern trade routes. The strict tradition in the trading families of this region is that the first-born son into a sailing family is committed to the family’s ship, which means they are taken away from their mother as soon as they are weaned and grow up on the family ship. Starting from a very young age, they learn every aspect of life at sea and are expected to become proficient (or at least capable) in them all. On their 20th birthday, they go through a blood bonding ceremony with the ship and become First Mate under their father, and later Captain when their father either dies or steps down. In the absence of a son in the family, the responsibility falls to the youngest daughter – this is less than ideal, as it can create situations where the daughter is much older than the traditional heir, but it is also extremely uncommon as the trading families tend to produced large and hardy families.  Farryn Brightwater is the third daughter born to Captain Remi Brightwater and his wife, Liaroris Brightwater (neé Vyshaan). Remi and Liaroris had an arranged marriage by which their parents intended to improve trade prospects between the two families. Remi and Liaroris were cordial but there was never a great affection between them and Remi was away at sea for most of their marriage. Liaroris did become pregnant quickly, but as she was an elf carrying half-humans, she was only able to bear three living offspring -- all girls – and had very difficult pregnancies. After almost dying when Farryn was born, healers ordered her not to fall pregnant again or it would surely kill her. Thus, at the age of three, Farryn was grudgingly taken away from her mother and two older sisters and brought to live and work on the Brightwater’s family ship, the Cascade. Her daily care fell to a sulky cabin boy who knew nothing about children, so Farryn had to learn to fend for herself quite quickly. At first Farryn was very homesick for her mother and her two older sisters, Mialee and Shava, who had doted over their baby sister. Each trading cycles lasts about three months, and as she was still expected to perform her duties onboard the Cascade even in Memnon, she was only allowed a week leave from the ship to be in the family home when the ship was in port. Despite her ambivalence toward her husband, Liaroris was a warm mother who genuinely loved her daughters and was distraught over Farryn being taken away. The visits for the first few years were very emotional and bittersweet. But after a while, each visit became more and more like polite visits with strangers. Farryn saw how close her sisters became to each other and their mother and how much she missed during the time she was away. After awhile she only came home for shorter visits of a day or two.For many years Farryn worked hard on the Cascade. Her father always seemed disapproving no matter how well she did, so she threw herself into her work and kept pushing harder and harder. She started out as a cabin boy, running errands for crew. As she was waiting to grow and get stronger, she also took her turns assisting the cook in the galley, working as a nurse under the healer, and assisting shipwrights with repair as the needs arose. When she was old enough, she started working as a crew member, manning the sails, cleaning the ship, aiding with repairs, keeping watch, helping load and unload cargo. She learned how to balance cargo, how to operate the catapults on deck, the record keeping necessary for trading, navigation and map charting, and star reading. By her early teens she was doing rounds with the first mate on his daily ship inspections to be sure tasks are completed and everything is running efficiently, repairs are done correctly, etc. Over the years, the other shipmates didn’t know how to relate to her, as she was not only the Captain’s daughter but also female. But she consistently pulled her weight and more, and thus earned their grudging respect and eventually their cautious affection. She was happy with this until her mid-teens when she began to visit other family ships with her father to learn the business of trading. It was then she realized that on ships with male heirs the crew had much more respect and deference, and that the heir was truly treated as the future captain instead of like a mascot. She privately despaired of ever becoming the type of leader that she would need to be in order to command that type of respect. She knew that she would have to work three times as hard as a male in her position would, which made her all the more determined to be the best she could.   When Farryn was sixteen, her mother became very sick. Healers from around the trade route were transported to Memnon and finally, when it seemed there was nothing anyone could do, Farryn’s great-grandfather, the wizard Lianthorn Vyshaan, was transported from his home in Velen to be with his daughter. He was a private and reclusive old man who spent most of his time onboard in his cabin. But when he was on deck or at dinner, Farryn noticed him starting at her intently several times. This scared her a little, so she tried to avoid him after that. Her mother eventually passed away and after the funeral and mourning period, the Cascade started out on the trade route with Lianthorn on board, although this time he stayed exclusively in his cabin and had his meals brought to him. When they were nearing port, the most violent storm Farryn had even seen broke out. The ship was taking on water and sails were tearing and everyone was running around like mad. Even Captain Remi looked worried, which made Farryn terrified. Just when she was sure they would all die at sea, she heard a booming voice and saw her great-grandfather standing on the deck with his arms outspread, casting spells. The violent winds stopped and within a minute the sky above was clear. The water on decks was siphoned neatly back into the sea and with a series of complicated hand gestures the sails were mended and billowed out toward shore again. The decks leveled and Lianthorn looked around slowly, then turned and started shuffling back to his cabin. It was dead silent and the whole crew stood with their mouths open until Captain Remi barked at them to get back to work, as the ship wouldn’t sail itself. Before she returned to her work, Farryn darted over to her great-grandfather and pressed her hand into his. He looked at her with the penetrating gaze again and she felt a tingling in her hand. Then he was back in his room and she didn’t see him again until he debarked in Velen. Later, Farryn overheard a conversation where the other crewmen discussed reverently how amazing the wizard’s feats had been and how they wish they had those powers. But soon they were laughing and imagining how much time it would take to learn and how dull learning wizardry was likely to be. That was when Farryn began to long to become a wizard. She had always been resigned, if not satisfied, that she would eventually become Captain of her beloved Cascade, but for the first time in her life she wished fervently that she wasn’t the ship’s heir. But she was, and there was nothing she could do about it, so she pushed the dream aside as best she could and carried on.Shortly after her mother passed away, a new crew member came on board – a boy the same age as Farryn named West Calabra. The Calabras weren’t a trading family, so it was a little odd, but not completely out of the ordinary. West has to work just as hard as Farryn did to earn the trust and respect of the crew, but in short time he is very well liked. Despite Farryn being a little jealous at how quickly West is accepted by the crew, she can’t help but like him, as he’s very affable and continued to share her work ethic. As somewhat outsiders among the crew, the two became unlikely fast friends. For Farryn, this was the first time in her life that she had a close friend and confidante, which was an amazing feeling. Farryn and West worked side by side, covered each other’s watches when they were sick or exhausted and she began to teach him navigation at his request. He told her about growing up without a father as the only child of a poor bard and she told him about never getting to know her mother and wishing she knew her sisters better. They discussed trading and other ships West has worked on and the best meals they’ve had in ports. Farryn even confessed that although she loves the Cascade and her life at sea, she longs to learn wizardry so she can train to become a Ship’s Wizard and better protect the ship from the stormy seas, sea monsters, and pirates. West didn’t laugh at her like she was afraid he might, but told her earnestly how good she’d be at wizardry. At first, she developed a bit of a crush, but West kept her firmly at arm’s length. Regardless, this was the happiest time in Farryn’s life and for the first time she started to look forward to being Captain of the Cascade with West as her First Mate.The winter before Farryn and West were set to turn 20 (when Farryn would officially take over as First Mate) West’s mother fell ill. He got more worried and withdrawn each time the Cascade stopped in his home port of Calimport. Meanwhile, Farryn got more and more nervous about making the switch to First Mate, worried what it will mean for her friendship with West and relationship to the rest of the crew and whether any of them will take her seriously. Finally, in mid-summer, a month before Farryn’s birthday and days until West’s, the Cascade returned to Memnon. Before disembarking, West cornered Farryn and asked her if she could, would she give up becoming captain of the ship so she could learn wizardry. Surprised and confused, she said yes. West nodded and took her with him to her father’s quarters where he revealed that he is Remi’s bastard son and under the laws of the land is claiming his birthright to become captain of the Cascade. His mother is very sick and needs money for healers, rare medicines, and better quarters.  Farryn and her father were stunned. But before long, the story came out – Remi met West’s mother, Yetta, in Calimport (one of the mainland trading ports) when he was young and training to take over the Cascade from his father. They kept meeting up in Calimport over the years and eventually their friendship turned into love. When Remi found out that his parents were setting up an arranged marriage, he was devastated, but knew he could never ask his parents to marry a poor girl from a non-trading family. He wanted to run away with her but was afraid of his future wife’s great-grandfather, who was a powerful wizard. He went through with the wedding, but still saw Yetta in secret when he could. Remi was miserable and finally told Yetta that seeing her was too painful – Liaroris was pregnant and he had to turn his attentions to her and his future children as best he could. Yetta never told him that she was also pregnant, because she knew that his wife’s family would likely kill him. So she raised her son on her own and never told anyone who his father was, but pined after Remi for all those years. When West was old enough, he asked about his father and she told him the whole story but begged him not to tell anyone. West was curious, so he worked hard on several trading ships and eventually secured a position on the Cascade -- not with any intentions, only so he could get to know his father. His friendship with Farryn was an unexpected but pleasant surprise, and his affection toward his half-sister was genuine. He knew he would never risk hurting her by revealing the truth about his father, so he resolved to work hard enough and hopefully become First Mate one day. But then his mother got sick and forced his hand.Captain Remi became very emotional while listening to this story, and to Farryn’s surprise, he got up and hugged West for a long time. Farryn, who was in shock and felt deeply betrayed by West, ran out of the room and off the Cascade. She asked around and found a foreign merchant ship that was leaving for Velen that afternoon that would give her passage in exchange for her working on the ship. They cast off before her father can find her and before she can lose her nerve. She missed the Cascade terribly, but every time she thought about her father or West her resolve hardened. She got along wonderfully with the crew, who don’t know her true identity, and by the time they arrived in Velen they offered her a job. She was tempted to take it and just disappear forever, but when she looked to the dock, her great-grandfather was standing there waiting for her. She went to him and he looked at her for a long time and then wordlessly lead her back to his sea-side home. She finally asked him if her father had gotten word to him somehow and he said that no, he knew she was coming through his powers. He asked her to tell him what happened. Too afraid to lie, she blurt out the truth and told him she wanted him to teach her wizardry. He was silent for a long time. Farryn wondered if the ship already left, or if she could still take the job working on it. Finally, Lianthorn told her that if she is serious about learning wizardry he will teach her, but in order to prove that she’s a serious student, she must stay in his house and study alone for one full year. If she reads and studies every day for a year, then at the end of the year he will teach her. She was nervous, but agreed to the terms. She was given a room and shown the massive library and then left to her own devices.Farryn, true to her word, began her year of study. After a couple of days of her bumbling around not knowing where to start, Lianthorn began leaving books out for her in the library, although she rarely saw or spoke to him. Her great-grandfather employed a half-orc woman, Umag, who prepared food and kept the house running. Umag spoke mostly Orcish, so Farryn dedicated some time to learning it and they were able to get along well after that. She got the impression that her great-grandfather had helped Umag’s family and she was repaying a life-debt by working for him. Although Farryn was still angry and grieving and lonely and was very unaccustomed to living on land, her days began to take shape – in the mornings she would get up at dawn and study in the library until Umag brought a late brunch and tea. After eating, she would take a walk through the property’s gardens, then back to studying until dinner, which was served at a table and attended infrequently by her great-grandfather. After dinner she would walk down to the shore to stare at the horizon and put her feet in the sea. After week of this routine, Umag came to her and told her that her great-grandfather had a small sailboat that he was willing to let her use. After that she took the boat on the water every day after dinner, regardless of weather. When she returned after her sail, she would tidy her room and read until she fell asleep. One day a week, she ventured down to the port, disguising herself a bit, to get news of the trading families. She learned that her father had reunite with Yetta and that West had bonded to the Cascade. He and her father were running a new trade route together up the Sword Coast. The ship she booked passage with occasionally is in port and tried to convince her to come back to sea, which is tempting at times.She continued like this for the entire year, never missing a day of study, and when the one year anniversary came, Lianthorn was waiting for her in the library and began to teach her the wizardly arts. He was a good and fair teacher, although he was never particularly warm to her. He did catch him looking at her intently at times, which she guessed was because she looked so much like her mother. He did seemed pleased when she progressed quickly and proved a competent wizard, and told her that he knew when he saw her on the ship that he would teach her one day. She asked if her mother knew magic and to her surprise he said yes, but then no more. She stopped talking about her mother and threw herself even more into practice and studies. She still went down to the sailboat every day, and as she learned simple spell and cantrips she practiced mending the sails, shooting firebolts into the sea, and seeing through the eyes of a raven familiar.  She continued to train and become a more powerful wizard, and eventually her great-grandfather told her that her formal training would be done and that in one week, it will be time for her to move on. Farryn had been expecting this and after several years is ready to make her peace with her father and West, so she made arrangements to return to her home. On the day she is set to leave, Lianthorn met her in the library and praised her work ethic and skill, and told her that he was very happy to have had the chance to teach her. As she smiled and thanked him, his demeanor changed and he told her that they never discussed payment. Farryn balked, confused, and her great-grandfather said that it wasn’t her he was seeking payment from, it was her father. She listened horrified while he ranted and raved about the captain that was unfaithful to his favorite granddaughter and broke her heart and then repeated his sins when he cheated his favorite great-granddaughter out of her birthright and similarly broke her heart. Farryn tried to stop him and defend her father, but her pleas fell on deaf ears and before she knew it, he had gone into a type of trance and cast a powerful curse on her father, then stormed out of the room.Farryn hurried home as fast as she could, but Remi was already quite sick by the time she arrived. He seemed relieved to see her, though, and on his deathbed confessed that during her absence, he and West had become involved with a group called the Cult of the Dragon. The Cult paid him to smuggle goods across the Sword Coast. Wracked by guilt, he begged Farryn to promise him that she would investigate the cult and undo the evil he may have helped foster. He urged her to travel to a town called Greenest. Farryn abhorred the thought of being inland for so long when she only just got back, but she also felt extremely guilty about and blamed herself for her father’s death. Immediately after Remi’s burial at sea, she snuck off and secured passage to Candlekeep with a merchant vessel.At the start of our adventure, Farryn is sailing into Candlekeep – it would be a more direct route with more towns along the way if she sailed into Baldur’s Gate, but she’s still trying to process everything that’s happened (her father’s death, finding out he was involved in smuggling for the cult, her grandfather’s betrayal) and has always been uneasy in big cities, so she doesn’t mind camping along the way instead of staying at inns. Plus, she remembers a delicious meal she had in The Burning Wizard tavern in Beregost and Farryn never forgets a good meal. Her plan is to start out in the fortress libraries at Candlekeep to see if she can learn anything out about the Cult of the Dragon and/or Greenest, then take the Way of the Lion path to the Coast Way, where she will head south to Beregost for supplies (and her good meal). She’ll decline to stay in any of the three inns in Beregost and instead elect to camp along the road when she heads south on the Coast Way. Then she’ll continue to head south until she picks up the road into Greenest.

Known for its strategic coastal locations and large settlements, the Sword Coast is a prosperous but still very dangerous place to live. Some hundred miles away from the coast itself, protected by the surrounding Shaeradim Mountains is Evereska, one of the Sword Coast's largest settlements. It's known as the last haven of the elves. “Fortress Home” in the common tongue is the last and only standing Elven stronghold in all of Faerun. Encircled by mountains and dense forest, Evereska sits atop a plateau more than 1000 feet above the forest floor making it very difficult for outsiders to get to.Evereska is surrounded by a large magical force known as a mythal that not only acts as a protective barrier but also serves to control weather, regulate sickness and disease, allow large objects to be floated and has many other magical properties. The mythal also allows the citizens of Evereska to climb walls, ceilings and other surfaces like insects. The Eladrin that inhabit Evereska live with and use magic in all its different forms in their daily life. Made up of primarily moon elves, Evereska is no stranger to humans and even a handful of half elves. Tavneiros was known as not only the youngest Eladrin of the high council that governed over Evereska, but the only one to take a human wife. While it was not necessarily looked down upon in their society, Tavneiros was definitely an anomaly among his people. Kine Stokk, Tavneiros’ wife was born to one of the smaller noble houses in Baldurs Gate. A short rather petite figure with creamy pale skin, emerald green eyes and shoulder length auburn curls, Kine stands a striking figure next to her husband's pale blue complexion, raven hair and glowing pupil less blue eyes.One dark night, an ominous arcane storm was brewing over Evereska. It wasn't unheard of that the magic holding the mythal together could be unstable, but it was so rare that most Eladrin may only see one storm like this in their life while others may only hear about them. Tavneiros was apprehensively ecstatic, for Kine was pregnant and just happened to go into labor tonight, but he was unsure if the storm was a good or bad omen. The storm was as beautiful as it was frightening. Shimmering golden drops of rain poured down from dark clouds as bright powerful streaks of purple lightning flashed across the sky. Tavneiros kneeled beside his wife's head, stroking her damp hair in an attempt to soothe her while two priests and a cleric of The Seladrine tended to her other needsA loud crack of thunder boomed drowning out a scream from Kine and just a few minutes later a baby's cry. It's a girl one of the priests said as he presented the child with very Elven features and straight jet black hair just like her father. Another looming boom of thunder and an even louder scream of pain from Kine, the priest surprised held a second child in his arms a boy this time with curly hair like his mother but it was shining silver in the moonlight. As the cleric was starting her blessings of the children, she realized that they had identical birthmarks in the shape of a bird. She knew it was clearly a sign from Aerdrie, the bringer of rain and storms, the Lady of air and wind, the Queen of the Avariel.Growing up as the children of a noble wasn't easy for these two. Rivorthel and Celephindor were afforded many luxuries that other children growing up in Evereska weren't. Even though they were never chastised for being half-elven, their father felt as though he needed to make sure they were smarter, stronger and better taught than all the other children to make up for it. As it was it seemed that the twins were born gifted, touched by the arcane instability of the mythal during their birth. They both had an unnatural affinity for magic and the arcane arts. Most of the other children of Evereska teased them for the amount of time they spent with tutors and reading books that the others couldn't afford. Being teased by all the other children only made them grow closer together the older they got.Shortly after their birth, their mother became very ill. One of the priests ruled that it was most likely due to the level of energy from the mythal present at the time and her human body not being used to or able to handle it. Celephindor or Celeb as his mother called him grew very close to his mother in the few years that she was alive. Eladrin aren't known for having strong emotions and even less for showing them, but Celeb shared his mother's very human range of strong emotions. He let his emotions guide his actions and decisions, probably more than he should have and definitely more than his father liked. Celeb was a very frail child, always much smaller and weaker than his older sister. However none of the elders versed in the arcane arts had ever seen one single person possess so much raw arcane power and with no training or spellbook. As Celeb grew older, he realized his power much like the mythal itself was incredibly powerful but potentially unstable. In an effort to learn to control his powers, Celeb read every book he could get his hands on hoping that if he gained more power he could stabilize his magic. What he found was that he just really enjoyed reading and even though scripts on the arcane arts and history books were his favorite, the subject didn't matter, he just liked to read. He was somewhat of an introvert, often lost in his books and research and found it hard to trust anyone besides his sister.Ever since birth, Rivor felt a strong need to protect her younger brother, even laying into a few of the older boys that took to teasing Celeb about his frailty. After their mother's death, even though she was still a child, Rivor felt terrible that she wasn't able to help in anyway. It was from then on that she knew she would use her powers to help and heal others. She devoted much of her time to learning about The Seladrine, Aerdrie Faenya in particular, who was said to be the cause of the arcane storm that blessed them with their powers. She swore she would never let anything happen to those she loved ever again and with her devotion she became the youngest cleric of The Seladrine in Evereska’s history.Much like her brother, she loved to read and had an affinity for languages. However, most of her time was devoted to religious texts, focusing her arcane prowess in the arts of healing. She took to healing and helping as many people around Evereska as she could. She quickly became known all across Evereska for her ability to quickly heal wounds, soothe emotions and even bless people and objects.If it wasn't for their difference in hair, the twins would have been identical. Rivor had long straight jet black hair and a lithe but powerful build. A mix of their parents, she had a creamy pale complexion with undertones of blue primarily across her cheekbones and around her ears and eyes. Her ears were long and pointed just like her father's and her almond shaped pupil less eyes were a deep shade of violet. She usually wore fine Eladrin made golden armor with teal accents, the colors of their house. Her hair was normally held back by an ornate golden circlet, except for a single braid that fell over her right shoulder.Celeb had soft curls that fell to his shoulders, shining silver like the light from the moon. As he got older for some reason, he took to shaving half of his head and leaving the other side a mess of thick curls. Like his sister, the signature pale blue of the Eladrin was present across his face. With his long pointed ears and deep pupil less violet eyes, if the twins had no hair they'd be almost impossible to tell apart. Celeb most often wore flowing teal robes held together with shimmering gold thread. It wasn't abnormal for noble born Eladrin to adorn themselves with jewelry of all types as Celeb usually wore a golden chain that hung from his right ear, the other side attached to his right nostril. The only thing Celeb was never without was the dull greyish black stone he wore as a pendant around his neck, given to him by his mother it was his last connection to her.

Carl is the son of a famous bard, Carly Rae Jenkins, an impeccable harp players who would travel the world with her son, staying from tavern to tavern, and spoiling the young boy with any clothes, toy and instrument he desired. He had a happy childhood, filled with parties, music and art. Carl thought he had it all.One day, she fell in love with a charming human man and finally settled down when Carl turned eighteen. Not soon after, he came back home after a performance to find his mother dead, all their possessions and money robbed, and her mother’s lover nowhere to be found. Carl ran away with his mother's golden harp that he had been using that night and the clothes on his back, terrified that he would meet the same fate. Desperate for work after weeks of running, Carl found a job as a performer in a local tavern. One day, he accidentally interrupted an important heist that was going on in the room beneath it, and instead of being killed, the group spared him and decided he would work for them instead. Carl was forced to join a thieve's guild as the group's honeypot/bait, as they deemed him too aloof to actually carry out any heists, but they have no qualms using him as the group’s sex toy.Carl is stuck working for the thieve’s guild -- and as a tavern bard as his cover -- and wants to get out as soon as possible, and intends on running away once more, as he has always been too scared to face his problems head on. He dreams to be the famous bard his mother was, carrying on her legacy and playing the music that he loves, but for now, he’s stuck being the group’s whore.

Dehalid is a former member of a monastic order of druids who lived in isolation in the mountains. After taking in a lost traveller and healing their wounds, Dehalid learnt there was more to life than the rigid belief structure he had been raised in and dedicated most of his waking hours to. Experiencing a spiritual crisis, he left the monastery and descended into the world below, becoming an adventurer himself and drinking a great deal.

Ori comes from a small farming community of dragonborn like herself that began to be plagued by raiding orc marauders. Ori and her friends formed a ragtag militia that learned techniques mostly through secondhand military academy tomes and the advice of traveling veterans, and they were able to keep their town safe for many years. All was mostly well until an ambitious and powerful warlock of Valran formed an alliance with the orcs and, with the aid of demons, they overran the community and burnt it to the ground. Ori survived through what she has later decided was cowardice, and now travels around seeking to improve herself and protect those in need. As the only survivor of the militia, she feels personally responsible for the welfare of the few survivors of the town and tries to send gold to them whenever she can.
Was an abused familiar for a wizard before running away to become a brave knight.
Worked for the Mafia, or "Meowfia" before messing up a big job and having to run away.

Bullworth was the king of a distant land known as nyumbani, where he was born and raised. He was the son of the head cleric of the kingdom, the leader of the church of Osiris, and so his family was very close with the royal family, and he spent a lot of time with the princess, Rose. When the queen died, Rose took her place, and not long after she and Bullworth were married. After about 30 years, Rose fell ill for weeks, and the king from a foreign land offered to send 3 doctors that he claimed were the best in the world. They accepted the gift, and the doctors came and quickly cured Rose, and stayed in nyumbani afterwards to monitor her and make sure the illness didn't return. But after this Rose began acting strangely, she spoke to the doctors in a language Bullworth had never heard, and was more rash and unsympathetic in her ruling. The doctors noticed Bullworth's suspicion and cornered him one day, they possesed his mind, and bullworth was trapped in a mental prison for weeks, but was eventually led back to consciousness by Osiris. He left the palace as soon as this happened, knowing there were forces at play here that he wasn't yet ready to face, and devoted himself to osirsis, vowing to one day return and rid his kingdom of the evil that plagues it

Trained as a dancer, she longs to join the guild of assassins her family have led for generations. She feels that having a strong aesthetic is important to being a legendary assassin and researches magic to augment her murderous performances.

Trullan's ancestors had befriended a gold dragon, who stayed with the Serbellas for many centuries. The Serbellas enjoyed immense political power, as being good friends with a dragon gave them some leverage. And due to near-constant exposure to powerful draconic magic, many skilled sorcerers were born into the family over the course of centuries. For unknown reasons, the dragon left one day, never to be seen again. Sorcerers began to be more and more rarely born, and the Serbella family faded into obscurity.Trullan was the first sorcerer born in centuries. She had an easy, spoiled childhood as the family favorite. When she came of age, she decided to set off into the world and learn what happened to the dragon. She has convinced herself that they are still alive, and that she will bring them back home to restore her family to their former glory.

85-90 years ago in a nameless settlement at the edge of the Underchasm in the East Rift, a child with ambiguous genitalia was born to the Grimwright clan of Hill Dwarves, and given a name that meant "son/daughter of the gods." This made early life a little confusing, as did the fact that each parent called the child by a different diminutive of their name, one feminine and the other masculine. The child thought of themself as a third gender-neutral diminutive. As the child grew, they showed signs of significant fighting skills, and of quick learning. In their teen years they were recruited into the settlement's guard against the malevolent creatures that occasionally came from the Underdark. This became a bright point in their life, and remained so until one day when they were in their mid-30s and the settlement suffered an attack by three dragons simultaneously. There was only one survivor, and that was just barely.The lone survivor was discovered by clerics from a not-far-distant settlement who had felt called to the area. The clerics spent months helping the burnt, broken, and despondent patient regain health, only to be rewarded with their disappearance in the night.Dropping their original name and going solely by their clan name, Grim began to wander the wilds of Faerun. Eventually they stopped, deep in the Border Forest, built a small house (among Grim's skills is masonry), and settled into their hermitage.For decades, Grim lived alone, only dealing with the creatures (humanoid and not) of the forest. Then one day they felt an irresistible call. Berronar Truesilver spoke to them in a way that they knew she usually only spoke to her trained and chosen faenor. Grim was told to return home and seek a place to train.Following where they felt Berronar lead them, Grim returned to the East Rift, specifically to the settlement where some of his cleric saviours hailed from. Grim was taken in, trained, and achieved Cleric status fairly quickly, despite an occasionally surly attitude toward Berronar, who Grim felt should have protected their former clan.And now, sometimes, when she calls him to do so, Grim adventures.

Criminal - Odi was wrongfully imprisoned for years because she is the only Goliath to predict the future. She predicted the failure of the most loved fighter in her clan against a Frost Giant and was correct. The clan said it was her magic that made the fighter fail. After years of trying to convince the people she was not at fault, she took a risk and broke out of prison. Now she is on the run for freedom.

Breexi is a bit crazy. She learned alchemy from a disgraced dragonborn master, studying under him for the majority of her 20 years. In a blast originating from one of her experiments, he died. Breexi lost her right arm. It took two years for her to find another teacher, and ten years after that for them to together build her a prosthetic. The twist? The prosthetic is a crossbow. It's a literal hand crossbow.

Aubri is a wild sorcerer who gained her powers by encountering a planar rift while exploring in the woods with her father. Her father took the full force of the rift, but Aubri was left scarred and imbued with powerful new magics. Now alone in the world she took to the woods her father had loved and spent many decades alone, hating and honing her magic. Now she has made botanical discoveries that she dare not keep to herself, and has set out into the world once more.

Mac grew up on the streets.  An orphan for as long as he can remember.  He has no family, he has now friends, he has only himself.  Mac learns the streets well.  He knows when to apply some subterfuge or when it's time to ply his skills with the knife.  Mac knows there is only one person in this world you can trust, yourself.

Theia was a street urchin who bacame a priestess after being caught stealing from a church. She was saved by a former paladin when her temple was attacked by bandits. The two were directed directed by visions from their goddess to travel to another continent to be her representatives on a council of cl

Magical Trevor is a magical prodigy that never really had to study hard to master the art of pyromancy. Finding his calling at a young age when he absentmindedly burned his village down, he was quickly whisked away to a safer, more flame-proof, place of education. Unfortunately, this bored Trevor, who decided that he preferred hanging out with the circus folk and performing great feats of pyromancy for crowds, traveling around the countryside and fleecing unwitting rubes for their hard earned coin. Here he found true friends for the first time, and spent many days drinking heavily between his magical feats. Until one day, he returned to the camp grounds after drinking all night before to find his carnival friends murdered by a mysterious force. He kept his name in honor of his murdered friends, sworn to defeat the great evil that destroyed his only family.

Kestrel was born to a gnome woman who survived an orc raid on her village. Her mother dropped her on the doorstep of a temple to Set, and the priests raised her. She's a highly trained assassin, with a nonstop simmering rage in her soul. She hunts down enemies of Set by joining adventuring groups as cover.

Ellywick is a member of the Harpers faction. The same as all of her family and friends. She is the third child of four, with an older brother and sister and a younger brother. She's hyper and headstrong, so it was a surprise when she became a master of stealth and disguise!

Half-Giant Princess of a Celtic Amazonian Barbarian Tribe. Barbara Ann (aka Barb) wants to be an honorable hero and noble warrior. She is polite, honorable, always gives enemies a chance to surrender, etc. More like a Paladin than a barbarian, despite how she dresses. Her tribe, however, looks down on her for that, especially her mother, the Queen. “A Princess does not wipe her feet when coming in the castle.” and “A princess does not say excuse me after belching” and “A princess does not give her enemy the chance to surrender” and such. It’s like a reverse version of the movie “Brave.” Her mother “took” a Giant specifically so she would have “strong offspring.” Her mother is a real piece of work. She is a friend to all the animals and hides deep insecurity behind a wall of bravado. She does, however, continue to have the Barbarian problem of falling into a blood-rage when sufficiently pissed off.

Incredibly intimidating half-orc who thinks he’s a master thief. However, he’s really just so scary and strong that nobody bothers to argue with him. He does not pick locks, he punches the handles out of doors. He does not pickpocket, he rips people’s pants off and bolts. He does not break into vaults, he just BREAKS the vaults. Despite clearly being better suited to being a fighter of some kind, he insists he is the sneakiest, most agile thief in the world. The truth of it is, when he breaks into some place, he is very noisy and almost immediately spotted. When he is spotted, he shouts “YOU NO SEE GROK!!!”...People are usually inclined to agree that they do not, in fact, see Grok.

This gnomish girl is not a swashbuckling adventurer or a charming rogue, but a deadly agent of vengeance. She wears all black, has an eyepatch (which may or may not be enchanted to act like the Solid Eye from MGS4) and has an incredibly deadly arsenal of weapons. Most of her weapons are bows, throwing knives, shurikens, etc, but she also has daggers, pistols, etc. Where does she keep them all, especially since she’s only the size of a human toddler? Who the hell knows. At some point or another, her family was killed by a dark necromancer’s army of zombies. She’s henceforth decided to kill all dark lords that threaten her homeland and any who would ally with them or give them aid. She’s 3’1” of murderous, vengeful hatred in a package that’s too cute for such a character to reasonably be. She keeps a “war journal” and is sometimes seen narrating to herself. She has an unexplained hatred of jigsaw puzzles.

The Queenslayer”, whose real name is Lillys Felhani, is traveling the world as an outcast from her homeland of Dathros, she has been shamed and exiled by her people and their king.  Cast out from her temple for not being able to control her sexual urges, she seeks to continue her journey through quests that may redeem her in the eyes of her god and people. She hopes to regain the honor and position she once held in her temple by becoming a savior of the land. She thinks by becoming an adventurer and hero she can restore her honor and redeem herself in the people’s eyes. Lillys earned the name “Queenslayer” by seducing the queen of Dathros, and thus earning her expulsion from her temple and the land. That name has been used to mock her, but she embraces it and makes it a part of her personality in spite of those who use it against her.

Lyra was born into a noble family in Umar. She was a shy child, but talented, and quickly developed an interest in Botany. During her early teen years, she realized that many of the human-animal constructs that her city created as slaves were ill-treated and she began to adopt abandoned rabbit-people and take care of them. One day, she received a letter indicating that her Uncle in a distant province had left it to her, and he was dead or missing. She followed, and rapidly found herself nobility in a foreign land, undoing all the horrors her uncle had wrought. She made fast friends there, though she also brought along her bodyguard.

It was a child from a simple family of dwarf tinker , Torik had simple dreams in his caverns , but one day all his family was exiled because the shop of his father wasn't god enough , so he became a mercenary.

An impoverished college linguistics student who, after a chance encounter with a friend of a friend at a party, started thieving to help pay for school. He had to leave sudden before the law started to close the noose on him and turned the figurative hang-man's noose into a literal one. He now sells his skills to various adventuring parties, because you never know if that ancient scribbling on the tomb wall is a warning...or if the trap needs a little B&E.
Exiled prince looking to topple the usurper wizard, Gwildor.
Freewheeling student of draconic song.
Smiter of evil, doer of awesome deeds.
Bounty hunter and goat breeder
Former slave turned problem solver for hire

Greg was raised in a rural village's church to be a candidate for Paladin training at the denomination's head church, yet a few days after setting off with a wagon train heading there he is captured by highway men thinking to ransom him off back to the church. They tied him to a rock alongside another passenger inside their hideout where he was rescued by his soon to be compatriots.
On the run from an arranged marriage
Pirate. Lost a leg to an aquatic landshark.
Loyal warrior of Clan of Mogar Sixfingers. Searching for the seer, Orkimedes.

He was born under a blood moon in the forest kingdom of the Elves. The illegitimate child of the Queen and an evil god, he was sent away by the jealous king. He grew up in the human world, traveling to gain the skills he needed to survive. Once he learned of his parentage, he became obsessed with retaining his rightful place on the throne. So he made a deal with a demon to reclaim his birthright, the throne to the forest kingdom of the Elves. He regained is throne, but the price was his eternal imprisonment. After only a few short years, he was captured by agents of Hell. For ten thousand years, he was imprisoned. But a group of adventurers, searching for a relic of Hell, freed his soul and he returned to the world determined to reclaim his home. But in the millennia that had passed, the kingdom had crumbled. To reclaim his homeland, he had to defeat the Drow that now lived beneath the ruins of his capital city. With his crew aboard the airship Alfirin Elryn, they search the world for allies to rid the forest of the Drow menace.
Driven insane when the Elder Ones made him experience the lives of every alternate universe version of himself.
Slightly nutty inventor
A chef gathering regional recipes for a cookbook from the cultures and kingdoms he visits.

A cat from humble beginnings; Lock on an Open Door (Lock to those who know him) hails from outside the forested town of Croy. Born to Key with no Teeth (Mother) and Open Door to a Safe (Father), Lock spent his childhood studying under his parents as a locksmith, while playing with the other Tabaxi children in their small tribe.Always a great storyteller, Key told many grand tales of her ancestors in Talvar. She told stories of a master locksmith in the family from many generations ago working closely with Talvari royalty. Cage with no Bars once was a servant to the King, but at some point proved himself and became the King’s personal locksmith. He designed intricate and beautiful locks and safes for the King’s vast riches. Some stories go that Cage’s fleeting fancies led him outside of Talvar; others that he outlived his usefulness and the King sent him away to find other work; while yet others insist that he was banished for trying to steal from the very safes he created.Whatever the case, Lock knew from a young age that Talvar was where he wanted to call home eventually. The fantastical stories that his mother would tell painted vivid pictures in the curious cat’s mind of unending mystery, unbound opportunity, rich stories to be heard, and limitless new knowledge.
