Rather than write historical treatises like his forebears, Brundorff is compiling a series of dwarven folk tales for public sale.  The tales all revolve around the ancient dwarven hero Macton, a trickster figure from their mythology, who drank, swindled, romanced, and fought through the Age of Wonder, "a thousand generations ago, when dogs could talk and the last dragons fell."  Brundorff tends to emulate this hero a little too much, especially with drinking.  He's currently persona non grata in his homeland of the Kalatian Empire, having sung a song about a local mayor that crossed the line of good taste and attracted the mayor's rage.

When the Druidic Mountain Circle stopped a vicious raid by the local Thundering Axe orc clan, they took the orc chieftain's young half-human son Usk as a hostage.  Usk took to the Druidic traditions quickly, believing fervently that Nature is holy and must be protected.A high-ranking official in the Circle accused Usk of heresy, insisting that his "true orcish nature" would make him a despoiler of nature.  When Usk swore revenge, his other superiors ordered him to go on a learning pilgrimage, to defuse the tension.Usk's dual nature frequently causes him distress and anguish.  While he considers himself a peacemaker and healer, he also judges himself and others by harsh, inflexible standards.  He will usually offer his enemies a single chance to surrender; if they refuse, he will attempt to destroy them no matter the risk to his own life (or those of his friends, which is a sore point).

his website uses cookies to ensure you get the best experience on this site. More info here.HomeFantasy NamesReal NamesPlace NamesPop CultureOther NamesDescriptionsOther Gens.ContactAboutHelp The SiteThank YouCustom SearchsearchBackstory description generatorThis backstory description generator will generate a fairly random description of either a fortunate or unfortunate backstory depending on your choice.These backstories will fit respectable characters best, though some could be used for villainous characters as well. But there will be a separate backstory generator for villains in the future.The description is kept a little vague on purpose. The aim of this generator is to give a rough idea of what a character may have gone through, while keeping out some of the key details to make sure it could fit in most story settings.This way you can use the character ideas you have to further add to the history of this generator character or vice versa.Due to the random nature of a random generator, some descriptions might be a bit odd. It's possible to have somebody look for his or her significant other while being accompanied by his or her significant other and somebody who lost his or her brothers could be accompanied by his or her brother. But perhaps that character simply doesn't know it's his or her significant other or brother yet, ooh the mystery.Some of the grammar could also be incorrect due to all the randomness. But the mistakes are mostly limited to incorrect uses of plural or singular versions.To start, simply click on the button to generate a random description. Don't like the description? Simply click again to get a new one.She's polite, elegant, helpful and perhaps a little too timid. But there's more than this to somebody with her position.She was born in a small family in a developed capital. She lived in peace until she was about 17 years old, but at that point things changed.She started working for the family company and was making some great new friends. Having overcome plenty of obstacles, she is exploring new areas in a wonderful world. But with her diligence and capability, there's nothing to stop her from reaching great success. She could quickly become a person of (great) importance.Despite all this success, she is currently travelling the world. She feels like there's more to learn in this world. Luckily she has a great family to support her.

Gorton was conceived after his orc mother captured and sodomised ahuman male over one uncomfortable fortnight. At birth, his motherflipped a coin to decide whether to eat him or not. Luckily forGorton it landed on tails.At an early age, Gorton became lost and found himself in a humanvillage. He met a barren old spinster who, longing for her ownchildren, adopted (read: stole) him and took it upon herself togive him an education. Also she was a bit crazy from the syphilis.Gorton learnt to read after being given 7 scrolls that told thefictional tale of a boy wizard. This is what started his loveaffair with magic.As he reached his teenage years, he decided to pursue a career inWizardry rather than follow in the footsteps of his long forgottenmother. Barbarianism didn't interest him.He soon adopted a toad as his familiar. Whilst trying to perform alevitation spell on the creature, he accidentally turned itinside-out. After confirming that there was still a pulse, Gortonnamed the toad Giblets, as that is what he now resembles. Gibletsoccasionally pulsates, but mostly he attracts circling crows.Most recently he has been travelling the lands, using hisrudimentary literacy skills to learn magic. He's still prettyterrible at it and is prone to rage fits when his spells don'twork.Because he can't grow his own facial hair due to poor geneticsfrom his father's side, Gorton wears a fake beard to make himselflook wiser and more magicy. His greatest fear is someonediscovering that it's actually a second-hand merkin weaved fromboar hair. He also draws a scar over his left eye, similar to theone the boy wizard from his scrolls had. This is prone todisappearing in the rain.His wizard robe is blue with gold trim. It's also several sizestoo small, and ripped in places.One day he hopes to meet his father, if only just to apologise.

Abandoned by her human mother, horrified by the monster she gave birth to, she was found by a pack of wolves in a pile of leaves. They took her in and gave her her name, teaching her about the world of nature and the dangers of civilization.

Dayna spent her youth dodging Magic-Hunters as an orphan working for small change as a gray market healer - that is until she got caught. She spent two years as a prisoner to the Magic-Hunters (a group of Humans with no magic abilities that use their prisoners to do their dirty work for them while claiming that magic is unclean) and finally escaped when a fellow prisoner - a teenage girl named Kaemi with whom she had started a relationship with - blew up the compound as a distraction in order to save Dayna. Dayna presumes that she was killed and it still haunts her to this day. She has spent the majority of the last three years trying to form a bond with some adventurers in order to infiltrate the Magic-Hunters new compound, at the beginning to the Southern-most entrance to the Underdark. She knows she cannot go alone as she is paralyzed by the fear of going back there and being prisoner again. Dayna is Cleric specializing in the use of bolstering magics and has a true Utility driven set of magics.

May was raised in a smaller city wrought by crime and de facto ruled by various crime families. Her mother tried to shield her from the violence and rampant lawlessness, but failed early on as the young girl was groomed by recruiters from the Assassin's Guild who taught her how to shoot a bow with lethal efficiency as well as helped her tame one of the monstrous rats that roamed the severs of the city. After being ousted due to her unwillingness to engage in murder of the especially unsavory variety, she set out on her own with her riding rat Westley, seeking adventure and coin to send home for her parents' protection money fund.

Its true, as mentioned before, that the pixies of Sear Rie(new Kingdom) only have one parent, though it is not the one who birth's them.  When they are born, it is as a floating ball of pure magic, seeking out a "parent."  Their Parent is an adult who wishes to take on a new Pixie, helping it to form itself.  This parent's name was Moon, or at least, that is what others called her.  She was as bright and shining as the object in the sky, a sorceress who made all around her happy.  She was overjoyed the day a new life found her,  others said the sky was even brighter that night.Moon taught little "Fer"(Magic) all about the world and the life in it.  Fer realized that it didn't matter if the Pixies were distant from the Queen and the Seelie kingdom, they were in the forest, and the forest was filled with life and magic.  It was as Moon was teaching Fer about the forest around them that she was taught the most important, yet cruelest lesson of all.  Magic can be useless.Moon was captured that day.  Little Fer watched helplessly as her only parent was taken away.  To be a pet?  To be bred?  To use her body to produce drugs?  Fer wonders every moment to this day.She decided to shed her name, allowing only one person of the past to say it.  She raised herself alone, not seeking another parent.  It wasn't until she was physically formed that others gave her a name.  In a cruel manner to one that snuck but could not yet fly with ease, they called her "Snap", the sound a branch makes when stepped on.  When she became of age, she joined two schools, the Performer School and the War College; she barely slept until she graduated from both.  It took her into adulthood, but she became a pixie rogue, signing up to take on the laws which govern the New Kingdom, patrolling the forest along with the mages.Maybe it was desire for vengeance.  Maybe it was for a past self she could not help.  Maybe it was because the pixie of Sear Rie only get one parent.
He is wrong like all the time.

Aemon was born the heir of a noble house, but his parents were murdered by his brother, and he was framed for the crime. He escaped into the surrounding forests, and lived a life of exile among the plants and animals, eventually earning his way into a Druidic order and acting as a protector of the wilderness. He still wears his royal cloak, but after decades of use it is now threadbare and filthy, to compliment his own personal lack of grooming. He still remembers occasional social niceties, but is far more addled, blunt and erratic after spending most of his life as a hermit.

Raised on a farm, Tohmed knew nothing much of civilization, of fighting, or much of anything but tilling wheat and raising cows. He married the girl from the next town over at a young age, and inherited the farm when his parents passed during a particularly cold winter. With nothing but a few gold pieces in his pocket and the failing farm to his name, Tohmed was at a loss for how to be able to afford the necessities when his young wife became pregnant. A mercenary troupe was hiring in town and promised good coin, and Tohmed, naturally tall and sturdy from years of farmwork, took up the call. There he learned to fight, and to survive, and became a bit hardened to war and battle, learning of the ways of healing and of worship to the Warden, the local protection deity.When the war was over, Tohmed, afraid to admit his own fears of returning home to his wife and new daughter, stayed with the mercenary troupe even as they turned to banditry. It was only when a local chapel to the Warden was threatened, and the old cleric killed, that he turned on his fellow mercenaries, seeing the wrongs of his ways and beginning down the path of a true paladin. It was on a prison cart to trial for murder that his story began.

Early lifeBorn in a mid-sized town on the border of the inland sea, Sorra was marked as an outsider from birth. A mixture of her appearance, and a natural tendency for her to ‘snap’ and quickly become enraged, led to Sorra being rather isolated from other children. Sorra’s mother raised her alone, with no other siblings and no extended family still in contact with them.  She never knew her father – or even exactly what shade of being he was. Sorra’s mother did not talk about him when at all possible. Sorra always resented her mother, largely seeing her as to blame for her ‘condition’. Shortly after she turned 16, Sorra’s latent magical potential began to manifest, and she soon left home.TutelageSorra was picked up by a passing wise man named Chòt, who spent his years travelling from town to town with various merchant caravans. Predominantly Chòt was a medicine-man to the townsfolk, treating sickness or providing herbs in exchange for the means of scraping out a meagre living. Often, he would gather the local children and in exchange for a few coppers, teach them a lesson from among the seemingly endless depths of his memory and experience. More rarely, adults of a village might come to him for spiritual guidance, wisdom or arbitration. It was perhaps in this area most of all that he served as Sorra’s mentor.Chòt taught Sorra about her condition. About the types of being that represented who her father might be. He taught her that the elemental blood swirling within her was a challenge she was destined to overcome. Her magic, her rage – all traces of her heritage – could be overcome with rigorous application of mind and body. Sorra strove to control her wild natural state of emotions, suppressing them under layers of control. Through hard physical labour, she learnt the strength necessary to suppress what she thought of as her inner demons. In time, Chòt would come to teach her how to become closer to the pinnacle of perfection, in mind, body and spirit. Spitting in defiance of her imagined father, Sorra strove to conquer her chaotic self.With the passing years, Chòt grew older, and sickly. Several times, their travels were aborted while the old man was laid up in bed, Sorra having to balance gathering herbs and preparing remedies at his instruction, with working to earn food and board for the two while he rested at an inn. True to his dedication to a physical ideal, though, whenever his health looked on the mend Chòt would pack up and press on, heading back to the beaten trail.House BlackvyneIt was during this time, that Chòt was called upon by Lord Blackvyne, while traversing the realms of his Duchy. The Lord’s own coterie of astrologers, clairvoyants and other knowledgeable courtiers was inaccurate, or could not be trusted, or too personally involved – Sorra never really found out why the Lord came to her mentor. Neither did she know what matter of spiritual or moral council he sought; later, she came to suspect that it had to do with Lord Blackvyne’s place in the broiling politics that was shortly to erupt into war. Whatever it was, Blackvyne was most gracious to Chòt afterwards, but instead of accepting payment the old man simply asked the duke to take Sorra on as an advisor. The road was becoming ever more dangerous, and Chòt’s health ever-weaker; Sorra, now twenty-three was in the prime of her life, Chòt had told her, and was ready to strike out on her own.Sorra never saw the old man again. A few weeks later, a messenger arrived from the next village along on the old man’s route, bearing news of plague. Whether he was caught in the outbreak she did not know, but it seemed likely and, given his health, she doubted Chòt could have survived. The duke himself had grown large on fat meat and good wine, and needed a change in lifestyle if he were to keep up his lifestyle of hunting. He took Sorra on as a wellbeing instructor, the young woman’s excellent knowledge of athletic discipline bringing a small ray of rejuvenation into the aging lord’s life.Even in all of her travels, Sorra had grown used to staring looks, mistrust, abuse and occasionally even physical assaults from the locals of whatever villages they passed on their travels. Before Lord Blackvyne, no-one had ever simply accepted her, seen her for the freak of nature that she was, and then taken her in anyway. Well, no one except Chòt. Blackvyne was able to look under her disfigurement and see what, in Sorra’s own mind, was the disciplined young woman whose very body spoke of her underlying mastery of physical discipline. For that, she was forever grateful to the duke, and served him as dutifully as she had her old mentor.

Once a magical sword named Cutter, it was handed down through generations of adventurers. When its owner got killed by a gelatinous cube and it was absorbed, it decided that it was done being wielded by stupid kids and was going on its own adventures. It telepathically dominated the cube and decided it wanted to learn magic, and after a year of study it set off to see the world.

Dorion began life in a small elvish settlement towards the north of one of the larger islands. His parents were important envoys involved in diplomatic relations between the elves and humans as well as being notable for attempting to pursue a long term peaceful relationship with the local orc bands. Due to their bust schedules Dorion spent most of his time alone, wandering the forests and other natural areas of the world. Dorion became fascinated by nature and particularly a family of brown bears living in the area, for years Dorion studied this family of bears, forsaking his chores and working life to disappear into the woods and become part of the great ecosystem. Whilst living largely in the wilderness Dorion learned to channel the power of nature, despite generally being considered a weak child Dorion learned to move with grace and lethality through the forests. However when he was but 30 years old bold orc hunting parties started frequenting the forest. After they had killed several members of his beloved bear family, a distraught Dorion marshalled the animals of the wood and lead a swift, brutal assault on the orc camp. Dorion himself slew the orc chieftain in hand to hand combat, ducking around the slow clumsy blows of his greataxe and cutting him down. Afterwards Dorion searched the camp and found a baby orc crying desperately for his parents. Dorion could not bring himself to slay the innocent child and left the baby orc outside one of the major orc encampments. Fearing how his parents would react to his blatant acts of aggression Dorion fled from the island. For many years afterwards he travelled the wild learning all he could about the natural world. Gradually he understood how rash his actions had been and that alternatives to bloodshed should always be pursued if at all possible. Dorion generally spends most of his time in the wilds, living alongside the animals of the wilds. He will occasionally rest in a village paying his way with rare flowers and trophies from animals. Whilst he has mellowed over time Dorion is still a staunch defender of the natural world and can’t abide large cities and towns which don’t somehow incorporate nature into their construction.

Auri's older twin brothers were next in line to be the chieftain of her northern tribe when they both went missing during their ascendancy trials. Auri has traveled south to seek her brothers and to learn to become a leader should she need to take the trials herself.

It's an old story, really - a tribal people, trading with the city folk who lived on the good land, hunting and fishing and singing the songs of their ancestors, at least until the others come - with terrible weapons and sinister intent, they destroyed the tribe's home and chased them away into the darkness. The tribe roamed from spot to spot, settling here and there for a time, until finally finding a home among the people far from the ancient and terrible enemy.  Aquaria has lost track of her age. She was an adult, old enough to have mated and spawned, when the tribe found the ancient city, ending their long wandering after the Atlanteans had destroyed their rocky island home during the first flush of her adulthood. She remembers her joy at meeting the Dark Brothers (or so they called the city-dwellers), the glee at learning she would finally gain her true power as a Deep One - before finally she saw the horrific blood sacrifice of the city-dwelling cult of Dagon and Hydra. She fled, in horror - but where could she go, in a sea beset by her enemies, where even her own people were no longer her friends?  She picked the Surfacers and began a long, solitary journey up the East Coast of North America - she taught herself to read their language and understand the rudiments of their culture. When she learned of a Deep One attack against a Surfacer city, she headed that way - she'd heard confused stories of a Deep One hybrid leading the invasion forces and wanted to see what had become of it. So she showed her face in Freedom City - and promptly found herself battling superheroes. After all, this was just a few months after Archevil - nobody wanted to take any chances.  She nearly died in Blackstone, the air cold and dry, her voice echoing off the walls, alone - until she heard the halting echoes of Lemurian from the Surfacer outside her cell. An early volunteer for Project Freedom, her acclimation to Surface life - to the mistrust, the prejudice, the dry air, the bad food, the aloneness, was hard, but it was better than death.  And then things got even better when she met Singularity, aka Jessie White - she'd seen the Surfacer woman in a cell near hers in Blackstone and though they hadn't spoken then, the familiarity was enough to make them roommates at Project Freedom. Aquaria wasn't scared of Jessie's strange moods and desire for solitude - and Jessie didn't mind Aquaria's strange smells and bizarre habits so much. She was the first new member of Aquaria's pod.  Now they're free and living in the DuTemps Building, where their pod has grown substantially - even including friends who swim in the Sea of Stars. It's not the same as the world she left behind, but it's a good enough world.  She'll be reunited with her Deep One brothers and sisters again - when the stars are right.

The old world died on the night of December 31, 1999. As the sun dipped across the horizon around the world, the darkness brought with it a terrible Event - a sudden super-imposition of an unnatural forest across the landscape of the globe. Trees shattered roads and broke buildings, killing millions in architectural collapses and road accidents across the world as thick forest growth was suddenly everywhere, passing right through man’s technological civilization. The news media, and the Freedom League, had time to track the horrific event as it happened, beginning in eastern China and stretching across the planet with the terrible fall of darkness, time to observe that the new growth matched whatever forests were native to the landscape they were devouring - but not time to stop it. In the frigid days after the catastrophe, those few places that still had power were reassured by the government and by the Freedom League that help was coming. But no help came. It was the heroes who vanished first; the superheroes and brave humans who went into the forest looking for answers. And then the others began to vanish too - humans all over the planet left behind their families, their loved ones, and simply walked into the newborn Forest Primeval. The mystery of their disappearances was solved when they returned, feral and maddened by animal impulses and predatory desires, and began attacking the surviving human communities. The war between the Children of the Forest and the survivors of the old world lasted for several years and resulted in the deaths of most of the world’s surviving superhumans and many of the survivors - there was no treaty, no negotiation, no mercy - the Ferals simply stopped coming. Gradually the survivors learned how to cope with the new world - how to forage in the cities for food and gear without being caught by the Maddening Wild (avoiding the darkness was the key), how to resist the Maddening Wild’s call (sticking together in groups was the ticket), and about the small number of people, all of them without other superpowers, who had the ability to forage in the woods _without_ being maddened by the Wild. 2015 is the fifteenth year since the world ended. Freedom City lies, broken, by an impossibly old oak and pine forest in which trees with hundreds of years worth of rings lie at the heart of the civilization they impaled. The largest population of survivors lies at the edge of the city, a few thousand hearty souls dwelling in the community around the Raymond Nuclear Power Plant at the edge of North Bay. They can go into the city to scavenge and explore, but only during daylight hours. The Maddening Wild still calls - though perhaps less forcefully than it did in the grim days at the start of the new century. The woods themselves are haunted by the past - the murdered city they devoured, and what lies within.The Ferals themselves are dangerous enough, savage, animalistic humanoids, many of them with superpowers, but they are not the worst of it. The Forest Primeval came with animals too; bears and wolves and bobcats, all the creatures once endemic to coastal New Jersey. But they came back unnatural - too clever by half, and with an intelligence that has grown unnaturally in recent years. Bears have been seen in the Deep Woods wearing human clothing, and wolves howling to each other in some grim parliament. They have shown a terrible intelligence when fighting humans - hitting men carrying flashlights to blind them in the dark, making man-like noises to lure unwary travelers, and otherwise making it clear that the forest is theirs. Many kill not to feed - but to terrify the human survivors. The Forest is full of monsters - and the Forest is everywhere.   Riley Quinn was only about two months old at the Millennium. His parents, Casey and Peyton Smith-Quinn, lived in North Bay when he was born - their home was a mansion, small by the standards of the neighborhood, but spacious enough after the relative poverty of their youths in Mississippi. Maybe because they came from poverty themselves, with a history of dealing with emergency situations, they took action promptly on that terrible night of the 31st as the news of threatening global destruction came. When the Forest Primeval hit Freedom City, they had taken shelter at the nearby Raymond Nuclear Plant where his mother worked as a plant nuclear engineer, trusting in its solid construction to save them. And it did, to an extent - the Forest devoured the plant, too, but fate, radioactivity, and maybe just good engineering kept Raymond together. An oak tree's sudden growth shattered one reactor and a scrub pine forest sent one cooling tower cascading to the Earth in a deadly shower of debris, but quick hands prevented a meltdown and even kept electricity pumping from the plant's generators. It was a natural place to send refugees in the early days before the true horror of the situation had settled in.  Riley doesn't remember much about those days, but he's heard the stories a thousand times. The way the refugees at the power plant first scavenged for food, then began growing crops in their own right in the hastily-converted greenhouses. The way desperate engineers babied a wounded power plant, keeping two of five nuclear reactors alive and producing life-giving electricity even a decade and a half after the end of the world. The way they built a school, and a chapel, and a clinic, and a hospital out of the old plant, building an outpost to human dreams in the middle of an inhuman wilderness. The days when the Ferals hit the fences almost daily. The crack of gunfire, then of melee weapons, again and again. The heroic sacrifice of Lady Liberty, who finally succumbed to infection days after her last battle with the group of Feral metahuman teenagers who had so often led attacks against the reactors, willing to poison the whole city to stop the power plant. The horrific screams from Lonely Point as what had been the populations of Bayview and Port Regal, backed by a rampaging Feral Captain Thunder broke through the defenses. His father, whose cancer could have been easily caught five years earlier, and his grave in the old plant garden. Riley is almost certain he can remember his father's voice. For various reasons, Riley grew up dissatisfied with his lot in life. He had ample reason for this, raised in a community at the edges of a world murdered by the Forest Primeval. He knew how lucky they were, especially compared to other survivor communities that lacked things like power, machine shops, and other tools providing some echo of what had once been modern life, but he also knew from his exploration of the (long-since-picked-over) homes near the Raymond site just how much they'd lost. So he dreamed, in between schoolhouse lessons and chapel prayers, between working in the greenhouse and going fishing, of the world that had been lost - and the wonders that had once been his birthright. But most of all, when he climbed the long-deserted Cooling Tower #4 and looked out at tree-skewered Freedom, he dreamed of the lost city of Freedom, and wondered what secrets lay within.  Now these were no small dreams in the Raymond community, not when once a year or so someone would zone out and be sucked into the Maddening Wild, wandering into the Forest Primeval to either be eaten by animals or join the Ferals. So he kept them to himself as he got older, instead learning his mother's engineering skills with the idea of one day taking her place managing the reactors. But boys will be boys - by day he read technical manuals and worked in the machine shop, and by night he studied old city maps and the notes of those few explorers who had survived the journey into Freedom Primeval. On his fifteenth birthday, he presented himself to the Security Force as a volunteer for the Woodsmen, a dangerous, but highly valued part of life in their little community given the number of things the community's technology needed to survive - and how valuable the remaining scraps of super-tech scattered through the city still were. His mother wasn't happy - but after he demonstrated his skills at climbing and hunting, at marksmanship and hiding, even she couldn't say no.  Freedom Primeval was everything he'd dreamed - beautiful and terrifying, wonderful and dangerous, marvelous and lethal. He rested in the shade of the oak trees that had split Freedom Hall in half; he battled the wolf colony that had taken over lost Lincoln. He fought a desperate battle against the Feral pack in Bayview; he prayed beneath the pine tree cathedral in St. Sebastian's Church. From his fellow Woodsmen, he learned how to sneak and survive in the city, how to hunt and fish to keep himself alive (skills he'd already begun to learn in Raymond), and how to navigate the ruined metropolis. He also learned how to kill - building his own crossbow, he was able to fend off attacks from bears, wolves, and other of the too-clever, too-wise beasts roaming Freedom City. And the unclever beasts too - the savage, cannibalistic Ferals who might once have been people. It was grim work; but it was war. No - it was survival.  At the beginning of summer, 2015, Riley joined his fellow Woodsmen on an especially dangerous mission - a scrounging run into the heart of the Goodman Building, loaded with vital super-technology that, suitably adapted as spare parts, could potentially keep the Raymond reactors running for another decade and a half. But the risk was great. The Atom children had survived the Forest Primeval, though tree damage had eventually destroyed their grandfather's systems - but become a particularly bloodthirsty pack of Ferals. But the risk was greater than the Woodsmen knew - the Atom pack had, by whatever inhuman, unholy means, _bred_ - and a pack of Feral, superpowered younglings waited inside the tree-ruined building to greet them. Separated from the rest and trying to tune out the screams of horror he heard from his fellows, Riley ran. Fleeing down a darkened, overgrown emergency stair, he found his way blocked and so ducked inside what turned out to be a long-abandoned, nearly pristine research laboratory.  Fascinated by the discovery, Riley locked the doors behind him and wandered through what had once been Alexander Atom's sanctum sanctorum. He was particularly fascinated by one particular piece of technology; a big, circular, open disc mounted in the middle of the room - one that he realized with some shock still was powered up! Succumbing to temptation, he pressed a few buttons, bringing the big machine to life with a whine of long-dead circuits and the sudden sound of alarms! At the sound of fists pounding on the door he'd locked behind him and against the inhuman shrieks outside, Riley hefted his crossbow and dived through the hole to take up a firing position on the other side.  Except he found himself somewhere else entirely.  The Goodman Building had seen its share of dimensional refugees before and while Riley (or 'Woodsman' as he called himself initially, with vague memories of watching some old war movies on the projector in his school) was different than others, there was nothing particularly alien about him compared to some of the visitors they'd seen. He was kept in isolation for nearly two weeks, both to make sure he was no longer violent (he had made free use of his crossbow to try and escape the populated, brightly-lit, tree-free laboratory he'd stumbled into) and to make sure that whatever mysterious disaster had beset his homeworld wouldn't be coming with him. But nobody had any answers - consultants like Phantom and Harrier were unfamiliar with either the timeline he described or the kind of apocalypse that had destroyed his world's native civilization, and something seemed to make it impossible to return him to his homeworld. All attempts to trace the dimensional line that he carried with him led to tangled snarls along the generally smooth course of the Cosmic Coil.  Being unable to go home was hard. He knew his mother, his fellow Woodsmen, and his people would think he was dead - devoured by the Atom pack. And how strange it was to see them, alive and well, in a healthy, thriving city full of living human beings! As much as he missed home, he loved this place. He avidly read every book he could get his hands on and (once he learned how to use modern computers) and soon found himself taking online high school classes to keep up. He was behind in a lot of areas, but not too far behind - and determined to make up for lost ground as soon as possible. If he couldn't go home yet, and if even this world full of living cities and heroes had no answers for him, he could at least make himself better here. Once he was out of isolation, he could even go to the building's gym, where he kept himself in shape by exercise and drill, determined not to lose a step when he made it back home.  Riley was so focused on learning about Earth-Prime that he barely noticed when it was time to move out. He was shocked by the thought; where could he possibly go? But then his counselor told him remarkable news - news that in retrospect he could immediately have expected. On this world, Riley Smith and his mother Peyton lived in their North Bay mansion just as they always had after his father had divorced his mother six years earlier. (And what a strange thought that was!) And that other Peyton, upon learning that a dimension-lost version of her son was in Freedom City, had thrown open her doors to that other Riley.  They talked by email, then by phone, Riley a little surprised by his counterpart's voice - had he been born different in this universe? Riley and Riley met in one of the Goodman Building's rec rooms - Riley was reading a book while his counterpart, noticeably taller and heavier, entered the room, his sharp suit a contrast to Riley's flannel shirt, windbreaker, and jeans - all of them clothes he'd taken with him from his own planet. Riley met the eyes of his counterpart, saw his mustache and goatee, heard his deep-voiced, tentative greeting, and despite himself blurted out a question that, months later, still embarrasses him.  "Jesus! How did you grow a mustache?!" Riley had read about his condition in pre-Millennium books, of course - in the old days, men born with women's bodies had treated themselves with testosterone, the male hormone. But synthetic testosterone was out of reach of Raymond's medical facilities (an expanded version of the old plant's emergency clinic) and crystallizing it from other men was an idea that made him nervous. So he'd resigned himself to a lifetime of bulky clothing over tight bindings, and probably never getting so much as a girlfriend, much less getting married. But in the Prime reality, the chemicals were readily available - with a doctor's prescription, anyway. His double had come out to his parents at the age of 12 and had been transitioning (a whole new word!) ever since - and had been on hormones for years. This really was, he decided the first time he took a hormone shot, a wonderful dimension.  But of course it wasn't as easy as that. The two Rileys sharing a room was not the same as having a sibling; it was like having a shadow, and an alien one, at that. Riley-Prime was a smart kid on the school academic challenge team, a member of the Gay-Straight Alliance on campus and a future nuclear engineer. The other Riley was restless and angular, sleeping on the floor or a rope hammock, roaming the rooftops by night and converting the basement into a lab to rebuild his crossbow. One Riley had lost his beloved father to cancer and an early grave; the other Riley had lost his father to divorce when he was in his early teens. (It had been acrimonious - Casey hardly saw his family anymore) Competing for a mother's love, both of them young men going through changes, they clashed - and finally they fought. Healthy and strong though he was, Riley-Prime was no trained fighter; and the Riley from offworld hadn't learned to pull his punches.  The loss of his temper, the feeling of boiling, surging rage, and the look on Peyton's face all came together to make Riley feel for a frightening moment like he'd gone Feral - like he was the barbarian his counterpart had accused him of being. He grabbed his crossbow and jumped out his window, vanishing into the North Bay night over the alien sound of arriving sirens. Running away from the angry, frightened reflection of his mother, Riley roamed the city for four days, scrounging to survive and even stealing a dose of synthetic testosterone, before Bowman tracked him down and gave him two pieces of news. One was that his mother, and even his counterpart, had forgiven him - his counterpart had even reluctantly admitted to provoking him into the fight, even though Riley was pretty sure that had been all him. The other piece of news came from Bowman himself. He'd tracked Riley through the city and been impressed by his stealth and ability to survive - and had helped clean up after Riley had used some well-placed speciality crossbow bolts to take down a gang who'd been harassing homeless kids by the airport. Bowman couldn't help Riley figure out where he fit in on Earth-Prime, but he could make a suggestion - there was this school Bowman himself had graduated from...

orn in a small town outside Moscow in 1913, Dimitri Peshkov was not an attractive man in life. A bright student, he grew up lazy and a little jaded, convinced of his own intellectual superiority over his fellow students in high school and college. He became a veterinarian, tending to the animals in collective farms, out of a mild interest in helping those less fortunate but mostly for the chance to be the smartest and best-educated man in the room. When war threatened his country in 1941, he joined the NKVD, not the Red Army, not out of a special patriotism, but because he thought it would keep him away from the battlefield. He was wrong; and that would be the death of him. The old Dr. Dimitri Peshkov died beneath the sacrificial blade of the Thule Society in the spring of 1942. The NKVD doctor had been captured on the Arctic front during the defense of Murmansk and had, under the Commissar Decree, been handed over by the Wehrmacht to the SS for execution. He might simply have been shot, but a passing group of Thule mystics needed him for a special task. Operating in the far north under Kantor's commnd, the Thule circle had found an ancient Norse altar, consecrated to Hel and her father Loki, and had learned they needed human blood to open the gateway to another world. And so they did. But as Peshkov fell into darkness, a voice came to him. The life-long atheist found himself floating before Hel, the guardian of Niflheim and ruler of the Norse underworld, one of the first new arrivals in her realm in a long time. Hel explained to Peshkov, as one would to a child, that she could not be summoned to Earth by such powers the Nazis had. In the heart of the greatest war the world had ever known, Death already stalked the land, and no wizard could hope to control it. But she had seen the capture of her haughty uncle Donar, and knew the plans of the Thule Society for the world of men, and she loathed them for the blasphemers they were. So she offered Peshkov a choice. He was a descendent of Rurik and had died at the hands of her enemies; if he stayed in Niflheim in her palace, he could have a place at her side to tell her about the world above, and perhaps as master of those few Thule sorcerors who had fallen into her hands when they had died of disease or accident after taking up the worship of the Asgardians. Or he could walk the Earth again as a draugr, a being of great power and might, with the heart taken from him by the Nazis replaced by a gateway to the icy realm of Niflheim. Given the choice, Peshkov chose to live. If you could call it living. Dimitri awoke on the altar and froze his captors solid, burning their shrine down behind him and feeding on the heat within as he began the long, painful walk back to Soviet lines. He learned how to control his powers and feed from the heat of the sun, from burning fires and life's heat rather than life's blood, and when he arrived back among his own people (and immediately, wonderfully, was plunged into a hot bath...that he immediately froze solid), Dimitri Peshkov was ready to begin his new identity: Comrade Frost, costumed defender of the Soviet Union! But of course it wasn't that easy. Dimitri was the only one of his allies familiar with magic, something which his own government denied the existence of. Comrade Frost rapidly became the Peoples' Heroes' magic expert, a role he had to play very subtly. He took every chance he could to team up with the Allies of Freedom and the Liberty League, desperately trying to pool his resources with those better-connected and better-educated in these matters as he tried to stave off the threat of magical darkness at home. And there was the war, grim and terrible. Comrade Frost was one of the first Soviet super soldiers into Berlin, and was there for the last great convulsion of the Reich.His superiors denied his request to join the hunt for Kantor, and so he wasn't there when the Allies of Freedom were betrayed and murdered by the forces of darkness. It was a hard blow for the super-soldier and he slipped into a deep depression after the war. Only a battle against the snake-cultists of Lithuania roused him from his funk in 1948, the mystic-trained hero recognizing the cultists of Yig for what they were! If the cultists of the Unspeakable One and his dread allies had come to the Soviet Union, there were urgent matters to deal with indeed. His war wasn't over. Comrade Frost was not one of the better-known Soviet super-soldiers to the general public; he was just there in the various engagements with American heroes, German holdouts, Baba Yaga, and the other famous battles of the Peoples' Heroes but he was well-known to superheroes. Sometimes he was an enemy to mystic heroes in the United States and elsewhere, stealing mystic artifacts out from under their noses for the Soviet Union's use but for the most part he was an ally: a fellow enemy of darkness who could always recognize that there were threats to the universe as deadly as any nuclear missile. Briefly imprisoned in 1953, he was freed after Stalin's death. He was a busy man in the 1960s as Stalinist controls lapsed and the world of magic became more and more powerful in the Soviet Union, taking time out to fight Superior in Cuba in 1962 and war against the forces of Baba Yaga in the 1970s. Dispatched to Afghanistan in the late 1970s to help battle undead warriors summoned to life there by Muslim clerics, Peshkov was horrified at the violence and pointless waste of yet another war; when he returned home in the 1980s, he let others take over his role as magical champion while working to support Gorbachev's reforms. With the fall of the Soviet Union, Peshkov resumed his work as a defender of the world against magical threats, for the first time working regularly in countries besides the land of his birth now that he was free to travel. There was a whole world out there! Peshkov is currently assigned to Freedom City to act as the liaison between the Peoples' Heroes and the Freedom League, as well as deal with the worrisome reports he's heard about magical activity in Freedom City. Barriers he helped erect many, many years ago now are beginning to melt.

Butch' parents always wanted him to be strong and use his skill in the ring and by being muscle for hire to make them money, but he hated hurting people, so he ran away as a teen, and found an elf getting beaten up, and he defended her, and now he's a protector.

Once a minor mage in the Althori Empire, Zephyra was sent as part of an expedition to an dead lich's lair. Unfortunately, his traps and minions still proved effective, and she found herself the only survivor to reach the treasure room. Even worse, she looked upon a Mirror of Life-Trapping within and found herself locked in an extra-dimensional cell. After what seemed like an eternity of waiting, enough things were trapped within that she was released from her prison. Desperately, she ran out of the now empty treasure room, and found that the world outside was no longer the one she knew.

Imriel was the product of a union between Uriel, the head of a clan in the strict caste-based society of the Empire, and Jhessail, a travelling musician from the neighbouring kingdom of Kirisu. As a half elf (which made him an abomination in the eyes of the Empire) and illegitimate child, he was ineligible to inherit his father's title despite being the eldest child. This was a source of some bitterness for Imriel and soured his relationship with his father and younger brother, Michael. However, he was close with his sister Clariel. With the majority of the Meiji court refusing to see Imriel as anything other than an upstart, he began looking for ways to prove himself worthy of his family name. That was how he hit upon the idea of spying on a rival clan's heir, Lord Arai. He got himself a job as Ensign on the "Seraph's Grace", the ship in charge of taking Lord Arai on a tour around the Kirisu islands. When the ship was attacked, he decided to save Lord Arai to gain his trust and it was then that he met the rest of his fellow adventurers.

Abandoned at the doorstep of a temple of Torm, Sif had little idea about her parentage save for a mysterious amulet. She was raised in the temple and soon set her heart on serving Torm as a warrior, becoming deadly with a longsword and channeling Torm's power to heal her friends and smite her enemies. She loved to read stories of the heroes of old defeating dragons and other beasts of legend. When the chance came to leave the temple to go prove herself, she leapt at the chance. Setting off on a journey to Greenest with Jack, her fellow warrior of Torm, her focus was on spreading Torm's gospel and defending the weak.

Cal Tinnel was a cleric of Pelor the god of light and was loosely related to the Archbishop of his order (second cousin once removed). For this reason, though, he found favor in the eyes of the archbishop receiving perceived preferential treatment and his companionship.      This upset the rest of the order but things only got worse when the Archbishop fell mortally ill. On his deathbed, the Archbishop proclaimed that his successor would be Cal, which sparked an uproar from the rest of the older and perhaps wiser priests, particularly a longstanding priest named Gnoland.      Gnoland set out to find some sort of scandal or dark secret or anything to pin against Cal to show him unfit to be archbishop. Cal was aware of Gnoland’s plot but was confident that he was safe.      After months of fruitless searching and with Cal's inauguration nearing Gnoland sought one of Cal's closest friends, Lea Argelle, and promised him a high position in their order if he could divulge any damning evidence against Cal. Lea caved to his greed and shared that Cal had a lover, Wyn. While it was against the law of their order to take a wife, nothing legally stopped the priests from getting physical needs taken care of from time to time. Lea urged though that this was not a simple harlot but was like a wife to him. Gnoland knew that he would not be able to use this info directly to incriminate Cal but he planned to use her as leverage.      He and his guards set off to her location, as divulged by Lea, to take her into custody. This was not as easy a task as Gnoland had initially presumed, as Wyn was a seasoned adventurer before settling down after having met Cal. She killed two of the guards and wounded Gnoland before he ordered his remaining four men to kill her rather than capture her. She was the more skilled combatant but she was outnumbered and thus she was slain. Gnoland ordered his men to take care of the fallen guards and leave no evidence of their involvement making it look like it must have been outlaws that had murdered her.      When Cal heard that Lea had been consorting with Gnoland he rushed home only to find his love dead on the floor. He used all the healing magic he could but she was already gone. Knowing there was nothing he could do in his current state; Cal forsook his faith with Pelor and begged Wee Jas a goddess of death to bestow her power to him in an attempt to bring her back from the dead. Cal felt a new, darker power flow through his being. He cast aside his old holy symbol and etched the flaming skull of Wee Jas onto his ring that he wore to symbolize his love to Wyn. He cast his ritual to the extent of his ability but nothing happened.      Distraught, Cal thought his spell had failed but then Wyn started to move. As she stood up Cal was overjoyed! However, that soon turned to horror as he realized that this was not his love. Wyn’s body was moving but her spirit was not with her. The soulless husk of Wyn’s body groaned as it struggled to stay upright. Its dark eyes surveyed the dark room until it saw Cal; all of a sudden, it lurched violently towards him letting out an unearthly screech.      Cal resited the attack and managed to find a small hand axe left behind by one of the guards. Through tears, Cal slew the revenant and once again, his lover’s motionless body lay before him.      He knew that forsaking his devotion to Pelor would be heavily frowned upon let alone consorting with necromancy. Cal had to flee the city lest he too end up dead. Gnoland had won, Lea had betrayed him, and it seemed that all was lost.      He only had one goal as he set off; he had to grow in power so that he could one day bring back Wyn’s soul and bring Gnoland’s corrupted priesthood to justice.

As a half-orc, Jakor was the runt of his tribe, and so was thrown into the darkness. It was here, that his "small" stature and his natural stealth got him ironically noticed by the assassins of Shargaas. Under their tutelage, he became an excellent assassin for the tribe, up until his tribe leader fell under the influence of a demon lord. Under this power, tanarukks were born, both empowering the tribe, and tearing it apart. In disgust by the betrayal of their chief, Jakor killed him, but the damage was done. The monsters took over the tribe, and killed the followers of the Orcish Pantheon. Jakor left, forced to wander as he lacked the power to rid his tribe of these monsters.

Vera is one of the elvish princesses of the Summerset Forest, but has no place in the line of succession due to being a mute. Despite that, she refused to be useless, joining the Crown's Shadows, an elite group of guards and assassins with absolute loyalty to the crown, in hopes of achieving recognition despite her condition. Skilled and silent, she was looking to become an exceptional member until Duke Frost, a powerful fey spirit, assaulted the palace. With the royal family trapped in the palace, Vera was prepared to sell herself dearly alongside the rest of the Shadows, but it was not to be. Her father, in a final show of affection, ordered her to escape and live. Obligated by her orders, with tears in her eyes, she snuck past the enemy and escaped into the world, hoping to one day, if not restore her family's throne, then to avenge them.

Character's class (rogue, wizard, cleric: Bard/Paladin (or what I like to call a "pala-bard")
Character's backstory: Willa's story, like that of any other nobleborn, starts with her parents. Her father, Alastor Wise, is known throughout the Riordane Empire as the dear friend of the Last Emperor, having saved his life in circumstances that have been subject to the Empire's rumor mills (but does anyone know what really happened? Not really, no. Anyone who could tell you about the incident is likely dead.). Alastor, in truth, was a sculptor who believed deeply in the tenents of Yvaine, the goddess of love, and he was equally deeply in trouble when the Katalivorg family discovered their young daughter, Klara, was romantically involved with Alastor. He was just a yeoman artisan from the capital - and he was deemed "unfit for the fate of the family" by the Katalivorg patriarch, Adim.The Katalivorg family is known throughout Old Riordane as... questionably aligned. By no means were they darlings of the Empire or of even their own subjects. They just seemed somehow removed from the petty politics of the Empire. The Katalivorg family is cloaked in mystery and darkness, but they do wield some unnatural power. Klara grew up knowing that someday, she would be brought into the fold, but also knowing deep in her heart that she was not meant for it and was instinctually averse to becoming part of the Katalivorg legacy. Instead, she was attracted to light and beauty and good things, which eventually brought her to Alastor.Naturally, the Katalivorg's first move upon discovering this scandal was to find Alastor and have him killed by an assassin. Lucky for Alastor, Klara was an incredibly sneaky woman and she heard her family plotting her lover's demise without them even knowing. So, she packed a few things and took off into the night to find Alastor and run away with him. They came immediately to the Emperor's Palace in Abrogail to a warm welcome by the imperial family. Klara and Alastor spoke with the Emperor for many hours, and came out of the Palace in the middle of the night, now the earl and countess of what was now called "the Wiselands," and swiftly transported thence under an assigned troop of tuneless bards, who were really some of the Imperial Guard.Willa was the first child of Alastor and Klara Wise, born in the spring. She was raised humbly, given a grand education befitting the leader she was born to be, and grew up loving, to varying degrees, nearly everyone she ever met. Truly, she grew to be the best of both her parents, and even threw in some personal twists of being musical, poised in moments of negotiation, and unseemingly scrappy when negotiations broke down. Naturally, when The Tear randomly appeared in the middle of the Empire leaking goblins, she went headfirst into the aptly named Goblin War. The Wise family, though fearful for their daughter's life, knew that when a calling was placed on someone, it was placed for a damn good reason. So they let her go. And how Willa thrived. She gained trusted comrades, made decisions where all the options were double-edged, grew in skill both musically and in weaponry, grew in faith as she learned to forgive what was recognized as a problem by all involved parties, and was a fighter until the end.The night the Goblin War ended with the sacking of Abrogail and the murder of the entire Imperial family sent a shock to Willa's core. She knew the people whose bodies were now on pikes outside the ruins of Abrogail, even... even loved them. She knew that she had to go back to the Wiselands then, see the castle, hold her father, kiss her mother's cheek, give her brother Omar a noogie for old time's sake. It was then that what remained of Willa's battalion separated, many returning to their homes, but a fair number remaining with Willa, for they had no homes to return to. So, Willa and her band of lost soldiers returned to the Wiselands.Upon reaching the Wiselands, Willa had noticed that everything was silent, even in the small town near the castle. When her searching, perceptive eyes saw the drawbridge of the castle down and a little wrecked, she ran. When her comrades caught up to her, they saw something they were all too used to seeing - hundreds of bodies, all on pikes, and one person standing in the middle of the carnage, their very own Willa Wise. Unlike the other times, though, Willa was not weeping - she was still, unresponsive, emotionless, staring at the body of a man. It took a very long time for her to respond to their question of "Who is this?" All she managed was a small, "Dad," before an unnatural cry, seemingly ripped from her very soul, came out of her mouth and she collapsed at the dangling feet of her father and sobbed for so long. Her fellows carried her kicking and screaming from the castle when they saw soldiers dressed in black armor coming from beyond, carrying the banner of none other than the Katalivorg family.As they reached the forests beyond the farmlands around the castle, Willa had quieted, looking back at the castle with puffy, red eyes. Her fellows set her down, and immediately, she walked deeper into the forest. Her companions did not follow her. They knew she had things to think on.And think she did.As the night set in and she wandered the forest she had played in as a child, she came to a small clearing where the stars were so clear in the sky. She looked up, and after many silent minutes into her stargazing, she asked, "What will I do, Yvaine? I am so... lost." All of a sudden, a great bevy of stars began shooting across the night sky, her very body began glowing as brightly as a star, itself, and then, just before the light became too much for her mind to handle, a voice, feminine, soft, gentle, yet firm resounded around her, "You will fight, as you were born to do, Willa Wise." Then, she passed out. She awoke, as the sun just began to peak over the horizon, to someone's face nearly filling her eyesight. As she focused, she gasped as her heart began to fly.It was Omar.She began to laugh and cry with her dear brother whom she had feared lost forever. She held him, kissed his cheek - hell, she even gave him a noogie for old time's sake. Omar told her of the attack on the castle, how he was interrupted from his studies by their mother, how on their way to the kitchen, a bunch of goblins intercepted them and took Klara howling to her son to "RUN!", how the kitchen staff brandished their butcher's knives and rollers, meat hammers and pokers and defended him from the intruding horde of goblins as he escaped through a secret passage behind an oven. Omar had run into the forest, and watched the goblins, maniacally laughing as they hoisted black banners with the Katalivorg standard to the skies, leave nearly as quickly as they had come. The town was left unpillaged, but they all knew what had happened. The citizens were merely waiting for their new rulers to come, and they were quaking in their boots. They knew who the Katalivorgs were.At that moment, Willa knew what she'd be doing now. She had received her blessing from Yvaine. She walked with Omar in her wake as she lit herself up again and she burned like the morning sun. She returned to her compatriots and said to them, "Friends, the war is not over for me yet." She outlined a plan of expedient guerrilla tactics and robbing the Katalivorg nobles to give to the needy vassals and yeomen of the surrounding lands. "But, Willa, what of Yvaine? Is this not against her tenants?" one of her comrades asked. Willa gave a mirthless grunt of laughter. "No. Yvaine has given me the calling to fight for this. We're going to give these motherfuckers a price for the invasion of the Wiselands."And so they have been for the past few months, becoming folk heroes, not just in the Wiselands, but beyond. Willa herself has allowed herself her humanity again, to see beauty and happiness and laughter, despite the troubled times. Her Omar, darling baby brother he will always be, was never cut out for violence, and so has instead invested himself to traveling as much of the world as he possibly can and putting what he sees down on a map. He plans on returning soon, having written to Willa that he was traveling to explore the city of Ulkenbac in the Ashlands. Feeding her unease about her brother's safety, that letter was written two months ago. There has been no letter since. So, she has set out from the Wiselands to find her brother - hopefully alive.
Mother killed by orcs

Aidan wanted to be a paladin. He'd spent years in the local church of Azuth, the main god in the area as his town was built around a wizard college, training to become a paladin. After many years of training, he finally took his solemn vigil to commune with his god. And Azuth finally spoke to him to inform him his connection to the divine was unfit for use as a paladin. However, he was told to talk to the college about becoming an eldritch knight. Disappointed, yet happy that his god had given him a path, he spoke to the wizards who found he was rather bright for a paladin in training, and switched him over to learn the ways of magic. Once his training was complete, he set out to bring good and justice to the world as an eldritch knight, and maybe some books for the college library as repayment for their teaching.

Goragog lived under the blood sodden banner of the "Sand Scar Horde", a chiefdom of Nomadic Desert Orcs who roamed the Wurm wake Wastes. Wandering from town to camp to trading post, raiding and burning each settlement, and cementing their dominance over the valley. Nazur was the son of the Horde's Warchief: A high pressure position in such a cut throat hierarchy. His name was also Goragog, though his clansmen called him "Gog". As the Warchief he was expected to lead from the front, wielding a gargantuan pyramid block as a hammer (The "Unmaker" they called it) and riding a Dire-Jackal, the symbol of his house. His mother, Urug Nazur, was the clan seer and "Earth speaker" responsible for communing with the land, and more importantly the Worms. One day, when young Goragog was just 7, his mother was kidnapped by a human caravan of nobles who attempted to force her into protecting them from the Purple worms who ruled the area. She refused. resulting in the caravans death from a worm attack, as well as hers - their bodies were never found.The night before a raid on a fort, founded and defended by the same family of humans responsible for Urug's death, the chief disappears, seemingly without trace. The majority of the horde put his sudden vanishing down to cowardice, though his closest advisers disagree, calling it "out of character". As a result his eldest son, who happened to be Goragog, was made to take his place, leading the next morning's raid.Goragog rode the Jackle, Goragog wielded the "Unmaker", and Goragog was ready to take his father's placeBut the journey was long, and the warband were forced to set up camp, however in the middle of the night an ambush was launched on the army by the very people they were riding to face.But Goragog wasn't in the camp, he was about half a mile away with no memory as to how he got there. He woke behind a jagged rock with an eldritch rune carved into his hand and a voice in his head.The voice revealed itself to be Dendar, and explained it had given him it's boon to seek revenge, his father, and the true destiny of his mother

Gork once think good. Gork was tactic man. Gork thought of good plans, liked using berserkers as shock troops. Many did, but Gork didn't care, they got job done. They liked how Gork always got them in the thick of fight anyway. Once day, Gork camp was hit by ambush. Gork took major blow to head and knocked out. Only survived because one of berserkers dragged me to safety before charging back into fight. Gork couldn't think right, but Gork was mad at sneaky people for killing my guys. GORK BECAME MAD! Gork only remembers waking upon among many dead bodies, holding great ax. Gork couldn't remember which side he'd been on. Gork decided to start wandering, he wanted the thrill of fighting once again.

Arabella was born Mary Leach, the natural child of an affair between an elven wizard and a human servant. She never knew her father. Growing up a servant in a great castle, she had access to an impressive library, and read widely, even teaching herself magic when she discovered she had inherited her father's talents. Arabella ran away from her mother at the age of 12. She changed her name for her father's and took up with circuses and travelling shows, where she learned to cheat and deceive people. Eventually, she became a con artist, bamboozling yokels with 'elven magic' while a partner robbed them, or selling fraudulent charms and potions. They later moved on to more advanced schemes, insinuating themselves into high society and preying on the gullible rich. Six months ago she and her partner racked up a huge debt putting together a con on a powerful noblewoman, but things went south. The noblewoman caught wind of the scheme, Arabella's partner was killed, and she still owes the money she borrowed to unscrupulous creditors. Since that job Arabella has been laying low, searching for any way to make back the money without drawing too much attention - and, ultimately, to avenge her partner's death.
Serves her god, Chauntea, by brewing beer at the local brewery!
After her gnome village was destroyed by goblins, she took to the streets and the woods to survive.

Heir to a throne meant to unite the Elven and Human kingdoms of a distant land, Xanwraith had a stressful childhood. Viewed by most more as a symbol than a person, they resented their position, but loved their parents. When raiders invaded, killed their parents, and took their throne, they ran into the forest, where they enountered an Archfey. In their hurt and desperation, they swore to the being that they would serve it's quest, in exchange for the power to take back their throne. After making the deal, it told them to get on a ship, and go to another land, where they could train without fearing being murdered. After spending several months on board, where they learned to entertain the sailors in exchange for passage. When they arrived, they settled into this new city, establishing themself as a con artist extrodinaire, a position they still hold. They spend their days drinking wine, pulling card tricks, and seducing anything that walks, waiting for a sign from their patron that a quest is ready for them.

Panda was a giant panda for nine years, living a simple panda life eating bamboo, sleeping, and doing other panda things. That is, until one day when he was captured by a group of Yuan-ti, evil lizard-creatures. They were part of a cult doing experiments with dark magic, trying to create a soul-less army by fusing animal spirits with humanoid beings. Their experiments found some success with Panda -  he became a human that, like a panda bear, was extremely thick-skinned, and when enraged could withstand significant amounts of damage before losing consciousness. However, they soon realized that Panda still had his soul and free will intact. The experiment with him was done and they had the data they needed, and since he could not be easily controlled like they wanted, they sold him off to Underdark traders.After two years Panda was finally able to escape to the surface, where he eventually settled in the outskirts of Balder’s Gate, finding work doing manual labor when necessary but largely living off the land, eating plants, fruits, and whatever else he could find. He yearned for his simple life as a panda and tried to relive it the best he could, and for a couple years he was largely successful.One day, however, Panda needed some money as he ran out of supplies, and went into town to look for work. He entered his usual tavern hoping for a job only to find himself in an unexpected place…

Calliope was raised by her aunt and uncle on the Moonshae isles. Seeking meaning in an otherwise chaotic world, she joined the church of Torm, and was trained as a paladin. When Torm called for her to kill her her street smart, rogue friend and member of her party she went full grey guard, but eventually joined the church of Lathander.

Even as a young child, Cirri had innate Psionic power, but it caused such trouble that his parents moved all around the country before finding a School that would accept him. The trade off was that his parents had to pay extremely inflated Tuition fees, and the school catered mostly to Magical Studies, only a small and laughably shabby class for students of Cirri's talents.For the next few years Cirri rose in both knowledge and psionic power. Yet near the end of the 4th year, he began to feel far inferior to the many mages he spent  his school days around. During the fall of his Sophomore year, His close friend showed him his Fall Project, A Shield Guardian, 10 feet of hardened stone and glittering steel that stood proudly in the town square. It could do anything a human could do, and could be ordered to do such at the whim of its creator. Truly in awe, Cirri asked his friend to teach him all there was to know about making such a beautiful creation.  Immediately he sat about putting his grand scheme into action.By the middle of his Junior year, Cirri, with the  had sculpted the perfect body, had his friend help him do the small magical components needed to force the thousands of pounds of material to bend to their combined will. The very last step though, His friend could not help him. Cirri was informed of its Sliver, a tiny crystal embedded within the head of the  Shield Guardian that contained a small piece of its creator's soul. That was the most important part, without the sliver it remained amazing in form, but useless as anything more than a statue. But Cirri said not to worry, for he had been operating with Psi Crystals since his first year of school. He had learned a myriad of uses for them and they were second nature to him. A Crystal is a Crystal after all... What could go wrong?Cirri began preparations of another Psi crystal, this one enchanted by his friend and left as an open receptacle. He had no idea how such tiny differences in appearance and procedure could dramatically alter his fate. In the Psionic world crystals were used to hold a tiny portion of your consciences, a mere fleck of who you were as a person. This allowed greater focus, for this fleck was beyond mortal concerns and could shed insight on any problem, but in your own words and feelings. They were of an immense help to a Psion. Psicrystals, however, worked totally counter intuitively to  the Control Crystals used to produce a shield guardian's eternal loyalty. Cirri, of course, had not a clue nor care in the world.As he finished all the required gestures and incantations, Cirri reached deep into his mind to perform the final act, the act of shaving off a tiny portion of his being to inhabit the crystal. A blinding flash of searing pain later, He was picking himself off the floor... with hands not his own.In his great rush, Cirri, eager to have nothing more than a new toy, had instead transferred his mind and soul into this crystal, leaving none to inhabit his real body. After a great bit of wailing and sadness shared with his family, Cirri and his parents sought out the greatest healers, mages, and psions in their kingdom but came home unable to deny the horror of the situation. Hours later, crying but unable to shed actual tears, his mother and father helped as he used his new gleaming body to bury his own flesh and blood in the local cemetery. Seven thousand years later, through wars, droughts, plagues, the rise and fall of empires, the one-by-one death of everyone he has ever loved, and uncountable sleepless nights, walks a Brilliant Metal Man with power beyond words. But in the myriad of days since his death and rebirth, there is one thing Cirri Gragarren is most proud of. He has finally learned to cry.

A blacksmith-in-training apprenticed to an abusive father, he married young, only to have his pregnant wife turned into a dog by a terrible curse.  When the game begins, his goal is to finish his journeyman piece so he can go in search of a cure that will turn his wife back into a human again.

He is the heir to an ancient curse upon the kings of the Bear People.  He lost his power to change shape between man and bear at will when he inherited the rulership of his people -- a curse which tends to drive the Bear Kings mad.  He can break the curse only if he finds a queen and a steward who are both willing to pass through fire, water, earth, and air for his sake.  The catch is that he can't tell anyone how the curse is to be broken; they more or less have to stumble upon the answer.  So far, over hundreds of generations, no one ever has ... but with his loyal steward by his side, he thinks he's found someone who just might be able to save his lineage.

A werewolf bit him when he was 16, he became one of them and ate all his family during him first moon. During the cure he learned lycantropia is not natural, he is hunting evil for revenge and hope to kill the origin of his curse one day.

John McClane was a young, fast rising detective in the Waterdeep city watch. While visiting his wife Holly in Neverwinter, he fought off a terrorist attack (by the Zhentarim). He got slightly famous for doing so, and unfortunately found the new notoriety interfered with his day job. Nothing was simple anymore, especially expectations and he’s peers’ candidness. Jon didn’t cope well with this; he kept it in. His previous disagreements with Holly began to compound and overflow when he shut her out of his troubles. After one particularly bad shift, he came home to find a letter from Neverwinter: she has new opportunity and she’s cutting him loose to give it her all with a clean slate. She didn’t tell him what or where. (We’re in the beginning of Die Hard 3 here.) His spiral went deeper. He was soon suspended, demoted, suspended again, and ultimately transferred to police the northern roads reaching to Thornhold and Amphail. (The City Watch usually doesn’t operate outside of the city walls, but apparently one of the Masked Lords of Waterdeep… motivated the Commander of the Watch to make an exception.)This unique and solitary jurisdiction turned out to suit John well. He slowly found some peace with himself in this more isolated job --- one he’s excelling at again --- at the thinner edges of civilization. There are still good people living here, putting in hard work, taking care of each other, and fighting off the wilderness with barely token help from the city’s nobles back behind their walls.Over time John found the core Waterdhavian laws that most tenaciously uphold have been now revealed to be reflections of those of Nature and the balanced participation of people in. Ten years later, he’s now a Ranger, cooperating loosely and at a distance with the druids and rangers of the Emerald Enclave to stop the world’s vile, unnatural threats wherever and whenever (preferably before!) they rear their ugly face. (He’s not yet a member of the Enclave, but trusts their judgement and accepted their employ, which has taken him farther and farther into the wilderness.) He’s long since retired from the Waterdeep city watch, but his Emerald Enclave tasks do occasionally drag him reluctantly back into the human strongholds of the North: Waterdeep, Neverwinter, and so on. Returning to those places haunted by his old life never goes well, and he avoids it as much as possible.Now that he’s centered himself, John has relaxed his focus on Enclave matters just enough to start wondering about a new mission: finding Holly and making things right again, showing her his new life.
Her mother died when she was a child and she turned to prostitution and quickly turned to assassination whenever the clients wouldn't pay her

Brynna grew up in a small village in a family of four, joined by her parents and younger sister, Rosia.  She learned to be bard at a young age, strumming a dulcimer left by a stranger at her parents' shop. As she grew older, her talent for music did as well, and she was given her big break by an innkeep she had been working for. She started playing once a weeknight, then twice, then on the weekends as her audience grew. Soon, she was encouraged to move to the capital and play there. In the capital, she soon learned of the struggles between the ruling aristocracy and the citizens of the city. She became a folk singer, a champion of the people, calling for the end of injustice. Eventually, she joined a group of anarchists, meeting in secret and planning attacks on the homes, workplaces and loved ones of the aristocrats.  A few years later, during one covert meeting, a man ran in, shouting that they had been found out.  During the resulting chaos, she scooped up any paper with her name on it and burned it. She hid while her co-conspirators stood and fought and died. Afterwards she went home for a while, trying to reconcile with her cowardly actions. Only now has she begun to move back into the public sphere.

Nian Asphodel was born to sun elf nobility. "Her aunt" is the Queen of Ilyasharun and she grew up living a charmed life. The youngest of four sisters she was expected to marry well and do her family proud by becoming accomplished in the arts. But when her oldest sister ended up in a magical coma due to the result of domestic violence Nian endeavored to become a Paladin.
Former slave set free, now looking to avenge their murdered family.
Riding the trusty mammoth Tiny, Lari strives to drive out the armies of demons that threaten his homeland.

Mattais is a half-orc born to a human mother who loved him dearly, but she was sickly and when she found out she was terminally ill, she went in search of a magical cure. Poor and unsure if she would live or die, she left her son with the only people who would take a half-orc child in: a war cult.Young Mattais found himself, surrounded by humans who worshipped violence and saw orcs and by extension half-orcs as mindless killing machines. He found himself fighting to retain his sense of self while people tried to raise him to be what they thought half-orcs should be. When Mattais reached majority and finally left the cult, he went on a search to find what happened to his mother.
