The real journey though is to find himself.
From the mean streets of Absalom, Constantine always looks out for himself, but firmly stands against all forms of discrimination that impact him personally.
Urchin. Raised with humans.

Was a street urchin and don't remember much about parents (drow-elf male and human female slave). My mother was freed (into Neverwinter) with me when I was born by a single act of kindness by my father, but my mother died when I was young.  I tried to pickpocket a silver dragonborn cleric, who caught me. Instead of seeking punsishment, he saw potential and brought me to Temple of Oghma to train as a knowledge cleric. There the pursuit and spread of knowledge held the highest value.  This cleric also revealed to me that nature had fallen out of balance, and if not fixed dark days were coming. I left the temple to explore the world and accumulate knowledge to bring back.In Phandolin, I learned that Kaylar Darkstorm (owner of the PseudoDragon) also sense great darkness.When leveling to 6, instead of insight and a 6th cleric level from Oghma, a being from the Far Realm (another plane) called the King in Yellow reached into my mind, making a pact, promising to teach me the unknowable (and left the impression I didn't actually have choice to say no anyway). I awoke with 1 level of warlock (pact of the ancient one).

Fritz Hanswurst was born in the wagon of a travellin’ show; his Mama used to dance for the money they’d throw. Fritz learned, from an early age, how to accompany her dances on various instruments—lute, flute, concertina, bones—and how to collect the thrown money before the drunker folks in the front of the crowd tried to reclaim it and turn it into more ale. He and his younger sister, Helena, would seamlessly trade off musical duties to take turns fetching the coins that showered the stage (or, in harder times, sprinkled it) while ducking the whirling limbs of Mama and their two older sisters, Berthe and Marja.  In between dances came the songs, the stories, the jokes, the acrobatics. Fritz and Helena sang treble against Berthe and Mama’s deeper contraltos; Marja, not much of a singer, was the money collector then, but when it came time to get the crowd laughing, she took command of the performance. All of the children were acrobats—Mama had trained them, almost from birth it seemed, to juggle, flip, balance, leap, and twist in ways that made women gasp and men struggle to pretend they hadn’t gasped just as loudly. During the acrobatic segments, their rickety wagon barely managed to support the more elaborate routines, many of which threatened to hurl the Hanswurst children out into the audience, all of whom waited breathlessly for just such an instance. The only one who didn’t take part in any of this was Papa. Fritz’s Papa wasn’t a singer or a dancer, a juggler or a comedian; all of those gifts came from Mama. Papa would do whatever he could—preach a little gospel, sell a couple bottles of “Dr. Good.” Dr. Good wasn’t really that different from the ale the drunks wanted, but at least the coins that paid for the Dr. ended up in the family’s tattered purses, not stuck to the bar of some seedy village saloon. The gospel Papa preached changed from town to town, depending on the local God. That was Papa’s gift; he could make a crowd feel a religious ecstasy the priests of the temples never could. During his speeches, nobody moved to collect coins or to throw them, but after he was done the shower usually began in earnest, enough to require all the children at once. Fritz hated all of it: the singing, dancing, juggling, preaching—especially the preaching—and the travelling. The wagon wasn’t big enough for them all to sleep inside, so he usually ended up on the ground under it, huddled up against Helena with only one ratty blanket between them. Papa’s snoring, as thunderous as his prayers, shook the wagon nightly, pelting them with the grit that had settled into the boards over the long days of roaming between villages and towns, or during the even longer days of show after show in the cities. It hadn’t been so bad when Fritz was younger, sleeping inside the wagon with Mama, but when Helena was born he’d been kicked underneath, and he had only stopped resenting her when she chose to join him in his exile, warming him more than the blanket ever had. He still resented Mama and Papa. Life changed when Fritz was twelve, and not just in the way that life changes for everyone at about that age. For Fritz, those intimate, personal changes spurred him to bigger ones, ones that disrupted the family routine for everyone. In Riversend one evening, after a particularly successful run of performances, the family dispersed to purchase the supplies they needed for their next sojourn, through Tal Morai to Easar and stopping everywhere along the way and some places that weren’t. Fritz, with Helena in tow, was to purchase tar—the wagon had long needed patching, and there was nowhere in the kingdom where tar was cheaper. The man (or boy really, but 16 seems like a man to a twelve-year-old) who was selling tar at the first booth the children encountered was stunning. Perfectly formed, in Fritz’s eyes, the man was slender, pale-skinned, and had close-cropped hair that might have bespoken a need to keep his head tar-free, but to Fritz appeared just the height of fashion. Fritz gaped and stammered and bought twice the tar the family needed, at nearly three times the price it was worth. He was smitten. When Mama saw the amount of tar he and overburdened little Helena brought back to the wagon camped outside of town, her eyes hardened. When she heard what they had paid for it, they nearly popped out of her head. Her furious berating far outdid anything Papa was capable of at his loudest, whether preaching or snoring; she nearly upended one of the buckets over Fritz’s head, but Marja restrained her, and she merely slopped it onto the already black and stinking soil. After some adroit questioning from Berthe, Helena revealed the reason for Fritz’s fiscal irresponsibility, and the younger women nodded knowingly; they’d seen the young tar merchant in question, and they could tell precisely why poor Fritz, usually so good with money for his age, had been no match for his salesmanship. Mama and Papa were far from pleased, but there was nothing they could do—the tar merchants didn’t take their wares back. A few more choice words from Mama, with supportive growls from her husband, and the matter was closed. But for Fritz, it was far from over. The young tar merchant, all unknowingly, had shown him a whole new world, a dazzling place that seemed far from the muddy tracks between towns and the flashy performance that filled every other waking moment. In this world, there were beautiful young men instead of bossy older sisters; dozens of strange faces to observe each day instead of the five he had memorized years ago; and stable, stationary canvas booths instead of rolling wagons with no home. There was only one thing about the old world that he actually liked, the collecting money part of the show, and the new world seemed to have that part all the time! That was the last night Fritz spent under the wagon watching the paint peel and shutting his eyes against the falling silt. Early the next morning, before anyone else had even begun to consider waking up, Fritz was ready to go. He had stowed everything he needed inside one of the now-empty tar buckets before going to sleep, and now he slipped quietly out from under the blanket and picked up the bucket. As he turned back to bitterly spit towards the life he had always hated so, Helena sat up and silently waved goodbye. Fritz swallowed the spit and a sudden lump in his throat, waved back, and trudged off back toward Riversend. “Jack” had been called that for sixteen years now. Since leaving his family and his all-too-recognizable name, he’d seen nearly as many towns as he saw in his first twelve years. His dream of a stable life was no more than a childhood memory, and a none-too-pleasant one. A penniless boy has very little to offer the world and the world has even less to offer him—at least for free. Jack had matured quickly (with the help, one memorable fortnight, of that selfsame tar merchant), and he discovered early on that his Mama’s training served him well in areas quite distinct from theatrical performance; for about fourteen years now he’d been making his living as a thief. Agility, speed, and a sure-handed grace with a knife had gotten him far in the kingdom—both figuratively and literally, as he didn’t care to stay in any one place long enough for the law or his family to catch up with him.  The bitterness that Jack had felt toward the family had not faded over the years. Rather, the disillusionment that had followed on the heels of their estrangement had simply increased and generalized the bitterness; Jack didn’t like much of anyone anymore. He barely remembered why he felt that way, but he knew that the only person who really mattered was his youngest sister, Helena, and that he wouldn’t ever see her again without having to go back to the false smiles, incessant energy, and incredible discomfort of being an itinerant entertainer. He was in no way inclined to try that again, and he had absolutely no idea that being a thief who pretended, in well-lit and well-populated areas, to be anything but, was really quite a similar occupation.  Recently, Jack had decided to move from back-alley thievery to a higher-class, more breaking-and-entering burglary. Availing himself, after long years, of the musical half of his training, he purchased a few instruments—showing his roots even more—and used his reluctant but polished performances as opportunities to case rich houses. Never performing more than once in a town, so as not to be remembered by the cultural elite, he began to amass quite a bit of wealth (for a thief), and decided to attend a party of movers and shakers at the home of the Baron Orran...

Casimir came from a magical community called the Fold (basically, think of a cloister crossed with an Amish settlement populated by magically-adept halflings, and tucked away in an extradimensional space). In the Fold, people communicate through telepathy, using ideas and sensations, so no one learns spoken or written language. You’re allowed to leave as an adult, but you can never come back, because the Fold is magically guarded and impossible to find. He left because he didn’t believe what people told him, that the world outside is a terrible place. But so far they were mostly right, so he’s sort of on a lowkey quest to prove that there are good things in the world. Of course, Casimir's only been speaking for the few months since his quest began, so he’s very bad at expressing himself, tending towards odd gramatical constructions and completely inscrutable metaphors. Nonetheless, he fell into the company of a band of adventurers, who were glad to have an arcanist, and tolerated his strangeness while he picked up the quirks of language.
Raised in a dockside tavern in waterdeep, his aptitude for magic was noticed at a young age and he left at the age of 12 to begin his studies at the Hosttower in Luskan.

Born of the last tree cut down in a sacred forest. As the axeblade struck, Ironbark leapt from the tree fully formed and struck down the lumberjack, bent on revenge. They cut down every lumberjack involved with cutting down their sacred forest, so now what?

Risal grew up in an Orphanage for monstrous children whose parents had been killed by adventurers. As one of the more long lived races at the orphanage during her teenage years she became quite adept at mediating and breaking up fights between other orphans. She was happy there. However the orphanage being located way out in the wilds where pitchfork wielding humans were unlikely to venture, opportunities for arcane advancement were limited. When the time came that Risal was more caretaker than vulnerable orphan and space was needed for more orphaned intakes, Risal declared herself the most able to survive on her own out there in the world. She left. In search of Arcane secrets she negotiated passage on a ship to a foreign land. Already deeply suspicious of adults Risals formative travels did more to increase her suspicion and paranoia than alleviate them. Now somewhat embittered towards the rest of the world she dreams of building a sanctuary city in the sky where she can grant refuge to those persecuted on the land below.

Runa's childhood was peacefully spent in a tropical undine enclave. Spending her days fishing and playing with her best friend and younger brother. Wanting to see more of the world she found work aboard a sailing ship. It was a good gig until a storm hit. The mast was falling... and 100 years passed. She wakes in a strange metal box, a magical glow fading. Stumbling into the nearest settlement she discovers she must have been in stasis, the rest of the crew is also awake but no one knows how they got to be put in stasis, it's certainly technology beyond what anyone seen before. Grateful for the long lifespan of Undine Runa goes home to find her brother married to her best friend. they've had children, her parents are elderly but well and... life will never be same. She;s no longer the person her brother looks to for advice. She has remained the same yet everyone else has changed. She doesn't stay long. Going to the nearest free port she once again seeks work as a sailor but is kidnapped! Awakening from stasis aboard a ship a week later she pulls a sleeping kitchen hand from his bunk, shoving him in the pantry and taking on her appearance she bluffs her way through most of the voyage until a cleric confronts her. Fortunately this cleric already had suspicions about the ships cargo and is opposed to slavery. With new allies Runa's fortune is looking up.

Rosemary grew up in the Reid clan, a long-time Jedburgh family known for their thriving masonry business. She has many brothers, probably not worth naming for a one-shot. She grew up a committed tomboy and, together with best friend Jon, a comics and horror movie junkie. They spent many all nighters watching gore-fests on bootleg dvds, and pinky-swore they'd go on to better things together. When Jon disappeared, she went completely goth - forgot any ambitions, worked in the family business and other odd jobs, smoked a lot, and watched a TON of terrible movies. By the end of her 20's, she had become a fixture at The Pit, the local comic and DVD shop owned by Kurt Wilson across from the graveyard. She gave her life to that shop, started bringing in the cool horror anime and collectible figures. She even started a video blog, The Last Girl's Revenge, where she reviews cult classics and deconstructs the genre. She has a bit where she pretends all horror has a shared mythology, unravels the logic behind the monsters, and floats outlandish theories that catch on in certain fan circles. She does a lot of mail-order business.These days she runs The Pit, having almost completely bought out Kurt. She's a sensible business woman and has no other life, having mostly exhausted the local dating pool due to her low tolerance for bullshit and unwillingness to change her life in any way. She's only mildly goth now - still the black hair and nails, but just as likely to throw a flannel shirt over her Hills Have Eyes t-shirt. She knows every suburban myth and true-crime story in the county, as well as anybody who's ever had countertops put in.

Tamoni grew up as the middle child of her large family in an isolationist orc compound. She trained to defend the compound from threats. She always felt like she was missing out on something. When she was about 17 an injured human adventurer stumbled into the compound and spent some time there recovering. The adventurer spent a lot of time talking up her adventures to Tamoni who developed a crush - and a new goal. She wanted to explore the world, become a famous adventurer and kiss a lot of girls. When she was an adult, against the disapproval of her parents, she went out into the world where in the fullness of time she met her friends, The Wyrd Company and the plot started.
His precious beholder-skin bagpipes were lost in a contest and he has vowed to use his celebrity among the military to aid him in getting them back.

Demaile's parents loved him and each other, both are still alive.  Curiously, they're both half-elves, he's pretty sure he's a half-elf, too - which puts him well ahead of many of his racial peers who can't decide whether they're elves with human blood or humans with elven blood.He had a happy childhood, with no more than the usual aches and growing pains.  He got his sense of humor from his father and his impetuousness from his mother.  Both parents are often proud, usually exasperated, and always amused by his pranks and exploits.He finds paladins absolutely hilarious and will often pretend to be one if he needs to take on an alternate identity.  He's been more or less successful, depending on how much effort he's willing to put into the gag - considering he usually claims to be a paladin of Ahaz, this trick is rarely successful with people who know a thing or two about religion.  He generally expects people to be foolish, uninformed, or simply inattentive, and is often correct.He steals what he needs from those he thinks have more than they need, but generally prefers tricking them into giving it to him.  He'll put in an honest day's work if he absolutely has to, but it's a last resort.  He seldom keeps what he gets, though.  It's not so much that he squanders his earnings, but rather he is supremely confident in his ability to get more if he needs it again, so he sees no reason to save up.He prays to Ahaz pretty much constantly, usually half in jest, but also half seriously because he always needs the luck.  The day the god actually answered one of his prayers directly involved a traveling lord, the lord's daughter, a herd of pigs, and most of a jug of rum.  The lord, for his part, is still proud of the assistance he was able to render to the Holy Paladins of Ahaz.  The daughter also remembers the incident fondly, with only marginally more accuracy.  Demaile, who is the only one who really knows what happened (with the exception of some of the parts involving the rum) came away with a slight limp where his foot didn't quite heal properly, an intimate piece of women's apparel (that he promptly lost), and the lord's signet.  He also emerged with a newfound respect for what it really means for Ahaz to answer a prayer.  He considered it a sobering lesson up until his foot healed enough that he could dance again, at which point he decided that it was, instead, an exciting lesson, and he has been a devoted follower of Ahaz ever since (as much as he is devoted to anything).  He keeps the lord's signet and uses it the way most other clerics would use a holy symbol.  It also comes in handy if he needs to forge something official-looking, so that's nice, too.Of course, if you ask him his history Demaile won't tell you any of this.  He'll tell you something involving dragons and orphans, and perhaps a dark ritual gone awry, a quest for vengeance, or whatever else suits his fancy.  If he considers you interesting or important enough, he might even tell you the same story the next time you ask him, but probably not.

So!Eli doesn't know her parents. She was left at the Monastary of the Blooming Dagwood when she was three or four – the monks aren't even really sure, just that this small girl was left with only a note bidding them to raise her, and a small necklace with a a pair of simple steel rings – wedding bands with no obvious clue as to the owners. They, being monks, of course took her in and started raising Elisa Warsong, a girl with a quick grin and easy humor, that gave everyone a good boost of energy.She lived there until she was seventeen, learning how to craft tools from the wood of the orchards of dagwood that were always in season, helping with tasks, and being the youngest member of a community that normally took people in at the age of sixteen.That was when Rieta came into her life – a Tiefling woman clad in a travellers cloak and the clothing of a scholar, not there to commit herself to the celibate teachings of the Blooming Dagwood monks, but to learn from them, and perhaps, should she make a mark on the Monastary, commission a wand made of Dagwood for herself.Eli delighted in someone so close to her age being in the cloister. She and Rieta spent all of their free time together – and eventually a romance blossomed between them, a secret one that was eventually revealed. Rieta's welcome was withdrawn and Elisa was given a choice – go with Reita and leave the only home she'd ever had, or stay and renounce this newfound love.She left the next morning, with a carved dagwood charm on her necklace, and a strong bo strapped to her back, and her hand in Rieta's.They found a small village to settle in, and a small house with two stories and a modest basement for Rieta to practice her magic in. Life is good for a good few years.Eli stays around the village, helping whereever she can. Rieta travels at times, always yearning for more knowledge, more understanding of the world and the arcane powers she could wield. She always came back through.And thenwhen Elisa was 25, Reita started spending more and more time in the basement. She'd had to go downstairs more often than not just to get Reita to come upstairs for dinner.Something was wrong but whenever Elisa approached it, she'd be shut down, and for fear of starting arguments with the only family she had, she never pushed it.For years later, she'd wish that she had.Reita locked herself away for two days straight, and Elisa could hear a racket downstairs.She went downstairs to investigate and found Reita in a pitch black basement save for a few candles, and a glowing purple circle etched into the dirt.Elisa tried to stop whatever spell Reita was casting that sent chills down Eli's spine, but she was thrown back into a pillar of the basement and crumpled into an unconcious heap.When she woke up, the basement was empty – and flooded with sunlight. The house above was halfway destroyed (her most beloved belongings miraculously survived) and when she staggered up the stairs – so was most of the town, a scarred circle of ash and smoke where friends she'd known for years once lived.There were no other survivors – or at least, none that she could find. No bodies, either.Everyone she had known had presumably fallen victim to this dark magic Rieta had fallen into the thrall of.That was the day Eli swore to herself she would get stronger. She would get stronger so that noone else would die depending on her the way that ruined town did. And so if she ever crossed paths with Rieta, she would be prepared. She now travels, aiming to help as many people as she can.
Shadow Assasin for a church, noble in daily life working for his father who is a trader

Orphan who was raised at an orphanage/school/training camp thing that trains them to be adventurers and then sends them off to adventure. What she doesn't know is the man, who runs the place is actually the world's trickster god and her patron deity.

Ezhelya was born and grew up in Arsanith, a legendary githzerai monastery deep within the elemental chaos.  Its form is maintained through the collective psionic effort of the githzerai who live there.  All who have glimpsed enlightenment are welcome there, even githyanki who are normally the githzerai’s sworn enemies.  As a result of the way Arsanith is constructed and formed, it is impossible for creatures to hurt or harm each other within its limits.  It was constructed such that, if someone were to overcome the anti-harm spell placed on the city, the entire city would collapse into itself and become absorbed in the chaos that surrounds it.  In any case, overcoming that spell would be extremely difficult.  There is a similar prohibition on using psionic effects to control another’s mind unwillingly, although this can be bypassed by members of the Arsanith leadership on occasion.Ezhelya’s fellows were training from childhood to be fighting monks, mystics, or symbiotes, learning to make use of their psionic abilities to fight effectively without armor or weapons.  When their training was complete, they would leave the monastery and form bands to roam the planes and kill illithids and githyanki.  The prescence of githyanki in Arsanith made this something of a contradiction, but githzerai do recognize that there is variation among individuals within a race and considered the githyanki in Arsanith worthy of their respect.Ezhelya was a rare Githzerai born with a complete inability to use psionic powers, so she could not train in the usual gith classes.  At age eight, she met and became enamored with an old warrior, Cordelia, who had abandoned her calling to come study at Arsanith.  Inspired by Cordelia, Ez decided that learning to fight with heavy armor and a sword would be the best way to make up for her lack of psionic talent.  Cordelia cautioned her that the path of a fighter could lead to much bloodshed and suffering, but Ezhelya was stubborn and could not be swayed.As the young gith began monk training, Ezhelya worked on her own to develop her physical strength.  She found an old, beaten up sword and shield in the back of a storeroom, and trained to fight with those.  There was no armor anywhere in the monastery, so she sewed rocks and bits of metal into her clothes and put them in her backpack to practice fighting while carrying heavy loads. At age 15, the leaders at the monastery decided she had proven herself enough to merit crafting a suit of scale armor for her, as well as a new shield and sword.About a year after that, January Szclainski showed up at Arsanith.  January was an Illithid who, for some reason, turned out to not be evil like most Illithids are.  She thought going around to do evil stuff was boring and wanted to learn about the various races and cultures of the planes instead.  She left her Illithid colony at age 10 and came to Arsanith at age 13 (Equivalent to age 16 in human/gith years).  She wanted to learn more about githzerai due to their relationship with illithids.She knew she wouldn’t be welcome in most githzerai communities due to their well-known hatred of “mind flayers,” as they call illithids.  But she figured they’d let her live at Arsanith if she could convince them she had glimpsed enlightenment—if githyanki could live there, why not her?  Her plan worked, although she had to keep stunning people who were trying to kill her for awhile before they realized she wasn’t evil.  After that, convincing them that she was enlightened wasn’t too hard.Ezhelya got to know January better than any other githzerai during those two years.  Possibly because she was already different, she found herself drawn towards people who were even more “outsider” than her.   For whatever reason, she and Jan became good friends.One years later, Jan decided it was her time to move on.  Ezhelya was 17, almost at the age when she would leave the monastery anyhow.  She had kind of a crisis at that time—she suddenly realized that devoting her life to killing githyanki and mind flayers just wasn’t what she wanted to do.  She had learned so much about other worlds from January and she wanted to go out and see them for herself, not as a fighter but as an explorer.  She also realized that she was in love with January and didn’t want to be separated.  So she confessed her love to January and asked to leave Arsanith with her, a year before she was meant to.  January was like “cool sounds good to me” They moved to the Kapisi civiliation and started a bakery.  They lived happily as a couple for about a year and a half.  Romantic love was kind of an alien concept to January but she was party chill about it and they made it work.  January baked bread that she sold to the townspeople.  Ezhelya felt kind of aimless during this time.  The only thing she knew was that she wanted to be with January and do whatever January did.  She helped Jan at the bakery and learned a bit of baking.  She took odd jobs around the village, as much for the learning experience as to make money.  She kept practicing fighting, but not in the driven, single minded way she had before she met January.  It was just something she was good at, a skill she might be able to use later.To be continued…
Prince who ran away to live in the forest
Blind guy from a healer family who ran away
He's a cat.

An Orphan, Laoise became a Swashbuckler at an early age and adventured in the underground town she grew up in. She sailed the seas, fought the upper class families, and drank...a lot. When she was 16, however, she was in a bar when a two members of a royal family started arguing which ended with one sister killing the other...and the surviving sister ordering her guards to kill the witnesses.  She then met her new founded group of misfits that she now travels with in search of a mythical book that chronicles their every move.
A master swordsman training his apprentice Ash.
Two wilderness boys who went through 3 different moms.
Comes from a wizarding society of half-elves
A tiefling genius who sells lots of wares of his.
Former bouncer at a gnome fight club

Was once a soldier in a grand army, worked his way up to be the regimental champion, a high-up officer took umbrage at the young Kias and challenged him to a dual, the officer lost and was accidently killed, Kias was stripped of his rank and discharged, now works as a wondering fencing instructor for foolish nobles who get dragged into duals.

Kenna Merigold was born of a short-lived romance between a fire genie and a human male. Most of her early childhood she lived in the city of Yartar under the care of her father, a travelling bard. Due to her fiery appearance and equally fiery temper, she often found her way into trouble. To avoid any further scrutiny, her father decided to take her with him on his travels. During this time she became skilled in the art of entertainment (singing, fire-eating and juggling being her main acts) and their joint act (called The Wailing Sirens) never failed to impress their audience. However, her father grew old and weary of their travels and was forced to retire to a farm in Red Larch. With her solo act she struggled to make ends meet. Then one night, after a performance, she was approached by a dwarf called Brolin and ask to join him and his gang of seemingly shady individuals at their table. After watching her perform, they figured her skills would come in handy for their gang, known as the hand of Yartar. All through the night they shared stories of their mischievous deeds and all of the coin that they had made. And after a full night of drinking together, she decided to join them. After a couple of years, she built up quite an impressive reputation in the guild with her excellent thievery skills. Then one day, she was sent on an important mission to collect a great treasure, the mummified hand of a renowned saint. However, before they were able to deliver the treasure, Brolin mysteriously disappeared with the item still in his possession. Returning alone and empty-handed was not received well by the thieves' guild to say the least. However, instead of killing her, they decided to exile her instead. Following her exile she returned back to her father's farm in Red Larch. There her father told her about the rumours heard around the area about some dark and mysterious happenings. Broke and bored out of her mind she decided to set out and investigate these rumours.

Finduilas used to be a simple hunter selling his wares on the market of his small town. He loved being in nature, but also loved being among people, hanging out in the local pub. Drinking, laughing.. Drinking.. He was content. But he always felt that he was meant for something more, something greater. One day, when he returned from the woods, he heard screams coming from the edge of town and something else.. like a screeching of some sort. He dropped his game and ran towards the noise.. and there it was... a HUGE owlbear, swooping down from the sky lunging at the baker's boy... long story short.. Finduilas slayed the beast.. and from that moment on.. He swore to protect the world from the dangers of the world.. He knew I was destined for greatness
An outcast queen, fleeing from the usurpers of her homeland with the heir to the throne in her uterus.

M'herra grew up in a monastery because she was an orphan who never knew her parents. Tabaxi were pretty rare in the northern part of our world, so she had rarely seen a specimen. Her upbringing was nice and she grew up with a lot of other orphans from many different races. As we started the campaign, she had just become a knowledge seeker for her monastery, so she was sent out to travel the world and gather stories and information about just everything.

Bahkus grandmother Okna was the matriarch of a roaming clan of bandits. Small groups of clanmembers were send out to raid villages or assault caravans. Since the incidents were happening with increasing frequency, mercenarys of the University (an institution with a weird agenda in the world) staged a travelling caravan to capture the bandits. So Bahku was captured and through a pact of blood magic forced to work for the university. While at the university she faked her stupidity to escape some nasty tasks. For a while she was used as a dummy for some weird experiments and for training, but after a while she was assigned to a mercenary group lead by a half-orc to act as a tank.

Celia lived an average, ordinary life until the day she accidentally stumbled through a portal to the Feywild in her favorite park.  There, she found herself beset by strange fey beings that wanted to ravish her or eat her, or sometimes both.  Fleeing from encounter to encounter, she finally stumbled upon the palace of a powerful fey called the Queen of Spring Lilies.  The queen, amused and charmed by her, agreed to send her home and even grant her boons, on one condition -- she must entertain the queen.  Celia, desperate to return home, agreed.  She didn't really intend to hold to the bargain, but she's found that when she lets her life get boring, the queen takes it on herself to interfere, directing monsters her way or causing the entire staff and student body of a wizarding college to fall in love with her.  She's realized that it's usually less trouble to just go with any adventures that come her way, no matter how much they terrify her.

From her earliest childhood, Wildrose has had a keen eye for treasure.  She loves seeking out lost and forgotten trinkets that the larger races could never find, or gems and jewels hidden deep in the underground that no one else could track.  It's not so much the value that she cares about (though that is nice) as much as the thrill of having something no one else could ever discover.  As an adult, she set out wandering on her own, to look for treasures far and wide, but her life took a turn when she found an ancient ruin inhabited by a colony of sapient rats and mice.  They were threatened by extinction from a tribe of yuan-ti who were claiming the ruins and trying to resurrect a dead god sealed beneath it.  Wildrose couldn't stand for this (especially as the keystone of the ritual was a precious jewel with a composition unlike any other in the world), and so she rallied the rats to rise up against the reptilian cultists, discovering in the process that she was a natural leader and had an excellent mind for clever strategy and deadly traps.  The rats were victorious, sending the yuan-ti fleeing back to where they came from, and Wildrose left with the adulation of the rat clan.  Now she's thinking that it might be nice to have a group to lead on her next treasure-hunting expedition...

Ceta was originally the quiet, bookish priestess of a remote library-shrine to Ioun, goddess of knowledge.  She would have been content staying there her whole life, cataloging the books and scrolls and tending to travelers, but she could not have foreseen the fate awaiting her.  One night, she awoke to find the library in flames.  Rushing out in a panic, she found the inferno was already too big to quench.  Standing in the midst of it was a monstrously huge orc with one eye, looking down on her with contempt.  As she tried to rush past him, trying to save books from the fire and escape with her life, he struck her down brutally, leaving her for dead in the burning building.  When she awoke, weeks later, she was in a monastery run by clerics of Ioun who had been alerted to her plight by an omen from the goddess.  They told her that she had been saved, and granted new powers by Ioun, to track down the orc and exact ruthless vengeance on him.  This appalled Ceta.  She wanted rest, and quiet, and healing, and time to mourn.  Instead she was to be sent forth to enact violence and death.  Ceta felt she had no choice but to accept the quest of the goddess she had served for so long, the one who saved her life -- but she has grown bitter and cynical about it, and no longer feels any love for Ioun.  All she has left is her vengeance, and she hates having even that.

Rolvik was a sailor working on a Tethyrian merchant galley when a savage and destructive storm hit - he was cast overboard. All other sailors perished, but Rolvik was chosen by Talos the Stormlord as the sole survivor and marked him with a twisted lightning burn in the shape of his holy symbol. Rolvik now compulsively wears a hood at all times to hide his scar and allegiance to the chaotic god of destruction.

Keagan was a curse to his parents. His father, a well respected elf ranger by the name of Lord Ellannan the Ranger, and his mother, a human ranger in a small town by the edge of the elves’ territory who was called Gurthana Serpenthelm, met in the woods whilst doing various tasks. Gurthanna was out hunting, and Elannan was scouting out new territory for the elven king. They both saw each other, but under the canopy of the trees it was dark, and even though they both had vision accustomed to these environments, they failed to realise they were of different races. They spoke for a time, neither realizing that something had fallen over them. Perhaps it was their tiredness, or something far more sinister in the woods… Nevertheless, they loved each other very much, that night. They decided to sleep out in a hunting lodge. By the time they arrived, they were both tired, so they didn’t bother with lighting a candle, or the fire. Instead, they both crawled into bed, and made love. In the morning, however, Elannan woke up, and, realizing what he had done, killed himself. Took his hunting knife, and stabbed himself twice in the gut, and once in the chest. He bled out on the floor. Gurthanna woke up minutes later, and saw Elannan lying on the planks, dead. His hair had fallen over his ears, and Gurthanna, blinded by grief, still didn’t realize that he was an elf. She fled the cabin, and ran back to town. She concealed her grief well, though some people notice a slight change in her behaviour. She had stopped going out into the woods to hunt, and stayed at home for longer periods of time. 8 months later, Keagan was born. His elvish blood wasn’t apparent at first, but by the age of 5 his ears were more pronounced. His mother tried to hide him from the village, but it was inevitable that he would venture outside. By the age of 11, his mother had great trouble, keeping him inside. It was also at this age that he began getting far more elegant and graceful than any pureblooded human. When Keagan turned 14, he snuck outside for the first time. He became quite good at this, eventually. By the age of 15, it was apparent to even him that he wasn’t fully human. He decided to keep this a secret, though, and wove a net of lies, and made a mask of naivety. These skill would help him later in his life. By the age of 17, Keagan took up fencing and knife throwing to pass the time. Eventually, he bored of fencing imaginary opponents, so he bid his mother farewell. But, instead of doing this verbally, he snuck out in the dead of night, leaving a note for his mother to find. He wore his cloak with the hood up, to conceal his face, and slouched slightly to conceal his height. He took only his rapier and kunai. He travelled East, with no destination in mind, following the road. He kept following it as it grew wider, a sign that he was getting closer to a larger city. It was here that he put his disguising abilities to the test. He came upon a caravan, and was trying to pass it, when the owner ran up to him. The owner had seen Keagan’s sword, and needed some more guards on the caravan. Keagan declined at first, but the owner offered him a large sum of gold. He accepted, if only because he needed the gold. They were a few hours from the city when bandits attacked. Keagan had dismounted his horse to give it some rest, and when the bandits attacked, his horse bolted. Keagan dove into the bushes, to avoid incoming crossbow fire, and snuck towards the bandits. There were five of them, and only one of him. All the other defenders had been shot full of crossbow bolts. As the bandits drew near, he silently grabbed his kunai, and unsheathed his sword. Once the bandits drew level with Keagan, he threw his kunai. It hit the lead bandit straight in the chest. He charged out and fell a second with a quick slash to the throat. His speed and stealth allowed him to stab a third, before the remaining two realised what was going on. Keagan retrieved his kunai, and ducked under a swing. The bandits had maneuvered so one was on his left, and one on his right. He parried a blow from the left, and staggered as the flat of a sword hit him in the chest. He thought quickly, as he stumbled backwards, and then he threw himself backwards. He clutched at his chest, feigning pain. The bandits inched forwards, eager to finish him off. Quick as lightning, Keagan’s hand flashed out, throwing his kunai. It missed. The bandits followed it with their eyes. Seconds later they were both dead, easily dispatched with a few blows from a chakram Keagan had found on a corpse he had fallen next to. Keagan tore a few strips of cloth off a bandit’s shirt, and wrapped his left hand; the chakram had cut him when he swung it. He never took those strips off, keeping them as a memento of his first kills. He realised that as a half-elf, he would never fit in, and he loathed that fact. He realised he enjoyed killing these men, then shook his head. He must stay true to what his mother taught him. Only kill when necessary. But.. Keagan decided to put this moral dilemma off for the moment. He spoke with the owner of the caravan, who was very grateful, and they continued onwards. Once they reached the town, Keagan received his pay. He decided to stay in town for a while. There he stayed, honing his skills of stealth and deception, mastering the art of killing by being an assassin. He did this for 3 years, then set out for the coast. He hoped to get an overseas mission, and see the world. When he arrived, he attempted to resume work as usual. A few months later, he was approached by the mercenaries’ guild. They wanted him to be part of the guild, As a medium ranking agent. He accepted, on the terms that the guild would provide for him, at least in the city, and also pay him a small salary. Soon after he joined, he was given his first mission. It was to go see an old man by the name of Jacel, and assist him in his goal.

Born in Boshkin, Thu’rum was raised on tales of the motherland, and the mysterious black mountain . Like any child, he wanted to see these tales for himself. And unlike most tales, these ones were true, and could be seen. Thu’rum was given to his grandparents at a young age, soon after his father was terribly injured by a mining accident. He never knew his mother, but he knew that she was a part of an evil cult. He had four siblings. 2 sisters and 2 brothers. His older sister always despised him, and most siblings do, but this hate ran deeper. She blamed Thu’rum for all the misfortunes the family had. Thu’rum accepted this, but it hardened him. He loved his siblings, but when his younger sister was murdered by one of Thu’rum’s rivals at his school, he had enough. He beat the boy within an inch of his life. The guards hauled him away, and threw him in jail for 6 years. When he was released, he had seen the error of his ways. Both the dwarves had been in the same prison, and they had become allies, if not friends. Thu’rum would never forget his sister, but he never saw his family again. Saddened, he became a heavy drinker. To make money, he acted as a fence for a gang, gettin in good terms with them. All Thu’rum did was accept goods, and drink. This went on for 8 years. By the time Thu’rum came to his senses, he was 107. He decided to stop helping the gang, and became a mercenary,. A guard for hire. He protected many caravans, and became quite well know. During one of his journeys, he encountered a bear. The rest of the guards ran in terror, but Thu’rum stood his ground, angry that the caravan had been delayed. He roared loudly, and, much to everyone’s surprise, began to change. As he straightened up, he grew taller, nearly double his height, and his limbs got thicker. It was as if he had simply been leaning over, and now he straightened up. He sprouted thick brown fur, all over his body. Some of his humanoid features, such as hands, remained the same, and he still held his hammer and shield. He threw down his shield, gripped the hammer with both hands, and engaged the bear. A long fight ensued, both combatants wrestling back and forth. Eventually, Thu’rum ripped the bear’s throat out. Breathing heavily, he leaned against a tree, and returned to normal. He retrieved his tools, made an amulet out of the bear’s claw, and continued on as if nothing had happened.

Ranivorus, patron Immortal of the gnolls, is said to bestow multiple personalities on particularly holy gnolls as signs of his favor.  Whether that is true or not, Raia (and the four other personas sharing her body) believes it with all her might.  Spiritual power flows easily through her body, and the five of her share control fluidly, switching dominance to adapt fluidly to situations and surprise those who would try to predict her actions.  They have all taken names for themselves -- Raia-cal is the inquisitive youth, Raia-ravi is the fiery and dogmatic priestess, Raia-voz is the brutal berserker warrior, Raia-niv is the cunning social backstabber, and Raia-ool is the timid child prone to lashing out at the things that scare her.  When a war cry was sent out to rally the tribes to the great King Thar's banner, Raia was eager to serve, but an omen from the Immortals sent her off in a different direction, into human lands.  They are still not sure what their task is, though Raia-ravi studies everything to look for signs, but the surprising compassion and acceptance some of the humans have shown them is sowing doubt and confusion inside.  They do not yet know if they are meant to aid the humans, or destroy them from inside their own nation, but if it's the latter, some of Raia are starting to wonder if they'll be able to go through with it...
family was killed by monk cult and hidden in the monk temple by a monk that took pity on him. he learned how to use martial arts by watxhing the other monk train via a small window

She’s short, with a dancer’s muscles.  Fair-skinned, with long black hair threaded here and there with unexpected silver.  Bold, black eyebrows over bright blue eyes.  A snub nose and a generous mouth, usually smiling.  And a small blue butterfly tattoo on her right cheekbone, beneath the outer corner of her eye. She’s young, and more than a bit confused to find herself unceremoniously dumped in the wilds of the River Kingdoms.  City born and bred, raised in her parents’ theatre, an adventuring life in the wilderness wasn’t in the cards for her.  If she ever catches up with the so-called friends who ditched her with the bill in this Podunk town… well, let’s just say she knows a thing or two about music and magic and where they intersect.  And meanwhile, she’s slinging verbal mud all over their names. Now it’s just a matter of earning some coin.  Fast.  So she can get the hell out of here and back to civilization.  Joining a few nice, strong, well-armed adventurers seems her best bet… although she’s no one’s idea of a good investment in anything involving fighting or danger.  Or dirt.  But she’s nothing if not an actress; “fake it ‘til you make it” works as well here as anywhere else.  There’s determination behind that cheerful smile.
A foster father running away from his past

Mum was an adventurer, a tempest cleric of Sylvia specifically.  She had a short fling with a dwarf during the campaign to retake the lost forge of Merggon.  I was always bookish as a child, and would stay up stargazing with Mum. I was apprenticed to an astronomer named Aramil Naïlo at the age of 6.  My mother went to fight in defending the island of Myren, nearby to our island of Alora.  I was forced to watch the city burn in the distance as my mother died.  Horribly. The survivors return, and I went to the infirmary to see if mother was there.  Many of the survivors were injured, and told gruesome stories of what the goblins did to those who fell in combat.  I approached the avatar of Sylvia, Taleshi, and offered to become a conduit through which she would be able to smite those responsible for the death of my mother and the destruction of my city.  I was branded as a conduit (I told my master I was sick the next day), and was given a book through which I can study, cast spells, and communicate with my patron, Taleshi.  About 2 weeks later, I haven't been given any assignments, only training, so I decided to try and get some “practical experience” by leaving the islands of Imeth to go on a great adventure.  I hid in an empty crate of grain to stow away on a trade ship, leaving only a note saying “I’m fine, Mella” for my teacher, and with only a meal, a small pouch containing a small portion of my mother’s savings, my mother’s old water skin, and my book of light in my satchel. Three and a half days later (the winds were quite favorable) the ship comes in to port (of course, I don’t know where I am), where the crate I am in is unloaded and stored in a warehouse by the docks.

You're probably the first person to be RickRolled with their own dataset. Congratulations!
call me mayfly

Hawthorn was born “Amanita” to The Family, a cult of worshippers of the evil fungus goddess Zuggtmoy. There, she was raised in a collective with a group of other children from the cult (her brood-mates) by Helvella, an older member of the cult.Both "Amanita" and her closest friend from her brood-mates, Galerina, showedmagical potential—as a druid and cleric respectively. Before their coming-of- age ceremonies at age 16, though, Amanita and Galerina got impatient to test their abilities, which led to Amanita growing her first plant companion. However, Amanita was only used to seeing fungus incorporated symbiotically with thecult—she had never seen it act as a parasite, or kill. So, when the cult’s fungusinfected her plant companion and ultimately killed it, Amanita had a horrifyingawakening to the true nature of Zuggtmoy: the fungus wasn’t a source of unity and family, but of unnatural death. Galerina tried to reassure her, to no avail. And the night before the coming-of- age ceremony, Amanita ran away from the Family.She lived for several years alone, surviving in the woods based on her small herbal knowledge, but staying on the move to remain out of reach of the cult. It was during this period of time when she changed her name to Hawthorn. Eventually, the renamed Hawthorn joined the Von Raud household, a wealthy family of nobles the next kingdom over, who employed her as a gardener and herbalist. Hawthorn became close to the Von Raud’s daughter, Eliisabet (“Liis” for short). Liis tutored Hawthorn in reading and writing in exchange for instruction in botany. (This is how Hawthorn discovered her love of children’s books, which would later be how her current plant companion, Susan the Mulberry, got her name—after a favorite character.) Eventually, Hawthorn and Liis fell in love.Meanwhile, however, the Von Raud family had become involved in a necropolitandeath cult, interested in pursuing undeath for power through immortality—andthey expected their daughter to convert to undeath with them. Hawthorn tried to convince Liis not to follow her parents, but was too frightened to confess her past and thereby fully explain why she was so distrustful of cults. Liis ignored her warnings.The ritual of crucimigration is horrifying indeed—both to undergo and to watch, and Liis came to regret her choice... but only after it was too late to turn back from undeath. Instead, she did the next best thing, and she and Hawthorn ran away from the Von Rauds together.For the past several years, they have lived in hiding in the forest, with Hawthorntrying to use druidic abilities to restore Liis to life. Since nothing has worked, nowHawthorn is leaving to try to find other methods of saving the woman she loves.

All her life, Aria has been surrounded by music. It seems as though from the moment she discovered she could make sounds, she has been trying to sing. A Rock Star by nature and a bard by trade, Aria brings joy and life to everywhere she visits. She does her best to do good whenever she can, just like her parents told her to when she was a kid, but is usually too wrapped up in her music to notice anything like that. “Nothing a song can’t fix!” She always says, being wrong in most cases. It’s not like a simple melody could raise the dead, now could it? “Now, how the heck is that foreshadow-y statement relevant at all?” You rightfully ask, probably, but maybe you don’t since I don’t control your life. Well, I’ll tell you. When she was but a wee lass of 9 (or, y’know, whatever age a half-elf would mentally be 9 at) when the one major tragedy she’s ever experienced so far happened. Aria had a brother, the key word here being “had”. One day they were playing in a meadowy clearing at the edge of the woods that surrounded her small home village of Parsits, when the neighborhood bully, Fritz, and his cronies showed their disgusting faces. They started mouthing off some racist bullcrap at the siblings about being half-breeds or whatever, and then started a fight with her brother. Things got a bit too intense, and since her brother had studied some spells, he attempted to use magic on Fritz. The spell backfired horribly, and when the dust cleared, her brother laid in a still, lifeless heap where he had once stood so determinately only moments ago. This was the only tragedy in her life because what could possibly hurt her more than seeing her brother, her friend and protector, suddenly go from living to dead in a puff of smoke right before her very eyes.

Merric grew up an orphan on the streets of the great metropolis of Thur-kat-Nur, resenting the nobles who lounged in their golden towers while he and his friends starved.As he approached adulthood he began to hear a language in the whisperings of the city's rats. He could not consciously understand what they were saying, but listening to them seemed to open something in his mind, and he found that he could cast magic spells.Merric's first clumsy experiments with magic attracted attention. The city's priests declared him to be a warlock, in service to an alien entity known as the Great One, which according to legend had been defeated and driven underground when the city was founded. Merric managed to escape the mob that was trying to hang him, but was forced to flee the city and try to make a new life elsewhere.

It's a young gnome who grew as the son of a rich couple at the court of Biram VI. All of that happens in a gnome kingdom in the heart of the Mountains Valley.One day, a coup d'état is going on. The king is killed and all of the nobles were forced to exile, deep into the desert.Glibir walked for days with his people, in the hot sand. Most of them died during the travel. His own mother and his two sisters passed away...In the end some of the remain children were taken by some touareg guys who lived from robbering and other "works". Here is how he learned his tricks.One night, after some years learning and travelling with them, he leaved to go on his own adventure ~

Jonah was kidnapped and raised by halfling ranger fighting with slavery, grew up to be bold and cunning fighter, and continued fight of his adoptive father after he died besieging citadel of ogres. He commited to the party by performancing doompunkish ballads striking fear to the enemies and serving as comic relief during those long dungeoncrawling, deep in his heart always mournful after death of the first and only person that cared for him, in his special way.

Only Nadia's biological mother could tell why she left her with the caravan instead of entrusting her to the priests, but it turned out to make a good life for the young tiefling. Travelling the world, seeing different cultures, meeting new people... granted, a good lot of them weren't that keen on a curious child of an obvious infernal descent, but with time Nadia learned to ignore suspicious glances. Especially after meeting Larassa, who didn't try to hide her gleaming, golden scales and sharp teeth. And who talked passionately about wonders of the arcane. Nadia caught the spark and fed it well until it developed into full-blown wizarding skill. She passed the right of succession to her younger sister, Jana, and decided to seek out knowledge of magic instead; initially without leaving her family, but when the news of her mentor's disappearance reached her, she had to follow the track and learn what happened to the mysterious dragonborn.

Syrine was a slave in the Blessed Isle, whose mistress was involved with a Yozi cult. She Exalted by secretly spreading enough whispers around that the Immaculate Order took notice of the cult, but not her, and she slipped away with the cult's most sacred artifact

He turned out to be terrible at the family business (bootlegging) so he became a librarian instead.  The god of writing noticed, dubbed him a cleric, and shoved him out into the world because the god was bored and wanted some new stories.
She eats people.

Small but spry, Binder learned of his sorcerous potential while being raised on the free-trader All Rumors - after his catastrophic discovery, he was asked to disembark until he learned a little more controlHe has not yet learned of the implications his draconic heritage carriers for his sorcery and personality

Brannon Darrow is tall and thin, with a sharp gaze that seems to take everything in. He seems at once both easy-going and intense: he has a ready smile, and a sympathetic ear, but his eyes are piercing and often linger a little too long, always giving the impression that he's thinking something about what he sees. Which is probably because he is.His clothes are worn and travel-stained, but his insignia mark him out as belonging to the Temple of Flame in Glissom, and he wears the symbol of Brigantia around his neck. His fingers are ink-stained, and his hands rather worn and calloused - suggesting a strange mix of academic work and manual labour. He has a noble bearing, and fine features - upset by a pallor, a wasted look and a hacking cough that suggest he is no longer as well or as strong as he once was.

One day, when he was a mere lad of three years, Tutu was looked upon by the great elder who controlled the cookie pot. He retracted his hand from that vessel, but was dealt a rapid slap nonetheless. Said the elder, "Now run along and be a good boy." And so, Tutu ventured forthwith from his home to serve others and do battle against all fear and suffering. He wanders from place to place to this day, ready to leap at the slightest chance to affect the good without even the tiniest delay or the most vanishingly small hesitation regardless of all circumstances.
Political espionage.
Alton is a Druid who has fallen from the righteous path, he now supplements his meagre income by stealing as a small time criminal.

Rat was abandoned at birth on the streets of one of the world's largest cities.  She grew up a street urchin, developing a lean and wiry strength as she fought for scraps to survive on.  Never socialized or taught by parents or anyone else, she speaks little, and socializes only slightly more.  She developed a passionate fire for survival within her as she grew more in touch with the 'urban wilderness' -- knowing the tracks and trails of the gutters, sewers, and rooftops; learning the ways of the beasts of the streets whether they be pigeons, rats, stray dogs, or humans.  She leaps from rooftop to rooftop, dragging a rusty old sword nearly as large as she is behind her.  Her primary motivation is to protect her territory from all threats and intruders -- though she sometimes will protect the people and animals within her home from those threats as well.

I was born the only child of a middle class family in the unstable city of Ordulin. After contracting a rare disease as a newborn, my parents turned desperately to the demon Va'hanarr for help, for a miracle. In exchange for their wealth, he did the only thing that would save my life, & turned me into a tiefling. Now poor and shunned by the townsfolk, my parents lived in squalor in the slums. When plague hit the city, at the age of 8, I was left an orphan wandering the streets with nowhere to go. The leader of the band of thieves called the Bricks took pity on me, took me in, & taught me everything that I know today. 15 years later, Ordulin is in great turmoil, the indigent lower class began to rebel against the corrupt nobles that ran the city. Djaenn, my benefactor used this vulnerable time to his advantage, running secret missions for the rebels, steeling information and plans, and always pocketing a bit of the loot for himself. Knowing little but this life of crime, I blindly followed my trusted leader, except for one night. I was told that my mission was to break into the mayor's home and destroy his most prized possession. Assuming it was a family heirloom or jewel, I agreed. It was not until I was looking into the young girl's terrified eyes that I realized how blind I had been. Nothing is worth taking an innocent's life.After hiding the child, I abandoned my crew and ran. Upon arrest, my crew blamed the the entire heist on me, insisting I was the mastermind. To avoid prison, I fled to a neighboring town and waited for the clear from Djaenn to return, but word never came. After bribing a bar hand for information, a learned that Djaenn had been the one to accuse me, and was now, in exchange for protection, was aiding the guards in their search for me. Betrayed, and now wanted, I fled as far away as I could from Ordulin, but I shall return to  confront Djaenn someday.

"A family is a house made of bodies stacked up on each other for a long time." Magho may not have a true family, but many years of studying with a human monastery of monks has filled his head with many useful proverbs, such as this one.  Perhaps it is true that Magho misread some sections of the Book of Proverbs from which he loves to quote (being illiterate tends to have this effect), but he genuinely believes it's the thought that counts.  And Magho's original thoughts can probably be counted one hand (or at least they could, could Magho count that high).When he was just 7 years old, Magho's tribe returned from raiding a nearby settlement.  As part of their raid, after took all the loot, they burned everything they deemed as useless, including a mage's pouch of hundreds upon hundreds of valuable magical scrolls.  When the fire was lit, the arcane energy erupted.  Although nobody was killed, Magho was flung from the blast into a boulder.  When he awoke, dazed and confused, he picked up one of the scrolls and he saw a light turn on in front of him.  Perceiving this as a sign, Magho believed he just witnessed a spiritual calling.  (The light he saw was a prestidigitation cantrip triggered by one of the scrolls.) Astounded at all this, he began to closely observe his surroundings and discovered a scroll from the explosion.  Magho knew this paper contained the key to understanding life, the universe, and everything.  It was a blank sheet of parchment.  From then on, he studied this scroll of knowledge instead of  going out and fighting with his friends, until he turned 12.Magho was exiled from his tribe on his 12th birthday.  It is tradition in his tribe that to become a man at this age one must enter into a battle with the tribe's chieftain.  Upon entering the Ring of Valor, Magho sat cross-legged in the dirt and began reciting his learnings. "The short story of our lives is a story made of untold endings and forgotten beginnings;  He who fights first is the one who is going to show tonight without their best hat;  Little things are small, so are smaller things."  The tribe looked around at each other in disbelief, and soon rose up, cried out for his name never to be uttered by another tribesman ever again and exiled him with none of his belongings.After months of traveling by foot through the deserts and the plains, Magho came upon a group of three hairless men wearing dresses.  They were sitting in a circle with their eyes closed on the ground.  After observing them from afar for a few hours, Magho caught sight of an ogre from this corner of his eye.  It was in flight! As it descended towards the men, Magho picked up a long branch from the ground, charged it, leapt off a rock, and dashed out its brains with one miraculous swing.  The men broke their trance and saw the aftermath of what transpired.  Grateful as they were to have been saved from the ogre magi, they granted Magho rest at their monastery.  Mistaking their kindness for an invitation to join their order, Magho never left.  He spent the next 20 years sitting by them side-by-side, paging through books of proverbs,  hearing lectures about Ogmha, God of Knowledge, and learning virtually nothing.  As the monastery got older and the monks went their separate ways, Magho decided to venture out into the world himself to spread knowledge wherever he could in order to please Ogmha.
Dropped on his head as a child, he grew to be short and angry at the world. THere are no problems that cannot be solved with an axe or strong drink.
fuck you
Mortician by trade, but her work caught the attention of an eldritch death god who gave her Magic Powers. Now she's on a personal mission to learn more about death and the afterlife.

Comes from a semi-nomadic society of shepherds and craftspeople. Hickory was appointed by the clan's matriarch to spend a few months in a nearby town, making business connections. Hickory's stubborn, prideful nature prevented them from doing the task assigned. Instead of going home, they have gone off in search of adventure, trying to prove their worth.
Owns a bookstore in the nation's capital by day, steals arcane texts and builds magical explosives by night.

Addrir was born to human parents in Nantambu in the Mwangi Expanse. His father Tasgall was a ranger and member of the Pathfinder Society and his mother Apirka was a cleric of Gozreh. As a child Addrir was very withdrawn and often had trouble socializing and fitting in to any particular peer group. His parents were killed by soldiers of Ruthazek while they were out in the forest east of Nantambu. Addrir was only six years old when he learned of the death of his parents. After they died he went to live with his uncle Ailig on the outskirts of Nantambu. Addrir enjoyed being out of the city center and more immersed in nature. Ailig was a druid and while began to teach Addrir about nature and the ways of the druid, he also suffered greatly from a personality disorder that would cause him to fluctuate between periods of great anger and periods of quiet withdrawnness. At his worst in the periods of anger he would take it out on anyone around him, and living in isolation this was often Addrir. Addrir was often physically and mentally abused by Ailig. Even with all the abuse Addrir was fascinated by the ways of the druid and he put up with it to learn more about the druids path. Over time the abuse really began to wear at Addrir and he felt he knew enough to make it on his own. After living and training with his Uncle for three years Addrir decided to leave. His dislike of the large city atmosphere and love of nature led him to run away into the forest of the Mwangi Expanse. Addrir had always had an affinity for nature and training as a Druid had sparked something inside of him. He survived in the forest alone living off the land for a while until disaster struck. One day while Addrir was out foraging for food he saw a small contingent of Ruthazek's soldiers and was seen by them. He attempted to escape, but was caught and beaten within an inch of his life and left for dead, unconscious and bleeding in the middle of the forest. Shortly after the departure of the soldiers a great breeze began to blow in the area and storm clouds rolled in. There was a great thunderstorm and a lightning bolt shot down from the sky and struck Addrir in the middle of the chest, but instead of killing him it transported him to a timeless place where he communed with the deity Gozreh. Addrir surrendered his old life and accepted the blessings and new life from Gozreh and was returned to his body in the forest fully healed and newly adorned with a tattoo of a leaf with a large water droplet falling from it covering a large portion of his back. After waking Addrir was approached by a pair of Elven rangers of the Kallijae tribe who wittnessed the whole event. They were at first content to let him die as they generally regard humans as meddlesome and linked to trouble. However the elves knew and respected Gozreh and saw the dieties divine intervention on the part of Addrir. This softened their opinion of him considerably. They took him back to the elders of the Kallijae tribe and explained what happened. Addrir was permitted to stay with the elves. He had much in common with them and learned vast amounts about the natural world under their tutelage. Slowly over time Addrir discovered new abilities he had access to since his encounter with Gozreh. However old habits die hard and Addrir's predilection for not fitting in reared its head again, exacerbated by the natural differences between elves and humans. After three years with the elves Addrir is over come with a feeling that he is destined for more. Recalling his father's affiliation with the Pathfinder Society Addrir bids farewell to the elves and heads to the Pathfinder Society Lodge and seeks membership. Addrir desires to travel far lands and learn more about the natural world.The local head of the Pathfinder Society was a good friend of Addrir's father and remembered Addrir as a small child. At this point Addrir is too young to become a full fledged member of the Society, but is permitted to help out where he can for food and shelter and to begin light training to prepare him for a life of travel and adventure. After living at the lodge for three years Addrir is offered a chance to go to Avistan by ship to assist with a mission the Society is conducting. Upon reaching Avistan the party encounters a great storm that shipwrecks them in the Mushfens. They are discovered and attacked by Varisian wanderers. Addrir manages to escape, but he is alone again, this time on an unknown continent. Addrir recognizes many similar natural patterns in Varisia. Many things are the same but many are also very different. Addrir begins exploring The Sanos Forest and venturing further in to Avistan to see what is out there.
Fighting the good fight - traveling with caravans as a guard for hire. Always on the lookout for the down-trodden and dispossessed Vilmar lends his strong magical talents to those most in need.

Eryn is the daughter of the infamous pirate captain Bradesmar Wache, master of the town of Maidenspool. When she was very young, a freak locathah attack (probably caused by the druid pirate captain known as the Master of Gales) killed her mother and left her father obsessed with revenge.In order to protect her, Eryn was sent off to school in far off Absalom, where she learned magic. Now, nearly two decades later, she's come back to the Shackles to take up the family business: piracy!(She later became Hurricane Queen, BTW.)

Corro was a druid, but not just any druid. He wasn't like the wussy elf druids on the surface who only care about the pretty parts of nature, no. He was down there in the caves with the oozes! The mold! The weird swamp things that he wasn't quite sure what they were but they made a noise that sounded kinda like "glop"! He devoted his life to protecting these creatures from any outsider that would seek to harm them.One day, Corro got a bit lost. Then he got very lost. Then he found himself coming out of a sewer pipe in a major city several hundred miles south of his normal territory. There he met the party, as part of his quest to get back to his home cave and his job of protecting nature.

Gaverall exchanged the soul of his firstborn for a devil's favor. He then knocked up a whore named Jenora who gave birth to a deformed baby girl named Aria. Aria had six fingers on her left hand, a thin tail, a faint smell of brimstone, and later grew a twisted ram's horn on the right half of her skull in her teenage years. Her mother was forced by the brothel owner to give up her child, but no one was willing to take her until her mother came across the Temple of Giggles.The Temple of Giggles was happy to take her, but not all was as it seemed. To the outside world the Temple of Giggles was a fun loving, frivolous church that worshiped gnomish gods. From the inside it was a cult-like following of people who wish to be whisked away to the plane of Bytopia. Their rituals often involved hallucinogenics and they would indoctrinate new people by infecting them with Crackle Fever.Aria grew up believing that fits of spontaneous laughter was the norm. When she was young she would often break into forced laughter at unpredictable intervals, trying to make herself like the others devotees, but as she got older she only broken into a nervous laughter to keep the other churchgoers from interrogating her.Aria found her passion in translating and transcribing the gnomish scripture into common script, but that passion delved too deep and she began to pray to Deneir in secret. She was caught praying by her mother – who chose to undergo indoctrination so that she might be able to spend more time with her daughter – and recognized the risk when Jenora threatened her for worshiping the gods that forsook them.The Temple of Giggles managed to summon a Deva in the hopes that it would of spirit them from the mortal world to Bytopia, but the angel decided to only take Aria who didn't worship the plane nor the gnomish gods that reside there. The planes perverse goodwill infected Aria, turning her cynicism and anger into kindness and forgiveness. The Deva returned Aria to the mortal world after the goodwill had subjugated her former personality.
Unaccepted by a bigoted mining community, Gaylord set out into the world to find his fortune - but fortune found him!
Homeless

Timon started out as a regular, happy-go-lucky bard who could neither see nor do any evil. That is until fate lead him into a party made up of people who chose darker paths...Today, after an adventure with three people, who were either too stupid to think of such things or tried getting profit out of their quest to destroy the ancient armour of a lich, Timon is a cynical loner, his heart filled with distrust for those around him - and his songs filled with hatred for all of human-, elven-, and orcenkind.

After Master Tibu, one of the evil wizard Zrellaz's henchmen, performed sinister experiments on him, the badger Tanuki grew self-aware. Together with two other animals he managed to escape the laboratory, back into the forest he knew before. Yet something changed in him. Not only did the experiments awake the capacity for speech, they also woke certain... barbaric tendencies and a connection to an ancient, demonic bloodline.Even today there are stories in the villages surrounding Tanuki's forest. Stories of a creature, that seems normal at first, but releases supernatural strength and hatred if you get on its bad side.

Born to a human mother and a drow father (their relationship unknown), Orrin was left at an orphanage in a trading city, Eswick. Due to his parents, he had mostly human features, except for two obious details: his elvish ears and his grey skin. Often bullied by other children and neglected by the owners of the orphanage, Orrin had to adapt to survive his childhood. He learned to get his hands on what he needed even when others wouldn't give it to him, either through guile or charm. Quickly he left the orphanage to try and live on the streets of the slums, where he developped a sense of street smarts, by looking at cheating merchants or the thieves that operated on the streets.He never got the respect others did, though: his grey skin and elfish ears in a human city always got him the ridicule of others, always calling him a grey rat. Especially elves and particularly one or two drow that passed him looked at him with disgust. As such, he's developped a disgust for those who look down on others too, and he finds it necessary that those people will meet him at the same level: if a noble can be humiliated, he will be humiliated! When he works in a tavern at day, he's being tripped or laughed at. Usually those same people would find themselves with a strange liquid in their drinks, causing their bowels to break all food in the process of being processed.The local Thieves Guild, the Sons of the Traveller, did notice his skills and recruited him: from that moment on, Orrin had better protection and became more bold, robbing the houses of the very lords laughing at him or the other unfortunate souls on the street. What was meant as an insult become a badge of pride: The Grey Rat has visited you!This became more symbolic to him when he found Jester: a rat, slightly bigger than normal, whom he trained and kept as a pet. With his help, the thieves guild took on some very bold heists, stealing the signature ring of the head of the merchant's guild, sabotaging the guardhouses throughout the city and, most notably, stealing the sacred book of Onatar, the god of craft.This, however, earned them too much infamy in the eyes of the nobles and merchants: in their next heist, they were betrayed by some of their contacts. They lost two leaders, and were forced to leave Eswick. They decided to move their enterprise elsewhere, and start over with the gold and contacts they had left, but in order to move inconspicuously, they travel seperatly until they reached their new city.At this very moment, Orrin is still traveling, trying to find a new place to call home. Unexpected adventure found him first...
