About as lucky as he is dumb, this rogue is a terrible ally, but a great distraction.  Despite being incapable of conceiving any remotely productive thoughts, he tends to make ridiculous leaps and bounds in the party's progress both in and outside of battle.  He probably doesn't understand the concepts of good and evil, but his unpredictable conduct often results in some kind of harm.  Spent the last penny he ever had on his retractable-knife-tipped boots, and, well, the seven other pairs he donated to the local orphanage.

Twilek was born to Jard and Lily Gronleaf, nomadic gypsy halflings, on the 7th of Neth. The colourful displays and residual magic of the month's feast days to Nethys would have a permanent affect Twilek didn't unlock until much older. They travelled the Varisian deserts and plains, usually stopping in villages or towns or camping close to Shoanti tribes for safety without interfering and angering them. Lily was an entertainer by trade as well, adept in a multitude of performances whereas Jard provided for the family as a travelling merchant, able to buy most supplies and hunting or crafting whatever else.Twilek was the second son, 5 years after Imiko and 2 before his sister Irlana and another 3 years before twin brothers Radu and Nicu. All of them shared their rust-brown hair yet their eyes were all different, apart from the twins' grey irises. It was impossible to tell Radu from Nicu and they enjoyed pulling pranks and blaming it on the other.Life on the road was hard and after the twins were born the family was forced to settle to manage. The closest town friendly to halflings was Korvosa. Imiko was completely enthralled by the ships and inspired by the halflings who crewed them. When Twilek was 12, Imiko left on his first voyage, bringing back meagre savings to support the family. This continued for two years, until the day they received the terrible news that Imiko had turned to piracy. All of a sudden, the family was ostracized by everyone they knew and business quickly dried up. It took every last favour his parents had in the city to leave the city on board a ship for Magnimar.***Magnimar was not welcoming either. Life in Underbridge was harsh and cheap; Twilek witnessed muggings and other crimes on a weekly basis. He shut it out of his mind by visiting the monuments that gave the city its title and recklessly climbing the crumbled arch bridge. The awe he felt looking directly at history overcame all other thoughts. Arrested for the umpteenth for trespass, one day a curious scholar noticed what she thought was a child in the cells and decided to talk to Twilek. Noting his interest in the ancient artefact, she revealed she was an agent of the Pathfinder Society and paid the pittance for his bail. She led him to the Heidmarch Manor, which acts as one of many staging points for the society, and the centre of all missions into Varisia. As the centre was being repurposed from a home to a lodge, much work had to be done and he was given the mundane task of re-scribing the ancient books brought in from Absalom. So he learned as he recorded, returning day after day in the evenings, poring over books on every and any topic and earning a few silver in the process.***One day he was rerecording a table of all the previous pathfinders. "This record," Twilek grabbed the attention of his newfound tutor. "The last name is my mother's and the first name is mine!"The tutor raised her eyebrows as she walked over and looked at the record, reading aloud despite the archaic font of the writing, "Twilek Sigani - Halfling - Trap finding, minor evocation - 4588AR to 4603AR - Venture Lieutenant- MIA after black dragon collapsed tunnels at site 5F2... I'm so sorry you had to read that. Reading records like this at your age..."A Venture Lieutenant! No wonder exploring is in your blood. Such a prestigious position... there will surely be another book about him. Maybe you should cross reference the site code and go from there."Twilek had been told he was named after an uncle on his mother’s side, he never dreamt of something like this! He immediately did as he was told, ordering in chronicles of the site in Ustalav, specifically an ancient temple to Lamashtu, evil god of monsters. According to the books, the black dragon was an expected complication, but they didn't expect it to be as old and large as it was. Only two survived of the group of five. The survivors' records depicted various horrors both as frescoes on the walls and combating the very same in the corridors. This immensely excited Twilek rather than scaring him off and as he continued his work he also met with a few high-ranked pathfinders as the months passed.***However, Twilek's enjoyment was eclipsed by the harshness of life for his family. His father's store had been robbed twice and the other kids were housebound for fear of the outside. After just 8 months in town, the Gronleafs were on the road again, following the coast up to Sandpoint. Finally, a place they could be accepted and live freely! Except... many people in town already knew of Imiko the pirate. And so the family were confronted by the sheriff.The rest of the family stood against the back wall of The Hagfish as Jard stood defiantly against the sheriff, his small size juxtaposed against the built man."The people of Sandpoint won't wait to hear this," the sheriff said. "The family of the famous Imiko Gronleaf here in town.""Don't you mean infamous?" quizzed Nicu from the back. The sheriff let out a hearty bellowing laugh. "Not at all! Why he's among the best things that have happened to the town! Without his generous donation, my guards would be starving! But see them now in their imported armour and uniforms!"With that all the patrons in the inn applauded enthusiastically, and the family was accepted into the town quickly. They moved into a vacant house on Frog Alley (behind 17), and all commenced working, the kids taking apprenticeships. Two months later, they were relieved to meet Imiko in port after such a long time, yet he yearned for the sea and its adventures, leaving a small fortune for them and the town, apologising for not being with them and stating that he was a man now. Jard accepted this as Lily cried, but they all came to terms with it eventually.***The years dragged on and Twilek had good relations with Sheriff Hemlock, argued with Brodert Quink, conversed with Chask Haladan and listened attentively to Mayor Deverin's adventure stories on the rare occasion. Then the town experienced the Late Unpleasentness, the Gronleaf family grieving with everyone else, but luckily unscathed. During the rebuilding process, Twilek was called back to Magnimar for training with the Pathfinders and from there, sailed a long way to the Grand Lodge of Absalom. Surrounded by new experiences, purple and knowledge, his entire year in training went by like a flash to him. Numerous tests, challenges and missions later, he emerged victorious and a full-fledged society agent ready for adventure! ***With the bounties of the City at the Centre of the World at his disposal, he prepares himself a wagon to live in permanently, painting it brightly in blue with a red roof and stashing adventuring gear inside. Sailing back to Magnimar, upon his return he hears of the opening ceremony that same day and only stays at the lodge to report in before heading back to Sandpoint.
A Cleansed Blight warrior who found purpose in defending his tiny town. His weakness is expensive things, and he loves to cook.

Born in the high plains desert, Killweasel developed agoraphobia at an early age after his village succumbed to plague, leaving him to wake up alone in a pile of corpses. He lived feral for a while and shows signs of being partly raised by sand cats before an old woman found and adopted him. He befriended a party of dwarven geologists and was allowed to follow them home after saving them from hungry terrorbirds, where he stayed until politics required him to set out into the world once more. He worked as a caravan scout, a job that became exploitative of his talents with poisonous things that hide under rocks, and eventually escaped, heading off for the green lands over the mountains.

Made by a mad priest who accidentally captured an insane angel of vengeance in the course of his experiments, Alouette has the approximate comprehensive abilities of a slightly autistic six-year-old and is unaware of being powered by holy rage. Programmed to be "an angel" and protect mortals, the construct nonetheless only possesses two combat capabilities: "being in the way" and "raze the city".

She is one of nine children born to an elf cultist, raising up her children to be weapons. As the second oldest, it was her job to raise the younger siblings and keep the toddler's out of the mother's way. Through reading hundreds of children's books, she learned about good and evil, and that cults are evil. She ran away from the cult at age 13 to make it on her own, but wants to go back and rescue her siblings someday.

Rudy was born to wealthy parents in the Empire's capitol. From a young age they set a heavy mantle of education and prestige on his shoulders, expecting a successful and driven diplomat or merchant of him. They were to be greatly disappointed. In such a hard-hearted family Rudy most respected his black sheep of an uncle who left the city to become an adventurer and a scalawag. The rambunctious and rebellious sort from his youth, old Dunja Russ was just the sort of influence young Rudy's parents wanted to shield him from. Shield him they could not, as every solstice celebration and bacchanal would bring Dunja back from some exotic corner of the world to fill the child's mind with dreams of a bigger world and the adventure that might come of not becoming what was expected. At seventeen years of age Rudy left home once and for all, forsaking the last five years of Imperial Academy in favor of a ticket out. For the last ten years he's made a name for himself thieving, smuggling, womanizing, and generally losing as much money as he ever made.

A strong battle cleric, Rolloch spent many years training with weapons and studying healing magic. His large, round ears and thick gray fur make him very attractive to his own kind but to other races, he's usually considered cute. He hates that.

Prince Traorus sought to use an strange artifact, a powerful magic crown, to bring prosperity to his kingdom. But the crown was possessed by the spirit of the long-dead necromancer who created it, and soon Traorus' mind began to fade and give way to the necromancer's influence. The evil crown took control of the once-beloved prince and in place of prosperity, brought tyranny and ruin.

Zamären, as a young man, became disillusioned with his people's society and left his home in search of something more. For years he made a living as an entertainer, travelling from town to town along the coast. Eventually, he decided he'd seen enough of the world and was ready to return to his own kind. He journeyed back to his home city only to find it abandoned. Now, he travels in search of his lost people, seeking answers as he adventures.

a descendant of great bards, Selene joined a troupe at a young age. eventually she earned enough for schooling, but that came to an abrupt end when the school was suddenly attacked and burnt to the ground. She joined her classmates to solve the mystery of the attack and avenge their teacher.
when her home was taken over by metal beasts, tali quit her training and started punching robots.

Hester was born to two human parents in a monastery. There, she was raised around books of spells and religion. One day, the monastery was attacked by a cult of witches, killing her mother. Her father took up arms and they began traveling around the country hunting them down. As they travelled, She learned spells and combat from her father before signing with a small Paladin order as an Inquisitor. Now, she hunts the witches that ruined her idyllic life.

Redlen was an orphan in the capital city of Bactria, and learned to survive through quick fingers and quick feet. He spent a hundred years as an enchanted frog when he tried to steal the demon Harker's armored skin.
Made a pact with a devil in order to rescue her family

Jangaiva was a temple warrior for the Lord of Worms in the city of Sokátis on the plane of Tékumel. She and her clan sisters and brothers were on a mission to understand the circumstances of their clan patriarch's death. This lead them to venture far and wide seeking pages from the notorious Book of Ebon Bindings. Eventually the need for subterfuge in these dealings lead her to learn the assassin's arts and in the lakeside city of Bay Ssu, she made contact with the operatives of the Omnipotent Azure Legion in hopes of joining their ranks as a spy. Around this time Jangaiva came into contact with an enchanted maul who called itself 'Little Sister' and seemed to want to seek out powerful magic. After several adventures Jangaiva and her clanmates made it home to Sokátis and she is either in the hidden ranks of the OAL or seeking the Blue Room with 'Little Sister'.

The only real memory Chime has from his childhood is the sound of bells, singing a melody that has been etched into his mind. As a Kenku, his ability to talk relies on his ability to mimic voices and sounds, and so when people asked his name, the only thing he knows to do is mimic the sound of the bells. Unaware of his true origins as the Prince of The Roost, and the yet unexplored but dire fate of it’s current citizens, Chime was trained on the streets of Marianvale by a halfling woman named Blackberry to be a cutpurse and later, an assassin. Wearing a bird mask to disguise his actual bird face, he has mostly committed small crimes and targeted low level nobles. His story begins with an ill-fated attempt to steal a legendary sword, The Rose Revolution, while the nobles of the town are distracted by a private performance of the play Roselia, Roselia...and finds him and his party unwillingly trapped in the Feywild.

Born to a impoverished formerly noble family he quickly learned from his mother about how his father ruined their fortunately and reputation. During his childhood he found he was quite good at convincing people to his ideas, unnaturally so as it turned out. He found this out when he went to swindle a passing sorcerer into selling his items to him rather than the next town over. The sorcerer resisted his charm and decided to reveal to Tyrrell his innate abilities. Afer convincing the townsfolk to take care of his money while he trained himself in sorcery vowing to regain his families honor...as well as that fortune his mother constantly complained about losing. So after years of training he pilfered whatever he could from his Master Devexus, he'd pay him back when he was rich, he quickly set himself on the path to accumulating wealth it's far easier than reputation after all. Moving from town to town swindling money from those who wouldn't miss it.

My home was a small village in the River Kingdoms. My family was from a long line of hunters who supplied several merchants and traders with with luxurious leather and hide from elk, tigers, and owlbears. My parents were making a delivery when they found themselves in the middle of a dispute between the merchant and an international trade organization. As punishment for the merchant's attempt to compete with the trade organization, they killed everyone on the merchant's ship, including my mother and father and set the ship on fire. I had stopped at a nearby town for supplies and was to meet up with my family after the delivery. After seeing a huge plume of smoke from the river, I ran down the banks to see the trader's ship ablaze. A witness corroborated what had happened. From the distance I could just make out another ship with black and white sails drifting down the river toward the Inner Sea.Without a family, I joined a band of River Pirates and made a decent wage ambushing merchant ships. However, my true goal was finding the black and white sailed ship again. Eventually I made my way down to the Inner Sea where I spotted several such ships. I realized that the trade organization, who were called the Aspis Consortium, had a whole fleet of them!I left the River Kingdoms and reached the port city of Almas where I applied for a position on an Aspis vessel. I have been learning more about the Aspis Consortium, their leadership, and trying to find out who from this organization was responsible for my family's murder."The Consortium is deadly, powerful, and also extremely wealthy. I can tell you where one of their headquarters is located."

Nerys is highly analytical, but not very charismatic - she's not shy, but also not pushy enough with others. She'll stand up for herself but has trouble asking for help when she needs it. While Nerys doesn't have trust issues, it takes a lot to become close with her; she's cordial with the group, but keeps them at an emotional distance (I said cordial, not friendly). She knows she's a good fighter but relies on that too heavily to "prove" herself to others - she feels like she needs to show she's worth keeping around to the people she travels/trains with, which feeds into her focus on combat, the thing she's best at. Her cool, distant attitude towards others is sourced in part from her tendency to overthink relationships & social situations - she takes a "good" approach to interaction, but leaves people feeling like she just wants things from them, and isn't interested in becoming friends, etc.Nerys comes from a large forest region with several distinct elf communities - deer elves, fox elves, etc. While each is independent and distinct, there is comingling among them, and elves from different areas frequently travel between them. Deer elves, being sharp sensed (good hearing, smell, etc.) and lithe, are known for archery prowess. Nerys had little interest in this from a young age, however, and instead studied swords & magic. This made her a bit of a pariah in her home community, with only her family sticking by her (though there was tension at times). Other deer elves felt that Nerys' style of fighting was brutish and sadistic, and community members avoided her. This, combined with her desire to see the world outside the forest, resulted in her deciding to become a lone traveler, studying fighting by seeking out people to observe & learn from.Nerys likes the excitement of battle & the pleasure of winning a competition (her distant nature belies her competitiveness), and she likes observation and strategizing. Fighting feeds into all of that.

My real name is Theodas Mecla. But that's a secret. As is the rest of my story.Raised in a human village. My elven father hung around for a while, but underlying tension with the townsfolks finally chased him away. That was 50 years ago. No siblings.Mom and I worked as tinkers. We weren't destitute, but there was never anything extra. I've always hunted and scrounged to make life easier.For living in a small town, I'm well educated. When I was much younger, my mother put me in touch with teachers, so I learned some history and have always liked to read and write. I don't know what my mother had to do to get me these lessons. I don't want to know.Being exposed to these people with some class, ever since my lessons ended, I have hung around them when I could (which was rare) and snuck around to be near them when I wasn't supposed to. I watched their social events and was fascinated by the music. I'd hum along, up in a tree, behind a hedge, climbing the rooftops. Eventually I worked up the nerve to steal a viol. I'd go out into the foothills to practice, but apparently didn't go far enough. The constable confronted me at home after someone heard me playing and recognized the stolen instrument. My mother fought with him and I fled. (I don't know what happened to her. Maybe I don't want to know.) I panicked. I was sure this was a disaster and, um, maybe I overreacted. I ran through back alleys and broke into a few shops, where I grabbed a few weapons, some clothing, and some supplies, then headed out. I traveled for about a month, trying not to attract notice.A week ago I arrived here in Celia, tired and hungry. I've invented a new name for myself  and a new backstory.

My name is Tecla Moldovite. You probably haven't hear of me, but my family is of minor (very minor) nobility in the elven court of Duke Xander, Blessed Lord of the Silver Circle. I am the youngest son, and knew I needed to grow in order to serve my family. My education was broad, but not particularly deep in all areas. My parents loved me and hoped I'd be Chancellor of the Exchequer, but fully supported my decision to find my own way, learning about the world and eventually bringing that knowledge and experience back to my family and my people. I have been adventuring in ways large and small for about a year now. I have come to Celia to rest, restock, and seek my next task.

Sold into slavery by his tribe and forced into the fighting pits at an early age, he made his escape and adopted the name Wyvern after being taken in by the local thieves guild. Not content with the role of a bruiser, Wyvern adapted his skills of tracking and observation to become a skilled assasin.
Outlander
noble
Noble

I grew up on the streets. Begging for food doesn't work so well when you look like a devil child. So pickpocketing and larceny were the main ways to keep fed.Not long before "setting out for a life of adventure", I was involved in a robbery of a noble. During the robbery, I laid eyes upon the tome. Something about it stole my interest to the exclusion of all else. As I approached the tome I began to hear whispers in my mind. Upon touching the tome, time itself seemed to stand still. A bright light appeared and a voice of power proclaimed that I had been chosen; that I would be instrumental it plans.The light offered me a pact, if I would bind myself to its will, it would grant me great knowledge and power. Being a simple street urchin, the idea of power was enticing. This could be a way to lift myself out of the gutter and do something with my life. I agreed to the terms, and with a great flash of light, I was standing in the nobles house with the tome in my hands. None of my co-conspirators were anywhere in sight. I had no idea just how long I had been standing there, but the sounds of clamouring footsteps suggested I should be on my way with great haste. I managed to escape the nobles house, but not before being spotted and recognised, by the city watch. I spent the next few days escaping the city and haven't been back since.The tome whispers to me often, mostly just beyond comprehension. Sometimes the whispers continue into my dreams, showing me secrets that evaporate when conciseness returns the next day. But some days I awake and a new secret has lodged itself in my mind.So I find myself, on the run, with a growing power within. What better way to stay ahead of my pursuers and practice my new power, than to take up the life of an adventurer.
Arrested in a beer hall putsch in 83.

Hatched at the Cloudtop Monastery in the Spine of the World, Skal grew up as the only one of his kind. Quick to master the syncretic martial art taught at the monastery, Skal earned the ire and envy of the other students. Feeling more an outcast, Skal took wing and left to make a name for himself doing what he did best.. hitting things. Now a mercenary, he has found himself in Waterdeep, seeking new contracts.

Sold into slavery by his tribe and forced into the fighting pits at an early age, he made his escape and adopted the name Wyvern after being taken in by the local thieves guild. Not content with the role of a bruiser, Wyvern adapted his skills of tracking and observation to become a skilled assasin.

Sorcha's father was a tutor for a noble household, and from an early age she idolized the courtly knights. She persuaded the young lord to let her serve as a squire and riding off to battle with him was the proudest day of her life. Her journey took a turn for the tragic when he died under mysterious circumstances and another squire placed the blame on Sorcha! She fled and found a new home amongst the Harpers. She adventures now as one of their agents, determined to prove her innocence and do enough good in the world to earn respect as a knight.

Sir Alder grew up in a noble household that lost everything but their name in the Spellplague. He took his duties seriously and did everything in his power to become what a lord and leader ought to be. He left home to seek fame and fortune and find his rightful place in the world.

Abraxos was tragically kicked out of Klan Kardashian for not looking good in lip kits. Morose, he lived as a hermit for many years and devoted his time to studying zombies- the greatest menace to society. While alone, he befriended a wild mule who he named Mulie. Now, Abraxos travels with Mulie and his saddlebags full of research on zombies as he seeks to rid the world of this undead scourge.

Character's name: Bindle Growly Zook Papasko Eddy Donahue Dornbill
Character's backstory: Bindle grew up in a gnome village deep in the Heartwood forest, long before Pinecrest existed. From a young age he showed an unbridled sense of wonder at the world as well as a powerful wanderlust, but it wasn't till his 80th birthday that his unapproving parents finally relented. They gave him the family heirloom, a 5 pointed star medallion made of a silver metal, and sent him out into the world.Bindle explored to his heart's content, visiting all the far reaches of the continent. His travels lasted nearly a century before he returned to find his village gone. Abandoned abruptly many years past, the dilapidated homes still had tables set. Bindle searched for his people for decades to no avail before finally giving up, building a homestead and settling where his village once stood. As the years past and civilization encroached on the Heartwood, Bindle became a forest guide. To the people of the new frontier town of pinecrest, he is a fixture of the forest, ensuring safe passage and returning the lost.

Alton and his brother, a rogue, ended up being evicted from their home after a bad harvest caused their family to go bankrupt. They started running an easy con; Alton distracted people in a tavern with his music while his brother pickpocketed them. A thieves’ guild noticed their aptitude for theft and took them in. They ran many a con and a heist until meeting the party.

Began life in an upper-middle-class family in the Dawnworld, learning medicine as the family trade, but became interested in medical and magical artifacts. Eventually kicked out of her city on suspicion of necromancy.

Growing up on the shady streets of Sirpana (a bustling trade center), Cierro learned to make it the hard way; with his hands in other people's wallets. While he started off as an average pick-pocketing urchin, he quickly learned that the real valuables were not in one's pocket, but in their home. He lived as well as one could on the streets, stealing small fortunes to keep himself well fed and better equipped. If he bought the local tavern crowd a few rounds, well, they deserved it for having to put up with him. Even though he had moved on to big targets, the allure of stealing right from under peoples noses was still there. One afternoon in the market, he was caught stealing even amidst the hubbub - caught by a human, no less! One argument later, and he was stuck "atoning for his sins" with the worlds nosiest paladin.

Life is a Journey, Time is a River, the Door is AjarThe story of Lola Slaptrap can be categorized as a series of existential questions.  Why am I here? How the hell did that happen? Does this smell like chloroform to you?  Unfortunately for Duane Choquette, the GM who will be putting Lola through the Curse of the Crimson Throne, the fine line that divides truth and fiction gets a bit hazy in Korvosa.How Lola was initially sold into slavery appears to be a matter of some debate.  Respectable sources have provided several equally plausible explanations, the validity of which have been debated with academic vigor.  There is credible truth to the rumor that Lola talked her own parents into selling her for the sum of 18 coppers and a bag of tricks. It was a pretty good deal by halfling standards.  However, equally plausible is the explanation that a Chelaxian beekeeper found her stuffed in an apiary at the age of 12.  Lola may also have been part of an experimental halfling breeding program to reduce the cost of slaving expeditions. Unfortunately, the program was scrapped when it was discovered that the halfling work ethic gene was inextricably connected to an increased dependency on sardines, which anyone with half a brain knows are prohibitively expensive in Cheliax.  The breeding program was deemed financially unsustainable, and the Chelaxian state returned to the economically sound practice of kidnapping.It is likely that Lola escaped from the dreaded Chelaxian Turnip Pits through circumstances both mysterious and brilliant.  There may have been a situation involving a particularly lucky set of dice, a tribe of Mwangi cannibals, and a feat of diplomacy that ended with the slavers in a very bad position.  Unless you were a Mwangi cannibal.  In a comparatively likely account, a forged application, a misplaced mailbag and a judicious dose of whiskey produced a foreign exchange program that resulted in a Chelaxian halfling named Nigella landing in Varisia, and a somewhat disappointed Shoanti exchange student named Mofongo who later wrote a strongly worded letter about the quality of dormitories at the Chelaxian Turnip Pits.  It is also entirely possible that Lola smuggled herself out of the Turnip Pits disguised as a pack of wild dogs.  Reliable sources stipulate that three halflings dressed as a Calistrian concubine supposedly arrived in Korvosa aboard the Dread A’tuin.  Lola had the misfortune of playing the left leg.  If you were not already aware, it is extremely difficult to ride sidesaddle as three halflings wearing one yellow toga.  The logistics can be somewhat distressing. The standard explanation includes an exuberant sea captain known as Roberts.  If the stories are to be believed, Lola was swallowed whole by a whale halfway across the Arcadian Ocean.  She purportedly survived off of hard tack and the barnacles growing along the creature’s esophagus.  Only her mastery of the fabled Brown Note saved Lola from certain digestion, and placed her, somewhat odoriferously, in the Korvosan harbor. Credible accounts have also indicated that Desna herself brought Lola to Korvosa on a chariot, dropping the halfling off with three gold, 50 silver and a mandate to do something anywhere but Taldor.  Incidentally, you never want to be Nigella in Taldor.There is undeniable proof that Lola was chased by anywhere between 15 and 74 men in bath towels down Dyer’s Row.  Eyewitness accounts of the incident vary.  Apparently, this may have been due to Lola’s theft of a debutante’s virginity through unintentionally unique methods.  In fact, the young lady’s misfortune at Lola’s hands - or feet, if the rumors are correct - was due to a well-placed kick so impressively forceful that the Korvosan heiress in question suffered irreparable damage to her reputation. That is, at least, if we are to take the word of El Pompador Churrasco, philanderer extraordinaire.  Other viable explanations have implied a connection to the Laundress, a serial vandal who struck communal baths in Korvosa over a period of two and a half years.  Conservative political scholars have suggested that the Laundress may actually have been a radical member of the Elven People’s Front.  Debates are ongoing.  A third hypothesis suggests a case of unfortunate timing.  On the day in question, no less than twenty-six complaints were filed with the Brothel Owners’ Oversight Bureau citing misrepresentation of Calistrian concubines who turned out to be three male dwarves in a trenchcoat.  The bureau’s monthly meeting dissolved into riots when the coat check caught fire.“And that’s how I ended up getting chased by the guys in bath towels down Dyer’s Row.  Then I ran into you, and we ended up here.” said Lola, polishing off Diego’s third beer.  He hadn’t actually drunk any of this one.  Or the previous two.  Diego paused to wipe down the mug with a murky dishrag before asking “But who is Duane?”
A great and powerful dwarf running from home destroyed by orc!

Born and raised as part of a secretive order of assassins dedicated to “The Blessed One,” a good of death. The assassins believe it is their duty to ensure people die at their proper “time” and do not work for money. The hidden monastery is attacked by troops in service to allies of one of their victims and ultimately destroyed after a long battle. Deipho is the lone survivor...because he couldn’t go through with the ritual suicide that the assassins’ leader ordered to prevent their capture, fearing death in the end. Distraught at what he saw as his betrayal of his faith and god, Deipho managed to flee and, in despair, threw himself from a cliff (despair allowing him to do what his faith could not)...but was rescued by a flock of ravens, the symbol of his god, and fished out of the river by a guild master of an organization that helps those in need. Now, convinced his god is trying to teach him something, he travels with heroes and tries to learn the truth of his god’s will. (It later emerges that the Blessed One was always a god of Gentle Death, the peaceful end to life, and his teachings had been corrupted and his power stolen to form the assassins - he uses Deipho to restore his true ways).

Zarga was born as heiress to the throne of a large mountainous clan of half-dragons, but the thought of being in a leadership position scared her and she ran away. Now she travels the world looking for a new purpose, preferrably one with less responsibility.
Failed bard

After plague, war, and disinterest dissolved his clan, he wandered the realms without purpose, eventually settling into an abandoned monastery. Endless days practicing the forms in the waterlogged scrolls and chipped carvings have left him strong and lean, but no closer to finding a home.

Born into a loving but poor "family" in the city of Japset.-He lives in a commune/family of mouse-folk. 23 consistent members that all live together and around 10 more that come and go. -A massive fire tore through the city when he was 10 years old (adult age).-He and his large family survived the fire by fleeing underground and into the city's stormdrains. -The devastation was so complete that they had to flee to ???.-Joseph saw a recruitment flyer lying on the city street advertising decent pay and adventure in the King's army. So he decided to enlist in order to provide for his family and see the world.  -He was ridiculed, hazed, and even beaten during the start of his military enlistment. The other larger race soldiers wanted to make him quit. They thought mouse-folk were too weak for military life. After suffering through this he vowed to take my revenge on any bully he encountered.-After basic training, the recruiters pushed him towards stealth based roles instead of direct battle combat. Just like many of the gnome and halfling recruits.  -Worked as a spy and saboteur.-Would sneak close to enemy encampments, count troop numbers, and destroy heavy artillery by using delayed explosives. -Served during 3 separate wars for 8 years total-Escaped his time in the service relatively unscathed but developed his stealth and fighting skills greatly. -Left the service after 8 years because he was prevented from gaining a higher rank due to bigotry from his higher officers.

Talia was born in a middle class family in the kingdom of Dalimar. Her father built small machines and gizmos, which Talia loved to help with. Dalimar is ruled by a tyrant. The government tries hard to control all magic users, forcing them to work for the army or imprisoning and killing them. Talia showed magical ability from a young age. This worried her parents, who knew that sending her to the mage schools to learn to fight would be dangerous for a child. Instead, they scraped and saved everything they could to send Talia out of the country, to the kingdom of Eradis.Eradis is much more accepting of magic users, and generally much less of a dystopia. Talia joined the mage guild there, where she worked on developing the art of combining magic and technology. Talia loves Eradis and considers it her home, and hopes to bring her family there some day.Everything changes when a night elf assassin climbs through her window and tries to kill her. She defends herself. The next day, she's contacted by a government official. Dozens of those assassins came through town, attacking people and stealing something big. Talia is one of a handful who survived assassination attempts (though it is not understood why any of them were even targets) and the government offers to pay them to investigate what is going on.This ends up starting a bizarre adventure, fighting demons and yuan-ti and shadow elementals and zombie beholders, all the while becoming increasingly embroiled in a conflict that looks to become a world war...

Paul Fin is a puffin Aarakocra bird bard merchant. Specifically, Paul wants to sell used cars. Fortunately, Paul is a great merchant. Unfortunately, cars don't exist, let alone used cars. When he was young (about 3), he was told via divine message to sell a car. Even now as he is older and wiser (at 8 years old), the knowledge of what a car is eludes him. A chatty bird who loves to sell and prefers not a fight. Sheds a lot when nervous and is flirty with most (if not all) customers.

Ember is the half-efreet child of a local blacksmith.  Growing up, she faced prejudice for her unusual appearance.  When she was a young adult, her father was struck ill suddenly, and she turned to forgery and other illegal activities to get enough money to support him.  No matter what, her father must not find out.

At a young age, he was trained in a monastery dedicated to the way of the Blood of Vol cult, which taught the ways of becoming immortal through sheer inner strength. He rejected what he believed to be wicked and deceitful magic, instead focusing on perfecting his body and mind to defeat those evils. However, after finding himself the lone survivor of a raid on his cult compound by their foes at the Mages guild, he began to travel the world to perfect his arts and achieve immortality through force of will.

Hired for his brute strength and blind loyalty to the mageguild, this sadistic yet rule-abiding dumb brute has joined the expedition. Probably with secret orders from a parallel dimension (make something up dm)

The daughter of a noble and renowned family in Calimport, she set out to the north as an ambassador of her city and, being noble-born, she expects everyone she meets to pay deference to her. Even in the Underdark.

Jin traveled with a traveling preforming caravan through her childhood, where she learned to sing and tumble. Shortly before she came of age, her wild magic began to manifest, starting small and becoming more and more unpredictable and dangerous. One night, when her magic flared while the caravan slept, she caused a fire that did significant damage not only to the caravan, but also to the town they were staying in. She was asked to leave - she remembers this being on better terms than it was. She has worked as a traveling performer since then to earn her keep, until she took up adventuring as a way to meet new people.

Mara has two passions: the arcane arts, and cats. At a young age she knew she wanted to be a wizard, and therefore devoted her time to mastering her magical abilities, eventually becoming a professor at an elite wizarding academy. While she never expected her life to change outside of her academic lifestyle, at the age of 60 she was let go by the university. The dean wished to have youngeer professors to teach incoming minds, and Mara simply did not fit the bill. Heartbroken and aimless, Mara sought out to find magical artifacts that would catapault her back into wizarding fame (and maybe secure her job once more). However, she couldn't leave her beloved cat, Sir Purr, behind as she traveled. So she brought her cat with her, and the two set off together on a elderly adventure.

A researcher who's been abroad for a long time (this is no young gnome). He is fascinated by biological phenomena and is driven to understand the natural world - but will suffer no one to mock him or his endeavours.
Lived on a farm, but when he inherited and was supposed to take over he lacked wisdom to run it properly
Albert ze Owlbear is very tired of, how you say, these shenanigans.

Created as a very bad Star Trek knock-off, Mr. Wok has probably been through more unpleasant situations than his namesake, including being set on fire on a regular basis and catapulted into the sun.  However, it is all worth it because he now has DeForest Kelley on a stick.  Some day he will get to sit in the captain's chair without getting catapulted into the sun.
Parents left her at the doorstep of an elven temple, where she was raised in their faith - and then she stole a sacred book in order to find its missing pages
Ran away from an arranged marriage to join the church. With a sword.
Orphaned in an attack on his village, lived in the wilderness raised by wolves.
Deserted the army after a terrible injury. Now she does crime.

The day is bright, at odds with the expression on the face of the drow who watches two children playing together; one a human, the other an elf, though both have the characteristic pointed ears of the high elves. The children are both nobles, but for nobles they are rather decent people still. Emman isn't looking forward to the day they decide to leave him, and with the ninth birthday of the girl he's realised just how close that day is getting. He outgrew all of his friends who were high elves, and now he's faced with a friend who will outgrow him. It's not a good feeling. "Em, c'mon, it's my birthday!""Hm?"Emman flinches as he realises he's being addressed, and meets the eyes of the high elf child tugging on his wrist. "Yeah?""Me and Georgie want to know what you think about the new law my dad passed."Emman's eyebrows raise, and he leans in conspiratorially, whispering in undercommon,"Which law is this?"Music bites her lip and says,"Oh, yeah. Um, they haven't told anyone about it yet, but it's um, a curfew thing, for drow. My dad says we can't have a bunch of shads wandering the streets after dark."Emman winces, both at the curfew and the word she uses. "I know you didn't know this, Music, but 'shad' is not a good word to use.""Oh," Music says, looking hesitant. Georgie cuts in,"It's like how people call us mold cus we grow so faster.""So /much/ faster," Emman corrects his grammar. "Yeah, that," Georgie says, switching back to Elvish. "So what do you think?"Music continues in Undercommon again. "Not all who wander are lost," Emman says, "and I think your father is just so used to being lost that he assumes everyone else is too."Georgie giggles, but Music looks Emman in the eye and nods solemnly. She gets it. It's better than nothing.---"I wanted to return this to Music."He holds up the necklace Music gave him, the one that had been passed down through her family for generations. Since it's a valuable heirloom, and belongs, under law, to Music, the dwarves selected it as her side of their secret communication set. Music's father notes with satisfaction that his daughter's (hopefully former) best friend no longer wears the prosthetic ears she fashioned for him all those years ago. "You really think that after the way you've insulted my family and culture, I'll allow you near her?"Georgie takes a deep breath, and lies through his teeth."I know my actions were unforgivable, sir, and in no way do I claim to be deserving of the opportunity to see her. However, I cannot help but feel that Music deserves better than to--"The king's advisor takes a menacing step forward, and for a few tense seconds after Georgie stops talking, he genuinely fears for his life. "You don't even deserve to utter her name, human scum.  Give me the necklace, and I will see that she receives it. My dear Music may possess only as much life force as your kind, but she is still infinitely better than you will ever be.""I know," Georgie says, and means it.He hands the necklace over, full of anxieties about this plan, but against all odds, it works. Later that week, after he's left the elvish region completely, he speaks into his signet ring, reciting a phrase that he knows is dear to both his heart and Music's:"Not all who wander are lost."He hears a startled shuffle, and then Music's voice, and relief washes over him as he realised it worked. "Georgie?""It's me. Are you like, okay? Like are you alright?"He hears her sigh, and then she says, hesitatingly,"Father told me a servant found this necklace outside the gates, by a roadside."Georgie's expression twists for just a moment, but his voice is light when he replies,"Your dad is a liar and a thief."“I know,” Music says solemnly. She gets it.

Tezelin's father was a wandering do-gooder. He didn't actually get around to doing much good, but he did things like find lost animals and the medieval equivalent of changing that one annoying-to-reach lightbulb, so everyone loved him anyway.When Tezelin was born, everyone assumed that he was going to be the same but better. After all, there were only two possible fates for someone who looked so evil, and no one wanted to think of themself as one of the cheerful villagers who was murdered to show that someone was turning to evil. Being the supportive childhood friend of the hero sounded much nicer.Of course, no one bother to consult Tezelin about that. He would have been just as happy hanging around town and learning a trade, preferably one that didn't involve too much physical labor. When everyone's expectations got too be too much for him, he joined the clergy, on the grounds that 1) it sounded suitably heroic without involving much danger, and 2) the thought of being a tiefling cleric amused him. He didn't feel any particular affiliation with Bes, but Bes seemed like the sort of god who was chill and wouldn't mind someone worshiping him for fun.Tezelin's plan worked splendidly until Bes appeared to him in a dream and told him to go out adventuring, on the grounds that "if you're worshiping me to amuse yourself, you should at least amuse me back". Tezelin wasn't exactly thrilled by the idea, but it's hard to say no to a god who's providing you with magical powers, especially when said god can and will pester you in your dreams until you do the thing.Tezelin isn't really sure what he's supposed to be doing, so he's kind of just falling in with the first group of adventurers he finds and hoping for the best. Or the Bes-t, if you will.This will only end well.

Prince of a kingdom where the monarchy has completely collapsed, and being a prince is therefore completely meaningless, Septimus was raised from childhood to take up his family's mantle of necromancy. However, he hated the thought so much that he ran away to become an adventurer, hiding his mastery of the dark arts and pretending to be a warrior. However, he is absolutely useless with a sword, so when push comes to shove, he reluctantly falls back on his necromantic powers.

While a young newlywed pregnant with her first child, she was turned into a large herding dog by a spellcaster who wished to punish her half-elf husband.  She used her new form to rescue herself and her husband from his abusive father, and now she poses as his familiar.  She is much more competent than he is.

The younger brother of a great warrior, Janamir signed on with a slightly insane warrior-woman as her dungeon-crawl companion.  He is collecting material for a book of old poetry from the ruins they explore.  Also, they got married at some point.

Matteo is the second of seven sons.  His father, a fire mage and the bastard son of the king of the Unseelie Court, incited rebellion against the king's legitimate heir and was killed.  The seven sons were punished for his high treason by being separated and forbidden to see each other ever again.  Now bereft of his brothers, Matteo had to fulfill an oath his father had made to another faerie lord in exchange for a promise of fealty if the rebellion was successful.  He became a servant to that lord and ultimately lost his right hand as part of a struggle to reinterpret the contract that bound him.  He is now sworn to the service of the king's legitimate grandson, who is himself planning to oppose the king in a new rebellion of his own.  Matteo doesn't really believe that there's a possibility of success, but he loves his liege-lord and will never abandon his cause.

Rillian is the grandson of a great paladin-king who died gloriously at war after a dispute with his god.  As a teenager, he discovered some staggering moral failings on the part of his parents that he strongly suspects may have contributed to his grandfather's death.  Unable to countenance their crimes or to continue tacitly approving of them, he departed to pursue an audience with the god who once abandoned his family, to see if he will be allowed to complete the task that his grandfather once rejected and fulfill the family's aims.

An urban planner, archer, and whitesmith who is estranged from his family, he led a community of brilliant artificers until an unwise romantic choice destroyed everything he'd worked for and led him to a pointless, agonizing death.  His gods have now resurrected him as an infant in the arms of a stubborn young queen so that he can make things right.

Rhokimira was born to a pair of very forgetful parents. A rare pair, the human and orc truly loved each other and wished to raise their child together. Unfortunately, one evening while her father was at the market, he set her down to inspect a fruit sellers merchandise and forgot by the time he was done. He didn't realize what he'd done until after he'd returned home. Her mother questioned where he'd put her. In his backpack perhaps? Among the pears? Panic quickly set in and they rushed back to the market. They searched and searched but Rhokimira was nowhere to be found. Her parents would never see her again, instead wondering day to day what terrible fate must have befallen their child. Did she fall from the barrel and drown in the sewer? Was she kidnapped? Will she be raised in slavery? These were questions they would never answer.However, the truth of Rhokimira's fate takes a quite different tone. Shortly after her father left the stand, a passing elf named Lurias would see her sleeping form. Lurias was a very intelligent elf, learned in many forms of science, history, and magic, and he was quite aware how half-orc children were frequently abandoned by their parents out of disgust or hatred. He also had a large heart and knew that he could not leave this child to die in the market place. Gently, he took her from her perch and carried her home, whispering assurances all the while.It was with Lurias that Rhokimira, now bearing the nickname 'Kimi,' would grow. Living with the nomadic elves within their forest, she believed completely that she was also an elf, and a young one at that. Her adoptive father, while very bright, was also quite scatterbrained and overlooked the vast gap in lifespans between their races. Though she was much taller than the elves her age, she would play with them and learn with them, leaving her mental age at about 6 years old by the time she turned 21. Though she was young in her villages eyes, she was strong and insisted on following her father on his trips into nearby towns. Knowing how the roads could be dangerous, Lurias decided to teach her some of what he knew as a magus and a spelldancer. Under his careful eye she learned how to wield swords and axes in defense of herself and her family. At the same time she would learn dances and songs to strengthen her body and spell casting. The more she learned of the performing arts and magic, the more she learned to weave them together to the benefit of those around her. With Lurias and her village, Kimi was happy.When she was 18, however, she was lost again. On a visit to new town, Kimi and her father became separated in the crowd. Once she realized she couldn't see her father, she began to panic and cry. Desperate to find her father, she nearly knocked over a bard who'd been playing for tips on the side of the street. The half-elf, Rhea, was startled by the large crying woman, but held her ground and demanded an apology. Kimi immediately sobbed out an apology and an explanation of what had happened, begging Rhea to help her find her father. The woman in question was taken aback at the force of the apology and the tearful request, but took to comforting the larger woman and agreed to help. Learning that Kimi's father was, in fact, and elf was a surprise, as was her mental age, but Rhea resolved not to press and moved on. They searched the streets for several hours, but the crowds were loud and thick they could not find Lurias. They settled in a tavern for dinner and tried to find the way back to Kimi's home so that she might find her father there, but the elven village had moved only recently and Kimi had never been the best at geography. When they left to try and find the path they unknowingly left in the opposite direction. The two women found themselves hopelessly turned around come nightfall having attempted to follow a path through unfamiliar woods with the hope that it was simply a very new path to the elven village. They made camp and Rhea found herself once again comforting the scared and lonely half-orc. By morning they'd concocted a plan.They'd go on an adventure! With Rhea's street smarts, Kimi's swordsmanship, and their combined musical talent, they could go anywhere and find anyone they wanted to! And so they set off, travelling for several years and adopting each other as their new sister. While Rhea would occasionally have Kimi act as the unknowing distraction to some of her less-than-lawful activities, She cared for her and made sure that the two of them would be comfortable and happy through their travels. Though they wouldn't find her father, they kept looking as they performed from town to town.

Rilla grew up in a loving, well-adjusted elf family, and became a ranger due to her love of animals and nature. She hasn't met the right guy yet, but she does have a unicorn BFF, which is a huge incentive to stay single. She enjoys adventuring, though she always prefers negotiating her way out of a dilemma to fighting her way out. Her alignment is Chaotic Good, and her notable achievements include helping to defeat a black dragon and establishing a trading partnership with the local Merfolk. Her least-favorite vacation destination is the Isle of Dread.
From the highest mountains to the deepest seas, your quest is to find the bestest piece of lacquered wood, also known as a club, to beat the ever-living shit out of any elf you see.

The bastard son of a minor noble, Erik preferred to read books on magic all day, rather than learn much of politics.  Eventually, he  set off on a journey to regain his standing, and to find stories to tell, with his brother Albrecht staying behind.

Doryc never fit in particularly well among the gnolls of Bloodfang tribe. Despite his strength, he was never assertive or vicious enough to rise through the ranks, and was picked on by those of higher status. Though he didn’t realize it consciously at the time, this was in part because his slowly developing psionic powers allowed him a slight degree of telempathy. As an unusually nice gnoll he was disturbed both by the psychic emanations of the evil gnolls and his own instinct that they were not like him.One day, a Bloodfang raiding band attacked a group of adventurers, taking heavy losses but killing most of them and capturing one, a paladin of Pelor. It was decided that as recompense for the gnolls his party killed he would be sold into slavery the next time a slaver caravan came by, which it generally did about once a month. However, Doryc sensed something of a kindred spirit in this paladin, known as Sir Gerard.For about a week after Gerard’s capture, Doryc would sneak over to where he was kept to talk with him and offer a share of his food. Seeing both his kindness and the fact that he didn’t read as evil, Gerard became friends with Doryc and told him stories of his adventuring days. He talked about how close he felt to his companions, and spoke with fondness and almost paternal protectiveness about his party’s sorcerer. His role in combat was to keep her safe while she cast the mighty spells that won them the day. She was based fairly heavily on Nylin from the Shaldar campaign.After several days of interaction, Doryc decided that he couldn’t stand to see his new friend sold into slavery.  He and Gerard hatched a plan to escape. Because most of the low-status gnolls (like Doryc) got stuck with guard duty regularly, he would have a chance to free Gerard during the night when most of the gnolls would be asleep. Their plan worked perfectly, right up until the two of them were on their way out with most of Sir Gerard’s gear. By sheer awful luck, the one free survivor of Gerard’s old adventuring band chose that night to try and rescue Sir Gerard from the gnolls himself. When he couldn’t find Gerard, he panicked, and ended up waking up enough of the gnolls to sound the alarm. Gerard, realizing what had gone wrong, insisted on running back to save his old friend, and when Doryc tried to restrain him he broke Doryc’s nose getting free. Doryc ran back trying to save him, but arrived too late, and found both Gerard and his friend dying. With his last breath, Gerard urged him to run, take his holy symbol and find Gerard’s old friend Malkorak. Half-blinded by tears, he did.Though it took him several weeks of searching, he eventually managed to track down Malkorak and tell him what had happened. Fortunately, Malkorak scanned him with detect evil and found that he didn’t show up, otherwise Doryc’s lack of tact and poor explanation might have gotten him killed.
After falling in love with the thane’s daughter, Martigan is exiled from her homeland when she refuses to kill the child of a rival ruler.

Disabled goblin who has a steampunk mech suit, built with the help of their now dead wife. Uses the mech for adventuring, but also for fighting, as they had done in a barely legal combat arena for a criminal organization they were associated with. They got involved with the criminal organization because of their rage from their wife's accidental death, which they are still trying to work out.

She was a necroalchemist who was driven out of town for crimes against humankind. Now she wanders the world taking on dozens of identities and selling snake oil while failing to avoid the temptations of necromantic study.

Was the wise woman of an Orc tribe, until she started receiving the whispers of a god she couldn't identify. These whispers encouraged her to spread the word of nonviolence and peace for all people. Her son, the chief of the tribe, could not allow her to keep trying to spread the word within the tribe, so she left to try and find a better way to save her tribe and all people from a life of war and violence.

When Ruby was a youth she got into trouble with the law by engaging in petty shenanigans, some light breaking and entering, and vandalism. Fearing she wouldn’t find a respectable trade and would fall into a life of crime, her father apprenticed her to an archaeologist, who took her adventuring far from home, teaching her the skills needed to disarm traps and open old locks. A few years into her apprenticeship the archaelogist’s adventuring group was investigating an ancient temple when disaster struck. While Ruby was disarming a trap the roof collapsed, killing everyone else in the party, and Ruby trapped. It took her days to dig herself out and until this day she has no idea if the roof collapsing was a result of her disarming the trap incorrectly, or the result of the dilapidated temple finally giving way under its own weight.

Rairaela came from a clan of dessert Kobolds led by an adult yellow dragon. Rairaela left their clan when they found a cursed time of alchemy and artificer knowledge written by a gnome, the book couldn't take full control of the kobold, but it did influence their personality to give them a sense of wanderlust. They set out from the warren, meeting up with a band of adventures.

She grew up in her huge, well-established and powerful dragonborn clan, the Casaadi. Wralarys was the pride and joy of the clan, daughter to two of the most prominent leaders, and was on track to take over as clean leader when she was cursed. She is now haunted by a spirit and was forced to leave her clan, working instead as a freelance mercenary cleric until she can figure out how to remove the curse and return home.She hears the spirit talking to her in her head on occasion, and has to try not to lose her mind in the process.

Lord of the Rings setting: Udo was orphaned in a boating accident but rescued and raised by a wandering ranger, Halros, guarding the borders of the Shire. Udo was taught to track and to hunt with a bow and was also learned in letters and languages. Halros also imparted upon Udo the honor code of the Dunedain. When he was old enough to do so, Udo returned to his home town of Frogmorton and became a Bounder and eventually a Shirriff. He was remembered most for thwarting a small goblin camp northeast of Hobbiton and retrieving Aunt Prunella's favorite umbrella from the goblin chief.

Feklahr was an outcast to the human world despite his mother being a woman of their kind. Large by human standards but small for an ogre he would have to fight twice as hard to earn his place in their ranks. His ogre family were nomadic and only hunted large herd animals for food and clothing. The ogre chief would also earn them weapons and supplies by hiring the warriors out as mercenaries. A fearful group of humans attacked and captured many ogres one night. Feklahr was forced into slavery and used as a gladiator in arenas. Wishing to be free of his bonds, Feklahr looked to the sky and asked for the strength to gain his freedom. A not-entirely benevolent lesser deity named Zartos heard Feklahr's plea and agreed to give him great strength through rage if Feklahr would proclaim Zartos' name in his carnage and violence.Feklahr killed his captors and freed the remaining ogres. He also freed an elven man with odd mind powers that he had befriended in the arena and they traveled the Sword Coast raiding slavers. Feklahr's name was feared by evil-doers due to the ferocity of his assaults, but loved by the people he helped to free.

Pockets  (her street name)  uses the inherent nimble and delicate touch of an elf to aid in her thievery.  Rejected by her human father and her elven mother,  she grew to maturity among human children in an orphanage.  Being the smallest meant she learned early to hide, to cloak herself in shadows in order to avoid being bullied.  Honing her skills,  developing an almost magical "don't see me" aura,  Pockets became first a pick pocket,  then a professional thief.  Allied with the guilds in several cities,  she now makes her living procuring documents for the wealthy,  as well as what ever else migrates into the many hidden pockets of her patchwork cloak.

Faila was born to a very wealthy merchant family on the way to royalty. Her parents had arranged a marriage between her elder sister and a duke to secure the Marivaldi tie to royalty and hopefully come into more money. Faila, being jealous and materialistic, wanted to be married to the duke herself. She spent her time studying the occult to learn how to make a deal with a demon so she could rise to opulence. She hoped if this demon could give her a silver tongue, a crafty mind, and a the dirt on her enemies, perhaps her parents could change their mind about arranging the marriage between the duke and her sister. Faila also had a more sinister solution should her parents not see reason. She knew this demon could gift her the magic she needed to place spells on those she needed to and that she could possibly kill her sister this way. Unfortunately, as Faila has just signed the contract between her and her patron, a curious maid had opened the door. Faila’s dabbling with with dark magic was reported immediately to her parents and she was outcasted from the family so her actions would not besmirch the Marivaldi name. Having lost everything, she came to hate the pact she made and the demon with which she made it. She vowed to find a way to break the pact she made with him without losing her soul and so she adventures through the land in search of a way to break her pact and hopefully earn back her place in society.

Niddler grew up on the Hadozee homeworld, in a jungle of epic proportions, taking pleasure in gliding and swinging about the trees and vines. When he was 10, he set out on his first trip on a merchant-ship to the Rock of Bral, as a spelljamming shiphand alongside his father. He began spending more and more time on the Rock, learning to gamble and fight in an unorthodox manner.One day at the Rock of Bral, he stopped some sailors who were kicking around some urchins that offended them, and then gave the children a few gold pieces. Niddler's actions drew the eye of an elderly human noble, who saw potential in the young hadozee. He took him on as his apprentice, and Niddler lived with him on his homeworld while training under him as a warblade.Niddler's apprenticeship has just ended, and he has a thirst to adventure! To his knowledge, he is unique in the multiverse--an unusual magical incident before his birth led to him being a creature of Radiance as well as a Hadozee.

Kellett is a bounty hunter. It's a line of work he got into because he saw it as a route to quick money, and a route out of the miserable, muddy village in which he grew up. He got into has fair share of fights as a kid, teenager and young man, and often found he was just that little bit quicker than his opponent. He's also particularly fast with a throwing knife, and there's usually one stuck down the side of his boot. When Kellett first started as a bounty hunter, he'd take on pretty much any kind of contract, and he wasn't too picky about who was offering the bounty, or why. Then came the contract when, walking through a doorway like any other, in an inn like any other, he took a spider bite that should have killed him. His fellow adventurers carried him to a monastery, where the monks pretty much brought him back from death's door. They weren't concerned about his past, or his flexible conscience: it was enough, for them, to do whatever they could to revere and preserve life. When Kellett found out how his life had been saved, he made three resolutions: first, that one fifth of all his bounties would be paid over to the monastery; second, that he would only accept contracts that redressed an evil; third, that he would always try first to fulfil his contract without killing, and only kill as a last resort.

When she was ten, her father left her mother to destitution. The two were taken in by a kind priestess of Eilistraee whom fed and clothed them. To Koko's surprise, her mother and the priestess fell in love and married. Afterwards she became a permanent member of the faith and worshipped the Drow Goddess for her good fortune. She studied medicine and found her passion was in preserving life. It became her obsession. Eventually, she decided her new goal in life was to perform a life-saving miracle so grand it could only make her Goddess proud. She found her chance when a mysterious letter turned up from someone calling themselves "The Master". Intrigued, she made her way to meet a group of adventurers hoping to find the opportunity to prove her worth.

Okaat was purchased at a very young age by the powerful elf Bladesinger Evangeline. She was raised as a slave in Evangeline's household, although she enjoyed favored status as her mistress' acolyte. Okaat showed a talent for magic early on, and was rigorously trained to become a skilled Bladesinger and an artful thief. As she grew older, however, Okaat began to suspect that Evangeline was training her to become a weapon on the wrong side of a deadly impending civil war. She was tasked with killing Castile, a kindly cleric with whom she had grown close, and stealing a priceless relic of his that Evangeline believed had turned the last war against the Bladesingers and their plot to overthrow the Prismatic Queen. Rather than allow herself to become a pawn in her mistress' games, Okaat warned Castile and escaped to the town of Wander to begin her life anew. She knows she must hide her skills as a Bladesinger, as those skills unequivocally cast her as a villain in the eyes of most of the world. She is also careful to hide her tiefling origins, due to the prejudice shown her race by most of the world. When she hides her horns and ears, she can pass for a human or half-elf. She is currently in the town of Sparrow, searching for an entity known only as the Moonfire Phoenix.

Raised with his single mom, when he realized he was credited he delighted in his mom's attention. But his abilities free the attention of cuts that kidnapped him and tortured him. He broke out and killed the children of the cultists to pay them back for what they did to his mother. He was caught by green Paladins. One gnome vouched for him until his death. The gnome sacrificed his life for Romero. Now, Romero lives his life as a green paladin, oath of ancients, to live up to his hero.

The son of the village barber, his father was murdered before his eyes after he accidentally sliced the ear of an orc crime lord who was passing through town during a haircut. Orphaned, the young boy was taken in by the nearby monastery, devoted to the notion of natural beauty as the manifestation of the gods' love for their creation. Now, as a grown man and trained monk, he struggles to balance the peaceful teachings of his brothers and sisters with his deep-seated desire for revenge against the orc who destroyed his family.

Created as one of the first of a new breed of soldier--a living amalgam of adamantine, steel, and animating magics--impervious to pain, requiring neither sleep nor sustenance, and never questioning orders; the nameless warrior's destiny was irrevocably altered when he was captured in the aftermath of a great battle by a dwarven mage with a penchant for collecting rare and exotic objects. The dwarf saw the soldier as nothing more than an automaton, and used his magics to keep the soldier frozen in place, draped in a cloth and bent into a useful shape. For years, the soldier existed as the dwarf's chosen table, the only name he was ever given, unable to move or see the world around him, but ever-awake and ever more aware of both his surroundings and himself. At last, one day, he was freed in a daring raid on the mage's keep by a group of freedom fighters who had learned of his plight and, unlike the dwarf, believed him to be an intelligent being possessed of a soul. They broke the spell and unleashed him from his confinement, finally free to make his own choices and find his own way in the world, a magical metal hulk with a major chip on his shoulder (as well as a healthy smattering of spikes).

Riska grew up in the High Forest, in a gnome colony mainly consisting of her very, very extended family. The winter of her 16th year, a group of Traders from far away became lost in the forest, and were invited to spend the winter with the Gnomes. They brought with them an amazing new product: coffee. Risk I decided to travel with them when they returned to their Homeland and establish a trade route for this amazing drink.When they finally arrived in Midani, the current regime was unwilling to trade with Outsiders. Local gnomes convinced Rizka that they were evil and authoritarian and needed to be stopped. So Rizka helped them.She has yet to realize that this might have been a mistake.
Mei was a
Born of red dragon blood, but with a conscience.
He eats Thornax Stew, kills assholes, and breaks every bone in your body simply because he can.

- The Frentini are a race of bears that evolved to be bipedal and have human intelligence. It is a subrace of yhe general animorphs.  - The Frentini people are a very gender divided society, with the men hunting and ruling and the women foraging and tending to domestic duties. The chief of her tribe,her father, married a Frentini female the council of elders considered sickly and weak and only bore him two daughters. He didn't mind ,he loved her and was a very liberal against the grain kind of chief. As he raised his eldest daughter, Ursa  he allowed her to choose her own path in life and it turned out she was great at fighting. She was the best warrior in her village , and her father promised her she could be the next chief, despite tradition. He died suddenly and Ursa was set to be the next chief but her aunt who was on the council decided to rally against her in order to get her own son made chief. Despite the fact he was practically the drooling kind of stupid and much less qualified in combat . Regardless the Frentini are rooted in tradition and even though Ursa was appreciated for her skills throughout the village they decided to go with a male heir. Ursa was enraged by this and left her home. She loved her family but -from her perspective -  they did nothing to prevent her cousin's undeserving rise to power. She left for a land where she heard anyone could be anything . There she fell on hard times, looking for work with no luck,  living in the slums of the city reserved for fellow animorphs. One day she accidently ended up in a bar on slam poetry night. Many feminists and other minority groups were speaking about the discrimination they faced simply because of features they inherited from birth.  Ursa understood this struggle.  Their passion to change the world they are in reignited her own and she became an avid supporter of civil rights for all impressed peoples. A few days later she found a team looking for fighters and joined them. They dubbed themselves Tactical Grace and set off. Now she gets to do what she loves and fight and spread the word of justice and equality for all.  So,yeah she's basically a giant bear that goes around and will punch you out while also renlentlessly telling you about the struggles facing minority groups in that world.

Asher Evenwood is the youngest child of the family at 26. He has older twin siblings and parents. He had another older brother, but Reed died when Asher was 4 and Reed was 7. Asher doesn’t know the details; all he remembers is Reed being there one day, and then being gone the next. He remembers tears and being sent to his Uncle Rowan’s place more frequently and for longer periods of time. Reed had been kidnapped and subsequently killed in a plot to take his family’s estate. Afterward, Asher’s family was never quite the same.Before, Asher had been pampered and spoiled. After Reed’s death, he found himself either sent to Uncle Rowan’s or pushed aside so his family could take care of business. The twins, distant before, seemed equally less likely to take care of him and infuriated whenever he didn’t take anything seriously. His parents were more withdrawn, seeming only to talk to him when he did something wrong. But despite of that, there was always someone watching him, even if a hired guard. Asher found the combination of the constant guard and his family’s silence stifling. In fact, the only place he truly felt free was at Uncle Rowan’s. Even as he got older, he was still under guard (sometimes even without his own knowledge, which always ended in argument).Asher didn’t like to say that he left home on a negative note, but he wouldn’t say that he left on good terms. His father fell ill a few years before he ventured on his own, and his mother became preoccupied with caring for him. His twin siblings were responsible for most of the estate, essentially running it. The day before he left, Asher had argued with his brother on responsibility, with his brother accusing him of never helping the family (something which Asher insisted he tried but was always turned away). Asher left the next day, saying good bye to his siblings and parents, determined to prove that he was worthwhile to his family and to himself.

A group of monks found an abandoned tielfing infant one day in the woods.  They decided to raise her among them in their isolated monastery rather than let her die.  As she grows, she has a recurring nightmare about an impeding disaster that would destroy a city.  As she grows, they get more intense.  After talking with the monks, they realize her nightmare is actually a vision.  To stop the disaster from happening, she sets off on a journey to find the city from her vision and protect it.

Sevash's people inhabited a harsh, desert realm. They were nomadic, moving from oasis to oasis, city to city, their unrooted lives preventing much in the way of solid government. They were divided into clans that competed or went to war with each other as often as they worked together. Sevash's father, Tehebash, led his clan to great glory, becoming a powerful warlord. He eventually united most of the clans to fight a war against an elven kingdom, carving out a clear and lasting territory for the clans to live and work on. As a result, Sevash was essentially a prince to this new kingdom. He was sent to receive an urbane education in the northern cities, but he returned to the kingdom torn by strife. His father clung to power, but his uncles and other usurpers were all vying to control the kingdom. Along with his northern schooling, Sevash had been well-trained in combat by his father, using the ehl-herkar style of fighting, in which one gives in to the rage of battle, harnessing it to achieve great physical feats. Sevash excelled in this style of combat, yet he considered himself above it by virtue of his schooling. He wanted to bring the kingdom into a more sophisticated future, leaving what he saw as primitive tribal ways behind. When he did let the rage sweep over him, afterward he carefully combed his white hair and stitched any rends in his fine garments, seeming embarrassed by his own barbaric nature. He is constantly in conflict between his warrior heritage and his educated side, and has not yet figured out how to integrate the two halves of his life.

Smok is a small, wiry man with an awkward, crooked face. He's not especially strong or athletic, and in fact is rather clumsy. The one thing he's good at is making people laugh. He joined a group of Blue Banner warriors fighting in the War of the Nine Clans, and soon found himself promoted from cook to mascot.
