His ability to revive the morale of the soldiers after a defeat, keep them smiling on a hard march, or even whip them into a fervor just before a battle became far more valuable to the company than any combat skills Smok may have been lacking. He proudly declared his nickname as company mascot to be "Smok," which in his native language means "dragon." However, it is also used as a slang word for "penis." Smok knows this, and the other soldiers do as well, so they often ride into battle with cries of, "We never fight without our Smok!" with Smok singing a ribald song utterly out of tune. During battles, Smok often uses his wit to shout jibes at the enemy, affecting their morale and inciting them to make ill-considered decisions. Indeed, in one famous incident, Smok shouted insults at an orc captain, who grew so angry he accidentally choked on his own tongue. Smok had mocked him TO DEATH.

A clumsy elf from a seafaring nation became fascinated by stone. However, he wracked up a huge debt while learning magic and had to flee his homeland. Now he adventures as an unassuming wizard of moderate power and an outsized ego.

At the age of 15, Geirolf left his farming home in a small village in the kingdom of Bergenwald to join a mercenary company, lying about his age. The Whitestone Company accepted him, and he trained as a spearman in their infantry. For two seasons, they fought against orcish incursions from the northeast, and he distinguished himself enough to advance to the rank of squad leader, then Sergeant. In his third campaign year, the company was hired by Duke von Schoenbeck, one of the Dukes of Bergenwald, to hold his border against a Duchess with whom a dispute had broken into open fighting. Two of the company's three field cohorts  were tasked with guarding the Duke's own city and its surrounds from encroachment by the opposing Duchess, while the third, including Geirolf, was assigned to garrison the Blackwolf Fort, which guards a pass leading into the Duke's lands. The fort was assaulted by another mercenary company, Damian's Dragons, hired by the opposing Duchess, with vastly superior force. After holding out for four days, the captain in charge of the cohort surrendered the fort to the Dragons, who treated the Whitestone soldiers honorably. Those who gave their parole—their binding word not to resist the occupation of the fort by the other mercenary company—were permitted a great deal of freedom in and around the fort, though no weapons beyond a dagger. A few weeks into the occupation, another force was spotted approaching the fort. It proved to be the Sand Scorpions, a third company with a much more brutal reputation.  Duke von Schoenbeck had hired them to take his fort back...and when, after a few days, the captain of the Dragons met with the captain of the Scorpions under flag of parley to discuss surrender terms, he and his guards were slaughtered, in violation of the Code all three companies were sworn to adhere to. A long and bloody siege followed, in which the Dragons and the Whitestone Company fought side-by-side against the Scorpions. With both companies manning the defenses, the fort was too tough to break, but it wasn't long before supplies began to run out...especially when the Scorpions began using magic to ruin them from afar. After two months of siege, the defenders agreed they needed to get word out about the situation, and the Whitestone Company was closest. Geirolf and a half-dozen other men and women volunteered for a perilous mission to sneak past the besieging army and reach Duke von Schoenbeck's city with the news. Four survived the breakout, and were pursued relentlessly by squads of the Scorpions. By the time they reached the Whitestone outer pickets, only Geirolf and Adya, a woman from the Dragons, remained, and both were injured and feverish. Before they could deliver their message, the tenacious Scorpion pursuers caught up to them, and the Whitestone sentries died fighting them. The two continued on, but were set upon by the last two of the Scorpions within minutes. They were forced to stand and fight, and Adya gave her life to protect Geirolf. He wears her armband even now in her memory and that of all the honorable Dragons who fought and died beside Whitestone soldiers. Geirolf continued to the inner perimeter of the Whitestone camp, where he was recognized and taken to the infirmary tent. There, he gave his message to the company's commander, Elisa Whitestone, who gave the order then and there to start packing up the camp and heading west to Blackwolf Fort.The siege was broken and the Scorpions slaughtered, almost to the man, but all that remained of the defenders were a scant few dozen men and women, malnourished and demoralized.Geirolf was given the Company's highest decoration, and given a place at Commander Whitestone's side when she confronted Duke von Schoenbeck. The orders found in the possession of the Scorpions showed clearly that he had ordered them to kill every member of the Whitestone Company who had participated in the surrender, a direct violation of the contract he signed with them. However, he refused to pay—both the penalty fees for breach of contract and the original contract price, saying that by surrendering the fort, then leaving his city, they had forfeited anything he had agreed to (despite there being clauses in the contract for that express purpose).For this, the Mercenary Code has a clear answer: the Duke was blacklisted for life from ever being able to hire a bonded company again. Furthermore, the Whitestone Company's two remaining field cohorts sacked the Duke's city (mainly the Ducal palace) to make up for the pay he refused to give. Naturally, the Duchess he was feuding with also took ample advantage of the opportunity to take the territory she wanted from him.During the sack of the city, an important incident occurred. Behind a false wall in a warehouse belonging to the Duke, a squad Geirolf was leading discovered a hidden basement that had clearly been used to worship Tiamat, which is a capital crime in Bergenwald. Geirolf quickly pulled the squad out, replacing the false wall, and sought advice from his captain. That advice was to call on the local temple of Bahamut (which they had carefully avoided disturbing in the sack, along with the other temples) to see if they had anyone there who could ensure that the place was made safe for people of good will again. They were fortunate enough that the temple had a dragonborn paladin named Emidhaar resting there on her way through the land, and the next day, Geirolf's squad returned with her to the hidden basement.This time, they surprised a meeting of Tiamat's worshipers in progress, and a terrifying fight ensued. Geirolf had never before seen a clash of magics such as this, and was astounded by the paladin's ability to protect him and his squad from the curses thrown their way by the dark priest. With her aid, they slew the priest and the most obstinate of his followers, took the rest prisoner, and cleansed the evil taint from the place.To Geirolf, the Whitestone Company was never the same after that season. Most of his close friends had been killed in the siege, and his view of the Dukes who were effective rulers of Bergenwald had changed from one of somewhat petty but ultimately harmless distant figures to one of malicious overlords willing—even eager—to sacrifice anyone they viewed as beneath them if it served their ends...or just amused them.He served with the Company for another season, and in between seasons accepted a promotion to and training as an officer. He also began training in more individual combat styles, using a glaive instead of a spear. However, he was no longer able to fully commit to fighting for someone else's gain, and by the end of the season, he requested, and was granted, an honorable separation from the Company. Commander Whitestone herself told him that if he ever wanted a position within the Company again, he had only to ask for it: he would be made a full Lieutenant on the strength of his performance in that last season.After leaving the Company, he sought out Emidhaar, the dragonborn paladin of Bahamut who had aided him and his squad against the Tiamat-worshipers. She was not hard to find, as such people are not common, and provoke comment. However, it took him three months to catch up with her.Once he did, he first asked her if he could become her squire, but she said she did not wish a squire at this time—frankly, she told him that he would get in the way of what she had to do. However, upon understanding his deep desire to be able to protect people the way she did, she did agree to allow him to travel with her for a month and a half. That would take them to a major temple of Bahamut, and allow her to train him in the basics of both Bahamut's worship, and what it meant to be a paladin. If he still wished to follow that path when they reached the temple, he could stay there and they could finish his instruction. If not, he could depart and find his own way.By the time they reached the temple, Geirolf was only more certain that this life was what he sought. He spent the next few months there, practicing both his martial skills and his devotion to Bahamut and His ideals.

Caleb was born in a small town in the subterranean country of Heimgaar, to Jarrett Tierce and Silvana Langston. He, along with his older sister Nera, spent the first few years of Caleb's life in this town, mostly uneventfully but with a few exciting moments from Nera's newly manifesting magical abilities.Unfortunately, when Caleb was a toddler, the town was flooded in a tragic accident that ended up killing both of his parents. Thanks to Nera's latent magic, she and Caleb just barely managed to escape the disaster, though this event left Caleb with an intense phobia of water.Trekking through the underground with the few other survivors, Caleb and Nera were eventually taken in by their maternal aunt Beatrice, along with her wife, a dwarf named Olena, who lived in one of Heimgaar's larger cities.Beatrice began to teach the siblings in various skills as they grew; Caleb was tutored as a scribe and linguist, while Nera got further training in magic from her aunt, who used to be an adventuring wizard. However, Caleb was still a mischievous child, and would often sneak out after dark to explore the wider city.Eventually, around the time that Nera was getting ready to depart to the surface on her own adventure, Caleb's exploring caught the eye of a local mercenary, Dask Rellos (an ex-evil cult member and assassin who used to be an adversary to Caleb's aunts, but has since mellowed), who took him on as an apprentice and began training him in various rogue skills.Some years later, after most of his rogue's apprenticeship had been completed, Caleb received a letter from his sister encouraging him to come visit her on the surface, thus leading to the start of his own journey.

Finn is the eldest son of the McCool clan, a minor noble family. Deep in the misty past the McCools were a powerful family that produced many great heroes, but those days were long ago. The family has long since settled into a more comfortable bureaucratic role, and their prestige has fallen accordingly. Although they retain their legal status as nobility, the McCools are a family of modest means and few of the common people have heard of them in modern times.Although he has a build befitting his heroic ancestors of eons ago, Finn has none of their lust for battle and glory. As part of his noble upbringing, Finn was trained in the use of weapons, but the McCools have not fought for the Crown nor for the glory of the clan for centuries now. Instead, Finn leveraged his family name to secure a comfortable political appointment as the official accountant of the town of Fandolin. However, budgetary crunches have forced the town to cut back on employees and Finn found his job on the chopping block. Hearing rumors that the town of Thornwall was hiring public servants, Finn set out to try his luck...

Relwof is an outcast, cast out of polite goblin society for ruining one too many functions with ill-timed and worse-executed showmanship, including but not limited to incompetently cast spells wreaking havoc on his kin. In exile, Relwof falls in with a band of human and elvish adventurers, whose denigrating remarks can be relied upon while on the road and whose solidarity cannot when our poor goblin is denied entrance to a tavern or inn while in town.
I ama drunk
Secret order last member alive

A stubborn prince of an dwarfen mine, he never goes back on his word because of his pride. when he sets his target he is going to destroy anything to achieve it. although a nobility person he talks dirty, obsessed with work or what some might refer as workaholic. doesn't care and has no interest about non-magical items materials or crafts but instead is fascinated by the mysticism of living/clockwork/possessed/magic items, crafts,  creatures, constructs, tools, clothes, weapons and armors

Muriel was born in Waterdeep to a family of dwarves who had long ago left their ancestral lands. She joined the priesthood of Lathander early in life, in her 30s, despite the disapproval of her parents. One day, she and several of her fellow priests were sent to the Undermountain to retrieve a powerful relic of Lathander, but they were ambushed by undead foes and Muriel barely escaped with her life; her companions were all killed. After that experience, she devoted her life to healing and to the destruction of undead.

Shae knows very little of her backstory; her past comes to her in flashes and pieces. All she knows is that she died as an adventurer and her body was magically preserved long after her spirit had departed it. She awoke in a temple after a resurrection with a feeling of somehow having come back wrong, and no memory of her past. This experience has given her access to dark magic, but her driving force is to find out what happened to her in her first life and discover the source of her powers.
Wanderer

After a fairly uneventful childhood, Kava's life was going pretty great. Until she discovered alcohol whilst working as a Soldier. Despite not loving the way it tasted, she was frequently bored and would drink for the sake of it. Unfortunately, having a love for breaking things resulted in awfully destructive behaviours, especially when drunk. This lead to Kava being exiled from her town and family and, to this day, she doesn't know if her parents are alive or not. Whilst wandering in the wilderness drunk and alone she found a group of adventures who were, at first, worried at the sight of such a rare being, then accepted her into their group. After several years of travelling with this group, on the eve of their 10th year together, she suddenly realised she hadn't touched a drop of alcohol since she joined them. When she mentioned this, and that she wanted to know why she had started drinking, to the wizard who had sent them on so many journeys as a group, he sent her to see a friend of his who could allow her to uncover any lost memories. It was only at this time Kava uncovered that, while training to be a Soldier, she had not only been abused verbally and physically as part of her training, but sexually, by almost all the Officers training her. Kava had always known her promotion to Officer had come as a surprise at the time. The wizard's friend also helped her uncover short flashes of memories of torturing and murdering the Officers who had abused her. It was hard to tell if she had done this over some time or in one mad night. After these revelations, she remained tight lipped on the subject for several more years, never allowing any of her adventurer's group to know anything of her sessions with the wizard's friend. To this day, Kava has only absent mindedly uttered 3 intelligible words on the subject when asked why she went to see this man - "Past. Memories. Future."
Family murdered by dwarves, is on a vengeance quest to find the killers

Kethra Marivaldi is a tiefling, with charcoal grey skin; blank white eyes; and long black hair. She's five foot six, with a long tail, four feet long.She was orphaned at a young age--so young that she barely remembers her parents. The only thing she has left of them is her mother's holy symbol--a token left over from the Adarre society. Kethra herself is apathetic towards the gods, though she often clutches the symbol when she feels frightened or nervous--or perhaps just needs a bit of a courage boost.The streets were an unforgiving place. You either learned how to survive, or you died. It was here that Kethra learned the roguish abilities that allowed her to survive, and eventually become an adventurer worth joining the Wasteland Foxes. In addition to the roguish abilities of sleight of hand; insight; deception; persuasion; and acrobatics, Kethra also became a light sleeper who could fall asleep nearly anywhere and a knack for squeezing into tight spaces.Even now, her upbringing leaves its mark. She refuses to be separated from her supplies, keeping them close, always. She detests having less than twenty gold on her person. She hates leaving places where she has steady supply of food; medicine; and/or shelter. Her place in the world taught her the worth of words, and how much it can mean to be shown kindness--or even just a bit of respect. It also taught her how fast, and how easily, things could change.Perhaps the most prominent mark left on her is her inability to trust. It wasn't always this way. When she was young, she met a fellow urchin named Lia Anskuld--a Salma half-elf. The two worked together to ensure they had ample food and medicine, and took turns on watch to ensure they got sleep. They developed a bond of sisterhood they promised would last forever.But when Kethra was sixteen, Lia betrayed her. Kethra managed to evade prison?or perhaps served her time. Now, she seeks answers. She wants to know why Lia betrayed her… and whether it was worth it. And perhaps, when it's said and done, she might want revenge.(She might also like to discover the fate of her parents.)Despite her lack of trust, deep down, Kethra dearly wants a family--as most orphans do.

I was washed ashore onto an island and found by my friend-now-stepsister who brought me into a church where I grew up. She also was the one who named me. The head Life Cleric taught me everything I know about being a cleric. But I was more interested in death. So I learnt Life by day, and Death by night, secretly since the other clerics were opposed of me learning it. Head Cleric was nice to me, so he bought me books about Death. Over my readings I learnt of a legendary Ghostwise Halfling named Blaen who slain a dragon in his travels. I wish to become at least half as legendary as him, hence I gave myself my last name, Blaensworthy.

Left in the hands of the elderly living in a monastery, Borba grew up with no father and rarely ever saw her mother. Despite this, she loves them fiercely and always imagined someday they would return to her so they could finally be a family. Unbeknownst to Borba, her mother is on a mission to rescue her father from his Orc tribe, the Spine Breakers who abducted him for leaving the tribe many years ago for seeking a civilized life, a huge offence to his clan. Borba befriends the elderly in the monastery and learns much from their pacifist and nature-loving ways like caring for nature and the weak. If she is not exploring the forest, Borba is in the company of Sir Gregory, her best friend and ex-paladin from the Order. Fascinated with the tales of his life as a paladin, Borba requests that her old friend teach her how to become one too. Under his tutelage, Borba undergoes rigorous paladin training and learns how to heal wounds and wield a halberd. One day, her typical training session goes awry because Borba got distracted with the fantasy of her parents returning. Sir Gregory berates her for this, causing her to run deep into the forest to cry. Lost in her emotions, Borba fixates on the thought of being abandoned forever by her parents. This triggers her innate Orc bloodlust, causing her to wreck havoc on the trees around her. She passes out from the exhaustion of it all and dreams of a mystical Elk that assures Borba that her parents will not abandon her and that they are serving nature. The elk sees potential in Borba as a defender of nature and promises her that it will aid her should she venture forth to find her father. In return, Borba must protect nature and educate others on the importance of its preservation. Excited, Borba accepts the gift and takes the Oath of the Ancients. Before the dream ends, the Elk tells Borba that her necklace (a gift from her mother) will guide her way to her parents. When she wakes up, Borba rushes back to explain what happened to Sir Gregory and expresses her intentions to find her father. Guilty, Sir Gregory tells her the truth about her parents and supports her wishes to find him. When she is 17, she completes her training and leaves her old friends in the monastery to embark on a mission of reuniting her family. Her first stop is at a nearby village called Langdale, where Sir Gregory’s old friend is waiting for her.

The younger sister of the Essenspeak family, she and her older sister Thunilda Essenspeak lived a fairly childhood and teen life, with Thunilda taking to the sword while Elwis took to the bow.However, when Elwis' Chaos magic came to life, the Chaos took a single, important memory from her. Despite her and her sister's best efforts to remember that stolen memory, she could not remember it. Now a member of the Explorer's Guild in the city of Gionyamar, hoping to find her precious lost memory with her sister, she travels the Lost Isles, always searching for the memory she knows she lost, but can't remember.

Daughter of the Sylvan Oracle, she ran away from her mother and her birthright at a young age. While she maintains the gift of sight, her younger sister (now a mother herself) holds the title of Oracle. She watches her from afar.

Mi-xiang had to flee her home island when she tried to organize against the local magistrate. She joined a sailing ship's crew to see the world, where she acquired a twin brother from an alternate dimension. Then she was shipwrecked on an island where she met her current party.

They came from a society that was heavily rule bound. They were frustrated with the religion and sailed away to another continent. There, they only found more traditions, and gasp, religion. They vowed to uproot and destroy tradition wherever possible.
Learned herbalism at a monastery created by dragonborn, left home to find her purpose in life and help people.
Used to be a swindler but was shown the error of her ways by a priest. Vowed to do right with her life and heal people instead of stealing from them

After enlisting in the mercenery guild she was sent on several suicide missions by superiors, barely escaping with her life and losing several friends along the way she eventually gained enough seniority and renown to make a name for herself in the international police force as a scout.

After studying for many years about ancient civilizations, Ryder stumbled upon a first hand journal of a long past religion worshiping some kind of celestial. On the last page of the journal was written in an odd language. Spending almost a year translating it Ryder read it aloud and summoned the ancient Celestial. He signed a pact of power so they both may gain.
Born from infidelity to rich parents in the woods. Cast out from home. Grew up fending for themselves in the city.

Hailing from Droaam, Skurrg was something of a runt among his tribe growing up, a common target for the cruelty of his fellow children. Once, however, when he was driven off by a particularly savage beating, he stumbled upon an entrance down into Khyber, and within, the ruins of an old, militant monastery. Skurrg learned from the writings down there, mastering its powerful blade techniques--and as he stayed there, the strange influences of Khyber warped him slightly, growing to a monstrous size in excess of 8 feet tall. His skill and size earned him notice, and he was soon sent to Sharn by the Daughters of Sora Kell, to aid the criminal organization Daask. While he was a feared enforcer, Skurrg also led something of a double life, enjoying the finest restaurants and art galleries, and operas that Sharn had to offer, in no small part because his mere presence ruined it for everyone else there. Eventually, he was instructed to work with House Tarkanen, another criminal organization, to retrieve some members returning from an accidental trip to Xoriat, and that's where his adventure truly begins.

Tristan's mother is a famous orc adventurer, while his father is a human homemaker. When Tristan's orc village was attacked by an elf sorcerer, Tristan, the only sorcerer in the town, attempted to fight back. When the elf cast Polymorph, Tristan attempted to cast Counterspell and the two spells exploded, leaving the elf dead and Tristan under a curse. He fled his village, vowing never to return home until he found a way to undo his curse.

Born to an elvish mother and a human father, Pax was raised by their mom in an elvish village. As they understood things, their father had been a travelling silversmith who overwintered in the village, one thing led to another, and by the time their mom know about the pregnancy he was long gone. Since their mother held a relatively secure job as the town healer, she was happy to have Pax alone - the youngest by far of three children (the other two full elves, over a hundred years older and without interest in their half-elf sibling). When Pax was 12, their mother died in a plague that spared them only because of the human part of their background. They set off to the city where they thought their dad lived out of desperation. In the city, no man by that name seemed to exist, but a helpful elven man brought them to the administrative wing of the palace. There, Pax finally met their father: not a silversmith, but the Spymaster and younger brother of the ruling Duke of the province. The summer before he'd met Pax's mother, his beloved wife had died quite suddenly, and he'd decided to do a field posting himself to distract himself from her death; he'd never told anyone the truth and had no idea he'd had a child - well, a fourth child. Pax was the youngest of four children to Atlas Eterna. They took it in stride.Pax became a spy for their father gradually, between tutoring and weapons and similar training for a noble. They work primarily on small, local infiltration assignments, mostly with their sister Constance, who is the closest in age and who manages the raven/crow/rook-ery for all of the spies.

Pogon was a green kobold in an above-ground forest settlement who, being more dragon-like than any of the others, hatching with wings and growing to a towering 4’1, was taken under the wing of the dictator-like leader. He had many responsibilities thrust upon him because of his imposing stature. The village had a nearby entrance to the underdark, which became the main mining operation and income source for the village. After an altercation with the chief about not using transfiguration to morph underperforming workers into mice, Pogon accidentally fried the village leader with magic and fled the town through its mines into the Underdark. Eventually, he established a small lab in a hidden cave near Waterdeep to research transformation in, making semi-frequent supply runs to the city. Although he won’t tell anyone, the objective of his research is to completely and permanently transform himself into a dragon.

Nobody ever thought that Issachar Voss was destined for great things. As a scrawny child with large, mournful eyes, he seemed to be a natural target for the power-hungry would-be tyrants bred by Chelaxian society. But as the years passed, Voss managed to avoid any violent entanglements with his peers, ingratiating himself with those who were powerful and then using his new influence to blackmail and manipulate his enemies. When he reached his teens, Voss apprenticed with an alchemist, who introduced him to the secret cult of Norgorber Blackfingers. Voss was fascinated by the mysterious god of poisons, secrets, and murder. Though outwardly he continued to profess the worship of Asmodeus like everyone else in Cheliax, he devoted himself to the service of Norgorber.Though his time with the alchemist was fruitful, it was brief. The death of his parents left him orphaned and penniless, and he struck out on his own. After spending a while doing odd jobs to earn his keep and thieving when he couldn't find any work, Voss found himself in Longacre, doing work on the estate of Archbaron Darellus Fex. Using the skills that had served him so well as a child, Voss subtly brought himself to the attention of the baron. Fex recognized Voss's skills and offered him a job as one of his spies. Since then, Issachar Voss has worked as an instrument of the baron's will in Longacre, rooting out rebellion and meting out punishment as need demands. He's satisfied with the position for now, happy as long as he gets to bend others to his will while safe from reprisal — and the pay doesn't hurt either.

Allan Bellamy was born to a family steeped in the arts: his father was a composer whose works had been showcased at the Kintargo Opera House and his mother was an oft-featured soprano in the same venue. His older siblings — two sisters and a brother — were all virtuostic instrumentalists, well on their way to careers in the orchestra. Unsurprisingly, Allan's own artistic skills flourished in this environment. Though he was only an average singer and could never do more with an instrument than strumming chords on a lute, he was a powerful orator. He easily found a home in the Kintargo Dramatics Society, a group which performed classic plays between opera seasons. He was poised to perform his first starring role as King Haliad III, the instigator of the Everwar and a role every dramatic aspired to, when on the eve of opening, word came from Egorian that Queen Abrogail had banned any positive depictions of pre-diabolist rulers of Cheliax.Thwarted in his theatrical dreams and full of a newly-kindled hatred of the diabolist monarchy, Bellamy left Kintargo. He eventually joined a wandering band of guerilla performers who would perform brief works lauding the olden days and severely critical of the Thrune dynasty. Allan particularly distinguished himself through ridiculous performances as Queen Abrogail herself. Though they were hunted by the authorities, they managed to evade capture by never remaining in one place for very long. Friends in towns all over the Chelaxian countryside helped to shelter them between shows.On one particular night, Allan received word that there was to be a protest in Kintargo against the newly-installed Lord Mayor, Barzillai Thrune. He implored his fellow performers to hurry the show so they could be present for such a significant event. Unfortunately, as he took the stage to perform the part of the notorious Jackdaw, a hastily-knotted rope unfurled, dropping a sandbag squarely on his head. When he awoke in the home of a sympathetic audience member, the troupe was gone and his memories of his life were mixed up with the plot of the play he'd been about to perform. One thing remained firmly in his mind: he had to get to Kintargo to help incite rebellion, just as he had in the days of the Chelaxian Civil War. The Jackdaw would rise again!

She is a trans woman and a serpent sorcerer. She apprenticed under the black spider character in the 5e started adventure and has since gained a life of her own. She is sly, a master of voices and an incredible character actress. A recurring villainess, she is intelligent enough to flee and save herself, but will reliably return to gain what she has lost and then some. Vengeful, cunning and dressed to the nines at all times, she is both feared and loved. Her signature style is green iridescent snakeskin and obscene amounts of eyeshadow, alluding to her panache and desire to be center of attention. This stems from a cold and distant upbringing and elven cultures general disdain for tacky celebrity culture and the dark arts.

Thazsui grew up as a Yuan-ti pureblood trained to infiltrate human settlements. When he developed his powers during an expedition into ancient ruins he excitedly told his commanders, who tried to kill him for fear of him growing too powerful. This angered and shocked him, so he jumped through the Earth Plane portal they had been excavating. The time in the Earth Plane allowed for Thazsui to learn the basics of his abilities. The increased gravitational force in the Earth plane forced Thazsui to strengthen himself. Upon encountering a group of Xorn Thazsui realised he missed home, but knew he couldn't return to his clan. Wandering through the plane with the Xorn hardened his skin. Stone fused with his flesh and he became rough and stonelike.He saw the great evil of the Dao that hunted Xorn for sport. Seeing this reckless slaughter reminded him of how some of his brethren behaved, and so he vowed to never harm a defenseless creature again. Through some careful camouflage in his new rocky form he managed to trail a Dao to another portal. Leaping through it, without a concern for his destination, he landed on a mountain. While digging around in the mountain area looking for a way down he met a burly Goliath. So shocked to see another person he reverted back to his original Yuan-ti form.

As the King's second child and member of the respected House Fireforge, Ladardon was a respected Prince of Orzammar. On Ladardon’s 35th birthday a feast was held to celebrate his appointment as Orzammar's newest commander of the Crimson Guard. Ladardon participated in the Provings and was accompanied by Gorim Saelac, Ladardon's second and best friend. On the way through the Diamond Quarter and the Provings, Ladardon met his elder brother Trian and their younger brother Bhelen. Crown-prince Trian, the heir to the throne, had arrogantly demanded that Ladardon return to the ceremony at the throne room at once. So respectfully Ladardon attend his ceremony.  In the throne room Ladardon meet several other nobles, the King, and Kenshin Silverfire. After the ceremony Bhelen told Ladardon that Trian is plotting to kill him, because the Assembly might choose him over Trian, who "won't step aside." However, because of the impeding expedition, there was no time to talk to Trian. The king sent Ladardon, along with Gorim, on a special mission to retrieve the Crest of the Fireforge clan from the Fireforge Thaig. After fighting several Darkspawn encounters, Ladardon finds the chamber with the crest. However, there are mercenaries waiting to take Ladardon out. They carry with them Trian's Signet Ring. After retrieving the crest, Ladardon headed back to the meeting point, only to find Trian’s corpse eviscerated on the ground. As the Ladardon stood over Trian’s body, Bhelen and the King's party arrived. Bhelen claimed that Ladardon killed Trian to become the next Crowned-Prince. No amount of protesting convinced the Dwarven lords otherwise. As an added horror, the cocky scout and Frandolin Ivo, two other attendants, acted as eyewitnesses and vouched that Ladardon killed Trian. Ladardon was sent to the Deep Roads to die, while Gorim was banished to the surface. But Ladardon, being a skillful fighter in the arts of sword-play and lucky, was able to stumble upon Kenshin Silverfire and The Order of the Red Lotus and was recruited as a Warden-Recruit into the Order.At the Weisshaupt Fortress, Ladardon met the Grand Master as he came to greet Kenshin and his party as they entered the stronghold. After conversing with the Grand Master, Ladardon was informed of the Joining Ritual and its criteria. Ladardon after resting for the night was let into an arena filled with about a dozen or so Darkspawn, his objective was to kill the Darkspawn until he had obtained three vials of their blood. Upon accomplishing that no small feat, he was instructed to mix the blood with lyrium and drink it. The concoction was not the easiest drink to swallow and upon finishing the drink caused Ladardon to writhe in pain and experience visions of the true nature of the Darkspawn – Red Lyrium. Once the ritual was complete, Ladardon was promoted to Warden-Ensign and was taken under the mentor-ship of Kenshin, who would teach Ladardon all he knew in the manner of the sword, which could go unhindered since he was considered dead by the Kingdom. Many years passed and Ladardon progressed at a steady-rate. Ladardon rose up the ranks of the Order to the point of earning the title “Master”, he had now taken Kenshin’s command, as Kenshin had been promoted to “High Master”. He had run many operations and was a formidable fighter and had earned the respect of many of the members of the Order. He even studied the skill of smithing, and had become a formidable smith in the Order. However, he wished to earn the title of Paragon, and put his traitorous brother in his place, by finding the Dwarves greatest treasure, The Anvil of the Void, and with it craft the first ever Lyrium weapons. In order to do so he left the Safety of Weisshaupt Fortress, after gaining permission, and the underground Kingdom to find the knowledge of the location of the Primeval Thaig, knowing that Caridin, himself, had traveled outside the Kingdom to obtain knowledge for the creation of the Anvil of the Void.

Born into a noble family as the scion of a renowned candy manufacturer, Gustav Baccharnale was a quiet young man who often preferred the company of plants and books to the residents of his family's estate. Bookish, inquisitive, and polite, he spent most of his time studying the greenhouses where the family's renowned mint leaves were grown. However, adolescence brought with it dark tidings: Revel had been diagnosed with a rare debilitating disease. Doctors told him he had only a few years left to live... his naturally-long elven lifespan cut short by this new condition, too rare even to have a name. Gustav spent a long time in shock, coming to terms with the fact that all his learnings and training had been for nothing... and then, one night, he stole away in the dark. He fled his family's estate, vowing never to return and burden them with his tragedy again. After some time, he resurfaced with a new name: Revel Pharidian Junic Baccharnale. He had constructed a new identity, built on his final conclusion: if his death is approaching fast, then he might as well enjoy his life to the utmost while it lasts. The days that followed were a whirlwind of song and dance, drink and drugs, men and women; devoting himself to every hedonistic pursuit the world had to offer. He even won the heart of Lady Honey, a noblewoman and magical patron. Just when he had resigned himself to a loud life and a quiet death, however, he received a strange request from a foreign ruler...

Was a relatively normal student wizard, albeit with something of a Napoleon complex, until a critical success on a perception roll when there wasn't anything to see allowed her to catch a glimpse of the outside world. (Keep in mind - this is backstory. All she saw was game setup, no actual play.) Now she's dead set on learning more about the place she saw - even if it means she has to go against the universe itself to do so.

Nim was a product of (very) unethical magical experimentation. He was made sentient through these experiments, and remembers very little of his past before that. After escaping, Nim learned to fight. He swore that he would never let what happened to him happen to anyone else. As a result, Nim is an intensely moral character that loves a good fight and has a quick temper.

Ulara and her sister were sold into slavery to cover her parent's gambling debts. Both her sister and her master died from disease, at which point Ulara fled. She fended for herself on the streets as a pickpocket and thief, until she fell in with a band of mercenaries. Ulara's life experiences have left her with an intense instinct for self-preservation and very little moral code. Ulara looks out exclusively for herself, and is skilled in interpersonal manipulation. Ulara's greatest ambition is to find her parents and take her revenge. After that, her goal is to spend her time lounging around on a pile of gold.

Thalassa is a grandmother many times over, and lived most of her life happily married in a small town. That is, until playboy Nathaniel came to town, and got two (two!) of her granddaughters in the family way. Thalassa's goal is to track Nathaniel down and make him take responsibility for his progeny (or at least get child support). This will be more complex than Thalassa thinks, since Nathaniel is a vampire who leads an adventuring party of his own...
University scholar, stranded abroad.
Creed led a slave revolt in an agricultural region. He's now a folk hero, but has also made some powerful enemies.

After being disappointed in love, Verbule withdrew from the world to join a monastery, becoming a cleric of Erathis, god of civilization and innovation. Failing to find what he sought there, he began to wander the world again. Recently, he has invented his own sub-deity, the spirit of niceness, Cabindra. He's already constructed several shrines to her. At the moment, he is involved in a harebrained attempt to establish a theatrical academy in the city of Gargouille.
Carceri was born and raised in the Underdark, a vast system of caves. He made a pact with Tharizdun, divinity of madness, to secure his powers.

Lucien comes from a long line of nobles with odd magical abilities. His mother, for example, could make plants blossom by singing to them. Although he is first in line to inherit the family estate, he chose to spend some time traveling to gain some experience of the "real world". The fact that his father, being of elvish blood, is likely to live several more decades may also have factored into this, but Lucien would never admit this to you.
To Harth, setting out in the world to become an adventurer seemed like a fine way to gain honor and kill some things.

Epiphany was abandoned by her parents, left in a basket on the doorstep of the municipal orphanage. The orphanage was... not a good place..., and she ran away from it as soon as she could. For several years, she lived on the streets as part of a gang of child pickpockets and petty thieves. Her life changed, however, the day that they tried to steal the candlesticks from the temple of Bahamut. As the candlelight flickered in the vast cathedral, she heard a voice that reverberated through her bones. When the priests found her that morning, she was curled in a ball on the stone floor, shivering and begging for mercy. The temple took her in as an acolyte, and she dedicated her life to the god of justice. Unlike some of her faith, she sees her goal not as enforcing laws and bringing criminals to justice, but as eradicating the world's senseless inequalities.

O, tell to me, Tam Lin, she said, why came you here to dwell?"The queen of faeries caught me when from my horse I fell.And at the end of seven years, she pays a tithe to hell,And I so fair, and full a' flesh, am feared it be mysel'."

we as players were transported into the game world with our own minds but in random-race bodies. Lawrence's predilection for caution coupled with being in a strange world and immediately set upon by violence led him down the path of stealth and shadow magic. the necromancer in the party learned a ritual that makes vampires, and "The Rat Man" offered to become one. the necromancer later died, the party saved a town from an undead invasion propagated by a hidden necromancer NPC. the PCs took over the town's leadership positions, and fortified it against the overly militant church before leaving for the "plane of dungeons"

It takes a century to learn how to properly hold a sword-Proverb of the Elven Blademasters	Morning Song ancient blade of House Xiloscient; has been in the great house's keeping since the War of the Seldarine. The blade was forged to imprison Final Sunset, general of Lolth and demigod of curses and darkness. It became a living weapon, turning the powers of the Dark in service to the Light.Since the end of the war the sword has been kept imprisoned the depths of the family vault, bound and warded deep in the earth by the family’s greatest mystics and theurges; for the instrument of our salvation is also the key to Lolth’s return.The Blade still yearns to serve, advising and empowering Scions of the House as it sees fit. Though there hasn't been a Pact Holder in several elven generationsAll that changed when a young half-elf girl who saw no way to match her sisters, who would pass from this world before the Blademaster said she even learned to properly hold a sword; heard The Whispers. She followed The Whispers of the Sword; past the locks, past the wards, past the guardians. All the way to the Center of Hose Xiloscient's Dread Vault, to the place where House Elders consult their Most Ancient Vizier.Girl and Greatsword forged a pact, and Morning Song's power began to flow through Invicta; skill at arms and magic to rival the sisters she thought she would never match were granted that night, along with The Scabbard that no Sword Fits as a symbol of the bond, and a promise that the Sword would appear when her power bloomed.

Standin was a young gnome of 17 years when he began his apprenticeship with master Janata. Over the course of 12 years of study and training, Standin learned the ways of magic. From simple spells that would clean his master's home in an instant, to complex battle magicks that would reduce his foes to a pile of ashen waste. Standin was a quick study, and was praised by master Janata for his astounding ability to learn spells almost faster than his master could teach them. But casting spells was not the only thing Standin had been taught. He had been trained in the dangerous art of quick casting spells, firing off his spells in rapid succession. Having also been tough to use his small stature, agility and surprising speed to his advantage in avoiding opponents, he was quite a force to be reckoned with, if not a small one. Standin joined a small adventuring party some years after his training had been completed, and made some extraordinary discoveries whilst in there company. His greatest discovery, and most prized possession, was an ancient tome describing a long forgotten form of dwarven metal magic! Standin worked night and day to decipher the ancient language of the dwarves, to learn their spells, and to become a master of the five elemental magicks... and still does.
A noblewoman obsessed with an imbalance in the planes she sensed in her youth.

Dan Tempest was a phoney bastard who'd do just about anything for a bit of gold. A scoundrel, a mercenary, a cold-blooded killer. He'd steal, kidnap and kill his way through life, and he did it all with a smile. Eventually, his bad deeds caught up to him, and he was left bleeding on the doorstep of one of Elira's temples. The Sisters of Elira brought him in, saved his life and let him hide there for a few days. To repay the debt, he simply left a few gold pieces behind. Just enough to have the same value as his own life. Seasons came and went, and his ways were hardly changed. One sunny afternoon, he was travelling through the same road and saw the temple was aflame. In that moment, without a single thought, he rushed to the aid of the Sisters. It was the same bandits that had ambushed him long ago. Vengeance was his own, but he did not see it that way. He felt that if his life was enough to save the sisters that had selflessly saved him, it would finally gain some value. He unsheathed his weapon, and went inside. At first, the battle was not his to win. As he pushed through, as he persevered through his injuries, a voice could finally be heard. A voice that could only be described as sublime, divine, holy. In that moment, he was presented with a choice. To die a worthless villain, or to survive as an Inspired Blade of Elira. And survive he did. He slaughtered the bandits, saved the temple and most importantly, the priestesses that had once saved his own life. The debt was now truly repaid. Since then, he's been living his life as a self-appointed knight and a self-proclaimed hero. As a Paladin of Elira, he is a beacon of hope and courage in the battlefield.
Duck hunter

The Battlebell clan are known for their use of the hundred-pound bells that they carry on mounts into battle. The bells are beaten with maces and the reverberation from them confuses and disorients enemies. Ghug was no different from the other orcs in his clan, and he longed for the day that he too would carry his bell into battle. He practiced regularly, playing the same toned note over and over, practicing his flips and mace-twirling for added effect. Soon he was the best bell-battler among all of the Battlebell clan at only 11 years old. It wasn't long after that when he found himself riding out to meet his foes. The battle was bloody, orcs and men alike fought and died before Ghug found himself face to face with a near untouched soldier from the opposing army. Planting his battlebell mount firmly in the ground, he swung his maces against the metal, blasting arcs of sonic energy at the man. Long story short, a bunch of fighting happened as Ghug smacked his bell and did other bard things, and they won! Yay! Now Ghug travels the world, seeking to spread the fame and name of the Battlebell clan, striking fear (NOT laughter!) into the hearts of all who oppose him.

Character's name: Vailea Ebonshard AKA Snow Princess, Vee
Character's backstory: Vailea grew up on a small northern island with only her grandfather, powerful arch magus Cyrus Ebonshard under an enchantment where she only saw him as her master, training her in the mystic arts. This curse was placed on her when she was born by fair folk whose domain was ice and water, a twist of the knife in revenge for a power item Master Cyrus took from them in his adventuring days. They offered him the infant, the last of his kin, in exchange for the relic he stole those many years ago, and only later did he notice this tragic behavior, represented by a glyph on her upper left arm whenever she cast magic.There was an upside to this curse, she excelled at water magic and could easily talk to spirits of water like they were her friends and neighbors. She spent her years mastering her craft when she wasn't enjoying her "Master's" vast library of plays, stories and legends. One day at age 15, her grandfather offered her a special assignment - she was to be enrolled in a new junior adventuring academy in the bustling city of Sharn. It was time she stopped being the meek, quiet little servant and grew up near talented young adventurers her own age to make some friends, gain some stories of her own and find her confidence.

For as long as he could remember there was a song in Maestro's heart. That said memory was never his strong suit. Why only a few years ago he was found by his foster father suffering from a near complete case of amnesia. His father, Jobeseph, was part of a gnomish caravan of traveling entertainers and tinkers. Not knowing who he was or what he was supposed to be doing Maestro fell in love with these gnomes despite the 3ft height difference and lack of any musical talent on his part. With the help of his new father modifications were made to his armoured form that allowed him to created music all of his own. This effect left him sounding like an accordion and a pair of bagpipes under a piano. Coupled with some facial modifications that allowed him to be more expressive, very uncharacteristic of a warforged, he was a monstrosity not seen since the works of Frankenstein. Still, a love of music was all he had left from the life he couldn't remember. This drove Maestro to become a full fledged bard. Nowadays he can be seen performing outside of taverns. Despite the excellent quality of his music, his off putting exterior often left him to earn coin by being paid to play in front of someone else's business. Though to be truley appreciated in fairer company he did aquire a hat off disguise.

The heir to a noble birthright, and military commander, Torhas left his life behind for greater goals and ambitions to start a new world order.  Along the way he sacrificed much of his morals, ethics, and allies to achieve what he thought was order but fell into his own ruin.

After his egg was nearly used for an omelette by an unsuspecting dwarf, Flit hatched and fled civilization. He spent his life in isolation, learning spells from books he found in order to protect himself. Eventually, he was summoned by the same dwarf that had nearly fried him as an egg. Having heard of his natural skills, the dwarf sent Flit on a quest with a ragtag team of other adventurers. It was from interacting with these strange people that Flit began to learn how to socialize.

Lord Furion is a career soldier of noble birth that has been left in charge of Hirikith whilst the king is off fighting his secret war.  Furion is beloved by the nobles and common folk alike and has formed a peoples militia to help protect the kingdom.
Born on a Mountain, Raised in a cave, Fucking and Trucking is all I crave

We start our story with a young forest gnome. Like most gnomes living amongst their own kind, in his youth he had many names given by many people. Some stuck, some did not. For now, I’ll introduce him as the name he will come to use – Naoise ‘Zapp’ Garrick.Naoise grew up a very average forest gnome, albeit in a slightly unusual forest gnome community. In the wake of the Starstone’s cataclysmic effects on the land, this particular clan of forest gnomes had found themselves more exposed to the other races then they found comfortable. Cut off from the Sylvan elves they once knew as friends, they had formed an alliance with the halflings who lived across the plains on the edge of their forest. Needing allies to survive, the Garrick clan gnomes and the plains halflings had formed a comfortable pact – both perhaps relieved to be fighting alongside other small folk. As the land changed in the great roil the Starstone brought about, Naoise was born into a forest gnome clan whose isolated patch of woodland sat atop great cliffs and extended into the Hinterland of a sheltered bay – the remnants of the now sea-flooded plains the halfings once lived across. The halflings they called allies had founded a prosperous harbour town, with mercantile ships often taking shelter from storms, receiving repairs, or restocking their supplies in the welcoming – if pint sized - settlement.The forest gnomes stayed in the forested hinterlands so long as masts of ships could be seen in the harbour. But when the port sat empty, and no big folk were striding about the town, they would venture down to trade and talk with the halflings they befriended. Perhaps unusual for forest gnomes once, this was the status quo into which Naoise was born – but in all other ways his childhood seemed normal for one of his people. He loved animals, and would spend endless days searching out their nests and homes, returning daily to check if they were safe – sometimes stealing food from his mother’s table to feed them. Their underground home was warm and bright, and the temperate forest canopy was an above-ground labyrinth of verdant green and occasional blue sky which Naoise climbed through, gracefully as the small creatures he adventured with.His parents were loving, but Naoise was in the younger half of his 14 siblings. Never causing trouble, he was a profoundly average boy. Almost boringly so. But the gnomish zeal for life shone through him like it did all his clan, and he was content throughout his childhood and teenage years with the mostly peaceful life he thoroughly enjoyed, occasionally excited by their trips to the halfling town when no ships were docked.Naoise was 15, and never expected his unremarkably average life to change. He was content, but unknowingly on the precipice of a great change. It was a late summer night, and a fierce storm was rolling in off the sea. The first-of-the-season thunder boomed and heavy rain beat against the gust-battered leaves of the forest. Naoise didn’t know what spell drew him out of his burrow that night – although the wise will recognise fey enchantments when they hear of them. In the thrall of a powerful fey creature, he ventured out into the storm, slowly making his way through the trees to the cliff edge overlooking a tempestuous sea. He remembers this through his own eyes, but his thoughts were alien. Standing on the verge of the cliff, waves boiling beneath him, and shaking with the peal of thunder, the fey creature appeared behind him, shrouded in bright blue light and glowing mist. He remembered facing this captivating creature, held in awe, fear and reverence – utterly enchanted. The fey held its hand against his head, and with an explosive arc of lightning he was sent spiralling unconscious into the furious seas below.Naoise first reckoned he should have died that night, although has since grown to accept that his fate was in the control of something more powerful than a simple storm. He had been hauled up at daybreak by a damaged ship, slowly creeping its way to find repair in the halfling port-town after suffering at the hands of the same storm Naoise had been drawn out to. By all rights he should have been terrified – he came-to surrounded by grizzled big folk of many races, colours, and degrees of hygiene. But traces of the fey enchantment still lingered on him, and presented with what many forest gnomes would consider a nightmare, he simply took a deep draught of the spiced liquor offered, and allowed himself to sit up. Stood far away was someone who clearly dressed as the ship’s captain – or perhaps not stood far away, but standing half the height of the other sailors. A halfling. A Captain Halfling. At the time, Naoise was still not himself. He answered simple questions, and seemed happy that they were on their way to the halfling port town. The superstitious amongst the sailors thought him a sea spirit, and thought best not to risk upsetting him for fear of ill-luck on the waves. To the rest he was a few hours amusement, and a day later he departed the ship – still fettered by the remnants of enchantment, his farewell to the Captain was as simple as if he were saying goodbye to his mother before she left for market.It wasn’t until he had made his way home that the final echo of the fey spell which held him died away. He came back into himself whilst sat at his family burrow table, surrounded by his 14 curious and concerned siblings, tearful mother and bewildered father. He cried – finally feeling the terror that should have taken hold of him a day before. He rested for days. And when he awoke, he noticed something that his siblings had been forbidden to mention – a forelock of his strawberry blonde hair had turned brilliant white. Finally refreshed to his gnomish self, he and his family dismissed it as but a quaint quirk. They buried their concerns beneath an optimistic excitement for the adventure Naoise had experienced – and the amusing mark it had left on him.His family took the unusual step of going down to the harbour without checking for ship masts – their good-natured need to thank the ship who saved Naoise overcoming their terrified reservations of big folk. But the ship had moved on. They enquired with the dockmaster – who told them that as luck would have it, the ship was due to return in the Spring – the town had been commissioned to make some replacement parts in light of the temporary repairs the ship had been given. Whilst his parents seemed pleased to hear this, Naoise felt different. Not anxious, not excited, but vexed. He didn’t know why, but it burdened him.Months began to pass, and things began to change in Naoise. His old habits lost their appeal. The hinterland forest seemed small, the boughs of the trees less exciting to climb. His smile dropped, and amongst gnomes, this was a thing of great concern. His family thought him sick but he showed no signs of physical illness. Their worries multiplied when the strangeness started. Gusts of wind would surge through the burrow in the night. Candles were blown out. Lanterns rattled. And Naoise became more distant. He would spend hours at the edge of the cliffs staring out to the horizon, or looking up at the clouds secretly hoping for wild weather. A thought burned in him, and whilst he ignored it initially, it couldn’t be snuffed out.It was only when spring came back around that his family persuaded it out of him. They knew he had been changed that night. And when sixteen loving faces all peered down on him imploring him to share his burdens – he told them he needed to leave. He needed to be on the seas, in the winds and the rain and the salt spray. He yearned for this like nothing before – and planned when that same ship returned, to entreat the captain to take him on.A wanderlust and need for adventure is not unknown in gnomes – and whilst unusual for those in the forest – they remained very gnomish in the outlook. Excited for his experiences. Happy that there was something to be done to make him better. They all awaited the day ships would return to the harbour with nervous excitement.It was 8 months since the storm that the ship finally returned. Naoise carried out his plan, although admittedly without much planning. A day after the ship docked he asked to be let aboard – and the sailors who still thought him a sea spirit gladly obliged. He spoke with the Captain – who humoured him for a while. Naoise and his family perhaps never expected his offer to actually be accepted. A rugged crew of humans, half-orcs, and an odd wayward dwarf was no place for a gnome. Perhaps Captain Burrbough saw something of himself in this diminutive aspiring Sailor. He was a strange sort of man – full of laughter and a sense of humour which others struggled to master. Maybe the image of this tiny gnome alongside his half-orc helmsman was too humorous for him to pass up. But arrangements were made – and within two weeks, Naoise Garrick was aboard a ship on the high seas.The transformation on deckhand Garrick was profound. His gnomish love of life returned twice as strong – his grin was broad, his energy high, and his zeal for the seas near unmatched. Captain Burrbough’s vessel – the Foamrover, was a ship of exploration and trade. Many edges of the map had changed after the effects of the Starstone – and there was profit and excitement for those ships willing to re-chart the seas and trade with the newly isolated pockets of the changed world. The life seemed to suit deckhand Garrick – and he quickly grew into his role. His gnomish sight, and life living in burrows, meant that life below deck was without challenge for him. His days climbing through trees and running along boughs meant he took to the sails, ropes, and masts of the ship effortlessly. He could even entreat seabirds to lead them to land, and after they found a new island doing just that, it seemed his place on the ship was secured. Captain Burrbough liked him, the crew found him humorous. The only quirk was his white forelock – which the crew quickly deduced could predict the weather. Straight, flat, glossy meant clear skies, hot suns. A curl to the left meant rain. To the right meant wind. A corkscrew-ringlet meant both. The superstitious thought this troubling. The practical thought it useful.The only snag was the severe, unreadable First Mate – the half elf Lady Thalasstra. Her sharp features, keen intuition, guarded mannerisms and forceful presence were respected and almost feared by the crew. And Garrick had no idea what she thought of him. For all the whimsy and laughter of Captain Burrbough, First Mate Thalasstra provided a sombre counterweight. Deckhand Garrick avoided her as much as he could, but on one night during his 8th month aboard, he couldn’t avoid scrutiny any longer.Deckhand Garrick awoke in the night – the ship was anchored, but tossed around in surging waves. The seamen were arguing as to whether to hoist the anchor – but they were near shoals, and couldn’t afford to drift. Rain poured down and winds were increasingly strong. In the distance, a peal of thunder rolled across the swell. Naoise’s blood pounded in his veins – he was breathless, wracked by adrenaline and a compulsion he could barely control. He had to get above deck. The crewmen saw as he staggered passed them – noticing one thing over any other - his white forelock of hair writhing, twisting and coiling ceaselessly like the dismembered tentacle of some abyssal creature. First Mate Thalasstra heeded the nervous calls of her crew to come see – and she was greeted by a spectacle that left the crew terrified to step out onto deck. Stood amidst the storm was Deckhand Garrick – seemingly unmoved by the wind, streaks of fog rose like smoke from his skin, only to be snatched away by the fierce gusts – facing the crew, his white lock still twisted and thrashed like some wild serpent. Thalasstra stepped out towards him, but before she could get within arm’s reach, Garrick yelped and she was thrown back, sliding along the slippery deck, driven by an unnatural blast of wind. Her eyes widened, and as the hairs on the back of her neck rose away from the skin, she dived backwards. A great crash of thunder seemed to sound from the deckhand’s hands – arms outstretched either side of him as he struggled against some unseen grip. The crew had barely recovered from the shock when his hands were twisted skywards, two great arcs of lightning erupted forth into the clouds. The scene played out for the next half an hour. Captain Burrbough joined the crew in watching as the deckhand’s arms were thrown around like a puppet – bringing with them surges of wind which went unnaturally against the storm, earsplitting bursts of thunder, and flashing bolts of skyward lightning.The half hour passed, and the storm quietened. Deckhand Garrick was left prone, slumped in a pool of fog which shrouded his form. The crew were spooked, and more than one were ready to end his life there and then – thinking him cursed, that he had raised this storm. Thalasstra, however, wore a characteristically reserved expression. She promised the crew that if anyone threatened their fellow deckhand again, she would have them dragged behind the keel of the ship – and with all the grace her half-elf blood afforded her, she scooped the unconscious gnome up in her arms, and laid him down in the Captain’s Quarters.Much happened in the following weeks. Captain Burrbough and First Mate Thallastra spoke at great lengths with a terrified Naoise, under which circumstance he learned more about her than he ever thought to glean. She had been born to an elven mother, after a romance with a human sailor. She and her twin sister were raised by elves – and her twin sister showed a profound aptitude for magic. Whilst showing no inclination towards spellcraft herself, Thallastra had sat in many of her twin sister’s lessons, working on her own tutelage, and suspected that the young deckhand could be an addition to the crew unlike any other. She herself had joined the ship under similar desire to Naoise – her father’s seafaring blood nursing a need in her she could not bear to ignore – despite her education and childhood not lending itself to the sailor’s path. Captain Burrbough seemed to take this like anything else – another source of amusement for his bizarre humour, and some extra excitement to match his already exciting life.Naoise Garrick made a valuable friend that day – and under the encouragement and protection of the First Mate, and with the prompting of some beginner’s lessons she half remembered form watching her twin sister – discovered his gift could do more than forecast the weather. Years went by and with every storm, Deckhand Garrick would stand at the bow of the ship, learning to no longer fear the tempestuous power in him, but learning to evoke it. And with every step further along accepting his newfound power, his other tricks took on new life too. The ship continued exploring the changed edges of the map – and Naoise became an irreplaceable asset. A capable sailor with gnomish charm and optimism, his natural dexterity became athletic. His skin tanned, he became unusually strong (for a gnome). He loved nothing more than making new friends and meeting new people in the taverns of the towns they traded with. His magic progressed – he could mend snapped ropes or torn sails in a moment without any trace – his forest gnome illusions became the standard signals used to carry messages around the ship. The crew would eagerly await the storms to see deckhand Garrick perform a show of wind, thunder and lightning – tricks he had learned to produce even in the clearest of skies, although not with quite the same grandeur. One especially excitable young sailor started calling him Zapp, in light of his proclivity for lightning and thunder. The name grew instantly popular, and Naoise Garrick embraced the new title with a joy true to his gnome nature and their love of names.This brings up to the present day. We find Zapp decades older – a gnome of over 50 years. He remains short, lithe, and agile, but his athletic build can’t be missed under his tan sailor’s skin. The sun has kept his strawberry blonde hair light – worn pulled back into a messy braid but for his stark white forelock, which hangs loose down the side of his face. Captain Burrbough no longer sails – instead, he commands a whole fleet of merchant ships from a homely mansion not too far from the town Zapp knew as a child. Thalasstra was made Captain of the Foamrover, and unlike the rest of the now elderly Burrbough’s merchant fleet, her crew are pure explorers. They search out the remotest islands and towns into which to expand Burrbough’s trading empire. Zapp remained under Thalasstra’s wing – her initial acceptance, encouragement and mentorship proving the start of a long and powerful friendship. She made Zapp her first mate, and as a half elf in the prime of her life, leads a crew of motley explorers, all of whom revel in the magical gnome, who climbs from rope to mast, with hair which can forecast the weather.Zapp seems to be leading a fantastic life – always eager to see new towns and meet new people, although one has to wonder if deep down he has a desire to find people like him, touched with inexplicable power. He is loyal to Thalasstra, almost to a fault, but balances out her severity with his lust for life, and hearty enjoyment of ale when the crew makes landfall. He has become adept at a few spells useful on a ship, and otherwise seems naturally able to make storm-like magic. Other than that, he knows very little about his power, and perhaps now is growing curious enough at to seek out someway to develop it further.

Once a member of the Cult of Mangaia the New Moon, I discovered that the leader of the cult, Father Martin, does not believe in Mangaia, and has caused the cult prophet to suffer the backlash of defiance. He also abuses his power as cult leader. I criticized him publicly and was banished from the cult. Now, I hear the call of Mangaia in my dreams, and have hunted down (other) evil cults both for pay and to steal their knowledge for Mangaia. When I left the cult, I took one of its relics, a dagger infused with Mangaia's blood, with me. For some strange reason, I cannot part with it.

I am a pilgrim on a traditional "nest-leaving" journey to find something of value to return to the flock. I am ominally searching for the "Rod of Seven Parts" a mysterious and powerful artifact, but really I'm searching for any powerful item of magic or evil to help the tribe or deny evildoers power.

Wood elf raised by humans, who died of old age 20 years ago. Attempted to join a wood elf tribe, but lacked the proper customs and manners. Took their attempt to expel me as instructions to "prove my worth", and gather magical or social power to prove it.Have bred panthers after previous beast companion got old and sluggish. Currently has a 3rd-generation pet, that has inadvertently be bred for emotional support and domesticity, not combat.

I was thrust into combat at a young age, in to my country's war against the silent invasion of Yuan-Ti. After my general poisoned a major city rather than let be ruled by the Yuan-Ti, and ordered me to kill unarmed prisoners of war, I gathered my friends and we ran from the war, leaving the general to be captured. I stole a random artifact I did not understand, and traded it to a Great Old One in return for power and anonymity.I do not wish to go to war, but I will defend the innocent. There is no honor in violence.

Growing up on the streets, I have a knack for learning new things. After sparks and tricks showed that I had some magic ability, I stole theory books and tomes from a number of wizards. When one of my victims saw me, he hired the savage young killer, David, to make an example of me. I barely managed to get rid of David & flee into the city's dark maze of alleyways and shadows. Now I want to learn more magic, but constantly fear being hunted down by that wizard or others who I have stolen from.

I am a fugitive from an Aasimar society, one that believes in a purity of spirit through forced asceticism and purity. Defied society's social and unspoken cultural laws and formed a resistance group opposed by cultural pressure for suicide for the "imperfect".I believe that I am always in the right, as I still receive advice from my deva (angelic guide), despite defying my people. I stood up to the tyrant's agents, and organized people into a militia to begin resisting the tyrant.

Fiorello longed for a bigger audience than the one his little halfling village could supply, so he set off for the Big City. However, fresh young performers were a dime a dozen, and he found himself out of work more often than he would have liked. He was almost ready to pack it all in and go back home when he got an unusual offer from a half-orc with whom he had become acquainted. “I work in a brothel, and we need someone to keep our patrons entertained while they are waiting. Would you be willing to join us?” Fiorello jumped at the chance - regular work, six nights a week, plus a room, and earplugs could take care of the extraneous noises from the other areas. He became known as the “half-pint with the horn”, and assumed the stage name Fio Hornblower. Once the brothel caught fire under suspicious circumstances, however, his real adventure began.

Martin is a Knight-Justiciar of the Order of the Shining Rod. He is charged to travel the land and eradicate lawlessness, protect the innocent, and offer services as a judge. In nations where the authority of Erathis is legally recognized, his judgement is law and can only be overridden by a High or Grand Justiciar, the High Marshal, or a clergy member of Prelate rank or higher. Smaller communities often defer to the judgement of the Order, whether or not it is legally binding.Martin was the third born child in his household and so, as was customary, he was given to the church to train as they see fit. Martin never knew his birth family, and has no desire to know them - they honored the ancient traditions, and he is grateful that they did.Martin lived with the monks and priests for his first 14 years, learning languages and the teachings of Erathis. On his fifteenth birthday he was offered his choice of paths, and he chose the military Order of the Shining Rod. The next ten years were spent learning tactics and fighting techniques. At the age of 25 he was sent out into the world, to gain experience and help those in need. For the next 25 year he traveled, offering his services as a judge, healer, and military commander where needed. He was 51 when the dragon war started.The Order sent Martin out to aid the resistance fighters in any way he can, without violating the tenants of his faith. Since then he has traveled with various cells, aiding them where he could while bringing law and justice to any lands he passed through.
Princess of a tribal island nation, invaded and conquered by an expanding empire. Sold into slavery on the other side of the world, she must find a way to reclaim her land and reunite her tribe.

She was born and bred to be a proper lady, but she found herself alone in the forest, facing a 20 foot tall bear. She fought for her life and discovered an inner strength. Her true destiny: the path of the berserker.

Born into an upper-middle class family (her great-grandfather invented some very very good mead). Then a fire raged through her hometown and a small girl died in her arms, but her parents didn't really seemed bothered, so she set out adventuring as a way of realigning herself morally.
urban bounty hunter

Raised by single mother in formerly-nice suburb that was on the decline. Father abandoned family when James was 1-2 y.o.Graduated High School from Prospect High School (Mt. Prospect, IL, northwest of Chicago), where he earned a scholarship for linguistics to go to Northeastern Illinois University (Age 18). Worked on losing Chicago Working-Class accent, but still expresses when rattled.Mother killed by junkie in robbery at home while James was away @ college. Junkie found, killed by CPD in stand-off after unrelated traffic stop a few weeks later.Earned his Associate's (Age 20) but interrupted in his work toward a Bachelor's by his mother's murder toward the end of his 3rd year (Age 21).Following year was spent dealing with loose ends. Sold everything, and having no immediate family, joined the US Navy. Specialised in Communications Operations.Worked his ass off, became a SEAL. Attached to Seal Team 5 on USS Colorado, a Virginia-class nuclear sub under command of Cmdr. Douglas Wright, as part of Raven Squad.

Mavis is a 19-year-old hedge witch (strong knowledge of the properties and behaviours of plants and animals, how to heal and how to hurt with them, occasional bits of ritual and incantations to local gods and spirits, that sort of thing) from a small town not much worth mentioning a bit north of Ravenwood. Early on, Mavis' mum ran off to "reinvent herself" and the re-invented version didn't have a tiny daughter, father unknown, so Mavis was raised by her gran, dead now the past couple years, who taught her the witching trade.Mavis' appearance, like her place of birth, is barely worth mentioning. She is certainly not ugly, but not beautiful either. Average enough that you would probably see her and promptly forget. If she were inclined towards a life of crime this would be useful - "Well, officer - she was a -- person? of average height? her hair was... brown maybe...?" In fact, her hair is the same brownish color of bathwater after child #7 has had their turn in the tub, not quite straight enough to be remarkable; her eyes are a similarly unremarkable brown and her skin, apart from having finally grown past a blemishy phase is equally average.
