Her bosom is on the smaller side and she has a figure that will probably settle to pear-shaped when she reaches her gran's age.Mavis, however, has an overblown belief in her own beauty, imagining that it is her loveliness and feminine charm that had all the young men of the neighborhood making indecent suggestions, rather than an ability to observe that the women of Mavis' line have had daughters but no husbands for the last few generations, and a hope that the daughter might take after the mother. Mavis has no time for the attentions of these village louts and is generally mistrustful of any man's intentions.Not long ago, the town's mayor discovered that his wife's failure to conceive was not just bad luck, but aided by an occasional potion; and that the mayor's wife had solicited this prescription to avoid the chance that her future child looked more like the innkeep than the mayor; and Mavis' hometown became much less hospitable. Mavis made clever use of a sleeping draught and "borrowed" a set of clothes from one of her gentleman admirers, chopped her hair off, and set out with a pack and a knife at her belt rather unconvincingly disguised as a young man ("Martin") to seek her fortunes elsewhere.Unfortunately, Mavis has hardly any money (scraped up the bit gran had sat aside for just-in-case) as the neighborhood witch often gets paid in barter (at least she has some idea what to do with the knife, people aren't that different from goats or pigs, right? and gran taught her some very basic hand to hand combat, just-in-case - two or three ways to squirm out of someone's grasp, etc.) and very little idea of how to make it in the outside world. Besides her skills, she's got two things going for her - she has basically no other choice, and at least in Mavis' mind, she's as clever as she is beautiful (and she learned things proper, not that garbage book-learning they do in the cities to seem all high-and-mighty.)

I have a half-sister, six years my senior. Her dad was married to our mom, my dad wasn't. Our mother was a blacksmith who mostly raised us alone and taught us a thing or two about fighting and weapons. Being a half-elf bastard in a small town can inspire wanderlust, and I ran away from home to join the circus in my teens. I spent some years as an acrobat and magician's assistant (the theatrical kind of magician, not the real kind) but although I thought it was fair to sneak aside a bit of extra coin in exchange for the humiliating outfits I was expected to wear (and that I always had to have the knives thrown at me and never throw them, even though I could have done just as well) the circus master had a different opinion, and I found myself out of a job and needing to make a hasty departure. As such, I have sought out my elder sister to prevail on her kindness and our familial bond. I would like to amass enough of a fortune that I can be comfortable and don't have to do anything I don't care to do, if there's a bit of fame that comes with it that would be nice too, because maybe people would buy me drinks when I stop by an inn. Harm.... What harm can it do, if they have plenty and I haven't, to just even the score a smidge? Like as not they wouldn't even notice.... Now, I'd rather not cause any undue harm... but if it comes down to them or me, I'd rather do the harming than be harmed. Small, slim and pale (by human standards, anyway.) white-blond hair and dark eyes. Restless, happy-go-lucky, a bit impetuous. I don't have any special possessions, I'm not particularly sentimental. Last thing I remember was meeting up with my sister at an inn because I missed her soooo much and by the way I'm in a bit of a bind and did she think she could put me up for a while?

She was raised in the circus as a contortionist but as her powers started to develop, she used them to control those around her and to get her way. As a child she wasn't skilled at hiding this and people in the circus would look at her with mistrust and scorn except for one kid: Babs. Eventually, when Olevar was nine the feelings of fear and discontent bubbled and they kicked her out of the circus, not listening to the five year old Babs grabbing their knees and pleading with them as to how she was just a child and didn't know any better. Olevar went to the harbor and convinced her way on to the first boat, a marauding party going up and down the coast. They raised her and taught her how to steal and kill for fun and riches. They valued her powers and helped her practice and refine them and use them for gain at around 24 the boat got in a serious storm and most of the crew died. Olevar was adrift in the ocean when her adoptive younger sister Flaatora found her and brought her to shore. Olevar left on her own as not to corrupt Flora and she grifted and conned her way through the country.   For a while she grifted a princess who fell in love with her and gave her title and riches but she got bored with her as it wasn't a challenge anymore and went back to the circus, initially to get revenge but when she arrived she found out Babs too had been kicked out of the circus so she went to find Babs and keep her safe because in her mind Babs is still the sweet child who stood up for her when no one else would.

Born and raised in the circus, Babs becomes a stage magician. She grows bored of illusions and slight of hand and goes to wizard school. She gets fired from the circus for doing legit magic and ''ruining the act". Devastated, she does the only other thing she knows wizards do:  adventuring.

He has a big family and got in trouble with an organised crime group in his youth, because he was dumb. He was a stage magician until his wife died, (spoilers she isnt dead she's a spy). these days he travels with and eclectic group of fellow adventurers.

A natural medium, Nox started seeing and communicating with the dead at a young age. She was a cheerful and imaginative child, so her parents believed that the incessant babble of one-sided conversation was just Nox speaking to imaginary friends. Something she would grow out of. But as she grew older, her love of exploring the spirit world grew with her. Her trusting nature eventually led to tragedy. As she slept one night, a vengeful wraith entered her family home through her dreams. This spirit killed her parents, leaving Nox and her young brother Hob orphans. Rather than live with their well-meaning foster parents, Nox ran away. She thought it would be best for Hob to forget his family tragedy and grow up believing himself to be the son of a normal, loving couple. Unable to forgive herself for the death of her parents, Nox became withdrawn and morose. At only 13 years old, she was a steely pragmatist, indifferent to fear and inured to pain. She took up her current path, the life of a nomad wandering the world in search of arcane knowledge—this is how she discovered the path of the white necromancer. At 16, Nox became an apprentice to a powerful medium. He instilled in her a code to live by; a code of maintaining the balance between life and death—serving the dead who were killed unjustly by helping lay them to rest, and destroying spirits who interrupt the balance.Secretly, though Nox knows it is forbidden, she dreams of finding the spell that will bring her parents back to life so they can reunite as a family again. Appearance: * Short–3 feetish (seriously)* 30 lbs, yes halflings are truly tiny * Freshly shaved head (she does this every morning) * Whorls of black tattoos all over her body* Distinctive tattoo under her eyes simulates "necrotic seepage,” elder mentor gave it to her to symbolize “grave sight” the power to commune with the dead * Loose-fitting robes, bandolier with potions and powders

He was part of a band of highwaymen that would prey on small caravans. One day as his cohorts waited in the forest for their next target, he heard an enchanting noise. A caravan rounded the corner of the road and he saw a man playing a tin whistle and he knew he had to know more. While his band attacked the caravan, he stole the man into the forest and demanded to learn how to play this instrument. The terrified man managed to give him a very brief lesson before  they were discovered and the musician was killed. He picked up the tin whistle and began practicing at all hours. It was terrible. So terrible that he was kicked out of the band of highwaymen and left to pursue a life of music.
Abandoned in a monastery as a baby.
Parents were killed by bandits

She’s a young woman from a revered family of knights. Sadly, thanks to his duties, her father is largely absent (and neglectful of his eight offspring when he’s around) while her mother is emotionally abusive and hates magic. She also had an inept and selfish teacher who nearly destroyed her. Mailys fled from her family’s impossible demand that she give up magic and from her teacher, period, and started trying to build a life where she could be both powerful and a hero.

He grew up in a human village that had little regard for elves (who are treated as second-class citizens in that land) and thought of dark elves as moral monsters. All his attempts to blend in and be accepted failed. His older sibs left home (one to become a warrior/paladin supporting the human government, one to become a necromancer revolutionary, and one to retreat from uncontrolled prophecy to a temple vocation) and were never heard from again. While Nazarr stayed with his parents as long as he could, he eventually left because simply existing in a trap is not living.

She’s an orphan no one cares about who prays gods no one accepts (and who grant no redemption from death) and whose only strength lies in her ability to pummel others senseless. The fact that her human side is disregarded while she is deemed to be a pirate, a savage, and an invader does not help. She trusts few people; there seems to be little point in it.

Went to a posh-and-sheltered school, got three firsts in archery but not much else, then returned to her home town to discover she'd been volunteered to travel into the nearby dungeon for the town's yearly ritual. Unfortunately she's afraid of bugs.

Lalo was an aspiring musician despite his family's strong leaning towards cavalry and protecting the village. The old town minstrel taught him to play mandolin, and left him the instrument when he died.Not long ago, Lalo's carefree romantic whims got him caught with a married lover, forcing him to flee his homeland in shame. He still hasn't learned discretion, however.

The son of a woodcutting family, Therin dreamed of adventuring while his family wanted him to do something more sensible. In an ill-conceived attempt to teach Therin about responsibility, his parents gave him the money to go into town and buy some new tools. Therin promptly spent the money on adventuring gear, and styled himself anew. He joined up with an adventuring party just as his town was attacked by a necromantic wizard. After much adventure and misadventure, the party defeated the wizard, and Therin (determined to become a pirate captain) flew away on a haunted pirate ship - the Blanche Nef.

Son to the matriarch of a travelling band of nomadic gnomes, Latitude immigrated to the big city in the hopes of going to university and inventing an air-machine. He was unable to acquire legal entry to the city and so lived a semi-homeless existence as unpaid engineering labor on the famous 'blink-train circuit'. His main skills were shaped around avoiding the authorities, and ultimately he teamed up with an adventuring party with the promise of earning him permanent, lawful citizenship and a chance at university.

Before he hatched, Flock's egg was stolen by a rogue and sold at an auction as a 'dragon egg'. The buyer, a wealthy elf adventurer and treasure-hunter, was disappointed when Flock hatched from the egg, rather than a baby dragon, but did his level best to bring the young kenku up. Flock was thus exposed to a life of adventure, treasure hunting, and exploration. He learned a great many languages, and how to lie in all of them. Unfortunately he and his adoptive father trespassed on a sacred religious site and both earned 100 years in prison. As his father was an elf and likely to outlive Flock, his father begged the judge to take Flock's 100 years as well as his own, so that Flock could enjoy a full and happy life. With his father imprisoned and nowhere to go, Flock drifted until he found a big city, where he lived in the fringes and alleys, until finally he found a quaint little shop selling lesser treasures. He immediately struck up a friendship with the proprietor, a fierce Minotaur lady called Feather, and set up a small-time detective agency. The shop subsequently became known as 'Flock and Feather's Emporium and Detective Agency' until the two earned the interest of the local magical authorities, who employed them as contractors.

Dorcy learned at a very young age that she could talk to animals.  In fear, her mother threw her out of the house.  Dorcy lived in the woods alone until she was 10, when her grandparents took her in to train her as a proper and obedient lady.  She put up with their controlling behavior for four years, and then went back to the woods, this time by choice.  She made a living by harvesting herbs for potions and trapping animals, and traveled into town once a month to trade her goods for the necessities she wasn't able to harvest on her own.  Dorcy is still nearly feral in some ways, and is generally considered by her friends to be the most dangerous and unpredictable of the group.

Rachel entered school at the age of four, specially chosen directly by her god to become a paladin.  When the time came for her consecration, the negligent god left her abandoned.  After months of fighting through the  feelings of worthlessness, depression, betrayal, and wishing to die, Rachel finally started to come out of it with the help of one very important friend.  Now, still dedicated to her ideals of Justice and righteousness, she is trying to perform the job of a paladin with none of the miracles and divine protection a paladin would have.

"Collector of Antiquities" - a specialist in tomb robbery.  Works alone, likes it that way.  Has lived like this for 30 years.  Apprenticed to other thieves before that.  Never knew parents.  Agnostic but carries 61 different small charms on person, just in case.
Healed scars and severe sunburn on face.  Escaped from Garamantes tribes across Libyan Desert.  Escaped her half-siblings and others in desert.  Cooling her heels as far away as possible.
Young stonemason from Cydanus on the edge of the Western Desert.  Hit his head on an architrave.  Suffers headaches, sees visions – is learning to bring them on
Street kid from Tyre who travels and lives by her wits: gambling, street tricks, pipe playing, drumming, singing, snake charming, and thievery

Last member of Mazax oasis tribe.  Will put on a show of being devoted to “my people’s closest equivalent to Sobek/Athena/Sol Invictus” but is really devoted to bull-headed sun god Ghizl of her people. After suffering final raid on home oasis, has no surviving friends, family or tribe.
Elderly “scholar” from Mesopotamia– discreetly studies magic. Curious about mysteries, but mostly just needs money.  Not averse to “acquisition” of items from tombs

Tall, wild-looking desert tribesman from west of the far-Southern Kingdom. Has the bowlegged gait of someone who would rather be on a horse or camel.  Likes riding horses and camels and can shoot arrows backwards while riding them.  Smells a little pungent.
Unrepentant, only sometimes discreet heretic; narcissist; natty dresser
Barbarian from distant border region; taciturn; living by dubious means in southern cities
From eastern border city, trades in “curiosities and antiquities” - tomb-raider for treasures, magic items, mummies’ teeth, etc.  Interested in local legends; in debt; needs a lot of money

Barbarian seeress from north of the border rivers; her visions were interpreted as criticizing the ruling warlord, so she had to flee to “civilization”, where she can melt into city crowds. In times of extreme stress, such as combat, she has a strong chance to be overtaken by a vision.
Middle-aged ascetic who lived atop a pillar for two decades; recently arrived in city; does not conform well to monastic rules or conventional  roles for women in society.

Disgraced barbarian ex-horseman without a horse; bowlegged, hides painful unhealed wound; short but tough; ritually scarred face; cannot grow a beard; bristling topknot hairstyle. Needs money, wants to heal wound, buy a horse, maybe or maybe not return to his own people. -1 in combat until embarrassing wound he hides is healed

Half descended from a long line of Golden City garum fish sauce workers, half descended from Uldin’s tribe; not conventionally pretty; very quick to make puns, humorous comebacks to insults; good emotional intelligence, strong-willed, persuasive

The Many Misadventures and Mysterious Misgivings of the Magical and Maleficent FLYING SWORD FOLLOWS GOOSEThe Times after Escape	Goose ran away from his hometown of Wah’Serine when he was at the young age of 20 right before the ceremony that would greet him to adulthood. The God Talkers of his village (better known in elvish as the Amanduné) had plans for Goose that would help unlock his true potential... as they had said many times in the past. Goose, wanting no part of whatever stuffy ponderings these ancient, withered, willowy, elves had in store for him, used his quickly developing power to beat a hasty escape from the ancient tree city, never to return.	On the road, Goose learned that growing up as an outsider had its’ advantages in the wider world. With his dashing good looks and quick tongue he was able to turn many situations with rough rapscallions from potential beatings into nights of merriment. Finding that beyond having a quick wit and a few parlor tricks up his sleeve, he had no real employable skills, Goose fell in with a band of Musicians, Actors, Entertainers, Storytellers, Escape Artists, Magicians, and Mercenaries known as the Wild Rovers. Being relatively green and clueless, the band of merrymakers, miscreants, and murderers taught him most of what he knows, and molded him as a person. In this band is also where he earned his famous moniker, as his attempt to perform a daring sword dance turned into a wild magic burst that polymorphed him into a goose, resulting in much leaping and honking as the animated blades twirled around him.For twenty years Goose roved the land as one of the wild bunch, womanizing, drinking, and honing his performance craft everywhere he went. But he found that no amount of liquor and laughter was able to drown out the baleful chorus resounding from within. Since he was a child, Goose had been tormented by some unknown force, that to him were simply bad dreams or perhaps the result of too much magical exertion. But no matter the rest he had or the control over his abilities mastered, Goose found these dark visions were always close at hand. Having no shape or form, he only knew the presence and the voice that occasionally penetrated the woeful din.Morohtar… Morohtar...LINGER NOT LONG. THE EVE OF ARRIVAL DRAWS EVER NIGH. HE REQUIRES YOUR PRESENCE.II. Discovery and Ruin	Around the age of 40 Goose left the Wild Rovers and set out on his own, determined to find some semblance of inner peace. He wandered from town to town, telling stories of the land  and giving various performances for spending money whenever he could. He became somewhat of a household name in the towns surrounding the capital, and after a time began to attract attention. After a rather rowdy show in the Dwarven mining encampment near the city of Oresdepth, Goose was approached by an agent of The Bard’s College nearby. Goose took the invitation as an opportunity to settle his mind and perhaps change his ways, maybe mending the chaos inside.	Goose found himself rather comfortable in the melodic atmosphere that encompassed the Oresdepth Bardic University, but the university did not seem to be as comfortable with him. Other students and bardic hopefuls knew of Flying Sword Follows Goose, but mainly as an uncouth halfbreed magician that thought himself a talented performer. Goose of course wanted only to learn himself better, and cast aside his old ways. 	Goose spent years studying the bardic ways in that place, and was soon due to graduate, he would a be a full blown bard! The final performance was at hand and Goose had prepared what he believed to be a stunning mix of magic, music, and storytelling. The headmaster called him to the stage and beckoned him to begin, in front of all his peers. A feeling of peace washed over Goose as he told his story, his past. Weaving spells into images, accompanied by a soft lute that he played. 	The hoi polloi, refusing to recognize the talent inherent in Goose, would stand no longer to let such a disgraceful excuse for a bard continue to perform. All it took was a lone voice to start the avalanche, as a small voice in the audience shouted “Down with halfbreeds!” and hurled a ball of refuse at the spellbound sorcerer, followed in suit by a wave of others. And before their eyes the gentle melody and images vanished, only to be replaced by a wild magical field that seemed to fill the room; and the slight, joyful, musician that was once Flying Sword Follows Goose was replaced the by a wrathful beaming entity of hate and destruction. With little more than a glance from Goose, a thunderous boom resounded from the glowing godlike figure, causing the close-by audience to cover and cower as the hall around them was ripped apart by a wave of pure force throwing chairs, books, chandeliers, and bards through the air. 	Seeming more like a demon from the Abyss, the jovial entertainer was no more. On ethereal black wings the spellbound entity tore a swath across the building, rending the great hall from its foundation with a simple gesture. Abyssal heat burning in his eyes, the entity’s blackened visage cracked a freakish smile, and as quickly as it came the dark entity vanished, leaving the frail body of Goose shaking on the cracked earth. The Building crumbled around him as the occupants all pointed, aghast, and ran for their lives. Beating a hasty exit Goose left his home at the University and fled the city for the East.III. The Golden Lion’s Tail	After 15 years away, hiding in the far desert city of Shabal, still haunted by the growing chorus inside, almost moreso everyday, Goose did his best to keep to himself and stifle his wanderlust; when he heard the all too familiar sound of a Northern ballad. Having lived the simple life of a street performer for many years, Goose had learned to speak the flowing native tongue of the East and had dealt with all manner of rough sellswords and fortune seekers, flowing into the city port from foreign lands. He excelled at eavesdropping and pickpocketing, becoming one with the city, and the din of livestock, horses, and northern men were a welcome sight; more purses to lift. 	As Goose watched the gleaming caravan from afar, he leapt from his roost in a garden above the city into the street below. No sooner had he adjusted his hat to the sun and shifted his belt, he heard a familiar hiss behind him. “Gooossssssse. Ssssso nice to ssssssee you here.” It was none other than the Yuan Ti Body Trader known as Utszu, a grotesque creature with the head of a snake and the body of a muscular humanoid man.	Utszu was a member of a proud and noble family of Yuan Ti, who used their might and keen senses to enslave lesser races that they had dominated and venture to the port cities to trade them to rich merchants and landowners who wanted cheap labor. Goose was no stranger to these ‘people’ and had on several occasions used a few sorcerous tricks to release the more unfortunate among the slaves right under Utszu’s nose. Although he had evaded Utszu and his patrols on many occasions, it looked like his number was finally up...	Goose saw the way this reptilian man handler leered at him and knew from prior experience that there would be trouble. The Yuan Ti were rare to encounter in these parts, but he had never met one with anything but a foul temper and an even fouler stench. “You owe me coin Gooosssssse. Thosssse ssslaves were not yoursss to take, and you will pay, with blood or gold, I do not care.” Seeing several other heavily armed reptiles behind Utszu, Goose could feel the magic inside beginning to boil up, but he kept it down and reasoned with the lizard. A bag of fine Northern treasure from the foreign caravan in exchange for the trouble he had caused. Utszu’s eye slits narrowed and he waved the sorcerer off. “Ssssundown Goossse, or we will find you.” The band of dinosaurs departed and Goose released the burning, clutched, orb in his fist.	Keeping pace with a richly adorned carriage in the massive caravan that was slowly parting the human sea of Shabal, Goose distracted the guards with wonderous illusions of Phoenixes flying and flaming dragons making circles overhead, much to the amusement of the wide eyed escort. Using this distraction Goose deftly grabbed a loose bag from the carriages luggage rack and began to drift back into the crowd, when a rough voice called out from behind him.	“You are quick lad and that was a fine trick, but you might want to put that back before the clergy has your head” Slowly turning around, Goose was met by a grizzled older man in plain travelers clothes. “Look, with skill like that I think we might be able to work something out and forget this whole situation hmm?” His thick Northern accent blew through the greying mustache that covered his entire mouth, giving him a walrus-like appearance. “The name is Halfdan and i’m the master of The Golden Lion’s Tail, this caravan you see here. And that bag you decided to swipe belongs to the Church of Bahamut, who I guarantee will NOT take kindly to theft”	Realizing that the first good thing to happen in many years may have just rolled up next to him, Goose had flashes of his life with the Wild Rovers and felt the omnipresent wanderlust boiling up inside him. A way out of the grasp of Utszu and an excuse to restart in another place... The stout man who called himself Halfdan held out his hand, “Now I don’t usually do this, but I can tell you aren’t a Shabali pickpocket here to beguile us out of a few holy symbols and a handful of tithings. Hand over the bag and come work for the caravan for a while. Then we might call it even.” 	Without so much as a word Goose thrust the bag into the burly caravan master’s hands and climbed aboard the back carriage. Onward, Goose felt that this is where he was meant to be...

Born to the Two Axe Clan of Borthfagldur, Bridget's parents had hopes for her to become an engineer and named her accordingly. But as she matured, she rebelled against her traditional upbringing and, shortly before an arranged marriage to an intelligent and conscientious architect, she ran away from home. Leaving the mountain holds, she fled to the human lands where she earned her keep through physical labour. But her brash nature and general anger with the world (and herself) pushed her from job to job, and she didn't settle down or make friends. Unable to make ends meet, she took the ceremonial axe (that she had brought with her as a memento) to sell for a bit more coin; but, mistaken for an experienced warrior, she was invited to join an adventuring party by a bypasser. Having little to lose, she accepted the offer, hoping that the decorative axe would hold out when wielded in battle. Until she has proven herself to be independently successful, her pride prevents her from returning to the hold that she misses so much; but one day she dreams of going home with glory and riches to her name, and vindicating her rash decisions as a young girl.

Raised by a cult of Jaziran during the spell-plague, he's been sent out into the work to try to gather pieces of the world-serpent to send to Jaziran in an effort to restore him to full power. He's been wandering the slums of various cities, offering cut-rate healing services and proselytizing for a god that most people think he's a little crazy to worship.
Orphan that was saved by Odin

Jayda grew up in a small coastal town, and when she was around 14, she ran away from home and joined the crew of a pirate ship. One night, when she was about 19, a huge storm hit while her ship was at sea, and she was the sole survivor of the shipwreck. Before, she had been rather skeptical of her crewmates' faith in the sea goddess Umberlee, but she certainly believed now. She devoted herself to Umberlee and became a cleric. In addition, she built her own ship, the Stormbreaker, and sailed it as a one-woman pirate crew. Now she sails the high seas, looting and pillaging and spreading chaos wherever she sees fit.

Orryn was sent off to a prestigious wizard school at a young age. However, she quickly realized that she had no interest in studying or learning magic. Being a mischievous person with a mean sense of humor, she began to devote herself instead to troublemaking and devising elaborate and often convoluted pranks. Over time, she did end up picking up some enchantment and illusion magic, mostly to aid her in her pranks. When she was around 18, however, she pulled a prank on her best friend that went way too far and her friend got seriously hurt. In the fallout, Orryn dropped out of school and made a new life for herself as a rogue.

Nara was raised by her orc father; the only connection she had to her human mother was a stone pendant that she wears as a necklace. When Nara was about 8, a magical message revealed itself on the pendant, telling Nara to journey to a faraway cave by the ocean where her mother would be there to give Nara a magical birthright. Nara left home and set off on this long journey. Along the way, she met a half-elf named Kael, who was on her own journey to become a paladin. They traveled together for almost 10 years, but parted ways when Nara reached the cave promising each other that they would meet again in the future and get married. However, she discovered that someone, or something, had gotten to the cave first. There was no sign of her mother or the magic. Frustrated but refusing to give up, Nara went to a tavern in the closest town with the intent to simply rest up until she figured out what to do next. However, in the tavern she overheard some people talking about a prestigious and brutal fighter's school nearby, Arrowhawk Academy. She decided to find the school. She attended for 6 years, learning two-weapon fighting and battlemaster techniques. Upon graduation, she came to the big city and became a mercenary for a while, primarily helping escort groups of people to the nearby mountains to search for gold.

He was just a normal child of nobles. Then, one day, he found a cursed hat and put it on. Now the hat controls his will and makes him commit evil acts that if I’m being honest, he’d probably be complicit in anyways.

Lied Tea'Sun was the third son born to a stonemason in the township of Delphi of Phil. He was apprenticed with a traveling wizard after Lied's mental abilities began to manifest. The wizard Beltran as a minor court wizard, and a troubleshooter of sorts for Duke Beltran.Lied spent several years employed as a gopher and lackey, while trying to learn the mystic arts. He learned a great deal about magical theory, the planes and the players in the various courts, but was unable to manage even the most basic cantrip. However, his psychic powers continued to develop, eventually enabling him to create his own gophers to deal with the basic chores left to him.A winsome lad, Lied was often time trotted out at gatherings, in part to entertain the other guests with his "pets," and in part to help sway stubborn nobles to his master's view by offering counterpoint opinions with a child's voice. As he aged and grew into his position, Lied took on more diplomatic duties for his master. Lied also was sent to escort many young nobles of his age, while they traveled, in order to keep them safe.Eventually, Lied left Beltran's service after an unfortunate incident. Lied learned through mental whispers that Beltran intended to cheat a local lord out of his holdings, in order to find a place to settle down. Lied quietly informed the lord, but Beltran learned of Lied's interference. The parting was unfriendly; Beltran still holds a grudge against his former pupil.Lied traveled on his own for a few years before arriving at the rebuilt Shire of Hamp, which was in the midst of a spring solstice celebration. Later that night, Koa-Tao invaded, mere hours after the height of the celebration. Lied, along with several others in the village for the festival, managed to drive out the invaders, in large part because of Lied's ability to grant instant, quiet communication between the defenders. However, in the process of ousting, Lied learned that the Koa-Tao planned a much larger force to attack the nearby keep. The attack on the shire was meant to gain a staging area and resupply point. He also learned that another force was due to arrive soon.Lied convinced the local militia leader to send out a small force to warn the keep, while Lied prepared, along side those who were able, to defend the shire. Lied's strong words and personal magnetism inspired the defenders and, by the time the Koa-Tao arrived, they faced a group of grim, determined and nearly fanatical militia, along with potent astral beings. The siege of the Shire of Hamp took two days, with Duke Yueh's men arriving on the second night.The Koa-Tao were routed.Few of the village defenders survived, but those who did were hailed as heroes. At Duke Yueh's behest, Lied began an investigation into why the Koa-Tao attacked and how they managed to get so far inland without detection. On the way, Lied met up with a young priestess, Merrowynn, who was traveling from Livermore Falls to Derry. They agreed to travel together, at least as far as the city.It was in Derry the both learned how deep the corruption ran. Lied's investigation eventually uncovered a sizable group of clerics -- disaffected with the way the city refused to acknowledge their church as the true church, above all others -- had set up riots and other social unrest on the sly. Their intent was to show that having multiple faiths within a city, each equal, was disharmonious. Lied and Merrowynn uncovered and exposed the plot. They also learned that the funding the cabal used to bring in outside rabble rousers came from outside the city. Someone else wanted the city distracted while the Koa-Tao invaded. Merowynn, disgusted with how the clergy acted within the city, decided to travel with Lied to Gloucester, in part to get away from the very disappointing high priests, and in part to give Lied's warning weight when he arrived.Lied and Merrowynn's activities did not go unnoticed.Roland Cort was born into a minor noble family. The first son, Cort was raised with the expectation of ruling his lands, once his father passed away. However, Cort's father's passing came far earlier than thought. When Cort was 12, his manor was raided by Orcs, who slew his family, their servants and most of the local peasantry. Cort's father was not a benevolent ruler, and with the lands ruined by the raids, the remaining commonfolk left their villages for safer harbors. At the age of 12, Cort inherited his birthright: A burntout husk of a land, and none to work it. Bereft of kin or caretakers, Cort took to the streets. He spent several years earning his livelihood stealing what he could and always moving. His dreams were wracked by his memories of the slaughter. One night, after a particularly horrible nightmare, Cort awoke to a dread realization: He would forever be haunted by his past unless he took action.Not long later, Cort was caught stealing from a woodsman, Cypher. Cort plead, swearing his life and service to Cypher if he spared Cort's life. The woodsman, who was on a task set by his master, Walter, agreed to take Cort on; he was tired of carrying his own gear, and the thought of training someone so used to the city life amused him.Not long later, Cort began his tutelage into the arts of the woodlands, while stealing coin and other small trinkets from locked rooms to fund the pair's journey. Because Cypher did not have a sword small enough for Cort to train with, the woodsman gave him a long sword, far too large and heavy for Cort's slight build, and demanded Cort fight swiftly. Cort's training was strongly encouraged by Cypher's oak walking staff, which he used to beat the lad when Cort was slow.Within two month's time, the pair made their way to Keene, where the woodsman was to assassinate a local lord while the lord was on a hunt. Cort was given a bow, which he had proven to be naturally proficient with, and some distinctive silver-fletched arrows. The Cypher gave Cort a small bag of gold -- his share, he was told -- then left Cort at a tree copse and instructed the lad to wait. The gold made Cort suspicious, Cypher had never been generous before, which proved well founded. Cries of men quickly filled the forest, and not long later, men on horseback rode into sight. Cort hid, his eyes wide at the sight of one of the men, who was holding bloody, broken haft of an arrow, the fletchings identical to the ones he carried.Scared and furious, Cort managed to slip away from the men.Cypher didn't manage to slip away from Cort.Fifteen and angry, Cort decided the best way to get vengeance would be to strike out against the Orcs who first raided his home. Cort spent several months in the deep woods, carefully stalking and slaying any Orc or small Orc group that came across his path. He also made periodic forays back into human-controlled lands, buying whatever he needed, and killing whenever he needed something he couldn't buy.Cort's raw talent was noticed by an elder halfling named Arthur Bishop. Bishop introduced himself to Cort as a machinist, looking for someone to help him fix a problem: A young half-elf named Jill Ireland owes him money, and he wants it or proof she'll never pay. Cort takes the job, and does well. Soon, Bishop hired Cort on a more permanent basis, promising wealth and all the support Cort could want on his quest for revenge against the world, a world that Cort feels owes him. Bishop spent time training Cort in the arts of poison and stealth. He also attempted to dissuade Cort from favoring such oversized weapons, to little effect.After several years of service in the kingdom and abroad, Bishop asks Cort to deal with a simple matter: Two young adventurers are traveling near Derry, and should be delayed, but not slain. Bishop inform Cort that their current employer wants them holed up for at least a week, but not stopped entirely. Disgruntled, Cort makes his way to the outskirts of Derry and picks up the trail of two humans.Lied and Merowynn still remember their journey to Gloucester as among the worst treks of their lives. The horses they were riding constantly went lame, sometimes throwing them into burr patches or sharp ravines. Their food supply turned without them noticing; both took seriously ill from food poisoning. Not long after, a storm cut loose and a changed stream washed out the trail. After spending a full day getting the horses around the washout, one of the two geldings died, evidently from eating a particularly bad patch of nettles. A journey of five days stretched to 11. Sodden, hungry and fatigued, the pair arrived at Gloucester only to find the city in chaos and the gates closed: Someone had assassinated the city's lord as well as the heirophant of Baccob.Within a day, it is announced Koa-Toa glue was found near the assassination sites. A day later, Duke Yueh issues a call for the lords of the land to join together under his banner to take the war to the Koa-Toa.Lied and Merowynn manage to sneak into the city, and immediately begin their investigation. Through great effort, they are able to gain access to the sites where the lord and the heirophant were slain. They also track down an eyewitness, Serrano, who claims to have seen humans nearby when the assassinations occurred. The eyewitness says he could identify some of them, if he ever saw them again.Lied convinces Serrano to hide in a room in the dye district, then he and Merowynn quickly head to see Duke Yueh, who is preparing for war. Lied lays out all that he and Merowynn have learned so far: That someone funded dissidents in a nearby city to distract the local lord from the danger of the Koa-Toa army, and that someone seems ready to frame the recent death of a high clergyman and the Lord of Gloucester on the Koa-Toa. He also says they have found an eyewitness to one of the attacks, who says he can identify the culprits.The duke, in the midst of planning a campaign, did not appear convinced that the eyewitness was telling the complete truth. Lied tells him that Merowynn created a zone of truth to help confirm his story, and that many of the details in the witness's tale matched up with what transpired. Duke Yueh said that he'd need to investigate the man's story further; he told them he'd send other inquisitors to speak with him. Yueh then set the pair on a new task: They are to head to Manchester and speak with a man named Quisling. Quisling said he had information about a noble dealing with the Koa-Toa.After leaving the interview with Duke Yueh, Lied and Merowynn part company: Merowynn said that she had done all that she could, and that her church needed her to take up her assigned duties in Gloucester, especially after the assassination. Lied disagreed, but they parted on good terms.Merowynn returned to Gloucester, where Santibanez, the second in the city church, had ascended to power. After receiving her report on where she'd been and what she'd been up to, Santibanez assigned Merowynn to the comforting of the sick and dying, with strict instructions to stay out of the local political rings. Merowynn spent several ten-days tending to the ill, when she learned that the witness she and Lied hid away had been found dead, a bottle of cheap ale found in his hands.Merowynn, suspicious, begged Santibanez for permission to investigate. Santibanez told her that she'd spent far too much time on her own, and needed to learn discipline and order: The man's death was an accident, and any investigation was the purview of the local militia, not the church.The next night, Merowynn snuck into the church crypt and found Serrano's remains, a brown bottle placed on his chest. After careful consideration, she calls forth Serrano's spirit and asks him about his death. She learned that he did not die accidentally, but was instead poisoned. He never saw who killed him; Serrano found an ale bottle in his room, and thought it was a gift. He said the last thing he remembered while living was resting on his bed before sharp pains bit into his belly.After Serrono's ghost faded winked back into the afterlife, the world suddenly turned sideways as Merowynn staggered under an unfamiliar pressure. Her balance returning, Merowynn leaned up against one of the tomb walls and felt sickened as she realized her connection to the divine was muted and fading. Baccob, displeased with her disobedience to duty, stripped her of her divine connection.Weeping, Merowynn fled the tomb and into the night.Lied, riding his new horse, made his way over the space of a few weeks to Manchester, where he met up with Quisling. Quisling, a human with a happy temperament and a roguish grin, informed Lied about a local lord named Junta. Quisling told Lied that Lord Junta had a small cabal of wizards and monks serving him as a personal retinue, and that Junta had a hand in bribing station guards along the coast, as well as funding dissidents in Derry. Why, or incriminating documents, Quisling couldn't provide. He did however offer whatever aid he could in Lied's investigation.Lied spent several days wandering the city and asking questions, getting by on charm as best he could. He discovered that Lord Junta did indeed have a sizable retinue of powerful mages and monks at his service, and that many in the city felt that the king didn't support his faithful well: If they wanted things done, they'd have to do them.Lied mused for another day at the inn, then contacted Quisling and had him describe the seneschal of Lord Junta's house. Armed with the basics, Lied dominated the seneschal and arranged to be hired into the house as a servant. Once inside, Lied spent the better part of three weeks investigating and gathering evidence. It soon became clear to him that Lord Junta was extremely disturbed about being out of contact with one of his partners, though he never heard a name, and that whatever the lord was involved with, it was not going according to plan. Lied was able to gather several documents related to the plot, including a copy of the lord's ledger.Lied fled the lord's keep in the company of the seneschal, whom he then sent to local tavern with orders to get very drunk, then to brag about his lord's work. Lied left the city and began the long journey back to Duke Yueh, with proof of the mastermind behind the conspiracy.Lied rode a day away from the city, then teleported himself and his horse back to Derry. From there, he rode out to where Duke Yueh commanded the region's armies in a bid to strike back at the Koa-Toa. Lied laid out what he had discovered. Duke Yueh praised Lied, and set into motion plans to conquer Lebanon and put Lord Junta to trial, then death. Yueh ordered Lied to return to Derry and await word; he would require Lied's testimony at the high court. He also paid Lied well for his hard work. Lied returned to the city in the company of several warriors in Duke Yueh's service as a retinue.Some days later, a diminutive mage — seemingly half mad — forced her way past Lied's guard in an inn's commonroom, shouting about a poisoned gift that moved the body. Filthy, half-starved, the woman presented a human skull to Lied and begged him to listen to its words. It took Lied several moments to place this unkempt woman: Merowynn.After a lot of food and a bath, Merowynn was calm enough to tell Lied about what had happened to their witness, Serrano. She also told him that she'd later snuck back into the tombs and claimed his head after a particularly bad night of drinking. When Lied asked about her state, Merowynn told Lied that she had been cast out of the church for disobedience; since then she said she'd been too distraught to try and plan her future. After a very long discussion, including the promise of sobriety, Merowynn entered into Lied's service as a wizard.Deciding to make sure they had all the evidence they could for the high court of Lord Junta, Lied slipped into the tombs later that night in order to take the ale bottle buried with Serrano. While there, Lied was attacked by a young man carrying what appeared to be a troll's longsword. Summoning up an astral construct, Lied was able to fend his attacker off, but was badly hurt in the process. The running battle awoke the guardians of the churchyard. Foreseeing trouble, the man broke away from their fight. Seeing his own opportunity, Lied snatched the bottle from the tomb and teleported to an inn outside of town, then back to the townhouse where he and Merowynn were staying.That night, Lied got word from Duke Yeuh that it was time for him to assist in the capture of Lebanon and the subsequent high court: The war with the Koa-Toa was complete. Lied and Merowynn left Derry immediately, the bottle safely hidden away.The journey took several weeks to complete, as neither Lied nor Merrowynn had been to Lebanon before. The time on the road was not wasted, however. Merrowynn took samples from the bottle, in order to determine what kind of poison might have been used -- a long shot, at best. She also began performing scryings, using the bottle as the focus. Both resulted in limited success: There was enough residue left in the bottle to identify that poison was used, but not enough to clearly identify what it was, though it did seem to be potent, and rare. The scryings turned up little, save that the bottle was locally made, and had gone through several hands.Lied spent the journey partly riding in the carriage with Merrowynn, and partly back in Derry, teleporting between the locations during the evening stops. He spent the nights roaming the city and asking questions, often in disguise or, in certain instances, by using his charm. With the little information he was able to gather, he learned that the bottle had been placed in the room by a young human servant, who'd not been seen in the city since. A clear sign that a professional had been at work. He also learned that the wine was one of the more expensive, and usually only found among collectors or the wealthy, something their witness would not normally have access to.Slightly delayed, they arrived at Lebanon on the eve of the final assault. Lied and Merrowynn fought bravely, and played a good part in the city's taking. Lied also became fascinated by the use of ground troop maneuvers, which eventually spurred a life-long study of group tactics.The city taken, the guilty found, the land began to rejoice. Lied and Merrowynn were invited to sup with Duke Yueh and King Haart, who had arrived too late with his own men to help deal with the matter. After the dinner, the king was to hear the guilty's pleas, then render judgement.The duke spoke with the king at length that evening, accepting the king's praise. Duke Yueh began making inroads towards claiming the lands he'd saved, as it was clear those who ran it were unable to govern with any skill. The king seemed inclined, but noncommittal. After the feast, a dessert wine was served for the enjoyment of the royal table.The wine the Duke served came from a distinctive brown bottle, with Derry's mark.Lied 'arranged' for the bottle to be spilled, and then made sure to spirit it away after the next wine was brought. He passed the bottle to Merrowynn, and asked her to mystically examine the bottle for poisons. She didn't find any. What she did find was that this bottle and the bottle from the gravesite both shared owners.Lied pigeonholed Lord Malachai, the right-hand man of King Haart, and begged him to delay the hearings of the local lords by a day. Lied did not go into specifics, saying merely that he had stumbled across evidence of other crimes that might prove unconvictable, should the trials precede. Malachai recognized Lied's assistance in the battle, but was not greatly impressed with what little he brought forward. Still, he was willing to talk with the king, and suggest a noon-time hearing, rather than a late evening one, so that more of the local populous could attend. Lied, grateful for what time he got, moved quickly forward, doing his best to shake loose the wine of the evening.Lied presents his evidence, impressing the king, but the exchange is overheard. Lied and Merowyn fend off an assassin sent to slay them in revenge, Cort, eventually turning him to their side. After many further adventures, Lied gains the position of Minister of Law for the kingdom.

He was a member of a dangerous street gang, the Silver Serpents, and an underground cage fighter known as the Hook for his deadly chain and sickle combo. Recently, however, he abandoned the gang and joined a monastery, the Order of the Senephis, hoping to atone for his past sins. He has a habit of slipping into his old ways, but can usually catch himself before he goes too far.

Her father was the flighty third son of the Verdante traders; her mother, she assumes, was an orc of some kind. It's not like her father ever remembered which tryst she was.Left on her father's doorstep, Mara was instead mostly raised in a small neighboring town by her very religious Aunt Faith, who saw her as quite the charity case. She grew up attending church, cleaning storerooms, and staying out of trouble. She even made a few sales. A perfect model of what a proper upbringing could do for a savage half-blood; almost like a real human!That changed on Mara's 23rd birthday, when she stumbled on the town priest's darkest secret.The only attention her father ever gave her was to help her leave the town unscathed, but she didn't mind. As long as that damn priest was dead, she could rest easy... unless.Were there more priests like that, out there in the world? More predators?Then they had to be stopped.

Dilvish was the protege of a very powerful wizard, known to history as the Lungfish, who trapped the Aboleth below the sea to protect the world from their evil. Dilvish became a Lich in order to make sure the spell would hold and continue the Lungfish Festival, a carefully-orchestrated ritual disguised as a month-long celebration of the return of the rainy season in a port town known as Udram. Now, he is struggling to keep the Monks of the Deep from ruining the Festival and breaking the spell to unleash the Aboleth upon the world.

General:1) Selene Paige is terribly young, both in age and outlook. Just past 18, she's left her mother's hut and the care of her father, a farmer, to experience the world. (But: See goals.)2) She has helped fund the livelihood of what remains of her family through her witchcraft skills. She left nearly all of her years of savings behind to help her father, whom she treasures.3) Despite her youth and exuberance, she's remarkably skilled in getting along with others, as well as settling down disputes. She favors calm debate, and, if that fails, a frying pan to the back of a head.4) Not being a fool, she will present herself and her craft as a sort of 'hedge wizardry,' or herbalist  to strangers. Despite this, she is deeply proud of her studies, and has spent many, many hours listening to the secrets held within the songs of her familiar, a thrush.5) Her mother, Morgaise, and her mother's mother, were also witches. Her mother left the family when Selene was 8 in pursuit of her own goals. Her departure was not amicable among the family. The departure was glossed over to the best of Selene's father's ability among the communities they visited.Reasons for adventuring:1) The character is hunting down her mother, who left to join a coven of hags. Selene has heard vague, contradictory rumors of the types of damage this coven is doing. She sees it as her personal goal to end the group, and to either convince her mother to return, or take vengeance for those she's wronged. Selene is a bit fuzzy on what will actually happen when she finds her mother (as, again, she's inexperienced.) Unfortunately, Selene has no real idea where this coven is operating out of.2) The player would like a chance to watch the character develop. I'm not particularly interested in taking her into a dark and gritty place, at least not permanently. But it would be good to see an optimistic outsider try to establish her place in the world.Place in the world:1) Selene Paige keeps her witchhood secret, presenting herself as a hedge wizard or wise woman to anyone who asks. She's heard enough stories of scared villagers taking out frustrations on practitioners of the craft without really understanding what they are facing. [character known secret] 2) Selene's mother joined the coven under some duress, but she was never a particularly nice person: That was Selene's father, Rachel. How much Selene's mother regrets her decision is an open question. [character unknown secret] 3) [See people known, below] Selene is unaware that Lothos Marksbane argued passionately with Marcus Windfinder against racing ahead of the goblin raiding party, fearing the trio would be slain. During the congratulatory celebration later, Lothos swore a half-drunk Marcus to secrecy, something Marcus now deeply regrets. [character unknown secret]Friends and foes:1) Inquisitor Rodrick DelDemin has long trailed behind Selene. He suspects her of selling charms and curses linked to a slew of ill animals, stillbirths and failed crops, in part because of who her mother is. DelDemin is also a former adventurer partner of Selene's father, Rachel. As such, he won't commit to killing or capturing Selene until he's sure of her guilt. While DelDemin will not admit it, he wants Selene to be guilty.2) Lothos Marksbane is an archer of great skill, and a childhood friend. The pair, along with Marcus Windfinder, spent years traipsing the woodlands and territories surrounding her summer hut and getting into trouble with the local village elders. The trio discovered and warned a village of a raiding party of goblins, which earned each of them some renown.3) Marcus Windfinder is the second-best archer in the village, behind only Lothos. He spends his days bringing in game for the town, and his nights watching Lothos draw in eyes and ale in equal measure at the local tavern. The villagers who notice think Marcus, a plain-looking man, is jealous of Lothos's skill. Marcus, however, finds quiet doubt as to how honest his childhood friend really is.Personality quirks:Selene smoothes her shawl when nervous and widens her eyes when angry. She gets into music-mimic contests with her thrush when bored (which she loses. Badly.)She regularly carries a small frying pan, bound to a detachable rope tied to her belt. She refers to it as her 'iron logic.' While Selene is perfectly capable of being focused and on-task, if things are not actively urgent, her primary focus is exploration and discovery.Selene would most likely walk into the area of gameplay while searching for signs of her mother. She's not the kind of person who ignores others' troubles, so as long as there was some group actively seeking to solve whatever was taking place, she'd join in. Her reasonings: In part to help out, in part to earn her daily bread, but mostly for the excuse to discover more of the world around her.

For the brothers of the Monastery of the Yellow Rose, to ride the remorhaz is the ultimate test - a trial of agility, cunning, and the raw endurance necessary to withstand the beast's burning skin. As such, when a nest of Aarakocra fell betwixt the planes and surfaced on the White Worm's own head - and when, against all odds, one of these unlucky orphans actually survived the ordeal - the brothers took the child in without question. Only the Crying God could have brought such fate to pass.Hrrikke grew up slightly detached from the other monks, not least due to the suddenness with which his inhuman body matured. He grew and ascended the ranks rapidly as a scholar, but was prevented from mastery by an incomplete grasp of his own abilities. The Aarakocran body is simply not the same as a human's. He may have wasted away his potential, never passing the rank of Immaculate, had an expedition of penance not gone awry, leaving him stranded and alone for forty days and forty nights.By the time he returned, he had not only perfected his previously shaky martial arts, but also awakened to a primordial form of magic of his very own. The monks quickly agreed: this was beyond their grasp, as a group made - for the most part - by humans and for humans. The young Aarakocra learned best on his feet, without species-exclusive teachings to slow his progress down. They would have to entrust him to the care of the greater Church of Ilmater, and hope that the Crying God would reward young Hrrikke's continued sufferance in the outside world.Two years have passed since, and Hrrikke - now middle-aged by Aarakocran standard - has received some clerical training, and is considered a model servant of Ilmater. So much so, in fact, that he has been selected as part of an exclusive exchange program amongst the followers of the Triad. Now, he ventures forth alongside the clergy of Tyr and Torm, to introduce the light of Ilmater to the legendary Order of the Gauntlet.

His father a distinguished captain, and his mother a Lady of some repute, it was only fitting that Bairen himself ended up quite the dull young man. His youth was spent frittering away his allowance on bottle after bottle of ink for what he called ‘poems’, which mostly ranged from mediocre to dreadful. It was only after his mother stopped giving him gold in favor of glares that Bairen began to take life into his own hands, earning what spending money he could through practiced performance. He would have liked to believe that the poetry was what drew his crowds. Alas, more likely it was the brawl that would doubtless erupt once some poor local had had enough of his babbling. The boy couldn’t write to save his life, but he was a fine grappler.Perhaps he had some inkling of this, which led to his depression as he grew. Try as they might, his parents never quite managed to groom him into the noble sort; though his diction grew more genteel as time passed, his disposition remained as appealing as ever. That is to say, not quite. By his 30th birthday, his mother had finally given up on bequeathing the Kamelot inheritance upon her little Bairen. By his 35th, his father had given up patience. And so it was that Bairen came to find himself on the battlefield, packed off to a small mercenary band in the middle of nowhere, fighting a small local war he cared even less for than the rest of the world. The letter in his breast pocket told him not to come home until he’d learned to be proud, which confused him. He was incredible as people came, and none knew this better than Bairen Kamelot. His strength was ludicrous; his idiocy, much the same. But his comrades appreciated him, and in time, he came to reciprocate. He had never been trusted before, even to be a failure, but here he found allies who had no other choice. It was, in his life, the highest goods of his living times; so those last few missives said.Nobody knows what happened to the mercenaries Bairen first learned to trade drinks with. Nobody knows where his young daughter - Haato, she calls herself - came from. Certainly nobody knows how she got to the Kamelot estate, a year and a day from her father’s departure; or how she found her way inside, past the gate and the walls, to curl up at the foot of her grandmother’s bed; or how she did all that with a scroll in one tiny hand and a letter in the other.But the biggest mystery of all, they say, is about Bairen Kamelot himself. If he was with those mercenaries; if this is his daughter, as she claims; and if this letter truly is in Bairen’s own hand:Then when, where, how… Who or what could have taught him?For Bairen Kamelot has learned to write.

A homunculus created as a servant to an aging wizard, much of Unit SH3's early life was spent tending to the wizard's prized sheep, until the day the adventurers came.After that day, Unit SH3 continued to tend to the  prized sheep for about a week before returning to the keep to find it leveled. Discovering this, Unit SH3 proceeded to take a much larger portion of the flock than normal down to the village market, and set off into the wilderness with a small flock of its very own.Today, surviving members of Unit SH3's flock help carry some equipment for the band.

The daughter of a cleric, Hope was born quite pretty for a goblin, and treasured by her tribe as a potential interracial ambassador. These plans were crushed when the inhabitants of Cragmaw Keep were uniformly slaughtered by a band of gnomes known as Antimagic Inc., hired to investigate rumors of a corrupt wizard in Phandalin. However, she was saved by her father's contingency plan: a ritual that bound the souls of every goblin in the family to her own. Unearthly energy welled up inside her, helping her make a daring escape.Shortly afterwards, a certain guild mistress espied Hope fighting off a bear, and decided to offer her a job...
He was a teacher in a small town, then got recruited by a secret society to help defend from an evil secret society. Finally, he semi-retired as a bookstore owner and tutors other initiates.

In his childhood, Talebreaker was very fond of legends of the Giant gods of old, but often interrupted his elders. It took too long to grow out of it, he loved those fables so.In his youth, Pancrasher's tribe was subdued by pirates, and he spent his days serving as a drummer boy and occasional lookout for his captors, as they poached on the Sea of Moving Ice. In his seventeenth year, the young Goliath would suffer no more blasphemous slaughter, and dragged his captain into the waves for the Lord in Ice to judge. And the Eternal Sleeper smiled in his dreams, and the young boy rose up, and became Deepcrusher. The crusher in the deep.

Due to a traumatic experience as a child, Bojana was raised by the Battle Nuns of St. Lyrimin to be a Paladin of Iomedae. They cured her crippling PTSD by helping her suppress her fears under her martial training and religious teachings. Excelling with the sword and shield, Bojana wants to destroy the undead and hellish threats to Golarion by strength of arms, but must be careful not to uncover her traumatic past, or risk losing her mind.

Original Appearance:Kay is 5'9" tall, 140 pounds, with black-blue hair and glasses. In a work environment, he favors button down shirts and ties with semi-hidden star wars symbols on them. While trying to be comfortable, he tends to wear dark, loose-fitting clothing, usually while carrying a bag of carrot sticks or celery. On odd weekends, Kay is dragged out of his home by his older brother, Jay, to take part in mountain biking or paint ball events. While Kay vigorously protests going on these excursions, he finds they help him burn off a lot of his nervous energy, and keep him connected with his brother.Current Appearance: A member of the Yokai race, Kay has white hair and teal eyes, both of which he tries to conceal when visiting 'civilized' areas. He wears rough work gloves, a beginner set of greaves and breast plate, as well as an average cloak and a red knit cap. He uses the latter to hide his hair. He carries a simple scythe on his back, along with a longbow, both of which jut out above his 4'10"-tall frame.Pre-transformation Info:Kay is a 31-year-old corporate accountant, formerly of Wisconsin, most recently of Boise, Idaho. He spends most of his days tracking down tax-code errors and improving database cohesion. Needless to say, when the opportunity arrived to try a realistic-feeling game different life, he jumped at it.Kay has spent a number of years playing a variety of online games, including "World of Warppath" and "Ever Online." He has very limited experience, though, with the precursor full sensory dive systems that have become popular in recent years.Kay is a little surprised that his name got pulled as a winner, as he does not remember entering the contest. He suspects his brother, Jay, had something to do with it. That said, once he was notified he'd reached the semi finals a few months ago, he embraced the idea of exploring a VR world. He did, however, fill out a living will before arriving at the test center. He does not believe the kinds of trouble that happened two years ago will strike again, but it's always important to be prepared.Kay is definitely looking forward to spending a few hours of fun in the life of a barbarian, one who never has to worry about preparation or checking every detail twice, just to be sure. (The chance to vent a little of his nerd rage on a few helpless kobolds also sounds wonderful.)Background:Kay has an older brother, Jay, as well as an on-again, off-again girlfriend named Mary Sue Regionald. Mary, for reasons she refuses to explain, hates Star Trek, something Kay loves to tease her about. Kay's mother and father live in Florida, where they operate a bed and breakfast just outside Fort Walton Beach.Kay is happy with his life as an accountant, but feels like something is lacking. He finds both joy and stress when digging into the details at work: Joy at discovery and defeat of errors, and stress at the never-ending flow of labor, which rarely generates praise or much notice from outside the immediate work place.

An old shield dwarf whose love of abstract geometry led him to study the Weave. Stone is any dwarf's first love, but modern architecture cannot safely support the dimensions that he wishes to express. Magic has no such structural limitations.He had some adventures as he grew up, but eventually settled down and established a decently successful brewery to support an adopted child along with one of his former party members. They enjoy a platonic sedentary lifestyle.Klein has currently left his business in the hands of his family as he seeks out the culprit behind the mysterious death of an old friend.

Used as the sacrifice in a botched ritual to an elder god, damaging several key portions of his amygdala, and endowing him with eldritch powers. Thrall later discovers that the elder god is in fact dead, and the bleed-off of powers is slowly warping him into something like a mind flayer.Wavering without a clear purpose in life, Thrall attempts to summon an aspect of the god’s last desires. Having inherited the god’s essence, he instead splits off a portion of his own soul into a Sprite, who fulfills his wish for a companion who will always understand him.

Growing up in a city isn’t easy when you’re a tiefling. People are liable to attack you, either physically, through their words, or with small acts of passive aggression like raising prices or casting suspicious glances. By the time she was 10 years old, Dehlirhia had been arrested twice for something she hadn’t done, and while the true culprits were eventually found in both cases, she had been incredibly lucky that they were.    Her family - a single father and two brothers - were generally supportive of her, and they all generally helped each other survive off of whatever pay they could manage. When her eldest brother, Gaelen, was lynched for some crime he supposedly committed, the Axiom family silently agreed to spread out to have a better chance of surviving.    The somewhat well-respected Axeies, her father, stayed in the city and continued his job as an archivist of old tales and spells, while her younger brother Venaith moved to a smaller town, planning to make a living by selling magical ingredients. As for Dehlirhia, she decided that people were simply not for her, and moved to a secluded place out in the woods. She made a simple living there, hunting animals and occasionally selling the hide for a small amount of gold, which she would then use for small luxuries like soap and a heavier blanket. Usually, things were peaceful.    However, trouble did its best to find her, and during a particularly vicious attack Dehlirhia lost her old weapon - a simple axe - and gained several scars. She had intended to save what looked to be a stray cat from a pack of monsters, but instead ended up in the middle of a battle. Fighting one-handed with a cat in her other arm was not easy for her, and she had just about given up, assuming that the silvery mist beginning to cloud her vision was her life force fading.    And then she teleported up into a nearby tree along with the very confused cat.    As it turned out, the mist had in fact been a teleportation spell, not her last breaths, and the cat was in fact a rather awkward wood-elf druid. The two became friends simply due to having been in a life-threatening situation together, and when the druid eventually announced his intentions to leave the forest, Dehlirhia insisted on following him so that he “wouldn’t get himself killed”.

After drifting into a deep current during a tense battle against the sahuagin, Ouranos was nursed back to health by a family of merfolk en route to Myth Nantar. Finally, the young triton had found a family who truly required his services - and not long after, a god to whom to pledge his life. The next time he saw another member of his race, he had already adopted the title of Nantarath.A divine revelation drew Ouranos up to the surface, where he fought off a band of merrows attacking a ship flying the flag of the Gauntlet. There, he quickly befriended both captain and crew, and was strongly recommended to the Order upon arrival.

Physical Description: 5'8", 140 lbs, with brown eyes and dark blonde hair. Malcom favors simple tunics and rough pants; things he doesn't mind getting damaged as he wanders the woods. He does keep a, slightly stained, scholar's outfit in his backpack, for festival days or the rare visits to town.Background: Malcom grew up as a huntsman and occasional poacher in the woodlands near Duke Merci's summer manor. Malcom lost his father to a boar attack two seasons ago, when his arrow missed its mark, something he's still sore about. His mother weaves and raises bees, then sells what surplus she has at the local markets. Malcom has an older brother, Tomas, who handles the farmwork and has already inherited the land. His second-oldest brother, Ferrus, tends to the cow and several sheep to the best of his ability, which ranges from quite good to comically bad, depending on whether or not his leg is acting up.Malcom, following in his father's footsteps, hunted to bring in extra food for the family, as well as trade goods or tallow for candles. Since his father's death, however, Malcom sees that his family's needs are stronger than what the land can provide: It is obvious that they are one or two bad winters away from starvation and death. As such, he has set out to make his fortune, seeking better hunting in lands away from Duke Merci's control, or perhaps even treasure snatched from one of those rumored ruins he hears in the tales of bards. As well as he knows the uncharted lands, surely he can find his way to someplace long forgotten, and then safely home again.Personality: Dedicated. Untraveled. Has a deep respect for the learned, and wishes he was one.Animal Companion: "Meerkat," a Sunda Clouded Leopard (Big Cat animal companion). She is a sucker for dried Gecko strips, old boots to gnaw on, and lap time at inopportune moments. Malcom once trained Meerkat to pounce, sans claws, on any blanket rolls with red trim, as part of a prank on his middle brother. The trick stuck, but expanded to pouncing on Malcom when he's in deep sleep. Malcom now keeps a spare blanket specifically with red trim, to keep Meerkat occupied and happy at night.Additional notes:Boar spears were created specifically because boars are ridiculously dangerous; European nobility who hunted them were either bored (or boar-ed!), wanted a chance to prove personal bravery, or weren't too concerned about the staff (or some combination there-in). I was aiming to create the image of the classic rogue woodsman, rather than the more realistic hunter, the latter who'd be working with beaters, or who'd be on the watch for smaller game and quite possibly using traps.Malcom left to seek his fortune, specifically to help the family. I imagine that his relationship with his mother is good, and a little strained with the inheriting brother, in part because he is the inheritor, and in part because the inheritor isn't doing enough to see to the family's long-term future.I'd left both Duke Merci and the events surrounding his poaching past open, in part because I didn't want to overload the application, and in part because I was thinking to let that part of the story unlock as the game progressed. In my head, Duke Merci would be viewed as evil by Malcom -- he has land and refuses to let the commoners hunt on it. From Merci's viewpoint, he's performing medieval conservation efforts: He wants better hunts for himself, and knows there won't be enough game for him, or permitted hunters, if he allows his people to over-hunt the lands. I don't believe Malcom was ever caught, simply because he'd likely have lost a limb for the crime. There’d likely to be suspicion, though, especially on the local level.For a modern equivalent, I'd equate the poaching to moonshining: His family are the people you see if you want fresh meat, and the local law is overlooking it, either because the guards are also being supplied, are taking bribes, or have other things to worry about.(As a side thought: Depending on how prevalent monster attacks are in this world, armsmen/guards may not give a lot of thought to hunters heading out into the woods. If stepping in the wrong glen means vanishing for 30 years via a fairy ring or encountering a gnoll, poaching may be viewed as a 'self-correcting problem.')That said, if there's an interesting story to be had, I'm perfectly fine with the idea that one of Malcom's motivations was to get out of the region for a while to let the heat die down a bit after a deer hunt went bad. I'd prefer not to do a wanted man scenario with him, if for no other reason than it would be a detriment to other players' experience to have a hunted person stuck with them. But, I could easily see him wanting to avoid home until he has enough gold and influence to make any simmering problems go away.As far as childhood friends or Ferrus's leg injury, I was leaving those details open for discovery during game play. I know that Malcom can't be [I]too[/I] close with anyone, or he would have planned for a shorter journey, or talked a friend into coming. I also don't see him as having a girl who got away, mostly as I'm not interested as a player in pursuing that particular story arc. But these caveats wouldn't mean that he was an unlikable person, nor that he was antisocial growing up. The easiest solution is that he's independent minded, and likely wishes to solve his family's problems without dragging others into the mess (especially if, as was common for the era, his social peers are also subsistence living. With that being the case, a young body simply can't be spared from work to go out adventuring, unless the family in question simply can't support feeding everyone.)Personality for him is nebulous; I never really know who a character is until I sit down and run him for a bit. I know that he's been raised to view the law as a good suggestion, at best. I know that he'd have to be comfortable working on his own, as hunting can be an individual, or small group activity. I know that despite his time and resource constraints, he still made time to train up his animal friend to pull a long-term joke on his brother (which only mostly worked out for him.) I know he views family as very important, which would inform a good relation with most of them, as well as a need to protect, both of which would lean to a “Good” alignment type.So, he'd be a slightly lawless, self-sufficient type, one who'd likely think less of someone who couldn't handle themselves in the woods, as that's what he knows best. He's not humorless, and he will work hard for long-term goals. And he has a craving for knowledge: He carries a scholar's outfit, in part because he wants to dress as his ideal person, a person with wisdom or breadth of experience. His upbringing wouldn't have allowed him too much exposure to book learning, but he'd know enough to believe that all of the world's mysteries might be answered by finding the right sage or reading the right tome.If we're talking cooler climates, I'm happy to swap out gecko meat for something more accessible, such as owl or guinea. I was just fleshing out some details on the cat's personality.
