Character's class (rogue, wizard, cleric: Sage (Adjunct professor of humanities at Maine Maritime Academy)
Character's backstory: Appearance: Duke is a wiry fellow with dark hair and a thin goatee. He generally carries himself loosely, walking with confidence. He favors a brown corduroy jacket, which is worn over button-down shirts.Archetype: Sage (Doctorate in Literature [old English])Job/Profession: Dr. Duke Balfour teaches humanities to undergraduates at the Maine Maritime Academy. Balfour has been working as an adjunct professor there for the last two years while he finished his doctoral thesis, Body, Text and Self in Old English Verse: A Study of “Beowulfian” and “Cynewulfian” Rhetoric. On the weekends, he helps shepherd the academy's Small Watercraft Club's activities, to mixed results.Nationality/Languages: Duke has a U.S. nationality. He speaks, or at least reads, English, Old English, Middle English, Latin, Portuguese and French. He has an abiding love for French poetry, and is constantly collecting older, or rarer, works for his library. He very nearly wrote a thesis on Marceline Desbordes-Valmore's work. While the call of dusty libraries eventually won out, he has since published a number of academic analyses on her poetry.Back story: Born in Kansas, Duke Balfour was born the first child of three to Emily and Lucas Balfour, and grew up on in a small suburb outside Topeka, Kansas. Lucas taught mathematics at Topkea West High for decades. Emily took a medical retirement from the Coast Guard when Duke was six, after an accident at sea cost her the lower part of her right arm, directly below the elbow. Evenings at home consisted of hearing wild sea stories while diligently working simple mathematics problems. Weekends were spent on Kansas River, learning to read the water and general boat safety. As he got older, Duke began taking the boat out with fellow high school friends, which lead to a number of scraps between his fellows and some of the rougher sorts around the docks. While none of it was serious, it did spark an interest in self defense. Duke spent his sophomore and junior years learning to box at a local YMCA, before dropping the sport in his senior year to the combination of waning interest and limited time for extra hobbies. While Duke never mastered the higher-order mathematics to his father's satisfaction, his mother's wild sea stories, and both of their encouragement, eventually led him towards a career in academia, with a focus on the softer arts. Duke's siblings include a sister, Olivia, and Peter, the youngest of the family. Olivia has a degree in law enforcement, and recently started working in a Montana police department. Peter has just graduated from high school, and is at loose ends. Duke has dated off and on, most recently with a professor in the physics department, but has not yet made a solid connection. He does speak at least once a week with family, and emails more often. Peter visits Duke at the academy for a weekend every now and again.Temperament/Behavior: A confident dreamer. The combination of boxing during his youth, as well as overcoming rough waters and rougher weather, have left him with a general confidence in his ability to handle challenges. He knows he's not the toughest guy out there by any stretch, but he has already faced danger, and knows where his limits are. He has a general dislike of computers for anything more complicated than word processing or sending an email. He usually carries a book of some sort with him, wherever he goes, in case he gets bored. He walks whenever possible. Duke has heard every single John Wayne reference imaginable, and hates all of them. He's not big into movies: He prefers being active, or spending time among the comforts of the archives and rare book collections.Supernatural experience: Walking back late at night from a weekend sailing event, Duke noticed an unusual glow coming from the waters near a crag. Curious, he half-climbed, half-skid his way down to the edge of the Atlantic, where he found nine glowing lights just under the surface of the water. The yellow lights faded, leaving three blue-green lights, which almost immediately shifted to seven red dots. The ocean air blew in strong at that moment, which forced Duke back on his heels. As he regained his balance, he saw five purple lights wink out of existence. Getting cold, he made his way home. The following day, he revisited the site, to see if he could see anything. When he arrived at the bottom of the crag, he found a strange plant growing out of the water, with knots grown in odd patterns throughout the stem. When he reached in to touch it, for a moment he lost his hearing altogether, and a shine of iridescent light flowed through the veins of the weed, before settling into the knots. The plant now sits, alive, in an aquarium in Duke's office, while he tries to discover what type of plant it is, and why he saw what he did.

A failed squire who, frustrated at the loss of his hundredth duel, blamed the blacksmith for creating a faulty sword and blasphemed against the honor of the forge. For his insolence, Calusar was struck down by an apparent agent of the blacksmith’s god; he unexpectedly survived, but was cursed to serve the surprised blacksmith until further notice.Despite his initial resistance, Calusar came to understand the blacksmith’s dedication, and even began to enjoy working at her side, and seeing the efforts that went into masterpieces he could never dream of creating. As such, when another unsatisfied customer came by – a knight who had twisted his wrist on the battlefield – the young squire lost his temper and challenged the knight to a duel. His patron, pleased with this development, granted him the ability to pour the strength of his own emotions into his weapon; and though it broke in the end – he was not yet a true smith himself – he won the duel handily.With that, the blacksmith’s honor was restored, but Calusar, having challenged and defeated a knight, drew the ire of the local nobility. In order to avoid damaging the smithy’s business, he bargained with his patron to change the nature of his sentence, and left town bound to carry out his patron’s whims.

Mika was an anomaly in their small farming village when they were born - a half elf with innate magic in a village of humans. Quickly decried as the bastard child of an unfaithful mother, Mika’s mother gave them to the leader of the village, an exiled noble who saw the potential to further their own schemes in Mika’s innate powers. The noble raised the child to believe in a made-up harvest deity named Pieri, and to also view themselves as nothing more than an extension of this deity. Over time, they were taught to call themselves Pieri as well, and to view all other deities as inferior and dangerous due to events in the story of deity-Pieri. They grew up into a religious zealot whose idea of evangelism was “convert or die - for your own good” - just as the noble had planned. The noble then set Pieri out on the countryside. Their plan was to let Pieri wreck havoc on the countryside, only for the village to step in and provide aid (and surreptitiously take over in the process). If people actually converted, then that was another way to take power. If anyone in power took notice, the village would then step in and take Pieri down, knowing their weaknesses and all. Then they would get quite the boon for taking down such a dangerous fanatic - and the noble would have a base of power to work off of.The plan worked, except for one small detail - the noble vastly underestimated Pieri’s power. Eventually, someone did call for the destruction of Pieri, but when the village sent soldiers out, they were decimated. Enraged by their home sending forces against them, Pieri made their way back and burned the village. After that, they mostly disappeared, occasionally resurfacing to enact their particular brand of evangelism. Now flying under the radar, Pieri gained even more power - until the world began unraveling around them. Due to wider world events Pieri had been unconcerned with, the entire plane was falling apart. They sought shelter in a remote desert town under the protection of a demigod druid; the town would soon become the only remaining place on the Material Plane, held together by the druid’s willpower alone.Parties of the plane’s most powerful heroes were sent out as the plane unraveled - but all of them were doomed, never to return. Finally, there were only six “heroes” left - including Pieri. And so they set out with the others, the Material Plane’s last hope for survival.

Her parents were sailors but she got seasick easily, so had to stay on land. She stayed with her grandparents, but was much taller than them and kept bumping into things as she got older. One day she stumbled into an inn in need of a barmaid/cook. She loved cooking above all else, so applied and got the position, that alsp came with a room off of the kitchen. She then fell in love with the innkeeper's son, and they eventually got married and ran the business. They had a few kids and everything was dandy until a disaster struck the town. Hordes of undead were shambling toward the town. She happened o be shopping at the time in the market, so she immediately started herding people into the local church. Almost everyone was inside except one small child. She threw herself on top of the child and prayed, then got a divine blessing of clericdom. After the event, her children were all adults and helping her husband run the inn, and she felt called to travel and help others as her parents had done. She makes sure to write and travel back whenever possible, but she is now a healer and protector of the nearby towns.

The fact of the matter is, some kids don't get to go to Wizard School.Rochia was born in a slum outside of a large city, and promptly abandoned in a dumpster. Too homely to be adopted by some benevolent noble and too alien to be picked up by the average orphan gang, he was instead picked up as an experimental subject for the local hospital. They called him "roach" for his seemingly miraculous survival, no matter what they did. He was understood to be useful for testing new surgical techniques or medicines for several years, until small tremors and strange sounds began to manifest in his immediate vicinity. He was dropped back out onto the streets with the vague understanding that magic had helped him somehow; and so he came to take an interest in the magic users of the city.Wizard school is expensive, class-restrictive, and a full-time job; completely outside of Rochia's reach. He instead took up odd jobs at anywhere he could have chances to be close to the city-dwellers, and took his time becoming a familiar, uninteresting sight. Bathing was right out; the dust hid his reddish scales well. Never raise your head, never meet any eyes, never surpass mediocrity in any way: this was his mantra. In this way, he managed to steal arcane secrets for almost a decade before being caught, taking time to add each eked-out spell to his mental toolbox.Rochia meets the party soon after fleeing for his life from the only place he's ever known. He carries with him the fruits of years of contingency plans, set into motion over the course of a week: a full set of stolen adventuring equipment, and more gold than he knows what to do with. Driven by desperation, he offers any service he can to the mighty-looking group, if only they'll take this miserable little urchin along with them.

Charmed her way into the Guild of Alchemists & Apothecaries at a young age and worked her way up.Very good at her job, and a popular conversationalist at guild parties, but for reasons which totally have nothing at all to do with racism, she doesn’t work at the front desk. Fascinated with the inherent dissatisfaction of the sapient condition, she studies how chemistry may improve it for individuals. An ancestor of hers, tired of being a tiefling, permanently infused the family bloodline with dragon essence by unknown means -- and yes she's certain it wasn't by mating -- so solving that mystery may go some way toward her goal.

Llewellyn was born in the sprawling ramshackle slums outside the walls of Macropolis. Unlike most of his peers and his parents, Llewellyn is literate, havingreceived a better than average education from the free school run by the monks of the Hand In the Flame cult. When he was twelve, he was apprenticed to his uncle's glovemaking shop, and fully expected to follow both his uncle and father into the garment business. However, in his late teens, he had a life-changing encounter with an itinerant festival mage, who convinced Llewellyn to leave off glovemaking. What followed was nearly 40 years of tedious and oft-regretted servitude as a student-scholar and steward to the Mage's Council, located in the Office of the Seven Towers. Now, after his retirement from the civil service, Llewellyn has struck out on his own as a sellspell, always hungry for the one big job that will allow him to buy his way into the landed gentry.

She seemed the ideal warrior. Her agility was remarkable; here was one who truly felt how to dance with the blade, coursing like water around her opponents' attacks. Belying that seeming lightness, her magic was incredible; with a flick of her hand, she could clear vast swathes of a battlefield at once, a force of nature unto herself. And even when that arcane might ran out, she would never falter, pushing her way through her foes like a wildfire on its inexorable path of destruction.If only she wasn't so damned mysterious.Styl Neinarte was the perfect Eladrin warrior in every aspect but one, in that she didn't seem like a very good Eladrin. She never wept at the beauty of the stars; she never lost her temper in a brawl for dominance; she never even threw her hat in the air in celebration at the conclusion of the day's training. It was unnatural, was what it was. Like some kind of stone-faced shadow from beyond the moon, Styl was always simply... there. And then there's the matter of those eerie new spells she was experimenting with. What were her classmates supposed to think? Steinheart, they called her. If we're all being honest here, I have to agree. That girl just isn't right.It couldn't be helped. There was simply no way we could send her out into our society like that - not if she never learned to let loose, like a real fey fighter, show everyone the color of her blood and laugh it off for once - you understand, don't you? That is not how things are done. Not at this institution. So, well, we had to make her... disappear.Oh, don't look at me like that. No, no, she can come right back, after she's grown up a bit. You know how it is, with these younglings. A few beatings out there, a human or two she can raise and care for until it dies - do her a world of good.Give it a century or two, she'll come right around. You watch.Nothing like the proper fey way to solve a problem child.

A mid-autistic daughter of a new-money noble family, born with access to the best private tutors. Kannadi acquitted herself well in academics and magic, but her talents were spent running much of her family's accounting.One day she inspected her family's newest holding, a salt flat relatively unexploited due to it being a nesting ground for monsters. The mercenaries she employed to clear it out were killed to a man, not by local fauna but the archfey Nacil, the self-proclaimed Crystal Dame, Dehydrated Duchess, Lady of Salt, et cetera. Nacil would have killed Kannadi too, but found her mind so fascinating she offered a pact so that she might realize her true potential. Kannadi agreed on condition that her family alone could (carefully) harvest the flat.

Pen is a merchant with dreams of power and wealth and a willingness to do just about anything to get it. Their mercantilism started in basic trade goods - primarily food and raw materials - but he quickly expanded into black market goods, most frequently magical items and artifacts of questionable origin. With the death of his grandfather, he inherited a set of magical stones, unlike anything else known to the Three Nations, that his grandfather had supposedly found on an uncharted island after a shipwreck. Determined to find the source of the stones and secure a monopoly, Pen signed up to become part of a ship’s crew.

Syprinn Rubrofuscus, cheerful enough to go by her juvenile name "Meteor" if you're her friend, loved history and hated how much of it lay forgotten.Her greatest desire was to uncover hitherto-forgotten secrets, to remember for those who can't and preserve for those who can, but archaeology doesn't come cheap. She attached herself to whatever expeditions she could in the hopes of building up more connections and gathering funding. One day her expedition discovered a forgotten temple. She stood in the wrong place and touched the wrong thing, and found herself chosen by the temple's god to defend others in their name.The decision wasn't hers, but knowing the need that she could fill, she accepted it regardless. Now she balances service with education and exploration, not exactly enthusiastically when it comes to holiness. She has something of an eye-rolling relationship with her patron, humoring them for the power to better learn and serve and protect rather than worshiping them on their own merits.

So, he hails from a small tribe of Ghostwise halflings who lived under a mountain pass, on the border of the Underdark, known as the Crystalline Clergy. They believe that their ghostly blue eyes and their limited telepathic capabilities (Silent Speech) are gifts from sharing the heritage of a Sapphire Dragon who once ruled this area of the Underdark; and in thanks for this, they worship the god of the gem dragons, Sardior of knowledgeA group of adventurers from the Surface (I've taken to the name "The Primordial Heart", but whatever works) went on a mission to assassinate the Elder Brain of the nearest illithid colony, and didn't do so hot. They fled, and stumbled upon the Crystalline Clergy, hiding and resting outside of the village to discuss their options; the mind flayers caught up to them, which they figured out when they started seeing halflings dropping from psychic blasts. In the ensuing battle, they rebuffed the mindflayer attack, but most of the village was destroyed. They picked up the first halfling they'd seen fall, and ran, fearing a cave-inBetween guerilla attacks from various other Underdark beasts and simple lack of supplies, they weren't in any shape to take care of their halfling ward, so when they got to the Surface, they made a deal with a local Druid to heal him and their party rogue, who seemed to have gone down on the way out; then, they left to wherever they came from, whoever had sent them on that quest, to lick their wounds and have their own continuing adventuresThe halfling was nursed back to health, but the extended period of time without treatment made some of the damage too severe; he couldn't remember his name or identity, and he could no longer comprehend Common, which put him in a dark place for a bit. The Druid eventually turned him around to a greater appreciation of nature, with a major breakthrough being when the Druid realized that always taking him out into the sun didn't make him listen - it was night, another of Sardior's domains, that made the halfling appreciate the beauty of the worldThe halfling took a new name from the phrase the adventurers had left - they wanted the druid to heal their 'canary in the mines', so he became "Canary (Temporary)". He became accustomed to the Surface, interacting with Surface animals, and began returning to books again to get a better hold of more languages.The sad thing about the Underdark is that it has a lot of horrible things, like Intellect Devourers, which eat your brains and possess your body. This is what had happened to the Primordial Heart's rogue, who had also been left with the Druid for healing; which is why Canary had to fight off a powerful assassin puppeted by an aberration with the help of the old druid; which is why, at the end of the fight, the old druid died, and Canary had nothing to do but seek out the rest of the Primordial Heart.At first, he didn't really know what he was doing - it was just a goal to follow. But, as he tracked them, he started noticing more and more destruction in their wake, and began to suspect that more than one member of the party had been replaced by an Intellect Devourer, in the mad dash for the Surface; and that said devourer may be capable of reproduction.So that's where Canary's at, headspace wise. Short term goal, hunt down and destroy aberrations nearby. Long term goal, seek out the Primordial Heart, if necessary kill the Devourer(s?) in their midst, and gain closure for everything that happened to him and his village. Life goal, learn every language there is, so that someday, even without the Common tongue at his disposal, he could impress Sardior with the strange knowledge and story of his life.

Xandor Undoviel is an elven ranger from Dernall Forest on the island of Alaron, which belongs to the Moonshae Isles. He has been well-trained to fight against the goblin hordes that infest his forest home. As a young man he took on forester duties, but soon after reaching adulthood at 100 years, he joined a group of human and elven rangers called "The Righteous Arrow", which is led by the human ranger Dorn Strongbow and which wages war against the goblin infestation, often in cooperation with a group of druids called "The Sacred Circle".Dorn has taken Xandor under his wing and become his mentor. Xandor is also close friends with Thia Siannodel, a young half-elf ranger who is also a member of the Righteous Arrow. She and Xandor may have deeper feelings for each other but have never acted on those feelings. Finally, Xandor has become good friends with Benjen Snowraven, a human fighter who washed up on the shores of Alaron one day and joined the Righteous Arrow after being nursed back to health by the group.Less than a month ago, Dorn spotted a dragon cultist in Alaron. Intrigued, Dorn followed the cultist to Caer Callidyrr and watched her board a ship to Baldur's Gate. Leaving behind a message for Xandor that promised a quick return but unfortunately did not reveal his motivations, Dorn boarded the same ship to track the cultist to the mainland. But Xandor began worrying when Dorn had not yet returned to Alaron after two weeks, and he decided to search for him. Docking with a ship in Baldur's Gate, Xandor quickly discovered secret ranger signs that Dorn had left behind and tracked him through the Wood of Sharp Teeth to the Uldoon Trail in the Greenfields, but still hasn't found him.Xandor is an intellectual, logical, quiet person that doesn't easily show his feelings; this can be interpreted as coldness or aloofness but in actuality he has a lot of compassion and always tries to do the right thing. Through his experience in the Righteous Arrow where humans, elves, and half-elves work together against the goblins, and the broader cooperation he's seen across Alaron including dwarves, gnomes, and halflings, Xandor realizes the benefits of diversity and is not biased against other races. He is less familiar with exotic races such as dragonborn, tieflings, and githzerai, as they are very rare in Alaron, but he has read about them and is fairly open-minded toward those who are different.He wants to learn about the Sword Coast's geography, cities, races, and lore because the land is new to him. In the early morning hours after his trance, he likes to read books about Faerûn's history while the other party members are still asleep. He recalls the maps later with a photographic memory. Within the party, he favors the role of scout: stealthily preceding his companions on the lookout for traps, tracks, and enemies. If he discovers something, his job is to forewarn the party rather than engage alone. When the fighting starts, he prefers to keep his distance from the enemy and fire his crossbow. In battle, he favors a well-planned rather than spontaneous approach. He refuses to kill helpless enemies or torture them.He wants to help others and make the world a better place. To do that, he feels compelled to continuously improve himself in order to become "the perfect ranger". And to do that, he must enhance his skills and equip himself with the ideal items (discovered in books and from other people). In towns he visits, he often asks around about such items. He's also interested in learning rogue skills — not what he considers the "negative" ones like stealing, backstabbing, and assassinating — but the "positive" ones like discovering and disabling traps and picking locks. These are meant to complement his outdoor ranger skills with similar indoor skills that enable his party to proceed in its missions unimpeded and unharmed.Around his neck on a leather cord, as a memento, Xandor keeps a fang from the first worg he ever killed. He plays the flute proficiently but usually when others aren't around to hear. He has an idiosyncrasy where he often employs other people's full names and titles in everyday conversation.

Olon, born with a club foot and abandoned by his birth mother, was raised in an orphanage not far from Pwyll, and was indentured to the Yellow Wizard at the age of seven. Now at the ripe old age of 22, Olon has broken his contract, stolen his master's spell book, and hit the road. Only his closest companions know any of this, and to the general public, he is simply "The Ormolu Kid."

High-spirited magic-endowed huntress of a certain age, youngest of six half-elf daughters (born to a youngest-daughter human who married an elf for political reasons). Currently happily single after three husbands and four daughters of her own: twins Alphae and Betrys (quarter-elf, 26), Gamwynn (half-dwarf, 24), and Deltine (tiefling, 22).Surprisingly not disowned by her fabulously well-to-do old-money family because, well, she did produce children, and all of them have invariably increased family connections by marriage.With few responsibilities now that her children are grown, Orona is completely free to indulge in her loves of politics and adventure, in the name of the wonderful society which gave her so much.

The tiefling’s mother died upon childbirth; the father, long ago. The baby was a burden. Other residents of the slums harvested her horns (massive), and disposed of the excess child in the river. Had some nixies not been looking for toys downstream, this tale would end here. They called her Sanguine, the bloody child; but a happy one too, it seemed. An amusing toy indeed.The nixies picked her up, at least; it’s no fun to drown something that’s already drowning. She clung to them, and was used as a prop in and, as she grew, allowed to help in, the nixies’ many pranks. When they left her on her own, she learned survival; when they brought her along, deception; and when they stayed with her, play. A rounded upbringing.She explored more her own path as she grew. soon dipping in and out of the city, nicking trinkets for her caretakers’ amusement and learning the ways of the slums. And she explored the water as well, looting the corpses the nixies left behind and the debris of the city. It was one such foray that caught her in an undercurrent, straight into the mystic domain of Sarula Iliene. An unexpected chance.The Nixie Queen was, if not welcoming, gracious; and her Sylvan accent did her well. She received a task, in exchange for power: to be her Queen’s eyes and ears among the commoners, to watch the flow of the land and report Sarula Iliene’s place in it. As for proof of her loyalty… the horns and hair she’d been growing out, pride of any common tiefling, did nicely. Sanguine left Sarula Iliene’s realm with head lightened, and life renewed. A successful pact.Recently, she’s noticed a change in the flow of the streets. Rumor has it that the fates are at it again; that adventurers are gathering, even in the backwaters nearby. She sets out to investigate…

Reese worked as a Ranger at a nature reserve in the savannah and desert, giving him an expertise in more feline-like wildlife. He worked with his close friend, Ger Many, to help make the world a better place. One day, Ger Many goes missing and he sets out on a quest to find him.

Varyik is smart and adventurous, so she was a scout for her kobold clan--going outside their warrens to search for scavenging opportunities. One night, as she was exploring a new, strange human structure that had appeared by the side of a nearby river, the humans returned unexpectedly, forcing her to hide among the crates and boxes. Then the room began to lurch and sway. Days passed, and the humans didn't leave the structure, so Varyik couldn't sneak away. Eventually, the structure stopped moving and most of the humans left, but when Varyik made her way carefully outside that night--her mountain was gone! Now a kobold without a clan, Varyik scavenges battlegrounds and junkyards, hoping to somehow find her way back home, despite having no idea where she is or where home was.

Angie was born in a small farming village and showed unusual (explosive) magical potential at a young age. At 9, she was apprenticed (sold) to someone who could teach (handle) her -- the master of the Sea-Bone Tower, a powerful wizard and necromancer (?) who began to explore her potential. In addition to training her magical abilities (and bringing the explosions under her direction, if not always control), she also studied the lives of the greatest of wizards (pulp serials, and the odd smutty magical romance). Now that she has been graduated (released), she has set her sights on becoming a world-famous witch.

I set out to adventure from the City of Schools.  Fresh out of the academy, my merry band of dwarves were enlisted to explore some infested caverns far to the south. We were ambushed by a band of kobolds who had been terrorizing a local village, but we beat them back.  We tracked them to their lair and flooded it with water from a nearby reservoir.  Our mission to the caverns ended in tradgedy with the loss of several of our company and without much gain in the ways of stories, treasure, or experience.Several weeks later we blundered our way into trying to infiltrate a thieves guild.  Without much in the way of deceptive qualities, we were quickly discovered in our mission and an all out war ensued on the streets for control of the city.  We eventually prevailed and took over the local thieves guild building.  We repurposed the building as an inn and trading hub.  This new hub brought many new characters to the town, including a troop of gypsies circus performers with mysterious demeanors and trinkets.  During this time we also sold our services to a local merchant who had been losing shipments to his warehouses to the southwest.  We loaded up in a boat and proceeded to travel to his warehouses to investigate the situation. No sooner than having stepped ashore, than we were beset by giant rat men with swords whom our weapons did little to slow.  We fought our way through the mass of rats to a nearby building, barricaded ourselves inside, and took some time to rest, heal, and formulate a new plan of attack.  With little time, our only option was to clear out the infested buildings.  We foolishly set fire to the warehouses and we did manage to clear out the infestation of were-rats.  Unfortunately, it also destroyed what was left of the merchant's property and sent him into bankruptcy and destitution and meant that we could no longer expect payment for clearing out the rats.The most significant occurrence is when our band was called back to the stronghold of our youth.  Great earthquakes had broken open sealed tombs in the royal crypts and the stronghold was under attack from trans-dimensional armies.  We returned home and made our way to the crypts with magic scrolls to seal them up.  We entered the tombs and found mud creatures coming out of the walls and stealing treasures from the dead.  A battle ensued in which I picked up the armor and axe of a great dwarven king from ages past.  We battled the creatures and managed to seal the tombs from intruders.  I then returned to the stronghold and, using the appeal of the relics I now wielded, I raised an army to perform a sneak attack  on the besieging army outside our walls.  We crushed their resistance and they fled back to their own dimension.  After the battle though I was confronted by the current king of the stronghold. I would not relinquish my new relics that I was now weilding for I believed myself to have been chosen to lead a crusade against our enemies and to crush those that stood against us.  The king banish our group from our home and we returned to our lives at the inn and trading post and had many more adventures from there.

The earliest clear memory that Angelica Jones had was of sitting beside the mill pond and watching a frog slowly die. Her mother owned the mill, and the land along the river, in a farming community a thousand miles from the sea. She was the third of four living children, nearing nine years old in the spring, and a child like any other – by turns willful, curious, shy, laughing, angry, or any of the other moods that fill a child’s life. But today it was calm, and she had been skipping stones across the waters when a swift movement caught her eye. A snake lunged and bit at a bullfrog, and Angelica flung the stone in her hands, striking the snake in the side and startling it away. It disappeared in the grasses along the bank, and she forgot it as she knelt to watch the frog struggle. The frog kicked weakly, coordination gone as it bled in the mud. Then it only spasmed, then twitched, and then was still, even when Angelica poked at it.That was when she first heard her master’s voice, a long slow sigh in the still air. Would you burn? it asked, and she said aloud, “Yes.” And the frog was burning, and the grass was burning, and Angelica shouted in alarm and excitement and stamped out the thin flames amid the grasses and the greasy smoking frog, and because there are few things as dangerous as a fire near a grain mill, she had nearly forgotten everything but her fear by the time she ran back, out of breath.The next day she had a fight with another girl, and when she shouted, it was with a voice like thunder, and the fire was there, and that was another set of clothes ruined and another scolding. It grew from there, the growing flame inside her and the damage around her, the fear on the faces of the other children and the worried set of her mother’s mouth as she was beaten. Then came the knock on the door, late at night, and her master had come for her.A woman in tattered black stood on the doorstep, holding her hand out for Angelica. She was tall – too tall, inhumanly tall, bent down to reach for a child’s hand. She was bald, and her skin was a waxy yellow and spotted with age, and she smelled like damp earth and sweet rot, and Angelica didn’t care in the least as she was lifted up and held close. They traveled through the night, through cold empty air and tunnels of dirt, through places that chimed like bells as the moonlight twisted around them, and places where the slightest breath was a shriek. When morning came, she was home.The sunrise revealed an ivory spire, the Sea-Bone Tower, built from the bones of whales and leviathans, the teeth of squids and sharks. It also revealed the first of her sisters, Muire and Tess. They were also students and apprentices here; they hugged her and called her Angie, and made her welcome. Muire was the oldest, an elf wrapped in vines of holly, a soft-spoken historian and mentor. Tess was in the middle, a human with dyed pink hair, a poisoner and a friend. Angie was the youngest, completing the trio as she began her training.The first year was for learning, more than Angie had ever had before. Muire taught her history and politics, the names of figures known and unknown, maths and logic and rules of magic and scholarship. Tess taught her the thirteen classical poisons, anatomy and dissection and the secrets of life and death, blood and pain. Her master visited only infrequently, but taught her to call the fire in her veins and to strike with it. Muire also taught her the joy of reading, whispering softly aloud the fanciful tales of handsome witches and ages of adventure as they lay in bed feigning sleep. Tess taught her to run, and to cook, and held back her hair when she vomited out one of the fouler potions. And at the end of the year, when her master died in the dead of winter, Angie burned the old black rags in the fireplace where they held their vigil and waited for the master to return.The second year was for magic. Muire taught her runes and sigils, binding, cursing, and haggling. She also gave Angie the first volume of the chronicles of Tabitha, and showed her the secret corners of the library where the smutty tomes of dubious historical accuracy were tucked away. Tess helped her carve her first wand, and learn to see the glitter of magic, to tell a ward from a blight, and a charm from a curse. She also taught Angie to lie with a straight face, and helped pick up the pieces when she was caught. This was the year her master first killed her, passing her the bowl of poison and laying her on the table, catching back a piece of her death when that first new gasping breath again filled her lungs.In the spring of the third year, Muire left. They all cried together, and held a celebration with cakes and a far-too-good wine, and swore to be sisters forever. Before she left, she gave Angie a broom bound in iron, and made her promise to learn to fly it, and Angie instantly and forever forgave her for growing up tall and beautiful and swore that she’d only remain a little bit jealous. Some weeks later, her master left and returned with a new charge for them. Her name was Crane, and she was bleeding and fearful and would speak only a whisper when they met. Tess was the oldest now, and her skills could be turned to healing, and so she cleaned and bound the wounds while Angie cooked and drew a bath, and they learned of Crane’s slavery in the gladiator pits. Together, they were agreed – Tess would teach her how a woman fights, and Angie would help unlock the magic in her blood, and they would make her a great witch and a sister.At the height of that summer, their master gathered the three girls on the slopes in front of the tower in the early morning light. She spoke a grand spell and split open the air to let forth a torrent of salty water and a monster, summoning thirty feet of whale to a place that had never seen the sea. She bade them to kill it, and clean the bones, and prepare the flesh. For three days they worked without pause, surrounded by blood and fat and viscera. Tess brewed potions to chase fatigue and strengthen tired arms. Angie cut and sawed, with blades as large as she was and knives as small as her finger. Crane cooked and boiled and salted, casting wind to disperse the ceaseless crowding flies and throwing gobbets of flesh to the watching coyotes and foxes in the night. And at the end, they drowned Crane in a vat of blood and oil, to separate her spirit as they reshaped her flesh. And for all that they complained of the monotony, few things ever tasted as sweet as the whale steaks they ate afterwards.The fourth year passed in a blur. Crane grew taller than Angie, which was hardly fair when she was a senior witch to the other girl, but it couldn’t be helped. She studied more magic, learning to call other powers through the fire inside her, and to lend her power to others. She conjured with Tess while the other witch summoned ghosts, and she read with Crane, teaching her to study and learn. When her master died at the end of the year, Angie washed and oiled the body, while Tess whispered the secret name in her master’s ear.In the fifth year, for a short time they were four. The master of the tower brought them a young girl, covered in pox, one eye milky white and the other crudely sewn shut. They sat with her through the sickness, bathed away her sweat and cut open her eye to pack the socket with healing moss. Her name was May, and with her arrival, Tess’s smile grew thin and edged. One night, Tess came with her pack of poisons to say goodbye, leaving Angie with a brace of ritual daggers and a promise that they would be sisters forever. And then Angie was the oldest of the three witches.She dueled with Crane on the lawn, swirls and arcs of magic leaping back and forth between them. She sat with May while the other girl learned another sight, tearing open the veils of the past and future. She showed Crane the secret corners of the library, and they laughed together over the ridiculous romantic witches and their adventures, while vowing to have their own adventures one day. She taught May to cook, and May taught her to make tea, and they both fed Crane when she would forget her meals.  They were sisters together, and though she knew she would eventually leave, she loved them.As the time grew nearer, she made for Crane a goad, a wand and weapon and mark of authority all in one. For May she sewed a cloak, heavy and soft and weighted like the warmth of a hug. For herself she made a tall hat, and found a set of tall boots, because she wasn’t going to be this short forever, not if she could help it. And when her master told her there was a new world, and a ship to sail her there, Angie knew this was the start of her adventure. She would be a great witch, and make her sisters proud.
Grumpy old cat-person, pharmacist, occasional adventurer

Book was forged to manage the library of a great wizard, a duty he faithfully performed for 100 years.  One day, the wizard vanished.  Decades (centuries?) later, after he had read all the books, he decided to explore the countryside surrounding the castle, returning each night to tend to his duties.  Eventually he wandered too far and the castle became lost to him.  Book began to lurk at the edge of the villages he would come across, trying his best not to be seen.  One day he came across a village being terrorized- by raiding kobolds, or a starving owlbear, or a power-mad undead dwarven tax collector (it was so long ago it really no longer matters)- and, inspired by many of the stories of heroism and bravery he had read and re-read, he stepped in and saved the townsfolk.  Now he happily wanders the countryside, visiting all the villages he comes across, no longer lurking but making friends, sharing fantastic stories, and offering help where he's needed most.

Disylgi was born on a goat farm and lost their three parents at a young age; their elder sibling took over the farm and they helped out until an unfortunate incident involving goats turning into demons. After this, they worked a while in the Dwarf King's treasuries before experiencing the call to become a paladin of the protector goddess, protecting a holy relic of healing. After several years of devoted service, Disylgi discovered their order was corrupt and preventing the poor from accessing the relic. They set up a system to bypass this. Unfortunately, it was stolen. Disylgi was stripped of rank and duties, flogged, and thrown out of the Order. They proceded to get very drunk and attempt retail therapy, but ended up buying a cursed necklace, and it was in this sorry state they encountered their future companions in a bar.

Leanora was born to a single human mother in the lower class of the city of Nathe. Her mother died in a plague when a con man sold her a fake cure to the disease. Leanora survived the sickness, and the con man, an elf named Baldan, noticed her nimble hands, and took some pity on her situation. Baldan took Leanora in and trained her in how to steal, charm, and con her way into a quick buck. Despite being her mentor, Baldan's pity only extended so far and he was not an affectionate figure in Leanora's life. Leanora did not realize this for most of her young life, until the pair got in a little too deep into trouble during a con. The two got caught and arrested. During her interrogation, Leanora realized that Baldan would sell her out to save his own skin if given the opportunity, so she beat him to the punch. She put all the blame on him, escaped, and got the hell out of dodge. Left with very little money even after their cons, due to a gambling habit, Leanora now found herself directionless. She turned to a life of adventuring to see if she could use her talents for a good cause for once, or accomplish anything meaningful with her life.

Once, a tiny child desperately wanted to play with fire. And storms. And the sea itself. This wasn't really a problem; they lived in an island fishing village that always needed sea witches, their uncle was a sea witch already. Unfortunately, unbeknownst to Brégevic - an only child - their mother was the last in a secret bloodline. They had been exiled from their home country hundreds of years ago, as members of a forbidden order of lorekeepers, and she wanted Brégevic to continue the tradition.Brégevic preferred consorting with the elements. After thoroughly wrecking their relationship, she gave in. Brégevic became a very competent, but very reckless sea witch. When they were twenty-five, they were approached in a bar by a fish person asking them to help a ship navigate the sea long past the season it should have been possible. They agreed, and the fish person sent them on their way and wiped their memory of the encounter.The voyage was a disaster; they limped into Brégevic's home village, halfway through the crossing, and many told them to winter there. It would be foolhardy to press on. Brégevic insisted. The ship set out, and was wrecked.Brégevic washed up on shore alone, the only survivor. They fled south, taking casual work as a dock hand despite their physical frailty, their confidence gone. They didn't contact their family again, too ashamed to admit their mistake. Eventually, they met several other misfit transients and decided to set up a private investigation enterprise together, and Brégevic slowly regained confidence in their skills.

"BANG. BANG *crashhh*!BANG BANG. BANG *crashhh*!"The lorekeepers of G'mkaugh Caverns watch the children of the tribe very closely. They heard Thashk's drumming potential by the way he would synchopate with a piece of bone for hours, and his cleverness in using jokes and antics to stop the bigger children from beating him.Now he has come of age, become tall and broad-shouldered, and taken the less-traveled path of the initiated bard: he ventures into the wide world, gathering lore, telling tales of orcish ferocity, and learning the war-beats of the other races as he serves in whatever mercenary army will pay him for his drum, and his long, bladed berimbau.He has just finished a tour, and spent a lot of that bloodied gold on ale and company. This tavern's regulars have grown fond of him, and they can even passably bang their tankards to his favorite drinking beat. But he is looking to resume his education, and has his pointed ears open to rumors of adventurers who could use a song to get their hearts racing.

I was abducted by slavers as an infant and bought by a basically goodhearted thief-master, Shulven, who trained me. Try though I might, I have never learned who my true parents were, or even where I was abducted from, and neither has Shulven (or so he says).

Rain is a younger son of the Silvertrees family that holds Caermeirion and its surrounding shire in service to the Lords of the Silver City.WarDuring the war, he was sent to the Temple of the Sun monastery as part of a political intrigue involving how to structure the company of men at arms being sent from Caermeirion and the Temple of the Sun. Some of the members of the company owed their allegiance to the ducal family of Caermeirionshire, and others were affiliated with the Temple of the Sun.Rain was a senior commander in the Silver Company, a group of mixed Sun Soul monks and Caermeirionshire vassals during the end of the war, and Aldren Steelwing was the junior commander. Rain and Aldren have some level of name recognition / minor celebrity from that and from the bard’s song (more below).Notable BattlesBetrayal in the Silver City – Rain was involved in foiling a High Lord’s plot to betray the Temple and the Silver City from within.Rescue from the Mad Wizard’s Maze – Rain was captured by the enemy for several days and questioned about intel – Rain lied to the inquisitors in a way that led to escape/rescue. Aldren and Rokan led the rescue.The Battle of the Seadrake — Met and recruited Rokan of Kanutu.The Battle of the Maw: Rain risked burnout to help his cadre hold the front, and was left with visually distinctive sun-scars on both palms from channeling sunfire for too long.Since the warRain’s rejoined the monastery as a teacher and occasional diplomat with a particular interest in mending the harms left by the previous war and ensuring that the next generation of acolytes is better prepared in the event of the next war. In the absence of warlike hostilities Rain takes groups out into adventure-prone areas for training and mending.Some bard Rain kinda wants to strangle went off and wrote a stupidly popular song about the captivity and escape, and the battle that left Rain with star-scarred palms from fire channeling – not that it’s a bad song, it’s good enough to be popular and memorable, but Rain doesn’t like the reminders.He’s always taken care to be well-dressed and respectable-looking for both his house and his monastery, but he’s intent on impressing on the younger acolytes that good manners and ass kicking are not at all mutually exclusive.On a mission for the Relief Agency, Rain is captured by cultists (for the third time) and nearly sacrificed; Aldren and Rokan rescue him, and Aldren spends the next 7 years solid teasing him about “again? seriously? you need to break this habit, it’s bad for your health.”

People who met him online know him either as Kenobi or as Solo depending on whether they met him as a white hat/“Light Side” or black hat/“Dark Side” hacker/slicer/term du jour. People who met him in real life are sometimes not entirely sure how much is cosplay, how much is eccentricity, and how much is flat out nuts. He has a hackervan called The Falcon (because of course it is).Ben is so dedicated to his Jedi facade that he’s either delusional, the ultimate method actor, or an epic troll. Has a British / mid-Atlantic accent, but nobody’s sure whether it’s real, whether he’s convinced/deluded himself into thinking it’s real, or whether he’s constantly jerking everyone’s chain.Nobody actually knows his legal surname. He’s careful to keep it that way. MacGregor is his most frequent “meatspace” surname-like alias, though he’s also been known to use Ford, Hamill, or Guinness; Kenobi and Solo are for online spaces. He’s been covering his own digital tracks for years… including making it a point never to have the same surname twice in any of his yearbooks from fifth grade onward. (He doesn’t appear in any yearbooks earlier than that. People guess he may have been homeschooled.)

What is a Kenku without her flock? Apparently, a highway robber. Coins-clinking-in-a-stolen-purse (or “Jingles” to those without the ability to perfectly imitate sounds) got fed up with her flock’s lack of initiative at a young age, and struck out on her own in search of shiny things.Jingles fell under the mentorship of an older highway robber, who trained her to survive in the wilderness, speak with the horses of passing stagecoaches to get them to halt, and fence the ill-gotten contents of mail coaches. At night, by the campfire, he’d play dragonchess with Jingles, and frighten her with tales of the undead highwaymen who roamed the backroads—they were the competitors of still-living highwaymen, and she would have to learn to fight them off!Sadly, Jingles’ mentor died after getting run over by a nobleman’s carriage, and she’s since had to fend for herself—with mixed success. She lacks her mentor’s charisma, and has had to use her crossbow to shoot one or two drivers who wouldn’t acquiesce to her demands. To her own surprise, she feels little regret about this--like the Shrike (whose plumage hers resembles) Jingles finds it very satisfying to impale her victims on the ends of pointed sticks.

Ffion grew up on a smallholding in the middle of Golden Fields (northwest of Nightspell, near Left Hand River) as the only child of her human father Hywel Battlesea and her elven mother Jhaer Shacyne. Her childhood was not idyllic; she was expected to do her fair share of work and times could be lean if the harvest didn't come through. Nonetheless, she worked hard, even if it was just so she could finish faster and hide out in the fields to write poetry and compose little songs, her true passion.Her father was kind but also stern, and more than once Ffion found herself in trouble for letting the pigs out of their pen or encouraging the chickens to roost outside the barn (due in part to her conviction they'd be happier free, but she couldn't pretend it didn't make her happy to see the chaos a pig trying to get into the kitchen caused). Ffion grew up knowing her father expected her to take over the running of the farm one day, and his expectations weighed on her. Added to her mother's apparently inability to see that Ffion was maturing like a human child, not an elf, by the time she reached sixteen she had come to the decision that she had to run away.Still, it took another three years of plotting and saving the pennies she earnt by singing on market days and penning love poems for hapless farmhands before she eventually left home, and even then, it was the long-awaited birth of a baby brother, Rhys, that pushed her to take the plunge. She begged a place in a passing troupe of entertainers, the Lucent Chorus, winning them over with a flattering song and the promise that she was a good cook, and left a note telling her parents she was leaving for good.She spent the next several years travelling with that same troupe, honing her craft and learning how to draw a crowd and keep their attention. It was also with this troupe that she met the first man she'd truly fall in love with, Hallam Dain. A minor human noble (the fourth son, unlikely to inherit), they met in a tavern when she was performing in Oakengulf, and he pursued her respectfully but determinedly. When the troupe moved on from Oakengulf he insisted on travelling with them, and Ffion was charmed, taking him into her bed soon after. They spent a year together, but Ffion—young and trusting—didn't realise that behind her back, he was also pursuing another member of the troupe, a tiefling woman called Temerity who Ffion counted among her friends. The two lied to her for the entirety of that year, even making excuses when Ffion expressed worries to both that she and Hallam were growing apart. When Ffion discovered the deception, heartbroken, she left the troupe and went to the only place she could think of: her family's farm.Despite her fears that she would be rejected as Hallam rejected her, her parents welcomed her home with open arms, introducing her to not only her brother Rhys, now four years old, but a baby sister as well, Meredith. For the first time in her life, Ffion threw herself into the backbreaking labour of farm work, and came out stronger mentally as well as physically. When she left home again, it wasn't under cover of night but on good terms, and to this day she makes sure to visit her family at least every second year, sending home trinkets and letters when she can't be there.Since then, Ffion has most often travelled alone, though she has many friends across the continent, and more lovers. Unwilling to place her heart in danger again, she tends to pursue single nights with men and women who often have spouses at home, feeling sure it's better to know ahead of time that they can't commit themselves to her than to believe she deserves anything more.She is currently in Xaphingden City with the intention of performing for the royal family, as she's built up enough of a reputation over the years that there are nobles who will speak for her if she asks.Ffion has no idea that she has two full-blooded elf half-siblings from her mother's previous marriage. Her mother doesn't ever talk about her life before meeting Hywel, and all Ffion knows is that her mother's family were traditionalists who disowned her for marrying a human.

Born prematurely to a family horrified by her demonic features and glaucous skin, Blessing was abandoned at birth, exposed to the elements to die. She lay alone for almost a full day and night, kept alive by her higher body temperature and some primal determination not to give up on life.Near dawn on the day following her birth and abandonment, a nomadic clan of gnomes passed by and, alerted by the sound of crying, a woman called Mina Fairsteel discovered the baby. Mina was kind hearted, childless and filled with longing, and saw past Blessing's appearance, seeing only an infant in need of love and a family. She wrapped the baby in her cloak and took her at once to her wife, Teribeth, and the two agreed this child was the blessing they had been waiting for.Though the rest of their clan was not so quick to accept Blessing, the high status of the Fairsteels meant they were willing to take the chance, and as she grew up into a sunny, cheerful little girl, the whole clan came to love her as her two mothers did. And grow she did; slowly at first, but it soon became apparent that Blessing would end up half as tall again as her gnomish family. They never complained about Blessing's size to her face (and in fact, most welcomed it as a help) but after one too many incidents of too-small furniture broken, she came to think of herself as big and clumsy in comparison, and to this day tries to make herself small and unobtrusive whenever she can.Her teenage years came with another challenge. While she remained cheerful most of the time, Blessing became prone to mood swings and her temper was short enough to cause concern. After a bout of screaming rage that resulted in Blessing defiantly and deliberately breaking a beloved heirloom, her mothers decided enough was enough. Blessing needed an outlet for her anger and her strength, and fighting fit the bill in a way nothing else did. She showed a particular affinity for the greataxe, but her penchant for throwing herself into battle body and soul with little regard for her own wellbeing meant she was dangerous with all melee weapons, her fists included. On more than one occasion, merely her presence and reputation allowed the clan to avoid a bad situation becoming an all-out fight.On her twentieth birthday, she gave her mothers the heirloom, repaired, and received in turn a greataxe, forged and made for her in every way.
A mountain dwarf, she became intrigued by the eyeless amphibians deep in the caves. She soon left to research newts in the wider world. Sometimes she wishes the whole world were a newt.

Character's name: Angstrom Wolfslayer of Whom the Bards Sing
Character's backstory: Noble and slightly misguided, Angstrom found a powerful magical ring that enabled him to fight a mighty greater werewolf, slaying the creature but perishing from his wounds.
A stalwart and tone deaf dwarf warrior who achieved renown by defeating the Flying Sahaugin of Canmarsh.

Though lacking the courage of his father (Angstrom Wolfslayer of Whom the Bards Sing), Aileron was a successful adventurer in his own right, until he was struck by a fireball whilst spider climbing and, ironically, fell to his death.

Yffrei was raised by her father on a lonely homestead, largely separated from society. She doesn't know a lot about the outside world, but knows her home, the surrounding woods, and her dog extremely well. When her dog, Nemo, got lost in the woods, farther from home than she had ever explored, Yffrei got lost. Unbeknownst to her, she wandered and stumbled through a planar portal which brought her to the Shadowfell. This encounter with planar energy bestowed her with sorcerous abilities. She still wanders the Shadowfell, trying to find her dog and her way back home.

Her egg was poached by some drow hunters. After hatching, she was put up for sale as a four-taloned raven familiar. She was sold off to a coven. Her owner named her Cowbell, for the sound she often repeated. Over the years, it was becoming more and more apparent that she was no animal, but rather a kenku. Upon realizing this, she was made a fully fledged honorary member of the coven.

Noria is the youngest daughter of retired adventurers. She hoped to follow in her parents' footsteps, but the mysteries of fighting and magic eluded her. So her parents called in a favor with a fae they knew from their adventuring days and the fae agreed to grant Noria powers. Noria knows she now owes the fae a favor, which is never a good thing, but she is too busy enjoying her new status as a famous adventurer, just like her parents.

Bungletop Schitkicker was born to a lowly potato farmer and used to dream about being a royal knight.  When he came of age he took his sturdiest pot and ran off to enlist.  He didn't realize being a soldier sucked and got really uncomfortable being around a bunch of smelly macho men who constantly made fun of his man bun and beard beads.That's when he met Lyra Quartzsmith, a stout dwarven lady of noble birth who had a rockin' beard and huge biceps.  She punched an offending soldier in the codpiece for mocking Bungletop's flower crown and he swore her a oath of service on the spot.Now they travel far and wide in search of crystals and bones and flowers to sell to aesthetic witches who want to look rustic without doing the work and are currently financing their first underground stronghold.

There's a popular phrase among children: "Last one there's a rotten egg!" It's supposed to be a challenge, "We're now racing because the loser faces ridicule."There's a slightly different saying used by conscriptors for the Iron Circuit's Cast Iron Brigade. "The last soldier to muster is tortured to their death before the rest of the platoon." This brigade was named because it was a melting pot of sorts; any time the numbers of the Cast Iron dwindled, the conscriptors used this line to get recruits from every background. Different homeland, different religions, different races. Half the soldiers couldn't even communicate with each other in the first rounds of recruitment and, for the most part, they didn't need to. The Cast Iron Brigade was faced with the missions that the more refined and homogeneous groups deemed too dangerous. The Front-Line, Sacrificial Lambs of the Iron Circuit army, so to speak.These conditions led to the rise of a few Champions. Linu Lomivazi wasn't planning on becoming one of those. She was second to last answering the conscriptors, she was first in line to watch as the last recruit was dragged out by the hair and tortured for two hours in the public forum. She was immediately, then, fearful of any part of the military and attempted every method she could to get out that also wouldn't get her executed. Every attempt failed, so horribly so that she earned the name Lomivazi, or "Unlucky" in the bastardized slang that formed in the camps.When basic training was complete, she ended up stronger than most after suffering the extra attention from the weapons masters who saw a need for discipline. When the first sortie occurred, Linu was one of the only 200 who returned from the front lines. Linu was the one with the most notches on her weapon. Linu was the one who took on the duty of calling the next draft. Over the next 5 years, Linu stayed with the Cast Iron Brigade as it was called to test the defenses of the Iron Circuit's foes. She grew to enjoy the thrill of a battle, she grew to be the shining example of foolhardy courage for the recruits who had to watch the last among them shrivel and die to the conscription. Eventually, she hit her 7 year promise and was released (forcefully) from military service. The woman who had tried to escape at every chance for the first two years was sad to see it go. So much so that she began searching for something to stoke that fire that was ignited in her by the Cast Iron Brigade. She went back to visit old friends in her home town when she ran into Vanyr who brought her attention to the summons of Rollo Brockhouse.Before her time in the military, Linu lived among the poor.The Purple stripe in her hair symbolizes power and mystery. Earned because of Linu's encounter with the slumlords who dominated the Iron Circle's poor district. Mystery because of Linu's heritage as a Half-Orc in a primarily Dwarvish and Halfling district.When Linu was living with the poor and dejected, she had to deal with the protection payments demanded by the slum lords just like everyone else. Linu had no skills in any craft and struggled to make the ends meet. When she couldn't, she had her bones broken and possessions taken. The only thing that never broke was her spirit as she vowed every day to pay back every pain she suffered.The monastery that fed and rested her came into the sights of the ruffians and she found herself stepping in to protect her source of food which put her in the good graces of Vanyr Oakenwood. After she found herself broken and bloodied and victorious, Vanyr is the one who nursed her back up. This started a friendship that lasted at least until Linu was conscripted to join the Cast Iron Brigade for the Iron Circuit. Linu did always respect the way Vanyr never backed down even when he was facing unwinnable odds.That's why she came back to check on him after her service. That's when she told him about her expedition north. He had to take care of some soup kitchen matters before he left so he promised to meet her at the encampment.

Tordek Strongarm comes from Citadel Adbar. Having seen his home kingdom weaken during his (relatively short) lifetime from military losses and young, untrained leadership, Tordek, somewhat of a hothead, began to foment dissent and rebellion among the younger dwarves. After all, why should the king and the head guild crafters grow wealthy off the strength of working dwarves? King Harnoth caught wind of these rumblings and had Tordek cast out of the kingdom, and the king continues to bear a grudge to this day.Tordek leaves behind a family: Thorfin and Periodot (Dottie), his parents, his older brother Thorfin, and a younger brother, Cromnel. The Strongarm Clan is an old, respected mining clan in the Citadel. Tordek doesn't know what's become of his family after having to escape the wrath of the king.

Nicholas Tillinghast is the town physician for the village of Sorin. Nicholas arrived a couple of years ago and quickly established himself within the town. He's friendly though very private. The townsfolk don't really know much about him or his past, but he's gotten enough townsfolk through illnesses that most people don't think too much about it.
Nebula is an artist who was called to action via healing by the goddess Selune.

Francis was the only son of a wealth merchant who quickly realized the sins and evils of riches from an early age.  One day, Francis decided he'd had enough and vowed to be a force of change in the world.  He returned everything his father had ever given him- including the very clothes off his back- and left the estate naked.Francis eventually dedicated himself to the goddess of healing, who could physically manifest Herself and bestowed powerful divine magic upon him so that he could heal the subjugation wreaked on the impoverished masses.  During his adventures, Francis refused to handle or accept coin for services rendered, relying entirely on the donations of others for food, clothing, and shelter.One of the most confusing and stressful times of Francis' career as a celebrated cleric was his time in the Ashforth region.  While attempting to expose the town's reclusive mayor as a vampire and chase rumors of a dragon brood, he built rapport with the town's elders by leveraging his status as a cleric of a benevolent goddess who- he assumed, was a figure of power everywhere as proof of her existence was irrefutable.  In the end, the townspeople refused to believe his warnings or evidence that the mayor was indeed a blood sucker for infathomable reasons that still don't make any sense, nor did his impassioned cries for action against concrete proof that dragons WERE nesting in an abandoned church just outside of town.  The villager's bewildering actions aside, Francis met with further horror and confusion when his divine powers suddenly hinged on his ability to pay for them with jewels and gold.In all, it was a very stressful time and he left as quickly as possible, suspicious that he had wandered into a bizarro dimension.
She came from a village, and loves animals. She does fire magic. Her favourite spell is Soul of the Bill.
His chaotic alignment made him different than the other lightfoot halflings. He left of his own accord, making him an outcast, and went on to become a stealthy rogue.

Yareach was once the ruler of a kingdom of elves and humans. Seeing that her subjects needed a figure to look up to, she stepped down from the throne and became a thief from the rich and a giver to the poor. Yareach realized that the underlying systems of her kingdom were corrupt, and is now gathering support for a revolution against her brother, Maor, the current ruler.

Malfeas found herself in the frozen peaks of the frost backs.There she took to the proofing of her clan, when a spirit of the fade came to like her very much and adopted her guide. Looking like she does herself.Cast out, she now finds luck with a mercenary company

Junebug is a painter from the city of La Vieille.  She is gifted in a particle white art that permits her to summon things she paints into reality. She joined a group of anarchists who have been looking to bring down the class of lord argents and bring equality to the lower classes. To do so, she has helped commit murder, has impersonated a noble woman, stole a thousand books from a restricted library, went to another plane where she befriended a malevolent entity, who eventually showed her shape shifting, and raised a whole part of the city into the sky to prevent it from falling to the hands of the orarch nitrum and having the rebels arrested.
Protector of the honey badger

Emeric was the first-born child of the noble family of House Argent. His mother died in his infancy, and when he was a child, his father was killed by a mob - in his grief, he discovered his power to control fire, and escaped in the chaos with his younger sister. He spent the rest of his childhood bouncing between caretakers and learning how to rule, his sister always in tow. Then when he was eighteen, he met a young pirate who stole his heart and offered to smuggle him out of the city, in return for a small favor: help him stage an "accident" against the pirate's captain, an infamously cruel man. Emeric had long dreamed of a break from the city, though he expected he wouldn't be long ... until he went with his lover to stage the accident, and discovered that the captain was in league with the other nobles in the city to kidnap and "disappear" political dissidents and their families. In a rage, Emeric killed the noble who told him of the plan, burned down the captain's boat, and fled the city for good with his pirate lover. In the power vacuum he left behind, his sister stepped up to his seat, becoming Lord Argent in his place. Emeric, meanwhile, found belonging on the seas, among his lover and their crew, that he never had as a child. But he never forgot about his sister, the city he'd left behind, or the terrible things he'd seen there, so long ago ...

he was born without his vocal chords, when he turned the ripe age of one, he was sent off on his sasur-amen, which lasts a year and a day, those that are on their sasur-amen are to learn of the world and come back to be trialed only then may they be accepted into the society

alabaster's grandfather made his fortune in the mining industry. whereupon alabaster's father squandered it away on prostitutes and wine. now alabaster wishes to reclaim what was lost to him, his money.
wiliam walker aka Double Double U aka Dubs has wandered the land anoying others, and it would make sense, good luck getting Dubs to stop talking. found himself in the hold of a slavers ship

ashta was a jewelers wife, he was mostly drunk and ashta would be hard put to do most of the work for him. one day he came home particularily drunk and beat ashta, that is when ashta reached into the forge and pulled out a tong of flame and whiped her husband into a pulp, afraid of the consequences of her actions ashta ran away into the mountains. where a blue dragon found her put her through trials where she emerged like unto a phoenix. able to control her inner fire and fires around her

Abandoned by her family as an infant, Lilith was taken in by a local noble. She was raised to revere the dark arts, and taught that she was better than others. Unsure of her destiny, she ran away from home and lived on the streets. There, she came to realize that everyone deserved to have the chances she had had, and began her quest for a better world.

As the youngest daughter of the High Wizard of the small Triton Kingdom of Vuuz, Feloren never felt like she fit in with her family and their academic ways. She was a fighter, not a dusty nosed scholar! When she came of age, she took part in the traditional Deep Hunt, as all young Tritons did, but she was blessed by a vision from Tempus, God of the Deep. Feloren hunted down the white squid and laid it on the altar to Tempus, and an ethereal tentacle took her sacrifice and pulled it deep into the inky dark. Then the tentacle touched her forehead, and she had a vision of herself as a glorious defender of the temple. When she awoke, she had been marked with a sucker print on her temple, where the tentacle had touched her skin. Awoken to her duty, Feloren forswore her previous life of luxury and lived instead for the glory of Tempus. For twenty years, Feloren was a glorious defender of the faith, as strong in her prayers as in her mighty arm. However, she forgot her duty for Tempus and drank heavily the night of the Blood Tide Festival, and a mighty host destroyed the temple while she slept in the marble halls of her father’s palace. The next day, Feloren woke to find that she was the sole survivor of a massacre - all Vuuzians around her had been slain by an unidentified weapon, and the temple desecrated. No trace of the killers was left behind. Crazed with grief, Feloren roamed the seas, fighting all comers, drinking dryland wine to ease her grief. She found no trace of the mysterious sea killers, and had given up hope, collapsing on the altar to Tempus to await her death. The ethereal tentacle returned, but instead of a gentle caress, it wrapped around her, crushing her nigh unto death, and dragged her through the deepest reaches of the ocean, finally flinging her above the waves and into a dryland city. Feloren fought against those drylanders who tried to touch her, until she passed out from her injuries. While she was unconscious, the drylanders took her to prison, and left her there to dry out and disappear.She awoke tied up, in the back of a cart, on her way to the Castle of the Mad Archmage...

Born in Chondalewood Forest the seventh son of Northwind, he was cursed by his father's wife when she learned of his affair with a human. He joined an adventuring company that fought against a blue dragon, but they were subsequently killed in an expedition to a necromancer's fortress in the sky. Then, he was transported into a demiplane of terror, where he quested with others to find his way home.

He was a rogue-like bard and a typical cat. But he ended up performing in the jellical ball and gained a shadow friend, so now he has become a shadow dancer. He and his band of other bards are traveling through Melodia trying not to die and winning musical competitions.

Taggin Lufah Kootoo was always a curious gnome. If there was anything unknown, any questions to be asked, he would seek out the answer. That was always fine by his family and his fellow gnomes, who were more content with their own simple lives, but still encouraged his inquisitive spirit. As such, it came as no surprise when he decided to leave on his own journey of discovery.When he returned, however, Taggin was changed. He had learned things, as he had hoped, but the things he had learned were not meant to be known. During his journey and research, he uncovered dark secrets about the universe, secrets about creatures older than time, with powers beyond comprehension, and try as he might, he couldn’t stop himself from delving deeper, learning more, until his mind broke under the weight of the truth.From there, his research led him to arcane rituals, that would allow him to tap into their dark powers. He completed the ritual, taking his first step down the path of a Warlock, but his studies had led him to one simple conclusion.If knowledge leads to madness, then madness is knowledge. It is through insanity that we become truly aware.But his inquiring mind was never satisfied. There were so many more secrets left in the world. So many dark secrets, waiting to be learned. So much madness left to uncover. So he continues to travel and study, lost and content in his own madness, but seeking to dive deeper into the sweet abyss of insanity by uncovering more truths of the world.

Da’reth hails from the Underdark, as Drow are known to do. As a lowborn male, there wasn’t supposed to be much hope for him to advance in Drow society, or even survive. If he was lucky, he’d be strong enough to join the Drow’s military ranks, and perhaps rise moderately high enough to gain some respect before being assassinated by an underling.Yet Da’reth was not strong of body either, at least not enough to be a worthwhile soldier. And the frequent beatings he received did little to change that, although he did grow better at dodging.What he lacked in strength, however, he made up for in strength of personality and a creative mind. Where other Drow toiled away, he found a way to get others to handle his burden, as he composed quick little rhymes and ditties.Naturally, that was looked down upon in Drow society.One day, while out on basic patrol (also known as the position most likely to result in a quick death by invading adventurers), he came upon a party of travelers. Among them was a bard, who strummed away on his lute and improvising songs that had magical effects on his companions, in a very literal sense.So Da’reth introduced himself to the party, using his quick wit and clever tongue to convince them that he meant no harm. In fact, he assured them, the cruelty of the Drow was just a rumor spread by the outside world, that feared the creatures of the Underdark. When not under attack, the Drow were actually a welcoming species, and he would be more than happy to introduce them.Needless to say, he walked the adventurers straight into an ambush.
