But he picked up a few tricks from the bard along the way, and took the lute from the lad’s dead hands.From there, he practiced the bardic arts in secret, researching from the books he pilfered from the adventurers’ bodies. His ambush had earned him a little renown, but it was short and fleeting, and his curiosities were elsewhere. The outside world seemed to beckon to him, full of mysteries and opportunity for even a lowborn Drow such as himself.And so, on his next patrol, he deserted his post. In doing so, he let another band of adventurers through, and the damage they caused was surely enough to earn him an execution for his negligence. He’d tossed away any chance of ever returning to the Underdark, but he had earned his freedom, and that was worth far more.

Soren Oerkali was a typical Aarakocra, spending his days in flight and freedom. He had little in the way of aspirations, but being fit of body and charismatic, it was still assumed that he’d do well in life.In fact, his opportunity to prove himself came earlier than expected, when a group of bandits tried attacking his hometown. Soren was the first to rush to fight them off, and the sight of an enraged bird-man, swiping away with his talons, was enough to frighten off the invaders.Naturally, praise was heaped upon him afterwards, because why would it? He was, after all, the hero of the day. In fact, his fellows were beginning to compare him to the paladins who patrolled the countryside, fighting evil wherever they found it.That sounded like a pretty good career path to Soren. After all, paladins fought in the name of righteousness, so if he became a paladin, he could fight as much as he wanted, and it would be the righteous thing to do. The logic, he determined, checked out.After saving up enough to afford weapons and armor, Soren made his debut as the “paladin of the skies,” as he liked to call himself. Sure, he wasn’t entirely sure what being a paladin entailed, or what he’d have to do to truly become one, or the great risk he was taking on himself by journeying out into the unknown with no formal training or experience, but he was fairly certain he’d be fine. After all, there was evil to smite, and he was looking forward to starting the smiting.

Don’t bother asking Yorelin what his full name is, he wouldn’t remember. After all, his family name was taken from him the same time his family was; the fact that he even remembers his first name instead of just “Cabin boy” is a blessing, although he could be remembering it wrong anyways.At a young age, his elven outpost was attacked by a band of raiders, who slew his family and took him as a prisoner. He was handed from captor to captor for a while after that, until he ended up enslaved by the Drow pirate, Kirth’et. He was to be kept as a cabin boy for a short while, until they next returned to the Underdark and made him an offering to the spider goddess Lolth.That return trip took longer than anticipated, though, so he spent a good amount of time on the ship, where he had to learn to steal whatever he could to survive - food to keep through the day, a blanket to keep through the night, and whatever else he could to keep his hopes alive of ever making an escape. In secret, he watched the pirates fight, and tried his best to pick up on their swordplay as well (though any time he was caught doing so, he was then used as a training dummy by the rest of the crew).One day, however, he did manage to make his escape. In the middle of a raid, he let himself get knocked overboard, and swam to safety as far as he could. There, he washed up on the Sword Coast, a battered Elf, but a free Elf.One would think that his life would have taught him to be compassionate to those not as well off as him, to compensate for the cruelness that he was shown. One would be wrong, in such a case. For he had grown hardened, and greedy, and after losing all the world had taken from him, he was determined to take all that he could, wherever he could, from whoever he could.Other people had done nothing to help him; other people had used him and sold him. So why should he care for anyone else? No, other people were just tools to be used, and a disarming smile while calling them “friend” was the best way to use them. After all that he had been through, Yorelin was hard to phase, and learned to keep a smiling poker face in any situation. His time on the high seas among pirates had made him an expert smuggler as well, which he took as his profession. But should his possessions be put at risk, he’d show no mercy nor kindness, and when given the choice between riches and the wellbeing of other people, he’d pick riches every time.

To look at the history of a Half-Elf, one must first look at their parents, especially in the case of a Half-Drow such as Ereldril. How could it be that a Drow and Human could consummate, given the nature of Drow society?Ereldril’s mother was a Drow from a decently ranked house in Menzoberranzan; not high enough for a place in the council, but well enough to get by with decent respect. As such, the house could often afford certain status symbols, such as one-time adventurers turned slaves.It seems there’s never an end to the adventurers seeking to root out evil by venturing into the Underdark, but so many are unprepared for the dangers that await within. So when one human expedition was captured, their captors opted to sell them to nobles; a fair amount of noble houses enjoyed forcing lesser beings to bow to their whims, and once they grew bored of their slaves, they made decent sacrifices to Lolth.That was how Ereldril’s parents met, with his father as captive to his mother. The strong-willed adventurer was not easy to break, and often required some charm or domination spells to be fully compliant, until a combination of the constant magic manipulations and Stockholm Syndrome made him eager to serve his mistress.Naturally, such affection disgusted the Drow, who found increasingly life-threatening tasks to give her slave. Yet he carried them all out, time and time again, proving himself particularly hard to kill, so long as he could win her favor.Eventually, in a moment of curiosity and weakness, she decided to lay with the human. Thus, Ereldril was conceived.For a Drow noble to give birth to a vile half-breed would normally be enough to make her house not only lose Lolth’s favor, but lose its standing altogether. So Ereldril’s birth was kept secret, and after much prayer, it was decided that the house would maintain Lolth’s favor only so long as Ereldril remained a true Drow. Naturally, his human father had to be sacrificed to Lolth as part of the deal.Thus began Ereldril’s upbringing, to the same harsh standards as any Drow, and then some. With his Human blood, he lacked certain talents that came naturally to other Drow, though fortunately he inherited the natural ability to cast certain spells. He was expected to always have Disguise Self cast upon himself before going outside, so as to hide any signs of his Human heritage, and only show his true face to a very select few.Among those few were the house’s weapons master and mage, who trained him from a young age, as they would any other Drow children of the house. What Ereldril lacked in physical strength, he made up in finesse and quick-thinking, and he quickly took to magic and light weapons. Together, his instructors taught him the way of the Bladesinger, seeing his natural talent for weaving weapons and spell craft.Of course, Lolth later had them both turned into Driders for teaching Bladesinging to one who carried human blood, but that came long after.Eventually, a unique opportunity came to Ereldril, as his house was tasked with connecting with a certain faction outside of the Underdark. Fearing the light of the sun, many Drow declined to leave, but Ereldril realized that this was one case where his Human traits could perhaps come in handy; as a Half-Drow, his Darkvision wasn’t nearly as great as that of his kin, but he in turn lacked their sensitivity to the sun. As such, he was chosen as the house’s representative, and went to the surface, where he eventually joined the Lord’s Alliance. By forging an alliance between his house and those in the faction, he could provide his family with a link to the world outside the Underdark, and several important connections they could later use.

When Phyll was a young child, he was part of a caravan with his family. His father was a merchant, not one of much wealth, but he did well enough for them to get by; he sold gear to adventurers, but he never thought he’d be caught up in any epic battles himself.Of course, the caravan was attacked by an evil necromancer and his army of the undead. Traveling heroes managed to save the day, but the  moment stuck with Phyll.“Why should undead only be used for evil?” he wondered. “Think of all the good they could do if utilized right.”He realized the the undead could serve more purposes than just attacking caravans and guarding evil lairs. There are plenty of tasks that skeletons and zombies could be put to work at - street cleaning, security, plowing fields, the list goes on.So Phyll began studying to be a wizard; he was an intelligent young lad, so his family used what money they had to get him books on magic that he diligently poured over, until he began getting a grasp of the basics of magic, with the focus of his studies on necromancy. Eventually, he was ready to head out and explore the world.Phyll has a dream for the future, a world where the undead are used to carry out society’s menial tasks, allowing a degree of comfort for all who live in it, and the freedom to pursue their passions. In return for fulfilling, safe, and comfortable lives, people would willingly allow their bodies to be used after death as the undead workforce for a time, paying back the society that has provided for them.Of course, consent is always important, particularly when animating the dead. So don’t be surprised if he asks early on if you’re okay with him animating your corpse should you die during the quest, at least until they can find a cleric to properly revive you.

Once, a band of goliath barbarians ventured down from their home in the mountains to raid a nearby village. Unfortunately for them, the village just so happened to be home to a band of paladins, united as members of the Order of the Gauntlet.Suffice to say, the raid did not go well.By the time it was over, only one goliath still lived: a newborn child, carried into war on his mother’s back. The paladins agreed that, though his kin may have been invaders, the child was blameless, and decided to raise him as a member of their order.So the child was raised, a goliath among humans (and the occasional elf and dwarf), to be a paladin like no other. Strong, fearless, and utterly devoted to upholding the law. Should any break society’s rules under his watch, he had the might and the guidance to be judge, jury, and executioner. He is the shield that protects order, and the sword that delivers its judgement. He is Thelaw Jujurex, and he delivers justice in the name of the law.

Lilth’et is the younger of twin sisters, born to a priestess of Lolth. Naturally, her mother raised them both to follow in her footsteps, while slowly working to earn her place as the matron of the house over her own sisters. (As Drow, of course that included a fair amount of poison and backstabbing, but that’s only natural.)Lilth’et’s older sister, Kirth’et, decided she had other plans. Though still loyal to the spider queen, she felt her talents were best used outside of the Underdark, and went off to become a pirate, of all things. Yet she managed to consistently deliver goods and sacrifices to the family, so Lolth remained pleased.Lilth’et’s mother would never see her dream of becoming the matron fulfilled, as she came down with a nasty case of dagger to the throat. That left Lilth’et herself to carry on as she’d been raised, continuing her unceasing servitude to the spider queen and scheming her way to the top of the house.She was good, too. Quite good at maintaining Lolth’s favor, not being around when her rivals happened to perish, and avoiding would-be assassins of her own. So good, in fact, that the house’s matron took notice of her skill and ambition, and decided to give her a special mission, well outside of the Underdark.So Lilth’et was sent to join up with the Zhentarim, and carry out some missions for the faction on behalf of her house, in return for certain favors from the family. Though she was certain that it was only a means to get her out of the way, she still had to carry out the assignment as ordered, and thus made her way to work with inferior species, where surely she would shine as a prime example of what a Drow priestess should be.Some Drow head to the surface to escape the evil of their race. She embodies the evil they’re fleeing from.

Heroes have songs sung in their name. This is no secret. Those who vanquish evil and save the day are forever remembered in poetry and music, tales of their brave deeds echoing through taverns, around campfires, and in the ears of those who hear them.A young kenku grew up listening to those songs, and could repeat them backwards and forwards at a moment’s notice, as kenku do. He’d spend hours around taverns and courtyards, listening to the remarkable tales the bards sung of - the man called Jayne, the continuing story of Bungalow Bill, and the story of St. Jimmy, to name a few. Every drinking song, from Bink’s Sake to songs about pina coladas, reached his ears as well, though nothing engaged him as much as songs about heroes of renown.The kenku wanted nothing more than to be the hero of such a song, and he studied the bardic arts, repeating every song he heard to perfection. There was only one problem: he couldn’t come up with his own. Kenku, after all, are cursed to have an absolute lack of creativity, so while he could play back anything, he couldn’t compose one for the life of him.Well, there’s only one solution to that: he’d need someone else to write a song of his exploits, and to do that, he’d have to have some exploits in the first place. So he set out on a journey of his own, hoping to be the very best, like no one ever was, so that people would one day sing his name.Some people call him the space cowboy. Some call him the gangster of love. Some people call him Maurice, ‘cause he speaks of the pompitous of love.

Yan is a member of the Phasewinder Guild, an organization devoted to preventing the malicious magical manipulation of time. Although he's a human, most of his comrades are planar beings of pure law and logic, offering him few opportunities to embrace his emotions.The guild is based in Kaliopteris, a secluded bubble of space somewhere in the outer planes, near the realm of the lawful deities. Kaliopteris was once, itself, a being named Kaliopter who believed so deeply in ensuring the safety of time that he committed his very being to creating the guild and its home.Yan came to "join" the guild by happenstance. While investigating a temporal anomaly in a far-off realm, a group of agents found a timeline on the verge of collapse after a magical curse was triggered by the birth of a king's first child. Everyone and everything that existed before the child's birth was doomed, but the child could still be salvaged. When the agents returned to Kaliopteris, they had no choice but to raise the orphaned child as one of their own, naming him Yan.Being one of the only humans in the guild, Yan found it an odd fit. He could never be quite as cold or calculating as his purely logical comrades, and his curiosity sometimes left him at odds with his superiors. Shortly before he was cleared for field duty, however, he discovered the case file detailing the destroyed world and timeline he was to be born into.Struck with conflict, not content to live a life unfit for a creature of emotion, Yan jumped into a foreign timeline on a routine mission before destroying his temporal anchoring device, leaving him stranded in the material world and among his own people.From there, he sought a way to live a relatively normal life, doing things the way normal people do, living in a community and making friends without having to skulk around behind the curtains of history. Still, it's been hard to leave his training and habits behind; socializing has been particularly difficult.He wants to matter, and to be remembered.

As a child he was sent to live alone, tending a remote shrine to the god of earthly life. On his 127th birthday, he finally grew too restless and decided to leave. Now he's entered the big city, devoid of social skills.

Iorad was born in Chornak, a distant outpost of Sundabar in the Nether Mountains. Originally a settlement of dwarves and humans, it fell to the Thousand Fists orc tribe over four generations ago and the survivors were enslaved. There had already been mixed blood between the dwarf and human populations, and some orc blood passed into the slave population as well. Though he seems human in stature and most features, Iorad has a powerful, stout build and an unusual gray cast to his skin, perhaps a hint at mixed ancestry.The lives of most slaves were short and brutal, and Iorad often fought both with the orcs to fend off the monstrous threats in the mountains, and against the orcs to protect the weaker slaves. The settlement was ruled by Rugud the Howler, an orc with some shamanic power. In Iorad's teen years, a party of Bloodaxe Mercenaries from Sundabar found the lost outpost, and battle ensued. Iorad helped drive out the orcs, but Rugud collapsed a cavern, escaping and killing most of the other slaves.Iorad returned to Sundabar, finding work with his immense strength until he was found by Teppers, a halfling leader of a mercenary party called the Death Caps. Teppers' tall tales and fine mushroom wines enchanted Iorad, and he joined his mercenary group, along with Hawktree the human ranger and the elven siblings Llideth and Bealias.Iorad traveled with the Death Caps for many years, content to follow a clever leader and enjoy the entertaining atmosphere they had at camp. However, he was easily fooled and grew to love gambling, quickly losing his wages at any new town.On one occasion, the Death Caps were hired to protect a secret location for the trade of rare magic items. Iorad, however, found himself in debt to a Zhentarim woman named Tatarra the Red Glove, who ran the gambling establishments in the nearest town. In exchange for relieving his debt, Iorad divulged the secrets of the location and its defenses. The Zhentarim acted on this information to strike mercilessly, slaughtering the other Death Caps and the merchants. Iorad was left alive, taunted by Tatarra, and fell into a vagrant and meaningless life until he met Augustine, saving him from a giant serpent in a ruin in the Southwood.
Elf assassin from Mexico, sworn to climb over the wall of Mordor.

Originally a circus bear, a slight magical accident gave Bear advanced intelligence. He escaped his captors and ran into the woods where he was found by druids. Intrigued by the talking bear, they began to teach him druidry (although he had to take winters off). Now Bear travels the world promoting the rights of wildlife and searching for the most delicious salmon.
thought he was cool, but had to work in AV

Jun grew up in a ordinary town, and at the age of eighteen left home.Soon to find himself in a bar playing a game of cards, in 30 seconds his opponent won Jun asked how he did it, and he said that he would teach Jun the ways of card magic.So after 2 years of training, he could defeat someone with a deck of cards.
Was born a tree
Rides rocks into battle

Ollie's upbringing before the attack on Emon was, for the most part, a charmed existence. Born to a wealthy family of academics, it was assumed early on that Ollie, the second oldest child, would continue on the grand tradition of the Porters. While Ollie did very much enjoy study, they found themselves not only wrapped up in tomes of history and magic, but also fictional works of great heroism. The idea of being in the back lines - at best - slinging magic spells quickly lost its appeal, though they dutifully, for a long time, at least studied as their parents asked.Enrollment into the Lyceum was a given - practically a family tradition. Ollie got good marks, but constantly felt a pull of wanting to do something more than sit among books their entire life. Troubled by the pulls of obligation and choice, they spent much of their childhood silently miserable. They likely would've remained that way, too, if not for him happening upon a duel in the streets of town.Ollie was utterly enraptured by the scene. The winner dispatched the man with a few clean motions, leaving the thug unconscious on the ground. While most went on their way after things settled, they quickly went over to introduce themselves to the Half-Elven woman who they'd come to know as Eliora. Eliora, a woman recently retired from military life, was amused at this young scrap of a person asking her to train them to be as good as she was with the sword for coin, but their clear drive was enough to grab their interest. The amount they could pay up front didn't hurt.Eliora would become a good friend and mentor as Ollie proved themselves to be more than just a child trying to play hero. They threw themselves into swordsmanship like they threw themselves into anything - with an almost insatiable drive to be the best at it. Still, having to hide the training created a bit of a double life for them, and they quickly started to find it overwhelming to juggle both the side of them that wanted to be an academic and learn about the arcane and the side that wanted to become the hero they always dreamed of being. What's worse, their parents found out about their little trips into the city to train and didn't take it well. After the discussion devolved into a fight, their relationship was strained to a breaking point.Refusing to give up on their dreams, they decided to go beyond their schooling - which really offered them nothing for their problem - and visited the local curiosity in town. Gilmore had quite a reputation among students, and it was clear very quickly why. The man was easier to talk to than Ollie ever imagined such a known figure could be, and they found themselves confiding in him what was happening and what they wanted to do - to find a balance somewhere. After considering the dilemma, they went into the back and returned with a book that was as old looking as some of the oldest in the Lyceum's library.This might be of use, he promised. He hadn't been lying. Enchantment had always been a bit of a focus subject for Ollie, and the book, written by an unknown author who Gilmore could only say was probably from the Rifenmist Peninsula area, spoke of something that went far beyond that. They realized they could build on what was clearly someone's unfinished research on the topic, which they realized just in time for all hell to break loose.Thordak changed everything. Suddenly they were thrown out of their comfortable student life and he could do nothing but watch it all burn. In the ensuing time between the attack and the taking back of Emon, Ollie quieted the panic of losing contact with literally everyone they cared about by throwing themselves into their research. They realized they could essentially use runes on his weapons, armor, and even body to tap into their innate magical talents. Though the ensuing time often involved failures at best and near brushes with actual injury at worst, they eventually found success. Their training with the arcane as well as their martial training finally found a connection point.It became their project, their obsession. When it became clear they would have to mark their body to get some of the magic spoken inside to work, they didn't hesitate, even though the Academy would've expressly forbade it. It didn't take him long to unlock the secrets of the book, and he found reason to believe that perhaps it wasn't the only one.Perhaps there was still things yet to find.When the Academy began asking for volunteers to go to the corners of the world to begin rebuilding the Academy's lost libraries, they were among the first to sign up, surprising even their teachers when they chose one of the most dangerous assignments - into the Rifenmist Peninsula. It was of course on purpose - they knew, after all, the book they'd been given had been found in that area. With little reason to question their motives, they agreed to allow them leave from the Academy for more...hands on experiences.They weren't stupid, though. They knew it wasn't a journey they could take alone. When it was clear none of their fellow peers had any interest in the area, they turned to a tavern to see if anyone was looking for a shield while traveling. As it turned out, there was...
A good thug. How? It was possible in Indonesia.

He was a lost from his tribe. He tried to find a way, but ended up in a monastery. There, he was hypnotized to learn the Asian martial arts. After finished the training in three years, they kicked him out the monastery. Now he is a confused-and-lost traveler.

KEKEKEKEKKEKEKEKEKKEKEKEKEKEKKEKEKEKEKEKKEKEKEKEKEKKEKEKEKEKEKKEKEKEKKEKEKEKEKEKEKKEKEKEKEKEKEKEKEKKEKEKEKEKKEKEKEKEKEKEKKEKEKEKEKEKKEKEKEKEKEKEKEKEKEKKEKEKEKEKEKEKKEKEKEKEKEKEKKEKEKEKEKEKEKEKEKEKEKEKEKKEKEKEKE.....Okay, here is the real story.The guy was a mysterious guy. Nobody knows who he was, or how he got to be known. But one thing for sure, he KEKEKEKKEKEKEKEKKEKEKEKEKEKEKEKEKEKEKKEKEKEKKEEKKEKEKEKEKKEEKEKKEKEKEKEKEKEYes, he's crazy.
There was a legend of a man. Named You. No certain class, no certain motives, but he became a real adventurer.

Grelk was born the bastard son of a noble woman and an orc. The noble woman's husband believed Grelk to be his child until Grelk grew fangs. At that point he was banished. Grelk moved in with gnomes until he was about 17 when he joined an orc war band. He soon grew to dislike orc life and missed the comforts of civilization. He is now about 24 and discovering the joys of being a wondering adventurer.

She is the daughter of two wealthy sailors and traders from the water ashari island of veshra. She worked for many years above the ship Lady Danacos Favour and has now take  up work as a monster slayer to earn enough money for her own ship.

Left at the door of the monastery one stormy night, Whirl grew up among the predominantly human worshippers of Chaundi. Because of this, unlike other air genasi, Whirl lacks the disconnected pride for their race and it instead emerges as a single-minded devotion to fulfilling the teachings of Chaundi. Their drive to self-sacrifice is fiercely competitive, much to the annoyance of their human fellows. Whirl's air genasi nature is a source of pride for them. Despite their constant attempts to help, their village never fully accepted them. Their race was too foreign and their origin too unknown for full trust. With their pale blue-tinged skin and hair that blew in a breeze even indoors, Whirl was a familiar oddity. At the age of 16, they went to a larger town where an elven woman familiar with the genasi designed and gave Whirl distinctive tattoos on their face and arms. Strong and swirling white ink swoops down their forehead and along their cheek bones while straight lines run down their arms. Speaking with the elf woman gave Whirl some insight into their race and culture and they got the tattoos to bring them closer to that distant history. Whirl set out at 18 to help the needy and to bring peace where ever they could. They began to follow the Way of Tranquility, seeking to bring understanding to the daily struggles of the people. In battle, Whirl is fiercely focused against evil entities, but usually tries at peace with non-evil beings.

Acqaeous grew up in an undine enclave, learning magic and the arts from the many adults of the colony. He grew enamored with the heroes of the stories he heard, and nearly equally enamored with the writers of those stories. He grew an interest in writing the perfect story, either spoken or acted aloud. He deemed that his main character would be himself, so when he reached adulthood he set out with his book and quill, eager to participate in an adventure worthy of being passed down and retold for centuries.
Raised by a dragonborn Barbarian Warlock Pirate, Myekal is trained in martial arts by his sensei a wererat druid. He now seeks to emulate the adventures of his foster fathers.

Elezar was born and spent her early years in a human village that was only an hour’s walk from a permanent orc encampment. Her father had Rushed into marriage with her orc mother after the death of his first wife, who was human.Elezar grew up with an older human half-sister, Gudrun. Then when Gudrun was 15 and Elezar was 7, their father disappeared in the company of other adventurers while on whag he told his wife and daughter would be a short business trip. Gudrun, who had formerly doted on Elezar, decided that Elezar and her orc mother were the reason that their father had left. Gudrun left at the age of 18 to become a knight in the service of the Order of the Lightbringer, while Elezar was taken to live in the orc encampment and trained to become a cleric of Gorum. Elezar’s mother remarried within the orc tribe, and arranged a marriage for Elezar, who by that time had come of age and was the finest and fiercest warpriest of Gorum that the tribe had ever seen. Elezar ran away from her tribe in order to avoid the marriage, and eventually found herself among a group of adventurers sailing for a mysterious continent to the east.

Born to a family of Bahamut disciples, I, Alyssana Grace Hearthburn am the daughter of a Cleric and High Priestess of the order.  Having two other siblings, one being my twin sister Kariana, and the other, an elder brother of 5 years, Mathias.  We were raised to follow in our parents footsteps among the clergy though Mathias was resistant and I wasn’t too interested.  Our home, the temple, was located in the Castle district of the capital city Orphia. We were looked upon in high regard by everyone in the city, including the King.	Mother and father were always busy in matters of church and state so we grew to see other members of the clergy as more of a family. Growing up, my sister and I were the best of friends while our brother grew distant, and would avoid being around us as much as he could. Often I would catch Mathias sneaking off somewhere and I would follow. He would make his way to an abandoned cellar where he had stacks of books. There he would spend hours on end reading and what seemed to be him attempting magic. One night he caught me as I knocked something over watching him from the doorway, he spun around and launched a ball of fire in my direction, hitting the stone wall beside me. “What are you doing here?!” He yelled. “I-I’m sorry big b-brother… I was just curious..!” I replied as he stomped over and grabbed my wrist. “Don’t tell ANYONE what you saw!” he replied as he started dragging me back to the temple.	The years passed, I told no one about what I saw, though I don’t know why he was so secretive about it. I would often go and hang around soldiers as they trained, and I liked to try my hand at different weapons they had laying around. I got decent at a few but I didn’t quite find anything I was good at. My sister spent her time doing what our parents wished and learned the ways of being a cleric. I studied it as well but I was not as diligent as her nor as skillful. 	On the eve of Kariana and my sixteenth birthday alarm bells started ringing in the dead of night waking everyone up. There was smoke in the air accompanied by the sounds of fighting. Kariana and Mathias were nowhere to be found. Rushing out, there was flames and bodies everywhere, but not all the bodies were still. The guards were cutting down troves of undead, yet they kept coming. I grabbed a sword off a fallen guard and went searching for my siblings. After I had looked everywhere within the temple I remembered the place I had followed my brother to years ago. I made my way out of the temple grounds and into the city, where things were just as bad as inside. Using all I had learned I made it with only a few scratches and found the door locked. “Brother! Kari! Are you in there?!” I yelled as I pounded on the door with my fist. There was no reply but I could hear sounds coming from within.	Throwing my shoulder into the door a few times, I managed to burst into the room, where I happened upon a horrific scene. The room was aglow in unnatural lights, with sigils and runes painted everywhere in what seemed to be blood. Mathias was standing there with his back toward me over an alter that was not there the last time I had been here. Staring for a moment I suddenly was able to recognize that upon the alter laid Kariana, motionless, but a horrified look on her face. “Ah, took you long enough, dear sister. I’m sorry to say you’re too late, you’ve missed all the fun!” Mathias said as he slowly turned to me. He was completely covered in blood and in his hand he grasped a still beating heart. “I was hoping you would be first, but it seems the fates chose our dear sister instead.” He said with a large unnatural smile creeping along his face. I stood there, speechless, tears starting to well in my eyes and I started to stumble towards him. Before I could get close, the heart, still beating started to be surrounded by a purple miasma then burst into a hellish flame. “Ah, don’t worry.” he said in a cheerful voice. “Our dear sister wants to greet you as well!”	With that her body convulsed violently for a moment, then sat up, turned on the table and stood there. Her face still frozen in horror and her chest cavity was exposed as if something had burst forth from it. “WHY HAVE YOU DONE THIS MATHIAS?!” I screamed at him while tears were falling from my eyes like waterfalls. “WHAT DROVE YOU TO THIS MADNESS?!”	“Madness? No. THIS IS NOT MADNESS! I WILL SHOW YOU, OUR PARENTS, EVERYONE WHAT TRUE MADNESS IS!” He replied screaming back at me.	With that my sisters body ran towards me, distorting it’s features, her legs elongated and twisted, spines started protruding along her back and arms. As she swung at me, her fingers grew into long claws and her eyes went black. Before I could react she sent me flying backwards into the wall hard enough to crack the stone.	“You see sister, don’t you think she’s more useful like this? You will turn out even better! Mother and Father won’t be able to ignore me any more!” he exclaimed walking over to me.	Time seemed to stop. For a moment I laid there in silence in a pool of my own blood. The pain wasn’t present, and there was no sound for what seemed forever. Then out of nowhere a voice, “I task you with cleansing this blight your blood has wrought upon the world. End those that would corrupt the world and the natural order and be a protector of life.” As the voice faded my body felt as if I was being embraced, it was warm and my body seemed to knit itself back together. Then time flowed again, my brother stood over me with my sister, who aside from her face with the same frozen look, was unrecognizable.	I stood up, grabbing my sword, and turned to face him. “Oh you still have some fight left in you? He sneered. “We’ll have to fix that then, dear sister, if you’d please?” And Kariana’s body lunged forward again. Before I knew I reacted, my blade bathed in a radiant glow and in one swift motion removed her head, ending the flourish with me standing in front of my brother and the sword through his chest.  With a shocked look on his face he spat up blood on to me. “Heh… Well I’ll be seeing you shortly… Dear… Sister…” Where his last words as we both collapsed to our knees. I stayed there sobbing, for what seemed like ages, until I passed out.	When I awoke I was in my mothers bed, an acolyte was sitting by the door reading a book. She took notice of my stirring and ran out of the room yelling for my mother. Moments later my parents, along with a few others from the clergy walked into the room. I sat up, but before I could say anything my mother rushed over and wrapped her arms around me. “Where is Kariana? Where is Mathias? Please tell me I was only having a nightmare...” I uttered in a raspy voice. With that she squeezed me harder and I could hear a couple of the priestess’ crying. “They… are gone. We thought we had lost you as well… You’ve been asleep for over a week now and even my gifts could not wake you.” Mother said  as she pulled back to look at me. 	“I… Something, someone spoke to me… I think it was Bahamut… They felt warm… Like this… Oh! What about the undead that was attacking?!” I asked, concerned. Father walked up, handed me a cup of water and said “They were dealt with. There were plenty of injuries but...” Mother interrupted him with “There will time for that later, for now let her get her strength back.”	After that I had explained everything to them that I had witnessed, going back to me following him years ago. They did not doubt what I told them about hearing a voice. They also explained to me that after the fighting had ended they could not find us so they used a spell to lead them to us. Staying silent on what they saw, they told me that going through things in the room it was uncovered that the undead were Mathias’s doing but he was being taught, coerced by another. As they spoke, my eyes uncontrollably started to well up once more. They decided that was enough for now and had me rest some more.	Time passed, and I felt as if my task the voice had given me was not over yet. I started training in the ways of the paladins, there are several oaths one can take but there was one that stood out to me. An obscure oath that not many followed because of how it seemed to be of a more sinister nature. However it fit perfectly with what the voice had asked me to do. This was the Oath of Death. Many see it as something to fear, however death is only natural, and those that would disrupt the order should be ended. Though not entirely happy with my decision, my parents did not try to stop me.	I never let the events escape my mind, but instead of letting them chain me down, I used them to fuel my actions. In my brothers notebooks he would detail his encounters with his benefactor, a man who used the name Carthapilus. The notes told of long rants the man would go on about society and how people who did not use their life to the fullest did not deserve it. Though unsure of how accurate the accounts and descriptions of the man were, I had memorized them and kept the books on my person at all time, in search of this man.	More years passed, with my training completed I went traveling with a group of adventurers. We had our ups and downs but we became good friends, helping people, exploring dungeons, etc. Along the way I gathered more clues on the man I hunted. I also grew close to one of the men traveling with me by the name of Timon Court. He was a roguish sort, devilishly handsome, yet withdrawn from most interaction with other people. We shared our pasts and eventually decided to share out future. Getting married in my home city, with my mother being the one to head the procession. We wanted a small ceremony but with who my family was and the good our group had done there were countless people there. Afterwards we continued with our companions on our journeys, though a few months later we learned I was pregnant and decided for the time being we would take a break.	My daughter was born to us when I was twenty one and we named her Aislin Kari Hearthburn. Three years had passed before my restlessness couldn’t be quelled any longer and I set back out. Timon stayed at our home, he felt his days adventuring were over.	In my travels we discovered the man I was looking for was a disgraced baron lording over a secluded city in the mountains. Hordes of undead patrolled the streets but they weren't attacking the people, who looked disheveled and worn down. Not daring to take on the hordes with only the handful of us we stealthily entered and talking to people found there was an underground resistance. We devised a plan for an all out attack, they would deal with the undead while we entered the manor and dealt with Cathaphilus. The battle wasn’t that long, the undead he commanded were many, but weak. He himself was no fighter, when he was beaten and bleeding out, I told him who I was, his only reply was a guttural blood filled laughter. I had finally finished what I set out to do so long ago but I didn’t know if I should have felt relieved or frustrated.	I returned to my home and family with the news, deciding that my life on the road with finished. I visited the graves of my siblings often, told my daughter stories about the good memories I had with them and about my travels as she grew. I took up new responsibilities in the monastery such as teaching new acolytes and acting as a midwife to those in the city.	One night while taking my bath, there was a noise behind me. I figured it was Timon coming to join me. The figure knelt down behind me, wrapped one arm around my neck and plunged a blade into the underside of my skull.	I then woke up on an alter, with 3 others in a cold, desolate world.
Acolyte

Created from the shadow of a machine that makes angels, Zahav knew their purpose - to bring Light and Justice to the world - from the moment they were born. By day, they're an average town guard with a fluffy cat. By night, they're Gilded Word, champion of Good.

Now, this is a story all about howMy life got flipped-turned upside downAnd I'd like to take a minuteJust sit right thereI'll tell you how I became the prince of a town called Bel AirIn west Philadelphia born and raisedOn the playground was where I spent most of my daysChillin' out maxin' relaxin' all coolAnd all shootin some b-ball outside of the schoolWhen a couple of guys who were up to no goodStarted making trouble in my neighborhoodI got in one little fight and my mom got scaredShe said 'You're movin' with your auntie and uncle in Bel Air'I begged and pleaded with her day after dayBut she packed my suit case and sent me on my wayShe gave me a kiss and then she gave me my ticket.I put my Walkman on and said, 'I might as well kick it'.First class, yo this is badDrinking orange juice out of a champagne glass.Is this what the people of Bel-Air living like?Hmm this might be alright.But wait I hear they're prissy, bourgeois, all thatIs this the type of place that they just send this cool cat?I don't think soI'll see when I get thereI hope they're prepared for the prince of Bel-AirWell, the plane landed and when I came outThere was a dude who looked like a cop standing there with my name outI ain't trying to get arrested yetI just got hereI sprang with the quickness like lightning, disappearedI whistled for a cab and when it came nearThe license plate said fresh and it had dice in the mirrorIf anything I could say that this cab was rareBut I thought 'Nah, forget it' - 'Yo, homes to Bel Air'I pulled up to the house about seven or eigthAnd I yelled to the cabbie 'Yo homes smell ya later'I looked at my kingdomI was finally thereTo sit on my throne as the Prince of Bel Air

As a child, he was exposed to large quantities of shadow magic in an accident, which granted him his powers as a sorcerer. However, the darkness which gave rise to his power also dulled his emotions, resulting in a True Neutral alignment. He now fights the darkness so that nobody else has to go through this.

He's the second son of a merchant. He always knew that his brother would inherit the family business and was fine with that. Lucas travelled with the caravans learning that part of the business and how to fight. When their father died the older brother cheated Lucas out of most of his inheritance and firing Lucas. Lucas is now traveling as an adventure until he figures out what to do next

After the Orcs and Giants invaded her homeland she traveled with fellow refugees to human cities where she learned of the human gods who's priests had convinced the cities leaders to let them stay and decided to dedicate herself to the new god and gain the strength to help regain her homeland by adventuring

Muspell Heavyhand is a deep gnome wizard specializing in illusion magic but also partial to evocation and abjuration spells. He is hunchbacked and burn-covered, and the left side of his face is paralyzed in a grimace. Lacking eyebrows and his head a web of scar tissue, Muspell prefers to shave off what little black hair still grows there. His slate-grey eyes are rarely visible because of the dark-lensed goggles he keeps on unless he is underground. To avoid stares in very populated areas, Muspell usually hides behind his illusion magic. He is gruff in all senses of the word but also sagacious. He is paranoid, neurotic, and has a short, violent temper, but is ultimately good-hearted and fiercely loyal to those who have won his trust. He speaks little of the Underdark, so full of shame and trauma is the memory of his time there. He despises drow.Muspell was born during the Festival of the Star in the gnome city of Hypogaia Though birth at such a time is usually considered an auspicious omen, Muspell’s life has been anything but lucky. Nearly strangled by his own umbilical cord, it was only through the intervention of a skilled midwife that he survived his first day. He was the only child of his family, and unusually happy and curious. He was always poking around the forbidden corners around his family’s property, a sly grin on his angular face.Muspell idolized his father Surtr, a mighty breachgnome who answered directly to the king. Shortly after his family was moved to the outskirts of the territory for a long term assignment, they were attacked by a band of drow. Muspell’s father was on patrol when the drow came; Muspell hid successfully but had perfect view of the drow as they viciously raped and butchered his mother. When Surtr returned, he vowed vengeance upon the dark elves and departed with his son in tow.Muspell spent his adolescent years deep in the drow tunnels following his father in his quest for revenge. Father and son spoke but minimally, numb to all feeling but rage. Surtr, a gnome possessed, provided but the barest essentials for his son’s survival as he cut his way through the drow ranks. Eventually making their way to the temple of the drow priestess that ordered the raid, Muspell and his father stumbled into a chamber with a surprise - a chained red dragon. The dragon attacked instinctively with its flame breath. When Muspell came to, his body seethed with pain of a full body burn.    As a slave of the drow priestess he’d come to kill, he often wished he’d succumbed to his injuries that day. Muspell was beaten daily and nearly driven mad by starvation, surviving only on carrion rats and mold scraped from corners of his cell. The priestess loved to tease him about his dead father as she forced him to do humiliating acts for her entertainment, ranging from the sadistic to the sexual. He managed to escape his cell one night while the priestess did battle with a rival in the nave of her temple. While sneaking out, Muspell stole a book from under an altar, hoping its pages might provide some nourishment for his aching belly. Somehow making his way outside of the city, he opened the book. The eldritch tome contained profane secrets unfit for a sane mind, and would have killed him outright with its energies if he were not already half insane. The experience left the poor young gnome in a coma.  Muspell would not awaken until nearly a year later, back in the city of his birth. Though the book was nowhere to be found, its evil had infected his psyche, the images within burned into his brain. He was physically rehabilitated and adopted by a family friend, the illusion mage Segojan Seamseeker. Unfortunately, Muspell’s mind had been warped by his traumatic childhood in such a way that he exhibited antisocial behavior frequently, eventually driving him to close himself off from even his would-be guardian. Forswearing all kinship, he threw himself into physical training, hoping to join the king’s forces to avenge his parents. He was rejected, however; years of abuse and malnourishment during his younger years had left him stunted and weak. Broken, Muspell attempted suicide by hanging himself.He awoke with Segojan standing over him. “Your sword arm may not be strong, but you possess a strength far rarer.” Segojan pointed to his head. “That of the mind. Study under me and channel your pain into a power which will aid you in your goal.”Muspell saw no other path. He was simply not strong to be a miner or gemcutter, he thought. He accepted. He started his studies late, but by adulthood he’d overtook his apprentice peers in magical proficiency. He simply had the knack. The confidence that accompanied this proficiency produced an emotion quite alien in him: confidence. Muspell began, cautiously, to try his hand at courtship. The object of his affections was Frigga Seamseeker Though Segojan carried many reservations about a relationship between Muspell and his daughter, he withheld them with the hope that Muspell and his daughter, who was herself troubled by mental illness, might find mutual comfort.Frigga was apprehensive at first. Muspell was kyphotic and scarred from head to toe, marked by dragonfire and drow’s whip. His demeanor was vulgar and uncultured. Yet, within him she saw the boy that once explored caves fearless and with a permanent smile, the boy whose only joy was nuzzling his mother’s neck. They married in the Temple of the Earthcaller, and for the first time in his life, Muspell wept with joy.All seemed to be well, but for one thing. Months went by and Muspell failed to consummate the union. He was simply... impotent. Muspell came to realize to his great shame that he was only sexually attracted to drow. Frigga tried to be understanding but grew impatient. She wished for children. The indignance turned into arguments and the arguments turned into yelling matches. Eventually, Frigga struck Muspell with a particularly strong verbal volley. Surtr was not dead, she claimed. He had been imprisoned as a traitor for abandoning his post and lay crippled in the burrow’s dungeons. She called him an idiot for his ignorance. Muspell screamed with the rage of his father and beat Frigga to unconsciousness with a stone pot. He flew to the dungeons, where he found Surtr, missing an arm and leg and pockmarked with burn scars. Muspell dared not interrupt his father’s labored snores, and forthwith journeyed to the prime material plane, cursing his land and its people and swearing never to return.

Alistair remembers nothing before his arrival in the cursed city of Yharnam. A young chondathan man in a city of xenophobes, he was given shelter by the Healing Church, a local institution which specialized in transfusions of extraordinary blood. His appellation came from the poor clothing in which he was found, and stuck. Yharnam is a curious city; shrouded in eternal darkness, the moon stands still, always staring from behind the gothic steeples that make up its skyline. Blood has a special place in Yharnam - transfusions are commonplace and a bigger source of intoxication than alcohol.In exchange for labor in the church’s weird gardens, Alistair was given food enough to live and blood enough to survive that life. None but the occasional nun spoke to him, and the church’s order of beast hunters ignored his very existence. The church was secretive enough never to allow him into its upper levels, but he sensed something mystical was at work behind its closed doors. A citywide plague known as Ashen Blood struck, leaving even the church crippled. As the city scrambled to find a cure, a now grown Alistair ventured into the forbidden areas through a broken window. There he found something quite surprising: an orphaned Great One, an infant eldritch power.The very sight of the being was shock enough that his hair fell from his scalp. He stared, perhaps for moments, perhaps for eons into the star-like eyes within the creature’s gaping, tentacled maw. He saw his life laid before him, every instant foreordained. Knowing how his life would end, he began to laugh, for it was suddenly hilarious to him. Life was a joke. He blinked and the vision ended. Like a dream, it faded from his mind too quickly to remember, all but one detail. He would serve Ebrietas’s inscrutable will; he would be her tool until such time as he earned his freedom... and transformation: the body of a spider and a brain lined with eyes.With an inhuman sucking sound and a flap of her her glowing, sinuous wings, Ebrietas, Daughter of the Cosmos bade him leave Yharnam to gather the weaponry necessary for her escape. For indeed, Ebrietas was not truly a prisoner of the church, she confided to his barely comprehending mind, but to another Great Old One. All Yharnam was. Caught in a dream ever-repeating yet never quite the same, dawn would only come to Yharnam if this yet unknown god could be slain, and only then could she be free.Forever changed by this encounter, Alistair started on his way. He was, however and perhaps for the first time, truly happy. No more tending the Lumenflower Garden. No more half-rotted bread and peasant blood. Only his own will and that of Ebrietas! Walking through the grey mists beyond the city, time again escaped him. His pilgrimage took years, though how many, none could say. Neither hunger nor thirst found him until he saw the sun on the horizon. He’d finally made it to Altain.To make ends meet while searching for leads for his quest, he took to swindling and murder. A favored tactic of his is to share the location of a “treasure” only to trap and rob those who would steal it. He loves to lie and will nearly always choose a lie over truth if it makes things more interesting. He is a bit clumsy and very much a coward, usually running from a fight he cannot win. He sees most people as pawns in the great game the Old Ones play.Alistair’s treachery knows some exceptions. He is, once one gets beyond his facade, a true and loyal friend. When swept up in the moment, he is even capable of true heroism and bravery though he’s usually quick to dismiss such behavior as a foolish lapse in judgment.

Became an evil warlock after his husband and dog were murdered by a marauding band of adventurers in a situation that turned out to be a misunderstanding. He harnessed the powers of an earth elemental and is now using this elemental's powers to corrupt anyone in power around the Felicity Wilds, his former home, with his ultimate intention being to get revenge on the specific adventurers that wronged him but also to start an all-out war and destroy the forest that hosts his most painful memories.

Devon is a recovering alcoholic who committed a murder during a drunken fight with a forest ranger. Vowing to change his ways, he started a juice bar with his former adventuring party member and sometimes-lover, who was then kidnapped by a vicious criminal gang hired by a warlock to produce and market a rival brand of juice which includes as one of its ingredients a terrible addictive potion that causes those that drink it to become mindless slaves of said warlock.

Gigmucc the grung, also called Gigmucc the frogman, is a grung hailing from a little-known marsh known as Darkspawn Swamp. One of the stranger travelers to visit the city, Gigmucc sells insects and spell components, and at extremely reasonable prices. He has spent the last few months vending his wares all about town, but found one of his products especially popular in the red light district, so is often there.    Gigmucc’s story is, unsurprisingly, a strange one. Growing up a blue grung in an extremely rigid, color-based caste system did not leave very much room for an advancement in his fortunes. Not quite at the bottom of this hierarchy, he was nonetheless treated like dirt. He was never popular with the females and his only skill seemed to be his talent for building traps. He yearned for a life outside the swamp, where he would not be forced to work long hours for a few insects.    One day, fate struck when the village’s eggs were stolen by a tribe of lizardmen. Short on warriors from a recent battle, Gigmucc was drafted into an expeditionary force to retrieve them. Upon defeating the lizardmen, Gigmucc’s squad discovered an interesting piece of property the lizardfolk had: human slaves. The grung also had human slaves, of course, but theirs were raised from birth by the grung, only spoke Grung, and were kept in a state of hypnotic semi-consciousness by regularly applied grung venom. The lizardfolks’ slaves were different. Captured by the lizardfolk, they spoke a language he’d never heard before.  Taking one of these slaves as his own, he made the man teach him the human tongue. The man then told stories of greater Tennarra, stories that eventually convinced Gigmucc to free the slave and venture out on his own. Gigmucc discovered a knack for salesmanship and taste for human decadence. “What a limited life,” he thought back on his village, “what a poor and pathetic way to live. Being a second class citizen in human society still beats the very best the grung village can offer!”

Only survior of a city-wide fire , made a pact with an outwardly patron

Early LifeThe Cullysters were far from a remarkable family. Marian’s mother, Celine, worked in the kitchens of House Witwood and his father, Feldran, was a local tailor. As a child Marian lived an easy enough life, with the Witwoods providing an education well above that someone of his status would normally receive, while his parents taught him their trades. Marian also loved the theatre, and every month when The Wandering Whale troupe came into town he would buy tickets, watch joyously, and badger the actors for the rest of the day. He was almost obsessive, and spent all his spare money buying new scripts, novels, and books about the wonders of the world.Leaving HomeAt around the age of 15 Marian began to feel discontented with his life. While his life in Emon was pleasant, Marian found the familiarity of the city increasingly dull. The tales he had heard of the world beyond thrilled him, but the refuge of fiction started to feel too shallow. Around the same time the Witwoods’ generosity was growing ever more limited, as many in the house began to see the now-teenage boy as a freeloader, not family.And so when The Wandering Whale came into town next Marian hopped on board, trading his services as a tailor for a small bed onboard their caravan. For the next few years Marian and Ruvin travelled with the troupe. Over time Marian began to take on greater roles in the shows, quickly becoming a regular feature of the troupe’s shows. It was a good time in his life, even with the chaos in the wider world, but once again Marian started to feel like there should be something more to his life. And so, caught up in dreams of greatness, he made a terrible mistake.The FeywildIt began, as so many dreadful things do, with wondrous dreams. Marian dreamt of a land of dream, where he was no longer bound with the ties of possibility. A place of colour and emotion that set his mind aflame with inspiration. Since then he has never been sure if she brought the dreams or if the dreams attracted her, he had always quietly hoped the latter.She called herself Amhuir Glamhain, later Marian learned that was actually a Sylvan title: The Lady of Glory. It took some time for him to realise that she was more than simply another dream, but slowly she grew more vital, more assertive, until eventually he could not deny her reality. She made him an offer: come out to the woods at midnight and she would grant him the inspiration he so desired. Marian went, of course, and she delivered on her promise dutifully.Marian remembers little of his time in her domain clearly. Perhaps he engaged in actions of enormity, perhaps he was comatose in a field somewhere. Lucid moments were few and far between, and Marian could count on one hand the number of days he is confident are completely real. Some days it was the vilest tortures, some days halcyon dreams, others grand quests. Dim memories tell of whole lifetimes he experienced, now only a vague recollection, or maybe all he ever had was that vague recollection, left to mock him with what he could never know. ReturningBut eventually, after what felt like both a moment and a millennium, it was over. Marian awoke on a cold hillside, jutting up from a fetid swamp. He was weak, exhausted, and still far from convinced that it was real. So he did nothing. For the rest of the night he just lay there, waiting for whatever vision this was to end, passing in and out of fevered consciousness. When he was found he was barely alive, laying in the grey light of dawn. He was taken in by a woman by the name of Eliza Vance, an elderly fisherwoman who had found him on a walk through the swamps. It took Marian a week to even remember his name from the tangle of lives he’d lived. For months Eliza housed and fed Marian as he recovered, both physically and mentally. It was during these months that he wrote his first full play: Fractures.The Grand PerformanceWith the play completed then came the true difficulty, which was managing to organise a performance as a penniless nobody - particularly one who’d been missing for several years. At first Marian did the obvious, and went around to the theatre troupes of the city, trying to find anyone willing to put on the performance, but without any money to offer such an experimental play was considered too risky. So Marian had to take matters into his own hands. To add to his challenges, soon enough his poverty wasn’t the only obstacle - a high-ranking local cleric of The Lawbearer, Talia Rayne, had heard tell of Marian’s play and become determined that it should not be performed. While exploring some more illicit means of funding for his play, Marian met Mijira Norixius, a woman of remarkable cunning.Together the pair worked for three months, raising money, putting together a troupe, and evading Talia’s efforts to shut them down. It was probably the busiest time of Marian’s life, juggling (not always strictly legal) funding exercises, dodging the increasing roster of people less than pleased with him, and rehearsing for the play itself. Eventually however, it was done. The first performance of Fractures was not exactly met with riotous popularity. It was received well enough, but it was rather too bizarre to be exactly an instant hit. In short time however, it did becomes something of a cultural fad amongst the wealthy, word having been spread by some visiting merchants who had seen the first performance. And so Marian Cullyster was, however briefly, catapulted to a state of near-celebrity. The Current TimeWhatever fame he had soon faded, and after a highly profitable initial tour of Fractures his stardom faded to more a topic of trivia than conversation. It was, however, enough to set him up to continue to travel the country, writing and performing plays in towns and cities across the land. For the next few years his life saw little variation, continuing the same life of a roaming thespian, until his most recent show at last brought him back to Stilben. This, he thought, was a great chance to meet back up with his old friends Ruvin and Mijira, and if they could be roped into performing, well all the better.
Sage
Sage
Entertainer
Repentant soldier turned goat farmer. Invading empire raids his farm and takes his favorite, most precious enchanted goat. Goes on a quest to reclaim his goat.

Distance grew up in the mining district of Oceanward, born to a Drunkard father and A Succubus mother, whom Distance only knew looked a lot like her, Distance spent most of her days sharpening her skills as a thief as well as charming her way out of trouble, should trouble ever find her. Soon after she left Oceanward and took to the sea, sailing on "the Devils Due" an all Tiefling Pirate vessel. Wherein she served as the negotiator, whenever the ship sailed to a more unfriendly port, she'd be the first one off the ship to persuade the local guards to let them sell their wares, using her natural charm to get the crew into town safely. The Captain of this vessel was Dharxik "The Red Devil." A bright red Tiefling, born of a Cambion, wasn't nearly the charmer that Distance was. Dharxik caught her picking pockets, she was brought aboard and became the face of the ship, she later ran away when she grew a moral compass, took a double share of the last haul, then got as far away as she could from the ship.
Her father and brothers were slaughtered by a political rival, now she travels and trains, disguised as a boy, in order to become strong enough to defeat her family's enemies.
A hopeless romantic, she wanders the wilds righting wrongs and helping the helpless while pursuing perfection in the pugilistic arts.
Driven mad long ago by his magical gift, he roams aimlessly, ever on guard against the chickens who cheated him in cards. Sometimes things catch on fire nearby for some reason.
A priest of the god of pain, he became a wandering mendicant in order to learn the pain of the world.
A priest of Blandly, Blandly is a fragment of the One True Mind (Blandly), going where the Dream takes him while searching for ways to heal the One True Mind's fragmentation and help himself awaken.
He fled from the evil Drow to live among the monks.  But when violence came to the monks, he fought back with anger instead of calmness as the monks had taught.  He left to find his own way.

Cheerful and optimistic almost to a fault, Byron roams and plays and increases his mastery of the manifold magics relating to his specialty field, Elemental Earth. Although an ivory-tower researcher by original inclination, he has found induction into an adventuring party to be an exciting change of pace so far, and wouldn't be averse to further fieldwork in the future.

Tarilide and his sister Bess were adventurers together. When his sister Bess died, he had to make a tough decision whether to retire or go on despite being alone. He continued and later he paid a magic smith to create a legendary pick to wage war. This was a +5 pick. Bandits tried to ambush him and steal his pick, but they never succeeded. He eventually retired and became an NPC.

Rosaen became a Tiger Catman after being polymorphed by a wizard. The polymorph had the miscalculated effect of being permanent. He became a famous arena fighter. Later he bought a fancy hat worth 1000 gold and became a pirate. Rosaen always used two scimitars in battle.

Hillary, sometimes called Hillary Banks, was a shapely and beautiful Druid. She often asked her daddy for money, but she was well-educated, and a staunch advocate for animal rights everywhere. As a leader of a small band of adventureres, she is most remembered for the time that she and her best friend Ashley ran away and abandoned the group while they were being ravaged by wild monsters.

A blue Dragonborn born into an influential family of bronze dragonborn, Aurelia never fit in. She was much more interested in explosions and the scientific method than in politics or the machinations of Dragonborn society. She ran away to university and studied for several degrees, focusing on chemistry and alchemy and making things go boom.

When Cadbury was a young Halfling, she desperately wanted to become a wizard. She tried to apprentice herself to a High Elf Wizard named Eddlebin the Perspicacious. He said that he would teach her magic, if she proved herself.The way he expected her to prove herself was to cook and clean and take care of all the menial work around his Wizard tower, even though he had unseen servants. Eddlebin seemed to delight in having Cadbury do his bidding. He never called her by her name and always called her Pumpkin instead. Each time that she asked to learn magic, he would put her off with a series of lame excuses. Cadbury picked up a little magic just by watching carefully, when Eddlebin thought she wasn’t looking.One day, Eddlebin brought home a new apprentice, his own nephew and another High Elf. Cadbury finally realised that Eddlebin was never going to teach her magic and that he had been exploiting her for his own amusement.Unfortunately for Eddlebin, he underestimated Cadbury. After stealing a scroll of Find Familiar, she tricked Eddlebin into turning into an owl and trapped him in that form until it became permanent. Then she turned him into her familiar and named him Pumpkin.After looting the tower for spells and treasures and framing the apprentice, Cadbury cheerfully set off on a life of adventure, determined that if anyone was going to be taken advantage of, she was going to be the one doing it. Luckily, she soon fell in with a lovely band of ***cough-profitable-chumps-cough***brave adventurers.

Waawoo was raised by wolves in the forest. He has no memory of the time before the forest, but his wolf family were all massacred by shape-shifting Wood elves living nearby. Little does Waawoo know that he is the bastard child of the shapeshifters. His parentage is vague but its clear he is half Lythari and half elf but its unclear how this happened as typically the Lythari grow by biting consenting wood elves. (much like werewolves but elves, not humans) How was Waawoo conceived? How is he only half Lythari? Why does he not have typical shape-shifting abilities? Roleplay him to find out.
Blacksmith's apprentice

Briar never knew either of her parents, and all she knew about them was what she had inherited from them physically. Morag always told her how like her mother she looked with her red hair and green eyes. All she knew of her father was that he was an elf, and her inheritance from her father meant that Briar was always very easily identified as a half-elf. Morag never let her feel awkward or as if she didn’t quite fit in, and Briar grew up learning to ignore and laugh off any attempts at shaming her heritage.Briar’s earliest memories are of Morag – Morag cooking, Morag preparing tinctures and ointments, Morag teaching Briar about the world around them and which parts of plants and animals can be harvested to create healing agents. Morag nurtured Briar’s love of cooking and herbalism, hoping to set her on a path of independence and self-sufficiency.When Briar was 5, she found the fiddle secreted away under Morag’s bed. Morag found her plucking the strings, enraptured by the sounds that she was producing with the instrument. From that point onward, Briar was rarely far from the fiddle, teaching herself what she could, seeking out musicians when they visited the town to learn what she could.At the age of 11, Briar met Thia, another half-elf who was in the service of the local blacksmith. Almost without realising it or knowing how it happened, Thia became another member of Morag and Briar’s family. Despite their many differences, Thia and Briar balanced each other out in ways they didn’t always recognise.As Morag grew older and began to slow down, Briar went to work in the local tavern as a waitress. She would pester the tavern owner to let her show off her cooking skills in the kitchen regularly, but her real dream was to get on the small stage to play the fiddle and sing for the crowd. Most of the town had heard her playing and singing at one time or another, but being on the stage was something different. It was almost a need for Briar.And then…everything changed. In one night, Thia made a decision that meant she had to flee the town, and Morag succumbed to her illness. With nothing left for her there, Briar gathered what was most important to her – Morag’s iron skillet and her fiddle – and fled the town with Thia to start a new life.

Fell in love with a light elf. They agreed to elope so they could be together. On the planned day she betrayed him, She only saw him as disgusting dark elf and nothing more. To save himself he had to kill her and her guards. The courts finally caught him and marked his face with the symbol of MURDERER. Since then he's made death his trade. What does race or appearance matter. All that counts is the money.

Gen grew up in a cult until she learned that the cult intended to sacrifice her soul to Tiamat. She refused to die and in retaliation the cult murdered her parents and sister. Gen fled and honed her skills to become an adventurer, but her aunt, a priest of the cult, draws ever closer to finding her.

1 Year ago, Eltar was drugged in a tavern by a small group of cultists in the service of Bhaal, lord of murder.Using dark magic, they convinced him that an evil beast , a Harpy, had come into his homestead, looking to murder his family. They gave him a dark blade (which the twisted cultists had stolen from an altar to Shar) and watched as their devious plan unfolded. The harpy rose up to attack Eltar but not quick enough, he thrust the blade into the monster's chest ... but as his blade sank into it's flesh, the harpy's shriek turned into his baby sister's (tweak) dying moans.The image shattered as he broke free of the dark illusion but it was too late. He could hear the chanting of the cultists now - Bhaal! Bhaal! Bhaal... then silence fell as they realised that something unexpected was happening. A dark rift, a knife wound in the fabric of the material plane, appeared behind his sister ... mist-like shadows began pulling her silently into the rift. He stood immobile - heart hammering in his ears. A satisfied, death-like sigh drifted from the rift and then she was gone. A second passed before a dark, shadow-like humanoid crept from the rift and crawled towards Eltar - a jagged grin appearing on its face. It came to eye level with Eltar, staring him in the eye before drifting onto the blade, allowing Eltar to stab its chest - and as he did, the creature began to flow into the sword until it was no more. Eltar looked ahead, the darkness drifting from his eyes, upon the lifeless form of his sister. The rift no longer behind her - only the cool evening air and deafening silence. A few days later at his sister's funeral, his mother presented him with a travel pack, warning him that the Clan believe him mad, guilty of purposefully killing his sister. They had found no cultists and intended to have him brought to justice. With his final words to her, he told her that he would grant justice to the true murderer's of his sister, and to all who would incriminate the innocent - no mercy, no cruelty, only justice. He had found it impossible to rid himself of the sword, it had become addictive to him, something of alluring power that he knew he could use in his mission. After a month on the road out of Tymanther, the sword  first spoke to him. It promised the power to enact vengeance, and told him it's name ... Belvari.

Damakos was the son of a tiefling commoner and a human nobleman who wanted to keep his tryst a secret. Damakos' mother died when he was a teenager and he confronted his father, who refused to acknowledge their love or even pay for her funeral, and sent Damakos away. He became a rogue and wondered the street for a few years until, after getting stabbed and left for dead, he was taken in by some monks of Pelor, who trained him in the ways of the sun god and introduced him to 'Pelor's Gift', cannabis. Damakos took his skills as a rogue on the road to help those like himself who were downtrodden and rejected by society.

You were born a little over 1000 years ago, when Pandora was not Pandora, but a land called Thay. The world was also not bordered by race, and this now backwater area was once rich with life, natural minerals, and ore. What is now The Badlands was once an ancient powerful city-state known as Netheril. The best and brightest of them all lived their, and the greatest wizards made their name there: Melf, Nystul, Ottiluke, Mordenkainen, Zifnab, and many more. As an undiagnosed and untreated kleptomaniac, you knew your sticky fingers would get you in trouble one day, but you never expected yourself to be bound in perpetual servitude to a God when you pocketed an unassuming rock while raiding a powerful wizard's tower 1000 years ago. This rock turned out to be the 'Stone of Inexplicable Absences', a legendary artifact by The Trickster. It looked like an ordinary smooth rock the size of a fist. On further inspection, it started shimmering with a faint hypnotic irridescence, and the next thing you know, you're several centuries in the future. Some big catacylsmic event happened and you should be dead, but you didn't due to the stone you are bound to. You've had little time between your 'gaps' to piece out some information of the world as time passed for everyone but you:-Netheril is no more, and it is now called 'The Bad Lands', an area that is a death trap.-Thay is no more, and many of the wizard towers are now in ruin, including the one that you swiped the rock from. That tower is in the ruins of Old Owl Well.-There was a local mining town and village called Phandalin that was raided by orcs and an evil wizard cult called "Heirs of The Dark Prince". They destroyed the town, your ally and local lord Aldith Tresendar (also known as Black Hawk) was overrun by orcs in his own manor, and the nearby mine was caved in.-Your last memory: a young healer woman named Nenneke and a half-elf knight named Daran Edermath discovered The Stone near the mine's cave-in and brought you back to a newly resettled Phandalin. You last thought was that you would explore the ruins of the Tresendar Manor (it had been about 480 years since you last saw it) to see for yourself the fate of the Black Hawk.
Small girl from fishing village gets kidnapped by demons to fight in their gladiatorial matches, escapes after a literal deal with the devil
He was an angry chaotic neutral magic user. His order of wizards were all required to wear a certain kind of bizarre hat. You'd be Pistoph, too if you had to wear that hat.

Amras was born the bastard son King Yaevinn of Kahis, in order to escape the persecution of Half Elves in the city he fled the city he joined a mercenary company called the Forsaken he eventually gained the rank of sergeant during this time he gained a few enemies as well as few rivals in other squads. As his name was more well known his half siblings decided to try and remove the shame of a half elf from their family. He fought off some assassins, after this encounter he resolved to prove that he was worthy of the throne and become king and stop the persecution of half elves.

Harland is one of the many adopted children of the Morningstar family. He grew up in a lavish home most of his life, surrounded by wealth. The majority of his days were spent in the family's library, where he and his brother would spend hours reading stories about the gods and magicians. While his brother set off to study the arcane, Harland instead joined a monastary in Ravensedge to worship the Raven Queen. Harland dedicated half of his 28 years of life to studying the Raven Queen, praying to her, and trying to study the moment between death where the soul begins to fade from the material plane.
