Over the past few months, since being reunited at Port Nyanzaru, Hesnu hasbeen training Amon-ra to become a bloodhunter. Secretly gathering materials and gaining the trust of their captives, Hesnu has finallygiven Amon-ra the Hunter's Bane, and with it, new abilities to help himescape. After the captives found Amon-ra writhing in pain on the ground, theybelieved that Hesnu poisoned Amon-ra and killed him. With the help of three other prisoners, Amon-ra killed his captivesand managed to escape with the ship.

From what captain told me my parents were on a ferry that his crew attacked and they sold me to him so that they could live. I remember nothing of them being that I was a baby at the time but what I do remember was a rough life on the sea. I grew fast and became tall and strong at a young age as a result I was he crews designated enforcer. I learned how to survive on the cutthroat seas from my Captain Julius Grimborn. I am no stranger to bloodshed and violence. However after a while the rough seas and the constant sieges on enemy pirates got boring and mundane to me. And one day we sieged a ferry and Captain Grimborn threatened to kill a family if they didn't and over their baby half-orc son and I stopped my captain from killing them after they refused. I was apprehended by him and my other crew-mates and that night I broke from my holding cell, stole a rowboat and some rations and rowed to shore. From there I became a hand for hire and after a while I started doing full on adventures for those who paid the right price.

Miles lived his life as a guild artisan, using his woodcarver's tools to craft instruments and weapons to sell. His instruments were always beautifully crafted, and expertly made. He loves music and dancing, and believes them to be the greatest embodiments of freedom. He is a member of the Harpers, and holds their beliefs to heart. He travels with his group in the hopes of gaining more information about the world, and feeling a little more free in the process, too.He was a guild artisan, and during his time in the trade, he met a dwarf named Amber Gorunn. She taught him how to fight, and he learned Dwarvish along the way. Afterwards, during his time with the Harpers, he met a cleric named Foster. The firbolg taught him much of what the Harpers believe, and he spoke of the truths of freedom and opportunity. Foster even taught him Giant, which was easier as he knew of the Dwarvish alphabet.

Born from a drow father and a human mother, Regis lived with his poor farmer mother for the first few years of his life and learned the benefits of hard work and the plight of the poor. After the death of his sickly mother, his father took him to live with the Drow. His father, a high level Drow, used him as a political pawn and he learned how to manage social interactions. However, at night he took to the streets as a vigilante to help the poor. After turning to 21, I left to become an adventurer and fight for the poor all over the kingdom.

Abandoned by his parents from birth, Zuq Kachiga knew nothing of his identity besides his father's whiskey bottle with his name engraved. Knowing nothing of his lineage, Zuq remained an outcasts throughout his adolescence. In response, the socially shunned elf changed his name, with rebellious spirit, to "Zuq Maddiq." Despite his pitiful upbringing, Zuq found success as a crime investigator and happily established a family life. This success, however, was short-lived. Briefly after his investigation work took down an infamous crime boss, henchmen kidnapped both him and his family. Upon waking up face-to face with his kidnappers, Zuq expressed pure torture as the fiends slowly slit his wife and little daughter's neck. Though he survived the encounter, he did not remain emotionally unscathed. Zuq promptly fell into depression, where his only escape from eternal pain was his father's whiskey bottle.He became a heavy alcoholic, as he appeared to always be intoxicated. Knowing no desire or purpose in life, he sought to feed his addiction in hopes of finally overdosing. This, however, has proved fruitless and he now pursues death through misfit adventures with a rogue, dragon-born, cleric, and a bard. Oh, and he's somehow a fighting Christian monk
Was turned into a newt (he got better).

My name is Chomsky Teren. I am a Forest Gnome from Baldur’s Gate. My parents wouldn’t speak much about where they came from and any time that I asked they shied away from the question and told me that their village didn’t exist anymore. From the time I was young I was always fascinated with any book I could put my hands on. I knew that we didn’t have money for me to go to a mages school, so I went into the “family business” and by that I mean I worked at one of the counting houses until I helped my bosses out of a legal dispute over a silly matter involving some elves and a currency that they claimed didn’t exist anymore. I had been reading the accounting tomes for fun and realized I could help out the company. The company was called “Small Change” a counting house ran mostly by dwarves and gnomes. We weren’t well known, but boy were we reliable. My boss Torven decided that since I helped them out of that jam, they would pay for me to become the legal advocate for the company, I was moving up in the world. As I was learning the ropes at the legal college I met the love of my life. Gorgeous gnome and heck of a gal, Eilissa. In one of the first meetings of our cohort I could not take my eyes off of her. Those swirling blue globes sparkling in any light. After a few years of learning we graduated and soon after I took her as my wife. Her parents were already gone at that time, but my family at the counting house paid for our modest ceremony. Life was good. I was working as a representative for “Small Change” and working towards buying a small house on the edge of the city for us. We were happy and nothing in the world could bring us down. For 20 years we thrived as a couple and finally we were hoping to soon have children. During this time I became a teacher at the school that we both went to years ago. I was one of the best and brightest due to my voracious appetite for books of any and every kind. I started really making good money and Eilissa was so proud. Early in the year 1490 Eilissa started having a deep cough that sounded quite unnatural. We thought it was just some easy malady, something easy to be fixed. We went to the apothecary to find a remedy, and the potions stopped the coughing for a while. Soon the coughing came back and there was nothing the local apothecary could do to help my dear wife. (She had a very high resistance to magical potions and healing you see.) She started coughing up blood in the summer of 1491 around Kythorn. So late in 1491 after trying any remedy available to us, I started roaming the world with my wife. I quit my job and decided that I needed to care for my wife. I took her all over the sword coast, to witches, shamans, wizards, clerics, but none could break this sickness. Finally in early 1492 I was out of money and out of options.My wife’s condition was worsening and there was nothing I could do. I went back to work part time and started saving up for a possible resurrection spell, something I did not want to think about, but something that was very possibly necessary in the future. My wife died on the morning of the Autumn Equinox on the 21st of Eleint. I was in mourning for a week. I could not bear to leave my bed save to relieve myself and to drink. I heard a rumor that resurrection spells were not working and there were problems with bringing people back from the dead. There was a wizard that claimed that he could still perform the spell, but I would have to pay up front. To pay for the procedure I had to use the last of my savings and sell our beautiful little home, but I would do anything to bring my dear Eilissa back to me.I have nothing. My wife is dead and I was conned out of all of my earthly possessions save a few gold, my pack of books, and my pack. I decided that I was going to learn the arcane, I was going to bring my wife back if it kills me. I keep a locket of her hair in a glass bauble around my neck on a thin golden chain. I will fix this and I will bring resurrection back. I started researching this curse and all research leads to Chult. There was an adventuring group going to Chult seemingly to find the source of this curse maybe I can find them and join them in their journey.

The serving-child of an abusive merchant princeling who poisoned his "master" in increments. This mysterious "affliction" baffled chirurgeons and allowed Moth to purge the poison with a topical antitoxin, passing it off as an inherent ability to purge disease with a touch. The merchant-lord, seeing the abused servant as an asset sent him to apprentice with a leechfinder/anatomist named Storax.  Now he plies his trade as a gutter physic and free man on the docks and along the coasts, but is in debt to the merchant-lord for his apprenticeship.

A lone traveler in the night, a priest of no faith, a faithful man who’s lost his hold on the gods; he travels with two eidolons, ghostly companions: they were once close friends and now are slowly deteriorating revenants.
The last scion of the Blackhorn House. His blighted family was eradicated by a band of adventurers while he was handling business in a far-off city.
A mason on the Gilded Way. When the bridge collapsed on the day of Falling Coins his family was torn from his hands, taken with half of the bridge and half of the city. He was left broken.

“Cleric” of Greed & a holy thief that worships an ethereal, primordial giant who embodies the concept of greed. Though not exactly divinely linked with her god, she acts daily in accordance to their concept. One day, she hopes to commune directly with Izolt, the Grinning God Greed, who tithes life and blesses us with hunger.
A  war witch and spellsword with a chip on her shoulder, a penchant for naming blades, and a love for ostentatious hats.

An academic and librarian, Rannoch stumbled into the adventuring life after accidentally walking through a portal in the back of his archive. He comes from a bright, happy world where half-orcs are reknowned for their brains and intelligence and where his family in particular are known to be the sharpest minds of their society. Thrown into a world where half-orcs are thought to be clumsy, blood-thirsty beats, Rannoch is determined to use his wits, magic and determination to save lives, and ultimately return home.

Locke had an unusually charmed childhood as far as dhampirs go.  His mother survived until he was five years old--far too young to remember her, due to dhampirs' slow aging.  Rather than be abandoned and loathed, he was raised by a loving grandmother and aunts, and when they passed away his cousins took over.  As far as Locke was taught, his mother was a hero to be honored and revered, while his father was rarely mentioned.  However, his slow aging resulted in bullying and eventually ending up with a group of relatives who only barely remembered how he was related.  While they didn't reject his presence, he clearly made them uncomfortable.  He had also discovered a talent for the performance arts, and in a group of traveling traders and entertainers, often found himself overshadowed.  So, despite being perhaps a bit too young to strike out on his own, Locke left the caravan and opted to become a wandering bard.On his own, Locke quickly learned that the world didn't welcome dhampirs.  He started out reveling in his freedom, but when mobs with torches and pitchforks or unintended pregnancies became a concern, he adjusted his behavior.  He prayed to multiple good-aligned deities for guidance, and while he never received any direct intervention, he became sincere in his devotions.  He began to focus on being well-behaved, polite, and above all, not scary.  Within a decade or two, he was effectively pretending to be an ordinary human.  As an adult, he is more even-tempered, and cares more about gaining friends than lovers.That said, Locke is still a dhampir.  Though he is aligned chaotic good, being good does not, and never will, come easily for him.

I come from Anchorhead, a small village of fishermen. We're all quite pleasant, and quite like everyone else, but we're a bit like the fish we catch as well. We're also without a village, without our ancient relic, and without freedom of any sort, but I have hope that this will change in due time. Until then, I'll continue to spread the good word of the Father Below, may his strange dreams bring us stranger fortune.

Eva Ava was recruited by a shady organization to become a hero of legend with the powers of old gods, codenamed "Eve." Dissatisfied with the organizations lack of utilizing her abilities, she escaped and took the adventure into her own hands.
That's a personal question, so how about you mind your own business?

ROLLO is a dragonborn cleric who has been with a circus caravan since his birth.The son of the popular strongman performer in the caravan, Rollo shares his father's girth, but decidedly not his attitude -- he's been an inveterate slacker since the age of six. On top of his near-total lack of ambition, Rollo is oftentimes vacant and kind of flaky, which is reflected in his religion: he worships Ao, a God who has never been seen or heard from, and who has never interacted with anything in the universe (to anyone's knowledge). Since there is practically no canonical text to worship Ao by, Rollo has used his faith to spin together various improvised bits of New Age-ish philosophy, all of which seem only superficially profound. If he had to be pinned down on a goal in life, he would volunteer it's "going with the flow" or "being in and around".Despite this (or perhaps because of it), he is an extremely friendly, helpful, and outgoing dragonborn, and thus the members of the caravan in general think well of him. Well to a certain point, perhaps, but well. And not too many members of the caravan say much about his odd faith because it *does* seem to work, after all -- Rollo has shown himself to be unusually talented at healing other people's ills. Never mind that he claims it's because he's been "touched by life".Rollo is a strict vegetarian, and his favorite foods are blueberries and mushrooms. (More the latter than the former.) He also has a great fondness for unusual and exotic incenses, and deliberately goes out of his way to sample some whenever possible.When pressed into combat, he is unexpectedly effective, since strength comes naturally to him, but he maintains his off-kilter view of the world even in battle: he wields two maces, one with a giant peace symbol painted on its head, and the other mace's head is painted with a giant yellow symbol of a smiling face. He has yet to name his two maces, although he says that they will reveal their names to him when the time is right.

Character's name: The Branch that Floats Down the Left-Hand Side of the River
Character's backstory: "The branch that floats down the left hand side of the river", also known as "Branch" to his friends is the son of 2 tabaxi who escaped prison dimension. His parents people had essentially served as food for the giant dragon living in the prison world, and as a result of their trauma, we're perpetuallyally drunk. As a result he was named the branch that flows out of the left hand side of the river, and they adopted a young Dragonborn just because he was shiny. Branch hates that Dragonborn. Upon their death, Branch was made aware of a way to escort his people out of the prison world and spent the rest of his life looking for a way back.

Varis was raised by his father, a scribe for the regional library in Aratheas. It was through this connection that Varis learned to appreciate the knowledge that his father had access to, but yet he never fully committed to. At a young age, around his 40th year, his father was handling some blighted scrolls recovered from the catacombs of Shahabel, a fallen elven stronghold. His father soon fell ill, hallucinating with visions of his dead wife, and died after a painful week of festering sores.Seeing this drove Varis into a dark depression, unusually deep for most elves even after a loss so dear. He became consumed by the loss and sought answers to his father's death in the library's tomes. Four years after starting his search Varis found the answer to his father's death in an unremarkable book, titled The Curious Fungus of Iylelea. It had taken time, but never again would he let someone he loved die from a careless lack of knowledge. The answers to everything were in the parchments, and he would make sure to read everything he could.Following in his father's footsteps he became an under-scribe in the regional library of Aratheas. His fervor for knowledge helped him to comprehend books that elves double his aged had hardly heard of. By the time he was 75 he was promoted to scribe and then over-scribe by 100. Varis was destined to be a scholar, cloistered in dusty rooms over obscure, crusty scrolls his whole life, but events in his 103rd year would change his life forever.The orcs led by war chieftain Shulhug were rumored to be roaming outside there ancestral lands, but no one imagined that they could move so far, so quickly. Varis was in his study when the first screams in the city were heard. He grabbed as many scrolls and parchments as he could and loaded them into a wagon. He didn't stop to inquire about the other scribes, he only cared and was consumed with the preservation of knowledge. Knowledge would outlive them all anyway, just as it outlived his father. As Varis passed the ridge on the edge of Aratheas he looked back to see the city smoking, and the famed library, his home for over 50 years licked by flames.The screams faded into the distance as Varis drove further into the heart of elven territory. When he reached the next city it became clear he was the only survivor of Arathea. Well, him and his two dozen books. He looked at his cart, a measly scrap of what glories were now lost in the dust. He thought of his fellow scribes, abandoned by their friend and left to be flayed by the orcs. The shock of the situation had worn off and now he saw his actions in full day and was filled with the same sadness that he felt after his father's death. He sank to his knees and wept. When Varis looked up he saw the unsleeping eye of Helm on sign above a door. He walked towards the chapel as in a trance. Inside was a cleric of Helm, who offered absolution to Varis in exchange for a lifetime of service--a deal accepted readily in the moment, though questioned many times since. Varis became a cleric of Helm that day. With his vast knowledge he rose through the ranks to become second in command of the regional Helm order. He now is zealous to become first in command, which can only happen if he has exploits to boast about. Exploits in which it is clear that Helm protected him and is with him. Varis has put his scholarly pursuits on hold for the last 20 years as he tries to fight for glory and honor, in the hopes of one day reigning supreme in his order.

Hailing from clan MacGregor, young Dougal proved to be a particularly brash and outspoken young lad.  His mischief was often overlooked until he was caught quite literally with his pants down entertaining the chief's daughter.  Dougal was chased out of his homeland, but not before his father handed the family greatsword and some words of advise to his son.  Now let loose upon the world the young man seeks a place to satisfy his youthful ambitions.
Born to a family of storytellers in a remote mountain village, Jaden left to find treasure and sexy ladies.

Hansom was randomly selected to participate in a royal warrior academy, but failed out and became a potato washer. He learned the hard way that you should never agree when your girlfriend asks you if she looks fat.
In west Philidelphia

The father was a beloved priest of Pelor.  He took in his charge the tiefling street urchins who were shunned, seen as fiendish spawn.  To the worshippers he told them of forgiveness, but behind closed doors the children in his care saw no such salvation.  He taught them to smile and sing praises as they were lashed and toiled towards atonement.  Penance learned to wear a sweet face and speak with elegance, but there was nothing behind the mask he wore.  However, the father's words held true, evil must be atoned for, and there is much evil within the masses.  A simple word or two was all it took to turn brother on brother.  Thus the father found his end underneath a thousand scornful lashes, and brought a tiny smile to the empty face behind the mask.

Bronwin is a traveling storyteller and musician, but is perhaps most well known as a champion drinker. Inns throughout the vast land of Faerun have been held captive at the bar, as Bronwin drunkenly tells another tale of heroes, dragons and great battles. Bronwin is also the brewer of the famously strong mead "BANG! Mead", known in dive bars and guild halls throughout the land. He travels the land in his mobile brewing wagon. He has been enlisted by the group as a guide to the land, knowledgeable about travels on Faerun's roads. Bronwin Bangmead sees this adventure as a chance to be witness to another great story, and perhaps spread Bangmead into new markets. And if he has to get his axe a bit bloody on the necks of a few giants, all in good fun! "Oil the udders! SPANK ALL THE MAIDS!"
Former assassin before trying to redeem his past actions
Disinherited gentry turned troubadour, charlatan, and free-trade advocate. (Lawful Evil)
Wanderer searching for treasure and prestige before returning home.
Traveling stage magician pretending to be a real mage.

Ijya grew up in a society in which all crimes are punishable by death. As a child she was caught stealing food to survive. In cases of young children the death sentence can be waived, if the local monastery of Illmater decides to take in the child and once they come of age release the child to perform some quest of penance. Ijya is currently on such a quest.

Azalis grew up in a small village of forests elves, having very minimal contact with any outside societies. She was trained from a young age in the art of druidcraft: however, she was not born a natural in the art. There were several moments I her youth when she made simple mistakes; once she mistook an edible berry for a poisonous one, and was ill for several days, another time she had placed a burning herb over an open wound of one of her friends- she was mocked endlessly over this event. Eventually, she moved out from the village proper, but was still within a days walk so that anybody in need of her services may come. One day, while meditating on the power of nature, she felt a disturbance in the fell magic that surrounded the land, and set out to seek the sources, hoping to gain it's power.
Noble

Hugo was born in a temple, his mother a priestess to a goddess of pleasure.  Like the other children his father was one of many patrons that passed through, but it is likely he was of a non-human nature as Hugo was born "touched by fire".  His spirit, too, was quick tempered and passionate.  A meeting with a like minded gentleman let to his departure from a confined life.  This mentor taught him to fight, flirt, and flaunt.  Eventually this lifestyle would claim the life of Hugo's father figure, but has not discouraged the man of fire from forging his own legend.

In a time before arcane history, before humans could do magic without direct assistance from a deity, Soren Sarkynyt was born. Soren was a troubled child, born to His older brother Kai was born with obvious draconic traits, a manifestation of previous draconic ancestry. His deformities caused the other children to ostracize him, and this extended to his family. After enough bullying, Kai retaliated and killed another child. He was exiled for it, and Soren was left even more lonely, with the hatred of Kai leaking over to his broody younger brother. Soren spent his free time in a nearby forest, just enjoying nature, and trying to befriend some of the animals. At the age of ten, he fell asleep in a tree one day, dreaming of flames emanating from his body, and when he woke up the forest was aflame all around him, with handprints scorched into the wood where his hands were, but he was unburnt; fire danced in his blood, and he felt new channels of a mysterious force opening in his body. Soren had become a monster of some kind. He managed to escape the flames, but had no way to fight the fire, so he ran. His hometown was a logging village, and he had inadvertently ruined a good portion of their livelihood for the season. Knowing that the villagers would not believe that the outcast would not have done this purposely, Soren decided that he would run, and let everyone believe he had died in the blaze. He ran, and made it to the nearest city, where he learned to live on the streets. He found ways to use his new tricks to his advantage, panhandling and performing small tricks for change, stealing when necessary. When he was 17, Soren was finally caught and arrested. Rather than lose his hands, he opted to join the local military for service to work off his debt to society. Soren requested an audience with General LeClezio, showing him his abilities, whereupon he was placed with a group of "special forces" who take on specific assignments that the main army is ill-equipped for. This is where the story begins.

She was born in the city of Janderhoff into a smithing family that venerated many dwarven gods. At a young age, she began to aspire to be like the church priests and took to the study of metallurgy and dwarven history with great passion. However, she found she was not improving, and so took to he World in a search for a new path. Her journey to the Five Kings Mountains, however, had little to no effect on her skills. Dejected, she returned home, but in the way heard her younger brother, in the city of Korvosa, had been defamed for failing to protect his child. She journeyed to the great city to help him reclaim his reputation.

She was abandoned by her human parents and adopted into an order of warrior monks. They believed her to be the reincarnation of a great warrior, and trained her in martial arts. Now she is embarking on a pilgrimage to see the world.

“To crush your enemies,To see them driven before you, andTo hear the lamentations of their women.”The wisdom of the legendary Cimmerian was indeed helpful to any aspiring Barbarian, but Fronan wished with every ounce of his 3’ frame that Conan had also left behind advice for Halfling orphans who fainted at the sight of their own blood.“It is not safe for the boy,” a voice as gravely as a stone golem’s backside said.“Since when has a Barbarian’s own safety ever influenced his decision?” The second voice, perhaps not as rough as the first, but just as strong, belonged to his mother, Varelen. Fronan peered around the thick boar skin that served as a barrier between his room and the house’s central common area.“Since the sight of his own blood rendered him weak as the people from which he came.” Rendar crossed his arms over a chest covered with grey hair. “I know you love the boy; I do as well, and you cannot gainsay me. Do not forget who it was that convinced the tribe to keep him.”“Then why?” Varelen hissed in a harsh whisper. “Why send him away if you love him so much?” The Barbarian woman took a slow, deep breath to calm herself before continuing. “Rendar, I will forever be grateful to you. You convinced the Council to allow me to keep Fronan. You fought with me to allow him to train with the other children. But if you insist on this nonsense of sending him away, by Crom, I will show you just how strong a Barbarian maiden can be.”Rendar sighed and inclined his head. “As you wish, but if he fails to bond, I am not sure I can keep the Council from doing forcibly what I am suggesting he do on his own. If Durnjak wins the High Seat, there is nothing I can do to keep Fronan safe.” The seasoned Barbarian warrior ducked under the tent flap and was gone.Now, several months later, Fronan wished his mother had listened, wished he himself had stood up and made his own decision. But he had not, and both Rendar and his mother hunted with the ancestors, struck down by Durnjak when they fought the Council’s decision.Fronan peaked into a belt pouch to check on Jonathan. He slept. Though weak and fragile, Fronan loved this strange creature, the only one he had ever been able to bond. Perhaps, somehow, with training, magic, or the luck of the gods, Jonathan would grow strong. The small ship creaked around him, and Fronan tried to sleep. This new group of companions could be just what he needed to help him fulfill the wishes of Rendar and his mother. Perhaps, with their support, he would defeat the man (not necessarily human) with three eyes, murderer of his first, halfling family, and overcome the weakness that had kept Fronan from protecting his second, human family.Fronan laid his head back against his pillow, dreaming of a mighty Jonathan at his side and the look of fear on Durnjak’s ugly face as Fronan returned to crush his enemies, see them driven before him, and hear the lamentations of their women.

Alton was a happy man, a successful performer who settled down on the outskirts of his local village with his wife and had a son. One day, he went into the village, and, when he returned, a barbarian had burned his house down with his wife and child inside. He found their skeletons, his wife's ribbone cracked from the attack and blackened with soot. He fashioned a bone flute out of his son's bones and vowed to try and find vengeance on the one who did this. Alton wandered for around 20 years, before running into the Drow Arch Necromancer Cal, who took him in and taught him his ways for 15 years with the promise that Alton could resurrect his loved ones. Cal later threw him out, telling him that he could never be a necromancer. 5 years later, Alton had managed to awaken his latent magical abilities and met up with an adventuring party, who were soon employed by the Stolzkernian royal family to seek a magical amulet which would cure their lands of a 40 year sickness. As they travelled, and his companions discovered what magic he practiced, Alton grew seperate from the group. Eventually, when in an ancient city under the desert sea, Alton discovered a portal to the underdark which, he hypothesized, would give him the material component for the resurrection spell he sought. In order to attain this component, a black diamond, Alton sacrificed his right forearm and a curse was placed on him, with a black corruption slowly consuming him from his stump up. After freeing a Monastary from an invading force, Alton killed two beasts, and for the first time, held onto their souls as the passed through him on their way to the afterlife. These last two events shook Alton and he began to see the darkness he had surrounded himself in. On their way to meet with a Viridian Lady who knew the location of the amulet they sought, Alton ran into a travelling priest of Pelor, Alton's old god, whom he had renounced when his family perished, who told him that he might be able to speak with them through the light of Pelor and, Alton, not yet strong enough to speak with them by necromantic force, began to try this. When they reached this Viridian Lady, she told him of the curse he was under and how he might be able to reverse it--he would need the help of one familiar with the magic of the Underdark, his old mentor Cal.....

Born "Venn Silverquill, as a child, Oberax preferred the company of dwarfs to his high elf kin. As a result he often skipped school to consort with his dwarf friends, competing in the rock crushing games of their traditional mining games.Finally having been caught by his parents he snuck out and ran away, becoming a miner. After several years becoming the most successful elf miner of the past millennium, Oberax began to pine for something more. It was then that he had the dream that changed his life.He dreamed of his teacher, Orion Feathered Tiger, a forest spirit who beckoned him to become his apprentice. Oberax spent the next seven years searching the jungles to the South for his mentor, finally finding him as he took ill and almost died...

My story began at 19, with a book that I found, I was traveling to the nearby village of Rathernway to trade the crops my family harvested that month. When I reached the village, after trading, I felt a presence in my mind pushing me towards an alleyway, intrigued at the possibilities I followed the voice to the end of the Alleyway and found a book. I picked the book up, and an influx on knowledge rushed in to my mind, the book disappeared and a voice boomed inside my skull "Good, you have taken the first step!" I then promptly fainted.I woke up that evening to the knowledge of the power of the Warlock, able to fire Eldritch energy from the palm of my hands, also upon closer inspection, I found a tattoo had appeared on my back. I travelled back to my town that evening and found in the week that I had been away the town had literally vanished, and no one knew of the town at all, every time I mentioned the town of Forgehaven I would get blank looks and pointed stares.

xenora was born on the outskirts of a smaller town, and was practically a plague upon her mother. she was a delightful little girl, but it seems that many small towns are not too happy to have neon blue devil’s spawn in their midst.her father was a pairaka, a succubus of sorts, and his heritage in her is quite obvious; blue skin, demonic eyes, horns on her head, a long pointed tail, sharp nails, and long pointed ears. while the last of these is a trait of elves, they are still considered a little strange when your mother’s whole family is made up of humans.xenora was always rather naive to the town’s feelings, having been sheltered as best she could. never sent to school, her mother did her best to teach her how to read, how to write. she was always quite fond of music, and her mother doted on her as best she could. she’d go into town and spend her meager wages on things for her little princess, buying new strings for xenora’s lute and purchasing any sheet music she could get her hands on.as xenora grew up, it became much harder to keep her in their home, and her mother began allowing her to go into town somewhat regularly. she grew much more familiar with the uncomfort of those around  her, but did her best to ignore it. she spent her teenage years as a performer, perfecting the art of tumbling and playing various instruments. she earned some coin and did her best to help her mother, a seamstress. when xenora turned 16, a package arrived on their door. it was very large, wrapped in heavy paper. upon opening it, it was discovered that it was a gift from her grandmother- but not her own mother's parents, they had died some time past. this was her grandmother on her father's side- it spoke fondly of her granddaughter, having apparently kept an eye on the young girl growing up. it wished her well to her future, asking her to come visit someday. it was a strange gift, really, a lute with keys across it. xenora was, of course, delighted. she named her new instrument jenny and spent weeks mastering the play of it. her mother was cautious of it due to the source of the gift, but was not one to deny her princess.a couple years after, having turned 18, xenora set off. she was unhappy to leave her mother, but she wished to further her career, and a small town wasn’t the best place to do that. she bounced from place to place, making what coin she could playing in taverns and sometimes as a street performer, showing off her acrobatics and musical ability.not too long ago, she found herself in with a traveling group of musicians, and she played with them for a while before realizing that they were not only musicians, but thieves. she wasn’t entirely comfortable with it at first, but she leaned into it after a while, picking up her own tricks. one night, while some of the group was playing, the rest of the group was caught stealing from the patrons of the tavern they were in. xenora escaped, but most of her group was arrested. xenora moved on from the town quickly, doing her best to make space between herself and it.
Born a poor farmer, he turned to banditry to survive. After a near-death experience, he received a vision from Sarenrae and became a paladin in order to atone.

A small, young kobold with dull red scales examines her small herb collection, tapping one clawed finger on her snout thoughtfully.  Patches of her body here and there show leathery red skin where she's missing clusters of scales and from the flat top of her head a crop of small horns protrude haphazardly in different directions.  She picks up two little pots with 'drakeroot' and 'moon-pepper' scrawled on them in blue cave-ooze ink, sniffs one then the other, goes to place one back on the shelf, pauses... and then changes her mind again.  Just then, the voice of Cram, the Bonesnapper clan's chief comes screeching from outside the kitchen.  "Kip!  Hurry the skeg up with the food, we need to go out scavenging!""Sorry, sorry!"Her ears flatten and she scurries over to a large, simmering pot and quickly but carefully measures out a pinch of moon-pepper which she sprinkles into the pot.  She holds her paws up to the warmth of the fire below, closes her eyes in concentration and traces a circle in the air with a claw.  After a moment the fire roars and the flames pick up, causing Kip to smile as the pot boils and bubbles enthusiastically.  Just then, Cram jerks his head through the kitchen door.  "Come on you little scrotling!  I've told you about pratting around with the food!  Just BOIL THE SLUGS!"Kip ducks behind the counter and peeks between a sack of dried crickets and a pile of tattered books.  She stammers "y-yes chief, I'm sorry!"Cram snarls and yanks his head back into the corridor, nearly knocking over a young boy as he storms off.  The bright-scaled kobold boy rolls his eyes at Clam then strolls cheerfully into the kitchen. Kip's ears twitch happily as she recognises her brother.  "Hi Bunt, I've got something new for you to try, I hope it's ok".Bunt's eyes light up and he licks his fangs. "Smells great.  Don't worry about Cram, he's nervous because the big boss lady is making some kind of deal with a visitor right now"Kip slops a steaming spoonful of the slug stew into a bowl and piles some sad-looking, wilted leaves on top.  "A visitor?  I wonder if that's the person she's been getting letters from.  She normally gets me to read all her letters aloud to her and then dictates a reply for me to write back but for some reason she wouldn't let me near these ones.  I suppose that's ok though, dragons do like to have privacy."Bunt reaches for the bowl but stops as Kip sheepishly gestures for him to wait.  He scritches thoughtfully at one of his shiny black horns.  "Well I wonder if she'll let this visitor leave without setting them on fire or eating them this time."Kip covers the top of the bowl with both paws and closes her eyes again.  When she removes her paws and wafts away the steam, the previously sloppy lumps floating in the stew are crisp and brown and the leaves are a luscious green, curled into small canoe shapes that float on the surface.  "Ok it's ready."Suddenly, a voice booms from beneath the caverns.  Much, much deeper than Cram's... Less of a screech and more of a firm, confident rumble.  Nevertheless, Kip instinctively cowers behind the counter top again."KIP BONESNAPPER!!"Bunt puts a gentle, well-kept set of claws on her back.  "You better go, seems the boss lady wants you.  This looks delicious though, thanks Kip."When Kip enters the chamber, the familiar but always majestic sight of Ysnoth greets her but this time the dragon's normally disinterested scowl is fixed intently on Kip, eyes narrowed.  Next to Ysnoth, dwarfed by her impressive size stands an unfamiliar figure.  A sharply-dressed dragonborn with a green-eyed doberman standing to attention at their side.Though the dragon's voice resonates deep within Kip's gut, Ysnoth speaks gently and deliberately like a cautious diplomat.  "Kip, my faithful servant.  I have come to an agreement with this... person.  You and your brother are, as I'm sure you know... a little different to the rest of your clan and you will be leaving very shortly to be tutored by this person's associates to achieve your full potential.  I shall speak to your brother seperately.  For now, go and start gathering your belongings immediately.  And Kip... don't forget the books you 'rescued' from my discarded treasure".

Lady Imogene n'denGina 'Brightwalker' a female elven paladin of... Erastil??Erastil holy symbolWhat? Why?HOW???Ooh, well, it would start - I believe - with the tales I'm not supposed to have heard about my mother, and I have been hearing them from a somewhat young age, thanks to my nanny, Pefantica... how she loved to gossip!I'm told - and told by those who should know - that I take after my mother to a quite alarming degree, and that the fervent hope of my extended family is that in a few centuries I'll settle down and study the tomes of arcane & divine lore and become a mystic theurge just as my parents have.Until then, though, I'm still a youth - though not by any accounting a maiden! - I'm unattached, unbound, unpromised and now I am out experiencing the world, though experiencing it a lot more first hand than my father or brother would ever had permitted, had they known of my plans!I have mother to thank for the fact that they don't... I still can't believe that she hid my pregnancy so well, she's truly amazing. And... now I think about it... I am aware of a few year long absences of my mother that I know about, and ... there are many more, now that I have made some discreet enquiries.Gosh. My mind is quite boggled. . .Wow, mother dearest... that's a lot of ploughing that has happened in your field! How many half siblings am I likely to meet on my travels and travails? I think I am sure of at least four... and maybe several more!Nevertheless, with her example to lead me, I'm far more certain, now, that I'm on the right path!And that path is helping those of less fortunate birth than I, which is why I'm a paladin of Elastril.Living in Brevoy for several decades convinced me of the true nature of my desires to serve the greater good by living as an example of what should be, rather than what is. What should be is freedom to live a natural and wholesome life that doesn't ask for more than you can give, and where you don't take more than you need. Less procedural, more pragmatic. Tolerant and accepting of change, rather than rigid and unalterable.You share as needed, charity is rewarded and encouraged. Mutual obligations, rights and respect are what bind a society together.That's why I eloped with the human merchants and, kind of, how I became pregnant with Erianis half a century or so ago. My they were good carefree times... Oh that party... it only lasted a week but gave me a lovely child who will last, well, her lifetime if not mine...  if only I knew which one of the merchants was her father... oh well, it's not really that important, what matters is that she's here now, enjoying life thanks to their and my momentary though many moments of passion! Besides, they're all long dead by now, poor short lived humans.Pregnancy. It's quite a sensitive subject amongst elven society, a half elf child - any pregnancy is a sensitive topic, really - not that children out of wedlock - or species - are illegal or even immoral, just frowned upon ny elves of my families acquaintance. So Eriana is an unacknowledged child of mine, as to not bring shame upon the noble elven name of n'denGina... long may they flourish. It's likely the God's wish that elven women are far more fruitful with non-elves than elves, who knows? As yet, not I. Hmm, I might make some enquiries about that. Or... not.Where was I? Oh yes, I'm a paladin, lawful as well as good. And a paladin of a God recognised as human. And... I'm elven, not human! And a woman, presumed maidenly. It's... it's like the shorter lived races don't even begin to realise that an elf feels everything they do, but for centuries, not mere decades.Erastil taught me pragmatism, not poetry. Accomplishments not artistry.  And survival not sophistry...He taught me things that matter here and now, to enable survival in the here and now. No elegant semantics about Natures balance, the wheel of time, eugenics, and the guidance planning of the 'lesser' races. Just simple, basic and common sense guidance and knowledge about how to survive, how to build and how to prosper.That's what I want.Prosperity.Prosperity for that which I consider under my guidance.I shall bring these lands under my, our, loose guidance to bring to them the prosperity that they can offer. I'll guide the farmers to farm the fertile lands, the woodsmen to crop the forests, and give the townsfolk the wisdom to plan ahead, to store water and food gathered in the good times and to keep some in reserve for when times - inevitably until paradise arrives - get tough.I'll help make laws to bring profit, honour and respect to the travelers who trade goods between outposts, to the farmers and artisans who create those goods, and to the merchants who gather, collect and organise the transfer of commodities between each layer of the nation, slowly binding the land into a bond of mutual and bountiful trade that brings benefits to all who live in the Duchy of Novus Kyonin!By my honour:Imogene nden'Gina, known to some as Imogene Bright WaterPaladin of Erastil.Duchess of Novus Kynonin.-=-=-=-=-=-=-=--=-Imogene Brightwater's family:Illegitimate child: Erianis Heartgazer, half elf, female, 55 years old, whose Human father died 50 years ago, father is unknown to child and even I don't know his name or lineage (it was a GREAT party and a really awesome week, though, wow....!)Imogene's father, Inneash Darkspear, doesn't know of this child (or the long dead human father/s) nor does my brother, Tanae Bloodseeker. Tanae's a bit... odd, and more than a little forthright, but means well. Couldn't even be chosen by a non-derivative nickname though, and that's public, which is more shameful than my hidden halfbreed child, according to most etiquette I know!My mother, Ralaehen Sunseeker, knows of Erainis, since she helped hide my pregnancy, birth and 15 years of raising my daughter.I don't keep in regular contact with my daughter, but we do try to catch up every few years, liaising through my mother. Erianis
Geisha madam  opening a franchise of brothels.
Courier and messenger from Sigil
Wild child who ran away from her aristocratic home to join up with pirates.

Noomi is from a small island society. She is capable of entering a dreamlike state and communicate with the spirits of her ancestors and the spirits of nature. She is sent to a convent as a young girl but soon starts questioning the religion they preach. She decides to listen to her own visions and dreams and sets out on a pilgrimage of her own, sailing from island to island and helping those in need.

Ioviel the Autonomous was the 15th in a series of 25 experimental warforged granted wings and a divine mission by the Church of the Silver Flame. She was tasked to go into the world and purify it, and she pursued this task tirelessly and without introspection. On the day her maker died toward the end of the Last War, she had a personal epiphany that led her to forsake the church, but not her values. Now she travels the land pursuing justice for the downtrodden and peace for the unprotected.

Cookie is a from the forest called The Cloakwood. She eats psychadelic mushrooms and has visions. She is trained at Candlekeep by the wizard known as Marlon the Magnificent, the two become lovers and travel the world together. Later in life she assembles a group of adventurers because she has a series of visions that involve all of them and vague impending doom.
Arius's noble family was framed for crimes and driven from their home by necromancers

Akacheta, or Aki for short, was raised in a flock of other Aarakocra high in a mountain range. He and his father were ostracized from other Aarakocra and lived alone on the outskirts of their rural village. Aki's father suffered from visions of threatening spirits, and often fell into fits of hallucination and fearful screams in public. However, his father wasn't the only threat to the peace. An evil organization of monks, the Monks of the Long Death, made their home not far from the sanctity of Akacheta's village. Seeing Aki cast out from the population made him their next project. The monks' leader, a nameless, ancient Kenku man, approached young Aki during one of the many instances he was entirely alone. The old man put a mangled wing around the small bird's shoulders and croaked a string of horrible words into his ear. From that moment on, Aki was never the same. He became even more finicky than before. He was paranoid that he was being watched. But he wasn't able to remember the Kenku man or what he said, or even what he was really afraid of. The rest of the Aarakocra just saw it as Aki following in his old man's footsteps. Eventually, Aki's father's condition deteriorated, and on his deathbed he made Akacheta promise to never become like him and to never be so afraid that he cannot live. At the time of his father's death, Aki was nearing adulthood. It was at this time that the Kenku monk decided it would be best to take Aki under his wing, so to speak. When approached, Ali was neither afraid or at all unhappy to see the man. He only felt compelled to comply with his wishes. After years of training by the Long Death monks, and after his mind became clearer and sharper, the monks' hold on Aki was deteriorating. He became aware of what was truly happening in that awful place. The monks weren't just a group of creepy self-proclaimed outcasts, they were all devoted to the same goal: finding a way to prevent death itself. They studied victims intensely, keeping them teetering on the brink of death in order to observe the process. Aki was naturally horrified by their purpose, and regained full control of his thoughts and actions. He used his newly-sharpened skills to fight his way out of the monks' hideout and never looked back. However, once his mind was no longer clouded, he began noticing a figure almost always at the edge of his vision. He heard whispers when he laid his head down to sleep. He slowly came to the realization that this was his inheritance; the very same visions his father had described. But he refused to become fearful. Instead, he fought his own fear by ridding others of theirs. He became a sort of mercenary, and travelled across the land devoting himself to relieving the world of its evils. For a price, of course; a man has to make a living somehow.

I am Sebastien Devanagali, gambler, traveller, exquisite dresser and participant in the great tradition of free enterprise and the self-regulating market, basically that what's yours could easily become mine, for free. From the day I achieved my majority and was sent out into the world to seek my fortune (accompanied by my sainted mother's blessing, admonishing me not to return home, I presume until I'd made my name in the world, God love her) I have travelled far and seen much. Much has happened to me since that fateful day on which I touched the white chest of the Warrior Rune and experienced the vision that has led me here.

She was somewhat of an odd one being born with the ears of a fox yet still being mostly human and even though the old legends say thay those born with fox ears are destined to become great hunters the other villagers treated her badly because few still believe the old legends and most have fallen into darkness and then after years of being treated badly because of her unique trait she eventually decided to leave the village starting a new life in the woods to become a lone hunter with plans to eventually come back as an expert hunter so she could prove those who treated her badly wrong

As a small child, Cricket -- not his given name -- was the sole survivor of a kobold raid on his village. He was found unconsciou by neighboring villagers, but surrounded by a half-dozen kobold corpses. He became withdrawn, distraught over his family's death. At the same time, word of his precocious martial feat spread, reaching the ears of a small band of mercenary warrior monks called the Hawks. They came and offered to take him and teach him their fighting secrets. At the monastery, Cricket blossomed. He became talkative and friendly, finding in the Hawks a new family, and was known as much for his good humor as his extraordinary talent as a fighter. He was given his name, "Cricket," for his incessant chirping; for his small, dark frame; and for his ability to leap about the practice field. He eagerly helped brew and drink the Hawks' beer, and his accordion was a lively addition to the merry music-making of the elven monks. As he grew, he started going with the Hawks to defend villages of wood elves from bandits, beasts and monsters of the forest, and always-encroaching human woodsmen. He learned quickly, and become a deadly tool against the evils that threaten the elves. And then his life turned upside-down, again. He was sent to bring a message to a village elder in the next valley, but when he returned all the monks were gone from their compound. They vanished, with no signs of where they had gone, or what their fate was. Cricket now wanders the land, looking for any sign of his brothers and sisters. And in their honor, and in honor of his village and family, he defends the commoners from any evil he sees. He also loves to play his accordion at weddings or funerals or solstice balls, and drink copiously. Word has spread of the talkative elf, and commoners are always glad to see him.

Born to a fishing village ale-draped, Ravenwood always dreamed of having power and wealth. He became a petty thief and confidence artist- little scams and cheats to accumulate what wealth he could. Then one day, a stolen trinket introduced him to an emissary of the Brass Empire and he was offered great power. He is deeply insecure, wearing the finest clothes and jewelry he can, and presenting himself as wholly mercenary and venal- but he really isn't as bad as he likes to pretend he is.

Bjorr is the eldest son of a well-known and wealthy beer-making family with political and class aspirations. Feeling that the time is ripe for a bid to join the dwarven aristocracy, Bjorr was trained in the noble martial arts and sent out to the world to make a reputation worthy of induction into dwarven society's elite. Bjorr himself loves everything about beer and beer-making, and in another life would have been delighted to settle for the life of an ordinary and accomplished brewer. However, his loyalty to his family is paramount, and he has vowed to not return home until the accolades necessary for upward mobility are his.

Nameless does not know his history. His earliest memory is stumbling out of a cave, wearing expensive, delicate clothes and clutching an ancient abstract figurine carved out of a rock. It depicts a faceless woman with enormous belly and breasts, and is the token of the spirit he has bonded with -- a nameless mystical force of life and fertility. The figurine hangs around his neck. Nameless wandered the wilderness, seeking out the agents of death and corruption and battling them, following the wordless commands -- bolts of inspiration and intuition -- of his Mistress. She gave him a sprite to keep him company during his isolation. He calls it "Jennifer," but he doesn't know why. Perhaps it's related to the reason he kept the scarlet waistcoat he was wearing when he emerged from the cave, carefully protecting it as the other clothes he wore disintegrated under the elements. Nameless wears the waistcoat under the leather armor he crafted from the skin of a possessed and rabid panther he slew. Occasionally, a flash of red can be seen under his black armor. After years, he has emerged from the wilderness, and he doesn't know why. His Mistress will guide him. With his tangled hair entwined by twigs and leaves; wild, filthy beard; rough black panther armor; vacant expression; and long silences interspersed by savage outbursts, Nameless is hopelessly out of place in civilized areas and looks like a dangerous lunatic to most. However, if you have the courage to approach and converse him, you will notice an intense earnestness that immediately earns your trust. He is not insane; he knows of things you would dare not know.

This is technically from Pathfinder, but it was too good not to be told. I randomly rolled for a backstory, so this may sound absurd.Falkalor was not any ordinary Halfling. He was a bounty hunter, a damn good one at that, he wasn't the same kind of cheery and affable little folk many Humans and others may be accustomed to; Flakalor was raised by dragons. According to the dragons that appointed themselves as his mother and father, his true parents were slaves in a far off Kingdom called Meed. They escaped one night, running as far away from Meed as possible, they hitched rides with Halfling caravans and went to many different kingdoms, preforming and selling wares to the common man. Eventually, Falkalor's birth mother became pregnant with him, the two could not be happier. However not all was good. Not too long after his birth, soldiers from the kingdom of Meed arrived in a town that was in the clutches of the wicked Elvish king, they were there to collect new Halflings as slaves. His parents made a break for it, his father was struck down with a crossbow bolt, and his mother barely made it to a nearby forest. There she hid for what seemed months on end, becoming weaker and weaker due to a terrible illness, she prayed to Desna the goddess of luck, to bring forth someone - anyone to care for her child. A grand roar rolled over the mountains and hills and a massive dragon landed before her, it polymorphed into a Halfling man. He walked over and spoke in the common tongue."Desna has heard your pleas. Fear not, your child shall be safe within our care.""I didn't think dragons answered to gods and goddesses...""Not all, but dragons whose hearts see more than material possessions and destruction are often alligned with the gods, it is... A mutual benefit."Falkalor's mother hesitated, kissed her baby's forehead and handed hi to the dragon."Thank you... Praise be to Desna..." She said as she walked into the woods to die peacefully. Many years passed by and Falkalor was trained by the dragons to speak Draconic and to fight. He became well versed in swordplay and so decided to leave the cave he called home to use his skills for the better of the world. In his adventures he ended up exposing the corrupt Elvish king, this landing a bounty on his head. He remains within the shadows and still hunts if the coin is good enough. He has no alignment to anyone but his family, and if he were to feel they were in jeopardy, he'd kill the client without hesitation. He now roams the world of Azeran as a sell sword, earning money and keeping his family legacy alive.

Hoi had made the journey from Baysgate to the North Country many a time, working on deck as a sailor for the SS Marianne, a merchant vessel carrying goods to and from Baysgate.One day, the captain of the Marianne was being pressured to speed up the boat voyage. The merchants and cargo he was transporting was worth a massive amount of gold, and they were concerned with missing a Full Moon Festival to sell their goods. Against the captain's better judgement, he sailed the ship directly into an oncoming storm. It was then a  sea monster ambushed the ship and tore it to pieces. As it began to pick off survivors, a massive thunderbolt came down from the heavens and severely wounded the creature, causing it to retreat without even touching a single sailor on board.Hoi looked up. The clouds were already parting, and yet the thunderbolt had came and saved him regardless. As he swam over and clung to a piece of debris, he swore he saw a shimmering dolphin say, "you're welcome."His chance meeting with Father Ripplelake was caused by Hoi going on a drunken stumble through the streets, rambling about how no one would believe that he and his crew were saved by the "shiny golden talking dolphin."After sobering up the following morning, he discovered that Deep Sashelas had saved his life, and perhaps even chosen him to be his cleric.Heart accepted, as he felt grateful for the god who saved his life. Father Ripplelake then mentored him, teaching him the Elvish language, martial proficiency, and how to be a divine conduit.Hoi is now a holy man, repaying whom he believed to be Deep Sashelas, the elven god of the sea by serving him.The rest of his faith, and even Father Ripplelake to an extent, sees Heart somewhat suspiciously, and even with contempt at the idea of a human attempting to worship and Elven god, when they and only they have ever truly heeded His teachings. Deep Sashelas does not curry the favour of many followers, the hundred-year-war causing surface dwellers to turn their attentions and prayers inland than beyond the shores.And the followers Deep Sashelas attracts are almost all Elven, or of Elvish descent. The other races tend to far favour the teachings of their own gods.Heart understands the contempt towards him by the fellow members of his faith, but he largely has decided to ignore them, hoping to prove his own merits as a rightful cleric of Deep Sashlelas and spread His teachings by example.He cannot persuade the world by words, and he lacks the force of a paladin. But he can live as a cleric doing good for the Duchy, and he knows that with enough good deeds and glory, he will not need to speak for the world to follow.
A Guy with curse that He canto feeling fear

After the tragic slaughter of her family in an orc raid, Primyn found ways to survive through the pockets of others. She has traveled along the coast of Faerun searching for a place to call home. Taken in by a noble paladin, she is learning to mend her ways and find a second chance at having a functioning moral compass.

As the eldest child of the Marquis Jerron Wyderbox, Lady Althea, first of her name, has led what could mildly be described as a charmed life. After the loss of her mother, Althea came to shadow her father more closely, adopting an interest in the martial arts and discarding her music lessons in favor of sword play. She felt confident that as she grew, her father would cast aside the tradition of the patriarchs before and name her as his heir. However, with her father's recent marriage and a new baby on the way, Althea feels her place is no longer secure. She has set out into the world to prove that she is worthy of the title through deed and valor.

Born a nagaji, Jade and her siblings were caught in an explosion in an alchemist's lab. Jade and her brother were transformed to kitsune and their sister's color changed. The two kitsune were exiled from the village, and their sister joined them to protect them.

Left on her human father's doorstep, toddler Nadia was raised by him and her step-mother. Both of them loved her very much but when she became an adult, Nadia set out to find out what happened to her mother.

Freed from slavery when a revolution transformed her country to democracy and slavery was outlawed, JenJen joined the church of the god of freedom. She went out to share his message of freedom for all folk.

Born to a drow mother, raised to be a human sacrifice, Amber escaped. Eventually she made her way to the surface and was taken in by the church of Eilistraee. She strives to bring her mother's folk to the light.
Travelling to find out more about her mentor's death.

A quiet and withdrawn woman, due to her years in isolation, Ulrica often keeps her own council. But such reserve should not be taken for meekness, as she has been known to channel the wrath of her patron goddess, Selune. Accused of a crime she did not commit, Ulrica escaped the overbearing hand of her elven father's family to Kryptgarden Forest. Here she first discovered the song of the moonmaiden, the goddess Selune. She pledge an oath to seek out the last of the goddess' Silverstar warriors and the fate of their legendary Moonblades.

Born into a large family Kelwin was the third and last son ofa moderately successful merchant family. While his elderbrothers and sisters learned the family trade Kelwin had thefortune or misfortune depending on who you asked to beborn with powerful arcane abilities. Upon realizing this (hehad an uncanny ability to know what was for dinner) hisparents sent him to the local college of wizards.Upon acceptance into the college he was enrolled into theDivination School of magic which he had a natural affinityfor. In his spare time Kelwin would devour tomes andtreatises on magic and spell structure (the denser the better)from Human, Elven, and the occasional Dwarven orDragonborn scholar. His life revolved around the study ofthe arcane which he delighted in. And for many years thatwas enough.But this was soon to change. During a lecture Kelwin wasstruck by a vision of a grave threat reappearing into theworld. The vision was so powerful that he lost control of thespell he was demonstrating. The spell snapped it's restraintsand began draining arcane energy from the surroundingarea until it exploded devastating the lecture hall and injuring many of the attending students. Upon hearing Kelwin's description of the vision the Archmage of the College placed him on temporary sabbatical to seek out the source of this vision and if possible put a stop to it.This is how Kelwin found himself on a rickety merchantvessel called the Sea Dragon heading away from everythinghe'd ever known in his life on a journey with no certain end.

Character's name: The Merciful All-Knowing God-Emperor Drothan the Invincible
Character's backstory: Raised as a founding in the temple of a god of knowledge, Drothan proved as quick a study in the magical arts as in the martial. Upon coming of age, he left the temple to join a criminal organization. Soon, though, his life as a petty criminal and an enforcer ended as his home city was destroyed by a vengeful lich. With a handful of companions, he set out to find the lich's weakness and destroy him--a quest that lead him across the world. In his travels, he united a nation's orcish slaves through promises of his divinity and led them to overthrow their enslavers. With a new nation of orcs at his back, he and his companions fought and killed the lich, but were hurled into the hells of Baator by the lich's patron--a god of supposed good and justice.Drothan and his companions set about carving out their own domain in hell, and soon rose to significant power. Their standing rose even more when Drothan discovered the secrets to becoming gods themselves. He and his companions spread throughout the lower planes and amassed what power they could. Finally, they deemed themselves ready and challenged the fallen god in his new center of power--the Cliffs of Madness and Eternal Disillusionment. The battle was hard-fought, but they emerged victorious.Drothan still reigns from his throne in the Gray Wastes, and has taken the position of his former patron, who was killed by the fallen god, as the new god of knowledge. He seeks ever after more knowledge and power.

Her father is a human potter, her mother a semi-famous witch and adventurer by the pseudonym of Brimgard. Her mother left the family when Adara was still relatively young to go adventuring. Her current whereabouts are unknown. Adara went to a school for the arcane arts on a scholarship granted to her due to her talent and the renown of her mother, but was expelled when she inadvertently manifested her slumbering demonic powers and hurt another student. She knows just enough magic to be dangerous, but is committed to unraveling the mysteries of the arcane craftsmanship her mother left behind.
Army brat. Fathers was a soldier. Mother was camp laundress.
Orphaned at a young age, Raised by a master bard who trained him, Recruited by the Harpers,Sent on a mission

Myka has a flexible sense of property rights, and thinks that if you let rules get in the way of doing what's right, then you're an evil fucker. She's the sort of friend that would help you burn your own house down.The only thing that's certain about her is that she's a liar.  Ask three of her friends where she was born, and you'd end up with four different answers.  The people closest to her know when she's telling the truth because that's the only time she sounds like she's lying. Take the following with that observation in mind.Myka grew up in a human village with an absent father.  The common folk never really gave any mind to her lineage, but those 'in charge' sure did.  See, they had rules.  Some applied specifically to elves, and Myka have one foot in both worlds, ended up at the mercy of those in power who decided when which rule set applied to her and when it didn't.  She learned early on that laws are just words, and can be used just like any other words, to help or to hurt.  Mostly they're used to hurt; to hurt the common folk, to keep them poor and indebted.There was an orphanage in her town run by a retired ranger of some sort. An older man ill-equipped to tend to children, but still gamely trying.  There was no law that helped him or the kids.  One of her friends lived there, and one day she went with her to visit and play.  It wasn't until she left to go home that she realized that the never *opened* anything.  The entire facility was open to the world. Myka approached the old man and asked why that was, and he said, "Well, I'm building this place myself.  Walls and a roof are more important than doors.  I've build it so that most of the rooms can stay warm, and the common area can stay cool. Whenever we get the supplies or can afford them, I'm sure we'll get to it."  Well that was some bullshit, she thought.  Her house had at least THREE doors.  That night, while her mother slept, she disassembled front door to her house, dragged it to the orphanage, and left it leading in the aperture.  It wasn't until she was almost home and saw the empty doorway that she realized just how angry her mother was going to be.  She thought quickly, if her house had had three doors, surely those large fancy houses in those places she wasn't allowed to go - because rules - would have even more to spare.  It was already late, verging on early morning, so she didn't have much time!She snuck out and up over the walls intended to keep people like her out, and discretely tapped at windows until she found one loose enough to open wide enough for a door to be dragged through, and empty enough not to be caught immediately. Fortunately, these homes were way to large for the number of people living in them, so finding an empty room was not much of a challenge.After removing the door, shoving it out the window and back over the wall, damaging but not destroying it on the way, she managed to drag it back to her home and install it.The next morning, she realized what was wrong: the door was way too fancy for her home and stuck out.  Never mind her mother would have - and did - notice immediately.  And despite the space population density in the richer part of town, the residents did in fact notice that an entire door was missing, a window was open, and things were torn up.So she ran.  Grabbed the few things she thought she would need: some clothes, a knife, a sack of food, and she ran.  She lied her way into a caravan, and... well, here we are.  Where are we going again?
A dwarf cleric who's village burned down, seeking peace in a small woodland town.
An elf who was enslaved as a child, now seeking peace in small woodland town. She has few friends, but loves her dog and gets along just fine by herself.

Mother was human, died 30 years ago when Bryn was 6. Father was an unknown elf, presumably a moon elf. Bryn had a reasonably privileged, if distant, upbringing by an adventurous scholar who was always away on expeditions. Bryn used the access to books to learn about elves, planar mysteries, and various languages and cultures. At boarding schools and such, Bryn learned to avoid the notice of others when necessary, since there are some prejudices associated with being half elf. Bryn has a “don’t actually care” gender identity, and so will not mind whatever gender pronoun is used to refer to them. They were sorted in as male where the sexes were separated in school, but that time is long past. Bryn’s name is a child name among the elves. It predates Bryn’s adoption, and was presumably given by their father, about whom Bryn has no other information. This is a large part of why Bryn has not chosen to adopt a human name or an adult elven name, even knowing that their publications in research journals will seem to be written by a child from an elven perspective. Bryn’s research was ostensibly about extraplanar creatures and those touched by extraplanar entities, but they were discovered to be using local myths and cryptid stories as serious academic sources, even if the person giving the tale appeared to be insane. This nearly destroyed Bryn’s credibility and only a few colleagues have remained in touch. Bryn, mindful of how tenuous this position is, has refrained from mentioning to any professional colleagues that they found a way to harness the power of Dendar to acquire warlock powers.

Mortimer was born a farmer near the frontier between Past and Alexis. After his parents were killed by bandits when he was 6, he was adopted by the local priest of The Mountain, who was unsure whether or not he was Mortimer's actual father. He was raised with the goal of becoming a priest of The Mountain. When he was 13, another bandit raid on the village claimed the life of his new family. The new tragedy, and the memory that resurfaced with it, made him loose his sanity. He ran off into the woods and refused to let anyone approach him for several years, learning to live off the land. In time his mind settled into a more manageable schizophrenia with witch he struggles to this day, living on the edge of society, and trying to serve the will of The Mountain whenever She speaks to him.

Brother Aegis carries the faith of universal life and connection between all, embracing the god-head that is the interconnection of all things.  Aegis brings healing to those who need it and closure to the loved ones of those beyond his aid.  His kind manner and patient ways play against many traditions of adventurers, yet with every step Aegis honors his connections to the web of life.

Dagda was called to serve the Ki-Rin master against the darkness as all men in his line had before him.  This was a secret he had to puzzle out for himself from the cryptic journal his father left him in his will.  Now he plumbs the depths of the Underdark, bringing light to the darkness and a swift end to the evil that lurks in the depths.

Born in a village where everybody literally just rang bells all day, Rive grew tired of the sound of bells and slowly went insane until one day she snapped and straight-up murdered everyone in the village. To this day, the sound or mere mention of bells sends her into a murderous rage. She also collects goggles.

He always wanted to be a warrior, but his rich parents forced him to become a wizard. At the school, he was at the top of his class, but hated every moment of it. After schooling, he was hired by an adventuring group, but after one adventure as a wizard, he cemented in his mind how much he hated being one, and quit. When he gor back, however, he found that his parents had been killed in a goblin raid and left all their money to his brother, so now he is trying to make it as a wizard, as that is all he knows how to do.

When Stel was seven she was brought to the Dragon's Pool monastery after he family died due to a plague spread through her entire clan whiles their caravan were celebrating a festival to Yondalla and Dallah Thaun. Her master, a wood elf named Qinelis Mossmire, was a hard but caring teacher. Qinelis taught Stel the arts of medicine, clothcraft, and martial combat; his attempts at teaching Stel restraint and patience seems to have gone over her head, with Stel being particularily "intreagued" with men - but yet still happy with women. Stel's best friend is her 200lb mastiff K'alvin, whom she found as a puppy and adored as he was the only thing smaller than her at the monastary... he is no longer smaller than her...Stel has completed her training and has chosen to travel the realms to use her gifts to help others. She refuses to wear shoes. Stel can't remember how she got to Dragon's Pool, but she dreams of being carried accross the sea. Stel maked clothes and bathrobes for visitors to the hot springs at Dragon's Pool.Stel never knew her father but her mother had told her that Jak is a trader of great renown and was traveling in far off lands. Her idea for the travel cart came from his famous trader cart, which she imagined to be like a palace on wheels. She hopes one day she will find him and see his great wagon.Dragon's Pools is built onto the side of a dormant volcano on the island of Ruathym, although the erruption has always occured on the far side of the mountain. It was once home to a Silver dragon from Shou Lung who took the form of a Shou woman and the name Wen Xiao, Wen Xiao. Wen Xiao passed on her knowledge of the martial arts of Shou Lung to a number of accolytes. Wen Xiao had the bath house built on the hot springs to help fund the monastery.Master Qinelis Mossmire is around 450 years old and is in poor health.The only thing left of her family is a tiny gnome-crafted music box that plays a song she dimly remembers from her childhood.
A protector of a reclusive group of druids guarding a haunted ruin.

Sly was a servant in the BloodBlood goblin clan. During Sly's formative years, the clan was under the dubious leadership of Scrapper OrcBlood, a huge, violent, and dim goblin leader.Scrapper led by fear and violence, and led the clan into a series of devastating conflicts. In each one, Scrapper would savage the opponent personally, but the small, sickly BloodBlood warriors would be easily handled by any opposition, leading to heavy losses in the clan by attrition.Meanwhile, Sly was learning to grovel, bargain, wheedle, and snitch. After anothe devastating defeat, Sly collected the remaining clangoblins in a group assassination of Scrapper after a long night of celebratory drinking.From there, Sly attached the dwindling clan as servants to a succession of other goblin clans, slowly gaining strength and skill and keeping his brethren alive as each of their host clans collapsed from varied calamities, and now has finally taken the rejuvenated clan, along with the scions and refugees of other destroyed clans, and struck out alone.
