Titus is a young man who left the family farm with a desire to join one of the many storied mercenary companies criss-crossing the map.One day he appeared in a local town, alone, wearing a rusty suit of armor, carrying a chipped sword, and a bright orange banner.He claimed to be the last surviving member of a once-gloried company known as the Order of the Blazing Sun. According to his tale, the company was destroyed in a battle with monsters, and he survived only because the banner's hidden magics had protected him, and he was slowly unlocking its arcane nature.Now, none of these statements could be verified by anyone, nor could the existence of any Order of the Blazing Sun. Either way, he is now committed to returning the Order to its lost glory.
shunned by both sides of his family he turns to a life of crime at a young age eventually joining the Thieves Guild.

Dun, short for Dunce, pronounced "Dum" in his own mouth, is a young half-ogre whose mother died in childbirth.He was raised by his mother's widower, who abused him, as he blamed Dun for his mother's death. Dun was sweet and eager to learn and be helpful, but was told he was slow and clumsy (and named "Dunce"), and by the time he was ten (standing more than five feet tall and weighing near two hundred pounds), he was spending his days as a laborer, making money for his guardian.By age 14, now six feet and three hundred pounds, he was finally driven from his home, and began to work for himself as a laborer, earning his bread and sleeping in barns, which he does not mind, as the larger spaces are more comfortable, and he likes the animals.

Raised among the clans of the Axe Mountains, his career as a mercenary began once it was relatively clear that there was no room for a competitor in the sorcerous circles of his home. He endeavoured to join the Bloody Axe Mercenary Company as a way to see what greater wonders the world offers and to escape the petty concerns of the local chiefdoms. Since then, he has become a valuable member of the Company, fighting in countless war actions on land and sea.

There is a turtle waiting for me in the water.I am only just becoming a woman and I am alone on this island with its strange plants and noisy frogs and jagged reefs and there is a turtle just outside the cove. It is a giant, and it will eat me whole if it catches me.I am surviving.In the dark in the hold of the ship I must be quiet or they will find me. It is not the ship I used to call home, it is large and well provisioned. I do not eat more than I need, do not take anything that might be missed. I breathe with the waves like mother taught me. We have been at sea so long and I do not know where this boat full of strangers is headed but I will not panic. If I only take what I need, if I stay quiet, they will not find me. I am a child and this is my life now.The sun on the island is hot and bright and the sea and sky stretch out forever. The nearest island is a faint spot on the horizon and I do not know its name and couldn’t swim that far if I tried. I am alone and I do not know how to make a boat and there is a turtle in the water as big as a hut, that rests on a sandbar just outside the cove at low tide, and I know it sees me and it knows I see it. It is waiting for me to make a mistake.I am a child and I am hiding in my mother’s trunk and I am very quiet while the man who named me yells at her. I have to stay out of his way. She tells me later that he is a good man and he takes care of us and we would not have food or a place to stay without him but I hate him anyway. He makes her sad and afraid and he named me a bad omen and when the other men come they talk with him and give him coins and I have to hide.His name is Indomitable Typhoon, and I am going to kill him.Ursoni Bright Eyes holds me on her hip. I am young and the world is large and bright and the city streets are crowded with merchants and travelers and so many people rushing from one place to another. Ursoni pretends to cry and tells the strangers that she needs money to feed me and I’m supposed to cry and say that I am very hungry but sometimes I forget and she hits me when we’re away from the crowd. I am always hungry. Ursoni wears a rag over her hair and sometimes I forget I’m not supposed to pull on it and she gets angry with me. There are other beggar children on the street, no matter what street we walk on. The vendors shoo us from their carts, wary of thieves.My hair is turning blue in the sun. So many years hidden away in the holds of ships, only coming out at night to peek above decks or transfer from sea to land or ship to ship, my hair had turned black as pitch. Now I am in the sun every day and it makes my skin brown and my hair blue, and there are no people here, no one but the frogs that chirp “ko-ki” in the night and the turtles that meander through the reef and up the streams and sometimes carry the little frogs on their backs in the tidal pools, and the turtle in the deep that is waiting for me.I am surviving.I am a child in bed with my mother. The sheets are soft and the blankets are heavy, the mattress is worn but comfortable and I sink into it a little. I never want to leave.The door slams open and a man stomps in. He grabs me by the wrist and I cry out in pain and surprise.“Leave her alone!” my mother yells. Indomitable Typhoon yanks me out of the bed and releases my arm, launching me into the wall. Instinctively I duck and lead with my shoulder, bouncing off with only a bump. He glares at me as he takes my place in bed, black eyes tinged with red from too much rum and shouting.I am supposed to leave when a man is in mother’s bed. I never forget this one thing. I skulk out quietly, shutting the door without a creak. I have to go somewhere and hide and be quiet. There is a turtle waiting for me in the water.I imagine myself asking him where my mother is. I could not find her on the ship. I imagine myself tying him to a chair, beating him, making him cry. I imagine letting him see my face, making sure he knows that it’s me as he dies. I imagine a lot of things.The room is dark. He does not know I am here. I will not ruin my chances by giving in to curiosity or spite.The knife feels heavier in my hand than it really is.I hit the water badly. The men who threw me overboard laugh as I bob up to the surface, proud of themselves for finding the stowaway. It is the first time I’ve been caught out. I thought I was quiet enough, careful enough, but now I am in the water and there is an island in the distance and if I do not reach it I will surely drown.I don’t look back at the men again. Getting to shore is the only thing that matters. I am surviving.“I can’t take her any more,” Ursoni Bright Eyes says. “She’s too big now, I don’t make any money with her.”My mother frowns. “The ship is no place for her.”“Then send her to an orphanage, or sell her,” Ursoni insists, shoving me away. I start crying, but she just shakes her head and leaves.“It’s alright, Red Sky,” mother tells me. “We knew she wouldn’t be able to watch you forever. You’ll just have to learn how to get by on the ship.”I nod and rub the tears away with balled up little fists. I am too young for this.At first I think it is a normal turtle nearby, but the water here is so clear it takes a moment to realize it is a giant turtle far away. Far away but getting closer. I swim with all my might towards the island, it is not far away now. Even if the turtle is racing towards me, even if it is a creature of the deep and I am already getting tired. All I can hear is the sound of my arms breaking the surface, my own gasping breaths. I don’t dare to look again below or behind me, it will cost too much time. I can see the shoreline clearly, there are trees and rocks ahead. “She is too young for this!” My mother yells. I am hiding in the trunk and I hope he does not look for me in here because I’ll be cornered.“You spoil her. The girl needs to work,” Indomitable Typhoon says.“Then let her work in the kitchen, or on the decks. She’s good with a mop and she’s a fine eye for a lookout…”“I don’t need a lookout, or a scullery maid! Now you bring her to me or I will have her in shackles on the next ship bound for the Wild!”“I don’t know where she is,” she lies. “You know that girl is always hiding herself away.”“You find her, and you bring her to me,” he growls.I have to keep quiet.My hand hits the sand and I scrabble onto the shore, disoriented and unsteady on my feet. The turtle is behind me, pulling itself up easily on the land and lunging towards me, enormous mouth open wide and full of spikes to pull still-living prey down its gullet forever. I run and shimmy up the nearest tree, turtle snapping behind. It breaks the trunk I am climbing and I have to jump into the branches of the next tree, grasping desperately.The turtle is so large if you made a bed of its shell five grown men could sleep comfortably without touching. Its eyes are like cannonballs, huge and black and impenetrable. Its shell bears scars from things too terrible to imagine, marks from the teeth of sharks and the hooked suckers of giant squid and the beaks of octopuses, and another deep gash that looks like nothing more than an enormous sword wound. It has survived things I cannot imagine. It is still surviving.The hurricane comes and I am not ready for it. How could I be ready for it?  Three seasons on this island and I still don’t know how to start a fire or braid a strong rope or build a boat. There is never enough water, I survive on fish and gulls and jackfruits when the trees deliver them, but the trees know the hurricane season is on us and there are no ripe fruits to steal. The crabs have all left the reef and the fish are cowering, and I have nowhere safe to be.There is a turtle waiting for me in the waterThe wind is too much and I am carried off my feet and far into the sea, the waves choppy and gray under the dark sky. I break the surface badly, plunging into water choked with debris churned up from the depths and washed out from the land. I can’t see.“You have to go away,” my mother says. “You have to leave the ship and never come back, do you understand?”“I can hide,” I say. “He won’t find me.”“You cannot stay. Hide on another ship.”“But mama!”She shushes me. “Do you want him to find you here? Do you want to be taken away to the Wild?”“No, mama.” I don’t want to be crying, I want to be brave.“You must be quiet, you must be careful,” She says. “I have a water skin for you and some clothes in a bag, it won’t be too heavy. Always make sure you carry water with you on a ship. Never drink the sea water.”“Yes, mama.”She opens the porthole and hands me the bag. “Hurry,” she whispers. “Be careful.”I climb out and dive into the water. Even with the bag, I barely make a splash.I am surviving.I throw the turtle a jackfruit. He gulps it down, then butts the tree with his head. I pull another of the yellow-green, bumpy fruits away from the trunk and hurl it down, catching a faint whiff of the syrupy sweetness as he snaps it in half. While he’s busy rooting in the sand for the rest of it, I jump to another tree. He groans, belatedly, and starts shaking the tree I was in just a moment ago. I have to keep moving. It’s hard to keep quiet in the canopy, but I know I’ll be safe if I just keep moving a little longer.I’m all turned around, the hurricane water is all around me and I cannot see the island or the seafloor it’s nothing but gray sky gray waves and I sputter and choke when I mistake one for the other. I try diving down to find the bottom, thinking if I can find the slope I can follow it home. It’s dark down here and I don’t know if the turtle is around but I’ll drown if I stay out too long. Even below the surface the waves are strong, but I can handle this, I can do this, then something too strong comes and I am tumbling my head my head my head I can’tIt is dark as night in the hold of the ship.“I’m scared, mama,” I whine. I clutch at her skirt with my tiny hands in the dark. “I don’t want to stay down here.”“Hush, Red Sky,” she says. “There’s nothing to be afraid of. We’re alone down here, just you and me and the rats, and the rats are so much smaller than a big, strong girl like you.”I don’t feel big and strong. I miss Ursoni and the market.“The dark is nothing to be afraid of,” she says. “You are the scariest thing in this room.”In the dark, I plunge the knife deep in his chest.I wake up on the shore, the storm clouds still overhead but brighter than before. I cough and gag salt water, turning to let it all out, gasping for fresh air. I was in the water… my head… I find the sore spot with my fingers and wince. Must have hit it on the rocks in the cove.Something is breathing on me.I turn and the turtle is there. Its head is so big I could curl up inside, its nostrils flaring wider than my fists.I don’t scream. I have to be quiet.The turtle nudges me with its snout, mouth closed. Why hasn’t it swallowed me whole? Why am I on this beach? My forehead burns, bright golden light blaring out, illuminating the dank little room like midday. Indomitable Typhoon looks at me, horrified, as the glow intensifies, building up in a towering aura behind me. Glittering feathers drift to the floor and fade to nothing, peeling gently away from the wings of a great, golden albatross.“Bad omen,” he laughs. He sputters, and there is no more.I dive in the water, not knowing what to do. The turtle is there waiting for me. I expect him to be afraid, but he swims right up to me and I grab onto the edge of his shell tightly. He still trusts me. We swim for hours into the open water, until my glow begins to fade and the sun begins to peek above the horizon.Stowaway. Murderer. Urchin. Anathema. Red Sky At Morning is right.

(Notes: Both names derived from Old Norse: first name pronounced like the English word “scare,” last name pronounced ees-kvAl-r. Don’t ask me why they pronounce h like k before a v, but they do. Also, "Martian" refers to being from our campaign world's sea-faring country of Mars, not the irl planet.)Sker was born the same as all Martians, on a boat. Now I could lie, and wax poetic of how he entered the world in the throes of a raging storm, amongst a tumult of waves and wind that threatened to rip the very clothes from your back, and this was to be an omen for his rancorous disposition and later druidic calling… but the truth is he was born on a clear day in mid-summer, and his early childhood was quite uneventful. No one can say where his surliness came from. To outside observers, he seemed to bear the weight of the world on his shoulders, and the weight of ice in his heart, although anyone who cared enough to see past his exterior quickly realized there was no malice behind his barking. Still, his hard abrasiveness was enough to earn him his True Name.Dwarves of Mars do not name their young at birth, but prefer to wait and watch until a True Name arises that fully encompasses the individual’s core. This first name stays with them always, as a label of sorts, and it is unthinkable to shorten it or alter it in any way. Over time, dwarves may earn additional names commemorating moments of personal growth or achievement. Their full name is their full story. “Sker” is the dwarven word for a small rocky protrusion jutting up out of otherwise calm waters, and that indeed is who he is at heart – a solid, stubborn mass sticking out like a sore thumb amongst his peers; a hardened, inhospitable one-man mountain impeding the natural flow. Yet, though he is a dedicated curmudgeon, he also exudes a sense of unwavering strength and competency, with his words as wise as they are biting, allowing him to act as a firm anchor point for those willing to trust him.(It should be noted that non-dwarves who meet him usually assume his name is a purely physically-descriptive moniker, claiming his dark stocky frame looks uncannily like a rocky outcropping when he is treading water. They are not entirely wrong on that point.)He earned his second name as a wee lad of 26 years. The story goes it was the dead of night in the dead of winter, and he had just stumbled onto the deck of the ship in a drunken haze, carrying two bottles of dwarven ale and singing loudly of the many ways the rest of the crew could bugger off. At the peak of his accompanying gesticulations to this little ditty, he lost his balance and fell right over the side of the ship. Though the sailors on night watch tried desperately to locate him amid the chopping waters, it was as though he had been swallowed whole by the sea.Nine nights later he was found by a passing trade ship, floating unconscious in the ice. When he came to, his skin was completely numb, his head hurt, his joints ached, he had difficulties hearing, and he claimed to have no memory of what had transpired during his time in the sea. The merchants wrote it off as a case of the bends coupled with extreme elemental exposure, and went about trying to track down his kin.Later, back on board his ship, his family noticed he was different, changed beyond just a simple case of decompression sickness. The merchants’ healer had alleviated his physical symptoms, but still the partial hearing loss persisted with no apparent medical or magical cause. He also seemed eerily calmer than normal, quieter, gazing out at the water with a faraway reverence that no one could explain. It was clear he remembered something, but he refused to talk about what happened. Over the course of the next few weeks, rumors abounded on the ship. “He was punished by the gods for his terrible demeanor and even more terrible singing!” some said of his partial deafness. “No,” others joked, “he almost died, but the ocean saved him because he offered it two bottles of our best ale!” Still he kept the truth to himself.Despite his injury and the ordeal he went through, he couldn’t wait to get back into the water; it was almost as if he felt more comfortable there than on the ship. It was only when he started publicly correcting the elders on matters relating to their surroundings, matters he should only have a passing knowledge of (their maps of the region, the local environment and weather patterns, the sea creatures they encountered… ) that they started suspecting what had really happened.Their suspicions were confirmed when, while their ship was under attack by a band of pirates, he unwittingly shot ice from his hands in self-defense.  As the pirates turned tail in fear, it was clear to the wisest of the ship’s leaders that Sker had formed a mystical connection with the frozen ocean, and was able to channel its power and magic to his own ends. They gave him the name “Íshvalr,” meaning “whale of the icy waters” (inspired by that great Jötunn of legend), to mark his new life as a creature permanently tied to the sea and the elements.Since he was still a child by dwarven standards, his parents felt uncomfortable sending him off for training, so they instead invited a respected druid by the name of A_albjörn Sævarr (pronounced ah-thahl-byurn sai-vahr, and meaning “noble bear” “defender of the sea”) to travel with their ship and instruct the boy in the basics.So life continued for a time. Eventually, Sker, a quick study, mastered all there was to be taught, and A_albjörn recommended he seek out further guidance from the Order of Benthos, the largest association of druids in that region of Mars. His parents grudgingly consented, knowing there was nothing more they could do for him, and recognizing that a rookie magic user on board was more of a liability than an asset.Thus it came to pass that Sker saw out the rest of his childhood on an unmarked forested island bordering Althean waters, deepening his bond with the natural world and learning all he could from the small conclave of masters there. During that time he never managed to endear himself to an animal companion, or any animal, really, since they seemed to react to him in much the same way as the people he had known. Instead, he grew to worship the ice-covered ocean, seeing its neutral coldness and harshness, which somehow still managed to support the lives around it, as a reflection of his own temperament.At 40 he was conscripted into five years of naval service, the standard for all who come of age in Mars. He found the strict discipline and chain of command antithetical to his nature, and constantly butted heads with his superiors. At the end of his required tour, he was happy to part ways with the military, and they were happier to see him go.For the past 18 years, he has hopped around from ship to ship as a freelance sailor and cartographer - sometimes on a fishing vessel, sometimes engaging in underwater prospecting or dungeoneering expeditions. He has gained the nickname “The Irascible Old Man,” due to being brusque and hard-of-hearing. Though he is generally seen as unpleasant to work with, he is recommended based solely on his skills and wide range of magical abilities. Also, there may or may not be a running bet at the local portside bar to see how long crews will put up with him.Catchphrase: “I don’t give a goshdarn damn!”

Jaspermunk Hildybin Bibbertyfimble had always wanted to be a pirate.  The only hitch in this aspiration was the fact that good girls did not run off to become salty sea dogs.  Her parents tried in vain to interest her in the noble arts of illusion and engineering, but Jaspermunk jokingly used what little magic skill she had to thoroughly annoy her siblings instead of taking her studies seriously.  After shaping her dancing lights into a ghostly humanoid to scare and chase around her little sister, using ghost sound to produce phantom pirate catchphrases such as “Arrrrr” and “Aye-aye captain” while her elder sister was trying to read, and making all of her younger brother’s food taste like fish and barnacles with prestidigitation, her family finally gave up on dissuading her.  She longed to leave the cursed Dwarf-occupied town of Bibbertysnoob and set off towards the high seas (maybe even exploring far away continents).  She was tired of listening to Dwarven epics about how each warrior had managed to fell “50...no 100!” Drow each, and she was equally tired of the stench of Dwarven ale that hung about the city like a plague-ridden fog.  As if that wasn't enough of a reason to get the heck out of Dodge, there was also the little “incident” last year when a large chunk of the city was carved away by a burning beam of death, due to the incompetence of Koshka and his band of bungling brethren. And the girl who tagged along with them in their shenanigans managed to get herself eaten by a sea-beastie in the process... not an entirely intelligent course of action. Jaspermunk was sure she could have done a much better job of handling the situation if she had been old enough at the time.  Recently, Japermunk finally got her chance for real adventure.  She was enamored of a group of experienced adventurers that were passing through the town, and resolved that through swash or buckle, she was going with them.  Comprised entirely of humans and elves, the group laughed and patted her on the head when she approached them, mistaking her for a much younger child.  That night she snuck out to their caravan while they were in one of the taverns, and stowed away within the luggage.  Upon awakening, she sheepishly gazed up into the eyes of four very angry humanoids, but decided to stick to her guns and put on a brave face.  She told them that she would become the greatest pirate ever to sail the seas, and that if they let her stay she would fight boldly and not even request a share of the loot.  They looked into the adorably hopeful face before them and sighed.  They explained that they had journeyed to Bibbertysnoob to meet up with a friend of their employer capable of high level magic.  While she had slept in, the entire group and their gear had been teleported to a jungle far from her town, and that at present they did not have the time or money to get her safely back home.  They grudgingly accepted that the only solution was to protect her for the time being, and try to get her home after the mission was completed.   She discovered she had fallen in with a group of treasure hunters retained by a human nobleman to seek out lost magic items and artifacts for his collection.  Their current goal was to find a specific scythe, a relic hidden within the temple of a long-dead religion.  She was to follow alongside the party closely, and learn as much as she could from them to protect herself.  They had no small-sized weapons to loan her, so she was stuck grappling with a too-big rapier.  To their surprise, she got the hang of it relatively quickly, and was soon wielding it with an uncommon grace.  Jaspermunk explained that she was simply destined to be a pirate, and that the art of swordplay ran through her veins instead of blood.  As they hacked and slashed their way through the wall of humidity and vines perforating the jungle air, the group told her stories of the original inhabitants of the temple and their monkey-headed god.   They laughed as Jaspermunk perched on top of a nearby stone performing a close approximation of said deity, puffing her cheeks out and holding her hands out for tribute.  Over the course of the three-day journey to the temple site, their initial anger subsided, as her continual antics had the effect of increasing the groups’ moral.  She also proved rather more capable at combat than they had anticipated, for her agility and speed far outweighed the hindrances of her size and strength.  She helped slay tigers, panthers, reptiles, and other assorted jungle fauna, and managed to dodge out of the way of poisonous gnome-eating plant life.     Jaspermunk was overcome with awe as they finally made it to their destination.  A dilapidated mountain of carved stone towered over the trees, like an ornately crafted caltrop set upon the land by a titan.  They group wended their way through the maze of fallen rocks and statues, and into the main sanctuary of the temple grounds.  Jaspermunk looked up to see a statue more than six times as tall as her, bearing the tell-tale monkey face of the forgotten god.  One of its outstretched arms had broken off and shattered across the floor, and she couldn’t help feeling sorry for him.  At the base of the statue one of her companions released a hidden lever, and the floor slid back to reveal a mold-covered stairwell.  Descending into the darkness, their path was only slightly lit by a growth of bioluminescent lichen along the walls.  They were heading into what appeared to be a maze of catacombs, and the pungent fragrance of the air suggested they were the first living visitors in hundreds of years.  Their goal was rumored to be stored in the back left corner of the dungeon, so they set out in that general direction.  The rogue managed to disarm the “pit of spiky death,” but most unfortunately missed spotting the “trap of acid-spewing death” which hit him full-on in the face.  The party immediately became somber and cold at his loss, yet they knew the dangers of their profession, and resolved to move forward with the mission. Seeing that Jaspermunk was inevitably more nimble of finger than the rest of them, they grudgingly handed her the fallen thief’s tools and had her attempt to fill in as best she could.  The tank took point in an effort to be a fortitude-saving trap-sponge, and Jaspermunk did her best to lock-pick and disarm the few obvious obstacles.  Luckily the grace of her reflexes saved her from her more-than-occasional snafus, and the tank decided it was probably easier to bash through the rotting wooden doors than to rely on her skill.At last they chanced across the room they were searching for, the hidden treasury of artifacts.  The problem arose when they discovered a giant cube of gelatin had taken residence, and was not taking kindly to the notion of leaving.  The tank quickly pulled Jaspermunk behind him as the spellcaster blanketed the ooze with fire and brimstone.  Then, wading through the sticky and partially-digested remains of the once-glorious treasury, they set about looking for the scythe.  Taking smaller treasures for themselves as bonus payment, they finally spotted their quarry hanging on the far wall.  Unfortunately for the group, no one prepared them for what they were about to discover.  Worse than a mantle afraid of the dark, worse than a sphinx with a lisp, worse than a horde of flumphs... the scythe was intelligent.  Not just intelligent, but imbued with the soul of the most sniveling, nagging, curmudgeonly priestess ever to have walked the earth.  (A priestess who just happened to speak a close-enough dialect of common to still be understood)  Every five minutes the scythe would go into a rant about how “This entire group combined does not have half the brains of a plague-rat...  How dare you even presume to set your hands upon me?  My son Un’kbuut would smote you heathens, bless his soul, if he were still alive...”  On and on it went until the group seriously decided leaving the scythe behind at the risk of not getting the nobleman’s reward.  Jaspermunk thought it was no wonder the scythe had been locked away, and seriously doubted she would remain sane for much longer with the ceaseless caterwauling from the enchanted weapon.  The plan was to hike another few days to the coast, where they would meet up with a ship to take them back to the northern continent.  Jaspermunk had never actually seen the ocean or ridden in a ship before, and she was almost bouncing with excitement as they were nearing the end of their trek.  The ranger had brought them out fairly close to the meeting site, and they could see the ship anchored in the distance.  Jaspermunk had to seriously stop herself from running and paddling through the saltwater with glee and hugging the bow of their transport.  She was finally going to be face-to-face with real sea dogs.  As the rest of the group sorted out the financial and practical end of things, mainly finding a chest big enough and dense enough to muffle the noise of the relic, Jaspermunk was given a brief tour of the ship.  Disappointingly, the sailors all spoke normal common instead of her imagined pirate-speak, but she giggled every time she heard words such as “starboard” or “rigging.”  They even laughed and let her climb up into the crow’s nest to get a better view.  They set sail that evening, and at first she was having the time of her life.  She drank grog and learned how to sing shanties, and the sailors had her practice tying knots so that she could help with the rigging the following day.  However, that night as she was sleeping in her hammock a storm hit, and she was not entirely pleased to have the ship swaying all about when she had a perfectly good hangover.  After a few days, though, she got used to the rhythm of the ship, and didn’t even mind eating hard tack, questionable meats, and moldy cheese for almost every meal (although she decided to stick with the rationed water instead of having a repeated run-in with the sailors’ firewater).  She missed bathing, but at least the cold salt air up on deck was fresher than the steaming sweat they had faced in the jungle.  All in all, she was quite content to be living like a real swashbuckler, and was sad to think of having to make port.  She lost count of the days, but eventually they sighted their destination in the distance.  Upon nearing shore, the three remaining party members told her that even though she had come into the party uninvited, she had proven her worth and therefore was entitled to a share of the reward.  They had planned on splitting the pay four ways anyway, and felt she deserved to have the rogue’s share for herself.  Jaspermunk didn’t even know what to say, and the others just accepted her silence as thanks.  Apart from being inside the town mayor’s mansion, Jaspermunk had never been near royalty.  Once they docked, the three companions led her to the estate of their lord, and she was allowed to freshen up from the journey.  She tried to make herself presentable by wearing the only half-decent outfit she had stuffed into her travel bag: a pair of flaming orange pants and her best purple and yellow tunic.  However, once they were in the receiving room, she felt out of place next to the elf in flowing green robes, the human fighter in his hand-polished armor, and the ranger in her simple gown of burgundy.  The nobleman, a baron, took one quizzical look at her, and his fears were confirmed by the curt nods of the others.  The told him the full story of her addition to the party, of the rogue’s untimely passing, and of her contributions in his stead.  Instead of giving her a share of the money, he gifted her with a mithril shirt.  Then he proceeded to lecture the group on leaving their luggage unattended, and on taking a child on such a dangerous journey, even if she proved capable.  He also gave Jaspermunk a full rant about worrying her parents sick and wandering off with strangers recklessly, although she caught a twinkle in his eye which hinted that he would have done the same thing at his age.  He was delighted with the scythe, and seemed fascinated in talking to it, much to the horror of the party.  That evening he threw a grand feast in celebration, but warned Jaspermunk that she was to be sent home via carriage the next morning.  Her parents had already received a sending spell informing them she was currently safe and in the Baron’s care...

Sil was taken by drow slavers from her family when she was a child.  She was sold as a domestic servant, which she did into her teenage years.  Her servitude ended in what started as an unremarkable day.  She was washing some dishes when the goddess Sehanine whispered to her that her chance to escape was at hand.  Without hesitation, Sil heeded the divine guidance and followed its careful instructions leading her away from the house she worked in, through the depths of the Underdark, and into the sunlight of the world above.  Sil was taken in by the family of elves who found her wandering the forest. She grew into a career of smuggling slaves escaped from the drow out of the Underdark and to contacts on the surface to start life anew.  That is until her adopted sister fell in with a band of questionable folk with a nose for trouble.

Mek Leth’Osh was born to Tagg Leth’Osh and Marianna Urquart on a muggy summer night nineteen years prior.  Her unwed parents, both adventurers by trade, had been a bit too “over-celebratory” and not quite so “over-celibatory” after the conclusion of a particularly arduous quest.  Upon discovering her condition, and weighing the possibility of finding employment as a rogue with a -25 modifier to stealth due to “screaming baby,” Marianna promptly inclined to leave her unnamed daughter in the care of the child’s father.  Henceforth nine months later, Tagg was not-so-pleasantly surprised to find a small shrieking bundle carefully laid inside the hut of his village, with only a small note, “Thanks for the memories Big T, but I believe this loot belongs to you,” as explanation.  The village didn’t think twice about her mixed parentage, as Tagg’s well-known heroic deeds had put him in a class above reproach.  And a few years later, Tagg found he rather enjoyed being a father.  His hardened warrior’s face softened with laugh lines as his small toddling daughter tried to put on his helmet, and proceeded to fall over due to the relative weigh of metal to child.  Tagg dazzled his young daughter with stories of his adventuring days: how he had single-handedly slain an entire band of marauding kobolds, how her mother had deservedly gotten a face-full of magic missiles when she tried to sneak a peak into a trapped chest they were supposed to be guarding, and how he had distracted a mock dragon long enough for her mother to sneak around behind it and deal a crippling blow.  Mek doted on her father, who was slowly starting to show his age, and vowed to make him proud by becoming a fierce fighter herself.  At the age of eight she begged him to let her learn swordplay.  Although he was hesitant to let her do anything dangerous (his fatherly nature winning against his Orcish bloodrage), he soon could be found dueling sticks with Mek in the village center (every so often exclaiming “Argh, you got me!” and falling overdramatically to the ground amidst his daughter’s fits of giggles.)  By the time she was thirteen, Mek was starting to show signs of womanhood.  She was easily considered the prettiest girl in the village, owing to the fact that her human blood had softened her Orcish features into something approximating femininity.  She was hard-pressed to find any suitors, however, because Tagg seemed to stare down any boy that looked even slightly amorously at his daughter (much to his daughter’s pouting).At the age of sixteen, Mek was “accepted” into the Guard of the Crimson Paw – a special branch of the village guard allegedly tasked with “escorting village elders to and from the big city” which lay a half-day’s journey away.  The elders went once or twice a month to stock up on hard-to-come-by supplies for the village, and to sell local trade goods.  She was told the journey to the city was long and difficult, and that she had to be ever-vigilant for danger.  (In actuality, though, the village elders simply did not want teenagers sneaking off to the city alone.  They had cunningly devised the “guard” as a way for teenagers to have a safe and sanctioned way to travel there without knowing that it was they themselves who were the ones being chaperoned.  The adults in the village are in on the joke, and persist in telling dramatic lies about the trip being dangerous to further discourage wanderlust.  The elders feel it is a win-win situation, however, as they are happy for the company, and they enjoy seeing the teenagers proud faces brimming with responsibility.) Tagg, of course knowing full well the true aims of the guard, decided to make a big show of being proud of his daughter anyway because he didn’t want to ruin her enthusiasm.  He gifted her with her first suit of armor, a shining breastplate with an emblazoned paw print on the front.Now nineteen, Mek still assists with the guard’s “educational field trips.”  Being an adult, she helps the elders watch over the “new recruits” who are visiting the city for the first time, delighting in teasing them with wild stories about potentially ferocious bugbears and hobgoblins who might be waiting to ambush them at any minute.  She can still feel her parents’ adventuring blood pumping in her veins, though, and wishes that one of those tall tales would actually come true so she could finally prove herself as a fighter and make her father genuinely proud.  However, the closest thing to action she has seen so far was when a particularly stupid band of thieves tried to intercept their group on the road.  The scoundrels were instantly caught in a reverse gravity spell from one of the elders, as the whole of the Crimson Paw looked on and roared with laughter.

[Lord Archibald Regulas N’Dare is a sprightly and vigorous human noble of 68 years.  Being blessed with 13 daughters and one son, he has taken it upon himself to preserve his bloodline at all costs.  His eldest two daughters were married off to gain alliance with the local nobility, and the remaining girls have each been trained in one of the core classes with the specific goal being for them to serve as council and bodyguards for his heir.  However, his 17 year old daughter, Orelka, has proven somewhat of a problem child...]From an early age, it was known that Orelka was a “special” child.  Her great-great-great grandfather had been some sort of air-based outsider, and it was very clear she had inherited his temperament.  Calm and gentle at one moment, she would fly off the handle at the slightest provocation.  She would also spend hours perched on the roof spires like a gargoyle, claiming she liked to be near the sky.  Between her furies and her fearlessness of heights, she drove her parents to righteous indignation.  She was a beautiful child in an eerie sort of way, though, being dark-brown skinned with shimmering blue-white hair that almost seemed to blow by itself.  Recently her father apprenticed her to a sorcerer, hoping that she could channel her growing elemental powers into a more useful and controlled format; however Orelka seems to care little about her duties, and has instead developed a vanity for her unique physique and abilities.  He once caught her showing off for the local teenage ruffians by showering his freshly manicured court gardens with bolts of electrical damage!  This simply would not do.  She was going to learn to be a responsible and pedigreed Lady if it killed her.  When the announcement came of an elite police force being assembled, it was music to Lord N’Dare’s ears.  He could ship her off into service, let someone else sort out her “little quirks,” and have her come back home with battle experience to boot.  Thus, equipped with a bag of supplies compiled by maidservants, an outfit that was ostentatious enough to seem out-of-place, and a tornado of an attitude, Lady Orelka Meloros N’Dare was thrust into the outside world...

Jemma's last name isn't Aurelian, but her gold hair and love OF gold has earned her the title. The bounty hunter doesn't tell anyone her real last name, as it seems to be connected to a past she doesn't like to talk about with just any stranger or employer. It's not that she's unfriendly, so much as she simply keeps her conversation firmly focused on the present. Most at least know that she's originally from Waterdeep, and moved to Baldur's Gate nearly five years ago. That city has been her base of operations ever since, but it's not uncommon for her to go traveling far afield at the prospect of earning better money, or to track down particularly contemptible criminals.As a bounty hunter, Jemma's known for taking on bounties that fit with her own sense of right and wrong. This has lead her to accept jobs from all over the spectrum of legality on the Sword Coast, and to sometimes broker deals to settle jobs rather than stick to strictly capture/kill. Consequently, some of her employers respect her, while others feel her in-the-moment decisions undermine their authority. She occasionally mentions that she'd like to save up for a day when she can take on any job, regardless of the payout, so she can really start to do some good in the world.

Kira has no memories of her family. She was raised at a well-known dueling academy near the Sea of Fallen Stars, where she attended classes in fencing, history, and etiquette along with the children of nobles and rich merchants. Most kids only stayed for a few years, but the academy was the only home Kira ever knew. She excelled in her schoolwork, and she also learned a few stealthier arts thanks to the kinds of things that lightly supervised teenagers tend to get up to while at boarding school. She and her friends let themselves into the school's administrative offices one night and learned that Kira had been left at the school at four years of age by someone who paid her entire tuition and fees in advance, but there was no record of who this mysterious benefactor might be. Kira began to believe that she was born out of wedlock to someone who had enough of a sense of responsibility to see to her welfare, but they clearly didn't want to be part of her life. That was fine by her though. When she graduated, she was planning to become an instructor at the school, but a pair of strange men arrived and explained they were taking her home. Even if they were on the level, Kira had no interest in rejoining the family who abandoned her. Unfortunately the men weren't inclined to take no for an answer. They tied her up and tossed her in a carriage. By the time she was able to escape, she decided it wasn't a great idea to go back to her school. That's the first place they'd look, and her presence would cause trouble for the people who'd raised her.Kira began to travel, and she moved from place to place often. Sometimes she still saw signs of pursuit. But after a year without any trace of being followed, she believed her supposed family may have given up hope of recovering her. She joined up with an adventuring group, and they did fairly well for themselves. Kira thought they were people she could rely on. Then they stumbled into a tavern and overheard the wrong set of rumors, and the next thing she knew, her companions had her drugged and bound and were looking around for a potential ransom. After a few nearly successful escape attempts, the group decided not to wait on the people who were looking for Kira. They found a group of slavers who knew there was a price on her head, and then they sold her.The slavers were secretly working for a medusa who had the habit of petrifying some of the more interesting people she captured. Kira was turned to stone for several years, until she was rescued by a different group of adventurers who'd hunted down the medusa.She'd been hidden away in the medusa's garden for long enough that Kira now hopes her family, or whoever they were, has stopped looking for her.

quenten was too cool for the rest of the normie warlocks in his city so he left to find a more fitting patron to serve. after wandering upon a black glass obelisk and being put through a trail of will in the shadowfell quenten was given the grace of the raven queen. he now serves her in the realm of the living finding her interesting souls to collect before they go to the 9 hells.
He was born by the toxic waste of a magician in the deepest trail of a strange dungeon. He can morph into anything and by doing that he attracts confused people to eat them alive.
Hip Hop Bard
A chaotic neutral amnesiac whose mood changes like the wind. The trauma that gave him his amnesia also gave him minor psionic abilities.

1078:  Times our camp moved to follow the seasons, the streams, or the hunt.182,509:  Berries I have gathered for evening feasts.2531:  Games of goatball played.1764:  Times my team won.36,512:  Stories of glory and victory heard around the campfire.532:  Baskets I have woven while talking with friends.14:  My age when I was first chosen for the hunt.3906:  Beasts felled by my hammer.70:  My personal best for kills in one day.8:  Minor shuns I have received for being willful.  Growing up in a peaceful and sheltered setting:  PricelessMy childhood was simple.  The kind you would expect of any other Goliath youth.  We played, we hunted, we shared in challenge and honor, we lamented the loss of the once-proud, and we sought for ways to live life as fully as possible.  Occasionally we ran into a Dwarven outpost, or passed by a group of adventurous Humans, and we would trade our goods for weapons and crafts.  Mostly, though, we kept to ourselves.  I progressed within the tribe from berry-gatherer to weaver, then to assistant den-mother, and finally to hunter.  I was gruff, opinionated, homely, not well-spoken, and generally off-putting, but by the time I was 18, my skill with the business-end of a hammer was enough to gain the honor of my tribe – and the heart of a man.  Our Dawncaller, Gul’mok, fancied me for his wife.  I told him he could have me, but only if he could beat me in a climbing race – a race I did not anticipate losing.  I was over-confident in my skills, having never lost a fair match in hunting, wrestling, or rock scaling.  We agreed to a race up the cliff-face and back - whoever touched the ground first, won.  I was already halfway down by the time he’d even scaled the summit. In an act of desperation and love-blind bravado, he jumped off the top of the cliff instead of climbing to the ground, and while he did in fact reach the bottom before me, he broke his leg in the process.  I sighed at him and his childish stupidity, realizing I never technically specified he had to climb both ways. Yet, in that moment I was also touched by how hard he was willing to fight for me, and decided to honor our bargain and marry him after all.  He spent the next two weeks being shunned while he recovered from his injury.  During that time I only looked at him once, but he was smiling that ear-wide grin of his.  By all accounts we were a happy couple, always challenging each other, but never fighting.  A year later I bore him a son, but it was born early and weak.  It was the second-hardest lament I have endured in my life.  Later that year, Gul’mok woke early to sing the dawn praises, as was his custom every morning.  I left a while later with the hunting party, but when I returned that evening, Gul’mok was still absent.  He should have reached camp hours before me.  Suddenly I heard my name, gasped and hollow like a cave wind, and I turned.  Gul’mok was crawling into camp.  I could barely recognize him, so coated in blood was he.  He tried to speak, but all I could make out was “Move...camp...Orcs...hundreds...”  The Orcs had always stayed north of our mountains, kept in check by the Goblins of Hob.  It was never our fight or our concern...until now.  The fact that the Orcs were boldly pushing as far south as here meant that Hob’s power must be weakening.  If they were attacking and invading any peoples who stood in their way, without provocation or ethics, than we had a large-scale problem brewing.  Our tribe, while harsh, had always lived life by rules and fairness.  These Orcs, however, lived by little more than violence and depravity – mere savages whose breath was as dirty as their fighting. With Hob’s defense cracking, someone had to step in and uphold the balance of order, to remain a steadfast wall in the face of impending destabilization, and somehow this called for more than a good shunning. The elders were not going to charge into a fight they could not win, though, and immediately made plans to move camp again.  I knew Gul’mok would not survive the night, let alone a move, so I asked that we be exiled together rather than leaving with the rest of the tribe.  I bit my tongue as I watched my people embark on a path of fear, running with their tails between their legs while our enemies went unchecked, while my husband’s assailants went unchecked. I was vehement and filled with a vengeance I could not contain.  The Orcs had crossed a line, and I would not let any more suffer like my husband had.  In the morning I planned to seek out a way to bring the Orcs to justice. Even if I stood alone, I would protect and restore our lands, our way of life, our honor.  I would always remember the cacophony of that night – the cries of the lamenters amid the chaos of packing and carting – fading into a still silence as in one pivotal hour all I had ever known vanished down a darkened mountain path, leaving my world shattered.  Alone with my husband, sitting by the smoldering embers of the dying fire, I tried to bandage his wounds.  I knew it was in vain, but it kept my mind focused.  We fell asleep in each other’s arms, and I awoke holding death.  Once-proud Vae’Ulov Feast-Bringer re-forged into exiled Vae’Ulov Dawn-Widow.  I set off toward the only peoples I thought might aid me in my cause, an outpost of Dwarven border guards we were on friendly terms with.  It was a one week hike south through the mountain passes, and I was never very good with directions.  It took me twelve days to find my way.  When I reached the outpost, the Dwarves were in full battle gear.  Apparently word had spread of the Orcs uprising, and the Dwarves had sighted incursions into their own territory.  Admitting we had a common enemy, I asked if I could help.  The outpost allowed me to camp with them, and in exchange for aiding them with hunting and standing watch, they offered military training so I could better defend myself.  Over the next 169 days, they bored me with stories of their kings and nobles, taught me to ride a horse and wear plated armor, equipped me with gear of unspeakable craftsmanship, and did their best to “culture” me as we fought side by side.  When the news finally came that Hob’s last stronghold had fallen, rumors began to spread that a group of warriors from every race were gathering into one untied army to make a definitive stand against the Orcish hoard.  I was invited to ride along with the local Dwarven envoy, having proven myself an able-bodied ally...

Fú g_ xi_ng ying was born in a remote catfolk village, nestled along the tree line of the auspicious mountain range that cuts through the province of Anhui in Lian. The runt child in an ominously-numbered litter of four, her parents always feared for her fate – for while she was beautiful and captivating, her health was far more frail than her brothers and sister. Thus, while her siblings busied themselves with fur-flying tussles and childish games, she was kept apart due to worries over her delicate constitution. She often found herself drawn to keeping company with the elders who sat in the town square playing small metal drums, beating earthen fou, and marking time on fish-shaped muyus. The echo of the percussion seemed to echo the heartbeat and rhythm of the village itself. She was fascinated by this innate ability of sound to evoke such vivid images of life – how hearing the drums instantly brought up visions of her mother banging around in the kitchen, or how the muyus seemed to mimic the clacking of wooden sandals on brick. In time she would grow to see the world through these terms. If you were to ask her now where she comes from, she would play you the sound of wind howling through Huangshan pine, of rain cascading off a tiled pagoda, or cicadas humming against cypress bark. She would simulate the hammering of craftsmen, the gentle scraping of ink against stone, the soft swish of silk beizi over hand-embroidered floor mats, the skittering patter of kittens running underfoot… To her, vocal communication is inefficient. Any attempt to describe a sunset, or a rainstorm, or a memory, or a feeling through words is reductive, derivative, and imperfect at best – like a child trying to draw a flower, it loses something in translation. She views pure sound, unshackled from the bonds of language, as a higher form of art. The others in her village initially laughed at the idea of this girl who barely speaks, and who views singing as “the high-pitched caterwauling of women masquerading as perpetually-surprised children,” wanting to train as a bard, but they eventually relented, recognizing her natural talent of turning any object she found into a percussive foley tool.Through the course of her studies she not only perfected her soundscape talents, but was also taught the ancient clan art of Anhui Nuo dance - a fearsome performance of stilts and masks. She learned that although she was physically weak, she could combine her skills to control the battlefield - frightening enemies down to their very core without needing to land a single blow. Now, no longer a protected flower but a fully-empowered adult, she has set off on her own paws to explore new lands and discover new sounds.

Created by undersea horrors to infiltrate and destroy humanity, creedy quickly blew his cover in an attempt to seem honest and avoid confusion. As an immortal human pretender, he strives daily to be accepted and find affection from those he was sent to destroy.

Olliechock Erralfizflin Norrfoodleis Queenipper III, “Ollie” to non-gnomes, was born in the small haven of Fotsblogginfarb along the coast of the Wetsprockett Sea.   From an early age, Ollie learned that if he spent enough time tinkering, he could pick up just about any skill (much to the infuriation of his parents and siblings when he knew more than he should, could get into more difficult places than he should, and had others’ possessions in his keeping more often than he should).  However, he doesn’t consider himself a thief or anything of the sort, he simply believes in the equal distribution of goods and information, and in mandatory charitable donations.  Being a dashing (well, he has good hair at least), daring (machismo), courageous (dumb bravado), and… wait, no, he doesn’t really care all that much… youth, he was always the first to rush into situations, yet he had enough wits about himself to not be completely reckless (i.e. to blame the other guys first).   When he was 53, he left his hometown because he honestly believed that he was too manly for the good of the village.  If he had stayed, the other men would have felt inferior and jealous by comparison, and the girls would have fought over him and had their hearts broken. He wanted to save the villagers from this cruel fate by going to live amongst other races who might not be as vulnerable to his virile charms. (The townspeople kindly waited until he was out of hearing range to double-over in laughter.)  After he left home, he made his living by doing odd jobs that piqued his fancy as he traveled, including scouting, bodyguarding, negotiating, recovering “lost” objects, and the occasional children’s party.  One day he chose to start worshiping the deity Kord because he heard Kord was strong and muscular - the epitome of manliness - and he figured they had a lot in common; although Ollie prefers the masculine grace of dexterous athletic skill over pure mindless brawling. He fancies himself a sort of “Chuck Norris Robin Hood,” but in actuality he has more in common with the likes of Nobby Nobbs.He likes to be prepared for anything, and has pocketfuls of junk that he keeps in his vest because he never knows when it might come in handy, although he is often not resourceful enough to ever use the items in any helpful way, so they continue to pile up.Ollie’s quirks include never being able to say no to an attractive (to him) female, calling everyone he meets “girlie” regardless of their actual gender (because no one else is as many as he is), taking every opportunity to pose and show off his manly physique, and whittling.

At a young age, Erlen found his way into a ancient ruined mage's lair, where he learned to use magic, as well as the dwarvish language. Ever since, he searched for other ancient knowledge, and eventually decided to take up adventuring in order to discover the secrets in even the most dangerous places.

Lady Gwynedd’s Grandfather had been a merchant with a knack for choosing wise investments. Using his charm and acumen he managed to curry favor with the king, earning himself a title in exchange for his contacts and expert council. With her grandfather’s aid, the king was able to expand trade routes further than ever before, importing exotic luxuries and a wealth of new information.However, after the king’s second son murdered the heir apparent and attempted to assassinate his father in a play for the throne, Gwynedd’s family knew their privileged life was on the verge of toppling. Before word of the kingdom’s troubles spread, Gwynedd’s grandfather secured a betrothal for his son, then a boy of only ten, to a young Elven noble far across the sea. He had hoped to train his son in the mercantile trade, but the boy was too spoiled and lacking in wits to be any kind of protégé, so potentially marrying him off to cement a bond with the Elves was the only use that could come from him.Eventually the prince succeeded in his machinations and ascended to the throne. Her grandfather visited the usurper in the hope he could somehow continue to live in the lap of luxury, but the new king was bold and arrogant, and rejected the old man’s help. However, by a stroke of good fortune, the prince soon took an Elven bride, and her grandfather used his influence with the Elven people to win her ear and monopolize trade routes between the two kingdoms for the next several years.Gwynedd’s father, now a strapping young officer of 18, finally came of age to marry his betrothed, but shortly after the wedding, Gwynedd’s grandfather fell victim to a freak storm and his ship was lost at sea. Her father was now the sole heir to a vast trade empire, suddenly making him a very wealthy and powerful noble - a wealthy and powerful noble with the business sense and charisma of a decomposing turnip.He squandered most of the money away on lavish gifts for his new wife, who, it turned out, was just as much of a ninny as him, and within a few years they had run the company near into the ground through mismanagement and incompetence. By the time Gwynedd was born, the family was destitute and cut off from all lines of credit and influence, yet still clung proudly to their noble title.Lady Gwynedd was a child cursed by fate. Born with exceptional beauty and flawless talent, she was scorned by women and objectified by men. Seeing in her gifts a last ditch effort to regain favor with the other noble houses, her parents decided to use her as a pawn. She was trained to sing, dance, recite poems, and play a variety of instruments, and then paraded from parlor to parlor like some exotic caged bird. Admirers fought for her presence at their parties, and showered her with presents (all of which were pawned to make ends meet and keep up appearances).As she grew up, she was better able to hone her skills to captivate and charm her audience, and soon had a following of potential wealthy suitors. When she reached the minimum legal age, her parents married her off to the wealthiest of the bunch, expecting her to supply them with the necessary income to maintain their immoderate lifestyle.Her new husband was an abusive drunkard with no respect for her, though, and she saw a chance to escape after he got himself killed in an alcohol-induced altercation. She was sick of being a pawn, and disgusted with the petty childishness of her family and the rest of the corrupt nobility that approved any and all methods of keeping themselves in power - even to the point of letting a murderer sit on the throne and letting liches infiltrate the city.She decided to take her husband’s wealth and her freedom into her own hands, transforming herself into a secretive vigilante, “The Mask of Thorns.” In her new role, she helped a group of adventurers rid the city of the undead threat, then turned her attention to the arrogant elite and lowly bandits that ran rampant through the streets, both having an equal hand in making life miserable for the common people. Her calling card was a stem of thorns, symbolizing the choked and stagnant state of the kingdom. Though her punishments were harsh, they were non-violent – her goal was to shock and scare (and possibly humiliate), not to kill.(Perhaps she should have studied combat more effectively, though, as she met an untimely end at the hands of a 4-armed sniper during the very first wave of the demonic invasion of the city. Trying to hide behind a well in an open courtyard is apparently not sufficient to avoid impalement by a guy double-wielding bows.)
a transexual dwarf that hate humans
Hermit
Acolyte

Matthias was born to a wealthy family of engineering tycoons. His family was responsible for many advancements in travel, creating steam powered engines for boats and trains. Matthias himself was a talented student but not in the subject one might expect of his family's name. He was skilled in medicine and he had a compassionate heart. Most of his time was devoted to the study of healing. A group of powerful clerics took notice of his talent and offered to teach him how to channel his energy into healing magic. Matthias accepted the offer and learned to use his newfound magical abilities quickly. He rose through the ranks of these clerics at a fast pace and eventually became their trusted leader.

kura was born to an a wood elf mother (deepa) and a human parent (gizem). her parents met when gizem’s trade caravan passed through her mother’s clan’s forest and requested shelter for a few days. deepa found gizem’s curious and humorous nature charming and one thing led to another and by the time the caravan moved on she was pregnant with kura.passing the child off as a product of her an elf from another neighboring clan, deepa tried to hide kura’s true heritage, and was moderately successful until kura was around ten or eleven and it became very obvious by her height and build that she was half human. outraged by deepa’s actions, the clan elders banished kura and her mother from their forest, forcing them to try and find a home in the nearest human city, masayume.with nothing but the clothes on their back, kura and deepa lived in destitution for many years. away from her family and her home, deepa fell into depression. it hurt kura to see how sad her mother was and she made a promise to herself that she’d do whatever it took to make her at peace again.as a teenager, kura wormed her way into masayume’s underworld, bouncing between minor gangs and thieves guilds, picking up whatever skills she could along the way. eventually she gained a reputation as a jack of all trades wrt shady business and for a while was in high demand for both gang leaders and noblemen alike who needed their dirty work done.kura took whatever job was handed to her in the hopes of saving up enough money to get her and her mother off the streets; eventually she was successful and was able to buy her mother a small home on the outskirts of town with a few acres of land (and some goats :) )it was around this time she was offered a body guard position for a young noblewoman named aino. aino was recently betrothed to a man from a foreign kingdom and had received multiple threats from former suitors and so her father wanted someone discrete to protect her. kura and aino immediately took a shine to each other and eventually fell in love.after many months, their affair was discovered and aino’s father kicked kura out of their home and forbade her from ever seeing aino again. bribing a servant, kura was able to get a letter to aino and the two came up with a plan to run away together. unfortunately, another servant loyal to aino’s father intercepted these letters and tipped him off; on the night of the planned escape he and his private militia cornered kura and aino in the forest outside of town. he ordered kura to be killed right then and there but aino begged him to have mercy. moved by his daughter’s tears, the lord spared kura’s life, but swore that if he so much as heard rumors of her being in the city, he would have his men hunt her down.  with no other options, and now no source of income, kura accepted her loss and left the city to become a rogue-for-hire.

Harper grew up in a small farming village in the countryside. His family wasn't destitute but they weren't well off so when he started to show some magical talent he went to the city to study and hopefully apprentice someone. While in school he caught the eye of a fairly prominent wizard by the name of Luce who asked Harper to become his assistant. Harper quickly discovered, unfortunately, that Luce was not a wizard but a powerful lich that enjoyed practicing necromancy and other dark arts and bound Harper to him to do his bidding. He was stuck under Luce's control for many years until the goddess Wee Jas appeared to him and promised to help free him if he destroyed Luce and pledged his life to her. He agreed and with his new divine powers he banished Luce and was able to rescue the other souls trapped in his mansion. After that Harper became a wandering cleric until he eventually met Sei, an elven healer, and his daughter Sera. Sei and Harper fell in love and eventually married, and now run a clinic together. Harper now occasionally does freelance work for the (since retired) world renowned detective/author Renee Redmoore.

Poe always felt alienated in her home town, so one day she ran away to live in the woods. There she met her future wife, a fae duchess, who also became her warlock patron and gave her powers. Poe began living nomadically, helping around the country where she could.

Mr. Giggles, as he likes to call himself, is a dude who just doesn’t understand life.  To him, dad jokes are real, pizza is scary, and his best friend in the world is his axe named Helga.  But Mr. Giggles isn’t crazy.  Rather, he’s just clueless how to live among people.It all began many years ago when Giggles was born Felldrop Smartbriar to the Smartbriar clan of Halflings in the village of Forgetmenot.  Felldrop’s father Spelldrop and his mother Dropdrop (known as Dropsie) had a long history of eccentricity, even in a place as weird as Forgetmenot...a town that was named, incidentally, after the regional government forget all about it for over a century due to a drunken scribe’s geographic oversight.  Located high in the Neverease Mountains, Forgetmenot was visited only by local yak herders,  lost mountain climbers, and holy pilgrims.Among even this village of loners, Spell and Dropsie were even further ostracized.  Spell, an herbalist and tea maker, had congenital narcolepsy, and would often fall down in the streets due to what his neighbors referred to as the sleeping sickness.  Spelldrop explained away his episodes with regular exhortations about being up late the previous night, or inadvertently mixing his herbs.  Hence, the nickname Spelldrop.  (No one recalls, nor cares, what his real name was and because Spelldrop secretly liked the attention, he avoided his real name as well.)Dropsie, like her husband, had a moniker that fit her personality.  She was clumsy.  But because Dropdrop was her given name (something about how her parents liked hearing the sound of rain, which itself was unusual so high in the mountains), it’s difficult to say if the name made her clumsy or if her parents were simply augurs.  Either way, if a villager wanted something broken, he’d hand it to Dropsie.  Spelldrop’s friends tried warning him of his girlfriend’s powers inopportune powers but, alas, he had a narcoleptic episode in the middle of their speech and they neglected to finish the story when he awoke.Conventional wisdom suggests either that Dropsie performed one of her clumsy maneuvers on her son or his father had an episode atop him, or perhaps both.  No matter how you cut it, though, Felldrop never had a chance at a normal life.  This led to much resentment and anger.By the time he was thirteen, Felldrop was known for his temper, and the local boys would tease him mercilessly just to watch him fly into rages.  A passing holy man saw one of these events and gave Felldrop a small hand axe, thinking it would allow the boy to focus his passion.  Instead, it led to bloodshed: Felldrop slaughtered every small animal he could catch.  The town boys quickly learned to avoid him, especially when he had the axe with him.  And in a village as small as Forgetmenot, this was no mean feat!At twenty, Felldrop had proven that he was incapable of being around others.  His friends had long since abandoned him and even his parents were scared to be around him.  He had taken to talking to his axe, which he’d named Helga, and he treated it like a girlfriend, often being seen caressing it in public.  On the eve of his 21st birthday, then, it was no surprise when Felldrop announced that he would be leaving Forgetmenot with the next yak herding caravan that passed through town.Felldrop traveled with the yak herders only a short time.  Within two weeks, he’d realized that there was far more to the work than just yak wool, and far more to his temper than just small animals.  It came to a head one night when he attacked one of the yaks.  The animal, far larger than he, gave him a good drubbing.  Felldrop ran off into the night, smelling of yak and urine.For many months, Felldrop roamed the lands, eating wild berries and scavenging raw meat from smelly carcasses.  In that time, he saw no other people, and the wild rages of passion quickly overcame him.  By the time he wandered into another civilized town, Axeborough (a fitting name) 300 miles from Forgetmenot, he had lost the ability both to speak the common tongue and to interact properly with other humanoids.  He had become a full barbarian.For approximately three years, Felldrop lived on the outskirts of Axeborough, only rarely interacting with other humanoids.  It wasn’t until a band of orc raiders attacked the town that Felldrop was drawn back into social contact.When the orcs attacked the town, a vicious battle ensued.  Felldrop watched from a safe distance and was amazed at the prowess of the raiders.  They mowed down the town guard with such ferocity and precision that Felldrop was awestruck.  Afterward, when the fighting had ended and the raiders had made off into the night with their booty, Felldrop gave chase.  He came upon their came about an hour later and walked in like he owned the place.  He was quickly overwhelmed and tied to a roasting spit.  The orcs danced around him and laughed, forcing him into deeper and deeper anger.  When the tide of emotion finally broke, Felldrop let out a primal yell, snapped his bonds, lifted the roasting pin over his head and plunged it into the chest of the nearest orc.  Before any of the orcs could react, their leader, a half-Orc man in his fifties or so, approached Felldrop.  He admired the little runt’s tenacity and decided to teach him how to be a raider, especially since they currently had an opening thanks to Felldrop’s anger.The leader of the orcs, named Kruger, was himself a barbarian, and he carried an icy hammer on his back and wore little more than the orcs themselves.  He was as battle-hardened and as bloodthirsty as they were, and so Felldrop couldn’t have asked for a better teacher.  And yet Kruger was merciless to Felldrop, always inciting him to anger and always at unlikely moments.  Kruger’s approach was to keep Felldrop guessing, but Felldrop was never able to make the cognitive leap required to read a scene and to surmise how events might play out.  As a result, Felldrop would go into his battle rages at all the wrong times, such as when eating, or getting ready for bed, or doing his business in the bushes.  Kruger found this all kinds of hysterical and never bothered to inform Felldrop of the right way to do things.Felldrop spent several years traveling with Kruger until the band was decimated by a patrol of Elven cavalry, which had been hunting them for some time.  Kruger was killed in the battle and Felldrop was “saved” when the warriors thought he was a child.Felldrop eventually got away from the elves, who had tried to adopt him and teach him their ways, and has been wandering since.  On the rare occasion that he crossed paths with other humanoids, most were drawn to his passion but put off by his anger.  And, in the end, Felldrop was left wanting something he couldn’t even name.  Eventually, he attempted to draw people to him to ward off his loneliness by adopting the moniker “Mr. Giggles”.  Some kids once called him that and he likes the idea that if anyone laughs at him, it will be the last thing that person ever does.

Lucrezia hails from the fair city of Firenze, Italia. While unacknowledged, she has had access from a young age to an excellent education and privileges as the bastard child of Pope Clement VIII. Upon his death in 1605, her position in society became much more tenuous. She is seeking to consolidate her position within the Catholic Church as an inquisitor through the accumulation of magical items.

Euzalia grew up surrounded by family on a isolated homestead. Her grandmother directed this small clan of tielfings in their daily labors of farming, sheep herding, and all the other tasks necessary to maintain the homestead. They lived not too far away from a small human settlement where they often traded their products for the goods that they could not produce themselves. Despite multiple visits to this village, Euzalia remained naive to human traditions as the human's prejudice against tieflings kept her and her cousins from making any close friends there. As Euzalia grew she started to manifest many magical powers, often creating floating lights to entertain her little nieces and nephews and once stopping a group of sheep from running away in fear with her magic. Her grandmother identified this talent as the gift that occasionally appeared in family members due to their tiefling heritage, but no one encouraged Euzalia to develop her gifts, viewing them as interesting, but not particularly useful. As a young adult, Euzalia was once sent to trade at in the village without the supervision of her older family members. This visit ended in disaster when she lost her temper at a rude shopkeeper and set his house on fire. Euzalia insisted that it was a complete accident, but it seems more likely that the only accident was how out of control the flames became. Although no one was hurt in this incident, the villagers were understandably upset. Seeing the risk of mob violence, Euzalia's family, led by her grandmother, sent her away under the cover of night with instructions to not return until she had mastered better control of her powers and some time had past to allow tempers to die down. Euzalia respected the decision of her family and set our to see a bit of the world. As she traveled, she discovered that there was a lot more to the world than small villagers and homesteads. She loves seeing new things and is very curious about new people and places. Although she can be hesitant to trust strangers, she can be overly trusting of her friends and very easily influenced by peer pressure and others' opinions. Her immediate instinct is often to protect herself at the expense of others, but if reminded that that action would be morally wrong, she will decided to do the right thing (unless under the threat of mob violence, which she wants to avoid at all costs). She is much more likely to do go when others are watching as she wished to give a good impression of tieflings. She cared about her own personal honor, but not about the laws of some distant king. Despite her families' concerns, she has no fear of her sometimes uncontrollable magic and will laugh at the unintended consequences of her spells.

Kalta was part of an all female guard at a temple in the mountains. While she was guarding the temple with her partner something attacked and knocked her out cold. When she came to her partner and a precious relic from the temple we gone. She has gone down into the world to search for them in a sort of self imposed exile from her tribe. She is not wise to the ways beyond the mountains and is driven to meet her basic needs as hopes to find what was lost and who took it.

A child abandoned by his original parents, he was found left on the doorstep of a church of Bahamut, and taken in by the clergy that lived there. He was raised as one of them, growing to learn the ways of the faith. A cult of Tiamat caused them constant troubles, and while the rest of his adoptive family did nothing to stop it, Grim grew increasingly angered at their lack of action. This culminated when he was a young man and the church returned from an outing to find the temple defiled. Enraged, he decided he would stand idly by no longer, and took an oath of vengeance against these cults, and any other organization that would attack the innocent.
