Eikarr is a Teifling born to a Human mother and a Teifling Father, born to a less than comfortable life. Both his parents work hard as Carpenters in the main city of Penmouth, Mostly fixer-uppers for housing, but they work together to make wonderful pieces of artisan furniture. Unfortunately, because the prices for the matierals, they don’t get to make them more than once a year, and any profits made goes right back into the next artisan piece. Eikarr’s Father, Helikr, made him his first wood instrument at the age of five, and He’s been enamoured with sound ever since. He, and his younger sister, Reikr, worked tirelessly with their parents until the age of 15, when Eikarr’s voice started dropping into something more usable for song. He then went along with a performance troupe, trying to work his way up the ranks to main performer (and if a little fey magic was needed to persuade the audience, well, who’s to say?). He sends almost all of his money back home when he has the chance.Since then, Eikarr has become a local hit, swaying the minds of the masses on taverns and stages alike with his music, and has fallen into bed with about the same amount.He is free with his emotions and loves people, loves a good jab and even more a wicked tongue. He has travelled around the Rosewood area giving performances and exploring where he can, but mostly he has stuck around his local haunts in Penmouth.

Appearance and objectsTinker Spin is a unicorn. His coat is red, copper colored (# D48E02, strips on the horn # 9C6802), and the mane is brown, almost black (# 4A3901). The shape of the mane is a narrow (3/4 of the distance between the ears) and relatively short (just below the ears) vertical brush, extending to the neck. Purple eyes (# E70AFF). Cutiemark - three pulleys of different diameters, connected by straps. The unicorn himself is quite muscular, tall and tightly knocked down. He is dressed in a cuirass. It automatically opens the wings, allowing the unicorn to soar, and not to fall from high places. The cuirass is additionally covered from the inside with a warm cloth.As a weapon, the unicorn uses two broadswords, inlaid with singing stones: the first with a flaming topaz and a glowing amethyst, the second with an icy sapphire and a glowing amethyst. Since recently, the unicorn wears the red fragment of Stalliongrad as a cloak with the coat of arms on its entire back. Steam was also put on all four hoofs. A small crossbow with a 6-bolt loading mechanism is attached to the left front nugget.Parents and ChildhoodTinker (for friends simply - Tink) was born and raised in the north, almost on the very border with Yakyakistan, in the Crystal Mountains in a small village. Even before his birth, his father, adventurer and warrior Whirlwind (Whirlwind, Whirlwind) left his mother, going on another adventure. No one in the village knows his real name, Whirlwind is a nickname given to Tink's father by fellow adventurers for his crowning reception - Blade Whirlwind. Both Tink's father and mother are unicorns. Tink's mother - Snowdrop Radiance (Snowflake) is a graduate of the Royal Academy of Mages. She is a silver-colored unicorn with a white mane and a cutie mark. After graduation, she decided to fight evil, joining a group of adventurers, in which there was Whirlwind. Whirlwind and the Snowdrop became friends after a dangerous adventure, in which they were left alone in the middle of the ziggurat and only the swords of the Whirlwind and the protective magic of the Snowflake helped them to escape. They became a couple and could no longer imagine life and adventures without each other. After a couple of years of active adventure, Whirlwind and Snowdrop got married and went to live in a remote northern village to peacefully build a future for their children. The villagers took the couple favorably. A graduate of the Royal Academy, and even a doctor, quickly found a job in the village, as well as her husband, who owned super-powerful telekinesis capable of raising a small log cabin. After several years of peaceful rural life in this small oasis in the middle of the icy mountains, Snowflake began to notice her Virl more and more with a distant and unfocused look. She was already at that time on a short pregnancy with Tink and his twin sister Radiant Solace (Radi) and was afraid to tell Whirl about her burden. Pregnancy passed easily, and inexperienced in the mare's constitution, Whirlwind joked over the fat, in his opinion, Snowdrop. She doubted for a long time, but when she was determined to tell that day and that morning, Whirlwind disappeared from the village. He left a confusing note that he loved Snowflake, but that the old enemies found him here and that he does not want to bring trouble to her and his fellow villagers, will carry away the danger behind him. At first, Snowdrop had a very hard time and suffered from such a hasty disappearance of her husband, but two months later she found the strength to cope with this and successfully resolved from the burden with the help of kind-hearted fellow-villagers, whom she helped several times already. Two foals appeared in the world, which surprised Snowdrop and her fellow villagers. Young unicorns grew quickly, listening to the mother's stories about adventures, dangers and true love. On the questions about the their father, she always responded with the words of his note and sincerely believed that he was still alive and protecting Equestria from evil. But, despite this, Snowdrop did not agree to teach the children her magic. Tink was fascinated by his father's images and wanted to become like him. His art of telekinesis grew rapidly. Foals learned to write and read. For several years of living in the village of Snezhinka with Whirlwind gathered a small library. Some of the books Snowflake brought with them, some they bought from visiting traders. Tink read out the "Adventure Guide". At the age of fourteen, her mother reluctantly let him go to a neighboring town, agreeing finally to train and Radi, realizing that she could not keep them forever under the light of her horn.YouthOnce in the city, Tink was struck. Stone houses ascended to an unreal height in 4 floors, and the tower of the Town Hall - on 8 floors with a belfry. A diverse, multiracial crowd of the central market took him to the station, which Tinka most surprised him-he was lucky enough to get into the city exactly at the time when the train left the station. A huge mass of cars moved and went by herself, without the help of a pony. A young unicorn ran around the station trying to understand how it happened, but it was necessary to go to the master. The snowflake sent Tinka as a disciple to her friend, the unicorn technician Steam Flare. At the beginning, Flare gave Tink simple tasks - he did not know what Tink was capable of. Tink learned how to screw up nuts and screws with telekinesis, lift and move complex mechanical devices without namagicizing them. Gradually the master warmed to the pupil, trusting him with more and more responsible tasks. Master told Tink how different mechanisms work. The unicorn, though absorbing the knowledge of jerkcraft as a sponge, still missed the house, wrote letters to his mother and sesres, and once every two or three weeks the master let him go home. After a couple of years of training, Tink learned to at least write and read. The master taught him to read and create drawings. Tink met the age of complete ignorance, although he was sure that his life would be connected with the jackcraft. Once in the workshop to Flare came a strange client - he was clearly not a city dweller, from his saddle bags looked the handle of something resembling a sword. He was dressed in a black cloak, connected with a black helmet-mask with strange protruding ears on his head. He asked to make for him an unusual device - a pistol shooting a hook with a rope, which this mechanism should pull up. The master entrusted the creation of this mechanism to his student. Strange customer demanded to monitor each stage of creating the device - the master did not refuse him. Tink drew a mechanism, showed the master and the client and began to collect it. The client did not fill anything in the drawings, but trusted the word of the Master, who, with a grin, said that the mechanism would work as the client wants. In the process of drafting, Tink kept throwing short glances at an unusual client. He did not seem to notice them, studying the goods and details of various products. In the end, curiosity prevailed over Tink and he asked why the client had such a strange weapon. In response, the strange pony smiled and began to tell the working Tinka about his adventures in big cities with skyscrapers and strange ponies that want other ponies only evil. His stories were full of daring arrests and pursuit on steam wagons. Tink listened and remembered the mother's stories about his father and their adventures. Gradually, in his telekinesis, a device with three large pulleys emerged, activating its elements from a small steam engine on the crystals. Turning the last bolt into the device, which took the form of a strange kind of knight, Tink felt a strange tingling in the sides. Suddenly the light shone from him in all directions - the unicorn got its own cutie mark. Three pulleys on the cutie mark resembled those that were on the device. The master went down to look at the strange light shining in the workshop. Tink handed him the device for verification. - Excellent design, and this drive, even I, I think, could not come up with more effective - praised the unicorn Flare. With this praise began the creative life of the red pony. An unusual pony left his business card:Darr Veter Senior Lecturer, Chairman of the Scientific Council Higher Technical College of Stalliongrad "So that's where you come from!" - Tink remarked with surprise, and the master only grinned into his apron. - If you are interested in adventure and technology, come to study with us, Tinker. Your task was an entrance exam. - on a muzzle of the young unicorn, surprise, joy and uncertainty turned in turn. He turned to the master. - Again, you take away my pupils, a cunning fox, - Flare looked at Darr Vetra with a light reproach, but through it shone difficultly hidden heat. - His invitation to anything you do not oblige Tinker. "All right," the unicorn picked up a business card with telekinesis and hid it in saddlebags. "I'll take this into consideration," he said, trying to be as neutral as possibleAdulthoodBut, despite all the neutrality and coldness in his voice, Tink could not refrain from knowing what kind of Higher Technical School he had been invited to. Mother Tinka on this occasion came to the city with her daughter, who by that time learned a lot from her mother. The mother initially objected a little, but was convinced Flare of the need for this training for the better future of her son. Obliging Tinka to write letters and, if possible, go home, his mother and sister went back to the village, and he began to collect things. The journey on the Stalingradsky train even more convinced him of the fidelity of his path. Tink settled in the hostel of the VTOS. Around him, a small group of like-minded people gathered and found several enemies - the unicorn stood out in a stream that consisted mainly of an earth-sitter - in one of the parallel groups Pegasus studied, who also joined the mug, as they were called on the stream, "Crazy Inventors". The school required attendance at lectures and good progress, but provided some freedom for its students. Members of the circle Tinka had time to learn and work - they had little money, which they spent on the purchase of various details. Then the circle gathered and often, in the silence of the night, explosions and gnashing of metal rattled. The administration of the hostel made comments and punished them, forcing them to sort out the consequences of their failures. But high scores in various competitions inside the VTsU provided this pony with immunity from exclusion. After the third year, most of the guys from the "Crazy Inventors" at a special meeting about their next victory were invited to join a secret organization - the Gray Knights. Those who could not receive training for various reasons, erased the memory. Of those who remained assembled the team and began to teach the possession of weapons. Tink was one of the first who learned to own swords. The team's talents gradually developed. The team was gradually invited to clean ziggurats, first as support. Magic unicorn himself studied, improving what turned out better. At the same time, for money, saved from dangerous adventures, Tink bought a cooperative 5-room apartment near the VTUs. His official work was the repair and creation of new models of electric and steam transport.

Charismatic; a true performer and an artist. Really intelligent and insightful, but generally considered a layabout even though he has two degrees from University (History and Philosophy) and is welcomed as a guest lecturer whenever he passes through. Adopted into a rich, noble elf family as a baby but has spent most of his adult life willingly skint and nomadic. His lifestyle is one of travel, poverty, and hedonism whenever he gets a chance - this lifestyle he believes is essential to artistic enlightenment. There may be some truth to this, as he is both well-known and acclaimed as a bard and a lutist. He is very street-smart (as a Tiefling in certain parts of the world, you almost have to be), but definitely prefers outwitting or escaping enemies rather than engaging in battle where his talents lack. When the DnD campaign starts, he is on a new continent he has never been to before, and relishes the chance for new inspirations, fresh crowds of admirers, and further avenues to debauchery. If this sounds really familiar, it's because he's a clone of Dandelion from the Witcher series - I'm new to this and still getting used to original character development.

Me and the One BehindMy ghostHe is everything I yearn to beHe is the shadow of the dreams I dreamThe one behind, the one beforeNow the one trapped behind our doors.My ghostMirrors they do show him time to timeI see his image and the life that could be mineThe one inside, the one less shownDo you see him, the life he wishes to own?My ghost, my selfI am that shadow that lingers and attacks the human that remains insideWishing to be something, to be someone I am notI am my own evil pelting at my own worth with razor tidesUntil I am a shadow once again.

Ilenia grew up among a secret colony of elves, when she came of age, she decided to venture into the wider world to learn what she could. She made her way as a dancer, her elven beauty earning her access to private parties of many wealthy citizens. Dancing for such illustrious citizens, she began to hear secrets and gossip, and quickly learned that she could earn extra money selling these things to the right people. One of these people, was a priest of Vecna, seeing the potential in Ilenia, he began to gradually induct her into the cult of Vecna, which she joined wholeheartedly. After several  years of working for Vecna, Ilenia returned to her home tribe, where she ritualistically sacrificed her father to the dark god.  Quickly found out, she fled the village and has since been traveling the world, searching for secrets and making offerings to the dark god.

Grew up in an abandoned dock with only the remaining supplies, of which there were many, to sustain him. Learned magic and how to build guns from the computer systems. Managed to combine the two. At a certain point the dock ran out of food; then he went and lived a life of adventure, soon leading to where he is now.

When he was a lad of merely five, bluegeared was kidnapped from his astral home by space pirates.  Shanghaied into their service, his only respite was crafting small intricately carved turtles, which would scuttle about doing his menial chores for him.Seeing his natural talent in artifice, the pirates tasked him with producing new peglegs and hook hands, magically enhanced weapons and tools which propelled them to new heights.When he came of age, bluegeared faced off against the pirate captain, slayed him in single combat, and took command of the fortressship, dread omnikaiser.

Long ago in a distant land, I, Aku, the shapeshifting Master of Darkness, unleashed an unspeakable evil! But a foolish Samurai warrior, wielding a magic sword, stepped forth to oppose me. Before the final blow was struck, I tore open a portal in time and flung him into the future, where my evil is law! Now the fool seeks to return to the past, and undo the future that is Aku!

Thulas was a simple spider furry who wanted more out of life than spinning dope silk walkways in a cave, so he left the Underdark and went on vacation. During this vacation, he discovered that light sucks actually, and so attempted to magically blow a hole in a cliff to use as a sweet secret lair and get some respite from the sun. This endeavor quickly went awry when the spell backfired, sending the wand he was using straight through his head... except instead of dying, he somehow now has a brain full of magic and is EXTREMELY hyped about using it to its greatest potential. AKA weird science. Also he's on a train now.

They were raised in a religious assassin cult (think the House of Black and White from GoT) but became disillusioned when they realized they didn't actually carry out the divine will of the god(s) of justice, they were just paid assassins. So they ran away to become and adventurer and do good deeds. This would have gone a lot better if they had any knowledge at all of the outside world, but luckily they joined a band of plucky adventurers who actually know things like what forks are.

Esther is the youngest daughter in the Mourningwood family, the second highest ranking noble family in Remus. Because she will inherit nothing and lost one of her older sisters to an assassination, she decided to become a cleric of Selune devoted to healing others. She soon becomes wrapped up in being a Crimson Champion, a protector of Remus and the Crimson Isles, after she volunteered once her cleric studies had been completed.

Brak the CursedIt is the year 6133.  Brak the Cursed was born in the year 6108 to Lorkus, a female Orc Shaman once revered by her tribe for both her visions and for the herbal healing potions she would prepare during times of disease or battle.  However, Lorkus fell into disfavor with the tribal elders due to the bizarre circumstances surrounding Brak’s conception and birth.  Shortly before Brak’s conception, Lorkus began to have visions and dreams of an impending doom that would be visited upon her tribe or perhaps all of Middle Earth.  During one of her visions, she was visited by a human glowing in blue light who laid with her.  At first she dismissed the event as a mere vision, but then 6 months later she gave birth to a thin Half-Orc baby with strange glyph birthmarks covering his back.Despite all previous service that Lorkus had provided to her tribe, the elders saw Lorkus’ vision, her mysterious pregnancy, and Brak’s strange birthmarks as bad omens.  The baby, they declared, was cursed with what appeared to be Elvish Ruins.  Lorkus and her newborn baby were banished from the tribe. For months Lorkus travelled alone through the wilds on the outskirts of both Orc and Human society.  She eked out a meager existence that allowed her to nurse Brak, but slowly drained her reserves.  One night she was attacked by wolves.  While she protected Brak from harm, Lorkus was mortally wounded.  With her life force draining and knowing that any Orc will likely make a sacrifice out of Brak, Lorkus carried Brak in the direction of the nearest human settlement.  As twilight breaks she found herself on a farm at the outskirts of New Breverik.  With luck, the farmer was blind and did not appear to recognize her Orcish nature.  The kindly farmer took them both in and he tended to Lorkus’ wounds as best he could, but it was clear from the moment of her arrival that she was on borrowed time.  Grateful for his kindness in her final moments, Lorkus confesses her story and her nature to the kindly farmer who promises to care for Brak after her passing.  After her passing, the farmer placed Lorkus’ effects aside and buried her on his farmstead.  The farmer, Olaf, nursed and raised Brak as his own.  At first, the people of New Breverik were disturbed by Olaf’s young ward and many complaints are made before the town council.  But the council was unable to discover any precedence to act upon and tells the people of New Breverik that they must honor and respect the decisions that Olaf makes; especially those that are made upon and regarding his farmstead.  While the people of New Breverik were never truly accepting of Brak, they eventually accept Olaf’s decision and resign themselves to the fact that Brak will be sharing their valley for the foreseeable future.   At the age of 10 Brak is large enough to start running the farm under the management and tutelage of Olaf.  Brak works the fields and tries to avoid contact with the humans of the valley and only occasionally goes into New Breverik.  In the evenings, Olaf teaches Brak reading, writing, and arithmetic and is pleasantly surprised at Brak’s ability to quickly learn complex concepts.  After Brak’s arrival the farmstead only retains one regular visitor, Skallagrím.  Skallagrím is a local herbalist who is fast friends with Olaf and is fascinated with Brak’s story.  While Brak is still a youngster, Skallagrím discovers that Brak has an amazing gift for preparing herbal remedies, perhaps inherited from his mother.  During his visits, Skallagrím teaches Brak about herbs and their preparation and application.When Brak is a young man of 16 years he witnesses an event of immense cruelty in the town of New Breverik which reminds him that Human culture and Orc culture are not divided by that wide of a gulf.  Unn, one of the daughters of the farmer Eirik, is accused of witchcraft, sorcery, and wizardry after she cures a boy's leg which had been crushed under an ox cart.  After a perfunctory trial in front of the town elders, and despite the fact that no one was harmed by her magics, she is sentenced to death by fire in the town's center.  Olaf Doomhammer, New Breverik’s high priest to Thor and also a Dwarf, tried to interfere with the town elders’ judgment and the building of the pyre; however, the people of New Breverik feared Unn’s potential magic more than they feared Thor’s potential wrath.  Olaf is held fast while Unn is burned alive.  During Olaf’s waning years, Brak comforts him by preparing herbal medicinals and poultices that alleviate Olaf’s chronic pain.  In the year 6129 Olaf passes, but not before performing two final acts.  First, Olaf passes onto Brak the possessions that Lorkus had left behind when she died on the farmstead years before.  Second, Olaf arranges for Skallagrím to take Brak on as his understudy.  Brak buries Olaf on the farmstead and quietly departs for Skallagrím’s camp.Skallagrím lives in an abandoned mining camp in the mountains just south of New Breverik where he roams the rough terrain in search of the herbs, roots, and other ingredients for the herbal treatments that he sells to the citizens of the valley.  Brak spends a short time with Skallagrim, but is restless following the death of Olaf.  Brak decides that it is time to try and make a connection with his Orcish side and sets off to locate the tribe of his mother.  Brak spends a few years in Orcish society, but ultimately determines that he is even more of an outcast there than in New breverik.  Both Humans and Orcs shun and ostracize Brak, but at least Human society is filled with a range of viewpoints and philosophies on the world that range from good to evil and from lawful to chaotic; here Brak at least fit on the spectrum.  In Orcish society, Brak only witnessed slavish obedience to cruel and evil masters.  In 6131 he returns to New Breverik and to Skallagrim.Skallagrim is happy to see Brak return.  Shortly after, Skallagrím takes Brak into his confidence and shows Brak that he, Skallagrím, is in actuality a Wizard who has retired from adventuring following a tragic encounter with a Landshark that killed his friends and left him as the sole survivor.  Since moving in with Skallagrím, Brak has found it necessary to travel into town more often in order to make purchases for the camp and while delivering the herbal remedies that Skallagrim makes for the people of the valley.  Brak has been befriended by a man in town named Fordin.  Fordin runs a small business where he employs mule barges and teamsters to ferry goods up and down the river.  Fordin’s enterprise is responsible for about 15% of the river traffic in and out of New Breverik and his travels provide him with a greater understanding of the world's diversity and a more open mind regarding Brak’s Half-Orc nature.Brak begins to learn the ways of magic.  Skallagrím’s first lesson for Brak is to be very careful with whom he takes into his confidence regarding his studies of the magic arts.  He is reminded of the trial and punishment of Unn.  Beyond the simple teachings of the magic arts, Skallagrím shares two more things with Brak; his theory of magic and his compendium of renowned users of magic.Skallagrím’s theory of magic is based upon years of study and travel and the review of ancient manuscripts.  On occasion, Halfdan Runeaxe, a cleric to Thor, has been of great assistance to Skallagrím.  Halfdan is a Dwarf attached to New Breverik’s Vigilance Committee and is also a collector of rare and ancient manuscripts.  On many occasions he has assisted Skallagrím with the research and formation of his theory.  Skallagrím is confident that his theory accounts for all the evidence that he has accumulated.  Skallagrím’s theory is only known by a few magic using friends that he has shared it with, and Skallagrím admits that not many other users of magic appear to care about the potential sources of their powers.      Skallagrím’s compendium of users of magic is based mostly upon his review of Halfdan’s manuscripts.  It represents knowledge that he was not initially looking for, but could not ignore or avoid as he was researching his theory of magic.  He felt it best to record some short notes regarding each user of magic that he encountered in the ancient scripts.Very recently Brak and Skallagrím have noticed that Brak’s dreams occasionally appear to be related to events that occur in the future.  Skallagrím believes that Brak may have inherited these abilities from his mother and has begun to study Brak in his sleep to see if he can determine how and when such predictive dreams are triggered.

AstridIt is the year 6133.  Your first memory is from the year 5783, the end of the Fourth age of Chaos and the beginning of the Fourth Age of Mankind.  You were discovered wandering the wooded hills in the southern reaches of Middle Earth by a patrol of humans; though you have a vague sense that you had been wandering in a daze through the greater region for weeks if not months.  The humans surprised you while you were feeding on a recent catch and they would later relate to you that you were feral in appearance and action and that it took the entire party to subdue you.  The humans took you back to their commune, a settlement of several hundred humans hidden in the middle of the Hyborean Bog.  According to stories, songs, and lore of the commune, it had been founded near the beginning of the Fourth Age of Chaos by several local farming communities that had been overrun by Orcs, Goblins and more.  At first they were excited to see another Human as their commune had not seen outsiders in approximately 25 years.  Their patrols had been encountering fewer and fewer Orcs, Goblins and the like and the discovery of a Human seemed like a good omen.  However, their initial excitement waned when they discovered you were not Human and turned to disappointment and suspicion when they discovered they could also not classify you as Elf or Half-Elf.  Despite their disappointment, the commune nursed you back to health.  Over the course of a few weeks your senses were gradually restored and your feral nature became recessive.  The commune was organized along traditional male and female roles which didn’t sit right with you, but it seemed to be a voluntary arrangement by both sexes so you swallowed what felt to you like an injustice in order to keep the peace.  Restless, eager to find clues to your past, and desiring to prove your worth; you volunteered for every patrol as soon as your mental and physical health were restored.     While the patrols did not lead you to any clues regarding your past, you did prove your worth to the commune and allayed most of their suspicions.  Month after month you patrolled and each month the patrols extended out further and further before they encountered signs of Orcs and Goblins.  In the year 6134, following months of patrols without a single encounter, the men of the commune voted and determined that it was time to leave the bog and resettle the fertile farm valleys to the north.You helped the commune organize, move, and found a farming community which they named Everdale.  Shortly after founding Everdale, the Human patrols encountered a community of Hobbits and regular trade commenced.  With trade, the Humans had their first taste of beer, a luxury they went without in the bog, in nearly 2000 years.  The men quickly determined that the women of the community should not be allowed to drink and just when you were about to approach the town elders to voice your concerns, you came across a man who was beating his wife in the streets.  It seems that he had been drunk the night before and had returned to his home where he demanded his wife honor her matrimonial obligations despite her protestations.  The next morning the husband was appalled to discover that his wife had entered her cycle.  It was forbidden in the community for women to share a bed with their husbands when they were menstruating.  The husband dragged his wife from the bed by her hair and was beating her in the streets as he continued to drag her to the town elders for judgment.  You interceded and beat the man into unconsciousness and then, in a moment of inspiration, you cut off his left nipple.  The town elders arrived too late to stop you, but just in time to witness the nipplotomy.  They dragged chairs into the street and with the townspeople gathering around they proceeded to immediately judge the matter.  It did not take them long to judge that your actions required punishment.  Owing to the considerable service that you had provided the community over the previous year, the elders decided that your punishment would be lightened.  Your punishment would be to have both right and left nipples removed followed by a period of indentured servitude to the man that you had assaulted.You glared back at the elders and at the townspeople.  You gave a stirring speech regarding the inequities within the community that you had witnessed.  At the end of the speech you stated that you did not accept the council's decree and instead declared your own judgment upon the community.  You declared that you would be the unseen protector of all women within the community from now until the end of time and that you would return to pass judgment on any man who so openly abused the women of the community.  With your closing words you threw the still bloody nipple onto the ground at the feet of the town elders.  The townspeople and elders looked around nervously.  With their eyes they pleaded with the fighting aged men of the community to do something with this woman who defied them.  But all of the fighting aged men of the community were they same men that you had patrolled with endlessly over the last year and it turns out they were more loyal to you than they were to the town elders.  You pushed your way through the crowd of townspeople, gathered your meager belongings, and left the town.  For a month you camped far from town and avoided all of the patrols.  At the end of the month you returned to town in the middle of the night.  You selected the home of one of the men from the village who was known for treating his wife and daughters poorly.  You snuck into his home, gagged him, and cut off his left nipple.  Not having been in town for the last month you did not know if he had abused his wife or daughters, but you knew it would be reasonable that everyone in town would believe that he had.  You knew this act would create terror in the minds of the men in town who would believe that you truly must be watching over the town and exacting vengeance as you saw fit. Despite the fact that you no longer remembered your past, these actions felt right to you.  Moreover, in recent months prior to the altercation in the streets, you had become aware of a spiritual presence in your life that not only guided you, but aided you with the supplement of some simple cantrips and other abilities.  The exact nature and identity of your deity remained as much of a mystery to you as your memories, but it is clear to you that your relationship with this higher power was longstanding.  Though your curiosity remains intact, you have also decided to give into your instincts which guide you through your daily devotions.  Your instincts provide you with something else.  While you cannot remember into your past, you possess an inward sense of foreboding regarding who you are, what you are, and your fate to come.  After leaving Everdale you decide it is time to search Middle Earth for the clues that will connect you with your past and your destiny.  During your extensive travels you appear to have the unconscious habit of encountering groups who are obsessed with prophesies.  These groups are generally very isolated and are cultist in nature; regarding the prophecy itself as a thing to worship.  The Taarakian Promise, Philmore’s Prophecy, The Quaranian Codices, The Prophesies of Eiselfane are just a few of the bizarre prophesies that you have encountered.  The Taarakian Promise was a fanatically held belief by a small city in the mountains that their city was protected by a single warrior called The Taarakian.  You never saw any evidence of this warrior, but the city did appear to have survived the preceding Age of Chaos unscathed so perhaps there was something to it.  Philmore’s Prophecy was kept by a small band of humans hidden away in a mountain valley who believed that a Savior would one day return to “undo what had been done”.  A blind sculptor was at work carving The Savior into stone on the side of a mountain, presumably by divine inspiration.  It did not yet possess any recognizable features when you last saw it several hundred years ago as most of the work accomplished by that time was clearing the surrounding land and preparing the rock surface.  They people of the valley believed they were cursed and that The Savior would lift the curse from the valley.  Many strange events occurred while you visited the valley and you did not doubt that there appeared to be some curse upon these people.  However, you did not see how you could help them and eventually you wished them luck and travelled out of the valley.  The Quaranian Codices dealt with a series of manuscripts that described how The Lost God would either be freed from her underground prison, or would have her soul destroyed forever depending upon the exact sequencing of events during a prescribed ritual.  The Quaranian Codices also described where the Lost God would be found.  Humans and Gnomes worked side by side exploring a vast network of underground caverns in search of the Lost God and you spent many weeks in those caverns as well assisting them before you determined that it was time to move on.  The Prophecies of Eiselfane are a series of seemingly unrelated and bizarre rantings of an insane Beholder who the men of Trillingham discovered and captured in the forests near their village.  Completely overcome by insanity, the Beholder was incapable of mounting any resistance and was easily captured by the humans who brought it back to Trillingham as a totem or as “counting coup”.  Eventually the villagers began to believe that the Beholder which they had named Eiselfane possessed prophetic powers and began to record his bizarre rantings.  These recollections are merely the most interesting of encounters with prophesy mad Demihumans as you recall encountering many more than described above.  You never stayed in these communities long and it is difficult to recall specific details regarding the many groups and prophecies you encountered.Throughout the hundreds of years that you have travelled Middle Earth you have found scant clues to your past.  Your only lead seems to be that your identity is occasionally mistaken for a man who shares similar features and temperament to yours.  His trail has led you to a small town in the north called New Breverik.  This man has not been seen in New Breverik, but the trail of sightings that you have followed indicate that he may be in this region.  You have decided to base yourself out of New Breverik while you wait for word from the many contacts you have developed in surrounding communities.While waiting to hear word, you have had some friendly banter with a group of budding adventurers who have gathered in New Breverik.  You have always had trouble relating to normal humans and other demihumans who do not possess the mentality of a fighter.  You find that there is a certain purity and purpose in patrolling uncivilized lands, meeting the monstrous, passing judgment, and delivering justice all in one short episode and that only fellow fighters can truly understand this purity and purpose.One other curious detail likely connects you to your past. From 33 June through 3 July each year and when bathed in the full moon as always appears on those dates, you can make out the faint traces of a strange symbol that appears on the palm of your dominant hand.  While you are an open book about much of the past that you remember, something tells you that this symbol is deeply personal and private.  You have not shared its existence with anyone.

Torvald Son of Tormond son of Tharmond, of the Doomhammer clan, from the citadel of Hammerheim, known as Torvald Doomhammer in the lands of Men.Personality: Torvald is young and optimistic, and convinced that with Thor’s might, all things are possible. He loves books and learning, and thinks people who don’t read are probably idiots. He’s a child of wealth, ignorant of his privilege, which makes him  Background: Scholar’s ApprenticeAs the apprentice and assistant of a dedicated scholar, Torvald has spent years painstakingly copying ancient manuscripts and translating tales written in dead languages, sorting out forgeries from real antiques, and piecing together stories by weaving together disparate fragments found across many documents. He is at home in a library, surrounded by books. He loves learning new things and sharing what he learns, and has a knack for remembering odd bits of information. Sometimes it’s even useful. Skill proficiencies: History, InvestigationFeature: Possibly Relevant InformationTorvald has read many, many books. There’s a very good chance that he’s run across something like whatever he’s dealing with in one of them. It might even be true! BackstoryAs a child, Torvald intended to follow in his father’s footsteps as a brewmaster, but found his calling in the worship of Thor as a warrior priest. For the past 15 years, Torvald has served Halfdan son of Hallbjorn son of Halvor, of the Runeaxe clan, a senior cleric of Thor, first as an apprentice and then as an assistant. Halfdan is an exacting master, but Torvald has thrived under his tutelage, learning to fight and to work through Thor’s grace in the casting of spells. Torvald’s master, Halfdan RuneaxeHalfdan was known in his younger days as a skilled warrior and cleric. As he has aged, he has become obsessed with the collection and study of writings from past ages. At times he seems possessed going days ignoring all things but his various collections of writings; reading, compiling notes, and dispatching letters across all of Middle Earth in search of more. He is regarded highly for his knowledge and is often sought out for his expertise in ancient scripts and the information they contain. Two years ago, Halfdan was asked to represent Hammerheim on New Breverik’s Vigilance Committee, the counterpart to Hammerheim’s War Council, a position of great honor and prestige. Together, the Vigilance Committee and the War Council oversee the defense and peacekeeping efforts throughout the valley, organizing patrols, staffing and maintaining defensive works and sentry posts. Halfdan has taken up residence in New Breverik in a small but sturdily constructed and comfortable house in the Noble’s Quarter of New Breverik, near to the Temple of Thor, where he and Torvald assist in services with the high priest, Olaf Doomhammer, a second cousin (once removed) of Torvald. HammerheimIt is the year 6133. Torvald was born in the year 6078 in the glorious Dwarven citadel of Hammerheim. He is of the Doomhammer clan, which has ruled Hammerheim since its founding by Bartel Doomhammer in 2276 CR during the Third Age of Chaos, almost 4000 years ago. The sappers and warriors of Hammerheim played a key role in Third Ragnarok, tunneling underneath the Goblin fortress of Urthag and rising from its depths to slay the Underking Gothmog and deprive Sauron of key allies. In the Fourth Age of Men, Hammerheim gained fame for its fine beers, due in part to the citadel’s long relationship with the Humans of Breverik, who supplied hops and barley. Today, in addition to the Doomhammer clan, Hammerheim is home to the Runeaxe, Stonebreaker, Steeldriver, Deepminer and Goblinslayer clans. Dwarves of the Stonebreaker, Steeldriver and Deepminer clans are most often builders, smiths and miners, while the Runeaxe and Goblinslayer clans provide warriors. During the Fourth Age of Chaos, with the valley overrun by monsters and fiends, the Humans of Breverik were encircled with no chance for escape or retreat and faced certain death. The Dwarves of Hammerheim worked quickly to save the Humans, carving tunnels from their citadel underneath the town. Then the Dwarves marched from Hammerheim toward the western flank of the forces of chaos, creating a diversion which allowed the Humans of Breverik to escape into the tunnels and to the citadel.The Humans of Breverik spent the entire Fourth Age of Chaos in Hammerheim. At first the Humans were regarded by many Dwarves as interlopers and freeloaders; however, the Humans proved to be capable fighters and loyal allies and soon won over the stony hearts of their dwarven hosts. After nearly 2000 years of shared isolation within the citadel, there was not a single element of dwarf and human culture that was not shared. They spoke each other’s languages, shared gods and values, and took each other as apprentices to train in artisanship. New BreverikIn the year 5785, with the dawning of the Fourth Age of Man, many Humans and quite a few Dwarves left Hammerheim to return to the valley, founding New Breverik just across the river from the ruins of Breverik. The Heimers and the Brekkers, as the two groups call one another, are close, and while they are fond of teasing each other regarding their cultural idiosyncrasies, they quickly unite against outsiders who show disrespect for either culture. As a sign of continuing gratitude, the Humans of New Breverik throw a feast after the fall harvest each year for the Dwarves of Hammerheim. At the third annual feast, the Dwarves reciprocated by bringing gifts from their artisans for the New Breverik Humans. It is an annual event that both Humans and Dwarves look forward to and has become known as Thanksgiving. Today, as in the past, the Humans in the valley provide two valuable services for the Dwarven citadel. New Breverik’s position on the river makes it an excellent trading post, where the wares created by Dwarven artisans are shipped and sold throughout the surrounding lands. In addition, the city and the fertile farms of the valley provide a steady source of food, including the golden hops and barley that make Hammerheim’s famous beers so well-regarded.

Anlyth (Vaniion)It is the year 6133.  Vaniion was born in the year 6101 in the royal halls of the Silvan Kingdom of Mirkwood.  Vaniion is a direct descendant of Oropher, Thranduil, and Legolas.  The wood elves of Mirkwood are held in high regard throughout Middle Earth for their role in defeating Sauron at the end of the Third Age of Mankind.Vaniion is the son of the Silvan King, Belwarthien, and Queen, Siohnen.  The Queen passed in the year 6128.  The Funeral was well attended by all the leadership of Middle Earth.  While she was a beloved Queen, it did not stifle the closely held rumors among those nearest the crown who whispered that Belwarthien was not the father of Vaniion.  Discrete and noble, the Elves of Mirkwood never discussed their suspicions in the direct presence of Vaniion, yet he is aware of the rumors. Vaniion has one older brother and a younger brother and sister.  The older brother disappeared under mysterious circumstances.  The younger siblings are twins. Lyestan is the eldest of the four siblings.  Born in the year 6097 He went missing from the kingdom in the year 6105 with his Akh Mathor.  An Akh Mathor is an Elf that is assigned to both protect and guide children of royal birth until they reach an appropriate age, generally considered around 50.  The Silvan Elves searched Mirkwood for close to 2 years without uncovering a single clue regarding Lyestan’s fate, which seemed as odd to the King and Queen as his disappearance.  Both the King and the Queen, despite the mysteriousness of Lyestan’s disappearance, have never given up hope that he will one day return.  At every meal a place setting is set in wait of Lyestan’s return.    While Vaniion does not have many memories of his older brother, the ones he retains are strong.  In these memories Vaniion remembers Lyestan as a loving older brother who included Vaniion on all of his childhood adventures.  Vaniion was heartbroken when his brother disappeared.  Lierin is Vaniion’s younger sister and his favorite sibling.  Bercareth is her twin brother.  As twins they are very close to one another and do everything as a team.  Lierin and Bercareth were born in the year 6115.  Lierin is arranged to be married to the heir apparent of the Lothlórien Kingdom in the year 6215 after they both have achieved an appropriate age and the opportunity to know each other.  Lierin finds the Lothlórien Elves a bit vain and proud and she has not yet noted any endearing qualities in her betrothed, but she admits that she is young and that there is time.  She will depart Mirkwood in 6135 to spend a few decades with the Lothlórien Elves.  Both the Lothlórien and Mirkwood Elves are looking forward to the wedding and the promise for better relations between the two Kingdoms that it portends.  Bercareth admits that he will be devastated when Lierin leaves the Kingdom.Yaladasnin is Vaniion’s Akh Mathor and has been his constant companion since birth.  Yaladasnin has been present for every major event in Vaniion’s life.  Yaladasnin taught Vaniion his first letters and how to wield his first sword and fire his first arrow.  There is an intrinsic trust between the two.At the age of 22, Vaniion was placed in charge of one of the kingdom’s patrols.  Vaniion loved patrolling Mirkwood and the surrounding lands and mountains.  He was a natural leader and his men and women of his patrol loved him. In the year 6130, Belwarthien left the Kingdom of Mirkwood for Valinor in search of clues related to The Mercenary’s Creed, a prophesy that he had become obsessed with.  In Vaniion’s youth his teachers and his Akh Mathor taught him many prophesies.  The Pylotic Prophesy, The Mrin Codex, The Mercenary’s Creed, and the Prophesy of the Lost Gods are just a few that he learned.  Belwarthien always stressed the importance of knowing prophesy and Vaniion knows many older Elves who regard certain prophecies very highly so it was not a complete shock to you when your father decided to depart on a journey in search of prophetic meaning.  Vaniion remembers bits and pieces of prophecy, but put most of that learning behind him after he started patrolling.  Vaniion knows that only the rich and royalty spend any serious time studying prophecies.With only 32 years of experience behind him, Vaniion was placed in charge of the kingdom with his Akh Mathor assigned as ghost regent.  Running the kingdom was never Vaniion’s aspiration and he did not enjoy it.  He was much more at home searching the Mirkwood or the neighboring mountains or plains.  After two years of enduring the privation and misfortune associated with ruling, and secretly plagued by thoughts that his rule might be considered illegitimate, Vaniion gathered his younger siblings and told them he was leaving the kingdom.  Lierin and Bercareth argued that this was not allowed as  Lierin had obligations to Lothlórien and Bercareth was considered too young, even with his Akh Mathor as ghost regent, to rule the Kingdom.  Vaniion, they argued, could not avoid his responsibilities.  Young and impulsive, Vaniion in company with his Akh Mathor left the Kingdom in secret shortly thereafter.    Knowing that his siblings will search for him and that they will send word throughout the known kingdoms, Vaniion dropped his family name and travels under the name of Anlyth.  Vaniion avoids discussing his past.  Yaladasnin although not completely behind Vaniion’s decision to leave the kingdom, cannot act in any other fashion than to support Vaniion’s chosen path and he has taken the name of Ayas while living outside the kingdom.After a year of constant travel Vaniion (Anlyth) finds himself on the outskirts of civilization in the town of New Breverik.  He and Yaladasnin (Ayas) decide that a short rest is in order before moving onward.

Lars GreentreeIt is the year 6133.  Lars Greentree was born in the year 6095 to Elgalin Greentree and Theran Greentree.  Elgalin, your mother was a Half-Elf and Theran, your father was an Elf.  Both Mom and Dad were distantly related to the Wood Elves of Mirkwood, but are descended from a long line of adventurers who left the Kingdom of Mirkwood early on during the Fourth Age of Chaos.  Both Elgalin  and Theran  were children born near the transition between the Fourth age of Chaos and the Fourth Age of Mankind and were more comfortable living a life of uncertainty that was common during the time of their births than they were in the confines of civilization.  Elgalin and Theran, in keeping with their recent ancestry, were adventurers in a small but modestly successful adventuring party. In the year 6105, Elgalin and Theran Greentree departed with an adventuring group to the ruins of Imrryr, once known as The Dreaming City.  It was a campaign that had been years in the planning as the dangers of Dragon Isle were well documented.  While the risks were high, the rewards promised to be equally so; the adventuring party had been to the outskirts of Dragon Isle several times and had never been disappointed.  The adventuring party never returned.  While he has fond memories of both parents, Lars remembers his mother the best as she was sometimes left behind while his father adventured to support the family.  Elgalin was a caring mother and a good teacher.  In their home on the outskirts of the port city of Bergen she taught him the languages of the Dwarves, Gnomes, and Halflings which she learned in her youth along with the language of Orcs and the peculiar dialect of the Drow which she learned during her adventuring years.  She was also fond of regaling Lars with tales of adventuring.On the eve of their departure for the ruins of Imrryr, Elgalin  and Theran travelled into Bergen and left Lars with Svavar Gardarson, a human and distant cousin on Elgalin’s side of the family.  Svavar was more than just a distant relation, he was also a close family friend who had helped Elgalin  and Theran on numerous occasions.Lars’ last memory of his mother was her attaching an amulet around his neck and making him promise that he would never remove it.  Elgalin claimed that it was magical and would help protect him while she and Theran were away.  She warned him that the amulet would now be specially linked with Lars, but that the link would be broken and it’s magic would fail if the amulet was ever removed.  Lars has never removed the amulet.  At times Lars wonders if his mother had kept the amulet for herself then maybe she would have survived.      At first, Svavar acted as Lars’s protector and continued his education and raised him as he felt that Elgalin  and Theran would have desired.  However, as the years wore on and it became apparent that Elgalin  and Theran would never return, Svavar began to treat Lars as his own son and raised him in that fashion.  It was not long thereafter that Svavar took Lars into his confidence and showed him a whole new world.  Svavar is the head of a vast network of thieves and assassins throughout all of Middle Earth called “The Organization”.  Not every thief and assassin in Middle Earth belongs to the organization, but many do.  Those that do not belong to The Organization typically deal in small petty crime and are seldom organized in anything larger than a street gang.  Thieves and assassins who aspire to greater crimes or who become organized at a higher level are generally approached by The Organization and made an offer that they cannot refuse.The Organization exists on two levels.  The outer ring is a network of smuggling, extortion, and similar higher level crimes which require a level of sophistication and organization beyond that of a mere street gang.  Those that belong to the outer ring work on the shadowy fringes of society and, while the existence of The Organization is difficult to conceal in entirety, they nevertheless go through great pains to eliminate all evidence that points definitively to its existence.  Thieves and assassins take blood oaths and frequently risk themselves personally in order to maintain the secrets of The Organization.  Despite these efforts and despite the lack of any direct evidence to its existence, rumors of The Organization and its alleged activities are common throughout Middle Earth.The inner ring of The Organization is a group within the group.  The inner ring does not deal in the affairs of organized crime for profit.  The work of the inner ring is that of statecraft; corrupting bureaucracies, stealing state secrets, blackmail and extortion at the state level, kidnappings of high officials, and assassinations of those who are supposed to be impossible to assassinate.  The inner ring works to obtain political power and leverage in order to advance the interests of The Organization.  While operatives in the outer ring sometimes act unknowingly to carry out the interests of the inner ring, only those thieves and assassins that are part of the inner ring know of its existence.     Svavar runs a legitimate shipping company in Bergen which allows him to launder money and also provides him the necessary excuses when he finds it necessary to travel on behalf of The Organization.  Most of his employees have no idea that they are working as part of a front for The Organization.  At the same time that Svavar was apprenticing Lars through The Organization, he was also apprenticing Lars through his legitimate shipping company in order to provide Lars with an adequate cover for his travels and entanglements.  Lars has worked as a longshoreman, foreman, dock supervisor, and warehouse manager.  While the initial years when the exact nature of their relationship was being forged were difficult for both Lars and Svavar, Svavar has proven to be a worthy adoptive father to Lars and it is plain to both those inside and outside The Organization that he cares for Lars deeply.  Svavar his striven to provide Lars with every advantage.  Svavar was widowed before taking Lars in and has never bothered to remarry.  Without any other children to his name and fast approaching the age of 80, he has made it clear to both the outer and inner rings that Lars will be his successor.  Lars, for his part, is well respected both within and without The Organization for his shrewdness and is seen as a worthy heir to both the legitimate and illegitimate dealings of his adopted father.Svavar does not see his activities as strictly criminal.  He understands that often times the activities that he is involved in are against the local laws or customs, but he is worldly enough to understand that the laws of mankind are often short sighted or poorly constructed and can vary greatly from region to region.  Svavar sees himself as an entrepreneur who is capitalizing on events and situations that would be capitalized upon by others if it were not for the simple fact that he was the first to act upon the opportunity.  Through his lens, Svavar neither sees his actions as good or as evil, he sees them simply as necessary.  Based upon this viewpoint, Svavar has a rather utilitarian philosophy to his organization’s activities.  Svavar does not act out of malice and is not willing to commit acts that will do great harm to others if they will only provide some limited good to The Organization.  He prefers what are generally considered as victimless crimes, although he is not opposed to doing harm to others when the amount of harm inflicted is considered small and the amount of gain that The Organization will receive is large. As Svavar has aged he has become more and more obsessed with a prophecy that was delivered to a distant ancestor and head of The Organization.  Lars never bothered much with prophecies as he was too concerned with the important business of the here and now to worry over such insubstantialities as prophecies suggest.  However, Lars could not fully avoid Svavar’s obsession and was at least aware that this particular prophecy was delivered by the Oracle of Pylos and that it described a time and circumstance when the “Kingdom within Kingdoms” would rule and guide Middle Earth through an age of chaos.  The Pylotic Prophecy is considered private family business and Lars is unaware of anyone beyond Svarvar who may have knowledge of its existence.   Svavar has confided in Lars that he believes that events are on the rise that will provide greater illumination regarding the Pylotic Prophecy and has directed Lars to proceed to the town of Breverik where you are to make contact with Fordin, an operative in the outer ring who acts as The Organization's eyes and ears in that region.  While Fordin is ignorant of the inner ring and the Pylotic Prophesy, he has delivered reports to Svavar that lead Svavar to believe that events are occurring in that region that were foretold in the prophecy.  Svavar believes these events are connected to the Temple of Thor and has directed Lars, his most trusted operative, to proceed to Breverik and to do his best to monitor the region and the temple along with Fordin.  Just prior to Lars’ departure, Svavar was a bit emotional regarding Lars leaving.  In an exceptionally warm and tender moment while Svavar was personally outfitting Lars for his journey, Svavar shared with him the following sentiment.  “In the past I have shielded you from certain truths regarding my past.  It is unlikely as you go out into the world that I will be able to continue to shield you from these truths.  I would share these truths with you now if I knew a path to do so.  But I do not.  Please know, Lars, that whatever you may learn about me regarding my past that it changes nothing with respect to us.  I have and will always love you like a son.”  Lars thought this was an odd thing for Svavar to say as there was nothing imaginable to Lars that would change the way he feels toward his adopted father.  Lars chalked it up to simple nerves and provided Svavar the typical reassurances that such a situation would warrant. Lars backstory for the good people of Breverik is that he has a desire to follow in the footsteps of his late mother and father and to try his skills at adventuring.

Devona and her twin sister Senra are the last daughters of the noble Ashlander house.  Their family's shipping fleet once boasted a hundred ships who made berth in the harbors of the capital when they weren't transporting goods between the nation's many islands.  The wealth they earned from this business bought the Ashlanders nobility and renown, and for generations they wanted for nothing.  Over time, however, as the political climate of the islands grew more severe, their business began to wane.  The Ashlanders refused to employ slave labor or slash the modest wages of their crews.  Inevitably, other traders unconcerned with taking on such practices made much greater profits, and attracted the patronage of those who shared their views on how the common people should be treated.  By the time Devona and Senra were born, the nobility of their blood existed in name alone.  The sisters spent many of their childhood hours playing within the vacant, cobwebbed corridors of the once opulent Ashlander manor.  Day by day, the borders within which they were allowed to roam grew ever smaller as more rooms and halls crumbled into dangerous disrepair.Eventually, the abandoned wings of the house grew too unsafe to continue exploring, and the sisters grew old enough to adopt more intricate hobbies - Devona taking up violin, which her sister accompanied with dancing.  The two remained one another's sole source of companionship... at least until the day that Senra's acrobatic skills caught the interest of a wealthy benefactor from outside the Capital, who offered to enroll her in a private academy where she could further hone the art of her performance free of charge.  The last time the twins saw eachother they were eight years old.  Devona would have been lying to say that she wasn't somewhat jealous - why were Senra's talents so much more impressive than her own? - but mostly she just missed her sister.  She spent much of the lonely years that followed perfecting her musical abilities and listening to her grandparents' stories.  The tales they told were of Ashlander manor during its days of glittering grandeur... of Mol'Darin before tyranny spoiled it... of their own youths spent out on the sea.Three weeks after the marking of Devona's thirteenth year her grandmother succumbed to a wasting illness she'd been battling with for some time.  Four months later, her brokenhearted grandfather followed her to the grave... and before the years' close, the letter arrived - a terrible accident, no body to bury, Senra - dead.A part of Devona never believed it - a twin just knew... but her parents put little stock in that superstition.  They mourned, they interred an empty casket in the family mausoleum next to those of their own parents, and the manorhouse grew silent.  But Devona had been inspired - both by the glimpses her grandparents' tales had given her to the life of splendor their family once enjoyed - and the power which the very words they'd spoken held... and by the mysterious fate of her twin sister.  Devona realized she didn't even know where the school Senra had been taken to was located... but she knew she would not find out - or find Senra - if she merely idled in their wasting mansion.It took little effort for Devona to convince her parents to allow her to accompany them on their voyages at sea.  Though her parents doubted their business would last to see their child take command of it, they were still eager to keep their daughter close by.  Initially Devona merely observed while they bartered and traded, but she was always eager to deepen her involvement, and soon proved to possess a natural charm and way with words.  She picked up the skills of shiphandling quickly, and used her free time during the long voyages to continue to practice her music, and, on occasion, entertain and inspire the crew with the same stories she'd grown up with.  Over the next seven years she made no progress toward the goal of discovering her sister's whereabouts, especially given that her attempts to seek information about this mysterious school and the man who ran it had to be done in secrecy so as not to upset her parents.  Instead, she made many friends among the sailors who'd remained loyal to her family.  She learned their songs, and acquainted herself with the ways of the common people from which she'd lived most her life in seperation.  It was during this period that she met and grew close to fellow Tiefling and captain in the Ashlanders' fleet Fatua Chaylum, coming to view her as a role model to look up to, and even a surrogate family member, especially after the loss of so many others.  When Devona was 20, the ship she and her parents were sailing on went down in a storm.  She washed up on a small island nearby, but there was no sign of her parents, the ship, or its crew.  It took her some time to recover from the incident, and longer still to make her way back to the capital.  When she arrived, she found that her home and her family's belongings had been seized by the nobles who had once been her neighbors.  Devona was furious and desperate to take back what was hers, but Fatua intervened.  Now that there were no Ashlanders left to ask questions, she was sure that Devona's claim on the property would prove no great obstacle to anyone currently helping themselves to her birthright.With Fatua, and a handful of other sailors behind her, Devona boarded her family's private vessel - The Midnight Star, a small pleasure craft unsuitable for carrying full shipments of goods - and sailed it out of its hidden mooring beneath Ashlander manor under cover of darkness.  Watching the lights of the great city sink into the sea behind, she vowed to restore her family’s wealth and honor by whatever means necessary.  Devona spent the next several years freelancing, taking any job that paid enough to profit - chauffeuring diplomats between cities, working as a courier for smaller loads of goods, even smuggling, and 'intercepting' other shipments if contracted to do so at a high enough price.  Not wanting to tarnish her family's name with the more sordid affairs she engaged in, Devona continued all further oceanborn adventuring under the alias of 'Captain Ash', though in situations where a different approach would be more advantageous, she sheds this persona and presents herself as the mild-mannered 'Lady Devona' instead.She still searches for her sister... but with nearly two decades gone since last they met, her hope is running thin.

Wakachaka's story begins with her swarm as they were raiding a country town - a normal activity for them to do on slow Sunday nights. After slaying the last peasant, they retired to the local tavern to revel in their looting. As the celebration wore on, Wakachaka got up on a table and started taking bets on how much ale she could drink and still remain standing.?Wakachaka doesn't remember whether she won any bets, but she assumes that she did not... She awoke the next day (maybe?) under a collapsed bed in a back room. It was a trick getting out, and once she did she found the tavern, and the whole town, abandoned. Apparently, buried under shards of wood and chunky blankets, the swarm had given up trying to find her, left her behind, and moved on... or perhaps they'd just been too hung over to realize she was even missing.?Having never been very good with directions, rather than try to find her way back, Wakachaka decided to make this town her new home. It certainly smelled better than the old den anyway, at least once she got done burning the bodies. The pantries were well-stocked and the tavern was still full of ale, and for two weeks Wakachaka lived in greater luxury than most gerblins ever know... until the visitors came... ?Luckily, it was an openminded band of adventurers (or at least not especially intelligent ones) who first arrived at her door. They thought nothing of the empty town, the wrecked tavern, or the fact that it had a gerblin for a barkeep. Wakachaka, dumbfounded by their sudden arrival, was halfway through pondering how best to slit their throats and take their coin when they just... gave it to her... in exchange for rooms and drinks. ?The next day the adventurers moved on... but they were back within the week, spending freely from the spoils of their expedition. In fact, they were so charmed by Wakachaka's somewhat vicious brand of hospitality that they promised to make her tavern a regular stop in their travels. By their next arrival Wakachaka had even managed to sweep up a bit.?This continued for a time, and before long other travelers began to filter in, brought by chance or by word of mouth from others who had sung her praises. Before she knew it, Wakachaka had a bustling business - which she named The Broken Bunk after the intoxicated accident that had ultimately led to her inheriting it. Even the empty village surrounding it was starting to attract new settlers to its conveniently vacant housing. Evidently assuming that she was the landlord, farmers and merchants started buying the land from Wakachaka and making themselves at home.?By this time, however, the ale supply was running dangerously low... but Wakachaka wasn't worried. Down in the caverns of her old den she'd been quite the accomplished poisonmaker, and she was certain she could apply those same skills to brewing. ?It took... a few attempts... and a few houses winding up mysteriously empty again when her patrons sampled from those early failed batches, but Wakachaka eventually found a method that worked, and the ale flowed freely from her tavern once more. For years to follow, Wakachaka diligently perfected her craft and expanded her menu. Her brews won awards and even gained her membership in the kingdom's renowned brewer's guild. Wakachaka became so elated with her string of successes that she began celebrating them with the same raucous fervor that she had the original raid on the town.?After one incident during which she all but emptied her whole stock herself, Wakachaka fell into an drunken stupor so deep that she slept three straight days, and during that extended unconsciousness, she received a revelation... Wakachaka woke up to find she'd been bestowed secret knowledge and power straight from the drink itself. The next day, without a word of warning to her customers, her employees, or her many taxpayers, she packed away her brewing equipment, emptied the remaining kegs in her storeroom, locked up the Broken Bunk, and disappeared.?Since then, Wakachaka has lived on the road, taking up a life of adventure like those first guests to come to her humble inn. She wanders the world in pursuit of a most profound quest - to assemble the perfect combination of ingredients needed to brew a beverage of the most sublime taste and highest potency... at which point, for her noble efforts, Wakachaka believes she will ascend to achieve a higher state of being. Along the way she intends to seek out and sample all manner of alchohols of exotic origin to help further hone her palatte for this monumental task.
Child turned street urchin after family home was destroyed by racist cult. Street urchin turned Bard by act of kindness.
Fishing village home was attached my merpeople, family was killed. Rescued by merchant ship captain, and lived as a sailor for 30+ years. Captain was replaced by a villain, so I left the ship.

Born in the city of Amthydor, Veit Hlin, a 4 feet 6 inch tall human wizard has aspirations to become the greatest wizard in all of Raia. He trains hard and has a natural intelligence of 26. After he becomes the most powerful wizard, he plans to conquer Pyyroth, the mageocracy rival to his home of Amthydor. If he succeeds at that, he wants to begin killing all of the demigod and absorbing their divine power. Eventually, he wants to destroy the entire pantheon and become the one, true god of everything.
Raised as a fairy slave until he escaped captivity .
Entire village was killed by kobolds. She was raised by wolves. She can shapeshift. She is weird abound "civilized" types.

Amaranthe was born into a noble family. Her land was invaded by a great empire, and lost the war. She led a resistance movement against it, defending the true heir until at least she was captured and sent to Exile. Exile was a strange pocket dimension full of mysteries and danger, and the remains of a great evil that was trying to re-enter the world.

Pteron's family were killed in a random act of wild sorcery. He was placed with the monastery afterward. Upon leaving the monastery after it was destroyed in an battle between 2 kingdoms, Pteron was left alone. He met with a group of others and began exploring the kingdom. He rose through the monastic ranks until his order's line died out. He began spying for various kingdoms in an attempt to root out the evils in the world and bring chaos under control.

Sort of a Huckster type, smooth talking half-elf rogue who goes by Cal (short for Rapscallion). Slave of house Arvu, probably originally from some rural tribe or another that one of the merchant caravans happened across. I'm thinking Grandwater took him, and then sold him off to Arvu when they got back to Khemi. Probably one of his parents sold him off, maybe because being a half-breed was shameful to them, but if it works better that he was just taken that's a good hook too.Quickly learned that words and subtle action had more power than violence. He was probably a bit of a bully at first, until someone taught him that lesson. Fast forward a ten-year or so and he's talked his way in the the personal service of one of Leopold Arvu's wives. Would put on shows, tell stories, go out and steal small trinkets for her, etc. I imagine it's not uncommon for both male and female high ranking merchants to keep consorts, but when Leopold found out about it (being a jealous type) he gave Cal over to the researchers of house Arvu who were looking to improve upon the design of their glyph of protection. Unfortunately this process has many trials and errors along the way... and Leopold was counting on an error. Cal was given a modified Glyph (mechanically maybe no protection as it was a total failure, or maybe just on par with a normal glyph at lvl 1 protection) and subjected to a Demon... who possessed him. In true quick talking Huckster fashion though, he struck a deal for their lives (they would kill him and the demon both after all). Leave Cal in control for now, lend him some power, and he would get them out.This process took place in a remote research facility of the Arvu, in a village secretly under their control. The place had a very Area 51 vibe in the cultural lore of the area, with more than the normal rumors circulating, sightings of monsters, villagers gone missing in the night, etc. The whole village is run through with a network of underground tunnels, and there are lots houses with fake doors and no occupants, used as fronts for the research labs and having their only points of ingress and egress as these tunnels. They had more food and fine inks being imported than the populace could possibly use (secretly needed for the researchers and slaves). Cal survived his ordeal, appearing not to have been possessed, and was kept on as a slave for further study and, he suspected, eventual dissection at Leopold’s request. So, Cal and the Devil set a plan into motion, leaking little tidbits to the villagers of the sizeable shipments being snuck in to the facilities at night. One evening raiders attacked the village, responding to the rumors of great wealth flooding in, and Cal took his chance. In a gambit he hoped would look to his masters like he was trying to protect their interests, he approached the raiders alone. He was feeling confident that he could talk his way into their good graces and in so doing make his escape… but he miscalculated. He was beaten within an inch of his life, tied in to a sack, and thrown into river. By a true stroke of luck, a war-tattered man (Chris’ character) saw this turn of events and plucked him from his watery grave. Mr. Noname brought Cal back to health over the coming weeks, but then snuck off with nary a word. A strange turn of events, to be so indebted to a stranger and have them ask for nothing in return. At least now the Arvu would take him for dead…. If he could just find a way to remove the slave mark he might be able to keep them in the dark for a while longer...

A dwarven paladin slew a mighty dragon, which released a magical burst when it died. A nearby dragon egg hatched into the world's first dragonborn. The dwarf took it back to his city, where the dragonborn, now known as Arjhan Ironbeard, was raised. The dwarves simply called him a "tall dwarf," and accepted him as one of their own. He learned a lot about tunneling, mining, and the ways of his dwarven ancestors. When Arjhan went out to adventure as a paladin in his own right, he was stunned to see all of the non-dwarf races in the world, and they were even more stunned to see him.

Sakis got in trouble with the drow for breaking their cultural norms, and while he was awaiting his punishment, he prayed to his house's demon lord patron, Socothbenoth. Fortunately and unfortunately for the good looking young drow, Socothbenoth is the demon lord of perversion, and immediately took a liking to Sakis, and chose him to be his champion. Sakis was wildly unqualified for the role, being so young and inexperienced, as well as not really being into the whole "evil" thing. His patron threw him into a city plagued with corruption and greed, and told Sakis to go do things and get stronger, until he could be a good champion. Sakis dresses like a member of a black metal band, and tries to do the right thing in ways that seem over the top scary and evil.

Bored with the simple lifestyle of her fellow halfling, Niershka set out to make a name for herself. Along the way, she made acquaintance with a lone inventor. He became her mentor and led her to the People of the Sand, and underground desert society where those of all races gather to form a rag-tag group of misfits, outcasts, warriors, and thieves. Many there do not worship and are prone to logic based thinking, but there is still a strong religious secret within the People of the Sand. As an apprentice, Niershka began to study mechanical contraptions. She soon became adept in tinkering, fixing, and inventing. Once her mentor passed, she took over his shop and has expanded the business. While her shop in the desert is her main business, she also occasionally opens pop ups with mechanical wonders. Despite her mentor's good heart and kindness for others, Niershka does not harbor said trait. She explores the world soley to make a profit and lies and steals her way to fame.
