What's important to her is to make a name for herself and gather riches to strengthen her shop and mechanical research. She is manipulative and sneaks her way through situation. No one ever expects such trickey from a small halfling female, and she's full aware of that. She is not wicked, but rather very selfish and focused on what's good for her. Despite her small mindedness, she is loved by the people of the Sand, and is considered one of the prices of their community, with many lining up long before her doors open to see what fantastic, new mechanical wonder she has in store for them next.

Nes’s mother was the town baker and her father was a sailor who was never in town. When her mother decided to go off on an adventure to find her father, Nes and her older sister took over the bakery and expanded it to include a brothel,”because they like to make things rise.” Eventually Nes went off in search of her own adventure leaving the bakery/brothel under her sister’s care. Along the way Nes developed a split personality, Sen, who was trained at a secret assassin school and comes out when Nes is threatened or under stress.

N’talhi came into her power very simply. Her family had been protectors of a death god referred to as the Unknown for generations. She was expected to continue this family journey as well. Spreading the word of the Unknown, and living by it’s rules. As the second child in her family, her brother was to take his place as the head of the temple once their mother chose to step down, while N’talhi was allowed to travel more freely. The local lord of their city, Lord Cavannaugh, was a very religious man and encouraged his family to regularly attend worship on the holy days of the Unknown. His youngest daughter, Kalina, was often in attendance. Kalina and N’talhi soon became fast friends, and then infatuated with each other. Together they schemed up a political pact that would ensure they could live together without any “family duties” preventing them from being together. They proposed a “political marriage” that really had little to do with politics and more to do with love. Their parents allowed this, and chose to view it as a political union between the heads of state and the head of religion in their region. One day, Kalina had been acting strangely, and had stopped attending worship at the temple of the Unknown. After about a week N’talhi, being of a stubborn sort, tracked her down and realized that not all was what it seemed. Through her connection with the unknown it became clear that Kalina had been killed, her corpse reanimated, and was being used by mecromancers to disrupt the political situation. In tears she struck down the creature that was once her fiancée, and carefully brought her body to the temple. Once the body had been slain a second time, it became clear that she had been dead for quite some time. N’talhi took it as a personal failure that she and her temple had not been able to notice the infiltration of the undead in their home. She was heartbroken and furious. She offered up a deal to the Unknown- eradicate the sect of mecromancers spitting in the face of their religion, and she would be granted her love back. Whole and unharmed. The Unknown accepted, and N’talhi now roams throughout the world, searching for whispers of the black sect, and making sure that no others fall to the same fate as she. Now all she needs is a group of friends to help her carve out the undead.
From the menzoberranzan, Drizzt escaped the ways of the drow to lead his own life of adventure and ass beating.

Gar's father was a noble with a bad gambling problem and he lost so much money that Gar had only hand-me-down weapons and armor and no warhorse. So, at age seventeen, he set out to make a fortune. His best bet, he figured, was to find a wealthy wife. But, meanwhile, he joined some treasure-seekers.

Oldest child and daughter of Jacob and Irina Timberson (the most prominent Carpenter family in the unapproachable east)Biography:in her youth Idun was plauged by nightmares - which she found out was a result of her heritage. several links back her lineage includes a black dragon and a Pit Fiend. She learned to control her inner chaos, after years of self-punishment and scarification (which she inflicted upon herself). Her "Black blood" as her tutor called her lineage. was also a source of power which she, with the help of her tutor, learned to channel into furious dark and destructive magic. Later on when Idun the felt there was no more to learn from her tutor she killed him in a dark ritual which honed her demonic powers even further. Her powers comes partly from af demonic pact. The demon of question, 'Ashkantosh' was humiliated several times by the Goddess Shar. 'Ashkantosh' found a way to create flames that tap the shadow weave, and hereby lessening Shar's power. This way Idun is able to conjure flames that cannot be put out by normal means. It consumes everything, even magical fire. And hereby it's able to damage creature, normally immune to fire damage (dealing half damage). The only thing that the flames can't consume is Idun herself, demons superior to 'Ashkantosh' and dieties.

Keezle had thing for jests since he was a wee little gnome. His memory turned out to be astonishing, so a local Wizard took him in as an apprentice(during a memory game contest at one of the many festivals). Though his master was very open to keezle creative ideas, at least in the beginning, it went out of hand, and Master Molton Runesprocket told Keezle to go explore the world and learn from it. Prior to the Time of Troubles, Keezle fought many underdark denizens to protect and help several Gnomen and dwarven societies in the Unapproacheable East. During the time of Troubles, Keezle was of great service to the avatar of Garl Glittergold (though Oblivious to the fact). Garl honoured keezle by making him one of his chosen. This has made Keezle unaging and further helps his vision to make Faerun a bit more jolly.At the moment Keezle enjoys tricking and annoying the evil population of the fallen kingdom of Mhourgh Brak. Currently his greatest enjoyment comes from the Young Adult Deep Dragon that dwells in a cave connected to the old Vault.

Pyriel was left broken on the steps of a church as a child. Raised by the priests and priestesses of the church of Bahamut, left him scarred and angry. As a man he was filled with hatred and strong desires for strict order, so he chose the Life of a Paladin to create the order he sought.While in battle, he committed atrocities that angered his God, causing Pyriel to lose his powers. The battle raged still, with Pyriel fighting to near his last breath. At death's door, a demon spoke to him, offering a deal. Follow Lord Dispater, in his city of iron and rust, forge a world of strict, unflinching order in Dispater's name. Become a tyrant and Dispater would Grant him life anew. Pyriel took the deal, cursing the dragon God's name. His armor, previously a vibrant adamantium, darkened. His Lance, broken from conflict began glowing green, as it pulled metal from around it to reforge. Sir Pyriel's faithful steed, shot down by bowmen, rose back to life, shadows clinging to it form. Pyriel's wounds healed and his anger renewed. Climbing atop his nightmare, Sir Pyriel rode once again in the name of order. In the name of the Tyrant God, Dispater.

The daughter of a noble Elven family, Althaea was brought up in the life of luxury. During her youth though, her homeland was thrown into turmoil as it became embroiled in a devastating civil war. She was recruited to be a spy by the Rebels due to her status as a noble allowing her access to sensitive areas.Althaea's status as a spy and assassin was eventually uncovered and she was stripped of her nobility and forced to ground. She managed to escape by tricking her persuers into believing someone else was her.She later sailed across the seas to the Sword Coast, were she makes a living as a thief, spy, assassin and adventurer.
Xenophobic noble

I grew up in The Evermoors, a secluded community of mostly halflings spread across a selection of small islands connected by rickety bridges and natural canals between the mangroves. The majority of our interaction with the world beyond was via trading boats with the nearby city. I would spend hours with my best friend Kaolan looking at the strange wares that the traders brought. Otherwise we’d be playing in the trees when we were younger or causing mayhem in and around the taverns as we got older – we we’re practically inseparable.One evening, after a few too many tankards of sour wine, Kaolan and I were huddled in the corner of the tavern listening to Bong-Eyed Balthezar the Untrustworthy (he’d never done anything to make him untrustworthy, there was just an old folk tale about being suspicious of people who don’t look straight at you when they’re talking to you) play a lute and sing of distant lands. I still only vaguely remember professing some level of love to be able to move a crowd as the music was moving me that night but the next morning Kaolan bought me my own lute from the trading boats and I couldn’t be happier! From then I spent countless evenings creating melodies and singing about the legends of our islands with Kaolan by my side, either helping with the lyrics or lamping anyone who got a bit too close and touchy-feely whilst I was performing (closer than I’d normally consider tolerable, that is). I couldn’t have been happier than I was those years. And then Kaolan was gone.His parents had important connections with the trading guild in the city and so he was sent away as part of an arranged marriage to secure a “financially beneficial future” they told me in a rather matter of fact way. Everything on the islands felt cold and unwelcoming. Even when the autumnal bonfires blazed high into the night sky and families would come together, laughing and joking, I felt lost. Turning to rotten mead and wine wouldn’t bring Kaolan back but it was certainly preferable to clarity. It was during an eve of drinking that Balthezar was weaving tales of travelling musicians – dwarves, halflings and the like who traveled the country, living a nomadic lifestyle with the their instruments, each other and nothing more.Early the following morning, as the hangover wore off and I could see in colour again, I packed up my possessions, got onto one of the trading boats, left The Evermoors for the first time in my life and never looked back.

Alisya was the daughter of the vicious Orc warlord Ugric and the farmer's wife Annisya. Ugric led an army that plundered Annisya's village, murdering her husband and leaving most of the town for dead. Annisya survived, however, and nine months later gave birth to the half-orc daughter, Alisya, who she cherished as a miracle emerging from the darkest moments of horror in her life. As a young girl, Alisya realized a powerful darkness coursed through her veins, and she became a cleric in hopes of atoning for the sins of her father -- and in hopes of holding her own demons at bay.

Growing up on a farm can be so boring, until you discover that one of the barn cats is your familiar!  Turns out she had a natural talent for spells and decided to turn her tllwntvto create spells that released her from her chores, but ishe lost control of the spells and her chores took over the farm and the whole farm got up and walked away.  The town wisely called for a mage to come from a neighboring city and train the hapless hedge wizard some magic discipline.

At only 8 years old, Pinnifer’s parents went missing. Turns out they were powerful Witches who stood guard against dark witchcraft and were abducted. A dark spell was placed on Punnifer, causing the town not to recognize that her parents disappeared. So for the next three years Pinnifer had to survive on her own with out the help of the local town-folk.  Now at 11 years old, Pinnifer has discovered her parents journal detailing their battle with dark witchcraft and she’s taken it upon herself to learn magic and strike out to find her parents and confront the evil witch who destroyed her childhood..

Father: A Wood Elf named Sindar, member of the Verdant Guard that patrols in and around Syngorn.  He is a member of the Wardens of Syngorn Faction and reports up to Verdant Lord Celindar, one of the 4 Elf Wardens.Mother: A human named Sharon, who originally came to Syngorn as a member of a trading party from Emon to The Tarn Ward.  She stayed behind to work for an Elven trader.Sindar met and fell in love with Sharon in the course of his duties in the Verdant Guard providing protection in The Tarn Ward.  Sirron was their only offspring.  Because this birth was not sanctioned by the Office of the Voice of Memory and the general feeling towards mixed race children, Sindar, Sharon and Sirron soon moved out into the Verdant Expanse and Sindar continued his duties around the The Shifting Keep.  Growing up in the wilds of The Verdant Expanse, I soon grew to love nature and developed my skills in hunting, tracking, and other ways of the wild.  In my mid 20's I started following the teachings of the Dawnfather, Patron of Rangers, supporter of the needy and destroyer of evil.  I have spent the last 3 years roaming the wilds and honing my skills.  My travels have recently taken me to the city of Westruun.

His family was murdered by a group of bandits. He spent the next few years hunting them down. Due to anger issues he fought as a barbarian. After a weird dream he came to peace with what happened and started practising his druidcraft again.
Mercenary

Bloodybucket is a minotaur trained as a ninja at Clan Ki, in the old empire. Clan Ki located on a stormy island to the south east of the known world. He was adopted by the clan leader after she found him on the island's shore among the shipwreck. Bloodybucket was presumably a baby minotaur that got captured with his parents and transport on a ship before it's shipwreck was found. Minotaur is a creature of unrelenting rage and anger, suitable as guardian who kill before ask a question, but it was creature relatively unknown to south eastern region. He was found in a large bucket filled with blood and burned corpses of two minotaurs with slit wrists next to it. Presumably his parents try to cover their baby with their own blood to repelled the fire burning the ship for the baby. And hence the nickname Bloodybucket.As for the clan leader, she only seen an abandoned baby creature in need of care. Clan Ki masters teached Bloodybucket how to control his rage at the early age. He mastered also the art of deception and martial art. As Bloodybucket come to an age, it's clan's tradition to venture on a pilgrim to find yourself before he can be allows back into the Island. The clan leader told Bloodybucket about his past and the west world beyond the sea, there he must venture forward to find himself. Adventure awaits...

Who else but Ducky would hate Geese more in the world? No one. That is the answer. But how did all this come to be, you ask? Well whether you are asking or not, too bad, I’m going to tell you anyways. Our tale begins in the magical land of Aenora. Well… only sort-of magical. Obviously there are wizards and shite, but that is beside the point. 20 years ago to the day this tale was wrote, a young boy by the name of Memely Pepeartly. Not a day over the age of 5 he was, the skipper young lad. His mother, a Halfling Bardess locally known as “The Iron Maiden” for her sick luting skills, raised her son lovingly, teaching him the small things about music that he would eventually grow to love.Upon the young halfing’s 5th birthday, his mother decidedly took him to a travelling fair, of sorts, complete with run magic, rides, and the many animals of the realm. The day couldn’t had been more perfect. The two were bonding as best a mother and her son could, and even a blind-man could see the love they had for each other. That all changed however, when one the pair decided to visit one of the animals on display to pet and play with. It all happened in a fun exhibit of the fair, for what could be considered the petting zoo of the event. Many sorts of small and exotic creatures were on display for the young ones to play with and pet. Nothing hostile or dangerous of the sort. Memely, curious of a rather large bird out on display with a large sign reading “Deep Goose”, cautiously walked forward to make friends with the animal. His mother, unaware what was going on, as she too, was interested at some of the cute animals, was unaware that her small, halfing child, holding his ice-cream happily in his hands, was venturing further and further into the exhibit in pursuit of the Goose. Eventually, far out of earshot of Memely’s mother, the Goose noticed the food that he had in his small hands. The Goose, concerned with nothing else but the food, attempted to take it from the small child, but only proceeded to pick up the boy entirely, and, scared at the mass now kicking and crying, proceeded to fly and jump over the crowds, over the fence enclosing the place, and, with Memely in tow, out into the woods, far away from his mother. Kicking and screaming, trying to get the Goose to release him, eventually, it let him go, and,seeking its reward, plucked the treat from the halfing’s small hand, and leaving him there; alone and crying in the woods without a mother, and no signs of any onlookers or rescue. Days went by, as Memely waited for help, finding shelter in trees, and calling out to anyone who would be able to hear him, but to no avail. Each day, he wandered out a little bit further in the hopes of finding someone… anyone; but each day he unknowingly became just a little bit more lost. One day, the halfling happened upon a rather large lake uncharacteristically dominating the once forested landscape he had come to know the past weeks. Finding refuge in this new place, Memely sought shelter within a large, hollowed tree bordering the forest outside of the lake. It wasn’t until the next morning, upon waking up, that the small halfing realized that, even without blankets, or any means but his clothes to keep warm, he felt a friendly presence around him, and upon further inspection, found that he was surrounded by Ducks; many of them, all huddled around him and sleeping in a group. Perplexed that these birds had taken such a liking to him, he befriended them over the coming weeks, foraging for food, seeking shelter, and learning to swim.Weeks went by, and the halfing, now considering the group of Ducks his family, felt considerably less sad at the prospect of losing his mother. Each day, he became more and more distant from the life he once had, and closer to the one he shared with his family of Ducks. Eventually, he donned the name “Ducky”, and this being part of his new identity, he slowly began forgetting about his previous one each day. It wasn’t until the age of 10 that things would interrupt the perfect life he lived with his family of Ducks. He had only just woken up one day, when the most peculiar noises started emanating from a far edge of the lake. It was mystifying to him; after years of hardly any other human, or humanoid, rather, contact of any form, there sat a group of fellow halfings. 3 or 4 of them, all playing a rather calming tune with, what looked like to Ducky, bowls with sticks on the end, with spanning strings down the length of the contraption. He had never heard anything like it. It was a wonderful freeing feeling to hear the notes and harmonies that sailed through the air.Wanting to learn more about it all, and to get a better listen, he neared closer and closer to the halflings that would soon have a defining effect upon Ducky’s life. Upon further inspection of the group, they took notice of the small boy. It had been years since he had been missing, so unsurprisingly, he was not seen as the missing halfling boy from years prior. In fact, at first they simply laughed at the mannerisms of the child as he approached, dancing all the while, beaming all the while.Setting up camp for the night, the group noticed that the strange child, who, they had figured out, spoke very little common or halfling, had not returned to a family of other halflings they had originally presumed were accompanying him around the lake, but rather took refuge in a large and empty tree. Upon further investigation, they realized that this child seemed to not have a mother or father at all. It was not until the next day that, before leaving, they offered to take Ducky along with them. With the little language that he had retained from childhood, he was able to understand their proposition, and was delighted at the prospect of being with others who looked like him, and others who he had found great enjoyment in the way they played their strange instruments. He told his family of ducks his farewells with the small gestures he had picked up as a child to communicate with them, and was off into the world with this strange band of strangers who had seemed to take a liking to him.The group of travelling performers had quickly realized that Ducky had no family to call on. It had simply been too long, and the search had been long over, so adopting him into their group, they traveled together for many years. Fast-forward about 8, and in that time, Ducky had been taught how to speak fluently in the two languages he grew up with, being Halfling and Common, and learned how to play all sorts of instruments. Though he has very skilled at instruments like the pan-flute, and all sorts of drums, he always took a very particular liking to the Lute, especially.As Ducky was 18 now, he felt profoundly inspired to get a greater education in the music he had come to love from his lively band of misfits, and wanting to do them proud, he went off to Bard College to become just that, a Bard!During his time in Bard college, however, his adventures and discoveries were still in great supply. Ducky, who was keen with people and very apt to being in front of large crowds, had noticed that there was always a good number of people willing to make fun of drawings and picture, seemingly with sarcastic undertones about facts of life, or just jokes in general. He had always been able to steer awkward conversations into hilarious ones when he combined his jokes and conversation with relation to pictures or popular stories in the news. Wanting to know more about this phenomenon, he decidedly began studying up on social interaction of this kind alongside his studies as a bard. The school itself had not had a name for this type of study, so they allowed Ducky time to come up with a name for the minor education he had started.Looking for inspiration on what to call it, he headed out into the woods to play some music in solace. It was there that he had met a being that would inspire him to be the Halfling he is today. There, cautiously looking up at him was a frog; one slightly larger than the average frog, but with very bulbous eyes, and a face that could display emotions of many types. He quickly broke out his sketch pad, and very artfully sketched out the creature, speaking to it all the while. It never spoke back, but it always seemed to understand, and stayed very still, sometimes smiling at the jokes Ducky had put forth. As soon as Ducky had finished the drawing, however, the frog had vanished; nowhere to be found. Looking back down at his drawing, a word, previously uninvented came to him that Ducky believed would describe very well, the study he was in. One that would define a generation many thousands of yearsinto the future… Memes. Ducky had just made the world’s first Meme, to which he named “Pepe”, out of impression that the mystical frog had given him.And so, it was decided. Ducky, the little bard from the forest, was to be educated, and pave the way for studies in Memes. His teachers, all very perplexed, yet interested in his studies, found them to be quite insightful, seeing as the school itself was a school for the entertaining arts, and the study Ducky had invented was exactly that; an art for entertainment.Around the age of 20, he graduated Bard College, ready and willing to put forth his magnificent music into the world, and to make the world happy alongside his invention of Memes. Ducky spent the last 5 years, coming up with new Meme ideas, as well as entertaining crowds all over the land of Aenora, and honing his skills as an adventurer alongside companions he has met through his travels; though none of them really stuck around for very long, as many of them were just out looking for work.It was a rather welcome surprise then, when, upon taking up a job in a local tavern, Ducky had stumbled upon the very group of oddballs he would soon become great friends with; travelling the world, and going on his greatest adventure in life yet!
Dwarven raised half-giant, that roam the desert to free enslaved half-giant tribes.
A foundling child, he grew up in the bosom of a Fae goddess and became her lover. Now he spreads her teachings and songs throughout the lands.

Raised as a painter in the forest, Crisis was a hundred years old when he met the love of his life. Unfortunately, she was a Tiefling, and his parents cut them off and threw them out of the community. They had a happy 30 years together, even raising a half-Tiefling half-elf son, but they knew their time was short. His wife left on a quest to find a way to elongate her life, and was killed along the way. Crisis (which was his wife's name, but he took it after she died to remember her) fell into despair, disappeared from his now grown-up son's life, and has been traveling and drinking as much as he can ever since (about 70 years). He recently picked up the Bard class. He doesn't know whether or not his son is still alive...

Clarity's mother, a human, had a tryst with a Tiefling named Excellence. When she realized she didn't have the means to raise the resulting half-Tiefling daughter by herself, she left Clarity with her sister to raise in a human village. The other villagers never liked her, although her foster parents did their best. Clarity finally ran away from home to become a cleric of Shah, the goddess of death. But along the way, she angered a wizard who retaliated by turning her foster parents into stone. One of Clarity's goals is to find a way to turn them back.

Erin Roxan started out his life working as a farmhand for his retired parents. His mother (Glynda Roxan) had been a popular professor in the field of planar lore, and his father (Jameson Roxan) used to be an adventurer of some renown, as far as Erin knew. As he grew a bit older however, Erin could sense that there was something they weren’t telling him, as the relationship between his parents had become somewhat strained lately. Little did he know that he would get his answers soon enough, but not in the way he had wanted. One night, a few days after his 19th birthday, Erin and his family were rudely awakened when a group of cultists invaded his home, and proceeded to trash the place. As they were attacked seemingly without cause, Erin tried to be brave by defending himself against one such cultist. Miraculously, Erin managed to disarm the attacker, knocking him unconscious with a shovel, before the young man was overpowered and beaten into submission by the others. As the family of three was held captive in their own home, the leader of the attack revealed himself. A cruel-looking Tiefling with dark-blue skin, he greeted Jameson, revealing that they were very much acquainted with each other. Ignoring Jameson’s pleas to leave him out of this, the leader prepared to ritually sacrifice the young man, only to be thwarted by another surprise visitor. Two cultists suddenly dropped dead as crossbow bolts pierced through a window and went through their skulls. Seconds later, a mysterious stranger cane crashing through what was left of the window, giving Erin enough of a distraction to slip out of the cultists’ grasp. The stranger, a rugged middle-aged man with a ponytail and an eyepatch, proceeded to make quick work of the leader’s lackeys, his dual hand crossbows piercing their robes and flesh with deadly accuracy. With no-one else left, the leader cursed Jameson’s name in a demonic tongue, before teleporting away. With the danger passed, the stranger revealed himself as Braig Zenedar, a human who was close friends with Jameson. And as this was revealed, Jameson now knew he had no choice but to tell his son the truth about him; a truth that Erin’s mother already knew. Erin learned that night that both Jameson and Braig were members of a semi-secret organization known as The Harpers, though Jameson had since retired from service in order to focus on raiding a family, hoping that Erin would grow up to have a more normal life. In the meantime, Braig had been tasked with secretly keeping an eye on the family, in case something happened to Jameson. Jameson and Glynda had been debating whether or not to tell Erin sooner, which was the cause of the marital strain from earlier. Unfortunately, now that one of Jameson’s enemies knew where he was, all three of them would have to leave the farm behind, so that Braig could take them to a Harper-owned safehouse, within the city of Berdusk. As a Harper, Jameson has apparently made enemies of the Cult of Worms, a group that worshipped twisted aberrations from the Far Realm. Although saddened and upset by the news, Erin was very grateful to Braig for coming to their rescue when they did. Along the way, Braig learned about how Erin had bravely tried to stand up to the cultists. So when the family was finally set up in the appointed safehouse, Erin was offered a choice: either stay with his parents, where he would be safe, or come to Twilight Hall with Braig, and begin training as an initiate of The Harpers. Although Jameson objected to some extent at this choice, he ultimately conceded that it was Erin’s choice. Wanting to find more answers about his father past as a Harper, and wanting to get back at the Cult for threatening his parents, Erin accepted Braig’s offer, and left with him to Twilight Hall. After a year’s worth of gruelling mental and physical training, Erin eventually surpassed the expectations of his peers, becoming very proficient in the art of dual-wielding, cutting his teeth on the local goblin and kobold population. As Braig looked on with some amount of pride, having taken a liking to the kid, Erin was able to truly join the Harpers as a fully-fledged Watcher, ready and willing to take on his first real mission for the clandestine organization.

Grimkhan was born within a nomadic tribe of dragonborn who respected and revered the gregarious and even-tempered copper dragons. However, his birth was struck by great misfortune when his mother perished in the process, leaving his father, Jhenovan, alone with the infant boy. Stricken by grief, Jhenovan gradually began to resent and blame Grimkhan for the death of his lover and mate. As his son grew, Jhenovan eventually spurned him entirely, leavin him to the care of a tribal elder, who taught him the fighting ways of his people as he matured. Soon enough, Grimkhan grew up to be an effective warrior for the tribe, while his father isolated himself more and more from his friends and tribe-mates, in spite of their pleas, slipping further into darkness.Then one day, the day Grimkhan was to reach the mature age of 15, Khenovan crossed the despair horizon. Unable to move on from what happened, he finally hung himself inside his own home. Having learned of the true ways of the dragonborn, Grimkhan soon grew to resent and hate his father for his cowardice in taking the "easy way out". And so it was that, to this day, the newly-christened warrior vowed to himself never to cower from the challenges of life, and to never retreat from a worthy foe. Seeing nothing else for his home to offer him, Grimkhan decided to leave the tribe to strike it out on his own, and scour the world for powerful beasts and foes to test the limits of his skill.

Jhuri never knew her father, and her mother had died shortly after giving birth to her. This would ultimately lead her to be passed down to the care of her criminal uncle, Kagaran the Spade. As a member of the Red Scarves Gang, Kagaran had to keep Jhuri's existence a secret from the other members because of Natalnya, tiefling leader of the gang, who had set down the rule that gang members were not permitted to have children, lest they become "excess mouths to feed". But out of respect for Jhuri's father, Karagan couldn't bring himself to get rid of her, and instead kept her secretly at his meager house in Crossroads City, teaching her calligraphy in order to help him forge documents for the gang. Eventually, he even told her what he knew about her father, mostly that he used to be a skilled adventurer, but allegedly perished in battle, leaving her mother to give birth alone.This was all well and good for a shockingly long time, until Beezle, a kapak draconian member of the gang, spied Karagan and a 15-year-old Jhuri and put two and two together. The moment Natalnya found out, Karagan's former "friends" quickly turned on him, breaking into his home and murdering him in cold blood. When Jhuri tried to fight back against them, she was rewarded for her efforts by being nearly gutted through the belly by Beezle's dagger work. But just as it seemed that Jhuri's life would end, the killers were attacked by a monk from the local monastery, forcing them to flee. Seeing Jhuri in her profusely-bleeding state, the half-elven monk sought to stabilize her out of kindness, and began to carry her to the monastery as she passed out.Days of recovery later, Jhuri's rescuer introduced himself as Vulkan, claiming to be a former friend of her father's, and extended an offer to train her in the martial arts, so that she would be able to better defend herself. Once she was well enough, Jhuri readily accepted, though primarily out of desire for vengeance. For the next four years, Jhuri became a worthwhile monk under Vulkan's tutelage, and quickly learned that anger would only deter her from reaching her potential. Although she would go on to complete her training, she would never fully rid herself of hit, instead burying her emotions under a cold and aloof exterior.Knowing that the Red Scarves would never truly leave her alone, Jhuri eventually consciously left Vulkan's care, seeking to become an adventurer, and become strong enough to tear down the Scarves, and everything they stood for.

The first true memory Kriv had upon his hatching was awakening inside the home of a female human thief.At first, when he was still learning to walk, he didn't think much of it, believing that it was somehow normal. But as he starting maturing rapidly over the next few years, he quickly realized that he was too different from the human that had apparently taken him in, and started demanding answers. The thief, Rukia Kazume, tried her best to do so, understanding that she could no longer afford to keep it a secret.Rukia had no idea who the dragonborn's real parents were, because she had found him as an egg, hidden in a section of the sewers she had been exploring in Brindol at the time. Feeling some amount of pity, she had decided to take it back with her, and try to take care of it as best as she could. "Kriv" had simply been the name SHE had given it. Although confused as to why his parents would ever abandon him, Kriv reluctantly accepted Rukia's story. Eventually, as Kriv continued to get older, decided that he wanted Rukia to teach him everything she knew about being a rogue, a request that his adopted mother was more than happy to indulge.Over the course of the next decade, Rukia groomed Kriv to become her successor in the various arts of rougery, starting off from petty theft and pick-pocketing, and eventually graduating to learning all the ways to kill a man, whilst remaining hidden within the dark and shady places that existed beyond the comfort of Red Larch. It was sometimes grim work, but gradually, Kriv became numbed to what he was doing. Not all of the work was dark however, as Rukia also took enjoyment out of stealing from the rich, and giving back to the poor on a regular basis.But ultimately, after Kriv became an adult at age 15, Rukia knew in her heart that she couldn't keep watching over him forever. After a long, heart-to-heart talk, Kriv and Rukia eventually concluded that they would both need to go their separate ways, in order for the dragonborn to continue to grow in his own way, without anyone else looking over him. After a hearfelt hug, and a few shed tears, Rukia left her former protege, packed her things, and left Brindol for parts unknown.Ever since becoming a true apprentice rogue, Kriv has been spending his time accepting odd jobs from pretty much anyone in Red Larch who can pay for his services, plying his beginner skills in the hopes that, one day, he might find a clue that leads him to discovering the fate of his true birth-parents, and finding out what really happened that caused him to be abandoned in the first place.

Arya comes from a secluded woodland to the north. While everyone in the village was kind, her father began to get visions from spirits. These spirits encouraged him to be violent, destroying property and harming other villagers. It got so bad that Arya's family was shunned from the community, and they became even more isolated. As Arya aged she was also visited by spirits, however these ones were much kinder, and taught her the ways of nature instead. Eventually she began to follow these spirits into the woods, often leaving home for days and months at a time. These spirits gave Arya powers as she learned more from them, however they told her she needed to venture beyond her home to become more powerful. This is where she begins her adventure.

Libitia is the daughter of Eadric Melandron, a revered paladin who had grown lonely in his duties, and desired to start a family of his own. Sadly, this desire was seemingly crushed when a fateful battle with a dark sorcerer resulted in him being struck with a spell that effectively rendered him sterile. Heartbroken by this, Eadric prayed and pleaded to his deity Sune, the Chaotic Good goddess of love and beauty. Felling sympathetic to the decorated paladin's plight, Sune sent down a celestial being to provide him comfort, and angel named Fidele. Through Fidele's holy blessing, she took on a human form, and was able to infuse Eadric with some of her own fertility, long enough to undertake an intensely pleasurable copulation, after which Fidele bore an Aasimar child, and brought her into the material world.Eternally grateful for this second chance, Eadric did everything he could to raise Libitia the best that he could, teaching her the values of goodness and valor, of mercy and helping your fellow man, and of the many dangers that lie within the outside world. Despite having her own celestial duties to attend to, Fidele also took fairly regular departures to the material realm to teach her daughter all about life and love. The birds and the bees, the differences between love and lust, intimacy, the works. As Libita grew older, she quickly developed the signs of emerging divine magic inherent to her kind, but was intensely more fascinated with the arcane schools of magic, much to her father's confusion. She also developed a knack for playing Eadric's old family viol as an instrument, which became her primary hobby outside of magic studies. Her magic skills soon developed after being enrolled into the local wizarding college, and the youthful aasimar developed a curious fixation on the illusory school of wizardry, experimenting with creating visual images that represented aspects of the domain in which her divine mother resided. Libitia was more introverted during this time in her life, and while her beauty caused many a boy or man to pine after her, the aasimar always sought to wait for that "special someone". Someone who would love her for being her.As a young adult, Libitia was growing into an illusionary savant, while also playing her viol for small crowds on the side, but she was also realizing that many people in this world were suffering unjustly, whether under the foots of other who abused their power, or at the hands of the myriad of monsters that roamed the world. It eventually came to a point where she actually felt guilty for the comfortable life she was leaving. This all came to a head one night, when Fidele came to her in an intensely-vivid dream. In this dreamscape, the angel of love told her half-celestial daughter that a woman whose children had gone missing had prayed desperately to Sune for help for two days and two nights. Fidele knew of Libitia's growing uncertainty, and asked her if she wanted a chance to do some real good in the world, to help people like that woman. Libitia hugged her right then and there, emotionally replying...."yes". When the two women came to Earric the next morning, the now-aging father was happy to hear Libitia say that she now wanted to use her developing skills to go further out into the world, and provide real help to those who did not have her comfortable upbringing, and to those who were suffering, even though her magical talents were not what he expected.And so, with Eadric and Fidele's blessings, Libitia voluntarily left the comfort of her home town, and set out on a journey to the town of Oakhurst, where mysterious disappearances and killings had been taking place. Wherever her travels took her, this would be the first step on a testing and trying journey the young Aasimar would never ever forget.

Sileena Blaize was born amidst a caravan of travelling Tiefling gypsies, gifted in the arts of mysticism, seduction, and occasionally, assassination, depending on who could pay. Even from a young age, Sileena displayed a great degree of magical aptitude, and yet she she had always felt that something seemed...missing, as if there was something keeping her from fully unlocking her full potential. The young tiefling spent much of her childhood learning the ways of her gypsy peers, even practicing seduction on the young boys of either their own, or whatever town they happened to visit at the time.Eventually however, when Sileena reached the age of 16, the gypsies were visited by the spirit that they worshiped with great fervor: a powerful fey spirit, that would often take the guise of a stunningly beautiful eladrin male. It was at this point that Sileena's grandmother, the gypsy elder, presented Sileena before the spirit, as a new pact-mate, for it was the budding magical gifts of the warlock that Sileena had demonstrated during her childhood. But in order to seal the pact, the spirit needed to take her into her bed in a mystical act of intimacy. Trembling with a mixture of fear, trepidation, and anticipation, the young Sileena was stripped down to her nubile body within her own tent by the spirit, before she was laid down to begin. The pact-bonding ceremony seemed to last the whole night, as Sileena's new, pleasurable experience crescendoed higher, and higher. But finally, in one great big climactic moment, the private ceremony was complete, and the Fey pact was sealed.With the full range of her warlock gifts accessible to her, Sileena Blaize would go on to spend the next fifteen years refining, and honing her powers alongside her gypsy brothers and sisters, while also mastering the use of her well-endowed body to seduce whoever she wanted, and making a respectable sum of money in the process. But after such a long time amongst her collective family, the warlock became dissatisfied with her life, believing that setting out, and using her gifts as an adventurer, would allow her to continue growing in her own way. After convincing her grandmother of this, the elder gifted her with a old, magical orb that has belonged to her mother, before she went missing shortly after she was born. She finally left the gypsies on her own, and set out into the wide world, with her first destination being the city of Greenrest. Despite the money she had made in the past, she soon discovered that it would not be enough for her to have a sustainable income. Faced with the uncomfortable possibility of living in the poor house, Sileena started advertising herself as a mercenary at her earliest opportunity, whilst also taking on-and-off work as an exotic dancer for whatever inn would take her at the time, hoping that the eventual rewards of such adventuring would enable her to avoid a life of prostitution.

Born an only child in Maloren's Rest seemingly destined to carry on the family business of fishing, Agama always dreamed of bigger and better things. On a particular stressing day Agama wandered into the tavern and met someone new to town, a human named Barrotz. Barrotz offered a large sum of money and fame for people to come with him on an expedition to an old ruin in search of evidence of an ancient civilization. Agama blinded by the promise of excitement almost immediately signed up and told his parents he was leaving within a week.  Agama, Barrotz, and some others soon left for the ruin and set up a camp site just outside to explore. Unfortunately the ruins seemed picked clean by the time they had gotten there and most left after the initial disappointment, however desperate not to return home empty handed Agama went back excavating with renewed vigor only able to find some faint scratchings that seemed to be written in Elvish script. Asking Barrotz for help, Agama discovered that the language was Sylvan and started to learn the language in order to discover what was hidden. After many long weeks of dead-ends and frustrations Agama managed to find a secret room not yet discovered by anyone. Inside was a preserved scroll written in Sylvan detailing how to control one's Ki, excited about this discovery Agama hurried to Barrotz with the scroll eager to try and learn how to harness the Ki. The two tried to teach themselves from the scroll, Agama was seemingly a natural, able to summon a small puff of wind. Barrotz however wasn't able to do anything after several days of practice, growing frustrated and seeing Agama only able to summon a puff of wind declared that the scroll was useless. Agama was enamored by the teachings of the scroll and saw that the scroll was just one of many. One night Barrotz stole the scroll and left the ruins leaving Agama by himself. Unable to find any trace of Barrotz or the scroll, Agama vowed to find Barrotz and the scroll and also to try and find the remaining scrolls.
Har Veris was a promising young troubadour who was expelled from the bardic college after he was caught plagiarizing ballads. He fell into a life of petty crime, and longs to regain his honor.

Kulima Uch grew up knowing only life on the farm with his human mother, Nyali. His father, Utani, had died of mysterious circumstances around the time that Kulima was born making Kulima the man of the household at a very young age. Having to forgo his education in order to make sure that he and his mother were always able to have food on the table. One day the small village where he lived, Kij, was attacked by Orcs, Kulima, strengthened by his long days on the farm, joined the fight only to discover his magic powers which aided him in leading the defense against the Orcs making him the hero of his village. Earning this title has allowed his mother to no longer worry about living off the farm allowing Kulima to leave his village and adventure. Kulima has now traveled to Erdiko searching for adventure and to display his heroism and although many scoff at him he was able to pick up a job to escort a cart to Rudnick

Grew up in a family of bards. had to make money w/(non existent) musical talent. ended up making that money by sellingworthless shit to idiots. The Mafia caught sight of her aftertwo years or so. Proposed a spot for her; accepted, age18. Made a lifelong friend of Haddock [old name Belurimm Friedenswächter] (half orc fighter at the time, currently a master carpenter) while in The Mafia. After five years, family found out anddisowned, age 23. discouraged, she left The Mafia and set out to wander around to find herself a new family. keeps in touch with The Mafia throughHaddock from time to time. has had a few fails in finding a newfamily. Finds it very hard to trust now because of those failed attempts

Born to a union of the archmage Jericho Mournsong and the nymph Li'lelia, Aria was raised in the very lap of luxury. Possessed of her father's keen and inquisitive mind, and her mother's grace and magical nature, Aria always dreamed of exploring the wider world. But her father's status meant she was unofficially nobility and subject  of the customs of the kingdom. That meant arranged marriage.Her fiance was a good man, a paladin and lord of the knights of the realm. By all accounts, she couldn't have done better to be matched to a prince. But she was young, restless and wanted to see the world. She took what she would need to set off, including a ring to hide her from magical scrying and other attempts to locate her, and disappeared into the night. Two days of almost ceaseless walking to reach a port town, then passage on a ship bought under a false name, and she was gone. Two years of adventure built up her confidence in herself, and she let her guard down. Traveling with a single guide through lawless country, they were ambushed by slavers. She was captured, but admitted the truth about her identity to avoid being forced back home, actually preferring to be "sold" into slavery than forced back into her betrothal. Her imprisonment was humiliating, but even stripped and bound, she nearly escaped mid-auction. Recaptured in front of the audience, a wealthy young man paid for her before she could be beaten for the affront. Magically subdued and carted off, she reawoke in his private manor, chained to his bed.Turns out, he was remarkably polite, given the circumstances. He had long suspected that his sword instructirs had been wasting his time to get at his money, and her near escape convinced him that she would help him expose them as frauds. He never forced himself on her, and they worked out a deal. She would pretend to be what everyone believed her to be, his new personal slave. The "master" sword instructors would have a tournament to prove which of them would be the best. The prize, in addition to a hefty bonus and becoming the only sword instructor of the house, she herself was part of the prize. Dressed to the nines, no one expected her to be the one fighting each of the supposed masters. By the end of the day, she was the victor, the frauds were banished, and she became his new, paid, instructor. She stayed for a year, but had no intention of staying permanently, especially aware that her appearance tended to draw affection from all those around her. Including her host. She told him he would need a better instructor to continue to advance and set off once again. This time, she needed a party, friends to watch her back.

Fall was born on the planet Triaxus, during the final year of the transitioning from Summer to Winter, in a small insignificant village. He grew up alone, never knowing his parents, and having only one real friend: an orphan named Sickle. The two grew up together, meeting at age 3 and immediately became inseparable. Sickle was all Fall had, and vice versa. And they were happy, but the kind of happiness that can only come from a long period of sadness.As Fall got older, he got more curious. At age 9, he and Sickle had a conversation about where they thought they came from, who they were. Sickle told Fall not to worry about his past, that it didn’t matter because he couldn’t do anything to change it. Fall took her advice lightly. He would not rest until knowing his true origins. He left Sickle alone that night, and went off into the wilderness to think, in solitude.That night, Fall dreamt of dragons. Specifically, one bronze dragon that came from the sky and flew into the wilderness behind the village. The wilderness was quickly surrounded by an impenetrable barricade of electricity. Months passed before the barrier was lifted. The dragon flew out, and the villagers rushed in and pulled something….someone...out. Fall woke up before learning who it was.Every night since then, Fall would head to the same exact spot and have the same exact dream, waking up at the same exact part where the figure would be revealed. He had to know who they were. He needed to know. Fall kept this up for 3 years until, on his 12th birthday, he arrived. He had his dream, but it was different this time. It didn’t end where it should have.The villagers in his dream pulled out a Triaxian woman, weak, feeble, barely able to stand and holding a child close to her chest…..It was the most beautiful image Fall had ever seen. And at that moment, the dream seemed to freeze and last for hours. Fall woke up the next day, surrounded by carnage. Trees had toppled, animals had been torn to pieces, and Fall was covered in ashes. He jumped up and gazed in horror at the disaster that had just missed him. Of course, he wondered what happened at first. Why he hadn’t been touched. Fall looked down at where he was resting and, unfortunately, learned the truth. In the midst of the destruction was an untouched silhouette of a young Triaxian boy, with a pair of massive wings resembling lightning bolts made from ashes, sprouting from the figure’s back. He had, unknowingly, performed his first Bloodrage. The Origin Rage. Stronger than any Rage to come. Taken aback by the scene, Fall fled home, where Sickle was waiting. She told Fall of a lightning storm that had happened in the wilderness. She told Fall of noises, ungodly screams that could only be described as pain. True pain. Pain only known by those experiencing it. She told Fall of the lights. Quick flashes of light, lasting only the blink of an eye, but blinding nonetheless. She told Fall of those who’d tried to investigate. Whatever happened to them...she didn’t say.  Then…Sickle told Fall of the blood.It was everywhere, marking the end of the storm in one of the most horrendous ways possible. It had seeped out of the wilderness, and through the village, never stopping or slowing down. It just kept going as far as the eye could see...It was too dark to be Triaxian, or anything native to Triaxus. Sickle asked Fall if he knew anything about the storm.Fall denied everything.A year past, but the memories would not. The blood streak was still present in the village, as full and dark as it had been the year prior. A reminder. Fall’s relationship with Sickle had strengthened much after the tragedy. It strengthened their belief that, if anything happened to one of them, the other would have nothing left. That had almost happened once, and they weren’t ready for it to happen again. It was now Fall’s 13th birthday. Sickle had done all she could to make this one special, the anniversary of when they’d almost lost each other. She’d gone so far as to give Fall his first gift, a steel pendant shaped like a maple leaf, inscribed with their names on the back, written in a heart. It had clearly taken Sickle months to get this for him. And to Fall, it was the most memorable gift from the memorable day of his life. That night, he had the dream again. He saw the face of the woman with the child again. And time froze, once again. It didn’t last as long as Fall remembered. It was nowhere near as powerful, and to his surprise, Fall was able to break out of it multiple times, catching glimpses of what was going on, of what He was doing.The screams came first. Then the gut-wrenching noises. Then his eyes were opened. He saw his village being bombarded by bolts of blue energy. He saw the blood streak, once dark and lifeless, now emitting a strong blue glow, forming a beacon of unknown energy that skyrocketed as far as the eye could see. He saw the townspeople, fleeing for their lives. He saw destruction everywhere he looked. Each time, closing his eyes and wincing as the woman and child appeared in his mindscape, then going dark. Fall awoke, standing among the bodies in the blood-soaked streets. Only one still breathed, barely. At his feet laid Sickle, looking up at him with a hurt look in her eyes. A look of betrayal, anger, but Fall could sense a splinter of love and hope. Her chest was raked with deep claw marks, soaked with light blood. Sickle looked deep into Fall’s eyes, seeking out a glimmer of the boy she had grown up with in the monster that stood before her. And then he had nothing.By the time he had calmed down, the Royal Guards had already come for him. The trial was quick, but painful. Fall was banished from Triaxus, forced to give up everything he knew. He was encased in a capsule, and launched into the unknown.    With his time in the capsule, Fall’s dreams changed. No longer was the woman holding a child close to her heart. There was no woman, and the child...the child was a monster, some hellish creature bearing no resemblance to a Triaxian, looming over Sickle’s fragile body, feasting on her.    Fall crashed on another planet after some time. How long, he could not guess. The capsule opened, and he was alone in a dark forest, mighty trees his only company. He had nothing.Over time, his dreams got less intense, but no less graphic. His Rage had mostly faded, weakened through long periods of calm, but still very present. It was as if his Rage was locked away, but with every battle a bit of it escapes the locks, strengthening his curse. Fall had learned to control his Rage, for now. It took time, and lots of it. Fortunately, when one is isolated, time is the one thing they can count on. On his 19th birthday, after years of survival training, Fall left the forest and entered civilization, leaving behind everything he had come to know. He had nothing, but the clothes on his back and the pendant around his neck.

Molasses III lived most of his life not knowing what he was. He was a Slothra, of course he knew that, but what were Slothra? He had no memory of ever meeting another Slothra. He couldn’t tell whether or not he’d even seen one before. Did they even exist? Was he a mutation? He couldn’t tell yet.Molasses was born in and grew up within the forest. His father was nowhere to be found, and his mother passed before he could walk. His only counsel was the forest, the only family he had left. He treated the trees like they were his brothers, the rivers like his sisters, and the animals better than he treated himself. In many ways, he was a Ranger back then. He lived this way until the age of 9, when he woke to the sounds of the forest. It was different this time. The forest was no longer calm and relaxing. Tonight, it was screaming. Molasses burst out of his den and stared in awe at his surroundings. What hadn’t already been taken was covered with flames, burning bright and true. What had been reached was reduced to a pile of smoldering ashes. Molasses could tell by the fire’s intensity that it wasn’t natural. There was something magical about it, he could tell. What kind of magic, he had no clue, but he didn’t have time to investigate. Molasses turned his back on his burning home and ran. He escaped minutes before the fire had engulfed everything. Everything. It was all gone.After leaving his home, Molasses became a wanderer. With nowhere to go and nowhere to stay, he wandered for three months until he reached civilization, and collapsed in front of the gates. He woke up in a hospital, an armored woman in the bed next to him. She was clutching her side, dark blood staining her hands. It seemed she would have little time left if nothing were done. Molasses rushed out of his bed in search for herbs, crushing them into a paste that he applied to the woman’s wound. It took 2 months for the woman, who Molasses learned was named Celeste, to heal. In those 2 months, Molasses earned a reputation within the kingdom. He was the mysterious stranger, unknown origin, unknown race. There were some who saw him as a monster, others a refugee. After Celeste healed, she became Molasses’ mentor. She taught him how to speak Common, among other languages. She taught him how to read, both words and people. Most importantly, she taught him how to fight. Celeste gave Molasses her Earth Breaker, a weapon she had once used daily. Since joining the army, however, she’d been limited to sword and shield.They lived like this for 6 years, the happiest years of their lives. They went on countless adventures, looking after one another at all times. After hostage situations, battling armies, killing a lich, and many others, they found themselves in a massive catacombs. In front of them sat an altar, behind them only darkness. Molasses cautiously approached the altar, laying his Earth Breaker on it, and looked around. From the darkness came a creature, something neither had ever encountered. The creature lunged at Celeste with such force, she was defeated instantly. Her body became still and lifeless, but her invisible soul still lingered in the air. Fearing complete abandonment, the soul of Celeste inhabited Molasses’ Earth Breaker. It was an artifact, in a way, a remnant of both their pasts. After narrowly escaping the same fate, Molasses immediately began researching. He read every book in the library, but it wasn’t enough. Nowhere in his collection held the key to resurrection. He had heard tales, however, of a book with the answer to summoning creatures powerful enough to restore Celeste’s form. The Necronomicon. This book, fact or fiction, was Molasses’ best choice. He risked his life for leads on the location of such a tome, but got nowhere. He almost died many a time, but that didn’t stop him. Through all this from inside the Earth Breaker, Celeste lived on, unbeknownst to Molasses. She protected him, as she’d always done. She also tried to stop him, knowing it was hopeless. Even if he were successful, a body with no soul was still just a body, and she was trapped. Helpless, she watched for years as Molasses tore himself up trying to find a way. He is still searching.Molasses joined the hunt for the Tower for one reason and one reason alone. If the legends are true, the Tower will hold the greatest treasures known by the living. If he could find answers anywhere, it’s there. Molasses’ journey is for one thing, and one thing only.Celeste

My name is Kaval Ergashed, or, at least it was. I was the firstborn of a poor family in the slums of Draconia. My mother, Shivan, died in childbirth, leaving me to be raised by my father, Gevran Ergashed. Being raised in the poor sections, I was quickly influenced by the violent nature of my neighbors, which my strict father did not approve of. He often told me all he ever wanted was to get me out of there. “But Lord Savras wants us here” he would always say. I was raised by the faith of Lord Savras, god of divination, truth, and fate.When I turned 7 years old, I was recruited into a gang known as The Black Sirens by the leader, a gray dragonborn by the name of Silver. They promised me the usual; fame, fortune, brotherhood. Silver was like a brother to me, so I made sure not to disappoint him. I was trained to gather information, by any means possible. I was forged into a killer. I swiftly moved up through the ranks, and by the time I was 10, had become a ruthless bounty hunter. With each man I killed, my reputation grew. I became known on the streets as ‘The Heartless One’, as I had never taken mercy on my target. I tried desperately to keep my father blind to what I was doing, as he would never approve.I was only able to keep the charade up for 3 years. When I was 13, I got back from a hunt late at night. My scales were cloaked with blood. I walked in the door, carrying a bloody sword with arrows in my arm. But my father was waiting for me. He took one glance at me and instantly knew what I had become. He told me no son of his would be a killer. He took out his whip and lashed me twice, leaving a large ‘X’ scar on my back. I lashed out at him, forgetting who he was and going by my training.I killed him in cold blood.By the time I had figured out what I had done, it was too late. He was unhealable. I knew I couldn’t stay, so I packed my things and made plans to head for the next town over. But as I walked outside, Silver appeared at my door. He peeked behind me and found what I had done. And he congratulated me. He told me my father was only holding me back, and that I could be unstoppable now. Nothing to hide from, nobody to keep me from my future. And the rage hit again. Silver was dead on my doorstep before I knew it. It was because of his gang that I had murdered my father,I was captured by my gang mates before leaving town. I was taken to Black Sirens HQ, the sewers. The leadership had passed to Blaze, a bronze dragonborn. Silver’s little brother. I was kicked out, and given one day before they would come after me, a courtesy they gave all traitors. If I was ever seen again, I would be captured, taken to Blaze, and killed. It was there, in the sewers underneath the Draconian dump, where I vowed to make things right with my father, and disband The Black Sirens.When I reached the next town, I started cursing to Lord Savras. Out of all the lives he could’ve given to me, he made me a killer, a traitor and a deserter. I blamed him for all of my problems. But when the rage had subsided, I asked him to change who he had made me.I realized I needed to reinvent myself. I rejected my family name, Kaval Ergashed, and took up my new identity. I became Mythheart, my version of the name the Sirens had given to me, so I would never forget what I am fighting for; but also, it was my way of carrying around my shame. Every time someone says my name, I am reminded of the crimes I’ve committed and the history I’ve made. I would never be worthy of my family name until then.After I left that town, I made way for the forest. I set up camp in a cave I discovered deep within. I stayed there for three nights, but on the morning of the fourth, I was awoken by the sound of hooves beating on the ground. I hobbled out of the cave to find a group of men in heavy armor. They called me by my new name, which I had not yet told anybody. They told me to gather my things, and I was taken away to an old marble monastery. It was there that I was told I had been called to Paladinship by Lord Savras himself.I told them there had to be a mistake, but they told me the instructions given by Lord Savras had been very clear. I attempted to refuse, but they told me Lord Savras would never allow it. Even if they hadn’t taken me, I still would’ve found my way.I was trained, against my will, in the Order of Lord Savras. I was trained slowly, learning the ways of stealth better than anything else. I made good friends with the cooks, an elf named Fern and a halfling named Sun. They had great talent, able to turn anything into a delicious meal. On the night before my official naming as Paladin, I was visited in my dreams by Lord Savras. He told me I needed to be a Paladin, it was my fate, and the world would not be the same if I thought differently. I became a Paladin, much to my dismay. Most Paladins are honored, but I thought of it more as a curse. I was not happy, and I wanted to find a way out. After being released, I committed small crimes to try to rid my life of the power of Savras. But Lord Savras would never allow it.People started looking at me with respect instead of fear. Everywhere I went, I was honored as a Paladin. There were some, of course, who did not take kindly to me. But everywhere I went, I brought my past with. Just because I’m a Paladin doesn’t mean I can dishonor my vow to myself. My Paladinship only made my vow stronger. The Black Sirens are evil that I need to rid the world of.Every year, on November 24th, the anniversary of my father’s death, I return to Draconia to visit my parents at the cemetery. I make sure I am not seen or followed. I light a torch for each of them, then leave because I was not not ready to make things right. I needed to be stronger. I go to the monastery, where I stay for the night. I’ve started collecting delicacies from other lands to bring to Sun and Fern. The recruits always ate well that night.When I met the main group in Newton, I was trailing a member on a hunt. I found him in a tavern and discovered he was just a mere rookie. I gave him the choice of death or desertion. He was cooperative. I was glad he had turned away from the darkness. I left the building and prepared to leave Newton, when the fire started. I could not save the rookie.The year before I met up with the group, The Black Sirens found me at the cemetery. They’ll be expecting me when I go back, on the fifth anniversary of my father’s death. They must be taken care of when I return. I am ready.
Run away concubine and petty criminal
Kamagumi followed a trickster God to earth as small child and was adopted by a pair of gay professors. She lost her leg in an accident, but uses her deity's strength to make difference in the world.

Reiki is the sixth of eight kids born to a strong, strong-willed barbarian mother and mild-mannered (for an orc) shaman father. After an idyllic childhood of hunting, gathering and raiding with all the cousins, it was clear that Reiki needed more structure and so when she expressed interest in the discipline of monkhood, was shipped off with well wishes.  Now she wanders the lands, building a name for herself and just punching the everliving crap out of whatever threatens her friends.

Yaryl was abandoned as a babe and raised by a mother wolf who had recently lost her cubs from that litter. When she was an adult, her mother was killed by a poacher. She and one of her pack mates left the pack to protect the forests she calls home.

In a small village under the watchful eye of a tyrannical Nobel a Dragonborn was born. Her parents were simple folk who worked at the local tavern. Her father passing at a young age, Sora was mostly raised by her mother. As soon as she could reach the sink she was put to work washing dishes. When her mother eventually passed she took over service in the front where she was quite happy. That is until the revolt. After a period of rumbling the local populace revolted against that pompous Lord with the intent of gaining more respect. Now you might expect that this is where Sora would start her adventure, but in fact it was not, for Sora was very much used to working in the tavern and didn't wish for much more in life. The night after the revolt Sora was visited by her ancient ancestors, great dragons of the past who told her of her heritage and her destiny. The next day she set up the tavern as a gathering place and makeshift hospital. Once the revolt was over and her townsmen liberated she set out to fulfill her higher calling as a paladin of Bahamut.

Character's name: Lord Francis Edward Lied Timothy Cancion Lamale Ethoic con Evelyn Rosemarel the III the Second
Character's backstory: The gnome bard, originally named Poshment, was born to the local alchemist family in the town of Wartle near the Mushfens.  He grew up learning the trade of alchemy, selling stuff to locals.  The family also had a specific clientele.  They must have been relatives since they all had the Smith surname, despite being many different races.  As he grew up he learned these guys were assassins and that his family was selling poisons to them.  These were small time assassins that lived around the area.  When Poshment came of age to take over the family business, he decided to leave in the middle of the night and go to the large city of Magnimar.  Once in the town, he joined the bard’s college.  Once there he made up a new family and came up with a new name, filled with lots of relatives that all led interesting lives.  He completely changed his look so that he would not be recognized in his home town.  He went back with one of his new personas to Wartle.  No one recognized him at all.  This meant he was ready for the world.  He decided to make money he would seduce influential or rich and get secrets and money.  Never would he black mail anyone, but he would sell these secrets to anyone willing to pay.  This brought him to the island town where a particular half giant wife lived.  The husband was part of an emissary to a local tribe of giants.
Left his home swamp to run a tavern after being quite literally possessed by the spirit of entrepreneurship
His family exiled him since he wasn't up to their standards as a sorceror, so he decided he wanted to become a magic con-man instead.

A descendant of the hated and condemned Vyshaan clan who were held responsible for the crown wars. Part of a small clan living in the frozen north sea of ice , hidden from other elves who hunt and kill all with vyshaan blood.    Raised in a travelling circus and true name hidden by using a stage name Lucky Longshot he was trained as an Archer and thief. Travelling from town to town both entertaining and stealing .    As an adult he left the circus and joined a band of adventurers until he eventually became embroiled in a battle to save his village.

Kas was born in a hunting village that unfortunately had not been far from the epicenter of a "Necromantic Nuke" that wiped the nearby capital city off the map.Having learned a little about hunting, alchemy, and caring for the sick, he was pressed into service tending the stricken when, after surviving the first wave of an unidentified dark magic plague, he proved immune to falling to it a second time. One night his brother passed away in the quarantine tent...then he got back up. Kas woke to the sound of his (now undead) brother attacking the other healers. In shock, he cried out for his brother to stop, when something miraculous happened.He listened.

"You thought you could betray ME?!"The Old One, a Being Who Should Not Exist, screams in outrage at the slight figure standing before him."I gave you my power through the Pact. I GAVE you the power to fulfill your lifes mission. Many have felt your vile touch and ended up exactly as you desire! HOW DARE YOU REFUSE TO UPHOLD YOUR END OF OUR BARGAIN!!!"The small figure smiles defiantly up at his 'benefactor'. "Our bargain was your power for my soul. Your power has been granted and my soul is forfeit BUT your end of the bargain is not complete." He takes a low, mocking bow. His next words drip with venom. "My lord.""The bargain was for your power until I can fill the world with my namesake! Many suffer but not nearly enough! Not even by half! I say it is YOU who is trying to betray our bargain!" Crimson eyes flash in a brilliant display of rage and power.The Old One glares angrily down at the young tiefling and tries to find flaw in his logic but cannot. He is indeed trying to take the soul of this powerful yet headstrong warlock. But he will not admit defeat nor admit he was trying to cheat. So he took it upon himself to alter the situation in his favor. He became fixated on erasing this foolish mortal from existence. Drawing forth the entirety of his incredible power, the Old One unleashed a wave of force with a singular purpose. To destroy all it touches. This included the forest around them, the countless numbers of creatures within and most importanly the annoyingly smug warlock Despair.But before that destructive wave could harm a single cell of anything within its range the world shifted. All color drained from the sky, the leaves, the creatures and even the power unleashed from the Old One. All became motionless, stopped in the moment. All save for the Old One and Despair. And one other."I think that will be QUITE enough out of the two of you!" Chronos bellowed as he stepped forth through a rift in time. "I absolutely despise stopping time like this but you've left me with no other alternative. Do you know how much energy this takes?! The only larger drain on my power came from a group of fools traveling backwards in time to try and rewrite history!" The powerful figure of the Lord of Time stopped in the direct center between the Old One and Despair. He turned his fury first to the Old One."This is your SECOND warning in as many aeons! You can't simply destroy an entire ecosystem because of the irritation caused by a mortal! Any further infractions will result in erasure!"The Old One's head shifted forward. Not quite a bow but more of a sad, sulking measure. "What's the use of all this power if I can't destroy the things that irritate me?"Chronos shook his head and waved his hand in a negligent manner. "You can destroy your irritants, by all means! Just KEEP the destruction to what is irritating you! No more mass destruction unless brought about by prophesy!""Yes Lord Chronos." the Old One intoned sadly. As he turned away and began sliding back to his own plane of existence a lowly muttered "Asshole." could be heard faintly before he disappeared altogether.Chronos finally turned to face Despair who had been watching the Old One get torn a new orifice with the greatest amusement. "Wipe that smile off your face, insect!" Despair's face melted from amusement to glaring hatred."I am no in..." "SILENCE! You continue to exist ONLY because I did not want to listen to this Plane's protector file a complaint! I've been keeping my eye on what you've been doing with this power." Chronos held up a hand to stop the protest he knew was coming. "Yes, yes. I know. 'I am Despair. My goal in life is to spread my namesake to the world that shunned me simply for existing.' I am WELL aware of your intentions, your reasons. I even don't begrudge you your desire either. You mortals, who live so briefly yet so fiercely, are free to live your lives as you see fit. No. What I have been watching is HOW you've been doing it. Using the power granted from the Old One to twist the minds of those around you into doing things they should not do and only freeing their minds when the task is complete so they can live the rest of their lives in utter misery at doing precisely what they would never do."At this point Chronos paused to take a breath from his tirade and gave Despair some time to speak. However limited that time would be depended on how Despair answered. "I used magic to charm those heartless bastards, yes. I cannot nor will I deny it. I'm proud of it. BUT! I did not twist any minds. Every person charmed. Every person who did such unspeakable acts. Did so because the desire to do it was within them in the first place! A husband's desire to remove his family from the picture so he could have the woman that wanted nothing to do with him when she found he was married. A child's desire to kill their friend so they can have that coveted toy. All we mortals possess darkness. I simply help them draw it out!"Chronos looks thoughtfully down at Despair, stroking a beard that seems to eternally shift from the coarse black bristles of youth to the gray wispy strands of old age. "You have a point, warlock. All you mortals do in fact possess darkness. But few act on it. And those majority that do not, do not for a reason you have failed to pick up on. All mortals ALSO possess light within them. That husband wouldn't have ever acted on his desire because his desire was fleeting. That woman completed his soul.
